Preface

This book aims to be both a graduate text and a study resource for Lie groups. It tries to strike a compromise between accessibility and getting enough depth to communicate important insights. In discussing the literature, often secondary sources are preferred: cited works are usually recommended ones.

There are four parts. Parts I, II or IV are all "starting points" where one could begin reading or lecturing. On the other hand, Part III assumes familiarity with Part II. The following chart indicates the approximate dependencies of the chapters. There are other dependencies, where a result is used from a chapter that is not a prerequisite according to this chart: but these are relatively minor. The dashed lines from Chaps.  and  to the opening chapters of Parts II and IV indicate that the reader will benefit from knowledge of Schur orthogonality but may skip or postpone Chaps.​ 1 and  before starting Part II or Part IV. The other dashed line indicates that the Bruhat decomposition ( Chap.​ 27 ) is assumed in the last few chapters of Part IV.

The two lines of development in Parts II–IV were kept independent because it was possible to do so. This has the obvious advantage that one may start reading with Part IV for an alternative course. This should not obscure the fact that these two lines are complementary, and shed light on each other. We hope the reader will study the whole book.

Part I treats two basic topics in the analysis of compact Lie groups: Schur orthogonality and the Peter–Weyl theorem, which says that the irreducible unitary representations of a compact group are all finite-dimensional.

Usually the study of Lie groups begins with compact Lie groups. It is attractive to make this the complete content of a short course because it can be treated as a self-contained subject with well-defined goals, about the right size for a 10-week class. Indeed, Part II, which covers this theory, could be used as a traditional course culminating in the Weyl character formula. It covers the basic facts about compact Lie groups: the fundamental group, conjugacy of maximal tori, roots and weights, the Weyl group, the Weyl integration formula, and the Weyl character formula. These are basic tools, and a short course in Lie theory might end up with the Weyl character formula, though usually I try to do a bit more in a 10-week course, even at the expense of skipping a few proofs in the lectures. The last chapter in Part II introduces the affine Weyl group and computes the fundamental group. It can be skipped since Part III does not depend on it.

Sage , the free mathematical software system, is capable of doing typical Lie theory calculations. The student of Part II may want to learn to use it. An appendix illustrates its use.

The goal of Part I is the Peter–Weyl theorem, but Part II does not depend on this. Therefore one could skip Part I and start with Part II. Usually when I teach this material, I do spend one or two lectures on Part I, proving Schur orthogonality but not the Peter–Weyl formula. In the interests of speed I tend to skip a few proofs in the lectures. For example, the conjugacy of maximal tori needs to be proved, and this depends in turn on the surjectivity of the exponential map for compact groups, that is, Theorem 16.3. This is proved completely in the text, and I think it should be proved in class but some of the differential geometry details behind it can be replaced by intuitive explanations. So in lecturing, I try to explain the intuitive content of the proof without going back and proving Proposition 16.1 in class. Beginning with Theorems 16.2–16.4, the results to the end of the chapter, culminating in various important facts such as the conjugacy of maximal tori and the connectedness of centralizers can all be done in class. In the lectures I prove the Weyl integration formula and (if there is time) the local Frobenius theorem. But I skip a few things like Theorem 13.3. Then it is possible to get to the Weyl Character formula in under 10 weeks.

Although compact Lie groups are an essential topic that can be treated in one quarter, noncompact Lie groups are equally important. A key role in much of mathematics is played by the Borel subgroup of a Lie group. For example, if   or   , the Borel subgroup is the subgroup of upper triangular matrices, or any conjugate of this subgroup. It is involved in two important results, the Bruhat and Iwasawa decompositions. A noncompact Lie group has two important classes of homogeneous spaces, namely symmetric spaces and flag varieties, which are at the heart of a great deal of important modern mathematics. Therefore, noncompact Lie groups cannot be ignored, and we tried hard to include them.

In Part III we first introduce a class of noncompact groups, the complex reductive groups, that are obtained from compact Lie groups by "complexification." These are studied in several chapters before eventually taking on general noncompact Lie groups. This allows us to introduce key topics such as the Iwasawa and Bruhat decompositions without getting too caught up in technicalities. Then we look at the Weyl group and affine Weyl group, already introduced in Part II, as Coxeter groups. There are two important facts about them to be proved: that they have Coxeter group presentations, and the theorem of Matsumoto and Tits that any two reduced words for the same element may be related by applications of the braid relations.

For these two facts we give geometric proofs, based on properties of the complexes on which they act. These complexes are the system of Weyl chambers in the first case, and of alcoves in the second. Applications are given, such as Demazure characters and the Bruhat order. For complex reductive groups, we prove the Iwasawa and Bruhat decompositions, digressing to discuss some of the implications of the Bruhat decomposition for the flag manifold. In particular the Schubert and Bott–Samelson varieties, the Borel-Weil theorem and the Bruhat order are introduced. Then we look at symmetric spaces, in a chapter that alternates examples with theory. Symmetric spaces occur in pairs, a compact space matched with a noncompact one. We see how some symmetric spaces, the Hermitian ones, have complex structures and are important in the theory of functions of several complex variables. Others are convex cones. We take a look at Freudenthal's "magic square." We discuss the embedding of a noncompact symmetric space in its compact dual, the boundary components and Bergman–Shilov boundary of a symmetric tube domain, and Cartan's classification. By now we are dealing with arbitrary noncompact Lie groups, where before we limited ourselves to the complex analytic ones. Another chapter constructs the relative root system, explains Satake diagrams and gives examples illustrating the various phenomena that can occur. The Iwasawa decomposition, formerly obtained for complex analytic groups, is reproved in this more general context. Another chapter surveys the different ways Lie groups can be embedded in one another. Part III ends with a somewhat lengthy discussion of the spin representations of the double covers of orthogonal groups. First, we consider what can be deduced from the Weyl theory. Second, as an alternative, we construct the spin representations using Clifford algebras. Instead of following the approach (due to Chevalley) often taken in embedding the spin group into the multiplicative group of the Clifford algebra, we take a different approach suggested by the point of view in Howe [75, 77].

This approach obtains the spin representation as a projective representation from the fact that the orthogonal group acts by automorphisms on a ring having a unique representation. The existence of the spin group is a byproduct of the projective representation. This is the same way that the Weil representation is usually constructed from the Stone–von Neumann theorem, with the Clifford algebra replacing the Heisenberg group.

Part IV, we have already mentioned, is largely independent of the earlier parts. Much of it concerned with correspondences which were emphasized by Howe, though important examples occur in older work of Frobenius and Schur, Weyl, Weil and others. Following Howe, a correspondence is a bijection between a set of representations of a group G with a set of representations of another group H which arise as follows. There is a representation Ω of G × H with the following property. Let π  i ⊗ π  i ′ be the irreducible representations of G × H that occur in the restriction. It is assumed that each occurs with multiplicity one, and moreover, that there are no repetitions among the π  i , and none among the π  i ′. This gives a bijection between the representations π  i of G and the representations π  i ′ of H . Often Ω has an explicit description with special properties that allow us to transfer calculation from one group to the other. Sometimes Ω arises by restriction of a "small" representation of a big group W that contains G × H as a subgroup.

The first example is the Frobenius–Schur duality. This is the correspondence between the irreducible representations of the symmetric group and the general linear groups. The correspondence comes from decomposing tensor spaces over both groups simultaneously. Another correspondence, for the groups GL( n ) and GL( m ), is embodied in the Cauchy identity. We will focus on these two correspondences, giving examples of how they can be used to transfer calculations from one group to the other.

Frobenius–Schur duality is very often called "Schur–Weyl duality," and indeed Weyl emphasized this theory both in his book on the classical groups and in his book on quantum mechanics. However Weyl was much younger than Schur and did not begin working on Lie groups until the 1920s, while the duality is already mature in Schur's 1901 dissertation. Regarding Frobenius' contribution, Frobenius invented character theory before the relationship between characters and representations was clarified by his student Schur. With great insight Frobenius showed in 1900 that the characters of the symmetric group could be computed using symmetric functions. This very profound idea justifies attaching Frobenius' name with Schur's to this phenomenon. Now Green has pointed out that the 1892 work of Deruyts in invariant theory also contains results almost equivalent to this duality. This came a few years too soon to fully take the point of view of group representation theory. Deruyt's work is prescient but less historically influential than that of Frobenius and Schur since it was overlooked for many years, and in particular Schur was apparently not aware of it. For these reasons we feel the term "Frobenius–Schur duality" is most accurate. See the excellent history of Curtis [39].

Frobenius–Schur duality allows us to simultaneously develop the representation theories of   and S k . For   , this means a proof of the Weyl character formula that is independent of the arguments in Part II. For the symmetric group, this means that (following Frobenius) we may use symmetric functions to describe the characters of the irreducible representations of S k . This gives us a double view of symmetric function theory that sheds light on a great many things. The double view is encoded in the structure of a graded algebra (actually a Hopf algebra)   whose homogeneous part of degree k consists of the characters of representations of S k . This is isomorphic to the ring of Λ of symmetric polynomials, and familiarity with this equivalence is the key to understanding a great many things.

One very instructive example of using Frobenius–Schur duality is the computation by Diaconis and Shahshahani of the moments of the traces of unitary matrices. The result has an interesting interpretation in terms of random matrix theory, and it also serves as an example of how the duality can be used: directly computing the moments in question is feasible but leads to a difficult combinatorial problem. Instead, one translates the problem from the unitary group to an equivalent but easier question on the symmetric group.

The GL( n ) ×GL( m ) duality, like the Frobenius–Schur duality, can be used to translate a calculation from one context to another, where it may be easier. As an example, we consider a result of Keating and Snaith, also from random matrix theory, which had significant consequences in understanding the distribution of the values of the Riemann zeta function. The computation in question is that of the 2 k -th moment of the characteristic polynomial of U( n ). Using the duality, it is possible to transfer the computation from U( n ) to U(2 k ), where it becomes easy.

Other types of problems that may be handled this way are branching rules: a branching rule describes how an irreducible representation of a group G decomposes into irreducibles when restricted to a subgroup H . We will see instances where one uses a duality to transfer a calculation from one pair ( G , H ) to another, ( G ′, H ′). For example, we may take G and H to be GL( p \+ q ) and its subgroup GL( p ) ×GL( q ), and G ′ and H ′ to be GL( n ) ×GL( n ) and its diagonal subgroup GL( n ).

Chapter 42 shows how the Jacobi–Trudi identity from the representation theory of the symmetric group can be translated using Frobenius–Schur duality to compute minors of Toeplitz matrices. Then we look at involution models for the symmetric group, showing how it is possible to find a set of induced representations whose union contains every irreducible representation exactly once. Translated by Frobenius–Schur duality, this gives some decompositions of symmetric algebras over the symmetric and exterior square representations, a topic that is also treated by a different method in Part II.

Towards the end of Part IV, we discuss several other ways that the graded ring   occurs. First, the representation theory of the symmetric group has a deformation in the Iwahori Hecke algebra, which is ubiquitous in mathematics, from the representation theory of p -adic groups to the K-theory of flag varieties and developments in mathematical physics related to the Yang–Baxter equation. Second, the Hopf algebra   has an analog in which the representation theory of GL( k ) (say over a finite field) replaces the representation theory of S k ; the multiplication and comultiplication are parabolic induction and its adjoint (the Jacquet functor). The ground field may be replaced by a p -adic field or an adele ring, and ultimately this "philosophy of cusp forms" leads to the theory of automorphic forms. Thirdly, the ring   has as a homomorphic image the cohomology rings of flag varieties, leading to the Schubert calculus. These topics are surveyed in the final chapters.

What's New? I felt that the plan of the first edition was a good one, but that substantial improvements were needed. Some material has been removed, and a fair amount of new material has been added. Some old material has been streamlined or rewritten, sometimes extensively. In places what was implicit in the first edition but not explained well is now carefully explained with attention to the underlying principles. There are more exercises. A few chapters are little changed, but the majority have some revisions, so the changes are too numerous to list completely. Highlights in the newly added material include the affine Weyl group, new material about Coxeter groups, Demazure characters, Bruhat order, Schubert and Bott–Samelson varieties, the Borel-Weil theorem the appendix on Sage , Clifford algebras, the Keating–Snaith theorem, and more.

Notation. The notations GL( n , F ) and GL  n ( F ) are interchangeable for the group of n × n matrices with coefficients in F . By Mat  n ( F ) we denote the ring of n × n matrices, and Mat  n × m ( F ) denotes the vector space of n × m matrices. In GL( n ), I or I n denotes the n × n identity matrix and if g is any matrix,  t g denotes its transpose. Omitted entries in a matrix are zero. Thus, for example,

The identity element of a group is usually denoted 1 but also as I , if the group is GL( n ) (or a subgroup), and occasionally as e when it seemed the other notations could be confusing. The notations ⊂ and ⊆ are synonymous, but we mostly use X ⊂ Y if X and Y are known to be unequal, although we make no guarantee that we are completely consistent in this. If X is a finite set, | X | denotes its cardinality.

# 1. Haar Measure

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

If G is a locally compact group, there is, up to a constant multiple, a unique regular Borel measure μ L that is invariant under left translation. Here left translation invariance means that μ(X) = μ(gX) for all measurable sets X.

If G is a locally compact group, there is, up to a constant multiple, a unique regular Borel measure μ L that is invariant under left translation. Here left translation invariance means that μ(X) = μ(gX) for all measurable sets X. Regularity means that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mu \(X\) =\\inf \\left \\{\\mu \(U\)\\,\\vert \\,U \\supseteq X,\\text{U open}\\right \\} =\\sup \\left \\{\\mu \(K\)\\,\\vert \\,K \\subseteq X,\\text{K compact}\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Such a measure is called a left Haar measure. It has the properties that any compact set has finite measure and any nonempty open set has measure > 0.

We will not prove the existence and uniqueness of the Haar measure. See for example Halmos [61], Hewitt and Ross [69], Chap. IV, or Loomis [121] for a proof of this. Left-invariance of the measure amounts to left-invariance of the corresponding integral,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{G}f\(\\gamma g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L}\(g\) =\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L}\(g\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(1.1)

for any Haar integrable function f on G.

There is also a right-invariant measure, μ R , unique up to constant multiple, called a right Haar measure. Left and right Haar measures may or may not coincide. For example, if

![
$$\\displaystyle{G = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,y\\,&x\\\\ 0 & \\,1\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,x,y \\in \\mathbb{R},y > 0\\right \\},}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_Equb.gif)

then it is easy to see that the left- and right-invariant measures are, respectively,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L} = {y}^{-2}\\,\\mathrm{d}x\\,\\mathrm{d}y,\\qquad \\mathrm{d}\\mu _{ R} = {y}^{-1}\\,\\mathrm{d}x\\,\\mathrm{d}y.}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_Equc.gif)

They are not the same. However, there are many cases where they do coincide, and if the left Haar measure is also right-invariant, we call G unimodular.

Conjugation is an automorphism of G, and so it takes a left Haar measure to another left Haar measure, which must be a constant multiple of the first. Thus, if g ∈ G, there exists a constant δ(g) > 0 such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}f\({g}^{-1}hg\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{ L}\(h\) = \\delta \(g\)\\int _{G}f\(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L}\(h\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_Equd.gif)

If G is a topological group, a quasicharacter is a continuous homomorphism ![
$$\\chi: G\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq1.gif). If |χ(g)| = 1 for all g ∈ G, then χ is a (linear) character or unitary quasicharacter.

Proposition 1.1.

The function ![
$$\\delta: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq2.gif) is a quasicharacter. The measure δ(h)μ L (h) is right-invariant.

The measure ![
$$\\delta \(h\)\\mu _{L}\(h\)$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq3.gif) is a right Haar measure, and we may write ![
$$\\mu _{R}\(h\) = \\delta \(h\)\\mu _{L}\(h\)$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq4.gif). The quasicharacter δ is called the modular quasicharacter.

Proof.

Conjugation by first g 1 and then g 2 is the same as conjugation by g 1 g 2 in one step. Thus ![
$$\\delta \(g_{1}g_{2}\) = \\delta \(g_{1}\)\\,\\delta \(g_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq5.gif), so δ is a quasicharacter. Using (1.1),

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\delta \(g\)\\int _{G}f\(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L}\(h\) =\\int _{G}f\(g \\cdot {g}^{-1}hg\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{ L}\(h\) =\\int _{G}f\(hg\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L}\(h\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_Eque.gif)

Replace f by f δ in this identity and then divide both sides by δ(g) to find that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}f\(h\)\\,\\delta \(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L}\(h\) =\\int _{G}f\(hg\)\\,\\delta \(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L}\(h\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Thus, the measure ![
$$\\delta \(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L}\(h\)$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq6.gif) is right-invariant. □

Proposition 1.2.

If G is compact, then G is unimodular and ![
$$\\mu _{L}\(G\) < \\infty.$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq7.gif)

Proof.

Since δ is a homomorphism, the image of δ is a subgroup of ![
$$\\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq8.gif). Since G is compact, δ(G) is also compact, and the only compact subgroup of ![
$$\\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is just ![
$$\\left \\{1\\right \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq10.gif). Thus δ is trivial, so a left Haar measure is right-invariant. We have mentioned as an assumed fact that the Haar volume of any compact subset of a locally compact group is finite, so if G is finite, its Haar volume is finite. □

If G is compact, then it is natural to normalize the Haar measure so that G has volume 1.

To simplify our notation, we will denote ![
$$\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{L}\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq11.gif) by ![
$$\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq12.gif).

Proposition 1.3.

If G is unimodular, then the map ![
$$g\\longrightarrow {g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq13.gif) is an isometry.

Proof.

It is easy to see that ![
$$g\\longrightarrow {g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq14.gif) turns a left Haar measure into a right Haar measure. If left and right Haar measures agree, then ![
$$g\\longrightarrow {g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_1_Chapter_IEq15.gif) multiplies the left Haar measure by a positive constant, which must be 1 since the map has order 2. □

# 2. Schur Orthogonality

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In this chapter and the next two, we will consider the representation theory of compact groups. Let us begin with a few observations about this theory and its relationship to some related theories.

In this chapter and the next two, we will consider the representation theory of compact groups. Let us begin with a few observations about this theory and its relationship to some related theories.

If V is a finite-dimensional complex vector space, or more generally a Banach space, and ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq1.gif) a continuous homomorphism, then (π,V) is called a representation. Assuming ![
$$\\dim \(V \) < \\infty $$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq2.gif), the function ![
$$\\chi _{\\pi }\(g\) = \\text{tr}\\;\\pi \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq3.gif) is called the character of π. Also assuming dim(V) < ∞, the representation (π,V) is called irreducible if V has no proper nonzero invariant subspaces, and a character is called irreducible if it is a character of an irreducible representation.

[If V is an infinite-dimensional topological vector space, then (π,V) is called irreducible if it has no proper nonzero invariant closed subspaces.]

A quasicharacter χ is a character in this sense since we can take ![
$$V = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq4.gif) and π(g)v = χ(g)v to obtain a representation whose character is χ.

The archetypal compact Abelian group is the circle ![
$$\\mathbb{T} =\\big\\{ z \\in {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }\\,\\big\\vert \\,\\vert z\\vert = 1\\big\\}.$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq5.gif) We normalize the Haar measure on ![
$$\\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq6.gif) so that it has volume 1. Its characters are the functions ![
$$\\chi _{n}: \\mathbb{T}\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq7.gif), ![
$$\\chi _{n}\(z\) = {z}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq8.gif). The important properties of the χ n are that they form an orthonormal system and (deeper) an orthonormal basis of ![
$${L}^{2}\(\\mathbb{T}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq9.gif).

More generally, if G is a compact Abelian group, the characters of G form an orthonormal basis of L 2(G). If f ∈ L 2(G), we have a Fourier expansion,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ f\(g\) =\\sum _{\\chi }a_{\\chi }\\,\\chi \(g\),a_{\\chi } =\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\overline{\\chi \(g\)}\\,\\mathrm{d}g, }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(2.1)

and the Plancherel formula is the identity:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{G}\\vert f\(g\){\\vert }^{2}\\,\\mathrm{d}g =\\sum _{ \\chi }\\vert a_{\\chi }{\\vert }^{2}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(2.2)

These facts can be directly generalized in two ways. First, Fourier analysis on locally compact Abelian groups, including Pontriagin duality, Fourier inversion, the Plancherel formula, etc. is an important and complete theory due to Weil [169] and discussed, for example, in Rudin [140] or Loomis [121]. The most important difference from the compact case is that the characters can vary continuously. The characters themselves form a group, the dual group ![
$$\\hat{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq10.gif), whose topology is that of uniform convergence on compact sets. The Fourier expansion (2.1) is replaced by the Fourier inversion formula

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(g\) =\\int _{\\hat{G}}\\hat{f}\(\\chi \)\\,\\chi \(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\chi,\\quad\\hat{f}\(\\chi \) =\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\overline{\\chi \(g\)}\\,\\mathrm{d}g.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equa.gif)

The symmetry between G and ![
$$\\hat{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq11.gif) is now evident. Similarly in the Plancherel formula (2.2) the sum on the right is replaced by an integral.

The second generalization, to arbitrary compact groups, is the subject of this chapter and the next two. In summary, group representation theory gives a orthonormal basis of L 2(G) in the matrix coefficients of irreducible representations of G and a (more important and very canonical) orthonormal basis of the subspace of L 2(G) consisting of class functions in terms of the characters of the irreducible representations. Most importantly, the irreducible representations are all finite-dimensional. The orthonormality of these sets is Schur orthogonality; the completeness is the Peter–Weyl theorem.

These two directions of generalization can be unified. Harmonic analysis on locally compact groups agrees with representation theory. The Fourier inversion formula and the Plancherel formula now involve the matrix coefficients of the irreducible unitary representations, which may occur in continuous families and are usually infinite-dimensional. This field of mathematics, largely created by Harish-Chandra, is fundamental but beyond the scope of this book. See Knapp [104] for an extended introduction, and Gelfand, Graev and Piatetski-Shapiro [55] and Varadarajan [165] for the Plancherel formula for ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq12.gif).

Although infinite-dimensional representations are thus essential in harmonic analysis on a noncompact group such as ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq13.gif), noncompact Lie groups also have irreducible finite-dimensional representations, which are important in their own right. They are seldom unitary and hence not relevant to the Plancherel formula. The scope of this book includes finite-dimensional representations of Lie groups but not infinite-dimensional ones.

In this chapter and the next two, we will be mainly concerned with compact groups. In this chapter, all representations will be complex and finite-dimensional except when explicitly noted otherwise.

By an inner product on a complex vector space, we mean a positive definite Hermitian form, denoted ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq14.gif). Thus, ![
$$\\left \\langle v,w\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq15.gif) is linear in v, conjugate linear in w, satisfies ![
$$\\left \\langle w,v\\right \\rangle = \\overline{\\left \\langle v,w\\right \\rangle }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq16.gif), and ![
$$\\left \\langle v,v\\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq17.gif) if v≠0. We will also use the term inner product for real vector spaces—an inner product on a real vector space is a positive definite symmetric bilinear form. Given a group G and a real or complex representation ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq18.gif), we say the inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq19.gif) on V is invariant or G-equivariant if it satisfies the identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)v,\\pi \(g\)w\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle v,w\\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equb.gif)

Proposition 2.1.

If G is compact and (π,V ) is any finite-dimensional complex representation, then V admits a G-equivariant inner product.

Proof.

Start with an arbitrary inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\left \\langle \\,,\\,\\right \\rangle \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq20.gif). Averaging it gives another inner product,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle v,w\\right \\rangle =\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)v,\\pi \(g\)w\\right \\rangle \\right \\rangle \\mathrm{d}g,}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equc.gif)

for it is easy to see that this inner product is Hermitian and positive definite. It is G-invariant by construction. □

Proposition 2.2.

If G is compact, then each finite-dimensional representation is the direct sum of irreducible representations.

Proof.

Let (π,V) be given. Let V 1 be a nonzero invariant subspace of minimal dimension. It is clearly irreducible. Let ![
$$V _{1}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq21.gif) be the orthogonal complement of V 1 with respect to a G-invariant inner product. It is easily checked to be invariant and is of lower dimension than V. By induction ![
$$V _{1}^{\\perp } = V _{2} \\oplus \\cdots \\oplus V _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq22.gif) is a direct sum of invariant subspaces and so ![
$$V = V _{1} \\oplus \\cdots \\oplus V _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq23.gif) is also. □

A function of the form ![
$$\\phi \(g\) = L\\big\(\\pi \(g\)\\,v\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq24.gif), where (π,V) is a finite-dimensional representation of G, v ∈ V and ![
$$L: V \\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq25.gif) is a linear functional, is called a matrix coefficient on G. This terminology is natural, because if we choose a basis e 1,...,e n , of V, we can identify V with ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) and represent g by matrices:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi \(g\)v = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\pi _{11}\(g\) &\\cdots & \\pi _{1n}\(g\)\\\\ \\vdots & & \\vdots \\\\ \\pi _{n1}\(g\)&\\cdots &\\pi _{nn}\(g\) \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{c} v_{1}\\\\ \\vdots \\\\ v_{n} \\end{array} \\right \),v = \\left \(\\begin{array}{c} v_{1}\\\\ \\vdots \\\\ v_{n} \\end{array} \\right \) =\\sum _{ j=1}^{n}v_{ j}e_{j}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equd.gif)

Then each of the n 2 functions π ij is a matrix coefficient. Indeed

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi _{ij}\(g\) = L_{i}\\big\(\\pi \(g\)e_{j}\\big\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Eque.gif)

where ![
$$L_{i}\(\\sum _{j}v_{j}e_{j}\) = v_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq27123.gif).

Proposition 2.3.

The matrix coefficients of G are continuous functions. The pointwise sum or product of two matrix coefficients is a matrix coefficient, so they form a ring.

Proof.

If v ∈ V, then ![
$$g\\longrightarrow \\pi \(g\)v$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) is continuous since by definition a representation ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) is continuous and so a matrix coefficient ![
$$L\\big\(\\pi \(g\)\\,v\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) is continuous.

If ![
$$\(\\pi _{1},V _{1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq31123.gif) and ![
$$\(\\pi _{2},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) are representations, ![
$$v_{i} \\in V _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) are vectors and ![
$$L_{i}: V _{i}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) are linear functionals, then we have representations π1 ⊕ π2 and ![
$$\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\pi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq35.gif) on ![
$$V _{1} \\oplus V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq36.gif) and V 1 ⊗ V 2, respectively. Given vectors v i ∈ V i and functionals ![
$$L_{i} \\in V _{i}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq37.gif), then ![
$$L_{1}\\big\(\\pi \(g\)v_{1}\\big\) \\pm L_{2}\\big\(\\pi \(g\)v_{2}\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq38.gif) can be expressed as ![
$$L\\big\(\(\\pi _{1} \\oplus \\pi _{2}\)\(g\)\(v_{1},v_{2}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq39.gif) where ![
$$L: V _{1} \\oplus V _{2}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq40.gif) is ![
$$L\(x_{1},x_{2}\) = L_{1}\(x_{1}\) \\pm L_{2}\(x_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq41.gif), so the matrix coefficients are closed under addition and subtraction.

Similarly, we have a linear functional L 1 ⊗ L 2 on V 1 ⊗ V 2 satisfying

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(L_{1} \\otimes L_{2}\)\(x_{1} \\otimes x_{2}\) = L_{1}\(x_{1}\)L_{2}\(x_{2}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equf.gif)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(L_{1} \\otimes L_{2}\)\\big\(\(\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\pi _{2}\)\(g\)\(v_{1} \\otimes v_{2}\)\\big\) = L_{1}\\big\(\\pi _{1}\(g\)v_{1}\\big\)\\,L_{2}\\big\(\\pi _{2}\(g\)v_{2}\\big\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equg.gif)

proving that the product of two matrix coefficients is a matrix coefficient. □

If (π,V) is a representation, let V ∗ be the dual space of V. To emphasize the symmetry between V and V ∗, let us write the dual pairing ![
$$V \\times {V }^{{\\ast}}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq42.gif) in the symmetrical form ![
$$L\(v\) = \\left \[\[v,L\\right \]\]$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq43.gif). We have a representation ![
$$\(\\hat{\\pi },{V }^{{\\ast}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq44.gif), called the contragredient of π, defined by

![
$$\[\\!\[v,\\hat{\\pi }\(g\)L\]\\!\] = \[\\!\[\\pi \({g}^{-1}\)v,L\]\\!\].$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(2.3)

Note that the inverse is needed here so that ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }\(g_{1}g_{2}\) =\\hat{ \\pi }\(g_{1}\)\\hat{\\pi }\(g_{2}\).$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq45.gif)

If (π,V) is a representation, then by Proposition 2.3 any linear combination of functions of the form ![
$$L\\big\(\\pi \(g\)\\,v\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq46.gif) with v ∈ V, L ∈ V ∗ is a matrix coefficient, though it may be a function ![
$${L^{\\prime}}\\big\(\\pi^{\\prime}\(g\)\\,v^{\\prime}\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq47.gif) where (π′,V ′) is not (π,V ), but a larger representation. Nevertheless, we call any linear combination of functions of the form ![
$$L\\big\(\\pi \(g\)\\,v\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq48.gif) a matrix coefficient of the representation (π,V ). Thus, the matrix coefficients of π form a vector space, which we will denote by ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq49.gif). Clearly, ![
$$\\dim \(\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }\) \\leqslant \\dim {\(V \)}^{2}.$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq50.gif)

Proposition 2.4.

If f is a matrix coefficient of (π,V ), then ![
$$\\check{f}\(g\) = f\({g}^{-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq51.gif) is a matrix coefficient of ![
$$\(\\hat{\\pi },{V }^{{\\ast}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq52.gif) .

Proof.

This is clear from (2.3), regarding v as a linear functional on V ∗. □

We have actions of G on the space of functions on G by left and right translation. Thus if f is a function and g ∈ G, the left and right translates are

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\big\(\\lambda \(g\)f\\big\)\(x\) = f\({g}^{-1}x\),\\quad\\big\(\\rho \(g\)f\\big\)\(x\) = f\(xg\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equh.gif)

Theorem 2.1.

Let f be a function on G. The following are equivalent.

(i)

The functions λ(g)f span a finite-dimensional vector space.

(ii)

The functions ρ(g)f span a finite-dimensional vector space.

(iii)

The function f is a matrix coefficient of a finite-dimensional representation.

Proof.

It is easy to check that if f is a matrix coefficient of a particular representation V, then so are λ(g)f and ρ(g)f for any g ∈ G. Since V is finite-dimensional, its matrix coefficients span a finite-dimensional vector space; in fact, a space of dimension at most ![
$$\\dim {\(V \)}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq53.gif). Thus, (iii) implies (i) and (ii).

Suppose that the functions ρ(g)f span a finite-dimensional vector space V. Then (ρ,V) is a finite-dimensional representation of G, and we claim that f is a matrix coefficient. Indeed, define a functional ![
$$L: V \\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq54.gif) by L(ϕ) = ϕ(1). Clearly, ![
$$L\\big\(\\rho \(g\)f\\big\) = f\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq55.gif), so f is a matrix coefficient, as required. Thus (ii) implies (iii).

Finally, if the functions λ(g)f span a finite-dimensional space, composing these functions with ![
$$g\\longrightarrow {g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq56.gif) gives another finite-dimensional space which is closed under right translation, and ![
$$\\check{f}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq57.gif) defined as in Proposition 2.4 is an element of this space; hence ![
$$\\check{f}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq58.gif) is a matrix coefficient by the case just considered. By Proposition 2.4, f is also a matrix coefficient, so (i) implies (iii). □

If ![
$$\(\\pi _{1},V _{1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq59.gif) and (![
$$\\pi _{2},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq60.gif) are representations, an intertwining operator, also known as a G-equivariant map ![
$$T: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq61.gif) or (since V 1 and V 2 are sometimes called G-modules) a G-module homomorphism, is a linear transformation ![
$$T: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq62.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{T \\circ \\pi _{1}\(g\) = \\pi _{2}\(g\) \\circ T}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equi.gif)

for g ∈ G. We will denote by ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{\\mathbb{C}}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq63.gif) the space of all linear transformations ![
$$V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq64.gif) and by ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq65.gif) the subspace of those that are intertwining maps.

For the remainder of this chapter, unless otherwise stated, G will denote a compact group.

Theorem 2.2 (Schur's lemma).

(i)

Let (π 1 ,V 1 ) and ![
$$\(\\pi _{2},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq66.gif) be irreducible representations, and let ![
$$T: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq67.gif) be an intertwining operator. Then either T is zero or it is an isomorphism.

(ii)

Suppose that (π,V ) is an irreducible representation of G and ![
$$T: V \\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq68.gif) is an intertwining operator. Then there exists a scalar ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq69.gif) such that T(v) = λv for all v ∈ V.

Proof.

For (i), the kernel of T is an invariant subspace of V 1, which is assumed irreducible, so if T is not zero, ![
$$\\ker \(T\) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq70.gif). Thus, T is injective. Also, the image of T is an invariant subspace of V 2. Since V 2 is irreducible, if T is not zero, then im(T) = V 2. Therefore T is bijective, so it is an isomorphism.

For (ii), let λ be any eigenvalue of T. Let ![
$$I: V \\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq71.gif) denote the identity map. The linear transformation ![
$$T - \\lambda I$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq72.gif) is an intertwining operator that is not an isomorphism, so it is the zero map by (i). □

We are assuming that G is compact. The Haar volume of G is therefore finite, and we normalize the Haar measure so that the volume of G is 1.

We will consider the space L 2(G) of functions on G that are square-integrable with respect to the Haar measure. This is a Hilbert space with the inner product

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle f_{1},f_{2}\\right \\rangle _{{L}^{2}} =\\int _{G}f_{1}\(g\)\\,\\overline{f_{2}\(g\)}\\,\\mathrm{d}g.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equj.gif)

Schur orthogonality will give us an orthonormal basis for this space.

If (π,V) is a representation and ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq73.gif) is an invariant inner product on V, then every linear functional is of the form ![
$$x\\longrightarrow \\left \\langle x,v\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq74.gif) for some v ∈ V. Thus a matrix coefficient may be written in the form ![
$$g\\longrightarrow \\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)w,v\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq75.gif), and such a representation will be useful to us in our discussion of Schur orthogonality.

Lemma 2.1.

Suppose that ![
$$\(\\pi _{1},V _{1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq76.gif) and ![
$$\(\\pi _{2},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq77.gif) are complex representations of the compact group G. Let ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq78.gif) be any inner product on V 1 . If ![
$$v_{i},w_{i} \\in V _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq79.gif) , then the map ![
$$T: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq80.gif) given by

![
$$\\displaystyle{ T\(w\) =\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi _{1}\(g\)w,v_{1}\\right \\rangle \\pi _{2}\({g}^{-1}\)v_{ 2}\\,\\mathrm{d}g }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(2.4)

is G-equivariant.

Proof.

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{T\\big\(\\pi _{1}\(h\)w\\big\) =\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi _{1}\(gh\)w,v_{1}\\right \\rangle \\pi _{2}\({g}^{-1}\)v_{ 2}\\,\\mathrm{d}g.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equk.gif)

The variable change ![
$$g\\longrightarrow g{h}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq81.gif) shows that this equals π2(h)T(w), as required. □

Theorem 2.3 (Schur orthogonality).

Suppose that ![
$$\(\\pi _{1},V _{1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq82.gif) and ![
$$\(\\pi _{2},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq83.gif) are irreducible representations of the compact group G. Either every matrix coefficient of π 1 is orthogonal in L 2 (G) to every matrix coefficient of π 2 , or the representations are isomorphic.

Proof.

We must show that if there exist matrix coefficients ![
$$f_{i}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq84.gif) of π i that are not orthogonal, then there is an isomorphism ![
$$T: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq85.gif). We may assume that the f i have the form ![
$$f_{i}\(g\) = \\left \\langle \\pi _{i}\(g\)w_{i},v_{i}\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq86.gif) since functions of that form span the spaces of matrix coefficients of the representations π i . Here we use the notation ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq87.gif) to denote invariant bilinear forms on both V 1 and V 2, and ![
$$v_{i},w_{i} \\in V _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq88.gif). Then our assumption is that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi _{1}\(g\)w_{1},v_{1}\\right \\rangle \\left \\langle \\pi _{2}\({g}^{-1}\)v_{ 2},w_{2}\\right \\rangle \\,\\mathrm{d}g =\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi _{1}\(g\)w_{1},v_{1}\\right \\rangle \\overline{\\left \\langle \\pi _{2}\(g\)w_{2},v_{2}\\right \\rangle }\\,\\mathrm{d}g\\neq 0.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equl.gif)

Define ![
$$T: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq89.gif) by (2.4). The map is nonzero since the last inequality can be written ![
$$\\left \\langle T\(w_{1}\),w_{2}\\right \\rangle \\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq90.gif). It is an isomorphism by Schur's lemma. □

This gives orthogonality for matrix coefficients coming from nonisomorphic irreducible representations. But what about matrix coefficients from the same representation? (If the representations are isomorphic, we may as well assume they are equal.) The following result gives us an answer to this question.

Theorem 2.4 (Schur orthogonality).

Let (π,V ) be an irreducible representation of the compact group G, with invariant inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle.$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq91.gif) Then there exists a constant d > 0 such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)w_{1},v_{1}\\right \\rangle \\overline{\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)w_{2},v_{2}\\right \\rangle }\\,\\mathrm{d}g = {d}^{-1}\\left \\langle w_{ 1},w_{2}\\right \\rangle \\left \\langle v_{2},v_{1}\\right \\rangle. }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(2.5)

Later, in Proposition 2.9, we will show that ![
$$d =\\dim \(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq92.gif).

Proof.

We will show that if v 1 and v 2 are fixed, there exists a constant ![
$$c\(v_{1},v_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq93.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)w_{1},v_{1}\\right \\rangle \\overline{\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)w_{2},v_{2}\\right \\rangle }\\,\\mathrm{d}g = c\(v_{1},v_{2}\)\\left \\langle w_{1,}w_{2}\\right \\rangle. }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(2.6)

Indeed, T given by (2.4) is G-equivariant, so by Schur's lemma it is a scalar. Thus, there is a constant c = c(v 1,v 2) depending only on v 1 and v 2 such that T(w) = cw. In particular, ![
$$T\(w_{1}\) = cw_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq94.gif), and so the right-hand side of (2.6) equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle T\(w_{1}\),w_{2}\\right \\rangle =\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)w_{1},v_{1}\\right \\rangle \\left \\langle \\pi \({g}^{-1}\)v_{ 2},w_{2}\\right \\rangle \\,\\mathrm{d}g,}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equm.gif)

Now the variable change ![
$$g\\longrightarrow {g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq95.gif) and the properties of the inner product show that this equals the left-hand side of (2.6), proving the identity. The same argument shows that there exists another constant ![
$$c^{\\prime}\(w_{1},w_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq96.gif) such that for all v 1 and v 2 we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)w_{1},v_{1}\\right \\rangle \\overline{\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)w_{2},v_{2}\\right \\rangle }\\,\\mathrm{d}g = c^{\\prime}\(w_{1},w_{2}\)\\left \\langle v_{2,}v_{1}\\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equn.gif)

Combining this with (2.6), we get (2.5). We will compute d later in Proposition 2.9, but for now we simply note that it is positive since, taking ![
$$w_{1} = w_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq97.gif) and v 1 = v 2, both the left-hand side of (2.5) and the two inner products on the right-hand side are positive. □

Before we turn to the evaluation of the constant d, we will prove a different orthogonality for the characters of irreducible representations (Theorem 2.5). This will require some preparations.

Proposition 2.5.

The character χ of a representation (π,V ) is a matrix coefficient of V.

Proof.

If v 1,...,v n is a matrix of V, and L 1,...,L n is the dual basis of V ∗, then ![
$$\\chi \(g\) =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}L_{i}\\big\(\\pi \(g\)v_{i}\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq98.gif). □

Proposition 2.6.

Suppose that (π,V ) is a representation of G. Let χ be the character of π.

(i)

If g ∈ V then ![
$$\\chi \({g}^{-1}\) = \\overline{\\chi \(g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq99.gif) .

(ii)

Let ![
$$\(\\hat{\\pi },{V }^{{\\ast}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq100.gif) be the contragredient representation of π. Then the character of ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq101.gif) is the complex conjugate ![
$$\\overline{\\chi }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq102.gif) of the character χ of G.

Proof.

Since π(g) is unitary with respect to an invariant inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq103.gif), its eigenvalues t 1,...,t n all have absolute value 1, and so

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\text{tr}\\;\\pi {\(g\)}^{-1} =\\sum _{ i}t_{i}^{-1} =\\sum _{ i}\\overline{t_{i}} = \\overline{\\chi \(g\)}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equo.gif)

This proves (i). As for (ii), referring to (2.3), ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq104.gif) is the adjoint of π(g)−1 with respect to the dual pairing ![
$$\\left \[\[\\;,\\;\\right \]\]$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq105.gif), so its trace equals the trace of π(g)−1. □

The trivial representation of any group G is the representation on a one-dimensional vector space V with π(g)v = v being the trivial action.

Proposition 2.7.

If (π,V ) is an irreducible representation and χ its character, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}\\chi \(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} 1&\\text{if}\\,\\pi\\,\\text{is\\,the\\,trivialrepresentation;}\\\\ 0 &\\text{otherwise.} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equp.gif)

Proof.

The character of the trivial representation is just the constant function 1, and since we normalized the Haar measure so that G has volume 1, this integral is 1 if π is trivial. In general, we may regard ![
$$\\int _{G}\\chi \(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq106.gif) as the inner product of χ with the character 1 of the trivial representation, and if π is nontrivial, these are matrix coefficients of different irreducible representations and hence orthogonal by Theorem 2.3. □

If (π,V) is a representation, let V G be the subspace of G-invariants, that is,

![
$$\\displaystyle{{V }^{G} = \\left \\{v \\in V \\,\\vert \\,\\pi \(g\)v = v\\text{for all}\\,g \\in G\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equq.gif)

Proposition 2.8.

If (π,V ) is a representation of G and χ its character, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}\\chi \(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g =\\dim \({V }^{G}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equr.gif)

Proof.

Decompose V = ⊕ i V i into a direct sum of irreducible invariant subspaces, and let χ i be the character of the restriction π i of π to V i . By Proposition 2.7, ![
$$\\int _{G}\\chi _{i}\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq107.gif) if and only if π i is trivial. Hence ![
$$\\int _{G}\\chi \(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq108.gif) is the number of trivial π i . The direct sum of the V i with π i trivial is V G , and the statement follows. □

If (π1,V 1) and (π2,V 2) are irreducible representations, and χ1n and χ2 are their characters, we have already noted in proving Proposition 2.3 that we may form representations π1 ⊕ π2n and π1 ⊗ π2 on V 1 ⊕ V 2 and V 1 ⊗ V 2n. It is easy to see that ![
$$\\chi _{\\pi _{1}\\oplus \\pi _{2}} = \\chi _{\\pi _{1}} + \\chi _{\\pi _{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq109.gif) and ![
$$\\chi _{\\pi _{1}\\otimes \\pi _{2}} = \\chi _{\\pi _{1}}\\chi _{\\pi _{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq110.gif). It is not quite true that the characters form a ring. Certainly the negative of a matrix coefficient is a matrix coefficient, yet the negative of a character is not a character. The set of characters is closed under addition and multiplication but not subtraction. We define a generalized (or virtual) character to be a function of the form χ1 − χ2, where χ1 and χ2 are characters. It is now clear that the generalized characters form a ring.

Lemma 2.2.

Define a representation ![
$$\\varPsi: \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(m, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(\\varOmega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq111.gif) where ![
$$\\varOmega = \\mathrm{Mat}_{n\\times m}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq112.gif) by ![
$$\\varPsi \(g_{1},g_{2}\): X\\longrightarrow g_{2}Xg_{1}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq113.gif) n. Then the trace of ![
$$\\varPsi \(g_{1},g_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq114.gif) is ![
$$\\mathrm{tr}\(g_{1}^{-1}\)\\,\\mathrm{tr}\(g_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq115.gif) n.

Proof.

Both ![
$$\\mathrm{tr}\\;\\varPsi \(g_{1},g_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq116.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{tr}\(g_{1}^{-1}\)\\,\\mathrm{tr}\(g_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq117.gif) are continuous, and since diagonalizable matrices are dense in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq118.gif) we may assume that both g 1 and g 2 are diagonalizable. Also if γ is invertible we have ![
$$\\varPsi \(\\gamma g_{1}{\\gamma }^{-1},g_{2}\) =\\varPsi \(\\gamma,1\)\\varPsi \(g_{1},g_{2}\)\\varPsi {\(\\gamma,1\)}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq119.gif) so the trace of both ![
$$\\mathrm{tr}\\;\\varPsi \(g_{1},g_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq120.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{tr}\(g_{1}^{-1}\)\\mathrm{tr}\(g_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq121.gif) are unchanged if g 1 is replaced by γg 1γ−1. So we may assume that g 1 is diagonal, and similarly g 2. Now if ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq122.gif) and ![
$$\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq123.gif) are the diagonal entries of g 1 and ![
$$g_{2}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq124.gif), the effect of Ψ(g 1,g 2) on X ∈Ω is to multiply the columns by the ![
$$\\alpha _{i}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq125.gif) and the rows by the β j . So the trace is ![
$$\\mathrm{tr}\(g_{1}^{-1}\)\\mathrm{tr}\(g_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq126.gif). □

Theorem 2.5 (Schur orthogonality).

Let (π 1 ,V 1 ) and ![
$$\(\\pi _{2},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq127.gif) be representations of G with characters χ 1 and χ 2 . Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{G}\\chi _{1}\(g\)\\,\\overline{\\chi _{2}\(g\)}\\,\\mathrm{d}g =\\dim \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{1},V _{2}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(2.7)

If π 1 and π 2 are irreducible, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}\\chi _{1}\(g\)\\overline{\\chi _{2}\(g\)}\\,\\mathrm{d}g = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{ccl} 1&&\\text{if}\\,\\pi _{1}\\mathop{\\cong}\\pi _{2};\\\\ 0 & &\\text{otherwise.} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equs.gif)

Proof.

Define a representation Π of G on the space ![
$$\\varOmega = \\mathrm{Hom}_{\\mathbb{C}}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq128.gif) of all linear transformations ![
$$T: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq129.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varPi \(g\)T = \\pi _{2}\(g\) \\circ T \\circ \\pi _{1}{\(g\)}^{-1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equt.gif)

By lemma 2.2 and Proposition 2.6, the character of Π(g) is ![
$$\\chi _{2}\(g\)\\overline{\\chi _{1}\(g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq130.gif). The space of invariants Ω G exactly of the T which are G-module homomorphisms, so by Proposition 2.8 we get

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}\\overline{\\chi _{1}\(g\)}\\,\\chi _{2}\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g =\\dim \\, \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{1},V _{2}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equu.gif)

Since this is real, we may conjugate to obtain (2.7). □

Proposition 2.9.

The constant d in Theorem 2.4 equals dim (V ).

Proof.

Let v 1,...,v n be an orthonormal basis of V, ![
$$n =\\dim \(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq131.gif). We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\chi \(g\) =\\sum _{i}\\left \\langle \\pi _{i}\(g\)v_{i},v_{i}\\right \\rangle }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equv.gif)

since ![
$$\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)v_{j},v_{i}\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq132.gif) is the ![
$$i,j$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq133.gif) component of the matrix of π(g) with respect to this basis. Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{1 =\\int _{G}\\vert \\chi \(g\){\\vert }^{2}\\,\\mathrm{d}g =\\sum _{ i,j}\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)v_{i},v_{i}\\right \\rangle \\overline{\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)v_{j},v_{j}\\right \\rangle }\\,\\mathrm{d}g.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equw.gif)

There are n 2 terms on the right, but by (2.5) only the terms with i = j are nonzero, and those equal d −1. Thus, d = n. □

We now return to the matrix coefficients ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq134.gif) of an irreducible representation (π,V ). We define a representation Θ of G × G on ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq135.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varTheta \(g_{1},g_{2}\)f\(x\) = f\(g_{2}^{-1}xg_{ 1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equx.gif)

We also have a representation Π of G × G on ![
$$\\mathrm{End}_{\\mathbb{C}}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq136.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varPi \(g_{1},g_{2}\)T = \\pi {\(g_{2}\)}^{-1}T\\,\\pi \(g_{ 1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equy.gif)

Proposition 2.10.

If ![
$$f \\in \\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq137.gif) then so is ![
$$\\varTheta \(g_{1},g_{2}\)\\,f$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq138.gif) . The representations Θ and Π are equivalent.

Proof.

Let L ∈ V ∗ and v ∈ V. Define ![
$$f_{L,v}\(g\) = L\(\\pi \(g\)v\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq139.gif). The map ![
$$L,v\\longmapsto f_{L,v}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq140.gif) is bilinear, hence induces a linear map ![
$$\\sigma: {V }^{{\\ast}}\\otimes V \\longrightarrow \\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq141.gif). It is surjective by the definition of ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq142.gif), and it follows from Proposition 2.4 that if L i and v j run through orthonormal bases, then ![
$$f_{L_{i},v_{j}}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq143.gif) are orthonormal, hence linearly independent. Therefore, σ is a vector space isomorphism. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varTheta \(g_{1},g_{2}\)f_{L,v}\(g\) = L\(g_{2}^{-1}gg_{ 1}v\) = f_{\\hat{\\pi }\(g_{2}\)L,\\pi \(g_{1}\)v}\(x\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equz.gif)

where we recall that ![
$$\(\\hat{\\pi },{V }^{{\\ast}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq144.gif) is the contragredient representation. This means that σ is a G × G-module homomorphism and so ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }\\mathop{\\cong}{V }^{{\\ast}}\\otimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq145.gif) as G × G-modules. On the other hand we also have a bilinear map ![
$${V }^{{\\ast}}\\times V \\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}_{\\mathbb{C}}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq146.gif) that associates with (L,v) the rank-one linear map ![
$$T_{L,v}\(u\) = L\(u\)v$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq147.gif). This induces an isomorphism ![
$${V }^{{\\ast}}\\otimes V \\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}_{\\mathbb{C}}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq148.gif) which is G × G equivariant. We see that ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }\\mathop{\\cong}{V }^{{\\ast}}\\otimes V \\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{End}_{\\mathbb{C}}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq149.gif). □

A function f on G is called a class function if it is constant on conjugacy classes, that is, if it satisfies the equation ![
$$f\(hg{h}^{-1}\) = f\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq150.gif). The character of a representation is a class function since the trace of a linear transformation is unchanged by conjugation.

Proposition 2.11.

If f is the matrix coefficient of an irreducible representation (π,V ), and if f is a class function, then f is a constant multiple of χ π .

Proof.

By Schur's lemma, there is a unique G-invariant vector in ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{\\mathbb{C}}\(V,V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq151.gif); hence. by Proposition 2.10, the same is true of ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq152.gif) in the action of G by conjugation. This matrix coefficient is of course χπ. □

Theorem 2.6.

If f is a matrix coefficient and also a class function, then f is a finite linear combination of characters of irreducible representations.

Proof.

Write ![
$$f =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}f_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq153.gif), where each f i is a class function of a distinct irreducible representation (π i ,V i ). Since f is conjugation-invariant, and since the f i live in spaces ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq154.gif), which are conjugation-invariant and mutually orthogonal, each f i is itself a class function and hence a constant multiple of ![
$$\\chi _{\\pi _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq155.gif) by Proposition 2.11. □

Exercises

Exercise 2.1.

Suppose that G is a compact Abelian group and ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq156.gif) an irreducible representation. Prove that n = 1.

Exercise 2.2.

Suppose that G is compact group and f: G ⟶ ℂ is the matrix coefficient of an irreducible representation π. Show that ![
$$g\\longmapsto \\overline{f\({g}^{-1}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq157.gif) is a matrix coefficient of the same representation π.

Exercise 2.3.

Suppose that G is compact group. Let C(G) be the space of continuous functions on G. If f 1 and f 2 ∈ C(G), define the convolution f 1 ∗ f 2 of f 1 and f 2 by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(f_{1} {\\ast} f_{2}\)\(g\) =\\int _{G}f_{1}\(g{h}^{-1}\)\\,f_{ 2}\(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}h =\\int _{G}f_{1}\(h\)\\,f_{2}\({h}^{-1}g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}h.}$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_Equaa.gif)

(i)

Use the variable change h ⟶ h −1 g to prove the identity of the last two terms. Prove that this operation is associative, and so C(G) is a ring (without unit) with respect to covolution.

(ii)

Let π be an irreducible representation. Show that the space ℳ π of matrix coefficients of π is a 2-sided ideal in C(G), and explain how this fact implies Theorem 2.3.

Exercise 2.4.

Let G be a compact group, and let G × G act on the space ℳ π by left and right translation: ![
$$\(g,h\)f\(x\) = f\({g}^{-1}xh\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq158.gif). Show that ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{\\pi }\\mathop{\\cong}\\hat{\\pi } \\otimes \\pi $$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq159.gif) as (G × G)-modules.

Exercise 2.5.

Let G be a compact group and let g,h ∈ G. Show that g and h are conjugate if and only if χ(g) = χ(h) for every irreducible character χ. Show also that every character is real-valued if and only if every element is conjugate to its inverse.

Exercise 2.6.

Let G be a compact group, and let V,W be irreducible G-modules. An invariant bilinear form B : V × W → ℂ is one that satisfies ![
$$B\\big\(g\\cdot v,g\\cdot w\\big\)=B\(v,w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_2_Chapter_IEq160.gif) for g ∈ G, v ∈ V, w ∈ W. Show that the space of invariant bilinear forms is at most one-dimensional, and is one-dimensional if and only if V and W are contragredient.

# 3. Compact Operators

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq1.gif) is a normed vector space, a linear operator ![
$$T: \\mathfrak{H} \\rightarrow \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq2.gif) is called bounded if there exists a constant C such that ![
$$|Tx| \\leqslant C|x|$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq200.gif) for all ![
$$x \\in \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq3.gif). In this case, the smallest such C is called the operator norm of T, and is denoted |T|.

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq4.gif) is a normed vector space, a linear operator ![
$$T: \\mathfrak{H} \\rightarrow \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq5.gif) is called bounded if there exists a constant C such that |Tx|≤ C|x| for all ![
$$x \\in \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq6.gif). In this case, the smallest such C is called the operator norm of T, and is denoted |T|. The boundedness of the operator T is equivalent to its continuity. If ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq7.gif) is a Hilbert space, then a bounded operator T is self-adjoint if

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle Tf,g\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle f,Tg\\right \\rangle }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equa.gif)

for all ![
$$f,g \\in \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq8.gif). As usual, we call f an eigenvector with eigenvalue λ if f≠0 and Tf = λf. Given λ, the set of eigenvectors with eigenvalue λ (together with 0, which is not an eigenvector) is called the λ-eigenspace. It follows from elementary and well-known arguments that if T is a self-adjoint bounded operator, then its eigenvalues are real, and the eigenspaces corresponding to distinct eigenvalues are orthogonal. Moreover, if ![
$$V \\subset \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is a subspace such that T(V ) ⊂ V, it is easy to see that also ![
$$T\({V }^{\\perp }\) \\subset {V }^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq10.gif).

A bounded operator ![
$$T: \\mathfrak{H} \\rightarrow \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq11.gif) is compact if whenever ![
$$\\{x_{1,}x_{2},x_{3},\\ldots \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq12.gif) is any bounded sequence in ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq13.gif), the sequence ![
$$\\{Tx_{1},Tx_{2},\\ldots \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq14.gif) has a convergent subsequence.

Theorem 3.1 (Spectral theorem for compact operators).

Let T be a compact self-adjoint operator on a Hilbert space ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq15.gif) . Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{N}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq16.gif) be the nullspace of ![
$$T$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq17.gif) . Then the Hilbert space dimension of ![
$${\\mathfrak{N}}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq18.gif) is at most countable. ![
$${\\mathfrak{N}}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq19.gif) has an orthonormal basis ϕ i (i = 1,2,3,...) of eigenvectors of T so that ![
$$T\\phi _{i} = \\lambda _{i}\\phi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq20.gif) . If ![
$${\\mathfrak{N}}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq21.gif) is not finite-dimensional, the eigenvalues λ i → 0 as i → ∞.

Since the eigenvalues λ i → 0, if λ is any nonzero eigenvalue, it follows from this statement that the λ-eigenspace is finite-dimensional.

Proof.

This depends upon the equality

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\vert T\\vert =\\sup _{0\\neq x\\in \\mathfrak{H}} \\frac{\\vert \\left \\langle Tx,x\\right \\rangle \\vert } {\\left \\langle x,x\\right \\rangle }. }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(3.1)

To prove this, let B denote the right-hand side. If ![
$$0\\neq x \\in \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq22.gif),

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert \\left \\langle Tx,x\\right \\rangle \\vert \\leqslant \\vert Tx\\vert \\cdot \\vert x\\vert \\leqslant \\vert T\\vert \\cdot \\vert x{\\vert }^{2} = \\vert T\\vert \\cdot \\left \\langle x,x\\right \\rangle,}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equb.gif)

so ![
$$B \\leqslant |T|$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq101.gif). We must prove the converse. Let λ > 0 be a constant, to be determined later. Using ![
$$\\left \\langle {T}^{2}x,x\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle Tx,Tx\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq23.gif), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & \\left \\langle Tx,Tx\\right \\rangle {}\\\\ & & \\quad = \\tfrac{1} {4}\\left \\vert \\left \\langle T\(\\lambda x + {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\),\\lambda x + {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\\right \\rangle -\\left \\langle T\(\\lambda x - {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\),\\lambda x - {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\\right \\rangle \\right \\vert {}\\\\ & &\\quad \\leqslant \\tfrac{1} {4}\\left \\vert \\left \\langle T\(\\lambda x + {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\),\\lambda x + {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\\right \\rangle \\right \\vert +\\left \\vert \\left \\langle T\(\\lambda x - {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\),\\lambda x - {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\\right \\rangle \\right \\vert {}\\\\ & &\\quad \\leqslant \\tfrac{1} {4}\\left \[B\\left \\langle \\lambda x + {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx,\\lambda x + {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\\right \\rangle + B\\left \\langle \\lambda x - {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx,\\lambda x - {\\lambda }^{-1}Tx\\right \\rangle \\right \] {}\\\\ & & \\quad = \\tfrac{B} {2} \\left \[{\\lambda }^{2}\\left \\langle x,x\\right \\rangle + {\\lambda }^{-2}\\left \\langle Tx,Tx\\right \\rangle \\right \]. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

Now taking ![
$$\\lambda = \\sqrt{\\vert Tx\\vert /\\vert x\\vert }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq24.gif), we obtain

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert Tx{\\vert }^{2} = \\left \\langle Tx,Tx\\right \\rangle \\leqslant B\\vert x\\vert \\vert Tx\\vert,}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equc.gif)

so ![
$$|Tx| \\leqslant B|x|$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq151.gif), which implies that ![
$$|T| \\leqslant B$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq152.gif), whence (3.1).

We now prove that ![
$${\\mathfrak{N}}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq25.gif) has an orthonormal basis consisting of eigenvectors of T. It is an easy consequence of self-adjointness that ![
$${\\mathfrak{N}}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) is T-stable. Let Σ be the set of all orthonormal subsets of ![
$${\\mathfrak{N}}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) whose elements are eigenvectors of T. Ordering Σ by inclusion, Zorn's lemma implies that it has a maximal element S. Let V be the closure of the linear span of S. We must prove that ![
$$V = {\\mathfrak{N}}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq28123.gif). Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{0} = {V }^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq29123.gif). We wish to show ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{0} = \\mathfrak{N}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq30132.gif). It is obvious that ![
$$\\mathfrak{N} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{H}_{0.}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq31123.gif) To prove the opposite inclusion, note that ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) is stable under T, and T induces a compact self-adjoint operator on ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq33123.gif). What we must show is that ![
$$T\\vert \\mathfrak{H}_{0} = 0.$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) If T has a nonzero eigenvector in ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq35.gif), this will contradict the maximality of Σ. It is therefore sufficient to show that a compact self-adjoint operator on a nonzero Hilbert space has an eigenvector.

Replacing ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq36.gif) by ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq37.gif), we are therefore reduced to the easier problem of showing that if T≠0, then T has a nonzero eigenvector. By (3.1), there is a sequence ![
$$x_{1},x_{2},x_{3},\\ldots$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq38.gif) of unit vectors such that ![
$$\\vert \\left \\langle Tx_{i},x_{i}\\right \\rangle \\vert \\rightarrow \\vert T\\vert $$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq39.gif). Observe that if ![
$$x \\in \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq40.gif), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle Tx,x\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle x,Tx\\right \\rangle = \\overline{\\left \\langle Tx,x\\right \\rangle }}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equd.gif)

so the ![
$$\\left \\langle Tx_{i},x_{i}\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq41.gif) are real; we may therefore replace the sequence by a subsequence such that ![
$$\\left \\langle Tx_{i},x_{i}\\right \\rangle \\rightarrow \\lambda $$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq42.gif), where λ = ±|T|. Since T≠0, λ≠0. Since T is compact, there exists a further subsequence ![
$$\\{x_{i}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq43.gif) such that Tx i converges to a vector v. We will show that ![
$$x_{i} \\rightarrow {\\lambda }^{-1}v$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq44.gif).

Observe first that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert \\left \\langle Tx_{i},x_{i}\\right \\rangle \\vert \\leqslant \\vert Tx_{i}\\vert \\vert x_{i}\\vert = \\vert Tx_{i}\\vert \\leqslant \\vert T\\vert \\vert x_{i}\\vert = \\vert \\lambda \\vert,}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Eque.gif)

and since ![
$$\\left \\langle Tx_{i},x_{i}\\right \\rangle \\rightarrow \\lambda $$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq45.gif), it follows that |Tx i |→|λ|. Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert \\lambda x_{i} - Tx_{i}{\\vert }^{2} = \\left \\langle \\lambda x_{ i} - Tx_{i},\\lambda x_{i} - Tx_{i}\\right \\rangle = {\\lambda }^{2}\\vert x_{ i}{\\vert }^{2} + \\vert Tx_{ i}{\\vert }^{2} - 2\\lambda \\left \\langle Tx_{ i},x_{i}\\right \\rangle,}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equf.gif)

and since |x i | = 1, |Tx i |→|λ|, and ![
$$\\left \\langle Tx_{i},x_{i}\\right \\rangle \\rightarrow \\lambda $$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq46.gif), this converges to 0. Since Tx i → v, the sequence λx i therefore also converges to v, and ![
$$x_{i} \\rightarrow {\\lambda }^{-1}v$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq47.gif). Now, by continuity, ![
$$Tx_{i} \\rightarrow {\\lambda }^{-1}\\,Tv$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq48.gif), so ![
$$v = {\\lambda }^{-1}\\,Tv$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq49.gif). This proves that v is an eigenvector with eigenvalue λ. This completes the proof that ![
$${\\mathfrak{N}}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq50.gif) has an orthonormal basis consisting of eigenvectors.

Now let ![
$$\\{\\phi _{i}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq51.gif) be this orthonormal basis and let λ i be the corresponding eigenvalues. If ε > 0 is given, only finitely many ![
$$\\vert \\lambda _{i}\\vert > \\epsilon $$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq52.gif) since otherwise we can find an infinite sequence of ϕ i with |Tϕ i | > ε. Such a sequence will have no convergent subsequence, contradicting the compactness of T. Thus, ![
$${\\mathfrak{N}}^{\\perp }$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq53.gif) is countable-dimensional, and we may arrange the ![
$$\\{\\phi _{i}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq54.gif) in a sequence. If it is infinite, we see the ![
$$\\lambda _{i}\\longrightarrow 0$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq55.gif). □

Proposition 3.1.

Let X and Y be compact topological spaces with Y a metric space with distance function d. Let U be a set of continuous maps ![
$$X\\longrightarrow Y$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq56.gif) such that for every x ∈ X and every ε > 0 there exists a neighborhood N of x such that ![
$$d\\big\(f\(x\),f\(x^{\\prime}\)\\big\) < \\epsilon $$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq57.gif) for all x′ ∈ N and for all f ∈ U. Then every sequence in U has a uniformly convergent subsequence.

We refer to the hypothesis on U as equicontinuity.

Proof.

Let ![
$$S_{0} =\\{ f_{1},f_{2},f_{3},\\ldots \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq58.gif) be a sequence in U. We will show that it has a convergent subsequence. We will construct a subsequence that is uniformly Cauchy and hence has a limit. For every n > 1, we will construct a subsequence ![
$$S_{n} =\\{ f_{n1},f_{n2},f_{n3},\\ldots \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq59.gif) of S n−1 such that ![
$$\\sup _{x\\in X}d\\big\(f_{ni}\(x\),f_{nj}\(x\)\\big\) \\leqslant 1/n$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq60.gif).

Assume that S n−1 is constructed. For each x ∈ X, equicontinuity guarantees the existence of an open neighborhood N x of x such that ![
$$d\\big\(f\(y\),f\(x\)\\big\) \\leqslant \\frac{1} {3n}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq61.gif) for all y ∈ N x and all f ∈ X. Since X is compact, we can cover X by a finite number of these sets, say ![
$$N_{x_{1}},\\ldots,N_{x_{m}}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq62.gif). Since the f n−1,i take values in the compact space Y, the m-tuples ![
$$\\big\(f_{n-1,i}\(x_{1}\),\\ldots,f_{n-1,i}\(x_{m}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq63.gif) have an accumulation point, and we may therefore select the subsequence ![
$$\\{f_{ni}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq64.gif) such that ![
$$d\\big\(f_{ni}\(x_{k}\),f_{nj}\(x_{k}\)\\big\) \\leqslant \\frac{1} {3n}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq65.gif) for all i, j and ![
$$1\\leqslant K \\leqslant m$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq153.gif). Then for any y, there exists x k such that ![
$$y \\in N_{x_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq66.gif) and

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} d\\big\(f_{ni}\(y\),f_{nj}\(y\)\\big\)& \\leqslant & d\\big\(f_{ni}\(y\),f_{ni}\(x_{k}\)\\big\) + d\\big\(f_{ni}\(x_{k}\),f_{nj}\(x_{k}\)\\big\) {}\\\\ & & +d\\big\(f_{nj}\(y\),f_{nj}\(x_{k}\)\\big\) \\leqslant \\tfrac{1} {3n} + \\tfrac{1} {3n} + \\tfrac{1} {3n} = \\tfrac{1} {n}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

This completes the construction of the sequences ![
$$\\{f_{ni}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq67.gif).

The diagonal sequence ![
$$\\{f_{11},f_{22},f_{33},\\ldots \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq68.gif) is uniformly Cauchy. Since Y is a compact metric space, it is complete, and so this sequence is uniformly convergent. □

We topologize C(X) by giving it the L ∞ norm | | ∞ (sup norm).

Proposition 3.2 (Ascoli and Arzela).

Suppose that X is a compact space and that U ⊂ C(X) is a bounded subset such that for each x ∈ X and ε > 0 there is a neighborhood N of x such that ![
$$\\vert f\(x\) - f\(y\)\\vert \\leqslant \\epsilon $$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq69.gif) for all y ∈ N and all f ∈ U. Then every sequence in U has a uniformly convergent subsequence.

Again, the hypothesis on U is called equicontinuity.

Proof.

Since U is bounded, there is a compact interval ![
$$Y \\subset \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq70.gif) such that all functions in U take values in Y. The result follows from Proposition 3.1. □

Exercises

Exercise 3.1.

Suppose that T is a bounded operator on the Hilbert space ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq71.gif), and suppose that for each ε > 0 there exists a compact operator T ε such that ![
$$\\vert T - T_{\\epsilon }\\vert < \\epsilon $$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq72.gif). Show that T is compact. (Use a diagonal argument like the proof of Proposition 3.1.)

Exercise 3.2 (Hilbert–Schmidt operators).

Let X be a locally compact Hausdorff space with a positive Borel measure μ. Assume that L 2(X) has a countable basis. Let ![
$$K \\in {L}^{2}\(X \\times X\)$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq73.gif). Consider the operator on L 2(X) with kernel K defined by

![
$$\\displaystyle{Tf\(x\) =\\int _{X}K\(x,y\)\\,f\(y\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu \(y\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equg.gif)

Let ϕ i be an orthonormal basis of L 2(X). Expand K in a Fourier expansion:

![
$$\\displaystyle{K\(x,y\) =\\sum _{ i=1}^{\\infty }\\psi _{ i}\(x\)\\,\\overline{\\phi _{i}\(y\)},\\psi _{i} = T\\phi _{i}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equh.gif)

Show that ![
$$\\sum \\vert \\psi _{i}{\\vert }^{2} =\\int \\int \\vert K\(x,y\){\\vert }^{2}\\mathrm{d}\\mu \(x\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu \(y\) < \\infty $$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_IEq74.gif). Consider the operator T N with kernel

![
$$\\displaystyle{K_{N}\(x,y\) =\\sum _{ i=1}^{N}\\psi _{ i}\(x\)\\,\\overline{\\phi _{i}\(y\)}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_3_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Show that T N is compact, and deduce that T is compact.
