# 4. The Peter–Weyl Theorem

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In this chapter, we assume that G is a compact group. Let C(G) be the convolution ring of continuous functions on G. It is a ring (without unit unless G is finite) under the multiplication of convolution:

In this chapter, we assume that G is a compact group. Let C(G) be the convolution ring of continuous functions on G. It is a ring (without unit unless G is finite) under the multiplication of convolution:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(f_{1} {\\ast} f_{2}\)\(g\) =\\int _{G}f_{1}\(g{h}^{-1}\)\\,f_{ 2}\(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}h =\\int _{G}f_{1}\(h\)\\,f_{2}\({h}^{-1}g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}h.}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equa.gif)

(Use the variable change ![
$$h\\longrightarrow {h}^{-1}g$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq1.gif) to prove the identity of the last two terms. See Exercise 2.3.) We will sometimes define f 1 ∗ f 2 by this formula even if f 1 and f 2 are not assumed continuous. For example, we will make use of the convolution defined this way if ![
$$f_{1} \\in {L}^{\\infty }\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq2.gif) and ![
$$f_{2} \\in {L}^{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq3.gif), or vice versa.

Since G has total volume 1, we have inequalities (where | | p denotes the L p norm, ![
$$1 \\leqslant p \\leqslant \\infty \)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq4.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\vert f\\vert _{1} \\leqslant \\vert f\\vert _{2} \\leqslant \\vert f\\vert _{\\infty }. }$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(4.1)

The second inequality is trivial, and the first is Cauchy–Schwarz:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert f\\vert _{1} = \\left \\langle \\vert f\\vert,1\\right \\rangle \\leqslant \\vert f\\vert _{2} \\cdot \\vert 1\\vert _{2} = \\vert f\\vert _{2}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equb.gif)

(Here |f| means the function ![
$$\\vert f\\vert \(x\) = \\vert f\(x\)\\vert $$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq5.gif).)

If ϕ ∈ C(G) let T ϕ be left convolution with ϕ. Thus,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(T_{\\phi }f\)\(g\) =\\int _{G}\\phi \(g{h}^{-1}\)\\,f\(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}h.}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equc.gif)

Proposition 4.1.

If ϕ ∈ C(G), then T ϕ is a bounded operator on L 1 (G). If f ∈ L 1 (G), then ![
$$T_{\\phi }f \\in {L}^{\\infty }\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq6.gif) and

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\vert T_{\\phi }f\\vert _{\\infty }\\leqslant \\vert \\phi \\vert _{\\infty }\\vert f\\vert _{1}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(4.2)

Proof.

If f ∈ L 1(G), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert T_{\\phi }f\\vert _{\\infty } =\\sup _{g\\in G}\\Big\\vert \\int _{G}\\phi \\big\(g{h}^{-1}\\big\)\\,f\(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}h\\Big\\vert \\leqslant \\vert \\phi \\vert _{ \\infty }\\int _{G}\\vert f\(h\)\\vert \\,\\mathrm{d}h,}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equd.gif)

proving (4.2). Using (4.1), it follows that the operator T ϕ is bounded. In fact, (4.1) shows that it is bounded in each of the three metrics | |1, | |2, | | ∞. □

Proposition 4.2.

If ![
$$\\phi \\in C\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq7.gif) , then convolution with ϕ is a bounded operator T ϕ on L 2 (G) and ![
$$\\vert T_{\\phi }\\vert \\leqslant \\vert \\phi \\vert _{\\infty }$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq8.gif) . The operator T ϕ is compact, and if ![
$$\\phi \({g}^{-1}\) = \\overline{\\phi \(g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq9.gif) , it is self-adjoint.

Proof.

Using (4.1), ![
$${L}^{\\infty }\(G\) \\subset {L}^{2}\(G\) \\subset {L}^{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq10.gif), and by (4.2), ![
$$\\vert T_{\\phi }f\\vert _{2} \\leqslant \\vert T_{\\phi }f\\vert _{\\infty }\\leqslant \\vert \\phi \\vert _{\\infty }\\vert f\\vert _{1} \\leqslant \\vert \\phi \\vert _{\\infty }\\vert f\\vert _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq11.gif), so the operator norm ![
$$\\vert T_{\\phi }\\vert \\leqslant \\vert \\phi \\vert _{\\infty }$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq12.gif).

By (4.1), the unit ball in L 2(G) is contained in the unit ball in L 1(G), so it is sufficient to show that ![
$$\\mathfrak{B} =\\{ T_{\\phi }f\\vert f \\in {L}^{1}\(G\),\\vert f\\vert _{1} \\leqslant 1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq13.gif) is sequentially compact in L 2(G). Also, by (4.1), it is sufficient to show that it is sequentially compact in L ∞ (G), that is, in C(G), whose topology is induced by the L ∞ (G) norm. It follows from (4.2) that ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq14.gif) is bounded. We show that it is equicontinuous. Since ϕ is continuous and G is compact, ϕ is uniformly continuous. This means that given ε > 0 there is a neighborhood N of the identity such that ![
$$\\vert \\phi \(kg\) - \\phi \(g\)\\vert < \\epsilon $$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq15.gif) for all g when k ∈ N. Now, if f ∈ L 1(G) and |f|1 ≤ 1, we have, for all g,

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\vert \(\\phi {\\ast} f\)\(kg\) - \(\\phi {\\ast} f\)\(g\)\\vert & =& \\Big\\vert \\int _{G}\\left \[\\phi \(kg{h}^{-1}\) - \\phi \(g{h}^{-1}\)\\right \]f\(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}h\\Big\\vert {}\\\\ &\\leqslant & \\int _{G}\\left \\vert \\phi \(kg{h}^{-1}\) - \\phi \(g{h}^{-1}\)\\right \\vert \\vert f\(h\)\\vert \\,\\mathrm{d}h \\leq \\epsilon \\vert f\\vert _{ 1} \\leq \\epsilon. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

This proves equicontinuity, and sequential compactness of ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq16.gif) now follows by the Ascoli–Arzela lemma (Proposition 3.2).

If ![
$$\\phi \({g}^{-1}\) = \\overline{\\phi \(g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq17.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle T_{\\phi }f_{1},f_{2}\\right \\rangle =\\int _{G}\\int _{G}\\phi \(g{h}^{-1}\)\\,f_{ 1}\(h\)\\,\\overline{f_{2}\(g\)}\\,\\mathrm{d}g\\,\\mathrm{d}h}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Eque.gif)

while

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle f_{1},T_{\\phi }f_{2}\\right \\rangle =\\int _{G}\\int _{G}\\overline{\\phi \(h{g}^{-1}\)}\\,f_{1}\(h\)\\,\\overline{f_{2}\(g\)}\\,\\mathrm{d}g\\,\\mathrm{d}h.}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equf.gif)

These are equal, so T is self-adjoint. □

If g ∈ G, let ![
$$\\big\(\\rho \(g\)f\\big\)\(x\) = f\(xg\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq18.gif) be the right translate of f by g.

Proposition 4.3.

If ϕ ∈ C(G), and ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq19.gif) , the λ-eigenspace

![
$$\\displaystyle{V \(\\lambda \) =\\{ f \\in {L}^{2}\(G\)\\,\\vert \\,T_{ \\phi }f = \\lambda f\\}}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equg.gif)

is invariant under ρ(g) for all g ∈ G.

Proof.

Suppose T ϕ f = λf. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\big\(T_{\\phi }\\rho \(g\)f\\big\)\(x\) =\\int _{G}\\phi \(x{h}^{-1}\)\\,f\(hg\)\\,\\mathrm{d}h.}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equh.gif)

After the change of variables ![
$$h\\longrightarrow h{g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq20.gif), this equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}\\phi \(xg{h}^{-1}\)\\,f\(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}h = \\rho \(g\)\(T_{ \\phi }f\)\(x\) = \\lambda \\rho \(g\)f\(x\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equi.gif)

□

Theorem 4.1 (Peter and Weyl).

The matrix coefficients of G are dense in C(G).

Proof.

Let f ∈ C(G). We will prove that there exists a matrix coefficient f′ such that |f − f′| ∞ < ε for any given ε > 0.

Since G is compact, f is uniformly continuous. This means that there exists an open neighborhood U of the identity such that if g ∈ U, then ![
$$\\vert \\lambda \(g\)f - f\\vert _{\\infty } < \\epsilon /2$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq21.gif), where ![
$$\\lambda: G \\rightarrow \\mathrm{End}\\big\(C\(G\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq22.gif) is the action by left translation: ![
$$\(\\lambda \(g\)f\)\(h\) = f\({g}^{-1}h\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq23.gif). Let ϕ be a nonnegative function supported in U such that ![
$$\\int _{G}\\phi \(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq24.gif). We may arrange that ![
$$\\phi \(g\) = \\phi \({g}^{-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq25.gif) so that the operator T ϕ is self-adjoint as well as compact. We claim that ![
$$\\vert T_{\\phi }f - f\\vert _{\\infty } < \\epsilon /2.$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq26.gif) Indeed, if h ∈ G,

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\big\\vert \(\\phi {\\ast} f\)\(h\) - f\(h\)\\big\\vert & =& \\Big\\vert \\int _{G}\\big\[\\phi \(g\)\\,f\({g}^{-1}h\) - \\phi \(g\)f\(h\)\\big\]\\,\\mathrm{d}g\\Big\\vert {}\\\\ & \\leqslant & \\int _{U}\\phi \(g\)\\,\\big\\vert f\({g}^{-1}h\) - f\(h\)\\big\\vert \\,\\mathrm{d}g {}\\\\ & \\leqslant & \\int _{U}\\phi \(g\)\\,\\vert \\lambda \(g\)f - f\\vert _{\\infty }\\,\\mathrm{d}g {}\\\\ & \\leqslant & \\int _{U}\\phi \(g\)\\,\(\\epsilon /2\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g = \\frac{\\epsilon } {2}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

By Proposition 4.1, T ϕ is a compact operator on L 2(G). If λ is an eigenvalue of T ϕ, let V (λ) be the λ-eigenspace. By the spectral theorem, the spaces V (λ) are finite-dimensional [except perhaps V (0)], mutually orthogonal, and they span L 2(G) as a Hilbert space. By Proposition 4.3 they are T ϕ-invariant. Let f λ be the projection of f on V (λ). Orthogonality of the f λ implies that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sum _{\\lambda }\\vert f_{\\lambda }\\vert _{2}^{2} = \\vert f\\vert _{ 2}^{2} < \\infty. }$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(4.3)

Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{f^{\\prime} = T_{\\phi }\(f^{\\prime\\prime}\),\\qquad f^{\\prime\\prime} =\\sum _{\\vert \\lambda \\vert >q}f_{\\lambda }\\;,}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equj.gif)

where q > 0 remains to be chosen. We note that f′ and f″ are both contained in ![
$$\\bigoplus _{\\vert \\lambda \\vert >q}V \(\\lambda \)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq27684.gif), which is a finite-dimensional vector space, and closed under right translation by Proposition 4.3, and by Theorem 2.1, it follows that they are matrix coefficients.

By (4.3), we may choose q so that ![
$$\\sum _{0<q<\\vert \\lambda \\vert }\\vert f_{\\lambda }\\vert _{2}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq28856.gif) is as small as we like. Using (4.1) may thus arrange that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \\vert \\sum _{0<\\vert \\lambda \\vert <q}f_{\\lambda }\\right \\vert _{1} \\leqslant \\left \\vert \\sum _{0<\\vert \\lambda \\vert <q}f_{\\lambda }\\right \\vert _{2} = \\sqrt{\\sum _{0<\\vert \\lambda \\vert <q } \\vert f_{\\lambda } \\vert _{2 }^{2}} < \\frac{\\epsilon } {2\\vert \\phi \\vert _{\\infty }}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(4.4)

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{T_{\\phi }\(f - f^{\\prime\\prime}\) = T_{\\phi }\\left \(f_{0} +\\sum _{0<\\vert \\lambda \\vert <q}f_{\\lambda }\\right \) = T_{\\phi }\\left \(\\sum _{0<\\vert \\lambda \\vert <q}f_{\\lambda }\\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Using (4.2) and (4.4) we have ![
$$\\vert T_{\\phi }\(f - f^{\\prime^\\prime}\)\\vert _{\\infty }\\leqslant \\epsilon /2$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq29585.gif). Now

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\vert f - f^{\\prime}\\vert _{\\infty }& =& \\vert f - T_{\\phi }f + T_{\\phi }\(f - f^{\\prime\\prime}\)\\vert \\leqslant \\vert f - T_{\\phi }f\\vert + \\vert T_{\\phi }f - T_{\\phi }f^{\\prime\\prime}\\vert {}\\\\ &\\leqslant & \\tfrac{\\epsilon } {2} + \\tfrac{\\epsilon } {2} = \\epsilon. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

□

Corollary 4.1.

The matrix coefficients of G are dense in L 2 (G).

Proof.

Since C(G) is dense in L 2(G), this follows from the Peter–Weyl theorem and (4.1). □

We say that a topological group G has no small subgroups if it has a neighborhood U of the identity such that the only subgroup of G contained in U is just ![
$$\\{1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq30685.gif). For example, we will see that Lie groups have no small subgroups. On the other hand, some groups, such as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{Z}_{p}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq31142.gif) where ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}_{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq32685.gif) is the ring of p-adic integers, have a neighborhood basis at the identity consisting of open subgroups. Such a group is called totally disconnected, and for such a group the no small subgroups property fails very strongly.

A representation is called faithful if its kernel is trivial.

Theorem 4.2.

Let G be a compact group that has no small subgroups. Then G has a faithful finite-dimensional representation.

Proof.

Let U be a neighborhood of the identity that contains no subgroup but ![
$$\\{1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq33865.gif). By the Peter–Weyl theorem, we can find a finite-dimensional representation π and a matrix coefficient f such that f(1) = 0 but f(g) > 1 when g∉U. The function f is constant on the kernel of π, so that kernel is contained in U. It follows that the kernel is trivial. □

We will now prove a fact about infinite-dimensional representations of a compact group G. The Peter–Weyl Theorem amounts to a "completeness" of the finite-dimensional representations from the point of view of harmonic analysis. One aspect of this is the L 2 completeness asserted in Corollary 4.1. Another aspect, which we now prove, is that there are no irreducible unitary infinite-dimensional representations. From the point of view of harmonic analysis, these two statements are closely related and are in fact equivalent. Representation theory and Fourier analysis on groups are essentially the same thing.

If H is a Hilbert space, a representation ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq34856.gif) is called unitary if ![
$$\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)v,\\pi \(g\)w\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle v,w\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq35.gif) for all v,w ∈ H, g ∈ G. It is also assumed that the map ![
$$\(g,v\)\\longmapsto \\pi \(g\)v$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq36.gif) from ![
$$G \\times H\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq37.gif) is continuous.

Theorem 4.3 (Peter and Weyl).

Let H be a Hilbert space and G be a compact group. Let ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq38.gif) be a unitary representation. Then H is a direct sum of finite-dimensional irreducible representations.

Proof.

We first show that if H is nonzero then it has an irreducible finite-dimensional invariant subspace. We choose a nonzero vector v ∈ H. Let N be a neighborhood of the identity of G such that if g ∈ N then ![
$$\\vert \\pi \(g\)v - v\\vert \\leqslant \\vert v\\vert /2$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq39.gif). We can find a nonnegative continuous function ϕ on G supported in N such that ![
$$\\int _{G}\\phi \(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq40.gif).

We claim that ![
$$\\int _{G}\\phi \(g\)\\,\\pi \(g\)v\\,\\mathrm{d}g\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq41.gif). This can be proved by taking the inner product with v. Indeed

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \\langle \\int _{G}\\phi \(g\)\\,\\pi \(g\)v\\,\\mathrm{d}g,v\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle v,v\\right \\rangle -\\left \\langle \\int _{N}\\phi \(g\)\\big\(v - \\pi \(g\)v\\big\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g,v\\right \\rangle }$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(4.5)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\Big\\vert \\left \\langle \\int _{N}\\phi \(g\)\\big\(v - \\pi \(g\)v\\big\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g,v\\right \\rangle \\Big\\vert \\leqslant \\int _{N}\\vert v - \\pi \(g\)v\\vert \\mathrm{d}g \\cdot \\vert v\\vert \\leqslant \\vert v{\\vert }^{2}/2.}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equl.gif)

Thus, the two terms in (4.5) differ in absolute value and cannot cancel.

Next, using the Peter–Weyl theorem, we may find a matrix coefficient f such that ![
$$\\vert f - \\phi \\vert _{\\infty } < \\epsilon $$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq42.gif), where ε can be chosen arbitrarily. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\Big\\vert \\int _{G}\(f - \\phi \)\(g\)\\,\\pi \(g\)v\\,\\mathrm{d}g\\Big\\vert \\leqslant \\epsilon \\vert v\\vert \\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equm.gif)

so if ε is sufficiently small we have ![
$$\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\pi \(g\)v\\,\\mathrm{d}g\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq43.gif).

Since f is a matrix coefficient, so is the function ![
$$g\\longmapsto f\({g}^{-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq44.gif) by Proposition 2.4. Thus, let (ρ,W) be a finite-dimensional representation with w ∈ W and ![
$$L: W\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq45.gif) a linear functional such that ![
$$f\({g}^{-1}\) = L\\big\(\\rho \(g\)w\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq46.gif). Define a map ![
$$T: W\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq47.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{T\(x\) =\\int _{G}L\\big\(\\rho \({g}^{-1}\)x\\big\)\\,\\pi \(g\)v\\,\\mathrm{d}g.}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_Equn.gif)

This is an intertwining map by the same argument used to prove (2.​4). It is nonzero since ![
$$T\(w\) =\\int f\(g\)\\,\\pi \(g\)v\\,\\mathrm{d}g\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq48.gif). Since W is finite-dimensional, the image of T is a nonzero finite-dimensional invariant subspace.

We have proven that every nonzero unitary representation of G has a nonzero finite-dimensional invariant subspace, which we may obviously assume to be irreducible. From this we deduce the stated result. Let (π,H) be a unitary representation of G. Let Σ be the set of all sets of orthogonal finite-dimensional irreducible invariant subspaces of H, ordered by inclusion. Thus, if S ∈Σ and U,V ∈ S, then U and V are finite-dimensional irreducible invariant subspaces, If U≠V. then U ⊥ V. By Zorn's lemma, Σ has a maximal element S and we are done if S spans H as a Hilbert space. Otherwise, let H′ be the orthogonal complement of the span of S. By what we have shown, H′ contains an invariant irreducible subspace. We may append this subspace to S, contradicting its maximality. □

Exercises

Exercise 4.1.

Let G be totally disconnected, and let ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq49.gif) be a finite-dimensional representation. Show that the kernel of π is open. (Hint: Use the fact that ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq50.gif) has no small subgroups.) Conclude (in contrast with Theorem 4.2) that the compact group ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{Z}_{p}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq51.gif) has no faithful finite-dimensional representation.

Exercise 4.2.

Suppose that G is a compact Abelian group and ![
$$H \\subset G$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq52.gif) a closed subgroup. Let ![
$$\\chi: H\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq53.gif) be a character. Show that χ can be extended to a character of G. (Hint: Apply Theorem 4.3 to the space ![
$$V =\\{ f \\in {L}^{2}\(G\)\\,\\vert \\,f\(hg\) = \\chi \(h\)\\,f\(g\)\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq54.gif). To show that V is nonzero, note that if ϕ ∈ C(G) then ![
$$f\(g\) =\\int \\phi \(hg\)\\,\\chi {\(h\)}^{-1}\\,\\mathrm{d}h$$
](A79351_2_En_4_Chapter_IEq55.gif) defines an element of V. Use Urysohn's lemma to construct ϕ such that f≠0.)

# 5. Lie Subgroups of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq1.gif)

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

If U is an open subset of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq2.gif), we say that a map ![
$$\\phi: U\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{R}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq3.gif) is smooth if it has continuous partial derivatives of all orders. More generally, if ![
$$X \\subset {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq4.gif) is not necessarily open, we say that a map ![
$$\\phi: X\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq5.gif) is smooth if for each x ∈ X there exists an open set U of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq6.gif) containing ![
$$x$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq7.gif) such that ϕ can be extended to a smooth map on U. A diffeomorphism of ![
$$X \\subseteq {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq8.gif) with ![
$$Y \\subseteq {\\mathbb{R}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is a homeomorphism ![
$$F: X\\longrightarrow Y$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq10.gif) such that both F and F −1 are smooth. We will assume as known the following useful criterion.

If U is an open subset of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq11.gif), we say that a map ![
$$\\phi: U\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{R}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq12.gif) is smooth if it has continuous partial derivatives of all orders. More generally, if ![
$$X \\subset {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq13.gif) is not necessarily open, we say that a map ![
$$\\phi: X\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq14.gif) is smooth if for each x ∈ X there exists an open set U of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq15.gif) containing ![
$$x$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq16.gif) such that ϕ can be extended to a smooth map on U. A diffeomorphism of ![
$$X \\subseteq {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq17.gif) with ![
$$Y \\subseteq {\\mathbb{R}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq18.gif) is a homeomorphism ![
$$F: X\\longrightarrow Y$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq19.gif) such that both F and F −1 are smooth. We will assume as known the following useful criterion.

Inverse Function Theorem. If ![
$$U \\subset {\\mathbb{R}}^{d}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq20.gif) is open and u ∈ U, if ![
$$F: U\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq21.gif) is a smooth map, with d < n, and if the matrix of partial derivatives ![
$$\(\\partial F_{i}/\\partial x_{j}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq22.gif) has rank d at u, then u has a neighborhood N such that F induces a diffeomorphism of N onto its image.

A subset X of a topological space Y is locally closed (in ![
$$Y$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq23.gif)) if for all x ∈ X there exists an open neighborhood U of x in Y such that X ∩ U is closed in U. This is equivalent to saying that X is the intersection of an open set and a closed set. We say that X is a submanifold of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq24.gif) of dimension d if it is a locally closed subset and every point of X has a neighborhood that is diffeomorphic to an open set in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{d}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq25.gif).

Let us identify ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq26856.gif) with the Euclidean space ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{{n}^{2} }\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{R}}^{2{n}^{2} }$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq27652.gif). The subset ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq2838165.gif) is open, and if a closed subgroup ![
$$G$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq29749.gif) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq30785.gif) is a submanifold of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{2{n}^{2} }$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq31746.gif) in this identification, we say that G is a closed Lie subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq32452.gif). It may be shown that any closed subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq33874.gif) is a closed Lie subgroup. See Remarks 7.1 and 7.2 for some subtleties behind the innocent term "closed Lie subgroup."

More generally, a Lie group is a topological group G that is a differentiable manifold such that the multiplication and inverse maps ![
$$G \\times G\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq34658.gif) and ![
$$G\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq35.gif) are smooth. We will give a proper definition of a differentiable manifold in the next chapter. In this chapter, we will restrict ourselves to closed Lie subgroups of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq36.gif).

Example 5.1.

If F is a field, then the general linear group ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq37.gif) is the group of invertible ![
$$n \\times n$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq38.gif) matrices with coefficients in F. It is a Lie group. Assuming that ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq39.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq40.gif), the group ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq41.gif) is an open set in ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq42.gif) and hence a manifold of dimension n 2 if ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq43.gif) or 2n 2 if ![
$$F = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq44.gif). The special linear group is the subgroup ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq45.gif) of matrices with determinant 1. It is a closed Lie subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq46.gif) of dimension n 2 − 1 or 2(n 2 − 1).

Example 5.2.

If ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq47.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq48.gif), let ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n,F\) =\\{ g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n,F\)\\,\\vert \\,g\\, {\\cdot \\,}^{t}g = I\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq49.gif). This is the n × n orthogonal group. More geometrically, ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq50.gif) is the group of linear transformations preserving the quadratic form ![
$$Q\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = x_{1}^{2} + x_{2}^{2} + \\cdots + x_{n}^{2}.$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq51.gif) To see this, if ![
$$\(x\) {= }^{t}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq52.gif) is represented as a column vector, we have ![
$$Q\(x\) = Q\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) {= }^{t}x \\cdot x$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq53.gif), and it is clear that ![
$$Q\(gx\) = Q\(x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq54.gif) if ![
$$g {\\cdot }^{t}g = I$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq55.gif). The group ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq56.gif) is compact and is usually denoted simply ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq57.gif). The group ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq58.gif) contains elements of determinants ± 1. The subgroup of elements of determinant 1 is the special orthogonal group ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq59.gif). The dimension of ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq60.gif) and its subgroup ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq61.gif) of index 2 is ![
$$\\frac{1} {2}\({n}^{2} - n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq62.gif). This will be seen in Proposition 5.6 when we compute their Lie algebra (which is the same for both groups).

Example 5.3.

More generally, over any field, a vector space V on which there is given a quadratic form q is called a quadratic space, and the set ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(V,q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq63.gif) of linear transformations of V preserving q is an orthogonal group. Over the complex numbers, it is not hard to prove that all orthogonal groups are isomorphic (Exercise 5.4), but over the real numbers, some orthogonal groups are not isomorphic to O(n). If ![
$$k + r = n$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq64.gif), let O(k,r) be the subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq65.gif) preserving the indefinite quadratic form ![
$$x_{1}^{2} + \\cdots + x_{k}^{2} - x_{k+1}^{2} -\\cdots - x_{n}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq66.gif). If r = 0, this is O(n), but otherwise this group is noncompact. The dimensions of these Lie groups are, like SO(n), equal to ![
$$\\frac{1} {2}\({n}^{2} - n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq67.gif).

Example 5.4.

The unitary group ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\) =\\{ g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)\\,\\vert \\,g \\cdot \\overline{{}^{t}g} = I\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq68.gif). If g ∈U(n) then |det(g)| = 1, and every complex number of absolute value 1 is a possible determinant of g ∈U(n). The special unitary group ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(n\) = \\mathrm{U}\(n\) \\cap \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq69.gif). The dimensions of U(n) and SU(n) are n 2 and n 2 − 1, just like ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq70.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq71.gif).

Example 5.5.

If ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq72.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq73.gif), let ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n,F\) =\\{ g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(2n,F\)\\,\\vert \\,g \\cdot J {\\cdot \\,}^{t}g = J\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq74.gif), where

![
$$\\displaystyle{J = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 0 & - I_{n} \\\\ I_{n}& 0 \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equa.gif)

This is the symplectic group. The compact group ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\cap \\mathrm{U}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq75.gif) will be denoted as simply Sp(2n).

A Lie algebra over a field F is a vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq76.gif) over F endowed with a bilinear map, the Lie bracket, denoted ![
$$\(X,Y \)\\longrightarrow \[X,Y \]$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq77.gif) for ![
$$X,Y \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq78.gif), that satisfies ![
$$\[X,Y \] = -\[Y,X\]$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq79.gif) and the Jacobi identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \[X,\[Y,Z\]\] + \[Y,\[Z,X\]\] + \[Z,\[X,Y \]\] = 0. }$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(5.1)

The identity ![
$$\[X,Y \] = -\[Y,X\]$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq80.gif) implies that ![
$$\[X,X\] = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq81.gif).

We will show that it is possible to associate a Lie algebra with any Lie group. We will show this for closed Lie subgroups of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq82.gif) in this chapter and for arbitrary lie groups in Chap. .

First we give two purely algebraic examples of Lie algebras.

Example 5.6.

Let A be an associative algebra. Define a bilinear operation on A by ![
$$\[X,Y \] = XY - Y X$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq83.gif). With this definition, A becomes a Lie algebra.

If ![
$$A = \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq84.gif), where F is a field, we will denote the Lie algebra associated with A by the previous example as ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq85.gif). After Proposition 5.5 it will become clear that this is the Lie algebra of GL(n,F) when ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq86.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq87.gif). Similarly, if V is a vector space over F, then the space End(V ) of F-linear transformations ![
$$V \\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq88.gif) is an associative algebra and hence a Lie algebra, denoted ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq89.gif).

Example 5.7.

Let F be a field and let A be an F-algebra. By a derivation of A we mean a map ![
$$D: A\\longrightarrow A$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq90.gif) that is F-linear, and satisfies ![
$$D\(fg\) = fD\(g\) + D\(f\)g$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq91.gif). We have ![
$$D\(1 \\cdot 1\) = 2D\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq92.gif), which implies that D(1) = 0, and therefore D(c) = 0 for any c ∈ F ⊂ A. It is easy to check that if D 1 and D 2 are derivations, then so is ![
$$\[D_{1},D_{2}\] = D_{1}D_{2} - D_{2}D_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq93.gif). However, D 1 D 2 and ![
$$D_{2}D_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq94.gif) are themselves not derivations. It is easy to check that the derivations of A form a Lie algebra.

The exponential map ![
$$\\exp: \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq95.gif) is defined by

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\exp \(X\) = I + X + \\tfrac{1} {2}{X}^{2} + \\tfrac{1} {6}{X}^{3} + \\cdots \\,. }$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(5.2)

This series is convergent for all matrices X.

Remark 5.1.

If X and Y commute, then ![
$$\\exp \(X + Y \) =\\exp \(X\)\\exp \(Y \)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq96.gif). If they do not commute, this is not true.

A one-parameter subgroup of a Lie group G is a continuous homomorphism ![
$$\\mathbb{R}\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq97.gif). We denote this by ![
$$t\\mapsto g_{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq98.gif). Since tX and uX commute, for ![
$$X \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq99.gif), the map ![
$$t\\longrightarrow \\exp \(tX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq100.gif) is a one-parameter subgroup. We will also denote exp(X) = e X .

Proposition 5.1.

Let U be an open subset of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq101.gif) , and let x ∈ U. Then we may find a smooth function f with compact support contained in U that does not vanish at x.

Proof.

We may assume ![
$$x = \(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq102.gif)) is the origin. Define

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cc} {\\mathrm{e}}^{-{\(1-\\vert x{\\vert }^{2}/{r}^{2}\)}^{-1} } & \\quad \\text{if }\\vert x\\vert \\leq r\\,, \\\\ 0 &\\quad \\mathrm{otherwise}. \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equb.gif)

This function is smooth and has support in the ball ![
$$\\{\\vert x\\vert \\leq r\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq103.gif). Taking r sufficiently small, we can make this vanish outside U. □

Proposition 5.2.

Let G be a closed Lie subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq104.gif) , and let ![
$$X \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq105.gif) . Then the path ![
$$t\\longrightarrow \\exp \(tX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq106.gif) is tangent to the submanifold G of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq107.gif) at t = 0 if and only if it is contained in G for all t.

Proof.

If exp(tX) is contained in G for all t, then clearly it is tangent to G at t = 0. We must prove the converse. Suppose that ![
$$\\exp \(t_{0}X\)\\notin G$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq108.gif) for some t 0 > 0. Using Proposition 5.1, Let ϕ0 be a smooth compactly supported function on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq109.gif) such that ϕ0(g) = 0 for all g ∈ G, ϕ0 ≥ 0, and ![
$$\\phi _{0}\\big\(\\exp \(t_{0}X\)\\big\)\\geqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq110.gif). Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(t\) = \\phi \\big\(\\exp \(tX\)\\big\),\\phi \(h\) =\\int _{G}\\phi _{0}\(hg\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g,\\qquad t \\in \\mathbb{R}\\;,}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equc.gif)

in terms of a left Haar measure on G. Clearly, ϕ is constant on the cosets hG of G, vanishes on G, but is nonzero at exp(t 0 X). For any t,

![
$$\\displaystyle{f^{\\prime}\(t\) = \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}u}\\,\\phi \\big\(\\exp \(tX\)\\,\\exp \(uX\)\\big\)\\,\\big\\vert _{u=0} = 0}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equd.gif)

since the path ![
$$u\\longrightarrow \\exp \(tX\)\\exp \(uX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq111.gif) is tangent to the coset exp(tX)G and ϕ is constant on such cosets. Moreover, f(0) = 0. Therefore, f(t) = 0 for all t, which is a contradiction since f(t 0)≠0. □

Proposition 5.3.

Let G be a closed Lie subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq112.gif) . The set Lie(G) of all ![
$$X \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq113.gif) such that exp (tX) ⊂ G is a vector space whose dimension is equal to the dimension of G as a manifold.

Proof.

This is clear from the characterization of Proposition 5.2. □

Proposition 5.4.

Let G be a closed Lie subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq114.gif) . The map

![
$$\\displaystyle{X\\longrightarrow \\exp \(X\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Eque.gif)

gives a diffeomorphism of a neighborhood of the identity in Lie(G) onto a neighborhood of the identity in G.

Proof.

First we note that since ![
$$\\exp \(X\) = I + X + \\frac{1} {2}{X}^{2} + \\cdots \\,$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq115.gif), the Jacobian of exp at the identity is 1, so exp induces a diffeomorphism of an open neighborhood U of the identity in ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq116.gif) onto a neighborhood of the identity in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\) \\subset \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq117.gif). Now, since by Proposition 5.3 Lie(H) is a vector subspace of dimension equal to the dimension of H as a manifold, the Inverse Function Theorem implies that the image of ![
$$\\text{Lie}\(H\) \\cap U$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq118.gif) must be mapped onto an open neighborhood of the identity in H. □

Proposition 5.5.

If G is a closed Lie subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq119.gif) , and if ![
$$X,Y \\in \\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq120.gif) , then [X,Y ] ∈Lie(G).

Proof.

It is evident that Lie(G) is mapped to itself under conjugation by elements of G. Thus, Lie(G) contains

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\tfrac{1} {t} \\left \({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}Y{ \\mathrm{e}}^{-tX} - Y \\right \) = XY - Y X + \\tfrac{t} {2}\({X}^{2}Y - 2XY X + Y {X}^{2}\) + \\cdots \\,.}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Because this is true for all t, passing to the limit ![
$$t\\longrightarrow 0$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq121.gif) shows that ![
$$\[X,Y \] \\in \\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq122.gif). □

We see that Lie(G) is a Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq123.gif). Thus, we are able to associate a Lie algebra with a Lie group.

Example 5.8.

The Lie algebra of GL(n,F) with ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq124.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq125.gif) is ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq126.gif).

Example 5.9.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq127.gif) be the subspace of ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq128.gif) such that tr(X) = 0. This is a Lie subalgebra, and it is the Lie algebra of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq129.gif) when ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq130.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq131.gif). This follows immediately from the fact that ![
$$\\det \({\\mathrm{e}}^{X}\) ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{\\mathrm{tr}\(X\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq132.gif) for any matrix X because if x 1,...,x n are the eigenvalues of X, then ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{x_{1}},\\ldots,{\\mathrm{e}}^{x_{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq133.gif) are the eigenvalues of e X .

Example 5.10.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{o}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq134.gif) be the set of ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq135.gif) that are skew-symmetric, in other words, that satisfy ![
$$X {+ }^{t}X = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq136.gif). It is easy to check that ![
$$\\mathfrak{o}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq137.gif) is closed under the Lie bracket and hence is a Lie subalgebra.

Proposition 5.6.

If ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq138.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq139.gif) , the Lie algebra of O (n,F) is ![
$$\\mathfrak{o}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq140.gif) . The dimension of O (n) is ![
$$\\frac{1} {2}\({n}^{2} - n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq141.gif) , and the dimension of ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq142.gif) is n 2 − n.

Proof.

Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{O}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq143.gif), ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq144.gif). Suppose ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{o}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq145.gif). Exponentiate the identity ![
$$-tX = {t}^{t}X$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq146.gif) to get

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\exp {\(tX\)}^{-1} {= }^{t}\\exp \(tX\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equg.gif)

whence ![
$$\\exp \(tX\) \\in \\mathrm{O}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq147.gif) for all ![
$$t \\in \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq148.gif). Thus, ![
$$\\mathfrak{o}\(n,F\) \\subseteq \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq149.gif). To prove the converse, suppose that ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq150.gif). Then, for all t,

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} I& =& \\exp \(tX\) {\\cdot }^{t}\\exp \(tX\) {}\\\\ & =& \(I + tX + \\tfrac{1} {2}{t}^{2}\\,{X}^{2} + \\cdots \\,\)\(I + {t\\,}^{t}X + \\tfrac{1} {2}\\,{t}^{2} {\\cdot }^{t}{X}^{2} + \\cdots \\,\) {}\\\\ & =& I + t\(X {+ }^{t}X\) + \\tfrac{1} {2}\\,{t}^{2}\({X}^{2} + 2X {\\cdot }^{t}X {+ }^{t}{X}^{2}\) + \\cdots \\,. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equp.gif)

Since this is true for all t, each coefficient in this Taylor series must vanish (except of course the constant one). In particular, ![
$$X {+ }^{t}X = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq151.gif). This proves that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{o}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq152.gif).

The dimensions of O(n) and ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq153.gif) are most easily calculated by computing the dimension of the Lie algebras. A skew-symmetric matrix is determined by its upper triangular entries, and there are ![
$$\\frac{1} {2}\({n}^{2} - n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq154.gif) of these. □

Example 5.11.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq155.gif) be the set of ![
$$X \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq156.gif) such that ![
$$X + \\overline{{}^{t}X} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq157.gif). One checks easily that this is closed under the ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq158.gif) Lie bracket ![
$$\[X,Y \] = XY - Y X$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq159.gif). Despite the fact that these matrices have complex entries, this is a real Lie algebra, for it is only a real vector space, not a complex one. (It is not closed under multiplication by complex scalars.) It may be checked along the lines of Proposition 5.6 that ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq160.gif) is the Lie algebra of U(n), and similarly ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(n\) =\\{ X \\in \\mathfrak{u}\(n\)\\,\\vert \\,\\text{tr}\(X\) = 0\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq161.gif) is the Lie algebra of SU(n).

Example 5.12.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{p}\(2n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq162.gif) be the set of matrices ![
$$X \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{2n}\(F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq163.gif) that satisfy ![
$$XJ + {J\\,}^{t}X = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq164.gif), where

![
$$\\displaystyle{J = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 0 & - I_{n} \\\\ I_{n}& 0 \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equh.gif)

This is the Lie algebra of Sp(2n,F).

Exercises

Exercise 5.1.

Show that O(n,m) is the group of ![

](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq165.gif) such that ![
$$g\\,J{_{1}\\,}^{t}g = J_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq166.gif), where

![
$$\\displaystyle{J_{1} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I_{n}& \\\\ & - I_{ m} \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_Equi.gif)

If ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq167.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq168.gif), let ![
$$\\mathrm{O}_{J}\(F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq169.gif) be the group of all ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(N,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq170.gif) such that g J t g = J, where J is the N × N matrix

Show that ![
$$\\mathrm{O}_{J}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$

$$\\mathrm{GL}\(N, \\mathbb{R}\)$$

Exercise 5.3.

Let J be as in the previous exercise, and let

with all entries not on one of the two diagonals equal to zero. If N is odd, the middle element of this matrix is 1.

Check that ![

](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq183.gif) is conjugate in ![

](A79351_2_En_5_Chapter_IEq184.gif) to O(N).

# 6. Vector Fields

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

A smooth premanifold of dimension n is a Hausdorff topological space M together with a set ![
$$\\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq1.gif) of pairs (U,ϕ), where the set of U such that ![
$$\(U,\\phi \) \\in \\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq2.gif) for some ϕ is an open cover of M and such that, for each ![
$$\(U,\\phi \) \\in \\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq3.gif), the image ϕ(U) of ϕ is an open subset of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq4.gif) and ϕ is a homeomorphism of U onto ϕ(U). We assume that if ![
$$U,V \\in \\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq5.gif), then ![
$$\\phi _{V } \\circ \\phi _{U}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq6.gif) is a diffeomorphism from ![
$$\\phi _{U}\(U \\cap V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq7.gif) onto ![
$$\\phi _{V }\(U \\cap V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq8.gif). The set ![
$$\\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is called a preatlas.

A smooth premanifold of dimension n is a Hausdorff topological space M together with a set ![
$$\\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq10.gif) of pairs (U,ϕ), where the set of U such that ![
$$\(U,\\phi \) \\in \\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq11.gif) for some ϕ is an open cover of M and such that, for each ![
$$\(U,\\phi \) \\in \\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq12.gif), the image ϕ(U) of ϕ is an open subset of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq13.gif) and ϕ is a homeomorphism of U onto ϕ(U). We assume that if ![
$$U,V \\in \\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq14.gif), then ![
$$\\phi _{V } \\circ \\phi _{U}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq15.gif) is a diffeomorphism from ![
$$\\phi _{U}\(U \\cap V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq16.gif) onto ![
$$\\phi _{V }\(U \\cap V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq17.gif). The set ![
$$\\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq18.gif) is called a preatlas.

If M and N are premanifolds, a continuous map f: M ⟶ N is smooth if whenever (U,ϕ) and (V,ψ) are charts of M and N, respectively, the map ψ ∘ f ∘ ϕ−1 is a smooth map from ![
$$\\phi \\big\(U \\cap {f}^{-1}\(V \)\\big\)\\longrightarrow \\psi \(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq19.gif). Smooth maps are the morphisms in the category of smooth premanifolds. The smooth map f is a diffeomorphism if it is a bijection and has a smooth inverse. Open subsets of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq20.gif) are naturally premanifolds, and the definitions of smooth maps and diffeomorphisms are consistent with the definitions already given in that special case.

If M is a premanifold with preatlas ![
$$\\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq21.gif), and if we replace ![
$$\\mathcal{U}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq22.gif) by the larger set ![
$$\\mathcal{U}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq23.gif) of all pairs (U,ϕ), where U is an open subset of M and ϕ is a diffeomorphism of U onto an open subset of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq24.gif), then the set of smooth maps M ⟶ N or N ⟶ M, where N is another premanifold, is unchanged. If ![
$$\\mathcal{U} = \\mathcal{U}{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq25.gif), then we call ![
$$\\mathcal{U}{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq26856.gif) an atlas and M a smooth manifold.

Suppose that M is a smooth manifold and m ∈ M. If U is a neighborhood of x and (ϕ,U) is a chart such that ϕ(x) is the origin in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq27856.gif), then we may write ![
$$\\phi \(u\) =\\big \(x_{1}\(u\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(u\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq28846.gif), where ![
$$x_{1},\\ldots,x_{m}: U\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq29861.gif) are smooth functions. Composing ϕ with a translation in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq30513.gif), we may arrange that x i (m) = 0, and it is often advantageous to do so. We call x 1,...,x m a set of local coordinates at m or coordinate functions on U. The set U itself may be called a coordinate neighborhood.

Let m ∈ M, and let ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq31365.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq32359.gif). A germ of an F-valued function is an equivalence class of pairs (U,f U ), where U is an open neighborhood of x and f: U ⟶ F is a function. The equivalence relation is that (U,f U ) and (V,f V ) are equivalent if f U and f V are equal on some open neighborhood W of x contained in ![
$$U \\cap V$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq33741.gif). Let ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq34365.gif) be the set of germs of smooth real-valued functions. It is a ring in an obvious way, and evaluation at m induces a surjective homomorphism ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{m}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq35.gif), the evaluation map. We will denote the evaluation map ![
$$f\\mapsto f\(m\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq36.gif), a slight abuse of notation since f is a germ, not a function. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq37.gif) be the kernel of this homomorphism; that is, the ideal of germs of smooth functions vanishing at m. Then ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq38.gif) is a local ring and ![
$$\\mathcal{M}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq39.gif) is its maximal ideal.

Lemma 6.1.

Suppose that f is a smooth function on a neighborhood U of the origin in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq40.gif) , and f(0,x 2 ,...,x n ) = 0 for (0,x 2 ,...,x n ) ∈ U. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{g\(x_{1},x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} x_{1}^{-1}f\(x_{1,}\\ldots,x_{n}\) &\\mbox{ if $x_{1}\\neq 0$,} \\\\ \(\\partial f/\\partial x_{1}\)\(0,x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\)&\\mbox{ if $x_{1} = 0$,} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equa.gif)

defines a smooth function on U.

Proof.

We show first that g is continuous. Indeed, with x 2,...,x n fixed,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\lim _{x_{1}\\rightarrow 0}x_{1}^{-1}f\(x_{ 1,}\\ldots,x_{n}\) = \(\\partial f/\\partial x_{1}\)\(0,x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equb.gif)

by the definition of the derivative. Convergence is uniform on compact sets in x 2,...,x n since by the remainder form of Taylor's theorem

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\big\\vert x_{1}^{-1}f\(x_{ 1,}\\ldots,x_{n}\) - \(\\partial f/\\partial x_{1}\)\(0,x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\)\\big\\vert \\leqslant \\tfrac{B} {2} \\,x_{1},}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equc.gif)

where B is an upper bound for ![
$$\\vert {\\partial }^{2}f/\\partial x_{1}\\vert $$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq41.gif). Since ![
$$\\partial f/\\partial x_{1}\(0,x_{2,}\\ldots,x_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq42.gif) is continuous by the smoothness of f, it follows that g is continuous.

A similar argument based on Taylor's theorem shows that the higher partial derivatives ![
$${\\partial }^{n}g/\\partial x_{1}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq43.gif) are also continuous.

Finally, the two functions

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{{\\partial }^{k_{2}+\\cdots +k_{n}}f} {\\partial x_{2}^{k_{2}}\\cdots \\partial x_{n}^{k_{n}}}\\quad \\mathrm{and}\\quad \\frac{{\\partial }^{k_{2}+\\cdots +k_{n}}g} {\\partial x_{2}^{k_{2}}\\cdots \\partial x_{n}^{k_{n}}}}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equd.gif)

bear the same relationship to each other as f and g, so we obtain similarly continuity of the mixed partials ![
$${\\partial }^{k_{1}+k_{2}+\\cdots +k_{n}}g/\\partial x_{1}^{k_{1}}\\partial x_{2}^{k_{2}}\\cdots \\partial x_{n}^{k_{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq44.gif). □

Proposition 6.1.

Let m ∈ M, where M is a smooth manifold of dimension n. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{O} = \\mathcal{O}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq45.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{M} = \\mathcal{M}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq46.gif) . Let x 1 ,...,x n be the germs of a set of local coordinates at m. Then x 1 ,...,x n generate the ideal ![
$$\\mathcal{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq47.gif). Moreover, ![
$$\\mathcal{M}/{\\mathcal{M}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq48.gif) is a vector space of dimension n generated by the images of x 1 ,...,x n .

Proof.

Although this is really a statement about germs of functions, we will work with representative functions defined in some neighborhood of m.

If ![
$$f \\in \\mathcal{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq49.gif), we write ![
$$f = f_{1} + f_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq50.gif), where ![
$$f_{1}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = f\(0,x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq51.gif) and ![
$$f_{2} = f - f_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq52.gif). Then ![
$$f_{2} \\in x_{1}\\mathcal{O}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq53.gif) by Lemma 6.1, while f 1 is the germ of a function in x 2,...,x n vanishing at m and lies in ![
$$x_{2}\\mathcal{O} + \\cdots + x_{n}\\mathcal{O}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq54.gif) by induction on n.

As for the last assertion, if ![
$$f \\in \\mathcal{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq55.gif), let ![
$$a_{i} = \(\\partial f/\\partial x_{i}\)\(m\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq56.gif). Then ![
$$f -\\sum _{i}a_{i}x_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq57.gif) vanishes to order 2 at m. We need to show that it lies in ![
$${\\mathcal{M}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq58.gif). Thus, what we must prove is that if f and ![
$$\\partial f/\\partial x_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq59.gif) vanish at m, then f is in ![
$${\\mathcal{M}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq60.gif). To prove this, write ![
$$f = f_{1} + f_{2} + f_{3}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq61.gif), where

![
$$\\displaystyle{f_{1}\(x_{1},x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = f\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) - f\(0,x_{2,}\\ldots,x_{n}\) - x_{1} \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{1}}\(0,x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Eque.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{f_{2}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = f\(0,x_{2,}\\ldots,x_{n}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equf.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{f_{3}\(x_{1},x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = x_{1} \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{1}}\(0,x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equg.gif)

Two applications of Lemma 6.1 show that ![
$$f_{1} = x_{1}^{-2}h$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq62.gif) where h is smooth, so ![
$$f_{1} \\in {\\mathcal{M}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq63.gif). The function f 2 also vanishes, with its first-order partial derivatives at m, but is a function in one fewer variables, so by induction it is in ![
$${\\mathcal{M}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq64.gif). Lastly, ![
$$\\partial f/\\partial x_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq65.gif) vanishes at m and hence is in ![
$$\\mathcal{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq66.gif) by the part of this proposition that is already proved, so multiplying by x 1 gives an element of ![
$${\\mathcal{M}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq67.gif). □

A local derivation of ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq68.gif) is a map ![
$$X: \\mathcal{O}_{m}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq69.gif) that is ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq70.gif)-linear and such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mbox{ $X\(fg\) = f\(m\)X\(g\) + g\(m\)X\(f\)$.} }$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(6.1)

Taking ![
$$f = g = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq71.gif) gives X(1 ⋅ 1) = 2X(1) so X annihilates constant functions.

For example, if x 1,...,x n are a set of local coordinates and ![
$$a_{1},\\ldots,a_{n} \\in \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq72.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ Xf =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}a_{ i} \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{i}}\(m\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(6.2)

is a local derivation.

Proposition 6.2.

Let m be a point on an n-dimensional smooth manifold M. Every local derivation of ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq73.gif) is of the form (6.2). The set T m (M) of such local derivations is an n-dimensional real vector space.

Proof.

If f and g both vanish at m, then (6.1) implies that a local derivation X vanishes on ![
$${\\mathcal{M}}^{2},$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq74.gif) and by Proposition 6.1 it is therefore determined by its values on x 1,...,x n . If these are a 1,...,a n , then X agrees with the right-hand side of (6.2). □

We now define the tangent space T m (M) to be the space of local derivations of ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq75.gif). We will call elements of T m (M) tangent vectors. Thus, a tangent vector at m is the same thing as a local derivation of the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq76.gif).

This definition of tangent vector and tangent space has the advantage that it is intrinsic. Proposition 6.2 allows us to relate this definition to the intuitive notion of a tangent vector. Intuitively, a tangent vector should be an equivalence class of paths through m: two paths are equivalent if they are tangent. By a path we mean a smooth map u: (−ε,ε)⟶ M such that u(0) = m for some ε > 0. Given a function, or the germ of a function at m, we can use the path to define a local derivation

![
$$\\displaystyle{ Xf = \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\\big\(u\(t\)\\big\)\\Big\\vert _{t=0}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(6.3)

Using the chain rule, this equals (6.2) with ![
$$a_{i} = \(\\mathrm{d}/\\mathrm{d}t\)\\big\(x_{i}\(u\(t\)\)\\big\)\\big\\vert _{t=0}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq77.gif).

Let M and N be smooth manifolds with a smooth map f: M → N. Let m ∈ M and n ∈ N such that f(m) = n. Then we have a map ![
$$\\mathrm{d}f: T_{m}\(M\) \\rightarrow T_{n}\(N\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq78.gif) defined as follows. Note that f induces a map from ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{n}\(N\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq79.gif) to ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{m}\(M\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq80.gif). Now X ∈ T m (M) then X is a local derivation of ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{m}\(M\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq81.gif), and composition with f produces a local derivation of ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{n}\(N\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq82.gif). This is the tangent vector we will denote df(X). The map df: T m (M) → T n (N) is called the differential of f.

We will use the notation

![
$$\\displaystyle{X =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}a_{ i} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}}}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equh.gif)

to denote the element (6.2) of T m (M). By a vector field X on M we mean a rule that assigns to each point m ∈ M an element X m ∈ T m (M). The assignment m ⟶ X m must be smooth. This means that if x 1,...,x n are local coordinates on an open set U ⊆ M, then there exist smooth functions a 1,...,a n on U such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ X_{m} =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}a_{ i}\(m\)\\, \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(6.4)

It follows from the chain rule that this definition is independent of the choice of local coordinates x i .

Now let ![
$$A = {C}^{\\infty }\(M, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq83.gif) be the ring of smooth real-valued functions on M. Given a vector field X on M, we may obtain a derivation of A as follows. If f ∈ A, let X(f) be the smooth function that assigns to m ∈ M the value X m (f), where we are of course applying X m to the germ of f at m. For example, if M = U is an open set on ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq84.gif) with coordinate functions x 1,...,x n on U, given smooth functions ![
$$a_{i}: U\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq85.gif), we may associate a derivation of A with the vector field (6.4) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(Xf\)\(m\) =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}a_{ i}\(m\)\\, \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{i}}\(m\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(6.5)

The content of the next theorem is that every derivation of A is associated with a vector field in this way.

Proposition 6.3.

There is a one-to-one correspondence between vector fields on a smooth manifold M and derivations of ![
$${C}^{\\infty }\(M, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq86.gif) . Specifically, if D is any derivation of ![
$${C}^{\\infty }\(M, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq87.gif) , there is a unique vector field X on M such that Df = Xf for all f.

Proof.

We show first that if m ∈ M, and if ![
$$f \\in A = {C}^{\\infty }\(M, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq88.gif) has germ zero at m, then the function Df vanishes at m. This implies that D induces a well-defined map ![
$$X_{m}: \\mathcal{O}_{m}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq89.gif) that is a local derivation. Our assumption means that f vanishes in a neighborhood of m, so there is another smooth function g such that gf = f, yet g(m) = 0. Now ![
$$D\(f\)\(m\) = g\(m\)\\,D\(f\) + f\(m\)\\,D\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq90.gif). Since both f and g vanish at m, we see that D(f)(m) = 0.

Now let x i be local coordinates on an open set U of M. For each m ∈ U there are real numbers a i (m) such that (6.4) is true. We need to know that the a i (m) are smooth functions. Indeed, we have a i (m) = D(x i ), so it is smooth. □

Now let X and Y be vector fields on M. By Proposition 6.3, we may regard these as derivations of ![
$${C}^{\\infty }\(M, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq91.gif). As we have noted in Example 5.7, derivations of an arbitrary ring form a Lie algebra. Thus ![
$$\[X,Y \] = XY - Y X$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq92.gif) defines a derivation:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \[X,Y \]f = X\(Y f\) - Y \(Xf\)\\;. }$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(6.6)

By Proposition 6.3 this derivation [X,Y ] corresponds to a vector field. Let us see this again concretely by computing its effect in local coordinates. If ![
$$X =\\sum a_{i} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq93.gif) and ![
$$Y =\\sum b_{i} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq94.gif), we have ![
$$X\(Y f\) =\\sum _{i,j}\\left \[a_{j} \\frac{\\partial b_{i}} {\\partial x_{j}} \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{i}} + a_{i}b_{j} \\frac{{\\partial }^{2}f} {\\partial x_{i}\\partial x_{j}}\\right \]$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq95.gif). This is not a derivation, but if we subtract Y (Xf) to cancel the unwanted mixed partials, we see that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\[X,Y \] =\\sum _{i,j}\\left \[a_{j} \\frac{\\partial b_{i}} {\\partial x_{j}} - b_{j} \\frac{\\partial a_{i}} {\\partial x_{j}}\\right \] \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Exercises

The following exercise requires some knowledge of topology.

Exercise 6.1.

Let X be a vector field on the sphere S k . Assume that X is nowhere zero, i.e., X m ≠0 for all m ∈ S k . Show that the antipodal map a: S k ⟶ S k and the identity map S k ⟶ S k are homotopic. Deduce that k is odd.

Hint: Normalize the vector field so that X m is a unit tangent vector for all m. If m ∈ S k consider the great circle θ m : [0, 2π]⟶ S k tangent to X m . Then ![
$$\\theta _{m}\(0\) = \\theta _{m}\(2\\pi \) = m$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq96.gif), but ![
$$m\\longmapsto \\theta _{m}\(\\pi \)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq97.gif) is the antipodal map. Also, think about the effect of the antipodal map on ![
$${H}^{k}\({S}^{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_6_Chapter_IEq98.gif).

# 7. Left-Invariant Vector Fields

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

To recapitulate, a Lie group is a differentiable manifold with a group structure in which the multiplication and inversion maps G × G ⟶ G and G ⟶ G are smooth. A homomorphism of Lie groups is a group homomorphism that is also a smooth map.

To recapitulate, a Lie group is a differentiable manifold with a group structure in which the multiplication and inversion maps G × G ⟶ G and G ⟶ G are smooth. A homomorphism of Lie groups is a group homomorphism that is also a smooth map.

Remark 7.1.

There is a subtlety in the definition of a Lie subgroup. A Lie subgroup of G is best defined as a Lie group H with an injective homomorphism i: H ⟶ G. With this definition, the image of i in G is not closed, however, as the following example shows. Let G be ![
$$\\mathbb{T} \\times \\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq1.gif), where ![
$$\\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq2.gif) is the circle ![
$$\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq3.gif). Let H be ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq4.gif), and let i: H ⟶ G be the map i(t) = (αt,βt) modulo 1, where the ratio α∕β is irrational. This is a Lie subgroup, but the image of H is not closed. To require a closed image in the definition of a Lie subgroup would invalidate a theorem of Chevalley that subalgebras of the Lie algebra of a Lie group correspond to Lie subgroups. If we wish to exclude this type of example, we will explicitly describe a Lie subgroup of G as a closed Lie subgroup.

Remark 7.2.

On the other hand, in the expression "closed Lie subgroup," the term "Lie" is redundant. It may be shown that a closed subgroup of a Lie group is a submanifold and hence a Lie group. See Bröcker and Tom Dieck [25], Theorem 3.11 on p. 28; Knapp [106] Chap. I Sect. 4; or Knapp [105], Theorem 1.5 on p. 20. We will only prove this for the special case of an abelian subgroup in Theorem 15.2 below.

Suppose that M and N are smooth manifolds and ϕ: M ⟶ N is a smooth map. As we explained in Chap.​ 6, if m ∈ M and n = ϕ(m), we get a map dϕ: T m (M) ⟶ T n (N), called the differential of f. If ϕ is a diffeomorphism of M onto N, then we can push a vector field X on M forward this way to obtain a vector field on N. This vector field may be denoted ϕ∗ X, defined by (ϕ∗ X) n = dϕ(X m ) when f(m) = n. If ϕ is not a diffeomorphism, this may not work because some points in N may not even be in the image of ϕ, while others may be in the image of two different points m 1 and m 2 with no guarantee that ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\phi X_{m_{1}} = \\mathrm{d}\\phi X_{m_{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq5.gif).

Now let G be a Lie group. If g ∈ G, then L g : G ⟶ G defined by L g (h) = gh is a diffeomorphism and hence induces maps ![
$$L_{g,{\\ast}}: T_{h}\(G\)\\longrightarrow T_{gh}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq6.gif). A vector field X on G is left-invariant if ![
$$L_{g,{\\ast}}\(X_{h}\) = X_{gh}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq7.gif).

Proposition 7.1.

The vector space of left-invariant vector fields is closed under [ , ] and is a Lie algebra of dimension ![
$$\\dim \(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq8.gif) . If ![
$$X_{e} \\in T_{e}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq9.gif) , there is a unique left-invariant vector field X on G with the prescribed tangent vector at the identity.

Proof.

Given a tangent vector X e at the identity element e of G, we may define a left-invariant vector field by ![
$$X_{g} = L_{g,{\\ast}}\(X_{e}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq10.gif), and conversely any left-invariant vector field must satisfy this identity, so the space of left-invariant vector fields is isomorphic to the tangent space of G at the identity. Therefore, its vector space dimension equals the dimension of G. □

Let Lie(G) be the vector space of left-invariant vector fields, which we may identify with the T e (G). It is clearly closed under [ , ].

Suppose now that ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq11.gif). We have defined two different Lie algebras for G: first, in Chap.​ 5, we defined the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq12.gif) of G to be ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq13.gif) with the commutation relation ![
$$\[X,Y \] = XY - Y X$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq14.gif) (matrix multiplication); and second, we have defined the Lie algebra to be the Lie algebra of left-invariant vector fields with the bracket (6.​6). We want to see that these two definitions are the same. We will accomplish this in Proposition 7.2 below.

If ![
$$X \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq15.gif), we begin by associating with X a left-invariant vector field. Since G is an open subset of the real vector space ![
$$V = \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq16.gif), we may identify the tangent space to G at the identity with V. With this identification, an element X ∈ V is the local derivation at I see ([6.​3)] defined by

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\\longmapsto \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\(I + tX\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{t=0}\\;,}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equa.gif)

where f is the germ of a smooth function at I. The two paths t ⟶ I \+ tX and ![
$$t\\longrightarrow \\exp \(tX\) = I + tX + \\cdots $$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq17.gif) are tangent when t = 0, so this is the same as

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\\longrightarrow \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\\big\(\\exp \(tX\)\\big\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{t=0}\\;,}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equb.gif)

which is a better definition. Indeed, if H is a Lie subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq18.gif) and X is in the Lie algebra of H, then by Proposition 5.2, the second path exp(tX) stays within H, so this definition still makes sense.

It is clear how to extrapolate this local derivation to a left-invariant global derivation of ![
$${C}^{\\infty }\(G, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq19.gif). We must define

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(\\mathrm{d}X\)f\(g\) = \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\\big\(g\\exp \(tX\)\\big\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{t=0}\\;. }$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(7.1)

By Proposition 2.8, the left-invariant derivation dX of ![
$${C}^{\\infty }\(G, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq20.gif) corresponds to a left-invariant vector field. To distinguish this derivation from the element X of ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq21.gif), we will resist the temptation to denote this derivation also as X and denote it by dX.

Lemma 7.1.

Let f be a smooth map from a neighborhood of the origin in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq22.gif) into a finite-dimensional vector space. We may write

![
$$\\displaystyle{ f\(x\) = c_{0} + c_{1}\(x\) + B\(x,x\) + r\(x\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(7.2)

where ![
$$c_{1}: {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}\\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq23.gif) is linear, ![
$$B: {\\mathbb{R}}^{n} \\times {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}\\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq24.gif) is symmetric and bilinear, and r vanishes to order 3.

Proof.

This is just the familiar Taylor expansion. Denoting u = (u 1,...,u n ), let c 0 = f(0),

![
$$\\displaystyle{c_{1}\(u\) =\\sum _{i} \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{i}}\(0\)\\,u_{i},}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equc.gif)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{B\(u,v\) = \\frac{1} {2}\\sum _{i,j} \\frac{{\\partial }^{2}f} {\\partial x_{i}\\partial x_{j}}\(0\)\\,u_{i}v_{j}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equd.gif)

Both f(x) and ![
$$c_{0} + c_{1}\(x\) + B\(x,x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq25.gif) have the same partial derivatives of order ![
$$\\leq 2$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq26856.gif), so the difference r(x) vanishes to order 3. The fact that B is symmetric follows from the equality of mixed partials:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{{\\partial }^{2}f} {\\partial x_{i}\\partial x_{j}}\(0\) = \\frac{{\\partial }^{2}f} {\\partial x_{j}\\partial x_{i}}\(0\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Eque.gif)

□

Proposition 7.2.

If X, ![
$$Y \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq27965.gif) , and if f is a smooth function on ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq28365.gif) , then ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\[X,Y \]f = \\mathrm{d}X\(\\mathrm{d}Y f\) -\\mathrm{d}Y \(\\mathrm{d}Xf\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq29358.gif).

Here X,Y ] means XY − YX computed using matrix operations; that is, the bracket computed as in [Chap.​ 5. This proposition shows that if ![
$$X \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq30365.gif), and if we associate with X a derivation of ![
$${C}^{\\infty }\(G, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq31684.gif), where ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq323585.gif), using the formula (7.1), then this bracket operation gives the same result as the bracket operation (6.​6) for left-invariant vector fields.

Proof.

We fix a function f ∈ C ∞ (G) and an element g ∈ G. By Lemma 7.1, we may write, for X near 0,

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\\big\(g\(I + X\)\\big\) = c_{0} + c_{1}\(X\) + B\(X,X\) + r\(X\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equf.gif)

where c 1 is linear in X, B is symmetric and bilinear, and r vanishes to order 3 at X = 0. We will show that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(\\mathrm{d}X\\,f\)\(g\) = c_{1}\(X\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(7.3)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(\\mathrm{d}X \\circ \\mathrm{d}Y \\,f\)\(g\) = c_{1}\(XY \) + 2B\(X,Y \). }$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(7.4)

Indeed,

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \(\\mathrm{d}X\\,f\)\(g\)& =& \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}\\,f\\big\(g\(I + tX\)\\big\)\\vert _{t=0} {}\\\\ & =& \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}\\,\\big\(c_{0} + c_{1}\(tX\) + B\(tX,tX\) + r\(tX\)\\big\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{t=0}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

We may ignore the B and r terms because they vanish to order ≥ 2, and since c 1 is linear, this is just c 1(X) proving (7.3). Also

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \(\\mathrm{d}X \\circ \\mathrm{d}Y f\)\(g\)& =& \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}\\,\\big\(\(\\mathrm{d}Y \\,f\)\\big\(g\(I + tX\)\\big\)\\;\\Big\\vert _{u=0} {}\\\\ & =& \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial t}\\, \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial u}\\,f\\big\(g\(I + tX\)\(I + uY \)\\big\)\\;\\Big\\vert _{t=u=0} {}\\\\ & =& \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial t}\\, \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial u}\[c_{0} + c_{1}\(tX + uY + tuXY \) {}\\\\ & & +B\(tX + uY + tuXY,tX + uY + tuXY \) {}\\\\ & & +r\(tX + uY + tuXY \)\]\\;\\vert _{t=u=0}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

We may omit r from this computation since it vanishes to third order. Expanding the linear and bilinear maps c 1 and B, we obtain (7.4).

Similarly,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(\\mathrm{d}Y \\circ \\mathrm{d}Xf\)\(g\) = c_{1}\(Y X\) + 2B\(X,Y \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equg.gif)

Subtracting this from (7.4) to kill the unwanted B term, we obtain

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\big\(\(\\mathrm{d}X \\circ \\mathrm{d}Y -\\mathrm{d}Y \\circ \\mathrm{d}X\)\\,f\\big\)\(g\) = c_{1}\(XY - Y X\) = \\left \(\\mathrm{d}\[X,Y \]\\,f\\right \)\(g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equh.gif)

by (7.3). □

If ϕ: G ⟶ H is a homomorphism of Lie groups, there is an induced map of Lie algebras, as we will now explain. Let X be a left-invariant vector field on G. We have induced a map dϕ: T e (G) ⟶ T e (H), and by Proposition 7.1 applied to H there is a unique left-invariant vector field Y on H such that dϕ(X e ) = Y e . It is easy to see that for any g ∈ G we have ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\phi \(X_{g}\) = Y _{\\phi \(g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq33415.gif). We regard Y as an element of Lie(H), and ![
$$X\\longmapsto Y$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq34956.gif) is a map Lie(G) ⟶ Lie(H), which we denote Lie(ϕ) or, more simply, dϕ. The Lie algebra homomorphism dϕ = Lie(ϕ) is called the differential of ϕ. A map ![
$$f: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq35.gif) of Lie algebras is naturally called a homomorphism if f([X,Y ]) = [f(X),f(Y )].

Proposition 7.3.

If ϕ: G ⟶ H is a Lie group homomorphism, then Lie (ϕ): Lie (G) ⟶ Lie (H) is a Lie algebra homomorphism.

Proof.

If X,Y ∈ G, then X e and Y e are local derivations of ![
$$\\mathcal{O}_{e}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq36.gif), and it is clear from the definitions that ϕ∗([X e ,Y e ]) = [ϕ∗(X e ),ϕ∗(Y e )]. Consequently, [Lie(ϕ)X,Lie(ϕ)Y ] and Lie(ϕ)([X,Y ]) are left-invariant vector fields on H that agree at the identity, so they are the same by Proposition 7.1. □

We may ask to what extent the Lie algebra homomorphism Lie(ϕ) contains complete information about ϕ. For example, given Lie groups G and H with Lie algebras ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq37.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq38.gif), and a homomorphism ![
$$f: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq39.gif), is there a homomorphism G ⟶ H with Lie(ϕ) = f?

In general, the answer is no, as the following example will show.

Example 7.1.

Let H = SU(2) and let G = SO(3). H acts on the three-dimensional space V of Hermitian matrices ![
$$\\xi = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} x &y + iz\\\\ y - iz & - x \\end{array} \\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq40.gif) of trace zero by ![
$$h: \\xi \\mapsto h\\xi {h}^{-1} = h\\xi \\overline{{}^{t}h}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq41.gif), and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\xi \\mapsto -\\det \(\\xi \) = {x}^{2} + {y}^{2} + {z}^{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_Equi.gif)

is an invariant positive definite quadratic form on V invariant under this action. Thus, the transformation ![
$$\\xi \\mapsto h\\xi {h}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq42.gif) of V is orthogonal, and we have a homomorphism ψ: SU(2) ⟶ SO(3). Both groups are three-dimensional, and ψ is a local homeomorphism at the identity. The differential ![
$$\\mathrm{Lie}\(\\psi \): \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(2\)\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{o}\(3\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq43.gif) is therefore an isomorphism and has an inverse, which is a Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{o}\(3\)\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq44.gif). However, ψ itself does not have an inverse since it has a nontrivial element in its kernel, − I. Therefore, ![
$$\\mathrm{Lie}{\(\\psi \)}^{-1}: \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{o}\(3\)\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq45.gif) is an example of a Lie algebra homomorphism that does not correspond to a Lie group homomorphism SO(3) ⟶ SU(2).

Nevertheless, we will see later (Proposition 14.2) that if G is simply connected, then any Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq46.gif) corresponds to a Lie group homomorphism G ⟶ H. Thus, the obstruction to lifting the Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{o}\(3\)\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq47.gif) to a Lie group homomorphism is topological and corresponds to the fact that SO(3) is not simply connected.

Exercises

Exercise 7.1.

Compute the Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathrm{Lie}\(\\psi \): \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(2\)\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{o}\(3\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq48.gif) of Example 7.1 explicitly.

Exercise 7.2.

Show that no Lie group can be homeomorphic to the sphere S k if k is even. On the other hand, show that ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(2\)\\mathop{\\cong}{S}^{3}$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq49.gif). (Hint: Use Exercise 6.1.)

Exercise 7.3.

Let J be the matrix (5.​3). Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{o}\(N, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq50.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{o}_{J}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq51.gif) be the complexified Lie algebras of the groups O(N) and ![
$$\\mathrm{O}_{J}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_7_Chapter_IEq52.gif) in Exercise 5.9. Show that these complex Lie algebras are isomorphic. Describe ![
$$\\mathfrak{o}\(N, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
