# 8. The Exponential Map

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

The exponential map, introduced for closed Lie subgroups of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq1.gif) in Chap.​ 5, can be defined for a general Lie group G as a map Lie(G) → G.

The exponential map, introduced for closed Lie subgroups of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq2.gif) in Chap.​ 5, can be defined for a general Lie group G as a map Lie(G) → G.

We may consider a vector field (6.​5) that is allowed to vary smoothly. By this we mean that we introduce a real parameter ![
$$\\lambda \\in \(-\\epsilon, \\epsilon\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq301.gif) for some ϵ > 0 and smooth functions ![
$$a_{i}: M \\times \(-\\epsilon,\\epsilon \)\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq3.gif) and consider a vector field, which in local coordinates is given by

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(Xf\)\(m\) =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}a_{ i}\(m,\\lambda \) \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{i}}\(m\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(8.1)

Proposition 8.1.

Suppose that M is a smooth manifold, m ∈ M, and X is a vector field on M. Then, for sufficiently small ϵ > 0, there exists a path p :  ![
$$p : \(-\\epsilon, \\epsilon\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq401.gif) → M such that p(0) = m and ![
$$p_{{\\ast}}\(\\mathrm{d}/\\mathrm{d}t\)\(t\) = X_{p\(t\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq4.gif) for t ∈ (−ϵ, ϵ). Such a curve, on whatever interval it is defined, is uniquely determined. If the vector field X is allowed to depend on a parameter λ as in (8.1), then for small values of t, p(t) depends smoothly on λ.

Here we are regarding the interval (−ϵ, ϵ) as a manifold, and p ∗(d∕dt) is the image of the tangent vector d∕dt. We call such a curve an integral curve for the vector field.

Proof.

In terms of local coordinates x 1,...,x n on M, the vector field X is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum a_{i}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}},}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equa.gif)

where the a i are smooth functions in the coordinate neighborhood. If a path p(t) is specified, let us write x i (t) for the x i component of p(t), with the coordinates of m being ![
$$x_{1} = \\cdots = x_{n} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq5.gif). Applying the tangent vector p ∗(t)(d∕dt)(t) to a function f ∈ C ∞ (G) gives

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\) =\\sum x_{i}^{\\prime}\(t\) \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{i}}\\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equb.gif)

On the other hand, applying X p(t) to the same f gives

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{i}a_{i}\\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\) \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{i}}\\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\)\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equc.gif)

so we need a solution to the first-order system

![
$$\\displaystyle{x_{i}^{\\prime}\(t\) = a_{i}\\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\),\\quad x_{i}\(0\) = 0,\\quad \(i = 1,\\ldots,n\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equd.gif)

The existence of such a solution for sufficiently small |t|, and its uniqueness on whatever interval it does exist, is guaranteed by a standard result in the theory of ordinary differential equations, which may be found in most texts. See, for example, Ince 81], [Chap.​ 3, particularly Sect. 3.3, for a rigorous treatment. The required Lipschitz condition follows from smoothness of the a i. For the statement about continuously varying vector fields, one needs to know the corresponding fact about first-order systems, which is discussed in Sect. 3.31 of [81]. Here Ince imposes an assumption of analyticity on the dependence of the differential equation on λ, which he allows to be a complex parameter, because he wants to conclude analyticity of the solutions; if one weakens this assumption of analyticity to smoothness, one still gets smoothness of the solution. □

In general, the existence of the integral curve of a vector field is only guaranteed in a small segment (−ϵ, ϵ), as in Proposition 8.1. However, we will now see that, for left-invariant vector fields on a Lie group, the integral curve extends to all ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq6.gif). This fact underlies the construction of the exponential map.

Theorem 8.1.

Let G be a Lie group and ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq7.gif) its Lie algebra. There exists a map ![
$$\\exp: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq8.gif) that is a local homeomorphism in a neighborhood of the origin in ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq9.gif) such that, for any ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq10.gif) , t → exp (tX) is an integral curve for the left-invariant vector field X. Moreover, ![
$$\\exp \\big\(\(t + u\)X\\big\) =\\exp \(tX\)\\exp \(uX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq11.gif) .

Proof.

Let ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq12.gif). We know that for sufficiently small ϵ > 0 there exists an integral curve p : (−ϵ, ϵ) → G for the left-invariant vector field X with p(0) = 1. We show first that if p : (a,b) → G is any integral curve for an open interval (a,b) containing 0, then

![
$$ { p\(s\)\\,p\(t\)} = {p\(s + t\)}\\,\\mathrm{when}\\,s,t,s + t \\in \(a,b\). $$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(8.2)

Indeed, since X is invariant under left-translation, left-translation by p(s) takes an integral curve for the vector field into another integral curve. Thus, t → p(s) p(t) and t → p(s \+ t) are both integral curves, with the same initial condition 0 → p(s). They are thus the same.

With this in mind, we show next that if p : (−a,a) → G is an integral curve for the left-invariant vector field X, then we may extend it to all of ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq13.gif). Of course, it is sufficient to show that we may extend it to ![
$$\(-\\frac{3} {2}a, \\frac{3} {2}a\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq14.gif). We extend it by the rule ![
$$p\(t\) = p\(a/2\)\\,p\(t - a/2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq15.gif) when ![
$$-a/2 \\leqslant t \\leqslant 3a/2$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq16.gif) and ![
$$p\(t\) = p\(-a/2\)\\,p\(t + a/2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq17.gif) when ![
$$-3a/2 \\leqslant t \\leqslant a/2$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq18.gif), and it follows from (8.2) that this definition is consistent on regions of overlap.

Now define ![
$$\\exp: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq19.gif) as follows. Let ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq20.gif), and let ![
$$p: \\mathbb{R}\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq21.gif) be an integral curve for the left-invariant vector field X with p(0) = 0. We define exp(X) = p(1). We note that if ![
$$u \\in \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq22.gif), then ![
$$t\\mapsto p\(tu\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq23.gif) is an integral curve for uX, so exp(uX) = p(u).

The exponential map is a smooth map, at least for X near the origin in ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq24.gif), by the last statement in Proposition 8.1. Identifying the tangent space at the origin in the vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq25.gif) with ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq26415.gif) itself, exp induces a map ![
$$T_{0}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)\\longrightarrow T_{e}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq27964.gif) (that is ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq28841.gif)), and this map is the identity map by construction. Thus, the Jacobian of exp is nonzero and, by the Inverse Function Theorem, exp is a local homeomorphism near 0. □

We also denote exp(X) as e X for ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq29365.gif).

Remark 8.1.

If ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq307151.gif), then as we explained in Chap.​ 7, Proposition 7.2 allows us to identify the Lie algebra of G with ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq312564.gif). We observe that the definition of ![
$$\\exp: \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq32445.gif) by a series in (5.​2) agrees with the definition in Theorem 8.1. This is because ![
$$t\\longmapsto \\exp \(tX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq33486.gif) with either definition is an integral curve for the same left-invariant vector field, and the uniqueness of such an integral curve follows from Proposition 8.1.

Proposition 8.2.

Let G, H be Lie groups and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq34.gif), ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq35.gif) be their respective Lie algebras. Let f : G → H be a homomorphism. Then the following diagram is commutative:

Proof.

It is clear from the definitions that f takes an integral curve for a left-invariant vector field X on G to an integral curve for df(X), and the statement follows. □

A representation of a Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq36.gif) over a field F is a Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\pi: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq37.gif), where V is an F-vector space, or more generally a vector space over a field E containing F, and End(V ) is given the Lie algebra structure that it inherits from its structure as an associative algebra. Thus,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi \(\[x,y\]\) = \\pi \(x\)\\,\\pi \(y\) - \\pi \(y\)\\,\\pi \(x\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Eque.gif)

We may sometimes find it convenient to denote π(x)v as just xv for ![
$$x \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq38.gif) and v ∈ V. We may think of ![
$$\(x,v\)\\mapsto xv = \\pi \(x\)v$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq39.gif) as a multiplication. If V is a vector space, given a map ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} \\times V \\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq40.gif) denoted ![
$$\(x,v\)\\mapsto xv$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq41.gif) such that ![
$$x\\mapsto \\pi \(x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq42.gif) is a representation, where π(x) : V → V is the endomorphism v → xv, then we call V a ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq43.gif)-module. A homomorphism ϕ : U → V of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq44.gif)-modules is an F-linear map satisfying ϕ(xv) = x ϕ(v).

Example 8.1.

If π : G → GL(V ) is a representation, where V is a real or complex vector space, then the Lie algebra of GL(V ) is End(V ), so the differential Lie(π) : Lie(G) → End(V ), defined by Proposition 7.3, is a Lie algebra representation.

By the universal property of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq45.gif) in Theorem 10.1, A Lie algebra representation ![
$$\\pi: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq46.gif) extends to a ring homomorphism ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq47.gif), which we continue to denote as π.

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq48.gif) is a Lie algebra over a field F, we get a homomorphism ![
$$\\mathrm{ad}: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq49.gif), called the adjoint map, defined by ad(x)y = [x,y]. We give ![
$$\\mathrm{End}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq50.gif) the Lie algebra structure it inherits as an associative ring. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathrm{ad}\(x\)\(\[y,z\]\) = \[\\mathrm{ad}\(x\)\(y\),z\] + \[y,\\mathrm{ad}\(x\)\(z\)\] }$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(8.3)

since, by the Jacobi identity, both sides equal ![
$$\[x,\[y,z\]\] = \[\[x,y\],z\] + \[y,\[x,z\]\]$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq51.gif). This means that ad(x) is a derivation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq52.gif).

Also

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathrm{ad}\(x\)\\,\\mathrm{ad}\(y\) -\\mathrm{ad}\(y\)\\,\\mathrm{ad}\(x\) = \\mathrm{ad}\\big\(\[x,y\]\\big\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(8.4)

since applying either side to ![
$$z \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq53.gif) gives ![
$$\[x,\[y,z\]\] - \[y,\[x,z\]\] = \[\[x,y\],z\]$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq54.gif) by the Jacobi identity. So ![
$$\\mathrm{ad}: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq55.gif) is a Lie algebra representation.

We next explain the geometric origin of ad. To begin with, representations of Lie algebras arise naturally from representations of Lie groups. Suppose that G is a Lie group and ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq56.gif) is its Lie algebra. If V is a vector space over ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq57.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq58.gif), any Lie group homomorphism π : G → GL(V ) induces a Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq59.gif) by Proposition 7.3; that is, a real or complex representation.

In particular, G acts on itself by conjugation, and so it acts on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = T_{e}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq60.gif). This representation is called the adjoint representation and is denoted ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq61.gif). We show next that the differential of Ad is ad. That is:

Theorem 8.2.

Let G be a Lie group, ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq62.gif) its Lie algebra, and ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq63.gif) the adjoint representation. Then the Lie group representation ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq64.gif) corresponding to Ad by Proposition 7.3 is ad .

Proof.

It will be most convenient for us to think of elements of the Lie algebra as tangent vectors at the identity or as local derivations of the local ring there. Let ![
$$X,Y \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq65.gif). If f ∈ C ∞ (G), define ![
$$c\(g\)f\(h\) = f\({g}^{-1}hg\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq66.gif). Then our definitions of the adjoint representation amount to

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\big\(\\mathrm{Ad}\(g\)Y \\big\)f = Y \\big\(c\({g}^{-1}\)f\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equf.gif)

To compute the differential of Ad, note that the path t → exp(tX) in G is tangent to the identity at t = 0 with tangent vector X. Therefore, under the representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq67.gif) in Proposition 7.3, X maps Y to the local derivation at the identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\\longmapsto \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}\\,\\big\(\\mathrm{Ad}\({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\)Y \\big\)f\\,\\Big\\vert _{ t=0} = \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}u}f\({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }{\\mathrm{e}}^{-tX}\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{ t=u=0}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equg.gif)

By the chain rule, if F(t 1,t 2) is a function of two real variables,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}F\(t,t\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{t=0} = \\frac{\\partial F} {\\partial t_{1}}\(0,0\) + \\frac{\\partial F} {\\partial t_{2}}\(0,0\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(8.5)

Applying this, with u fixed to ![
$$F\(t_{1},t_{2}\) = f\({\\mathrm{e}}^{t_{1}X}{\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }{\\mathrm{e}}^{-t_{2}X}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_IEq68.gif), our last expression equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}u} \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{ t=u=0} - \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}u} \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\({\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }\\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{ t=u=0} = XY f\(1\) - Y Xf\(1\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_8_Chapter_Equh.gif)

This is, of course, the same as the effect of [X,Y ] = ad(X)Y. □

# 9. Tensors and Universal Properties

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

We will review the basic properties of the tensor product and use them to illustrate the basic notion of a universal property, which we will see repeatedly.

We will review the basic properties of the tensor product and use them to illustrate the basic notion of a universal property, which we will see repeatedly.

If R is a commutative ring and M, N, and P are R-modules, then a bilinear map f : M × N → P is a map satisfying

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(r_{1}m_{1} + r_{2}m_{2},n\) = r_{1}f\(m_{1},n\) + r_{2}f\(m_{2},n\),\\quad r_{i} \\in R,m_{i} \\in M,n \\in N,}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_Equa.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(m,r_{1}n_{1} + r_{2}n_{2}\) = r_{1}f\(m,n_{1}\) + r_{2}f\(m,n_{2}\),\\quad r_{i} \\in R,n_{i} \\in N,m \\in M.}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_Equb.gif)

More generally, if M 1,..., M k are R-modules, the notion of a k-linear map M 1 × ⋯ × M k → P is defined similarly: the map must be linear in each variable.

The tensor product ![
$$M \\otimes _{R}N$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq1.gif) is an R-module together with a bilinear map ![
$$\\otimes: M \\times N\\longrightarrow M \\otimes _{R}N$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq2.gif) satisfying the following property.

Universal Property of the Tensor Product. If P is any R-module and p: M × N → P is a bilinear map, there exists a unique R-module homomorphism ![
$$F: M \\otimes N\\longrightarrow P$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq3.gif) such that ![
$$p = F \\circ \\otimes $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq4.gif).

Why do we call this a universal property? It says that ![
$$\\otimes: M \\times N\\longrightarrow M \\otimes N$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq5.gif) is a "universal" bilinear map in the sense that any bilinear map of M × N factors through it. As we will explain, the module ![
$$M \\otimes _{R}N$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq6.gif) is uniquely determined by the universal property. This is important beyond the immediate example because often objects are described by universal properties. Before we explain this point (which is obvious if one thinks about it correctly), let us make a categorical observation.

If ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq7.gif) is a category, an initial object in ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq8.gif) is an object X 0 such that, for each object Y, the Hom set ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{\\mathcal{C}}\(X_{0},Y \)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq9.gif) consists of a single element. A terminal object is an object X ∞ such that, for each object Y, the Hom set ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{\\mathcal{C}}\(Y,X_{\\infty }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq10.gif) consists of a single element. For example, in the category of sets, the empty set is an initial object and a set consisting of one element is a terminal object.

Lemma 9.1.

In any category, any two initial objects are isomorphic. Any two terminal objects are isomorphic.

Proof.

If X 0 and X 1 are initial objects, there exist unique morphisms f : X 0 → X 1 (since X 0 is initial) and g : X 1 → X 0 (since X 1 is initial). Then g ∘ f : X 0 → X 0 and ![
$$1_{X_{0}}: X_{0}\\longrightarrow X_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq11.gif) must coincide since X 0 is initial, and similarly ![
$$f \\circ g = 1_{X_{1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq12.gif). Thus f and g are inverse isomorphisms. Similarly, terminal objects are isomorphic. □

Theorem 9.1.

The tensor product ![
$$M \\otimes _{R}N$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq13.gif) , if it exists, is determined up to isomorphism by the universal property.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq14.gif) be the following category. An object in ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq15.gif) is an ordered pair (P, p), where P is an R-module and p : M × N → P is a bilinear map. If X = (P, p) and Y = (Q, q) are objects, then a morphism X → Y consists of an R-module homomorphism f : P → Q such that q = f ∘ p. The universal property of the tensor product means that ![
$$\\otimes: M \\times N\\longrightarrow M \\otimes N$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq16.gif) is an initial object in this category and therefore determined up to isomorphism. □

Of course, we usually denote ![
$$\\otimes \(m,n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq17.gif) as ![
$$m \\otimes n$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq18.gif) in ![
$$M \\otimes _{R}N$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq19.gif). We have not proved that ![
$$M \\otimes _{R}N$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq20.gif) exists. We refer to any text on algebra for this fact, such as Lang [116], Chap. XVI.

In general, by a universal property we mean any characterization of a mathematical object that can be expressed by saying that some associated object is an initial or terminal object in some category. The basic paradigm is that a universal property characterizes an object up to isomorphism.

A typical application of the universal property of the tensor product is to make ![
$$M \\otimes _{R}N$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq21.gif) into a functor. Specifically, if μ : M → M′ and ν : N → N′ are R-module homomorphisms, then there is a unique R-module homomorphism ![
$$\\mu \\otimes \\nu: M \\otimes _{R}N\\longrightarrow M^{\\prime} \\otimes _{R}N^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq22.gif) such that ![
$$\(\\mu \\otimes \\nu \)\(m \\otimes n\) = \\mu \(m\) \\otimes \\nu \(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq23.gif). We get this by applying the universal property to the R-bilinear map ![
$$M \\times N\\longrightarrow M^{\\prime} \\otimes N^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq24.gif) defined by ![
$$\(m,n\)\\longmapsto \\mu \(m\) \\otimes \\nu \(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq25.gif).

As another example of an object that can be defined by a universal property, let V be a vector space over a field F. Let us ask for an F-algebra ![
$$\\bigotimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq26985.gif) together with an F-linear map ![
$$i: V \\longrightarrow \\bigotimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq27516.gif) satisfying the following condition.

Universal Property of the Tensor Algebra. If A is any F-algebra and ϕ : V →A is an F-linear map then there exists a unique F-algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\varPhi:\\bigotimes V \\longrightarrow A$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq288484.gif) such that r = ρ ∘ i.

It should be clear from the previous discussion that this universal property characterizes the tensor algebra up to isomorphism. To prove existence, we can construct a ring with this exact property as follows. Let unadorned ![
$$\\otimes $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq29845.gif) mean ![
$$\\otimes _{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq30846.gif) in what follows. By ![
$${\\otimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq31745.gif) we mean the k-fold tensor product ![
$$V \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq32741.gif) (k times); if k = 0, then it is natural to take ![
$${\\otimes }^{0}V = F$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq3374962.gif) while ![
$${\\otimes }^{1}V = V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq34356.gif). If V has finite dimension d, then ![
$${\\otimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq35.gif) has dimension d k . Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigotimes V =\\bigoplus _{ k=0}^{\\infty }\\left \({\\otimes }^{k}V \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_Equc.gif)

Then ![
$$\\bigotimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq36.gif) has the natural structure of a graded F-algebra in which the multiplication ![
$${\\otimes }^{k}V \\times {\\otimes }^{l}V \\longrightarrow {\\otimes }^{k+l}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq37.gif) sends

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(v_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes v_{k},u_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes u_{l}\)\\longrightarrow v_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes v_{k} \\otimes u_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes u_{l}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_Equd.gif)

We regard V as a subset of ![
$$\\bigotimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq38.gif) embedded onto ![
$${\\otimes }^{1}V = V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq39.gif).

Proposition 9.1.

The universal property of the tensor algebra is satisfied.

Proof.

If ϕ : V → A is any linear map of V into an F-algebra, define a map ![
$$\\varPhi:\\bigotimes V \\longrightarrow A$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq40.gif) by ![
$$\\varPhi \(v_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes v_{k}\) = \\phi \(v_{1}\)\\cdots \\phi \(v_{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq41.gif) on ![
$${\\otimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq42.gif). It is easy to see that Φ is a ring homomorphism. It is unique since V generates ![
$$\\bigotimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq43.gif) as an F-algebra. □

A graded algebra over the field F is an F-algebra A with a direct sum decomposition

![
$$\\displaystyle{A =\\bigoplus _{ k=0}^{\\infty }A_{ k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_Eque.gif)

such that ![
$$A_{k}A_{l} \\subseteq A_{k+l}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq44.gif). In most examples we will have A 0 = F. Elements of A k are called homogeneous of degree k. The tensor algebra is a graded algebra, with ![
$${\\otimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq45.gif) being the homogeneous part of degree k.

Next we define the symmetric and exterior powers of a vector space V over the field F. Let V k denote V × ⋯ × V (k times). A k-linear map f : V k → U into another vector space is called symmetric if for any σ ∈ S k it satisfies ![
$$f\(v_{\\sigma \(1\)},\\ldots,v_{\\sigma \(k\)}\) = f\(v_{1},\\ldots,v_{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq46.gif) and alternating if ![
$$f\\big\(v_{\\sigma \(1\)},\\ldots,v_{\\sigma \(k\)}\) =\\varepsilon \(\\sigma \)\\,f\(v_{1},\\ldots,v_{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq47.gif), where ![
$$\\varepsilon: S_{k}\\longrightarrow \\{ \\pm 1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq48.gif) is the alternating (sign) character. The kth symmetric and exterior powers of V, denoted ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq49.gif) and ![
$${\\wedge }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq50.gif), are F-vector spaces, together with k-linear maps ![
$$\\vee: {V }^{k}\\longrightarrow {\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq51.gif) and ![
$$\\wedge: {V }^{k}\\longrightarrow {\\wedge }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq52.gif). The map ![
$$\\vee $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq53.gif) is symmetric, and the map ![
$$\\wedge $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq54.gif) is alternating. We normally denote ![
$$\\vee \(v_{1},\\ldots,v_{k}\) = v_{1} \\vee \\cdots \\vee v_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq55.gif) and similarly for ![
$$\\wedge $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq56.gif). The following universal properties are required.

Universal Properties of the Symmetric and Exterior Powers: Let f : V k →U be any symmetric (resp. alternating) k-linear map. Then there exists a unique F-linear map ϕ : ∨ k V →U (resp. ![
$${\\wedge }^{k}V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq57.gif) ) such that ![
$$f = \\phi \\circ \\vee $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq58.gif) (resp. ![
$$f = \\phi \\circ \\wedge $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq59.gif) ).

As usual, the symmetric and exterior algebras are characterized up to isomorphism by the universal property. We may construct ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq60.gif) as a quotient of ![
$${\\otimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq61.gif), dividing by the subspace W generated by elements of the form ![
$$v_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes v_{k} - v_{\\sigma \(1\)} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes v_{\\sigma \(k\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq62.gif), with a similar construction for ![
$${\\wedge }^{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq63.gif). The universal property of ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq64.gif) then follows from the universal property of the tensor product. Indeed, if f : V k → U is any symmetric k-linear map, then there is induced a linear map ![
$$\\psi: {\\otimes }^{k}V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq65.gif) such that ![
$$f = \\psi \\circ \\otimes $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq66.gif). Since f is symmetric, ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq66123.gif) vanishes on W, so ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq661234.gif) induces a map ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V = {\\otimes }^{k}V/W\\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq67.gif) and the universal property follows.

If V has dimension d, then ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq68.gif) has dimension ![
$$\\binom{d + k - 1}{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq69.gif), for if x 1,..., x d is a basis of V, then ![
$$\\left \\{x_{i_{1}} \\vee \\cdots \\vee x_{i_{k}}\\,\\vert \\,1 \\leqslant i_{1} \\leqslant i_{2} \\leqslant \\cdots \\leqslant i_{k} \\leqslant d\\right \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq70.gif) is a basis for ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq71.gif). On the other hand, the exterior power vanishes unless ![
$$k \\leqslant d$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq72.gif), in which case it has dimension ![
$$\\binom{d}{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq73.gif). A basis consists of ![
$$\\{x_{i_{1}} \\wedge \\cdots \\wedge x_{i_{k}}\\,\\vert \\,1 \\leqslant i_{1} < i_{2} < \\cdots < i_{k} \\leqslant d\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq74.gif). The vector spaces ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq75.gif) may be collected together to make a commutative graded algebra:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigvee V =\\bigoplus _{ k=0}^{\\infty }{\\vee }^{k}V.}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_Equf.gif)

This is the symmetric algebra. The exterior algebra ![
$$\\bigwedge V =\\bigoplus _{k} {\\wedge }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq76.gif) is constructed similarly. The spaces ![
$${\\vee }^{0}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq77.gif) and ![
$${\\wedge }^{0}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq78.gif) are one-dimensional and it is natural to take ![
$${\\vee }^{0}V = {\\wedge }^{0}V = F$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq79.gif).

Exercises

Exercise 9.1.

Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space over a field F that may be assumed to be infinite. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{P}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq80.gif) be the ring of polynomial functions on V. Note that an element of the dual space V ∗ is a function on V, so regarding this function as a polynomial gives an injection ![
$${V }^{{\\ast}}\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{P}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq81.gif). Show that this linear map extends to a ring isomorphism ![
$$\\bigvee {V }^{{\\ast}}\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{P}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq82.gif).

Exercise 9.2.

Prove that if V is a vector space, then ![
$$V \\otimes V \\mathop{\\cong}\(V \\wedge V \) \\oplus \(V \\vee V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq83.gif).

Exercise 9.3.

Use the universal properties of the symmetric and exterior power to show that if V and W are vector spaces, then there are maps ![
$${\\vee }^{k}f: {\\vee }^{k}V \\longrightarrow {\\vee }^{k}W$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq84.gif) and ![
$${\\wedge }^{k}f: {\\wedge }^{k}V \\longrightarrow {\\wedge }^{k}W$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq85.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\vee }^{k}f\(v_{ 1} \\vee \\cdots \\vee v_{k}\) = f\(v_{1}\) \\vee \\cdots \\vee f\(v_{k}\),{\\wedge }^{k}f\(v_{ 1} \\wedge \\cdots \\wedge v_{k}\) = f\(v_{1}\) \\wedge \\cdots \\wedge f\(v_{k}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_Equg.gif)

Exercise 9.4.

Suppose that V = F 4. Let ![
$$f: V \\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq86.gif) be the linear transformation with eigenvalues a, b, c, d. Compute the traces of the linear transformations ![
$${\\vee }^{2}f$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq87.gif) and ![
$${\\wedge }^{2}f$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq88.gif) on ![
$${\\vee }^{2}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq89.gif) and ![
$${\\wedge }^{2}V$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq90.gif) as polynomials in a, b, c, d.

Exercise 9.5.

Let A and B be algebras over the field F. Then ![
$$A \\otimes B$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq91.gif) is also an algebra, with multiplication ![
$$\(a \\otimes b\)\(a^{\\prime} \\otimes b^{\\prime}\) = aa^{\\prime} \\otimes bb^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq92.gif). Show that there are ring homomorphisms ![
$$i: A \\rightarrow A \\otimes B$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq93.gif) and ![
$$j: B \\rightarrow A \\otimes B$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq94.gif) such that if f : A → C and g : B → C are ring homomorphisms into a ring C satisfying f(a) g(b) = g(b) f(a) for a ∈ A and b ∈ B, then there exists a unique ring homomorphism ![
$$\\phi: A \\otimes B \\rightarrow C$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_IEq95.gif) such that ϕ ∘ i = f and ϕ ∘ j = g.

Exercise 9.6.

Show that if U and V are finite-dimensional vector spaces over F then show that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigvee \(U \\oplus V \)\\mathop{\\cong}\\left \(\\bigvee U\\right \) \\otimes \\left \(\\bigvee U\\right \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_Equh.gif)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigwedge \(U \\oplus V \)\\mathop{\\cong}\\left \(\\bigwedge U\\right \) \\otimes \\left \(\\bigwedge U\\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_9_Chapter_Equi.gif)

# 10. The Universal Enveloping Algebra

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

We have seen that elements of the Lie algebra of a Lie group G are derivations of C ∞ (G). They are thus first-order differential operators that are left-invariant. The universal enveloping algebra is a purely algebraically defined ring that may be identified with the ring of all left-invariant differential operators, including higher-order ones.

We have seen that elements of the Lie algebra of a Lie group G are derivations of C ∞ (G). They are thus first-order differential operators that are left-invariant. The universal enveloping algebra is a purely algebraically defined ring that may be identified with the ring of all left-invariant differential operators, including higher-order ones.

We recall from Example 5.6 that if A is an associative algebra, then A may be regarded as a Lie algebra by the rule ![
$$\[a,b\] = ab - ba$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq1.gif) for a, b ∈ A. We will denote this Lie algebra by Lie(A).

Theorem 10.1.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq2.gif) be a Lie algebra over a field F. There exists an associative F-algebra ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq3.gif) with a Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$i: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Lie}\\big\(U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq4.gif) such that if A is any F-algebra, and ![
$$\\phi: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Lie}\(A\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq5.gif) is a Lie algebra homomorphism, then there exists a unique F-algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\varPhi: U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)\\longrightarrow A$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq6.gif) such that ϕ = Φ ∘ i.

As always, an object [in this case ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq7.gif)] defined by a universal property is characterized up to isomorphism by that property.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathcal{K}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq8.gif) be the ideal in ![
$$\\bigotimes \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq9.gif) generated by elements of the form ![
$$\[x,y\] - \(x \\otimes y - y \\otimes x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq10.gif) for ![
$$x,y \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq11.gif), and let ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq12.gif) be the quotient ![
$$\\bigotimes V/\\mathcal{K}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq13.gif). Let ![
$$\\phi: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Lie}\(A\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq14.gif) be a Lie algebra homomorphism. This means that ϕ is an F-linear map such that ![
$$\\phi \(\[x,y\]\) = \\phi \(x\)\\phi \(y\) - \\phi \(y\)\\phi \(x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq15.gif). Then ϕ extends to a ring homomorphism ![
$$\\bigotimes \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow A$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq16.gif) by Proposition 9.1. Our assumption implies that ![
$$\\mathcal{K}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq17.gif) is in the kernel of this homomorphism, and so there is induced a ring homomorphism ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)\\longrightarrow A$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq18.gif). Clearly, ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq19.gif) is generated by the image of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq20.gif), so this homomorphism is uniquely determined. □

Suppose that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq21.gif) is the Lie algebra of a Lie group G. Consider the ring A of vector space endomorphisms of C ∞ (G) that commute with left translation by elements of G. As we have already seen, elements of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq22.gif) are left-invariant differential operators, by means of the action

![
$$\\displaystyle{ Xf\(g\) = \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\\big\(g{\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\\big\)\\vert _{ t=0}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(10.1)

By the universal property of the universal enveloping algebra, this action extends to a ring homomorphism ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)\\longrightarrow A$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq23.gif), the image of which consists of left-invariant differential operators [Exercise 10.2 (i)]. Let us apply this observation to give a quick analytic proof of a fact that has a longer purely algebraic proof.

Proposition 10.1.

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq24.gif) is the Lie algebra of a Lie group G, then the natural map ![
$$i: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq25.gif) is injective.

It is a consequence of the Poincaré–Birkhoff–Witt theorem, a standard and purely algebraic theorem, that ![
$$i: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) is injective for any Lie algebra. Instead of proving the Poincaré–Birkhoff–Witt theorem, we give a short proof of this weaker statement.

Proof.

Let A be the ring of endomorphisms of C ∞ (G). Regarding ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq2712.gif) as a derivation of C ∞ (G) acting by (10.1), we have a Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Lie}\(A\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq28123.gif), which by Theorem 10.1 induces a map ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)\\longrightarrow A$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq29.gif). If ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq3023.gif) had zero image in ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq31.gif), it would have zero image in A. It would therefore be zero. □

The center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq32.gif) is very important. One reason for this is that while elements of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq3312.gif) are realized as differential operators that are invariant under left-translation, elements of the center are invariant under both left and right translation. [Exercise 10.2 (ii)]. Moreover, the center acts by scalars on any irreducible subspace, as we see in the following version of Schur's lemma.

A representation (π,V ) of a Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq3412.gif) is irreducible if there is no proper nonzero subspace U ⊂ V such that π(x)U ⊆ U for all ![
$$x \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq35.gif).

Proposition 10.2.

Let ![
$$\\pi: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq36.gif) be an irreducible representation of the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq37.gif) . If c is in the center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq38.gif) , then there exists a scalar λ such that π(c) = λI V .

Proof.

Let λ be any eigenvalue of π(c). Let U be the λ-eigenspace of π(c). Since π(c) commutes with π(x) for all ![
$$x \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq39.gif), we see that π(x)U ⊆ U for all ![
$$x \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq40.gif). By the definition of irreducibility, U = V, so π(c) acts by the scalar λ. □

Thus, the center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq41.gif) is extremely important. One particular element, the Casimir element, is especially important. To give two examples of its significance, the Casimir element gives rise to the Laplace–Beltrami operator, the spectral theory for which is very important in noneuclidean geometry. It is also fundamental in the theory of Kac–Moody Lie algebras. This theory generalizes the theory of finite-dimensional Lie algebras to an infinite-dimensional setting in which (remarkably) all the main theorems remain valid. One of the key features of this theory is how the Casimir element becomes the key ingredient in many proofs (such as that of the Weyl character formula) where other tools are no longer available. See [92].

Our next task will be to construct the Casimir elements. This requires a discussion of invariant bilinear forms. If V is a vector space over F and ![
$$\\pi: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq42.gif) is a representation, then we call a bilinear form B on V invariant if

![
$$\\displaystyle{ B\\big\(\\pi \(X\)v,w\\big\) + B\\big\(v,\\pi \(X\)w\\big\) = 0 }$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(10.2)

for ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq43.gif), v,w ∈ V. The following proposition shows that this notion of invariance is the Lie algebra analog of the more intuitive corresponding notion for Lie groups.

Proposition 10.3.

Suppose that G is a Lie group, ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq44.gif) its Lie algebra, and π : G⟶GL (V) a representation admitting an invariant bilinear form B. Then B is invariant for the differential of π.

Proof.

Invariance under π means that

![
$$\\displaystyle{B\\big\(\\pi \({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\)v,\\pi \({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\)w\\big\) = B\(v,w\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equa.gif)

The derivative of this with respect to t is zero. By (8.​5), this derivative is

![
$$\\displaystyle{B\\big\(\\pi \(X\)v,w\\big\) + B\\big\(v,\\pi \(X\)w\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equb.gif)

We see that (10.2) is satisfied. □

If (π,V ) is a representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq45.gif), define a bilinear form ![
$$B_{V }: \\mathfrak{g} \\times \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq46.gif) by B V (X,Y ) = tr(π(X)π(Y )). This is the trace bilinear form on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq47.gif) with respect to V. In the special case where ![
$$V = \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq48.gif) and π is the adjoint representation, the trace bilinear form is called the Killing form.

Proposition 10.4.

Suppose that (π,V ) is a representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq49.gif) . Then the trace bilinear form on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq50.gif) is invariant for the adjoint representation ![
$$\\mathrm{ad}: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq51.gif) .

Proof.

Invariance under ad means

![
$$\\displaystyle{ B\(\[x,y\],z\) + B\(y,\[x,z\]\) = 0. }$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(10.3)

Since π is a representation, ![
$$\\pi \(\[x,y\]\) = \\pi \(x\)\\pi \(y\) - \\pi \(y\)\\pi \(x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq52.gif), so B([x,y],z) is the trace of

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi \(x\)\\pi \(y\)\\pi \(z\) - \\pi \(y\)\\pi \(x\)\\pi \(z\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equc.gif)

while B(y,[x,z]) is the trace of

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi \(y\)\\pi \(x\)\\pi \(z\) - \\pi \(y\)\\pi \(z\)\\pi \(x\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equd.gif)

Using the property of endomorphisms A and B of a vector space that tr(AB) = tr(BA), these sum to zero. This same fact implies that B(x,y) = B(y,x). □

Now given an invariant bilinear form on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq53.gif), we may construct an element of the center, provided the bilinear form is nondegenerate.

Theorem 10.2.

Suppose that the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq54.gif) admits a nondegenerate invariant bilinear form B. Let x 1 ,...,x d be a basis of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq55.gif) , and let y 1 ,...,y d be the dual basis, so that ![
$$B\(x_{i},y_{j}\) = \\delta _{ij}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq56.gif) (Kronecker δ). Then the element ![
$$\\varDelta =\\sum _{i}x_{i}y_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq57.gif) of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq58.gif) is in the center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq59.gif) . The element Δ is independent of the choice of basis x 1 ,...,x d .

The element Δ is called the Casimir element of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq60.gif) (with respect to B).

Proof.

Let ![
$$z \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq61.gif). There exist constants α ij and β ij such that ![
$$\[z,x_{i}\] =\\sum _{j}\\alpha _{\\mathit{ij}}x_{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq62.gif) and ![
$$\[z,y_{i}\] =\\sum _{j}\\beta _{\\mathit{ij}}y_{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq63.gif). Since B is invariant, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{0 = B\(\[z,x_{i}\],y_{j}\) + B\(x_{i},\[z,y_{j}\]\) = \\alpha _{\\mathit{ij}} + \\beta _{\\mathit{ji}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Eque.gif)

Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{z\\sum _{i}x_{i}y_{i} =\\sum _{i}\\left \(\[z,x_{i}\]y_{i} + x_{i}zy_{i}\\right \) = \\left \(\\sum _{i,j}\\alpha _{ij}x_{j}y_{i}\\right \) +\\sum _{i}x_{i}zy_{i},}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equf.gif)

while

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{i}x_{i}y_{i}z =\\sum _{i}\(-x_{i}\[z,y_{i}\] + x_{i}zy_{i}\) = -\\left \(\\sum _{i,j}\\beta _{ij}x_{i}y_{j}\\right \) +\\sum _{i}x_{i}zy_{i},}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equg.gif)

and since ![
$$\\beta _{ij} = -\\alpha _{ji}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq64.gif), these are equal. Thus Δ commutes with ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq65.gif), and since ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq66.gif) generates ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq67.gif) as a ring, it is in the center.

It remains to be shown that Δ is independent of the choice of basis x 1,...,x d . Suppose that x 1′,...,x d ′ is another basis. Write ![
$$x_{i}^{\\prime} =\\sum _{j}c_{ij}x_{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq68.gif), and if ![
$$y_{1}^{\\prime},\\ldots,y_{d}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq69.gif) is the corresponding dual basis, let ![
$$y_{i}^{\\prime} =\\sum _{j}d_{ij}y_{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq70.gif). The condition that ![
$$B\(x_{i}^{\\prime},y_{j}^{\\prime}\) = \\delta _{ij}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq71.gif) (Kronecker δ) implies that ![
$$\\sum _{k}c_{ik}d_{jk} = \\delta _{ij}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq72.gif). Therefore, the matrices ![
$$\(c_{ij}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq73.gif) and (d ij ) are transpose inverses of each other and so we have also ∑ k c ki d kj = δ ij . Now ![
$$\\sum _{k}x_{k}^{\\prime}y_{k}^{\\prime} =\\sum _{i,j,k}c_{ki}d_{kj}x_{i}y_{j} =\\sum _{k}x_{k}y_{k} =\\varDelta$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq74.gif). □

Although Proposition 10.4 provides us with a supply of invariant bilinear forms, there is no guarantee that they are nonzero, which is required by Theorem 10.2. We will not address this point now.

One might wonder, since there may be many irreducible representations, whether the invariant bilinear forms produced by Proposition 10.4 are all distinct. Also, since these invariant bilinear forms are all symmetric, one might wonder if we are missing some invariant bilinear forms that are not symmetric. The following proposition shows that for simple Lie algebras, there is essentially a unique invariant bilinear form, and that it is symmetric.

A Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq75.gif) is called simple if it has no proper nonzero ideals. An ideal is just an invariant subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq76.gif) for the adjoint representation, so another way of saying the same thing is that ![
$$\\mathrm{ad}: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq77.gif) is irreducible. For example, it is not hard to see that for any field F, the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq78.gif) is simple.

Proposition 10.5.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq79.gif) be a finite-dimensional simple Lie algebra over a field F. Then there exists, up to scalar, at most one invariant bilinear form on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq80.gif) . If a nonzero invariant bilinear form exists it is nondegenerate and symmetric.

Proof.

Let ![
$${\\mathfrak{g}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq81.gif) be the dual space to ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq82.gif). If ![
$$\\lambda \\in {\\mathfrak{g}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq83.gif) and ![
$$x \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq84.gif) we will use the notation ![
$$\\left \\langle x,\\lambda \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq85.gif) for λ(x). Let ![
$$\\alpha: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\({\\mathfrak{g}}^{{\\ast}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq86.gif) be defined by the rule ![
$$\\left \\langle x,\\alpha \(y\)\\lambda \\right \\rangle = -\\left \\langle \[y,x\],\\lambda \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq87.gif). It is easy to check using the Jacobi identity that this α is a representation. We will regard ![
$${\\mathfrak{g}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq88.gif) as a ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq89.gif)-module by means of α.

Every bilinear for ![
$$B: \\mathfrak{g} \\times \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow F$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq90.gif) is of the form ![
$$B\(x,y\) = \\left \\langle x,\\theta \(y\)\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq91.gif) for some linear map ![
$$\\theta: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow {\\mathfrak{g}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq92.gif). We claim that the condition for B to be invariant is equivalent to θ being a homomorphism of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq93.gif)-modules. Indeed, for θ to be a ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq94.gif)-module homomorphism we need α(x)θ(z) = θ(ad(x)z). Applying these linear functionals to ![
$$y \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq95.gif), this condition is equivalent to ![
$$-B\(\[x,y\],z\) = B\(\[y,\[x,z\]\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq96.gif) for all y.

Thus, the vector space of invariant bilinear forms is isomorphic to the space of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq97.gif)-module homomorphisms ![
$$\\theta: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow {\\mathfrak{g}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq98.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq99.gif) is simple, any such homomorphism is either zero or injective; if it is nonzero, it is bijective since ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq100.gif) and ![
$${\\mathfrak{g}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq101.gif) have the same finite dimension. By Schur's lemma (Exercise 10.5) the space of such θ is at most one-dimensional, and so, therefore, is the space of invariant bilinear forms.

We must show that if B is nonzero and invariant it is symmetric and nondegenerate. Since θ is injective, B(x,y) = 0 for all x implies that y = 0, and so it is nondegenerate. To see that it is symmetric, it is unique up to a scalar, so B(x,y) = cB(y,x) for some scalar c. Applying this twice, c 2 = 1, and we need to show c = 1. If the characteristic of F is two, then c 2 = 1 implies c = 1, so assume the characteristic is not two. Then we show that c≠ − 1. Arguing by contradiction, ![
$$c = -1$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq102.gif) implies that

![
$$\\displaystyle{B\(\[x,y\],z\) = -B\(z,\[x,y\]\) = B\(\[x,z\],y\) = -B\(\[z,x\],y\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equh.gif)

Applying this identity three times, ![
$$B\(\[x,y\],z\) = -B\(\[x,y\],z\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq103.gif) and because the characteristic is not two, we have B([x,y],z) = 0 for all x,y,z. Now we may assume that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq104.gif) is non-Abelian since otherwise it is one-dimensional and any bilinear form is symmetric. Then ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{g},\\mathfrak{g}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq105.gif) is an ideal of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq106.gif) (as follows from the Jacobi identity) and is nonzero since ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq107.gif) is non-Abelian. Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq108.gif) is simple ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{g},\\mathfrak{g}\] = \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq109.gif) and we have proved that B = 0, a contradiction. □

Exercises

Exercise 10.1.

Let ![
$$X_{ij} \\in \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq110.gif) (![
$$1 \\leqslant i,j \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq111.gif)) be the n × n matrix with a 1 in the i,j position and 0's elsewhere. Show that ![
$$\[X_{ij},X_{kl}\] = \\delta _{jk}X_{il} - \\delta _{il}X_{kj}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq112.gif), where δ jk is the Kronecker δ. From this, show for any positive integer d that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{i_{1}=1}^{n}\\cdots \\sum _{ i_{r}=1}^{n}X_{ i_{1}i_{2}}X_{i_{2}i_{3}}\\cdots X_{i_{d}i_{1}}}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equi.gif)

is in the center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq113.gif).

Exercise 10.2.

Let G be a connected Lie group and ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq114.gif) its Lie algebra. Define an action of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq115.gif) on the space C ∞ (G) of smooth functions on G by (10.1).

(i)

Show that this is a representation of G. Explain why Theorem 10.1 implies that this action of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq116.gif) on C ∞ (G) can be extended to a representation of the associative algebra ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq117.gif) on C ∞ (G).

(ii)

If h ∈ G, let ρ(h) and λ(h) be the endomorphisms of G given by left and right translation. Thus

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\rho \(h\)f\(g\) = f\(gh\),\\lambda \(h\)f\(g\) = f\({h}^{-1}g\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equj.gif)

Show that if h ∈ G and ![
$$D \\in U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq118.gif), then λ(h) ∘ D = D ∘ λ(h). If D is in the center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq119.gif) then prove that ρ(h) ∘ D = D ∘ ρ(h). (Hint: Prove this first if h is of the form e X for some X ∈ G, and recall that G was assumed to be connected, so it is generated by a neighborhood of the identity.)

Exercise 10.3.

Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq120.gif). Let B be the "Borel subgroup" of upper triangular matrices with positive diagonal entries, and let B 0 be the connected component of the identity, whose matrices have positive diagonal entries. Let K = O(n).

(i)

Show that every element of g ∈ G has a unique decomposition as g = bk with b ∈ B 0 and k ∈ K.

(ii)

Let ![
$$s = \(s_{1},\\ldots,s_{n}\) \\in {\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq121.gif). By (i), we may define an element ϕ = ϕ s of C ∞ (G) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\phi _{s}\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} y_{1} & {\\ast} &\\cdots & {\\ast} \\\\ 0 & y_{2} & \\cdots & {\\ast}\\\\ \\vdots & \\vdots & \\ddots & \\vdots \\\\ 0 & 0 & \\cdots &y_{n}\\end{array} \\right \)k\\right \) =\\prod _{ i=1}^{n}y_{ i}^{s_{i}},y_{ i} > 0,\\,k \\in K.}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Show that ϕ is an eigenfunction of the center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq122.gif). That is, if D is in the center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq123.gif), then Dϕ = λϕ for some complex number λ. [Hint: Characterize ϕ by properties of left and right translation and use Exercise 10.2 (ii).]

(iii)

Define ![
$$\\sigma _{s}\(g\) =\\int _{K}\\phi _{s}\(kg\)\\,\\mathrm{d}k$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq124.gif). Clearly σ s satisfies ![
$$\\sigma _{s}\(kgk^{\\prime}\) = \\sigma \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq125.gif) for k,k′ ∈ K. Show that ϕ is an eigenfunction of the center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq126.gif). This is the spherical function.

Exercise 10.4.

Give a construction similar to that in Exercise 10.3 for eigenfunctions of the center of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq127.gif) when ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq128.gif).

Exercise 10.5 (Schur's lemma).

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq129.gif) be a Lie algebra, and let V, W be ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq130.gif)-modules.

(i)

Show that the space of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq131.gif)-module homomorphisms ϕ: V → W is at most one-dimensional.

(ii)

Show that the space of invariant bilinear forms ![
$$V \\times W \\rightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_10_Chapter_IEq132.gif) is at most one-dimensional.

# 11. Extension of Scalars

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

We will be interested in complex representations of both real and complex Lie algebras. There is an important distinction to be made. If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq1.gif) is a real Lie algebra, then a complex representation is an ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq2.gif)-linear homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq3.gif), where V is a complex vector space. On the other hand, if ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq4.gif) is a complex Lie algebra, we require that the homomorphism be ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq5.gif)-linear. The reader should note that we ask more of a complex representation of a complex Lie algebra than we do of a complex representation of a real Lie algebra.

We will be interested in complex representations of both real and complex Lie algebras. There is an important distinction to be made. If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq6.gif) is a real Lie algebra, then a complex representation is an ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq7.gif)-linear homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq8.gif), where V is a complex vector space. On the other hand, if ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is a complex Lie algebra, we require that the homomorphism be ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq10.gif)-linear. The reader should note that we ask more of a complex representation of a complex Lie algebra than we do of a complex representation of a real Lie algebra.

The interplay between real and complex Lie groups and Lie algebras will prove important to us. We begin this theme right here with some generalities about extension of scalars.

If R is a commutative ring and S is a larger commutative ring containing R, we may think of S as an R-algebra. In this case, there are functors between the categories of R-modules and S-modules. Namely, if N is an S-module, we may regard it as an R-module. On the other hand, if M is an R-module, then thinking of S as an R-module, we may form the R-module ![
$$M_{S} = S \\otimes _{R}M$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq11.gif). This has an S-module structure such that ![
$$t\(s \\otimes m\) = ts \\otimes m$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq12.gif) for t,s ∈ S, and m ∈ M. We call this the S-module obtained by extension of scalars. If ![
$$\\phi : M \\longrightarrow N$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq1301.gif) is an R-module homomorphism, ![
$$1 \\otimes \\phi: M_{S}\\longrightarrow N_{S}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq13.gif) is an S-module homomorphism, so extension of scalars is a functor.

Of the properties of extension of scalars, we note the following:

Proposition 11.1.

Let S ⊇ R be commutative rings.

(i)

If M 1 and M 2 are R-modules, we have the following natural isomorphisms of S-modules:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ S \\otimes _{R}R\\mathop{\\cong}S, }$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(11.1)

![
$$\\displaystyle{ S \\otimes _{R}\(M_{1} \\oplus M_{2}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\(S \\otimes _{R}M_{1}\) \\oplus \(S \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(11.2)

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(S \\otimes _{R}M_{1}\) \\otimes _{S}\(S \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\)\\mathop{\\cong}S \\otimes _{R}\(M_{1} \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(11.3)

(ii)

If M is an R-module and N is an S-module, we have a natural isomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathrm{Hom}_{R}\(M,N\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Hom}_{S}\(S \\otimes _{R}M,N\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(11.4)

Proof.

To prove (11.1), note that the multiplication ![
$$S \\times R \\longrightarrow S$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq1601.gif) is an R-bilinear map hence by the universal property of the tensor product induces an R-module homomorphism ![
$$S \\otimes _{R}R\\longrightarrow S$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq14.gif). On the other hand, ![
$$s\\longrightarrow s \\otimes 1$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq15.gif) is an R-module homomorphism ![
$$S\\longrightarrow S \\otimes _{R}R$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq16.gif), and these maps are inverses of each other. With our definition of the S-module structure on ![
$$S \\otimes _{R}R$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq17.gif), they are S-module isomorphisms.

To prove (11.2), one may characterize the direct sum ![
$$M_{1} \\oplus M_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq18.gif) as follows: given an R-module M with maps ![
$$j_i : M_i \\longrightarrow M, p_i : M \\longrightarrow M_i \(i=1, 2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq1602.gif) such that ![
$$p_{i} \\circ j_{i} = 1_{M_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq19.gif) and ![
$$j_{1} \\circ p_{1} + j_{2} \\circ p_{2} = 1_{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq20.gif), then there are maps

![
$$\\displaystyle{M\\longrightarrow M_{1} \\oplus M_{2},m\\longmapsto \\big\(p_{1}\(m\),p_{2}\(m\)\\big\)\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equa.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{M_{1} \\oplus M_{2}\\longrightarrow M,\(m_{1},m_{2}\)\\longmapsto i_{1}m_{1} + i_{2}m_{2}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equb.gif)

These are easily checked to be inverses of each other, and so ![
$$M\\mathop{\\cong}M_{1} \\oplus M_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq21.gif). For example, if ![
$$M = M_{1} \\oplus M_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq22.gif), such maps exist—take the inclusion and projection maps in and out of the direct sum. Now applying the functor ![
$$M\\mapsto S \\otimes _{R}M$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq23.gif) to the maps ![
$$j_{1},j_{2},p_{1},p_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq24.gif) gives corresponding maps for ![
$$S \\otimes _{R}\(M_{1} \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq25.gif) showing that it is isomorphic to the left-hand side of (11.2).

To prove (11.3), one has an S-bilinear map

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(S \\otimes _{R}M_{1}\) \\times \(S \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\)\\longrightarrow S \\otimes _{R}\(M_{1} \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(11.5)

such that ![
$$\\big\(\(s_{1} \\otimes m_{1}\),\(s_{2} \\otimes m_{2}\)\\big\)\\mapsto s_{1}s_{2} \\otimes \(m_{1} \\otimes m_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq26.gif). This map is S-bilinear, so it induces a homomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(S \\otimes _{R}M_{1}\) \\otimes _{S}\(S \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\)\\longrightarrow S \\otimes _{R}\(M_{1} \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(11.6)

Similarly, there is an R-bilinear map

![
$$\\displaystyle{S \\times \(M_{1} \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\)\\longrightarrow \(S \\otimes _{R}M_{1}\) \\otimes _{S}\(S \\otimes _{R}M_{2}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equc.gif)

such that ![
$$\(s,m_{1} \\otimes m_{2}\)\\mapsto \(s \\otimes m_{1}\) \\otimes \(1 \\otimes m_{2}\) = \(1 \\otimes m_{1}\) \\otimes \(s \\otimes m_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq27.gif). This induces an S-module homomorphism that is the inverse to (11.6).

To prove (11.4), we describe the correspondence explicitly. If

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\phi \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{R}\(M,N\)\\quad \\mathrm{and}\\quad \\varPhi \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{S}\(S \\otimes M,N\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equd.gif)

then ϕ and Φ correspond if ![
$$\\phi \(m\) =\\varPhi \(1 \\otimes m\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq28.gif) and ![
$$\\varPhi \(s \\otimes m\) = s\\phi \(m\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq29.gif). It is easily checked that ![
$$\\phi \\mapsto \\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq30.gif) and ![
$$\\varPhi \\mapsto \\phi $$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq31.gif) are well-defined inverse isomorphisms. □

If V is a d-dimensional real vector space, then the complex vector space ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathbb{C} \\otimes _{\\mathbb{R}}V$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq32.gif) is a d-dimensional complex vector space. This follows from Proposition 11.1 because if ![
$$V \\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{R} \\oplus \\ldots \\oplus \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq33.gif) (d copies), then (11.1) and (11.2) imply that ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{C} \\oplus \\cdots \\oplus \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq34.gif) (d copies). We call ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq35.gif) the complexification of V. The natural map ![
$$V \\longrightarrow V _{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq36.gif) given by ![
$$v\\mapsto 1 \\otimes v$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq37.gif) is injective, so we may think of V as a real vector subspace of ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq38.gif).

Proposition 11.2.

(i)

If V is a real vector space and W is a complex vector space, any ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq39.gif) -linear transformation ![
$$V \\longrightarrow W$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq4403.gif) extends uniquely to a ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq40.gif) -linear transformation ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow W$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq41.gif).

(ii)

If V and U are real vector spaces, any ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq42.gif) -linear transformation ![
$$V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq4401.gif) extends uniquely to a ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq43.gif) -linear map ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow U_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq44.gif).

(iii)

If V and U are real vector spaces, any ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq45.gif) -bilinear map V × ![
$$V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq4402.gif) extends uniquely to a ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq46.gif) -bilinear map ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}} \\times V _{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow U_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq47.gif).

Proof.

Part (i) is a special case of (ii) of Proposition 11.1. Part (ii) follows by taking ![
$$W = U_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq48.gif) in part (i) after composing the given linear map ![
$$V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq4406.gif) with the inclusion ![
$$V \\longrightarrow W$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq4405.gif). As for (iii), an ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq49.gif)-bilinear map V × ![
$$V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq4407.gif) induces an ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq50.gif)-linear map ![
$$V \\otimes _{\\mathbb{R}}V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq51.gif) and hence by (ii) a ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq52.gif)-linear map ![
$$\(V \\otimes _{\\mathbb{R}}V \)_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow U_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq53.gif). But by (11.3), ![
$$\(V \\otimes _{\\mathbb{R}}V \)_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq54.gif) is ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}} \\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}}V _{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq55.gif), and a ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq56.gif)-linear map ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}} \\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}}V _{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow U_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq57.gif) is the same thing as a ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq58.gif)-bilinear map ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}} \\times V _{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow U_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq59.gif). □

Proposition 11.3.

(i)

The complexification ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq60.gif) of a real Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq61.gif) with the bracket extended as in Proposition 11.2 (iii) is a Lie algebra.

(ii)

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq62.gif) is a real Lie algebra, ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq63.gif) is a complex Lie algebra, and ![
$$\\rho: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq64.gif) is a real Lie algebra homomorphism, then ρ extends uniquely to a homomorphism ![
$$\\rho _{\\mathbb{C}}: \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq65.gif) of complex Lie algebras. In particular, any complex representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq66.gif) extends uniquely to a complex representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq67.gif).

(iii)

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq68.gif) is a real Lie subalgebra of the complex Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq69.gif) , and if ![
$$\\mathfrak{h} = \\mathfrak{g} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq70.gif) (i.e., if ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq71.gif) and ![
$$i\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq72.gif) span ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq73.gif) but ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} \\cap i\\mathfrak{g} =\\{ 0\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq74.gif) ), then ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq75.gif) as complex Lie algebras.

Proof.

For (i), the extended bracket satisfies the Jacobi identity since both sides of (5.​1) are trilinear maps on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}} \\times \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}} \\times \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq76.gif), which by assumption vanish on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} \\times \\mathfrak{g} \\times \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq77.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq78.gif) generates ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq79.gif) over the complex numbers, (5.​1) is therefore true on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq80.gif).

For (ii), the extension is given by Proposition 11.2 (i), taking ![
$$W = \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq81.gif). To see that the extension is a Lie algebra homomorphism, note that both ρ([x,y]) and ρ(x)ρ(y) − ρ(y)ρ(x) are bilinear maps ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}} \\times \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq82.gif) that agree on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} \\times \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq83.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq84.gif) generates ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq85.gif) over ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq86.gif), they are equal for all ![
$$x,y \\in \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq87.gif).

For (iii), by Proposition 11.2 (i), it will be least confusing to distinguish between ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq88.gif) and its image in ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq89.gif), so we prove instead the following equivalent statement: if ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq90.gif) is a real Lie algebra, ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq91.gif) is a complex Lie algebra, ![
$$f: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq92.gif) is an injective homomorphism, and if ![
$$\\mathfrak{h} = f\(\\mathfrak{g}\) \\oplus i\\,f\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq93.gif), then f extends to an isomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq94.gif) of complex Lie algebras. Now f extends to a Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$f_{\\mathbb{C}}: \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq95.gif) by part (ii). To see that this is an isomorphism, note that it is surjective since ![
$$f\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq96.gif) spans ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq97.gif). To prove that it is injective, if ![
$$f_{\\mathbb{C}}\(X + iY \) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq98.gif) with ![
$$X,Y \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq99.gif), then ![
$$f\(X\) + if\(Y \) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq100.gif). Now ![
$$f\(X\) = f\(Y \) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq101.gif) because ![
$$f\(\\mathfrak{g}\) \\cap if\(\\mathfrak{g}\) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq102.gif). Since f is injective, ![
$$X = Y = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq103.gif). □

Of course, given any complex representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq104.gif), we may also restrict it to ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq105.gif), so Proposition 11.3 implies that complex representations of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq106.gif) and complex representations of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq107.gif) are really the same thing. (They are equivalent categories.)

As an example, let us consider the complexification of ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq108.gif).

Proposition 11.4.

(i)

Every n × n complex matrix X can be written uniquely as X 1 \+ iX 2 , where X 1 and X 2 are n × n complex matrices satisfying ![
$$X_{1} = {-}^{t}X_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq109.gif) and X 2 = t X 2.

(ii)

The complexification of the real Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq110.gif) is isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq111.gif).

(iii)

The complexification of the real Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq112.gif) is isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq113.gif).

Proof.

For (i), the unique solution is clearly

![
$$\\displaystyle{X_{1} = \\tfrac{1} {2}\(X {-}^{t}X\),\\qquad X_{ 2} = \\tfrac{1} {2i}\(X {+ }^{t}X\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Eque.gif)

For (ii), we will use the criterion of Proposition 11.3 (iii). We recall that ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq114.gif) is the real Lie algebra consisting of complex n × n matrices satisfying ![
$$X = \\overline{ {-}^{t}X}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq115.gif). We want to get the complex conjugation out of the picture before we try to complexify it, so we write ![
$$X = X_{1} + iX_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq116.gif), where X 1 and X 2 are real n × n matrices. We must have ![
$$X_{1} = {-}^{t}X_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq117.gif) and ![
$$X_{2} {= }^{t}X_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq118.gif). Thus, as a vector space, we may identify ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq119.gif) with the real vector space of pairs ![
$$\(X_{1},X_{2}\) \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\) \\oplus \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq120.gif), where X 1 is skew-symmetric and X 2 symmetric. The Lie bracket operation, required by the condition that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \[X,Y \] = XY - Y X\\text{ when }X = X_{1} + iX_{2}\\text{ and }Y = Y _{1} + iY _{2}, }$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(11.7)

amounts to the rule

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & \[\(X_{1},X_{2}\),\(Y _{1},Y _{2}\)\] \\\\ & & \\quad = \(X_{1}Y _{1} - X_{2}Y _{2} - Y _{1}X_{1} + Y _{2}X_{2},X_{1}Y _{2} + X_{2}Y _{1} - Y _{2}X_{1} - Y _{1}X_{2}\).\\qquad \\quad {}\\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(11.8)

Now (i) shows that the complexification of this vector space (allowing X 1 and X 2 to be complex) can be identified with ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq121.gif). Of course, (11.7) and (11.8) are still equivalent if X 1, X 2, Y 1, and Y 2 are allowed to be complex, so with the Lie bracket in (11.8), this Lie algebra is ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq122.gif) with the usual bracket.

(iii) is similar to (ii), and we leave it to the reader. □

Theorem 11.1.

Every complex representation of the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq123.gif) or the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq124.gif) extends uniquely to a complex representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq125.gif) . Every complex representation of the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq126.gif) or the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq127.gif) extends uniquely to a complex representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq128.gif).

Proof.

This follows from Proposition 11.3 since the complexification of ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq129.gif) or ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq130.gif) is ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq131.gif), while the complexification of ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq132.gif) or ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq133.gif) is ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq134.gif). For ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq135.gif) or ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq136.gif), this is obvious. For ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq137.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_11_Chapter_IEq138.gif), this is Proposition 11.4. □
