# 14. The Local Frobenius Theorem

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

Let M be an n-dimensional smooth manifold. The tangent bundle TM of M is the disjoint union of all tangent spaces of points of M. It can be given the structure of a manifold of dimension ![
$$2\\dim \(M\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq1.gif) as follows. If U is a coordinate neighborhood and x 1,..., x n are local coordinates on U, then ![
$$T\(U\) =\\{ T_{x}M\\,\\vert \\,x \\in U\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq2.gif) can be taken to be a coordinate neighborhood of TM.

Let M be an n-dimensional smooth manifold. The tangent bundle T M of M is the disjoint union of all tangent spaces of points of M. It can be given the structure of a manifold of dimension ![
$$2\\dim \(M\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq3.gif) as follows. If U is a coordinate neighborhood and x 1,..., x n are local coordinates on U, then ![
$$T\(U\) =\\{ T_{x}M\\,\\vert \\,x \\in U\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq4.gif) can be taken to be a coordinate neighborhood of TM. Every element of T x M with x ∈ U can be written uniquely as

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{i=1}^{n}a_{ i} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}},}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equa.gif)

and mapping this tangent vector to ![
$$\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n},a_{1},\\ldots,a_{n}\) \\in {\\mathbb{R}}^{2n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq5.gif) gives a chart on T(U), making TM into a manifold.

By a d-dimensional family D in the tangent bundle of M we mean a rule that associates with each x ∈ M a d-dimensional subspace D x ⊂ T x (M). We ask that the family be smooth. By this we mean that in a neighborhood U of any given point x there are smooth vector fields X 1,..., X d such that for u ∈ U the vectors ![
$$X_{i,u} \\in T_{u}\(M\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq6.gif) span D u .

We say that a vector field X is subordinate to the family D if X x ∈ D x for all x ∈ U. The family is called involutory if whenever X and Y are vector fields subordinate to D then so is [X, Y ]. This definition is motivated by the following considerations.

An integral manifold of the family D is a d-dimensional submanifold N such that, for each point x ∈ N, the tangent space T x (N), identified with its image in T x (M), is D x . We may ask whether it is possible, at least locally in a neighborhood of every point, to pass an integral manifold. This is surely a natural question.

Let us observe that if it is true, then the family D is involutory. To see this (at least plausibly), let U be an open set in M that is small enough that through each point in U there is an integral submanifold that is closed in U. Let J be the subspace of C ∞ (U) consisting of functions that are constant on these integral submanifolds. Then the restriction of a vector field X to U is subordinate to D if and only if it annihilates J. It is clear from (6.​6) that if X and Y have this property, then so does [X, Y ].

The Frobenius theorem is a converse to this observation. A global version may be found in Chevalley [35]. We will content ourselves with the local theorem.

Lemma 14.1.

If X 1 ,...,X d are vector fields on M such that ![
$$\[X_{i},X_{j}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq7.gif) lies in the C ∞ (M) span of X 1 ,...,X d , and if for each x ∈ M we define D x to be the span of X 1x ,...,X dx , then D is an involutory family.

Proof.

Any vector field subordinate to D has the form (locally near x) ![
$$\\sum _{i}f_{i}X_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq8.gif), where f i are smooth functions. To check that the commutator of two such vector fields is also of the same form amounts to using the formula

![
$$\\displaystyle{\[fX,gY \] = fg\[X,Y \] + fX\(g\)Y - gY \(f\)X,}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equb.gif)

which follows easily on applying both sides to a function h and using the fact that X and Y are derivations of C ∞ (M). □

Theorem 14.1 (Frobenius).

Let D be a smooth involutory d-dimensional family in the tangent bundle of M. Then for each point x ∈ M there exists a neighborhood U of x and an integral manifold N of D through x in U. If N′ is another integral manifold through x, then N and N′ coincide near x. That is, there exists a neighborhood V of x such that ![
$$V \\cap N = V \\cap N^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq9.gif) .

Proof.

Since this is a strictly local statement, it is sufficient to prove this when M is an open set in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq10.gif) and x is the origin.

We show first that if X is a vector field that does not vanish at x, then we may find a system y 1,..., y n of coordinates in which ![
$$X = \\partial /\\partial y_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq11.gif). Let x 1,..., x n be the standard Cartesian functions. Since X does not vanish at the origin, the function X(x i ) does not vanish at the origin for some i, so after permuting the variables if necessary, we may assume that X(x n )≠0. Write

![
$$\\displaystyle{X = a_{1} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{1}} + \\cdots + a_{n} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{n}}}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equc.gif)

in terms of smooth functions ![
$$a_{i} = a_{i}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq12.gif). Then a n (0,...,0)≠0.

The new coordinate system y 1,..., y n will have the property that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(y_{1},\\ldots,y_{n-1},0\) = \(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n-1},0\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equd.gif)

To describe (y 1,..., y n ) when y n ≠0, let us fix small numbers ![
$$u_{1},\\ldots,u_{n-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq13.gif). Then we will describe the path which is, in the y coordinates,

![
$$\\displaystyle{t\\longmapsto \(u_{1},\\ldots,u_{n-1},t\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Eque.gif)

This path is to be an integral curve for the vector field through the point ![
$$\(u_{1},\\ldots,u_{n-1},0\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq14.gif). By Proposition 8.1 a unique such path exists (for t small). Thus, we have a path that is (in the x coordinates) ![
$$t\\longrightarrow \\left \(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\right \),$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq15.gif) satisfying the first-order system

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} x_{i}^{\\prime}\(t\)& =& a_{i}\\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\), \\\\ \\left \(x_{i}\(0\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(0\)\\right \)& =& \(u_{1},\\ldots,u_{n-1},0\).{}\\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(14.1)

For u 1,..., u n−1 sufficiently small, we have ![
$$a_{n}\(u_{1},\\ldots,u_{n-1},0\)\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq16.gif) and so this integral curve is transverse to the hyperplane x n = 0. We choose our coordinate system y 1,..., y n so that

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & y_{i}\\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\) = u_{i},\(i = 1,2,3,\\ldots,n - 1\), {}\\\\ & & y_{n}\\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\) = t. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

Now ![
$$\\partial x_{i}/\\partial y_{n} = a_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq17.gif) because the partial derivative is the derivative along one of the paths (14.1). Thus

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial y_{n}} =\\sum _{i} \\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial y_{n}} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}} =\\sum _{i}a_{i} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}} = X.}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equf.gif)

This proves that there exists a coordinate system in which ![
$$X = \\partial /\\partial y_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq18.gif).

If d = 1, the result is proved by this. We will assume that d > 1 and that the existence of integral manifolds is known for lower-dimensional involutory families. Let X 1,..., X d be smooth vector fields such that X i, u span D u for u near the origin. We have just shown that we may assume that ![
$$X = X_{d} = \\partial /\\partial y_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq19.gif). Since D is involutory, ![
$$\[X_{d},X_{i}\] =\\sum _{j}g_{ij}X_{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq20.gif) for smooth functions g ij . We will show that we can arrange things so that g id = 0 when i < d; that is,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \[X_{d},X_{i}\] =\\sum _{ j=1}^{d-1}g_{ ij}X_{j},\(i < d\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(14.2)

Indeed, writing

![
$$\\displaystyle{ X_{i} =\\sum _{ k=1}^{n}h_{ ik} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial y_{k}},\\qquad \(i = 1,\\ldots,d - 1\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(14.3)

we will still have a spanning set if we subtract h in X d from X i . We may therefore assume that h in = 0 for i < d. Thus

![
$$\\displaystyle{ X_{i} =\\sum _{ k=1}^{n-1}h_{ ik} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial y_{k}},\(i = 1,\\ldots,d - 1\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(14.4)

In other words, we may assume that X i does not involve ![
$$\\partial /\\partial y_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq21.gif) for i < d. Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \[X_{d},X_{i}\] =\\sum _{ k=1}^{n-1}\\frac{\\partial h_{ik}} {\\partial y_{n}} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial y_{j}}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(14.5)

On the other hand, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\[X_{d},X_{i}\] =\\sum _{ j=1}^{d-1}g_{ ij}X_{j} + g_{id}X_{d} =\\sum _{ j=1}^{d-1}\\sum _{ k=1}^{n-1}g_{ ij}h_{jk} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial y_{k}} + g_{id} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial y_{n}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equg.gif)

Comparing the coefficients of ![
$$\\partial /\\partial y_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq22.gif) in this expression with that in (14.5) shows that g id = 0, proving (14.2).

Next we show that if (c 1,..., c d−1) are real constants, then there exist smooth functions f 1,..., f d−1 such that for small y 1,..., y n−1 we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ f_{i}\(y_{1},y_{2},\\ldots,y_{n-1},0\) = c_{i},\(i = 1,\\ldots,d - 1\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(14.6)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \[X_{d},\\sum _{i=1}^{d-1}f_{ i}X_{i}\\right \] = 0.}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equh.gif)

Indeed,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \[X_{d},\\sum _{i=1}^{d-1}f_{ i}X_{i}\\right \] =\\sum _{ i=1}^{d=1} \\frac{\\partial f_{i}} {\\partial y_{n}}X_{i} +\\sum _{ i,j=1}^{d-1}f_{ i}g_{ij}X_{j}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equi.gif)

For this to be zero, we need the f i to be solutions to the first-order system

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\frac{\\partial f_{j}} {\\partial y_{n}} +\\sum _{ i=1}^{d-1}g_{ ij}f_{i} = 0,j = 1,\\ldots,d - 1.}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equj.gif)

This first-order system has a solution locally with the prescribed initial condition.

Since the c i can be arbitrary, we may choose

![
$$\\displaystyle{c_{i} = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} 1&\\text{if}\\,i = 1,\\\\ 0 &\\text{otherwise.} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Then the vector field ![
$$\\sum f_{i}X_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq23.gif) agrees with X 1 on the hyperplane y n = 0. Replacing X 1 by ∑ f i X i , we may therefore assume that [X d ,X 1] = 0. Repeating this process, we may similarly assume that ![
$$\[X_{d},X_{i}\] = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq24.gif) for all i < d. Now with the h ij as in (14.3), this means that ![
$$\\partial h_{ij}/\\partial y_{n} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq25.gif), so the h ij are independent of y n .

Since the h ij are independent of y n , we may interpret (14.4) as defining d − 1 vector fields on ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq26123.gif). They span a (d − 1)-dimensional involutory family of tangent vectors in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) and by induction there exists an integral manifold for this vector field. If this manifold is ![
$$N_{0} \\subset {\\mathbb{R}}^{n-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq28132.gif), then it is clear that

![
$$\\displaystyle{N =\\{ \(y_{1},\\ldots,y_{n}\)\\vert \(y_{1},\\ldots,y_{n-1}\) \\in N_{0}\\}}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equl.gif)

is an integral manifold for D.

We have established the existence of an integral submanifold. The local uniqueness of the integral submanifold can also be proved now. In fact, if we repeat the process by which we selected the coordinate system ![
$$y_{1},\\ldots,y_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) so that the vector field ![
$$\\partial /\\partial y_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) was subordinate to the involutory family D, we eventually arrive at a system in which D is spanned by ![
$$\\partial /\\partial y_{n-d+1},\\ldots,\\partial /\\partial y_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq31123.gif). Then the integral manifold is given by the equations ![
$$y_{1} = \\cdots = y_{n-d} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq32123.gif). □

If G is a Lie group, a local subgroup of G consists of an open neighborhood U of the identity and a closed subset K of U such that 1 G ∈ K, and if x, y ∈ K such that xy ∈ U, then xy ∈ K, and if x ∈ K such that x −1 ∈ U, then x −1 ∈ K. For example, if H is a closed subgroup of G and U is any open set, then ![
$$U \\cap H$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) is a local subgroup.

Proposition 14.1.

Let G be a Lie group with Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) , and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq35.gif) be a Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq36.gif) . Then there exists a local subgroup K of G with a tangent space at the identity that is ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq37.gif) . The exponential map sends a neighborhood of the identity in ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq38.gif) onto a neighborhood of the identity in K.

Proof.

The Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq39.gif) of G has two incarnations : as the tangent space to the identity of G and as the set of left-invariant vector fields. For definiteness, we identify ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = T_{e}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq40.gif) and recall how the left-invariant vector field arises.

If g ∈ G, let ![
$$\\lambda _{g} : G\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq41.gif) be left translation by g, so that λ g (x) = gx. Let ![
$$\\lambda _{g{\\ast}} : T_{e}\(G\)\\longrightarrow T_{x}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq42.gif) be the induced map of tangent spaces. Then the left-invariant vector field associated with ![
$$X_{e} \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq43.gif) has ![
$$X_{g} = \\lambda _{g{\\ast}}\(X_{e}\).$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq44.gif)

Let ![
$$d =\\dim \(\\mathfrak{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq45.gif) and let D be the d-dimensional family of tangent vectors such that ![
$$D_{g} = \\lambda _{g{\\ast}}\(\\mathfrak{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq46.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq47.gif) is closed under the bracket, it follows from Lemma 14.1 that D is involutory, so there exists an integral submanifold K in a neighborhood U of the identity. We will show that if U is sufficiently small, then K is a local group.

Indeed, let x and y be elements of K such that xy ∈ U. Since the vector fields associated with elements of ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq48.gif) are left-invariant, the involutory family D is invariant under left translation. The image of K under right translation by x is also an integral submanifold of D through x, so this submanifold is K itself. These submanifolds therefore coincide near x and, since y is in K, its left translate xy by x is also in K.

Since the one-parameter subgroups exp(tX) with ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq49.gif) are tangent to the left-invariant vector field at every point, they are contained in the integral submanifold K near the identity, and the image of a neighborhood of the identity under exp is a manifold of the same dimension as K, so the last statement is clear. □

We recall that the notion of a local homomorphism was defined in Chap.  before Theorem 13.3.

Proposition 14.2.

Let G and H be Lie groups with Lie algebras ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq50.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq51.gif) , respectively, and let ![
$$\\pi : \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq52.gif) be a Lie algebra homomorphism. Then there exists a neighborhood U of G and a local homomorphism ![
$$\\pi : U\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq53.gif) whose differential is π.

Proof.

The tangent space to G × H at the identity is ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} \\oplus \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq54.gif). Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{k} =\\{\\big \(X,\\pi \(X\)\\big\)\\,\\vert \\,X \\in \\mathfrak{g}\\} \\subset \\mathfrak{g} \\oplus \\mathfrak{h}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_Equm.gif)

It is a Lie subalgebra, corresponding by Proposition 14.1 to a local subgroup K of G × H. The tangent space to the identity of K is thus its Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq55.gif), which intersects ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq56.gif) in ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} \\oplus \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq57.gif) transversally in a single point. Thus ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq58.gif) is the direct sum of ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq59.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq60.gif). Concretely, this reflects the fact that ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq61.gif) is the graph of a map ![
$$\\pi : \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq62.gif). Using the inverse function theorem, the same is true locally of K : since its tangent space at the identity is a direct sum complement of the tangent space of H in the tangent space of G × H, it is, locally, the graph of a mapping. Thus, there exists a map ![
$$\\pi : U\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq63.gif) of a sufficiently small neighborhood of the identity in G such that if (g, h) ∈ G × H, g ∈ U, and h ∈ π(U), then (g, h) ∈ K if and only if h = π(g). Because K is a local subgroup, this implies that π is a local homomorphism. □

Theorem 14.2.

Let G and H be Lie groups with Lie algebras ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq64.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq65.gif) , respectively, and let ![
$$\\pi : \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq66.gif) be a Lie algebra homomorphism. Assume that G is simply connected. Then there exists a Lie group homomorphism ![
$$\\pi : G\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq67.gif) with differential π.

Proof.

This follows from Proposition 14.2 and Theorem 13.3. □

We can now give another proof of Theorem 12.2. The basic idea here is to use a compact subgroup to prove the complete reducibility of some class of representations of a noncompact group. This idea was called the "Unitarian Trick" by Hermann Weyl. We will extend the validity of Theorem 12.2, though the algebraic method would work as well for this.

Theorem 14.3.

Let G and K be Lie groups with Lie algebras ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq68.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq69.gif) . Assume K is compact and simply connected. Suppose that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq70.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq71.gif) have isomorphic complexifications. Then every finite-dimensional irreducible complex representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq72.gif) is completely reducible. If G is connected, then every irreducible complex representation of G is completely reducible.

Proof.

Let (π,V ) be a finite-dimensional representation of G, and let W be a proper nonzero invariant subspace. We will show that there is another invariant subspace W′ such that ![
$$V = W \\oplus W^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq73.gif). By induction on ![
$$\\dim \(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq74.gif), it will follow that both W and W′ are direct sums of irreducible representations.

The differential of π is a complex representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq75.gif). As in Proposition 11.3, we may extend it to a representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq76.gif) and then restrict it to ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq77.gif). Since K is simply connected, the resulting Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq78.gif) is the differential of a Lie group homomorphism ![
$$\\pi _{K} : K\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq79.gif).

Now, because K is compact, this representation of K is completely reducible (Proposition 2.2). Thus, there exists a K-invariant subspace W′ such that ![
$$V = W \\oplus W^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq80.gif). Of course, W′ is also invariant with respect to ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq81.gif) and hence ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq82.gif), and hence ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq83.gif). It is therefore invariant under ![
$$\\exp \(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq84.gif). If G is connected, it is generated by a neighborhood of the identity, and so W′ is G-invariant. □

Theorem 14.4.

Let (π,V ) be a finite-dimensional irreducible complex representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq85.gif), ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq86.gif) , or ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq87.gif) . If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq88.gif) is ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}l\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq89.gif) then assume that ![
$$\\pi : \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq90.gif) is complex linear. Then π is completely reducible.

Proof.

We will prove this for ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq91.gif)) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq92.gif). By Theorem 13.6, K is simply-connected and the hypotheses of Theorem 14.3 are satisfied. For ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq93.gif), we can take ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq94.gif), ![
$$K = \\mathrm{SU}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq95.gif). For ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq96.gif), we can take ![
$$G = K = \\mathrm{SU}\(n\).$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq97.gif)

The case of ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq98.gif) requires a minor modification to Theorem 14.3 and is left to the reader. □

Theorem 14.5.

Let (π,V ) be a finite-dimensional irreducible complex representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq99.gif) . Then π is completely reducible.

Proof.

We take ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq100.gif), ![
$$K = \\mathrm{SU}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq101.gif). □

Let G be a connected complex analytic Lie group, and let K ⊂ G be a compact Lie subgroup. Let ![

](A79351_2_En_14_Chapter_IEq103.gif) be the Lie algebras of G and K, respectively. Assume that ![

# 15. Tori

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

A complex manifold M is constructed analogously to a smooth manifold. We specify an atlas ![
$$\\mathcal{U} =\\{ \(U,\\phi \)\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq1.gif), where each chart ![
$$U \\subset M$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq2.gif) is an open set and ![
$$\\phi: U\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq3.gif) is a homeomorphism of U onto its image that is assumed to be open in ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq4.gif). It is assumed that the transition functions ![
$$\\psi \\circ {\\phi }^{-1}: \\phi \(U \\cap V \)\\longrightarrow \\psi \(U \\cap V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq5.gif) are holomorphic for any two charts (U,ϕ) and (V,ψ). A complex Lie group (or complex analytic group) is a Hausdorff topological group that is a complex manifold in which the multiplication and inversion maps ![
$$G \\times G\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq6.gif) and ![
$$G\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq7.gif) are holomorphic. The Lie algebra of a complex Lie group is a complex Lie algebra. For example, ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq8.gif) is a complex Lie group.

A complex manifold M is constructed analogously to a smooth manifold. We specify an atlas ![
$$\\mathcal{U} =\\{ \(U,\\phi \)\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq9.gif), where each chart ![
$$U \\subset M$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq10.gif) is an open set and ![
$$\\phi: U\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq11.gif) is a homeomorphism of U onto its image that is assumed to be open in ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq12.gif). It is assumed that the transition functions ![
$$\\psi \\circ {\\phi }^{-1}: \\phi \(U \\cap V \)\\longrightarrow \\psi \(U \\cap V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq13.gif) are holomorphic for any two charts (U,ϕ) and (V,ψ). A complex Lie group (or complex analytic group) is a Hausdorff topological group that is a complex manifold in which the multiplication and inversion maps ![
$$G \\times G\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq14.gif) and ![
$$G\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq15.gif) are holomorphic. The Lie algebra of a complex Lie group is a complex Lie algebra. For example, ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq16.gif) is a complex Lie group.

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq17.gif) is a Lie algebra and ![
$$X,Y \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq18.gif), we say that X and Y commute if [X,Y ] = 0. We call the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq19.gif) Abelian if [X,Y ] = 0 for all ![
$$X,Y \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq20.gif).

Proposition 15.1.

The Lie algebra of an Abelian Lie group is Abelian.

Proof.

The action of G on itself by conjugation is trivial, so the induced action Ad of G on its Lie algebra is trivial. By Theorem 8.2, it follows that ![
$$\\text{ad}: \\text{Lie}\(G\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}\\big\(\\text{Lie}\(G\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq21.gif) is the zero map, so ![
$$\[X,Y \] = \\text{ad}\(X\)Y = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq22.gif). □

Proposition 15.2.

If G is a Lie group, and X and Y are commuting elements of ![
$$\\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq23.gif) , then ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{X+Y } ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{X}{\\mathrm{e}}^{Y }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq24.gif) . In particular, ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{X}{\\mathrm{e}}^{Y } ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{Y }{\\mathrm{e}}^{X}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq25.gif) .

Proof.

First note that, since the differential of ![
$$\\text{Ad}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq26.gif) is ![
$$\\text{ad}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq27.gif) (Theorem 8.2), ![
$$\\text{Ad}\({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\)Y = Y$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq28.gif) for all t. Recalling that ![
$$\\text{Ad}\({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq29.gif) is the endomorphism of ![
$$\\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq30.gif) induced by conjugation, this means that conjugation by ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq31.gif) takes the one-parameter subgroup ![
$$u\\longrightarrow {\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) to itself, so ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }{\\mathrm{e}}^{-tX} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{uY }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq33.gif). Thus, ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq34.gif) and ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq35.gif) commute for all real t and u.

We recall from Chap.  that the path ![
$$p\(t\) ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{tY }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq36.gif) is characterized by the fact that ![
$$p\(0\) = 1_{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq37.gif), while ![
$$p_{{\\ast}}\(\\mathrm{d}/\\mathrm{d}t\) = Y _{p\(t\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq38.gif). The latter condition means that if ![
$$f \\in {C}^{\\infty }\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq39.gif) we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\\big\(p\(t\)\\big\) = \(Y f\)\\big\(p\(t\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Let ![
$$q\(t,u\) ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{tX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq40.gif). The vector field Y is invariant under left translation, in particular left translation by ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq41.gif), so

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial u}f\\big\(q\(t,u\)\\big\) = \(Y f\)\({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Equb.gif)

Similarly (making use of ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{uY } ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{uY }{\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq42.gif)),

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial t}f\\big\(q\(t,u\)\\big\) = \(Xf\)\({\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{uY }\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Equc.gif)

Now, by the chain rule,

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}v}\\,f\\big\(q\(v,v\)\\big\)& =& \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial t}\\,f\\big\(q\(t,u\)\\big\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{t=u=v} + \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial u}\\,f\\big\(q\(t,u\)\\big\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{t=u=v} {}\\\\ & =& \(Y f + Xf\)\\big\(q\(v,v\)\\big\)\\,. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

This means that the path ![
$$v\\longrightarrow r\(v\) = q\(v,v\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq43.gif) satisfies ![
$$r_{{\\ast}}\(\\mathrm{d}/\\mathrm{d}v\) = \(X + Y \)_{r\(v\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq44.gif) whence ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{v\(X+Y \)} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{vX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{vY }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq45.gif). Taking v = 1, the result is proved. □

A compact torus is a compact connected Lie group that is Abelian. In the context of Lie group theory a compact torus is usually just called a torus, though in the context of algebraic groups the term "torus" is used slightly differently.

For example, ![
$$\\mathbb{T} =\\{ z \\in {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }\\,\\big\\vert \\,\\vert z\\vert = 1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq46.gif) is a torus. This group is isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq47.gif). Even though ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq48.gif) and ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq49.gif) are additive groups, we may, during the following discussion, sometimes write the group law in ![
$$\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq50.gif) multiplicatively.

Proposition 15.3.

Let T be a torus, and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq51.gif) be its Lie algebra. Then ![
$$\\exp: \\mathfrak{t}\\longrightarrow T$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq52.gif) is a homomorphism, and its kernel is a lattice. We have ![
$$T\\mathop{\\cong}{\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{T}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq53.gif) , where r is the dimension of T.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq54.gif) be the Lie algebra of T. Since T is Abelian, so is ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq55.gif), and by Proposition 15.2, ![
$$\\exp$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq56.gif) is a homomorphism from the additive group ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq57.gif) to T. The kernel ![
$$\\varLambda \\subset \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq58.gif) is discrete since ![
$$\\exp$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq59.gif) is a local homeomorphism, and Λ is cocompact since T is compact. Thus, Λ is a lattice and ![
$$T\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathfrak{t}/\\varLambda \\mathop{\\cong}{\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{T}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq60.gif). □

A character of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq61.gif) of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\)\\mapsto {\\mathrm{e}}^{2\\pi i\\big\(\\sum k_{j}x_{j}\\big\)}\\,, }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(15.1)

where ![
$$\(k_{1},\\ldots,k_{r}\) \\in {\\mathbb{Z}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq62.gif), induces a character on ![
$${\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq63.gif).

Proposition 15.4.

Every irreducible complex representation of ![
$${\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq64.gif) coincides with (15.1) for suitable ![
$$k_{i} \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq65.gif) .

Proof.

By classical Fourier analysis, these characters span ![
$${L}^{2}\\big\({\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq66.gif). Thus, the character χ of any complex representation ![
$$\\pi$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq67.gif) is not orthogonal to (15.1) for some ![
$$\(k_{1},\\ldots,k_{r}\) \\in {\\mathbb{Z}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq68.gif). By Schur orthogonality, χ agrees with this character. □

We also want to know the irreducible real representations of ![
$${\(\\mathbb{Z}/\\mathbb{R}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq69.gif). Let ![
$$k_{1},\\ldots,k_{r} \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq70.gif) be given. Assume that they are not all zero. The complex character (15.1) is not a real representation. However, regarding it as a homomorphism ![
$${\(\\mathbb{Z}/\\mathbb{R}\)}^{r}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq71.gif), we may compose it with the real representation ![
$$\\mathbb{T} \\ni t ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{2\\pi i\\theta }\\mapsto \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\cos \(2\\pi \\theta \) &\\sin \(2\\pi \\theta \)\\\\ -\\sin \(2\\pi \\theta \) &\\cos \(2\\pi \\theta \) \\end{array} \\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq72.gif) of ![
$$\\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq73.gif). We obtain a real representation

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\)\\mapsto \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\cos \(2\\pi \\sum k_{i}x_{i}\) &\\sin \(2\\pi \\sum k_{i}x_{i}\) \\\\ -\\sin \(2\\pi \\sum k_{i}x_{i}\)&\\cos \(2\\pi \\sum k_{i}x_{i}\) \\end{array} \\right \). }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(15.2)

Proposition 15.5.

Let ![
$$T = {\(\\mathbb{Z}/\\mathbb{R}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq74.gif) and let ( ![
$$\\pi,V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq75.gif) be an irreducible real representation. Then either ![
$$\\pi$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq76.gif) is trivial or ![
$$\\pi$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq77.gif) is two-dimensional and is one of the irreducible representations (15.2) with ![
$$k_{i} \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq78.gif) not all zero. In the two-dimensional case the complexified module ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathbb{C} \\otimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq79.gif) decomposes into two one-dimensional representations corresponding to a character and its inverse.

Proof.

It is straightforward to see that the real representation (15.2) is irreducible. The completeness of this set of irreducible real representations follows from the corresponding classification of the irreducible complex characters (Proposition 15.4). It is also easy to see that the complexified representation is equivalent to

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\)\\mapsto \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} {\\mathrm{e}}^{2\\pi i\\sum k_{i}x_{i}} \\\\ & {\\mathrm{e}}^{-2\\pi i\\sum k_{i}x_{i}} \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Equd.gif)

□

If T is a compact torus, we will associate with T a complex analytic group ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq80.gif), which we call the complexification of T. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq81.gif) be the complexification of the Lie algebra, and let ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}/\\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq82.gif), where ![
$$\\varLambda \\subset \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq83.gif) is the kernel of ![
$$\\exp: \\mathfrak{t}\\longrightarrow T$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq84.gif). It is easy to see that this construction is functorial: given a homomorphism ![
$$\\phi: T\\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq85.gif) of compact tori, the differential ![
$$\\phi _{{\\ast}}: \\mathrm{Lie}\(T\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Lie}\(U\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq86.gif) commutes with the exponential map, so ϕ∗ kills the kernel Λ of ![
$$\\exp: \\mathfrak{t}\\longrightarrow T$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq87.gif). Therefore, there is an induced map ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow U_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq88.gif).

If we identify ![
$$T = {\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq89.gif), the complexification ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}\\mathop{\\cong}{\(\\mathbb{C}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq90.gif). Since ![
$$x\\longrightarrow {\\mathrm{e}}^{2\\pi ix}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq91.gif) induces an isomorphism of the additive group ![
$$\\mathbb{C}/\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq92.gif) with the multiplicative group ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq93.gif), we see that ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}\\mathop{\\cong}{\({\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq94.gif). We call any complex Lie group isomorphic to ![
$${\({\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq95.gif) for some r a complex torus.

By a linear character ![
$$\\chi$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq96.gif) of a compact torus T, we mean a continuous homomorphism ![
$$T\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq97.gif). These are just the characters of irreducible representations, known explicitly by (15.1). They take values in ![
$$\\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq98.gif), as we may see from (15.1), or by noting that the image is a compact subgroup of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq99.gif).

By a rational character χ of a complex torus T, we mean an analytic homomorphism ![
$$T\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq100.gif).

Proposition 15.6.

Let T be a compact torus. Then any linear character χ of T extends uniquely to a rational character of ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq101.gif) .

Proof.

Without loss of generality, we may assume that ![
$$T = {\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq102.gif) and that ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}} = {\({\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq103.gif), where the embedding ![
$$T\\longrightarrow T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq104.gif) is the map ![
$$\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\)\\longrightarrow \({\\mathrm{e}}^{2\\pi ix_{1}},\\ldots,{\\mathrm{e}}^{2\\pi ix_{r}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq105.gif). Every linear character of T is given by (15.1) for suitable ![
$$k_{i} \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq106.gif), and this extends to the rational character ![
$$\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{r}\)\\longrightarrow \\prod t_{i}^{k_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq107.gif) of ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq108.gif). Since a rational character is holomorphic, it is determined by its values on the image ![
$${\\mathbb{T}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq109.gif) of T. □

We will denote the group of characters of a compact torus T as ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq110.gif). We will denote its group law additively: if χ1 and χ2 are characters, then ![
$$\(\\chi _{1} + \\chi _{2}\)\(t\) = \\chi _{1}\(t\)\\chi _{2}\(t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq111.gif). We may identify X ∗(T) with the group of rational characters of ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq112.gif).

A (topological) generator of a compact torus T is an element t such that the smallest closed subgroup of T containing t is T itself.

Theorem 15.1 (Kronecker).

Let ![
$$\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{r}\) \\in {\\mathbb{R}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq113.gif) , and let t be the image of this point in ![
$$T = {\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq114.gif) . Then t is a generator of T if and only if ![
$$1,t_{1},\\ldots,t_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq115.gif) are linearly independent over ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq116.gif) .

Proof.

Let H be the closure of the group ![
$$\\left \\langle t\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq117.gif) generated by t in ![
$$T = {\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq118.gif). Then T∕H is a compact Abelian group, and if it is not reduced to the identity it has a character χ. We may regard this as a character of T that is trivial on H, and as such it has the form (15.1) for suitable ![
$$k_{i} \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq119.gif). Since t itself is in H, this means that ![
$$\\sum k_{j}t_{j} \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq120.gif), so ![
$$1,t_{1},\\ldots,t_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq121.gif) are linearly dependent. The existence of nontrivial characters of T∕H is thus equivalent to the linear dependence of ![
$$1,t_{1},\\ldots,t_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq122.gif) and the result follows. □

Corollary 15.1.

Each compact torus T has a generator. Indeed, generators are dense in T.

Proof.

We may assume that ![
$$T = {\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq123.gif). By Kronecker's Theorem 15.1, what we must show is that r-tuples ![
$$\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{r}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq124.gif) such that 1,t 1,..., t r are linearly independent over ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq125.gif) are dense in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq126.gif). If ![
$$1,t_{1},\\ldots,t_{i-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq127.gif) are linearly independent, then linear independence of 1,t 1,..., t i excludes only countably many t i , and the result follows from the uncountability of ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq128.gif). □

Proposition 15.7.

Let ![
$$T = {\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq129.gif).

(i)

Each automorphism of T is of the form ![
$$t\\longrightarrow Mt$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq130.gif) (mod ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{r}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq131.gif) , where ![
$$M \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq132.gif) . Thus, ![
$$\\mathrm{Aut}\(T\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq133.gif) .

(ii)

If H is a connected topological space and ![
$$f: H\\,\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Aut}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq134.gif) is a map such that (h,t)⟶f(h)t is a continuous map ![
$$H \\times T\\,\\longrightarrow T$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq135.gif) , then f is constant.

We can express (ii) by saying that ![
$$\\mathrm{Aut}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq136.gif) is discrete since if it is given the discrete topology, then ![
$$\(h,t\)\\,\\longrightarrow f\(h\)t$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq137.gif) is continuous if and only if f is locally constant.

Proof.

If ϕ: T ⟶ T is an automorphism, then ϕ induces an invertible linear transformation M of the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq138.gif) of T that commutes with the exponential map. Because T is Abelian, the exponential map ![
$$\\exp: \\mathfrak{t} \\rightarrow T$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq139.gif) is a group homomorphism, and ϕ must preserve its kernel Λ. We may identify ![
$$\\mathfrak{t} = {\\mathbb{R}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq140.gif) in such a way that Λ is identified with ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq141.gif), in which case the matrix of M must lie in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq142.gif). Part (i) is now clear.

For part (ii), since Tn is compact and f is continuous, as h ⟶ h 1, f(h)t ⟶ f(h 1)t uniformly for t ∈ T. It is easy to see from (i) that this is impossible unless f is locally constant. □

In the remainder of this chapter, we will consider tori embedded in Lie groups. First, we prove a general statement that implies the existence of tori.

Theorem 15.2.

Let G be a Lie group and H a closed Abelian subgroup. Then H is a Lie subgroup of G. If G is compact, then the connected component of the identity in H is a torus.

The assumption that H is Abelian is unnecessary. See Remark 7.2 for references to a result without this assumption.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq143.gif). The exponential map ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq144.gif) is a local homeomorphism near the origin. Let U be a neighborhood of ![
$$0 \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq145.gif) such that exp has a smooth inverse log: exp(U)⟶ U. Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{h} =\\{ X \\in \\mathfrak{g}\\,\\vert \\,\\mbox{ $\\exp \(tX\) \\in H$ for all $t \\in \\mathbb{R}$}\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Eque.gif)

Lemma 15.1.

If ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq146.gif) and Y ∈ U, and if eY ∈ H then [X,Y ] = 0.

To prove the lemma, note that for any t > 0 both e tX and e Y ∈ H commute, so ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{Y } ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{tX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{Y }{\\mathrm{e}}^{-tX} =\\exp \\!\\big \(\\mathrm{Ad}\(tX\)Y \\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq147.gif). If t is small enough, both Y and Ad(tX)Y are in U, so applying log we have Ad(tX)Y = Y. By Theorem 8.2, it follows that ad(X)Y = 0, proving the lemma.

Let us now show that ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq148.gif) is an Abelian Lie algebra. It is clearly closed under scalar multiplication. If X and ![
$$Y$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq149.gif) are in ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq150.gif), then ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{tY } \\in H$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq151.gif) and tY ∈ U for small enough t, so by the lemma [X,tY ] = 0. Thus, [X,Y ] = 0. By Proposition 15.2 we have ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{t\(X+Y \)} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{tX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{tY }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq152.gif) for all t, so ![
$$X + Y \\in \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq153.gif).

Now we will show that there exists a neighborhood V of the identity in G such that V ⊆ exp(U) and ![
$$V \\cap H =\\{\\exp \(X\)\\,\\vert \\,X \\in \\mathfrak{h} \\cap \\log \(V \)\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq154.gif). This will show that ![
$$V \\cap H$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq155.gif) is a smooth locally closed submanifold of G. Since every point of H has a neighborhood diffeomorphic to this neighborhood of the identity, it will follow that H is a submanifold of G and hence a Lie subgroup.

It is clear that, for each open neighborhood of V contained in exp(U), we have ![
$$V \\cap H \\supseteq \\{\\exp \(X\)\\,\\vert \\,X \\in \\mathfrak{h} \\cap \\log \(V \)\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq156.gif). If this inclusion is proper for every V, then there exists a sequence ![
$$\\{h_{n}\\} \\subset H \\cap \\exp \(U\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq157.gif) such that ![
$$h_{n}\\longrightarrow 1$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq158.gif) but ![
$$\\log \(h_{n}\)\\notin \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq159.gif). We write log(h n ) = X n . Thus, ![
$$X_{n} \\rightarrow 0$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq160.gif).

Let us write ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{h} \\oplus \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq161.gif), where ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq162.gif) is a vector subspace. We will show that we may choose ![
$$X_{n} \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq163.gif). Write X n = Y n \+ Z n , where ![
$$Y _{n} \\in \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq164.gif) and ![
$$Z_{n} \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq165.gif). By the lemma, [X n ,Y n ] = 0, so ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{Z_{n}} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{X_{n}}{\\mathrm{e}}^{-Y _{n}} \\in H$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq166.gif). We may replace X n by Z n and h n by ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{Z_{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq167.gif), and we still have ![
$$h_{n}\\longrightarrow 1,$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq168.gif) but ![
$$\\log \(h_{n}\)\\notin \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq169.gif), and after this substitution we have ![
$$X_{n} \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq170.gif).

Let us put an inner product on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq171.gif). We choose it so that the unit ball is contained in U. The vectors X n ∕|X n | lie on the unit ball in ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq172.gif), which is compact, so they have an accumulation point. Passing to a subsequence, we may assume that ![
$$X_{n}/\\vert X_{n}\\vert \\longrightarrow X_{\\infty }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq173.gif), where X ∞ lies in the unit ball in ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq174.gif). We will show that ![
$$X_{\\infty }\\in \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq175.gif), which is a contradiction since ![
$$\\mathfrak{h} \\cap \\mathfrak{p} =\\{ 0\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq176.gif).

To show that ![
$$X_{\\infty }\\in \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq177.gif), we must show that ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{tX_{\\infty }} \\in H$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq178.gif). It is sufficient to show this for t < 1. With t fixed, let r n be the smallest integer greater than t∕|X n |. Since X n → 0 we have ![
$$r_{n}\\vert X_{n}\\vert \\rightarrow t$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq179.gif). Thus, ![
$$r_{n}X_{n}\\longrightarrow tX_{\\infty }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq180.gif) and ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{r_{n}X_{n}} = {\({\\mathrm{e}}^{X_{n}}\)}^{r_{n}} \\in H$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq181.gif) since ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{X_{n}} \\in H$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq182.gif). Since H is closed, ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{tX_{\\infty }} \\in H$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq183.gif) and the proof that H is a Lie group is complete.

If G is compact, then so is H. The connected component of the identity in H is a connected compact Abelian Lie group and hence a torus. □

If G is a group and H a subgroup, we will denote by N G (H) and ![
$$C_{G}\(H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq184.gif) the normalizer and centralizers of H. If no confusion is possible, we will denote them as simply N(H) and C(H).

Let G be a compact, connected Lie group. It contains tori, for example ![
$$\\{1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq185.gif), and an ascending chain ![
$$T_{1} \\subsetneq T_{2} \\subsetneq T_{3} \\subsetneq \\cdots$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq186.gif) has length bounded by the dimension of G. Therefore, G contains maximal tori. Let T be a maximal torus.

The normalizer ![
$$N\(T\) =\\{ g \\in G\\,\\vert \\,gT{g}^{-1} = T\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq187.gif). It is a closed subgroup since if t ∈ T is a generator, N(T) is the inverse image of T under the continuous map ![
$$g\\longrightarrow gt{g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq188.gif).

Proposition 15.8.

Let G be a compact Lie group and T a maximal torus. Then N(T) is a closed subgroup of G. The connected component N(T) ∘ of the identity in N(T) is T itself. The quotient N(T)∕T is a finite group.

Proof.

We have a homomorphism ![
$$N\(T\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Aut}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq189.gif) in which the action is by conjugation. By Proposition 15.7, ![
$$\\mathrm{Aut}\(T\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq190.gif) is discrete, so any connected group of automorphisms must act trivially. Thus, if ![
$$n \\in N{\(T\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq191.gif), n commutes with T. If ![
$$N{\(T\)}^{\\circ }\\neq T$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq192.gif), then it contains a one-parameter subgroup ![
$$\\mathbb{R} \\ni t\\longrightarrow n\(t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq193.gif), and the closure of the group generated by T and n(t) is a closed commutative subgroup strictly larger than T. By Theorem 15.2, it is a torus, contradicting the maximality of T. It follows that ![
$$T = N{\(T\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq194.gif).

The quotient group ![
$$N{\(T\)}^{\\circ }/T$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq195.gif) is both discrete and compact and hence finite. □

The quotient N(T)∕T is called the Weyl group of G with respect to T.

Example 15.1.

Suppose that ![
$$G = \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq196.gif). A maximal torus is

![
$$\\displaystyle{T = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\,t_{1}\\, & & \\\\ & \\,\\ddots\\, & \\\\ & & \\,t_{n}\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,\\vert t_{1}\\vert = \\cdots = \\vert t_{n}\\vert = 1\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Its normalizer N(T) consists of all monomial matrices (matrices with a single nonzero entry in each row and column) so the quotient ![
$$N\(T\)/T\\mathop{\\cong}S_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq197.gif).

Proposition 15.9.

Let T be a maximal torus in the compact connected Lie group G, and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq198.gif), ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq199.gif) be the Lie algebras of T and G, respectively.

(i)

Any vector in ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq200.gif) fixed by ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq201.gif) is in ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq202.gif) .

(ii)

We have ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{t} \\oplus \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq203.gif) , where ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq204.gif) is invariant under ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq205.gif) . Under the restriction of ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq206.gif) to ![
$$T$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq207.gif), ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq208.gif) decomposes into a direct sum of two-dimensional irreducible representations of T of the form (15.2) .

Proof.

For (i), if ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq209.gif) is fixed by ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq210.gif), then by Proposition 15.2, exp(tX) is a one-parameter subgroup that is not contained in T but that commutes with T, and unless ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq211.gif), the closure of the group it generates with T will be a torus strictly larger than T, which is a contradiction.

Since G is compact, there exists a positive definite symmetric bilinear form on the real vector space that is ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq212.gif)-invariant under the real representation ![
$$\\text{Ad}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq213.gif). The orthogonal complement ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq214.gif) of ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq215.gif) is invariant under ![
$$\\text{Ad}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq216.gif). It contains no ![
$$\\text{Ad}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq217.gif)-fixed vectors by (i). Since every nontrivial irreducible real representation of T is of the form (15.2), (ii) follows. □

Corollary 15.2.

If G is a compact connected Lie group and T a maximal torus, then ![
$$\\dim \(G\) -\\dim \(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq218.gif) is even.

Proof.

This follows since ![
$$\\dim \(G/T\) =\\dim \(\\mathfrak{p}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq219.gif), and ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq220.gif) decomposes as a direct sum of two-dimensional irreducible representations. □

We review the notion of an orientation. Let M be a manifold of dimension n. The orientation bundle of M is a certain twofold cover that we now describe. One way of constructing ![
$$\\tilde{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq221.gif) begins with the n-fold exterior power of the tangent bundle: the fiber over x ∈ M is ![
$${\\wedge }^{n}T_{x}\(M\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq222.gif). This is a one-dimensional real vector space. Omitting the origin and dividing by the equivalence relation v ∼ w if v = λw for ![
$$0 <\\lambda \\in \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq223.gif), when v, w are elements of ![
$${\\wedge }^{n}T_{x}\\text{\(M\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq224.gif), produces a set F(x) with two points. The disjoint union ![
$$\\tilde{M} =\\bigcup _{x\\in M}F\(x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq225.gif) is topologized as follows. Let ![
$$\\pi:\\tilde{ M}\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq226.gif) be the map sending F(x) to x. If X 1,..., X n are vector fields that are linearly independent on an open set U, then ![
$$X_{1} \\wedge \\cdots \\wedge X_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq227.gif) determines, for each x ∈ U, an element s(x) of π−1(x). We topologize ![
$$\\tilde{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq228.gif) by requiring that ![
$$s: U\\longrightarrow \\tilde{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq229.gif) be a local homeomorphism.

Now an orientation of the manifold M is a global section of the orientation bundle, that is, a continuous map ![
$$s: M\\longrightarrow \\tilde{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq230.gif) such that ![
$$p \\circ s\(x\) = x$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq231.gif) for all x ∈ M. If an orientation exists, then ![
$$\\tilde{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq232.gif) is a trivial cover, and ![
$$\\tilde{M}\\mathop{\\cong}M \\times \(\\mathbb{Z}/2\\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq233.gif). In this case, the bundle M is called orientable. Any complex manifold is orientable. On the other hand, a Möbius strip is not orientable.

If M and N are manifolds of dimension n and ![
$$f: M\\longrightarrow N$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq234.gif) is a diffeomorphism, there is induced for each x ∈ M an isomorphism ![
$${\\wedge }^{n}T_{x}\(M\)\\longrightarrow {\\wedge }^{n}T_{f\(x\)}\(N\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq235.gif) and so there is induced a canonical map ![
$$\\tilde{f}:\\tilde{ M}\\longrightarrow \\tilde{N}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq236.gif) covering f.

Proposition 15.10.

Let G be a connected Lie group and H a connected closed Lie subgroup. Then the quotient space G∕H is a connected orientable manifold.

The manifold G∕T is called a flag manifold.

Proof.

To make G∕H a manifold, choose a subspace ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq237.gif) of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq238.gif) complementary to ![
$$\\mathfrak{h} = \\text{Lie}\(H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq239.gif). Then ![
$$X\\longrightarrow \\exp \(X\)gH$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq240.gif) is a local homeomorphism of a neighborhood of the identity in ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq241.gif) with a neighborhood of the coset gH in G∕H.

To see that M = G∕H is orientable, let ![
$$\\pi:\\tilde{ M}\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq242.gif) be the orientation bundle, and let ω be an element of ![
$${\\pi }^{-1}\(H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq243.gif). If g ∈ G then g acts by left translation on M and hence induces an automorphism ![
$$\\tilde{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq244.gif) of ![
$$\\tilde{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq245.gif). We can define a global section s of ![
$$\\tilde{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq246.gif) by ![
$$s\(gH\) =\\tilde{ g}\(\\omega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq247.gif) if we can check that this is well-defined. Thus, if gH = g′H, we must show that ![
$$\\tilde{g}\(\\omega \) =\\tilde{ g}^{\\prime}\(\\omega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq248.gif) in the fiber of ![
$$\\tilde{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq249.gif) above gH. We will show that the map ![
$$\\tilde{g}: M\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq250.gif) can be deformed into ![
$$\\tilde{g}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq251.gif) through a sequence of maps ![
$$\\widetilde{g_{t}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq252.gif), each of them mapping ![
$$H\\longrightarrow gH$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq253.gif), so that ![
$$\\tilde{g}_{0} =\\tilde{ g}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq254.gif) and ![
$$\\tilde{g}^{\\prime}_{1} =\\tilde{ g}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq255.gif). This is sufficient because the fiber of ![
$$\\tilde{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq256.gif) above gH is a discrete set consisting of two elements, and ![
$$t\\longrightarrow \\widetilde{g_{t}}\(\\omega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq257.gif) is then a continuous map from [0,1] into this discrete set.

The existence of ![
$$\\widetilde{g_{t}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq258.gif) will follow from the connectedness of H. Note that if γ ∈ G we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\gamma gH = gH\\quad \\Longleftrightarrow\\quad \\gamma \\in gH{g}^{-1}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(15.3)

In particular, ![
$$g^{\\prime}{g}^{-1} \\in gH{g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq259.gif). Since H is connected, so is gHg −1, and there is a path ![
$$t\\longmapsto \\gamma _{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq260.gif) from the identity to g′g −1 within gHg −1. Then ![
$$xH\\longmapsto \\gamma _{t}gxH$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq261.gif) is a diffeomorphism of M that agrees with left translation by g when t = 0 and left translation by g′ when t = 1, and by (15.3), each canonical lifting ![
$$\\widetilde{g_{t}}$$
](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq262.gif) takes H ⟶ g H, as required. □

We have seen in Corollary 15.2 that the flag manifold X is even-dimensional, and by Proposition 15.10 it is orientable. These facts will be explained by Theorem 26.4, where we will see that X is actually a complex analytic manifold.

Compute the dimensions of the flag manifolds for ![

](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq263.gif), ![

](A79351_2_En_15_Chapter_IEq264.gif) and ![
