# 16. Geodesics and Maximal Tori

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

An important theorem of Cartan asserts that any two maximal tori in a compact Lie group are conjugate. There are different ways of proving this. We will deduce it from the surjectivity of the exponential map, which we will prove by showing that a geodesic between the origin and an arbitrary point of the group has the form ![
$$t\\mapsto {\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq1.gif) for some X in the Lie algebra.

An important theorem of Cartan asserts that any two maximal tori in a compact Lie group are conjugate. There are different ways of proving this. We will deduce it from the surjectivity of the exponential map, which we will prove by showing that a geodesic between the origin and an arbitrary point of the group has the form ![
$$t\\mapsto {\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq2.gif) for some X in the Lie algebra.

We begin by establishing the properties of geodesics that we will need. These properties are rather well-known, though they do require proof. Some readers may want to start reading with Theorem 16.1.

A Riemannian manifold consists of a smooth manifold M and for each x ∈ M an inner product on the tangent space T x . Since T x is a real vector space and not a complex one, an inner product in this context is a positive definite symmetric real-valued bilinear form. We also describe this family of inner products on the tangent spaces as a Riemannian structure on the manifold M. We will denote the inner product of X,Y ∈ T x by ![
$$\\left \\langle X\\,,Y \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq3.gif) and the length ![
$$\\sqrt{\\left \\langle X, X\\right \\rangle } = \\vert X\\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq4.gif). As part of the definition, the inner product must vary smoothly with x. To make this condition precise, we choose a system of coordinates ![
$$x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq5.gif) on some open set U of M, where ![
$$n =\\dim \(M\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq6.gif). Then, at each point x ∈ U, a basis of T x (M) consists of ![
$$\\partial /\\partial x_{1},\\ldots,\\partial /\\partial x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq7.gif). Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{ g_{ij} = \\left \\langle \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{i}}, \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial x_{j}}\\right \\rangle. }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(16.1)

Thus, the matrix (g ij ) representing the inner product is positive definite symmetric. Smoothness of the inner product means that the g ij are smooth functions of x ∈ U.

We also define (g ij ) to be the inverse matrix to (g ij ). Thus, the functions g ij satisfy

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sum _{j}g_{ij}{g}^{jk} = \\delta _{ i}^{k},\\quad \\mathrm{where}\\quad \\delta _{ i}^{k} = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} 1&\\text{if}\\ i = k\\,, \\\\ 0&\\text{otherwise}\\,, \\end{array} \\right. }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(16.2)

and of course

![
$$\\displaystyle{g_{ij} = g_{ji},\\quad {g}^{ij} = {g}^{ji}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Suppose that ![
$$p: \[0,1\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq8.gif) is a path in the Riemannian manifold M. We say p is admissible if it is smooth, and moreover the movement along the path never "stops," that is, the tangent vector ![
$$p_{{\\ast}}\(\\mathrm{d}/\\mathrm{d}t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq9.gif), where t is the coordinate function on [0,1], is never zero. The length or arclength of p is

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\vert p\\vert =\\int _{ 0}^{1}\\left \\vert p_{\\ast}\\,\\left \( \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}\\right \)\\right \\vert \\mathrm{d}t. }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(16.3)

In terms of local coordinates, if we write ![
$$x_{i}\(t\) = x_{i}\\big\(p\(t\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq10.gif) the integrand is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\vert p_{{\\ast}}\\,\\left \( \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}\\right \)\\right \\vert = \\sqrt{\\sum _{i,j } g_{ij } \\frac{\\partial x_{i } } {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equb.gif)

We call the path well-paced if

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{0}^{a}\\left \\vert p_{ {\\ast}}\\,\\left \( \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}\\right \)\\right \\vert \\mathrm{d}t = \\vert p\\vert a}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equc.gif)

for all ![
$$0 \\leqslant a \\leqslant 1$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq11.gif). Intuitively, this means that the point p(t) moves along the path at a constant "velocity."

It is an easy application of the chain rule that the arclength of p is unchanged under reparametrization. Moreover, each path has a unique reparametrization that is well-paced.

A Riemannian manifold becomes a complete metric space by defining the distance between two points a and b as the infimum of the lengths of the paths connecting them. It is not immediately obvious that there will be a shortest path, and indeed there may not be for some Riemannian manifolds, but it is easy to check that this definition satisfies the triangle inequality and induces the standard topology.

We will encounter various quantities indexed by ![
$$1 \\leqslant i,j,k,\\cdots \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq12.gif), where n is the dimension of the manifold M under consideration. We will make use of Einstein's summation convention (in this chapter only). According to this convention, if any index is repeated in a term, it is summed. For example, suppose that ![
$$p: \[0,1\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq13.gif) is a path lying entirely in a single chart ![
$$U \\subset M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq14.gif) with coordinate functions x 1,...,x n . Then we may regard ![
$$x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq15.gif) as functions of ![
$$t \\in \[0,1\]$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq16.gif), namely ![
$$x_{i}\(t\) = x_{i}\\big\(p\(t\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq17.gif). If ![
$$f: U\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq18.gif) is a smooth function, then according to the chain rule

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\frac{\\mathrm{d}f} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\) =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}\\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{i}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{i}}\\big\(x_{1}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equd.gif)

According to the summation convention, we can write this as simply

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\frac{\\mathrm{d}f} {\\mathrm{d}t} = \\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{i}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\frac{\\partial f} {\\partial x_{i}},}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Eque.gif)

and the summation over i is understood because it is a repeated index.

If for each smooth curve ![
$$q: \[0,1\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq19.gif) with the same endpoints as p we have ![
$$\\vert p\\vert \\leqslant \\vert q\\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq20.gif), then we say that p is a path of shortest length. We will presently define geodesics by means of a differential equation, but for the moment we may provisionally describe a geodesic as a well-paced path along a manifold M that on short intervals is a path of shortest length.

An example will explain the qualification "on short intervals" in this definition. On a sphere, a geodesic is a great circle. The path in Fig. 16.1 is a geodesic. It is obviously not the path of shortest length between a and b.

Fig. 16.1

A geodesic on a sphere

Although the indicated geodesic is not a path of shortest length, if we break it into smaller segments, we may still hope that these shorter paths may be paths of shortest length. Indeed they will be paths of shortest length if they are not too long, and this is the content of Proposition 16.4 below. For example, the segment from a to c is a path of shortest length.

Let ![
$$p: \[0,1\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq21.gif) be an admissible path. We can consider deformations of p, namely we can consider a smooth family of paths ![
$$u\\longrightarrow p_{u}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq22.gif), where, for each ![
$$u \\in \(-\\epsilon,\\epsilon \)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq23.gif), p u is a path from a to b and p 0 = p. Note that, as with the definition of path-homotopy, we require that the endpoints be fixed as the path is deformed. We consider the function f(u) = |p u |. We say the path is of stationary length if f′(0) = 0 for each such deformation.

If p is a path of shortest length, then 0 will be a minimum of f so f′(0) = 0. As for the example in Fig. 16.1, the path from a to b may be deformed by raising it up above the equator and simultaneously shrinking it, but even under such a deformation we will have f′(0) = 0. So although this path is not a path of shortest length, it is still a path of stationary length.

Let ![
$$x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq24.gif) be coordinate functions on some open set U on M. Relative to this coordinate system, let g ij and g ij be as in (16.1) and (16.2). We define the Christoffel symbols

![
$$\\displaystyle{\[ij,k\] = \\frac{1} {2}\\left \(\\frac{\\partial g_{ik}} {\\partial x_{j}} + \\frac{\\partial g_{jk}} {\\partial x_{i}} -\\frac{\\partial g_{ij}} {\\partial x_{k}} \\right \),\\{ij,k\\} = {g}^{kl}\[ij,l\].}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equf.gif)

In the last expression, l is summed by the summation convention.

Proposition 16.1.

Suppose that ![
$$p: \[0,1\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq25.gif) is a well-paced admissible path. If the path lies within an open set U on which x 1 ,...,x n is a system of coordinates, then writing ![
$$x_{i}\(t\) = x_{i}\\big\(p\(t\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq26.gif) , the path is of stationary length if and only if it satisfies the differential equation

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{{\\mathrm{d}}^{2}x_{k}} {\\mathrm{d}{t}^{2}} = -\\{ij,k\\}\\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{i}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{j}} {\\mathrm{d}t}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(16.4)

Proof.

Let us consider the effect of deforming the path. We consider a family p u of paths parametrized by u ∈ (−ε,ε), where ε > 0 is a small real number. It is assumed that the family of paths varies smoothly, so ![
$$\(t,u\)\\longmapsto p_{u}\(t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq27.gif) is a smooth map ![
$$\(-\\epsilon,\\epsilon \) \\times \[0,1\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq28.gif).

We regard the coordinate functions x i of the point ![
$$x = p_{u}\(t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq29.gif) to be functions of u and t.

It is assumed that p 0(t) = p(t) and that the endpoints are fixed, so that p u (0) = p(u) and p u (1) = p(1) for all ![
$$u \\in \(-\\epsilon,\\epsilon \)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq30.gif). Therefore,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial u} = 0\\quad \\mbox{ when $t = 0$ or $1$}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(16.5)

In local coordinates, the arclength (16.3) becomes

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\vert p_{u}\\vert =\\int _{ 0}^{1}\\sqrt{g_{ ij}\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t}} \\mathrm{d}t. }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(16.6)

Because the path p(t) = p 0(t) is well-paced, the integrand is constant (independent of t) when u = 0, so

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial t}\\sqrt{ g_{ij}\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t}} = 0\\quad \\mbox{ when $u = 0$.} }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(16.7)

We do not need to assume that the deformed path p(t,u) is well-paced for any u≠0.

Let f(u) = |p u |. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{f^{\\prime}\(u\) = \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial u}\\int _{0}^{1}\\sqrt{g_{ ij}\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t}} \\mathrm{d}t\\,.}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equg.gif)

This equals

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & \\int _{0}^{1}{\\left \(g_{ ij}\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} \\right \)}^{\\,-\\frac{1} {2} }\\,\\left \[\\frac{1} {2} \\frac{\\partial g_{ij}} {\\partial u} \\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} + \\frac{1} {2}g_{ij} \\frac{{\\partial }^{2}x_{i}} {\\partial u\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} + \\frac{1} {2}g_{ij}\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{{\\partial }^{2}x_{j}} {\\partial u\\partial t}\\right \]\\mathrm{d}t {}\\\\ & & \\quad =\\int _{ 0}^{1}{\\left \(g_{ ij}\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} \\right \)}^{-\\frac{1} {2} }\\left \[\\frac{1} {2} \\frac{\\partial g_{ij}} {\\partial x_{l}} \\frac{\\partial x_{l}} {\\partial u} \\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} + g_{ij} \\frac{{\\partial }^{2}x_{i}} {\\partial u\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} \\right \]\\mathrm{d}t, {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

where we have used the chain rule, and combined two terms that are equal. (The variables i and j are summed by the summation convention, so we may interchange them, and using ![
$$g_{ij} = g_{ji}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq31.gif), the last two terms on the left-hand side are equal.) We integrate the second term by parts with respect to t, making use of (16.5) and (16.7) to obtain

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} f^{\\prime}\(0\)& =& \\int _{0}^{1}{\\left \(g_{ ij}\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} \\right \)}^{-\\frac{1} {2} }\\left \[\\frac{1} {2} \\frac{\\partial g_{ij}} {\\partial x_{l}} \\frac{\\partial x_{l}} {\\partial u} \\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} -\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial u} \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial t}\\left \(g_{ij}\\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} \\right \)\\right \]\\mathrm{d}t {}\\\\ & =& \\int _{0}^{1}{\\left \(g_{ ij}\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} \\right \)}^{-\\frac{1} {2} }\\left \[\\frac{1} {2} \\frac{\\partial g_{ij}} {\\partial x_{l}} \\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} - \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial t}\\left \(g_{lj}\\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} \\right \)\\right \]\\frac{\\partial x_{l}} {\\partial u} \\mathrm{d}t. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

Now all the partial derivatives are evaluated when u = 0. The last step is just a relabeling of a summed index.

We observe that the displacements ![
$$\\partial x_{l}/\\partial u$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) are arbitrary except that they must vanish when t = 0 and t = 1. (We did not assume the deformed path to be well-paced except when u = 0.) Thus, the path is of stationary length if and only if

![
$$\\displaystyle{0 = \\frac{1} {2} \\frac{\\partial g_{ij}} {\\partial x_{l}} \\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} - \\frac{\\partial } {\\partial t}\\left \(g_{lj}\\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equh.gif)

so the condition is

![
$$\\displaystyle{g_{lj}\\frac{{\\partial }^{2}x_{j}} {\\partial {t}^{2}} = \\frac{1} {2} \\frac{\\partial g_{ij}} {\\partial x_{l}} \\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} -\\frac{\\partial g_{lj}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\frac{\\partial g_{lj}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} = \\frac{\\partial g_{lj}} {\\partial x_{i}} \\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t} = \\frac{1} {2}\\left \[\\frac{\\partial g_{lj}} {\\partial x_{i}} + \\frac{\\partial g_{li}} {\\partial x_{j}} \\right \]\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equj.gif)

The two terms on the right-hand side are of course equal since both i and j are summed indices. We obtain in terms of the Christoffel symbols

![
$$\\displaystyle{g_{lj}\\frac{{\\partial }^{2}x_{j}} {\\partial {t}^{2}} = -\[ij,l\]\\frac{\\partial x_{i}} {\\partial t} \\frac{\\partial x_{j}} {\\partial t}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Multiplying by g kl , summing the repeated index l, and using (16.2), we obtain (16.4). □

We define a geodesic to be a solution to the differential equation (16.4). This definition does not depend upon the choice of coordinate systems because the differential equation (16.4) arose from a variational problem that was formulated without reference to coordinates. Naturally, one may alternatively confirm by direct computation that the differential equation (16.4) is stable under coordinate changes.

Proposition 16.2.

Let x be a point on the Riemannian manifold M, and let ![
$$X \\in T_{x}\(M\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq33.gif) . Then, for sufficiently small ε, there is a unique geodesic ![
$$p: \(-\\epsilon,\\epsilon \)\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) such that p(0) = x and ![
$$p_{{\\ast}}\(\\mathrm{d}/\\mathrm{d}t\) = X$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq35.gif) .

Proof.

Let x 1,...,x n be coordinate functions. Let y 1,...,y n be a set of new variables, and rewrite (16.4) as a first-order system

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & \\qquad \\qquad \\qquad \\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{i}} {\\mathrm{d}t} = y_{i}, {}\\\\ & & \\frac{\\mathrm{d}y_{k}} {\\mathrm{d}t} = -\\{ij,k\\}\\,y_{i}y_{j}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

The conditions p(0) = x and ![
$$p_{{\\ast}}\(\\mathrm{d}/\\mathrm{d}t\) = X$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq36.gif) amount to initial conditions for this first-order system, and the existence and uniqueness of the solution follow from the general theory of first-order systems. □

We now come to a property of geodesics that may be less intuitive. Let U be a smooth submanifold of M, homeomorphic to a disk, of codimension 1. If x ∈ U, we consider the geodesic ![
$$t \\longmapsto p_x\(t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq360.gif) such that p x (0) = x and such that p x,∗(d∕dt) is the unit normal vector to M at x in a fixed direction. For small ε > 0, let ![
$$U^{\\prime} =\\{ p_{x}\(\\epsilon \)\\vert x \\in U\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq37.gif). In other words, U′ is a translation of the disk U along the family of geodesics normal to U.

It is obvious that U is normal to each of the geodesic curves p x . What is less obvious, and will be proved in the next proposition, is that U′ is also normal to the geodesics p x .

In order to prove this, we will work with a particular set of coordinates. Let x 2,...,x n be local coordinates on U. At each point ![
$$x = \(x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\) \\in U$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq38.gif), we choose the unit normal vector in a fixed direction and construct the geodesic path through the point with that tangent vector. We prescribe a coordinate system on M near U by asking that ![
$$\(0,x_{2},\\ldots,x_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq39.gif) agree with the point x ∈ U and that the path ![
$$t\\longmapsto \(t,x_{2,}\\ldots,x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq40.gif)) agree with p x . We describe such a coordinate system as geodesic coordinates.

Proposition 16.3.

In geodesic coordinates, ![
$$g_{1i} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq41.gif) for ![
$$2 \\leqslant i \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq42.gif) . Also ![
$$g_{11} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq43.gif) .

In view of (16.1), this amounts to saying that the geodesic curves (having tangent vector ![
$$\\partial /\\partial x_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq44.gif)) are orthogonal to the level hypersurfaces ![
$$x_{1} = \\mathrm{constant}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq45.gif) (having tangent spaces spanned by ![
$$\\partial /\\partial x_{2},\\ldots,\\partial /\\partial x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq46.gif)), such as U and U′ in Fig. 16.2.

Proof.

Having chosen coordinates so that the path ![
$$t\\longmapsto \(t,x_{2,}\\ldots,x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq47.gif)) is a geodesic, we see that if all ![
$$\\mathrm{d}x_{i}/\\mathrm{d}t = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq48.gif) in (16.4), for ![
$$i\\neq 1$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq49.gif), then ![
$${\\mathrm{d}}^{2}x_{k}/\\mathrm{d}{t}^{2} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq50.gif) for all k. This means that ![
$$\\{11,k\\} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq51.gif). Since the matrix ![
$$\(g_{kl}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq52.gif) is invertible, it follows that [11,k] = 0, so

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\partial g_{1k}} {\\partial x_{1}} = \\frac{1} {2} \\frac{\\partial g_{11}} {\\partial x_{k}}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(16.8)

First, take k = 1 in (16.8). We see that ![
$$\\partial g_{11}/\\partial x_{1} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq53.gif), so if x 2,...,x n are held constant, g 11 is constant. When x 1 = 0, the initial condition of the geodesic curve p x through (0,x 2,...,x n ) is that it is tangent to the unit normal to the surface, that is, its tangent vector ∂∕∂ x 1 has length one, and by (16.1) it follows that g 11 = 1 when x 1 = 0, so g 11 = 1 throughout the geodesic coordinate neighborhood.

Now let ![
$$2 \\leqslant k \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq54.gif) in (16.8). Since g 11 is constant, ![
$$\\partial g_{1k}/\\partial x_{1} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq55.gif), and so g 1k is also constant when x 2,...,x n are held constant. When x 1 = 0, our assumption that the geodesic curve p x is normal to the surface means that ![
$$\\partial /\\partial x_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq56.gif) and ![
$$\\partial /\\partial x_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq57.gif) are orthogonal, so by (16.1), g 1k vanishes when x 1 = 0 and so it vanishes for all x 1. □

Fig. 16.2

Hypersurface remains perpendicular to geodesics on parallel translation

With these preparations, we may now prove that short geodesics are paths of shortest length.

Proposition 16.4.

(i)

Let ![
$$p: \[0,1\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq58.gif) be a geodesic. Then there exists an ε > 0 such that the restriction of p to [0,ε] is the unique path of shortest length from p(0) to p(ε).

(ii)

Let x ∈ M. There exists a neighborhood N of x such that for all y ∈ N there exists a unique path of shortest distance from x to y, and that path is a geodesic.

Proof.

We choose a hypersurface U orthogonal to p at t = 0 and construct geodesic coordinates as explained before Proposition 16.3. We choose ε and B so small that the set N of points with coordinates ![
$$\\{x_{1} \\in \[0,\\epsilon \],0 \\leq \\vert x_{2}\\vert,\\ldots,\\vert x_{n}\\vert \\leq B\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq59.gif) is contained within the interior of this geodesic coordinate neighborhood. We can assume that the coordinates of p(0) are (0,...,0), so by construction ![
$$p\(t\) = \(t,0,\\ldots,0\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq60.gif). Then ![
$$\\vert p\\vert = \\epsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq61.gif), where now |p| denotes the length of the restriction of the path to the interval from 0 to ε.

We will show that if ![
$$q: \[0,\\epsilon \]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq62.gif) is any path with q(0) = p(0) and q(ε) = p(ε), then |q|≥|p|.

First, we consider paths ![
$$q: \[0,\\epsilon \]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq63.gif) that lie entirely within the set N and such that the x 1-coordinate of q(t) is monotonically increasing. Reparametrizing q, we may arrange that q(t) and p(t) have the same x 1-coordinate, which equals t. Let us write ![
$$q\(t\) =\\big \(t,x_{2}\(t\),\\ldots,x_{n}\(t\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq64.gif). We also denote x 1(t) = t. Since ![
$$g_{1k} = g_{k1} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq65.gif) when ![
$$k \\geqslant 2$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq66.gif) and g 11 = 1, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\vert q\\vert & =& \\int _{0}^{\\epsilon }\\sqrt{\\sum _{ i,j}g_{ij}\\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{i}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\,\\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{j}} {\\mathrm{d}t}} \\mathrm{d}t {}\\\\ & =& \\int _{0}^{\\epsilon }\\sqrt{1 +\\sum _{ 2\\leqslant i,j\\leqslant n}g_{ij}\\,\\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{i}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\,\\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{j}} {\\mathrm{d}t}} \\mathrm{d}t. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

Now since the matrix ![
$$\(g_{ij}\)_{1\\leqslant i,j\\leqslant n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq67.gif) is positive definite, its principal minor ![
$$\(g_{ij}\)_{2\\leqslant i,j\\leqslant n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq68.gif) is also positive definite, so

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{2\\leq i,j\\leq n}g_{ij}\\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{i}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\,\\frac{\\mathrm{d}x_{j}} {\\mathrm{d}t} \\geq 0}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equl.gif)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert q\\vert \\geq \\int _{0}^{\\epsilon }\\sqrt{1}\\,\\mathrm{d}t = \\epsilon = \\vert p\\vert.}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equm.gif)

This argument is easily extended to include all paths such that the values of x 1 for those t such that q(t) ∈ N cover the entire interval [0,ε]. Paths for which this is not true must be long enough to reach the edges of the box x i > B, and after reducing ε if necessary, they must be longer than ε. This completes our discussion of (i).

For (ii), given each unit tangent vector X ∈ T x (M), there is a unique geodesic ![
$$p_{X}: \[0,\\epsilon _{X}\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq69.gif) through x tangent to X, and ε X > 0 may be chosen so that this geodesic is a path of shortest length. We assert that ![
$$\\epsilon _{X}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq70.gif) may be chosen so that the same value ε X is valid for nearby unit tangent vectors Y. We leave this point to the reader except to remark that it is perhaps easiest to see this by applying a diffeomorphism of M that moves X to Y and regarding X as fixed while the metric g ij varies; if Y is sufficiently near X, the variation of g ij will be small and the ε in part (i) can be chosen to work for small variations of the g ij . So for each unit tangent vector X ∈ T x (M) there exists an ε X > 0 and a neighborhood N X of X in the unit ball of T x (M) such that ![
$$p_{Y }: \[0,\\epsilon _{X}\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq71.gif) is a path of shortest length for all Y ∈ N X . Since the unit tangent ball in T x (M) is compact, a finite number of N X suffice to cover it, and if ε is the minimum of the corresponding ε X , then we can take N to be the set of all points connected to x by a geodesic of length < ε. □

If M is a connected Riemannian manifold, we make M into a metric space by defining d(x,y) to be the infimum of |p|, where p is a smooth path from x to y.

Theorem 16.1.

Let M be a compact connected Riemannian manifold, and let x and y be points of M. Then there is a geodesic ![
$$p: \[0,1\]\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq72.gif) with ![
$$p\(0\) = x$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq73.gif) and p(1) = y.

A more precise statement may be found in Kobayashi and Nomizu [110], Theorem 4.2 on p. 172. It is proved there that if M is connected and geodesically complete, meaning that any well-paced geodesic can be extended to (−∞,∞), then the conclusion of the theorem is true. (It is not hard to see that a compact manifold is geodesically complete.)

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\{p_{i}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq74.gif) be a sequence of well-paced paths from x to y such that ![
$$\\vert p_{i}\\vert \\longrightarrow d\(x,y\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq75.gif). Because they are well-paced, if ![
$$0 \\leqslant a <b \\leqslant 1$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq76.gif) we have ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\big\(p_{i}\(a\),p_{i}\(b\)\\big\) = \(b - a\)\\vert p_{i}\\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq77.gif), and it follows that ![
$$\\{p_{i}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq78.gif) are equicontinuous. Thus by Proposition 3.1 there is a subsequence that converges uniformly to a path p. It is not immediately evident that p is smooth, but it is clearly continuous. So we can partition [0,1] into short intervals. On each sufficiently short interval ![
$$0 \\leqslant a <b \\leqslant 1$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq79.gif), p(b) is near enough to p(a) that the unique path of shortest distance between them is a geodesic by Proposition 16.4. It follows that p is a geodesic. □

Theorem 16.2.

Let G be a compact Lie group. There exists on G a Riemannian metric that is invariant under both left and right translation. In this metric, a geodesic is a translate (either left or right) of a map ![
$$t\\longrightarrow \\exp \(tX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq80.gif) for some ![
$$X \\in \\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq81.gif) .

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq82.gif). Since G is a compact group acting by ![
$$\\text{Ad}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq83.gif) on the real vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq84.gif), there exists an Ad(G)-invariant inner product on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq85.gif). Regarding G as the tangent space to G at the identity, if g ∈ G, left translation induces an isomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = T_{e}\(G\)\\longrightarrow T_{g}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq86.gif) and we may transfer this inner product to T g (G). This gives us an inner product on T g (G) and hence a Riemannian structure on G, which is invariant under left translation. Right translation by g induces a different isomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = T_{e}\(G\)\\longrightarrow T_{g}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq87.gif), but these two isomorphisms differ by ![
$$\\text{Ad}\(g\): \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq88.gif), and since the original inner product is invariant under ![
$$\\text{Ad}\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq89.gif), we see that the Riemannian structure we have obtained is invariant under both left and right translation.

It remains to be shown that a geodesic is a translate of the exponential map. This is essentially a local statement. Indeed, it is sufficient to show that any short segment of a geodesic is of the form ![
$$t\\longmapsto g \\cdot \\exp \(tX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq90.gif) since any path that is of such a form on every short interval is globally of the same form. Moreover, since the Riemannian metric is translation-invariant, it is sufficient to show that a geodesic near the origin is of the form ![
$$t\\longrightarrow \\exp \(tX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq91.gif).

First, we consider the case where G is a torus. In this case, ![
$$G\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{R}}^{n}/\\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq92.gif), where Λ is a lattice. We identify the tangent space to ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq93.gif) at any point with ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq94.gif) itself. By a linear change of variables, we may assume that the inner product on ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n} = T_{e}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq95.gif) corresponding to the Riemannian structure is the standard Euclidean inner product. Since the Riemannian structure is invariant under translation it follows that ![
$$G\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{R}}^{n}/\\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq96.gif) is a Riemannian manifold as well as a group. Geodesics are straight lines and so are translates of the exponential map.

We turn now to the general case. If ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq97.gif), let ![
$$E_{X}: \(-\\epsilon,\\epsilon \)\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq98.gif) denote the geodesic through the origin tangent to ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq99.gif). It is defined for sufficiently small ε (depending on X). If ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq100.gif), then ![
$$t\\longmapsto E_{X}\(\\lambda t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq101.gif) is the geodesic through the origin tangent to λX, so E X (λt) = E λX (t). Thus, there is a neighborhood U of the origin in ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq102.gif) and a map ![
$$E: U\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq103.gif) such that E X (t) = E(tX) for X,tX ∈ U. We must show that E coincides with the exponential map.

If g ∈ G, then translating E(tX) on the left by g and on the right by g −1 gives another geodesic, which is tangent to ![
$$\\text{Ad}\(g\)X$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq104.gif). Thus, if tX ∈ U,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ g\\,E\(tX\)\\,{g}^{-1} = E\\big\(t\\,\\text{Ad}\(g\)X\\big\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equ13.gif)

(16.9)

We now fix ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq105.gif). Let T be a maximal torus containing the one-parameter subgroup ![
$$\\{{\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\\,\\vert \\,t \\in \\mathbb{R}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq106.gif). It follows from (16.9) that E(tX) commutes with g ∈ H when tX ∈ U. Thus the path ![
$$t\\longmapsto E\(tX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq107.gif) runs through the centralizer C(T) and a fortiori through N(T). By Proposition 15.8, it follows that E(tX) ∈ T.

Now the translation-invariant Riemannian structure on G induces a translation-invariant Riemannian structure on T, and since the geodesic path ![
$$t\\longmapsto E\(tX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq108.gif) of G is contained in T, it is a geodesic path in T also. The result therefore follows from the special case of the torus, which we have already handled. □

Theorem 16.3.

Let G be a compact Lie group and ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq109.gif) its Lie algebra. Then the exponential map ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq110.gif) is surjective.

Proof.

Put a Riemannian structure on G as in Theorem 16.2. By Theorem 16.1, given g ∈ G, there exists a geodesic path from the identity to g. By Theorem 16.2, this path is of the form t↦e tX for some ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq111.gif), so g = e X . □

Theorem 16.4.

Let G be a compact connected Lie group, and let T be a maximal torus. Let g ∈ G. Then there exists k ∈ G such that g ∈ kTk −1 .

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq112.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq113.gif) be the Lie algebras of G and T, respectively. Let t 0 be a generator of T. Using Theorem 16.3, find ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq114.gif) and ![
$$H_{0} \\in \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq115.gif) such that e X = g and ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{H_{0}} = t_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq116.gif).

Since G is a compact group acting by ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq117.gif) on the real vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq118.gif), there exists on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq119.gif) an ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq120.gif)-invariant inner product for which we will denote the corresponding symmetric bilinear form as ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq121.gif). Choose k ∈ G so that the real value ![
$$\\left \\langle X,\\mathrm{Ad}\(k\)H_{0}\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq122.gif) is maximal, and let ![
$$H = \\mathrm{Ad}\(k\)H_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq123.gif). Thus, exp(H) = kt 0 k −1 generates kTk −1.

If ![
$$Y \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq124.gif) is arbitrary, then ![
$$\\left \\langle X,\\mathrm{Ad}\({\\mathrm{e}}^{tY }\)H\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq125.gif) has a maximum when t = 0, so using Theorem 8.2 we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{0 = \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}\\left \\langle X,\\mathrm{Ad}\({\\mathrm{e}}^{tY }\)H\\right \\rangle \\Big\\vert _{ t=0} = \\left \\langle X,\\mathrm{ad}\(Y \)H\\right \\rangle = -\\left \\langle X,\[H,Y \]\\right \\rangle \\,.}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equn.gif)

By Proposition 10.3, this means that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \[H,X\],Y \\right \\rangle = 0}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equo.gif)

for all Y. Since an inner product is by definition positive definite, the bilinear form ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq126.gif) is nondegenerate, which implies that [H,X] = 0. Now, by Proposition 15.2, e H commutes with e tX for all ![
$$t \\in \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq127.gif). Since e H generates the maximal torus kTk −1, it follows that the one-parameter subgroup ![
$$\\{{\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq128.gif) is contained in the centralizer of kTk −1, and since kTk −1 is a maximal torus, it follows that ![
$$\\{{\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\\} \\subset kT{k}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq129.gif). In particular, ![
$$g ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{X} \\in kT{k}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq130.gif). □

Theorem 16.5 (E. Cartan).

Let G be a compact connected Lie group, and let T be a maximal torus. Then every maximal torus is conjugate to T, and every element of G is contained in a conjugate of T.

Proof.

The second statement is contained in Theorem 16.4. As for the first statement, let T′ be another maximal torus, and let t be a generator. Then t′ is contained in kTk −1 for some k, so ![
$$T^{\\prime} \\subseteq kT{k}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq131.gif). Since both are maximal tori, they are equal. □

Proposition 16.5.

Let G be a compact connected Lie group, ![
$$S \\subset G$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq132.gif) a torus (not necessarily maximal), and ![
$$g \\in C_{G}\(S\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq133.gif) an element of its centralizer. Let H be the closure of the group generated by S and g. Then H has a topological generator. That is, there exists h ∈ H such that the subgroup generated by h is dense in H.

Proof.

Since H is closed and Abelian, its connected component H ∘ of the identity is a torus by Proposition 15.2. Let h 0 be a topological generator.

The group ![
$$H/{H}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq134.gif) is compact and discrete and hence finite. Since ![
$$S \\subseteq {H}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq135.gif), and since S and g generate a dense subgroup of H, the finite group ![
$$H/{H}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq136.gif) is cyclic and generated by ![
$$g{H}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq137.gif). Let r be the order of ![
$$H/{H}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq138.gif). Then ![
$${g}^{r} \\in {H}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq139.gif). Since the rth power map ![
$${H}^{\\circ }\\longrightarrow {H}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq140.gif) is surjective, we can find u ∈ H ∘ such that (gu) r = h 0. Then the group generated by h = ug contains both a generator h 0 of H ∘ and a generator ![
$$g{H}^{\\circ } = \(gu\){H}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq141.gif) of H∕H ∘. Clearly, it is a topological generator of H. □

Proposition 16.6.

If G is a Lie group and u ∈ G, then the centralizer C G (u) is a closed Lie subgroup, and its Lie algebra is ![
$$\\{X \\in \\mathrm{Lie}\(G\)\\,\\vert \\,\\mathrm{Ad}\(u\)X = X\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq142.gif) .

Proof.

To show that H = C G (u) is a closed submanifold of G, it is sufficient to show that its intersection with a small neighborhood of the identity is a closed submanifold since translation by an element h of H will give a diffeomorphism of that neighborhood onto a neighborhood of h. In a neighborhood N of the origin in Lie(G), the exponential map is a diffeomorphism onto exp(N), and we see that the preimage of C G (u) in N is a vector subspace by recalling that conjugation by u corresponds to the linear transformation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(u\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq143.gif) of N. Particularly, ![
$$u\\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\\,{u}^{-1} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{t\\,\\mathrm{ad}\(u\)X}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq144.gif), so ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{tX} \\in C_{G}\(u\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq145.gif) for all t if and only if ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(u\)X = X$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq146.gif). □

Theorem 16.6.

Let G be a compact connected Lie group and ![
$$S \\subset G$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq147.gif) a torus (not necessarily maximal). Then the centralizer ![
$$C_{G}\(S\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq148.gif) is a closed connected Lie subgroup of G.

Proof.

We first prove that ![
$$C_{G}\(S\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq149.gif) is connected. Let ![
$$g \\in C_{G}\(S\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq150.gif). By Proposition 16.5, there exists an element h of C G (S) that generates the closure H of the group generated by S and g. Let T be a maximal torus in G containing h. Then T centralizes S, so the closure of TS is a connected compact Abelian group and hence a torus, and by the maximality of T it follows that ![
$$S \\subseteq T$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq151.gif). Now clearly ![
$$T \\subseteq C_{G}\(S\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq152.gif), and since T is connected, ![
$$T \\subseteq C_{G}{\(S\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq153.gif). Now ![
$$g \\in H \\subseteq T \\subset C_{G}{\(S\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq154.gif). We have shown that ![
$$C_{G}{\(S\)}^{\\circ } = C_{G}\(S\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq155.gif), so C G (S) is connected.

To show that C G (S) is a closed Lie subgroup, let u ∈ S be a generator. Then C G (S) = C G (u), and the statement follows by Proposition 16.6. □

Exercises

Exercise 16.1.

Give an example of a connected Riemannian manifold with two points P and Q such that no geodesic connects P and Q.

Exercise 16.2.

Let G be a compact connected Lie group and let g ∈ G. Show that the centralizer C G (g) of g is connected.

Exercise 16.3.

Show that the conclusion of Exercise 16.2 fails for the connected noncompact Lie group ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq156.gif) by exhibiting an element with a centralizer that is not connected.

If M and N are Riemannian manifolds of the same dimension, and if ![
$$f: M\\longrightarrow N$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq157.gif) is a diffeomorphism, then f is called a conformal map if there exists a positive function ϕ on M such that if x ∈ M and y = f(x), and if we use the notation ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq158.gif) to denote the inner products in both T x (M) and T y (N), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle f_{{\\ast}}X,f_{{\\ast}}Y \\right \\rangle = \\phi \(x\)\\left \\langle X,Y \\right \\rangle,X,Y \\in T_{x}\(M\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equp.gif)

where ![
$$f_{{\\ast}}: T_{x}\(M\)\\longrightarrow T_{y}\(N\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq159.gif) is the induced map. Intuitively, a conformal map is one that preserves angles. If the function ϕ = 1, then f is called isometric.

Exercise 16.4.

Show that if M and N are open subsets in ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq160.gif) and ![
$$f: M\\longrightarrow N$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq161.gif) is a holomorphic map such that the inverse map ![
$${f}^{-1}: N\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq162.gif) exists and is holomorphic (so f′ is never zero), then f is a conformal map.

The next exercises describe the geodesics for some familiar homogeneous spaces. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{D} =\\{ z \\in \\mathbb{C}\\,\\big\\vert \\,\\vert z\\vert <1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq163.gif) be the complex disk in ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq164.gif), and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{R} = \\mathbb{C} \\cup \\{\\infty \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq165.gif) be the Riemann sphere. The group ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq166.gif) acts on ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq167.gif) by linear fractional transformations:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a& b\\\\ c &d \\end{array} \\right \): z\\longmapsto \\frac{az + b} {cz + d}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equq.gif)

In this action, it is understood that ∞ is mapped to a∕c and z is mapped to ∞ if cz \+ d = 0. The map z↦ − 1∕z is a chart near zero, and ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq168.gif) is a complex analytic manifold. Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{A = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a& b\\\\ 0 & \\bar{a} \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,a,b \\in \\mathbb{C},\\;\\vert a{\\vert }^{2} = 1\\right \\},}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equr.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{SU}\(2\) = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a & b\\\\ -\\bar{ b} &\\bar{a} \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,a,b \\in \\mathbb{C},\\;\\vert a{\\vert }^{2} + \\vert b{\\vert }^{2} = 1\\right \\},}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equs.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{SU}\(1, 1\) = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a& b\\\\ \\bar{b} &\\bar{a} \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,a,b \\in \\mathbb{C},\\;\\vert a{\\vert }^{2} -\\vert b{\\vert }^{2} = 1\\right \\},}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equt.gif)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{K = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a&0\\\\ 0 & \\bar{a} \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\;\\vert a{\\vert }^{2} = 1\\right \\}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{U}\(1\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_Equu.gif)

It will be shown in Chap.  that the group ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(1, 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq169.gif) is conjugate in ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq170.gif) to ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_16_Chapter_IEq171.gif). Let G be one of the groups ![

# 17. The Weyl Integration Formula

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

Let G be a compact, connected Lie group, and let T be a maximal torus. Theorem 16.5 implies that every conjugacy class meets T. Thus, we should be able to compute the Haar integral of a class function (e.g., the inner product of two characters) as an integral over the torus. The formula that allows this, the Weyl integration formula, is therefore fundamental in representation theory and in other areas, such as random matrix theory.

Let G be a compact, connected Lie group, and let T be a maximal torus. Theorem 16.5 implies that every conjugacy class meets T. Thus, we should be able to compute the Haar integral of a class function (e.g., the inner product of two characters) as an integral over the torus. The formula that allows this, the Weyl integration formula, is therefore fundamental in representation theory and in other areas, such as random matrix theory.

If G is a locally compact group and H a closed subgroup, then the quotient space G∕H consisting of all cosets gH with g ∈ G, given the quotient topology, is a locally compact Hausdorff space. (See Hewitt and Ross [69, Theorems 5.21 and 5.22 on p. 38].) Such a coset space is called a homogeneous space.

If X is a locally compact Haudorff space let C c (X) be the space of continuous, compactly supported functions on X. If X is a locally compact Hausdorff space, a linear functional I on C c (X) is called positive if ![
$$I\(f\) \\geq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq1.gif) if f is nonnegative. According to the Riesz representation theorem, each such I is of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{I\(f\) =\\int _{X}f\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equa.gif)

for some regular Borel measure ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq2.gif). See Halmos [61, Sect. 56], or Hewitt and Ross [69, Corollary 11.37 on p. 129]. (Regularity of the measure is discussed after Definition 11.34 on p. 127.)

Proposition 17.1.

Let G be a locally compact group, and let H be a compact subgroup. Let ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq3.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq4.gif) be left Haar measures on G and H, respectively. Then there exists a regular Borel measure ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{G/H}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq5.gif) on G∕H which is invariant under the action of G by left translation. The measure d μ G∕H may be normalized so that, for f ∈ C c (G), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G/H}\\int _{H}f\(gh\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{H}\(h\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{G/H}\(gH\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equb.gif)

Here the function ![
$$g\\longmapsto \\int _{H}f\(gh\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq6.gif) is constant on the cosets gH, and we are therefore identifying it with a function on G∕H.

Proof.

We may choose the normalization of dμ H so that H has total volume 1. We define a map ![
$$\\lambda: C_{c}\(G\)\\longrightarrow C_{c}\(G/H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq7.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(\\lambda f\)\(g\) =\\int _{H}f\(gh\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{H}\(h\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equc.gif)

Note that λf is a function on G which is right invariant under translation by elements of H, so it may be regarded as a function on G∕H. Since H is compact, ![
$$\\lambda f$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq8.gif) is compactly supported. If ϕ ∈ C c (G∕H), regarding ϕ as a function on G, we have ![
$$\\lambda \\phi = \\phi$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq9.gif) because

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(\\lambda \\phi \)\(g\) =\\int _{H}\\phi \(gh\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{H}\(h\) =\\int _{H}\\phi \(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{H}\(h\) = \\phi \(g\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equd.gif)

This shows that λ is surjective. We may therefore define a linear functional I on C c (G∕H) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{I\(\\lambda f\) =\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{G}\(g\),f \\in C_{c}\(G\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Eque.gif)

provided we check that this is well defined. We must show that if λf = 0 then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{G}\(g\) = 0. }$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(17.1)

We note that the function ![
$$\(g,h\)\\longmapsto f\(gh\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq10.gif) is compactly supported and continuous on G × H, so if λf = 0 we may use Fubini's theorem to write

![
$$\\displaystyle{0 =\\int _{G}\(\\lambda f\)\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{G}\(g\) =\\int _{H}\\int _{G}f\(gh\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{G}\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{H}\(h\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equf.gif)

In the inner integral on the right-hand side we make the variable change ![
$$g\\longmapsto g{h}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq11.gif). Recalling that ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{G}\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq12.gif) is left Haar measure, this produces a factor of δ G (h), where δ G is the modular quasicharacter on G. Thus,

![
$$\\displaystyle{0 =\\int _{H}\\delta _{G}\(h\)\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{G}\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}\\mu _{H}\(h\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equg.gif)

Now the group H is compact, so its image under δ G is a compact subgroup of ![
$$\\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq13.gif), which must be just ![
$$\\{1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq14.gif). Thus, ![
$$\\delta _{G}\(h\) = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq15.gif) for all h ∈ H and we obtain (17.1), justifying the definition of the functional I. The existence of the measure on G∕H now follows from the Riesz representation theorem. □

We have seen in Proposition 15.9 that in the adjoint action on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\text{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq16.gif), restricted to T, the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq17.gif) is an invariant subspace, complemented by a space ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq18.gif), which decomposes as the direct sum of nontrivial two-dimensional irreducible real representations as described in Proposition 15.5.

Let ![
$$W = N\(T\)/T$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq19.gif) be the Weyl group of G. The Weyl group acts on T by conjugation. Indeed, the elements of the Weyl group are cosets w = nT for n ∈ N(T). If t ∈ T, the element ntn −1 depends only on w so by abuse of notation we denote it ![
$$wt{w}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq20.gif).

Theorem 17.1.

(i)

Two elements of T are conjugate in G if and only if they are conjugate in N(T).

(ii)

The inclusion T ⟶ G induces a bijection between the orbits of W on T and the conjugacy classes of G.

Proof.

Suppose that t,u ∈ T are conjugate in G, say ![
$$gt{g}^{-1} = u$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq21.gif). Let ![
$$H = C_{G}{\(u\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq22.gif) be the connected component of the identity in the centralizer of u. It is a closed Lie subgroup of G by Proposition 16.6. Both T and ![
$$gT{g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq23.gif) are contained in H since they are connected commutative groups containing u. As they are maximal tori in G, they are maximal tori in H, and so they are conjugate in the compact connected group H. If h ∈ H such that ![
$$hT{h}^{-1} = gT{g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq24.gif), then ![
$$w = {h}^{-1}g \\in N\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq25.gif). Since ![
$$wt{w}^{-1} = {h}^{-1}uh = u$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq26.gif), we see that t and u are conjugate in N(T).

Since G is the union of the conjugates of T, (ii) is a restatement of (i). □

Proposition 17.2.

The centralizer C(T) = T.

Proof.

Since ![
$$C\(T\) \\subset N\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq27.gif), T is of finite index in C(T) by Proposition 15.8. Thus, if x ∈ C(T), we have x n ∈ T for some n. Let t 0 be a generator of T. Since the nth power map T ⟶ T is surjective, there exists t ∈ T such that (xt) n = t 0. Now xt is contained in a maximal torus T′, which contains t 0 and hence ![
$$T \\subset T^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq28123.gif). Since T is maximal, T′ = T and x ∈ T. □

Proposition 17.3.

There exists a dense open set Ω of T such that the |W| elements wtw −1 (w ∈ W) are all distinct for t ∈Ω.

See Proposition 23.4 for a more precise result.

Proof.

If w ∈ W, let ![
$$\\varOmega _{w} =\\{ t \\in T\\,\\vert \\,wt{w}^{-1}\\neq t\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq29.gif). It is an open subset of T since its complement is evidently closed. If w≠1 and t is a generator of T, then t ∈Ω w because otherwise if n ∈ N(T) represents w, then n ∈ C(t) = C(T), so n ∈ T by Proposition 17.2. This is a contradiction since w≠1. The finite intersection ![
$$\\varOmega =\\bigcap _{w\\neq 1}\\varOmega _{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) is dense by Kronecker's Theorem 15.1. It thus fits our requirements. □

Theorem 17.2 (Weyl).

Let G be a compact connected Lie group, and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq31.gif) be as in Proposition 15.9 . If f is a class function, and if dg and dt are Haar measures on G and T (normalized so that G and T have volume 1), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g = \\frac{1} {\\vert W\\vert }\\int _{T}f\(t\)\\det \\big\(\[\\text{Ad}\({t}^{-1}\) - I_{\\mathfrak{p}}\]\\,\\big\\vert \\,\\mathfrak{p}\\big\)\\,\\mathrm{d}t.}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equh.gif)

Proof.

Let ![
$$X = G/T$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq32123.gif). We give X the measure d X invariant under left translation by G such that X has volume 1. Consider the map

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\qquad \\phi: X \\times T\\longrightarrow G,\\quad \\phi \(xT,t\) = xt{x}^{-1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Both X × T and G are orientable manifolds of the same dimension. Of course, G and T both are given the Haar measures such that G and T have volume 1.

We choose volume elements on the Lie algebras ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq33.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) of G and T, respectively, so that the Jacobians of the exponential maps ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq35.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}\\longrightarrow T$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq36.gif) at the identity are 1.

We compute the Jacobian Jϕ of ϕ. Parametrize a neighborhood of xT in X by a chart based on a neighborhood of the origin in ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq37.gif). This chart is the map

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{p} \\ni U\\mapsto x{\\mathrm{e}}^{U}T\\;.}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equj.gif)

We also make use of the exponential map to parametrize a neighborhood of t ∈ T. This is the chart ![
$$\\mathfrak{t} \\ni V \\mapsto t{\\mathrm{e}}^{V }$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq38.gif). We therefore have the chart near the point (xT,t) in X × T mapping

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{p} \\times \\mathfrak{t} \\ni \(U,V \)\\longrightarrow \(x{\\mathrm{e}}^{U}T,t{\\mathrm{e}}^{V }\) \\in X \\times T}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equk.gif)

and, in these coordinates, ϕ is the map

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(U,V \)\\mapsto x{\\mathrm{e}}^{U}t{\\mathrm{e}}^{V }{\\mathrm{e}}^{-U}{x}^{-1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equl.gif)

To compute the Jacobian of this map, we translate on the left by ![
$${t}^{-1}{x}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq39.gif) and on the right by x. There is no harm in this because these maps are Haar isometries. We are reduced to computing the Jacobian of the map

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(U,V \)\\mapsto {t}^{-1}{\\mathrm{e}}^{U}t{\\mathrm{e}}^{V }{\\mathrm{e}}^{-U} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{\\text{Ad}\({t}^{-1}\)U }{\\mathrm{e}}^{V }{\\mathrm{e}}^{-U}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equm.gif)

Identifying the tangent space of the real vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{p} \\times \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq40.gif) with itself (that is, with ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{p} \\oplus \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq41.gif)), the differential of this map is

![
$$\\displaystyle{U + V \\mapsto \\big\(\\text{Ad}\({t}^{-1}\) - I_{\\mathfrak{p}}\\big\)\\,U + V.}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equn.gif)

The Jacobian is the determinant of the differential, so

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(J\\phi \)\(xT,t\) =\\det \\big \(\[\\text{Ad}\({t}^{-1}\) - I_{\\mathfrak{p}}\]\\,\\vert \\,\\mathfrak{p}\\big\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(17.2)

By Proposition 17.3, the map ![
$$\\phi: X \\times T\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq42.gif) is a |W|-fold cover over a dense open set and so, for any function f on G, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g = \\frac{1} {\\vert W\\vert }\\int _{X\\times T}f\\big\(\\phi \(xT,t\)\\big\)\\,J\\big\(\\phi \(xT,t\)\\big\)\\,\\mathrm{d}x \\times \\mathrm{d}t.}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equo.gif)

The integrand ![
$$f\\big\(\\phi \(xT,t\)\\big\)\\,J\\big\(\\phi \(xT,t\)\\big\) = f\(t\)\\,\\det \\big\(\[\\text{Ad}\({t}^{-1}\) - I_{\\mathfrak{p}}\]\\,\\vert \\,\\mathfrak{p}\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq43.gif) is independent of x since f is a class function, and the result follows. □

An example may help make this result more concrete.

Proposition 17.4.

Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq44.gif) , and let T be the diagonal torus. Writing

![
$$\\displaystyle{t = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\,t_{1}\\, & & \\\\ & \\,\\ddots\\, & \\\\ & & \\,t_{n}\\, \\end{array} \\right \) \\in T,}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equp.gif)

and letting ∫ Td t be the Haar measure on T normalized so that its volume is 1, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g = \\frac{1} {n!}\\int _{T}f\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\,t_{1}\\, & & \\\\ & \\,\\ddots\\, & \\\\ & & \\,t_{n}\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\prod _{i<j}\\vert t_{i}-t_{j}{\\vert }^{2}\\mathrm{d}t. }$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(17.3)

Proof.

This will follow from Theorem 17.2 once we check that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\det \\big\(\[\\text{Ad}\({t}^{-1}\) - I_{\\mathfrak{p}}\]\\,\\vert \\,\\mathfrak{p}\\big\) =\\prod _{ i<j}\\vert t_{i} - t_{j}{\\vert }^{2}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equq.gif)

To compute this determinant, we may as well consider the linear transformation induced by ![
$$\\text{Ad}\({t}^{-1}\) - I_{\\mathfrak{p}}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq45.gif) on the complexified vector space ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq46.gif). As in Proposition 11.4, we may identify ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq47.gif) with ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) = \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq48.gif). We recall that ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq49.gif) is spanned by the ![
$$T$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq50.gif)-eigenspaces in ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq51.gif) corresponding to nontrivial characters of T. These are spanned by the elementary matrices E ij with a 1 in the i,jth position and zeros elsewhere, where ![
$$1 \\leq i,j \\leq n$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq52.gif) and i≠j. The eigenvalue of t on E ij is t i t j −1. Hence

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\det \\big\(\[\\text{Ad}\({t}^{-1}\) - I_{\\mathfrak{p}}\]\\,\\vert \\,\\mathfrak{p}\\big\) =\\prod _{ i\\neq j}\(t_{i}t_{j}^{-1} - 1\) =\\prod _{ i<j}\(t_{i}t_{j}^{-1} - 1\)\(t_{ j}t_{i}^{-1} - 1\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equr.gif)

Since ![
$$\\vert t_{i}\\vert = \\vert t_{j}\\vert = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq53.gif), we have ![
$$\(t_{i}t_{j}^{-1} - 1\)\(t_{j}t_{i}^{-1} - 1\) = \(t_{i} - t_{j}\)\(t_{i}^{-1} - t_{j}^{-1}\) = \\vert t_{i} - t_{j}{\\vert }^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq54.gif), proving (17.3). □

Let f be a class function on ![

](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_IEq58.gif). Suppose that

![

](A79351_2_En_17_Chapter_Equu.gif)
