# 19. Examples of Root Systems

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

It may be easiest to read the next chapter with examples in mind. In this chapter we will describe various root systems and in particular we will illustrate the rank 2 root systems. Since the purpose of this chapter is to give examples, we will state various facts here without proof. The proofs will come in later chapters.

It may be easiest to read the next chapter with examples in mind. In this chapter we will describe various root systems and in particular we will illustrate the rank 2 root systems. Since the purpose of this chapter is to give examples, we will state various facts here without proof. The proofs will come in later chapters.

A root system Φ in a Euclidean space ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq1.gif) is called reducible if we can decompose ![
$$\\mathcal{V} = \\mathcal{V}_{1} \\oplus \\mathcal{V}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq2.gif) into orthogonal subspaces with ![
$$\\varPhi =\\varPhi _{1} \\cup \\varPhi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq3.gif), with both ![
$$\\varPhi _{i} = \\mathcal{V}_{i}\\cap \\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq4.gif) nonempty. Then the Φ i are themselves smaller root systems. In classifying root systems, one may clearly restrict to irreducible root systems, and these were classified by Killing and Cartan. The irreducible root systems are classified by a Cartan type which can be one of the classical Cartan types A r (![
$$r \\geqslant 1$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq5.gif)), B r (![
$$r \\geqslant 2$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq6.gif)), C r (![
$$r \\geqslant 2$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq7.gif)) D r (![
$$r \\geqslant 4$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq8.gif)), or one of the five exceptional types G 2, F 4, E 6, E 7 and E 8. The subscript is the (semisimple) rank of the corresponding Lie groups. We have an accidental isomorphism ![
$$B_{2}\\mathop{\\cong}C_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq9.gif). The Cartan types D 2 and D 3 are usually excluded, but it may be helpful to consider D 2 as a synonym for the reducible Cartan type A 1 × A 1 (that is, A 1 is the Cartan type of both Φ 1 and Φ 2 in the orthogonal decomposition); and D 3 as a synonym for A 3.

In the last chapter we saw how to associate a root system Φ with a compact Lie group G. The Euclidean ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq10.gif) containing Φ is ![
$$\\mathbb{R} \\otimes {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq11.gif) where T is a maximal torus. The group G is called semisimple if the root system Φ spans ![
$$\\mathcal{V} = \\mathbb{R}\\otimes \\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq12.gif) where Λ = X ∗(T) is the group of rational characters of a maximal torus T. We will denote by ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq13.gif) the Lie algebra of G and other notations will be as in Chap.

Within each Cartan type there may be several Lie groups to consider, but in each case there is a unique semisimple simply connected group. There is also a unique simple semisimple group, which is isomorphic to the simply connected group modulo its finite center. This is called the adjoint group since it is isomorphic to its image in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq14.gif) under the adjoint representation. Here is a table giving the simply connected and adjoint groups for each of the classical Cartan types.

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}\\hline\\text{Cartan type}&\\mbox{ Simply connected $G$}&\\mbox{ Adjoint group} & \\mbox{ Other common instance} \\\\\\hline A_{r} & \\mathrm{SU}\(r + 1\) &\\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)/\\mathrm{center}&\\begin{array}{c} \\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)\\\\ \\mbox{\(not semisimple\)} \\end{array} \\\\\\hline B_{r} & \\mathrm{Spin}\(2r + 1\) & \\mathrm{SO}\(2r + 1\) & \\\\\\hline C_{r} & \\mathrm{Sp}\(2r\) & \\mathrm{Sp}\(2r\)/\\mathrm{center} & \\\\\\hline D_{r} & \\mathrm{Spin}\(2r\) & \\mathrm{SO}\(2r\)/\\{ \\pm I\\} & \\mathrm{SO}\(2r\) \\\\\\hline\\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Let us consider first the Cartan type A r . We will describe three distinct groups, ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq15.gif), ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq16.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{PU}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq17.gif), which is U(r \+ 1) modulo its one-dimensional center. These have the same root system, but the ambient vector space ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq18.gif) is different in each case.

The group ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq19.gif) is not semisimple. Its rank is r \+ 1 but its semisimple rank is r. The maximal torus T consists of diagonal matrices t with eigenvalues t 1,...,t r+1 in ![
$$\\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq20.gif), the group of complex numbers of absolute value 1. We may identify ![
$$\\varLambda = {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{Z}}^{r+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq21.gif), in which ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{r+1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq22.gif) with ![
$$\\lambda _{i} \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq23.gif) represents the character ![
$$t\\mapsto \\prod t_{i}^{\\lambda _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq24.gif). So ![
$$\\mathcal{V} = \\mathbb{R} \\otimes {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq25.gif) may be identified with ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{r+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq2612.gif) with the usual Euclidean inner product. Let ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{i} = \(0,\\ldots,0,1,0,\\ldots,0\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq27132.gif) be the standard basis of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{r+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq28123.gif). The root system consists of the r(r − 1) vectors

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathbf{e}_{i} -\\mathbf{e}_{j},\\qquad i\\neq j, }$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(19.1)

having exactly two nonzero entries, one being 1 and the other − 1. To see that this is the root system, we recall that the complexified Lie algebra is ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{g}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}_{r+1}\(\\mathbb{C}\) = \\mathrm{Mat}_{r+1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq29123.gif), since ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{r+1}\(\\mathbb{C}\) = \\mathfrak{g} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq30123.gif). (Every complex matrix can be written uniquely as X \+ iY with X and Y skew-Hermitian.) If ![
$$\\alpha = \\mathbf{e}_{i} -\\mathbf{e}_{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq31123.gif), the one-dimensional vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) of ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{r+1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) spanned by the matrix E ij with a 1 in the i,j-position and 0's everywhere else is an eigenspace for T affording the character α, and these eigenspaces, together with the Lie algebra of T, span V. So the ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{i} -\\mathbf{e}_{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) are precisely the roots of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq35.gif). The group ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq36.gif) has semisimple rank r, since that is the dimension of the space spanned by these vectors.

Next consider the group ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq37.gif). This is the semisimple and simply connected group with the same root system. The ambient space ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq38.gif) is one dimension smaller than for ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq39.gif), because the t i are subject to the equation ![
$$\\prod t_{i} =\\det \(t\) = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq40.gif). Therefore, the character represented by ![
$$\\lambda \\in {\\mathbb{Z}}^{r+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq41.gif) is trivial if λ is in the diagonal lattice ![
$$\\varDelta = \\mathbb{Z}\(1,\\ldots,1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq42.gif). Thus, for this group, the weight lattice, which we will denote ![
$$\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{SU}\(r+1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq43.gif), is ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{r+1}/\\varDelta$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq44.gif), and the space ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq45.gif) is r-dimensional. It is spanned by the roots, so this group is semisimple.

The group ![
$$\\mathrm{PU}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq46.gif) is ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq47.gif) modulo its one-dimensional central torus. It is the adjoint group for the Cartan type A r . It is isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq48.gif) modulo its finite center of order r \+ 1. A character of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq49.gif) parametrized by ![
$$\\lambda \\in {\\mathbb{Z}}^{r+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq50.gif) is well-defined if and only if it is trivial on the center of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq51.gif), which requires ∑λ i = 0. So the lattice ![
$$\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{PU}\(r+1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq52.gif) is isomorphic to the sublattice of ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{r+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq53.gif) determined by this condition. The composition

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{PU}\(r+1\)}\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{Z}}^{r+1}\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{Z}}^{r+1}/\\varDelta =\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{ SU}\(r+1\)}}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equb.gif)

where the first map is the inclusion and the second the projection is injective, so we may regard ![
$$\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{PU}\(r+1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq54.gif) as a sublattice of ![
$$\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{SU}\(r+1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq55.gif). Its index is r \+ 1.

Turning now to the general case, the set Φ of roots will be partitioned into two parts, called Φ + and Φ −. Exactly half the roots will be in Φ + and the other half in Φ −. This is accomplished by choosing a hyperplane through the origin in ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq56.gif) that does not pass through any root, and taking Φ + to be the roots on one side of the hyperplane, Φ − the roots on the other side. Although the choice of the hyperplane is arbitrary, if another such decomposition ![
$$\\varPhi =\\varPhi _{ 1}^{+} \\cup \\varPhi _{1}^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq57.gif) is found by choosing a different hyperplane, a Weyl group element w can be found such that ![
$$w{\(\\varPhi }^{+}\) =\\varPhi _{ 1}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq58.gif) and ![
$$w{\(\\varPhi }^{-}\) =\\varPhi _{ 1}^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq59.gif), so the procedure is not as arbitrary as one might think. The roots in Φ + will be called positive. In the figures of this chapter, the positive roots are labeled •, and the negative roots are labeled ![
$$\\circ$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq60.gif).

If G is a semisimple compact connected Lie group, then its universal cover ![
$$\\tilde{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq61.gif) is a cover of finite degree, and as in the last example (where ![
$$G = \\mathrm{PU}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq62.gif) and ![
$$\\tilde{G} = \\mathrm{SU}\(r + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq63.gif)) the weight lattice of ![
$$G$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq64.gif) is a sublattice of ![
$$\\tilde{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq65.gif). Moreover, if ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq66.gif) is an irreducible representation, then we may compose it with the canonical map ![
$$\\tilde{G}\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq67.gif) and get a representation of ![
$$\\tilde{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq68.gif). So if we understand the representation theory of ![
$$\\tilde{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq69.gif) we understand the representation theory of G. For this reason, we will consider mainly the case where G is simply connected and semisimple in the remaining examples of this chapter.

Assuming G is semisimple, so the α i span ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq70.gif), we will define certain special elements of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq71.gif) as follows. If ![
$$\\varSigma =\\{ \\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{r}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq72.gif) are the simple positive roots then let ![
$$\\{\\alpha _{1}^{\\vee }\\ldots,\\alpha _{r}^{\\vee }\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq73.gif) be the corresponding coroots. In the semisimple case, the coroots span ![
$${\\mathcal{V}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq74.gif), and the fundamental dominant weights ![
$$\\varpi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq75.gif) are the dual basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq76.gif). Thus,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha _{j}^{\\vee }\(\\varpi _{ i}\) = \\delta _{ij}\(\\mbox{ Kronecker $\\delta $}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equc.gif)

We will show later that if G is simply connected, then the ![
$$\\varpi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq77.gif) are in the weight lattice ![
$$\\varLambda = {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq78.gif), though if G is not simply connected, they may not all be in Λ.

Another important particular vector is ρ, sometimes called the Weyl vector. It may be characterized as half the sum of the positive roots, and in the semisimple case it may also be characterized as the sum of the fundamental weights. (See Proposition 20.17.)

For example, the root system of type A 2, pictured in Fig. 19.1, consists of

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & \\alpha _{1} = \(1,-1,0\),\\qquad \\alpha _{2} =& \(0,1,-1\),\\qquad \(1,0,-1\), {}\\\\ & \(-1,1,0\),\\qquad & \(0,-1,1\),\\qquad \(-1,0,1\). {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

With ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SU}\(3\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq79.gif), we really mean the images of these vectors in ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{3}/\\varDelta$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq80.gif), as explained above. Taking T to be the diagonal torus of ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(3\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq81.gif), α1 and ![
$$\\alpha _{2} \\in {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq82.gif) are the roots

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha _{1}\(t\) = t_{1}t_{2}^{-1},\\qquad a_{ 2}\(t\) = t_{2}t_{3}^{-1},\\qquad t = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} t_{1} & & \\\\ & t_{2} & \\\\ & & t_{3} \\end{array} \\right \) \\in T.}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equd.gif)

The corresponding eigenspaces are spanned by

![
$$\\displaystyle{E_{12} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} 0&1&0\\\\ 0 &0 &0 \\\\ 0&0&0 \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha _{1}},E_{23} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} 0&0&0\\\\ 0 &0 &1 \\\\ 0&0&0 \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha _{2}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Eque.gif)

The fundamental dominant weights ![
$$\\varpi _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq83.gif) and ![
$$\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq84.gif) are, respectively, ![
$$\\varpi _{1}\(t\) = t_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq85.gif) and ![
$$\\varpi _{2}\(t\) = t_{3}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq86.gif). Let v 0 = (1,1,1), so in our previous notation ![
$$\\varDelta = \\mathbb{Z}v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq87.gif). The vector space ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq88.gif) is ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{3}/\\mathbb{R}v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq89.gif), but we may identify this with the codimension one vector subspace of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{3}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq90.gif) consisting of (x 1,x 2,x 3) with ∑ x i = 0. The fundamental weights are represented by the cosets in ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{3}/\\mathbb{Z}v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq91.gif) of the vectors (1,0,0) and (1,1,0), or in the subspace of codimension one in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{3}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq92.gif) consisting of vectors ![
$$\(x_{0},x_{1},x_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq93.gif) satisfying ![
$$\\sum _{i}x_{i} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq94.gif) by ![
$$\(\\frac{2} {3},-\\frac{1} {3},-\\frac{1} {3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq95.gif) and ![
$$\(\\frac{1} {3}, \\frac{1} {3},-\\frac{2} {3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq96.gif), respectively.

Fig. 19.1

The root system of type A 2

Figure 19.1 shows the root system of type A 2 associated with the Lie group ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(3\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq97.gif). The shaded region in Fig. 19.1 is the positive Weyl chamber ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq98.gif), which consists of ![
$$\\{x \\in \\mathcal{V}\\vert \\mbox{ $\\left \\langle x,\\alpha \\right \\rangle \\geq 0$ for all $\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq99.gif). It is a fundamental domain for the Weyl group.

Fig. 19.2

The partial order

A role will also be played by a partial order on ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq100.gif). We define x ≽ y if x − y ≽ 0, where x ≽ 0 if x is a linear combination, with nonnegative coefficients, of the elements of Σ. The shaded region in Fig. 19.2 is the set of x such that x ≽ 0 for the root system of type A 2.

Next we turn to the remaining classical root systems. The root system of type B n is associated with the odd orthogonal group ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq101.gif) or with its double cover ![
$$\\mathrm{spin}\(2n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq102.gif). The root system of type ![
$$C_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq103.gif) is associated with the symplectic group ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq104.gif). Finally, the root system of type D n is associated with the even orthogonal group ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq105.gif) or its double cover ![
$$\\mathrm{spin}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq106.gif). We will now describe these root systems. Let ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{i} = \(0,\\ldots,0,1,0,\\ldots,0\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq107.gif) be the standard basis of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq108.gif).

The root system of type ![
$$B_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq109.gif) can be embedded in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq110.gif). The roots are not all of the same length. There are 2n short roots

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i}\(1 \\leq i \\leq n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equf.gif)

and 2(n 2 − n) long roots

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i} \\pm \\mathbf{e}_{j}\(i\\neq j\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equg.gif)

The simple positive roots are

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha _{1} = \\mathbf{e}_{1} -\\mathbf{e}_{2},\\alpha _{2} = \\mathbf{e}_{2} -\\mathbf{e}_{3},\\ldots \\alpha _{n-1} = \\mathbf{e}_{n-1} -\\mathbf{e}_{n},\\alpha _{n} = \\mathbf{e}_{n}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equh.gif)

To see that this is the root system of ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq111.gif), it is most convenient to use the representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq112.gif) in Exercise 5.3. Thus, we replace the usual realization of ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq113.gif) as a group of real matrices by the subgroup of all ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{U}\(2n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq114.gif) that satisfy ![
$$g\\,{J\\,}^{t}g = J$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq115.gif), where

A maximal torus consists of all diagonal elements, which have the form (when n = 4, for example)

![
$$\\displaystyle{t = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccccccccc} t_{1} & & & & & & & & \\\\ & t_{2} & & & & & & & \\\\ & & t_{3} & & & & & & \\\\ & & & t_{4} & & & & & \\\\ & & & & 1& & & & \\\\ & & & & &t_{4}^{-1} & & & \\\\ & & & & & & t_{3}^{-1} & & \\\\ & & & & & & & t_{2}^{-1} & \\\\ & & & & & & & & t_{1}^{-1} \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equi.gif)

The Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq116.gif) consists of all skew-Hermitian matrices X satisfying ![
$$X\\,J + {J\\,}^{t}X = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq117.gif). Now we claim that the complexification of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq118.gif) just consists of all complex matrices satisfying ![
$$X\\,J + {J\\,}^{t}X = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq119.gif). Indeed, by Proposition 11.4, any complex matrix X can be written uniquely as X 1 \+ iX 2 with X 1 and X 2 skew-Hermitian, and it is easy to see that ![
$$X\\,J + {J\\,}^{t}X = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq120.gif) if and only if X 1 and X 2 satisfy the same identity. Thus, ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{g} =\\{ X \\in \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)\\,\\vert \\,X\\,J + {J\\,}^{t}X = 0\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq121.gif). It now follows from Proposition 11.3(iii) that this is the complexification of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq122.gif). This Lie algebra is shown in Fig. 19.3 when n = 4.

Fig. 19.3

The Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{o}\(9\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq123.gif). The Dynkin diagram, which will be explained in Chap.​ 25, has been superimposed on top of the Lie algebra

We order the roots so the root spaces ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq124.gif) with α ∈Φ + are upper triangular. In particular, the simple roots are ![
$$\\alpha _{1}\(t\) = t_{1}t_{2}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq125.gif), acting on ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha _{1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq126.gif), the space of matrices in which all entries are zero except x 12; ![
$$\\alpha _{2}\(t\) = t_{2}t_{3}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq127.gif), with root space corresponding to x 23; ![
$$\\alpha _{3}\(t\) = t_{3}t_{4}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq128.gif) corresponding to x 34; and α4(t) = t 4, corresponding to x 45. We have circled these positions. Note, however that (for example) x 12 appears in a second place which has not been circled. The lines connecting the circles, one of them double, map out the Dynkin diagram, which will explained in greater detail Chap.​ 25. Briefly, the Dynkin diagram is a graph whose vertices correspond to the simple roots; simple roots are connected in the Dynkin diagram if they are not perpendicular. We have drawn the nodes corresponding to each simple root on top of the variable x ij for the corresponding eigenspace.

We have drawn a double bond with an arrow pointing from a long root to a short root, which is the convention when two nonadjacent roots have different lengths.

If we take ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{i} \\in {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq129.gif) to be the character ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{i}\(t\) = t_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq130.gif), then it is clear that the root system consists of the 2n 2 roots ![
$$\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq131.gif) and ![
$$\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i} \\pm e_{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq132.gif) (![
$$i\\neq j$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq133.gif)), as claimed.

The root system of type C n is similar, but the long and short roots are reversed. Now there are 2n long roots

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pm 2\\mathbf{e}_{i}\(1 \\leq i \\leq n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equj.gif)

and ![
$$2\({n}^{2} - n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq134.gif) short roots

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i} \\pm \\mathbf{e}_{j}\(i\\neq j\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equk.gif)

The simple positive roots are

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha _{1} = \\mathbf{e}_{1} -\\mathbf{e}_{2},\\alpha _{2} = \\mathbf{e}_{2} -\\mathbf{e}_{3},\\ldots \\alpha _{n-1} = \\mathbf{e}_{n-1} -\\mathbf{e}_{n},\\alpha _{n} = 2\\mathbf{e}_{n}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equl.gif)

We leave it to the reader to show that C n is the root system of ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq135.gif) in Exercise 19.2. (Fig. 30.​15 may help with this.)

The root system of type D n consists of just the long roots in the root system of type B n . There are 2(n 2 − n) roots, all of the same length:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i} \\pm \\mathbf{e}_{j}\(i\\neq j\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equm.gif)

The simple positive roots are

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha _{1} = \\mathbf{e}_{1} -\\mathbf{e}_{2},\\alpha _{2} = \\mathbf{e}_{2} -\\mathbf{e}_{3},\\ldots \\alpha _{n-1} = \\mathbf{e}_{n-1} -\\mathbf{e}_{n},\\alpha _{n} = \\mathbf{e}_{n-1} + \\mathbf{e}_{n}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equn.gif)

To see that D n is the root system of ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq136.gif), one may again use the realization of Exercise 5.3. We leave this verification to the reader in Exercise 19.2. (Fig. 30.​1 may help with this.)

Fig. 19.4

The root system of type C 2, which coincides with type B 2

It happens that ![
$$\\mathrm{spin}\(5\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Sp}\(4\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq137.gif), so the root systems of types B 2 and C 2 coincide. These are shown in Fig. 19.4. The shaded region is the positive Weyl chamber. (We have labeled the roots so that the order coincides with the root system C 2 in the notations of Bourbaki [23], in the appendix at the back of the book. For type B 2, the roots α1 and α2 would be switched.)

There is a nonreduced root system whose type is called BC n . The root system of type BC n can be realized as all elements of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i} \\pm \\mathbf{e}_{j}\(i <j\),\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i},\\pm 2\\mathbf{e}_{i},}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equo.gif)

where ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq138.gif) are standard basis vectors of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq139.gif). Nonreduced root systems do not occur as root systems of compact Lie groups, but they occur as relative root systems (Chap.​ 29). The root system of type BC 2 may be found in Fig. 19.5.

Fig. 19.5

The nonreduced root system BC 2

In addition to the infinite families of Lie groups in the Cartan classification are five exceptional groups, of types G 2, F 4, E 6, E 7 and E 8. The root system of type G 2 is shown in Fig. 19.6.

Fig. 19.6

The root system of type G 2

Fig. 19.7

The reducible root system A 1 × A 1

In addition to the three root systems we have just considered there is another rank two reduced root system. This is called A 1 × A 1, and it is illustrated in Fig. 19.7. Unlike the others listed here, this one is reducible. If ![
$$\\mathcal{V} = \\mathcal{V}_{1} \\oplus \\mathcal{V}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq140.gif) (orthogonal direct sum), and if Φ 1 and Φ 2 are root systems in ![
$$\\mathcal{V}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq141.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{V}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq142.gif), then ![
$$\\varPhi =\\varPhi _{1} \\cup \\varPhi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq143.gif) is a root system in ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq144.gif) such that every root in ![
$$\\varPhi _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq145.gif) is orthogonal to every root in ![
$$\\varPhi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq146.gif). The root system ![
$$\\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq147.gif) is reducible if it decomposes in this way.

We leave two other rank 2 root systems, which are neither reduced nor irreducible, to the imagination of the reader. Their types are ![
$$A_{1} \\times BC_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq148.gif) and ![
$$BC_{1} \\times BC_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq149.gif).

Exercises

Exercise 19.1.

Show that any irreducible rank 2 root system is isomorphic to one of those described in this chapter, of type A 2, B 2, G 2 or BC 2.

Exercise 19.2.

Verify, as we did for type ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq150.gif), that the root system of the Lie group ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq151.gif) is of type D n and that the root system of ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq152.gif) is of type C n .

Exercise 19.3.

Show that the root systems of types B 2 and C 2 are isomorphic.

Exercise 19.4.

Show that the root system of ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(6\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq153.gif) is isomorphic to that of ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(4\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq154.gif). What can you say about the root system of ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(4\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq155.gif)?

Exercise 19.5.

Suppose that G is a compact Lie group with root system Φ, and that H is a Lie subgroup of G having the same maximal torus. Show that every root of H is a root of G, and that if ![
$$\\varPhi ^{\\prime} \\subseteq \\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq156.gif) is the root system of H, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mbox{ If $\\alpha,\\beta \\in \\varPhi ^{\\prime}$ and $\\alpha + \\beta \\in \\varPhi $ then $\\alpha + \\beta \\in \\varPhi ^{\\prime}$.} }$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(19.2)

Exercise 19.6.

Conversely, let G be a compact Lie group with root system Φ. Let ![
$$\\varPhi ^{\\prime} \\subseteq \\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq157.gif) be a root system such that (19.2) is satisfied. Show that in the notation of Chap.​ 18, ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq158.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq159.gif) (α ∈Φ′) form a complex Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq160.gif), and that ![
$$\\mathfrak{h} = \\mathfrak{h}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq161.gif) is a Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq162.gif).

Exercise 19.7.

Let Φ be the root system of type G 2.

(i)

Show that the long roots form a root system Φ′ satisfying (19.2).

(ii)

Assume the following fact: there exists a simply connected compact Lie group G whose root system is Φ. This Lie group G 2 may be constructed as the group of automorphisms of the octonions (Jacobson [87]). Prove that there exists a nontrivial homomorphism ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(3\) \\rightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq163.gif) (known to be injective). (Hint: Use Exercise 19.6 and Theorem 14.2.)

(ii)

Exhibit another root system in Φ of rank two satisfying (19.2). Note that you cannot use the short roots for this.

It may be shown that the root systems Φ′ in (i) and (ii) of the last exercise correspond to Lie groups [![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{u}\(3\)$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq164.gif) for part (i)] that may be embedded in the exceptional group G 2.

Exercise 19.8.

Let ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq165.gif) (i = 1, 2, 3, 4) be the standard basis elements of ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{4}$$
](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_IEq166.gif). Show that the 48 vectors

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i}\\;\(1 \\leqslant i \\leqslant 4\),\\qquad\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{i} \\pm \\mathbf{e}_{j}\\;\(1 \\leqslant i <j \\leqslant 4\), \\qquad\\frac{1} {2}\(\\pm \\mathbf{e}_{1} \\pm \\mathbf{e}_{2} \\pm \\mathbf{e}_{3} \\pm \\mathbf{e}_{4}\)\\,,}$$](A79351_2_En_19_Chapter_Equp.gif)

form a root system. This is the root system of Cartan type F 4. Compute the order of the Weyl group. Show that this root system contains smaller root systems of types B 3 and C 3.

# 20. Abstract Weyl Groups

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In this chapter, we will associate a Weyl group with an abstract root system, and develop some of its properties.

In this chapter, we will associate a Weyl group with an abstract root system, and develop some of its properties.

Let ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq1.gif) be a Euclidean space and ![
$$\\varPhi \\subset \\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq2.gif) a reduced root system. (At the end of the chapter we will remove the assumption that Φ is reduced, but many of the results of this chapter are false without it.)

Since ![
$$\\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq3.gif) is a finite set of nonzero vectors, we may choose ![
$$\\rho _{0} \\in \\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq4.gif) such that ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\rho _{0}\\right \\rangle \\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq5.gif) for all α ∈Φ. Let ![
$${\\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq6.gif) be the set of roots α such that ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\rho _{0}\\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq7.gif). This consists of exactly half the roots since evidently a root α ∈ Φ + if and only if ![
$$-\\alpha {\\notin \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq8.gif). Elements of Φ + are called positive roots. Elements of set ![
$${\\varPhi }^{-} =\\varPhi {-\\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq9.gif) are called negative roots.

If ![
$$\\alpha, \\beta {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq10.gif) and ![
$$\\alpha + \\beta \\in \\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq11.gif), then evidently ![
$$\\alpha + \\beta {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq12.gif). Let Σ be the set of elements in Φ + that cannot be expressed as a sum of other elements of ![
$${\\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq13.gif). If ![
$$\\alpha \\in \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq14.gif), then we call α a simple positive root, or sometimes just a simple root and we call s α defined by (18.​1) a simple reflection.

Proposition 20.1.

(i)

The elements of Σ are linearly independent.

(ii)

If α ∈ Σ and β ∈ Φ + , then either β = α or ![
$$s_{\\alpha }\(\\beta \) {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq15.gif) .

(iii)

If α and β are distinct elements of Σ, then ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle \\leqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq16.gif) .

(iv)

Each element α ∈ Φ can be expressed uniquely as a linear combination

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha =\\sum _{\\beta \\in \\varSigma }n_{\\beta } \\cdot \\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equa.gif)

in which each ![
$$n_{\\beta } \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq17.gif) and either all ![
$$n_{\\beta } \\geqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq18.gif) (if β ∈Φ + ) or all ![
$$n_{\\beta } \\leqslant 0 \(if \\beta {\\in \\varPhi }^{-}\).$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq19.gif)

Proof.

Let Σ′ be a subset of Φ + that is minimal with respect to the property that every element of Φ + is a linear combination with nonnegative coefficients of elements of Σ′. (Subsets with this property clearly exist—e.g., Σ′ itself.) We will eventually show that ![
$$\\varSigma ^{\\prime} =\\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq20.gif).

First, we show that if ![
$$\\alpha \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq21.gif) and β ∈Φ +, then either β = α or ![
$$s_{\\alpha }\(\\beta \) {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq22.gif). Otherwise ![
$$-s_{\\alpha }\(\\beta \) {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq23.gif), and

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\alpha }^{\\vee }\(\\beta \)\\,\\alpha = \\beta +\\big \(-s_{ \\alpha }\(\\beta \)\\big\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equb.gif)

is a sum of two positive roots β and − s β (α). Therefore, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\beta =\\sum _{\\gamma \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}}n^{\\prime}_{\\gamma } \\cdot \\gamma,\\qquad - s_{\\alpha }\(\\beta \) =\\sum _{\\gamma \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}}n^{\\prime\\prime}_{\\gamma } \\cdot \\gamma,}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equc.gif)

where ![
$$n^{\\prime}_{\\gamma },n^{\\prime\\prime}_{\\gamma } \\geqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq24.gif) and so

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\alpha }^{\\vee }\(\\beta \)\\,\\alpha =\\sum _{ \\gamma \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}}n_{\\gamma } \\cdot \\gamma, n_{\\gamma } \\geqslant 0,}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equd.gif)

where ![
$$n_{\\gamma } = n^{\\prime}_{\\gamma } + n^{\\prime\\prime}_{\\gamma }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq25.gif). There exists some γ ∈Σ′ such that n′γ≠0, because β is not α, and (the root system being reduced), it follows that β is not a multiple of α. Therefore,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \({\\alpha }^{\\vee }\(\\beta \) - n_{ \\alpha }\\right \)\\alpha =\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{l} \\gamma \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}\\\\ \\gamma \\neq \\alpha \\end{array} $}}n_{\\gamma }\\cdot \\gamma,}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Eque.gif)

and the right-hand side is not zero. Taking the inner product with ρ0 shows that the coefficient on the left-hand side is strictly positive; dividing by this positive constant, we see that α may be expressed as a linear combination of the elements γ ∈Σ′ distinct from α, and so α may be omitted from Σ′, contradicting its assumed minimality. This contradiction shows that ![
$$s_{\\alpha }\(\\beta \) {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq26123.gif).

Next we show that if α and β are distinct elements of Σ′, then ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle \\leqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq27.gif). We have already shown that ![
$$s_{\\alpha }\(\\beta \) {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq28.gif). If ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq29.gif), then by (18.​2) we have ![
$${\\alpha }^{\\vee }\(\\beta \) > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq30.gif). Write

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\beta = s_{\\alpha }\(\\beta \) + {\\alpha }^{\\vee }\(\\beta \)\\,\\alpha. }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(20.1)

We have already shown that ![
$$s_{\\alpha }\(\\beta \) {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq31.gif). Writing ![
$$s_{\\alpha }\(\\beta \)$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq32.gif) as a linear combination with nonnegative coefficients of the elements of Σ′, and noting that the coefficient of α on the right-hand side of (20.1) is strictly positive, we may write

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\beta =\\sum _{\\gamma \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}}n_{\\gamma } \\cdot \\gamma,}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equf.gif)

where n α > 0. We rewrite this

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(1-n_{\\beta }\)\\cdot \\beta =\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{l} \\gamma \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime} \\\\ \\gamma \\neq \\beta \\end{array} $}}n_{\\gamma }\\cdot \\gamma.}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equg.gif)

At least one coefficient n α > 0 on the right, so taking the inner product with ρ0 we see that 1 − n β > 0. Thus, β is a linear combination with nonnegative coefficients of other elements of Σ′ and hence may be omitted, contradicting the minimality of Σ′.

Now let us show that the elements of Σ′ are ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq33.gif)-linearly independent. In a relation of algebraic dependence, we move all the negative coefficients to the other side of the identity and obtain a relation of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sum _{\\alpha \\in \\varSigma _{1}}c_{\\alpha } \\cdot \\alpha =\\sum _{\\beta \\in \\varSigma _{2}}d_{\\beta } \\cdot \\beta, }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(20.2)

where Σ 1 and Σ 2 are disjoint subsets of Σ′ and the coefficients ![
$$c_{\\alpha }, d_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq34.gif) are all positive. Call this vector v. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle v,v\\right \\rangle =\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{l} \\alpha \\in \\varSigma _{1} \\\\ \\beta \\in \\varSigma _{2} \\end{array} $}}c_{\\alpha }d_{\\beta }\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle \\leqslant 0}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equh.gif)

since we have already shown that the inner products ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle \\leqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq35.gif). Therefore, v = 0. Now taking the inner product of the left-hand side in (20.2) with ρ0 gives

![
$$\\displaystyle{0 =\\sum _{\\alpha \\in \\varSigma _{1}}c_{\\alpha }\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\rho _{0}\\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Since ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\rho _{0}\\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq36.gif) and ![
$$c_{\\alpha } > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq37.gif), this is a contradiction. This proves the linear independence of the elements of Σ′.

Next let us show that every element of Φ + may be expressed as a linear combination of elements of Σ′ with integer coefficients. We define a function h from Φ + to the positive real numbers as follows. If α ∈Φ + we may write

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha =\\sum _{\\beta \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}}n_{\\beta } \\cdot \\beta, n_{\\beta } \\geqslant 0.}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equj.gif)

The coefficients n β are uniquely determined since the elements of Σ′ are linearly independent. We define

![
$$\\displaystyle{ h\(\\alpha \) =\\sum n_{\\beta }. }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(20.3)

Evidently h(α) > 0. We want to show that the coefficients n β are integers. Assume a counterexample with h(α) minimal. Evidently, ![
$$\\alpha \\notin \\varSigma ^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq38.gif) since if α ∈Σ′, then n α = 1 while all other n β = 0, so such an α has all ![
$$n_{\\beta } \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq39.gif). Since

![
$$\\displaystyle{ 0 < \\left \\langle \\alpha,\\alpha \\right \\rangle =\\sum _{\\beta \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}}n_{\\beta }\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle \\,, }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(20.4)

it is impossible that ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle \\leqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq40.gif) for all ![
$$\\beta \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq41.gif). Thus, there exists ![
$$\\gamma \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq42.gif) such that ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\gamma \\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq43.gif). Then by what we have already proved, ![
$$\\alpha ^{\\prime} = s_{\\gamma }\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq44.gif), and by (18.​1) we see that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha ^{\\prime} =\\sum _{\\beta \\in \\varSigma ^{\\prime}}n_{\\beta }^{\\prime} \\cdot \\beta,}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equk.gif)

where

![
$$\\displaystyle{n_{\\beta }^{\\prime} = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cc} n_{\\beta } & \\mbox{ if $\\beta \\neq \\gamma $,} \\\\ n_{\\gamma } - {\\gamma }^{\\vee }\(\\alpha \)&\\mbox{ if $\\beta = \\gamma $.} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equl.gif)

Since ![
$$\\left \\langle \\gamma,\\alpha \\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq45.gif), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{h\(\\alpha ^{\\prime}\) < h\(\\alpha \)\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equm.gif)

so by induction we have ![
$$n_{\\beta }^{\\prime} \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq46.gif). Since Φ is a root system, ![
$${\\gamma }^{\\vee }\(\\alpha \) \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq47.gif), so ![
$$n_{\\beta } \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq48.gif) for all β ∈Σ′. This is a contradiction.

Finally, let us show that Σ =Σ′.

If α ∈Σ, then by definition of Σ, α cannot be expressed as a linear combination with integer coefficients of other elements of Φ +. Hence α cannot be omitted from Σ′. Thus, ![
$$\\varSigma \\subset \\varSigma ^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq49.gif).

On the other hand, if α ∈Σ′, then we claim that α ∈Σ. Otherwise, we may write α = β \+ γ with ![
$$\\beta, \\gamma {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq50.gif), and β and γ may both be written as linear combinations of elements of Σ′ with positive integer coefficients, and thus ![
$$h\(\\beta \), h\(\\gamma \) \\geqslant 1$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq51.gif), so ![
$$h\(\\alpha \) = h\(\\beta \) + h\(\\gamma \) > 1$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq52.gif). But evidently h(α) = 1 since α ∈Σ′. This contradiction shows that ![
$$\\varSigma ^{\\prime} \\subset \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq53.gif). □

Let W be the group generated by the simple reflections s α with α ∈Σ. If w ∈ W, let the length l(w) be defined to be the smallest k such that w admits a factorization w = s 1⋯s k into simple reflections, or l(w) = 0 if w = 1. Let l′(w) be the number of α ∈Φ + such that w(α) ∈Φ −. We will eventually show that the functions l and l′ are the same.

Proposition 20.2.

Let s = s α (α ∈Σ) be a simple reflection, and let w ∈ W. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ l^{\\prime}\(sw\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} l^{\\prime}\(w\) + 1&\\mbox{ if ${w}^{-1}\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$,} \\\\ l^{\\prime}\(w\) - 1&\\mbox{ if ${w}^{-1}\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{-}$,}\\\\ \\end{array} \\right. }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(20.5)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{ l^{\\prime}\(ws\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} l^{\\prime}\(w\) + 1&\\mbox{ if $w\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$,} \\\\ l^{\\prime}\(w\) - 1&\\mbox{ if $w\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{-}$,}\\\\ \\end{array} \\right. }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(20.6)

Proof.

Since s(Φ −) is obtained from Φ − by deleting − α and adding α, we see that ![
$${\(sw\){}^{-1}\\varPhi }^{-} = {w}^{-1}\({s\\varPhi }^{-}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq54.gif) is obtained from ![
$${w{}^{-1}\\varPhi }^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq55.gif) by deleting ![
$$-{w}^{-1}\(\\alpha \)$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq56.gif) and adding w −1(α). Since l′(w) is the cardinality of ![
$${\\varPhi }^{+} \\cap {w{}^{-1}\\varPhi }^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq57.gif), we obtain (20.5). To prove (20.6), we note that l′(ws) is the cardinality of ![
$${\\varPhi }^{+} \\cap {\(ws\){}^{-1}\\varPhi }^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq58.gif), which equals the cardinality of ![
$$s\(\\Phi ^ +   \\cap \(ws\)^{ - 1} \\varPhi ^ -  \) = s\\varPhi ^ +   \\cap w^{ - 1} \\varPhi ^ - $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq59.gif), and since sΦ + is obtained from Φ + by deleting the element α and adjoining ![
$$-\\alpha $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq60.gif), (20.6) is evident. □

If w is any orthogonal linear endomorphism of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq61.gif), then evidently ![
$$ws_{\\alpha }{w}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq62.gif) is the reflection in the hyperplane perpendicular to w(α), so

![
$$\\displaystyle{ ws_{\\alpha }{w}^{-1} = s_{ w\(\\alpha \)}\\,. }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(20.7)

Proposition 20.3.

Suppose that ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq63.gif) and ![
$$\\alpha $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq64.gif) are elements of Σ, and let ![
$$s_{i} = s_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq65.gif) . Suppose that

![
$$\\displaystyle{s_{1}s_{2}\\cdots s_{k}\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{-}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equn.gif)

Then there exists a ![
$$1 \\leqslant j \\leqslant k$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq66.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ s_{1}s_{2}\\cdots s_{k} = s_{1}s_{2}\\cdots \\hat{s}_{j}\\cdots s_{k}s_{\\alpha }, }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(20.8)

where the "hat" on the right signifies the omission of the single element s j .

Proof.

Let ![
$$1 \\leqslant j \\leqslant k$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq67.gif) be minimal such that ![
$$s_{j+1}\\cdots s_{k}\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq68.gif). Then ![
$$s_{j}s_{j+1}\\cdots s_{k}\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq69.gif). Since ![
$$\\alpha _{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq70.gif) is the unique element of ![
$${\\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq71.gif) mapped into ![
$${\\varPhi }^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq72.gif) by s j , we have

Proposition 20.4.

Suppose that ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq73.gif) are elements of Σ, and let ![
$$s_{i} = s_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq74.gif) . Suppose that ![
$$l^{\\prime}\(s_{1}s_{2}\\cdots s_{k}\) < k$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq75.gif) . Then there exist ![
$$1 \\leqslant i < j \\leqslant k$$

where the "hats" on the right signify omission of the elements s i and s j .

Proof.

Evidently there is a first j such that ![

Proposition 20.5.

If w ∈ W, then l(w) = l′(w).

Proof.

The inequality

![
$$\\displaystyle{l^{\\prime}\(w\) \\leqslant l\(w\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equr.gif)

follows from Proposition 20.2 because we may write w = sw 1, where s is a simple reflection and l(w 1) = l(w) − 1, and by induction on l(w 1) we may assume that l′(w 1) ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq1234.gif) l(w 1), so ![

](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq81.gif).

![

](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equs.gif)

Indeed, let ![
$$w = s_{1}\\cdots s_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq82.gif) be a counterexample with l(w) = k, where each ![

](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq83.gif) with α i ∈Σ. Thus, ![

This expression for w as a product of k − 2 simple reflections contradicts our assumption that l(w) = k. □

Proposition 20.6.

If ![
$$w{\(\\varPhi }^{+}\) {=\\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq85.gif) , then w = 1.

Proof.

If ![
$$w{\(\\varPhi }^{+}\) {=\\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq86.gif), then l′(w) = 0, so l(w) = 0, that is, w = 1. □

Proposition 20.7.

If ![
$$\\alpha \\in \\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq87.gif) , there exists an element w ∈ W such that w(α) ∈ Σ.

Proof.

First, assume that α ∈Φ +. We will argue by induction on h(α), which is defined by (20.3). In view of Proposition 20.1(iv), we know that h(α) is a positive integer, and if ![
$$\\alpha \\notin \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq88.gif) (which we may as well assume), then h(α) > 1. As in the proof of Proposition 20.1, (20.4) implies that ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq89.gif) for some ![
$$\\beta \\in \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq90.gif), and then with ![
$$\\alpha ^{\\prime} = s_{\\beta }\(\\alpha \)$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq91.gif) we have h(α′) < h(α). On the other hand, α′ ∈Φ + since α≠β by Proposition 20.1(ii). By our inductive hypothesis, w′(α′) ∈Σ for some w′ ∈ W. Then w(α) = w′(α′) with w = w′s β ∈ W. This shows that if α ∈Φ +, then there exists w ∈ W such that w(α) ∈Σ.

If, on the other hand, α ∈Φ −, then − α ∈Φ + so we may find w 1 ∈ W such that w 1(−α) ∈Σ. Letting ![
$$w_{1}\(-\\alpha \) = \\beta $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq92.gif) we have w(α) = β with w = s β w 1.

In both cases, w (α) ∈Σ for some w ∈ W. □

Proposition 20.8.

The group W contains s α for each α ∈ Φ.

Proof.

Indeed, w(α) ∈Σ for some w ∈ W, so s w(α) ∈ W and s α is conjugate in W to s w(α) by (20.7). Therefore, s α ∈ W. □

Proposition 20.9.

The group W is finite.

Proof.

By Proposition 20.6, w ∈ W is determined by ![
$$w{\(\\varPhi }^{+}\) \\subset \\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq93.gif). Since Φ is finite, W is finite. □

Proposition 20.10.

Suppose that w ∈ W such that l(w) = k. Write ![

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\{\\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\vert w\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{-}\\} =\\{ \\alpha _{ k},s_{k}\(\\alpha _{k-1}\),s_{k}s_{k-1}\(\\alpha _{k-2}\),\\ldots,s_{k}s_{k-1}\\cdots s_{2}\(\\alpha _{1}\)\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equu.gif)

](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq97.gif) is k, so the result will be established if we show that the described elements are distinct and in the set. Let ![

$$w_{1} = s_{2}\\cdots s_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq99.gif), so that l(w 1) = l(w) − 1. By induction, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\{\\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\vert w_{ 1}\(\\alpha\)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{-}\\} =\\{ \\alpha _{ k},s_{k}\(\\alpha _{k-1}\),s_{k}s_{k-1}\(\\alpha _{k-2}\),\\ldots,s_{k}s_{k-1}\\cdots s_{3}\(\\alpha _{2}\)\\},}$$

and the elements on the right are distinct. We claim that

(20.10)

Otherwise, let α ∈Φ + such that ![

A connected component of the complement of the union of the hyperplanes

![

is called an open Weyl chamber. The closure of an open Weyl chamber is called a Weyl chamber. For example, ![

is an open Weyl chamber.

If ![
$$y \\in \\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq114.gif), let W(y) be the stabilizer ![
$$\\{w \\in W\\vert w\(y\) = y\\}$$

Proposition 20.11.

Suppose that w ∈ W such that l(w) = k. Write w = s 1 ⋯s k , where ![
$$s_{i} = s_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq116.gif), ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{k} \\in \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq117.gif) . Assume that ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq118.gif) such that ![
$$wx \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq119.gif) also.

(i)

We have ![
$$\\left \\langle x,\\alpha _{i}\\right \\rangle = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq120.gif) for ![
$$1 \\leqslant i \\leqslant k.$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq121.gif)

(ii)

Each s i ∈ W(x).

(iii)

We have w(x) = x.

Proof.

If ![
$$\\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq122.gif) and wα ∈Φ −, then we have ![
$$\\left \\langle x,\\alpha \\right \\rangle = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq123.gif). Indeed, ![
$$\\left \\langle x,\\alpha \\right \\rangle \\geqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq124.gif) since α ∈Φ + and ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq125.gif), and ![
$$\\left \\langle x,\\alpha \\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle wx,w\\alpha \\right \\rangle \\leqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq126.gif) since ![
$$wx \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq127.gif) and wα ∈Φ −.

The elements of ![
$$\\{\\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\vert w\\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{-}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq128.gif) are listed in Proposition 20.10. Since α k is in this set, we have ![
$$s_{k}\(x\) = x - \(2\\left \\langle x,\\alpha _{k}\\right \\rangle /\\left \\langle \\alpha _{k},\\alpha _{k}\\right \\rangle \)\\alpha _{k} = x$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq129.gif). Thus, s k ∈ W(x). Now since ![
$$s_{k}\(\\alpha _{k-1}\) \\in \\{ \\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\vert w\\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{-}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq130.gif), we have ![
$$0 = \\left \\langle x,s_{k}\(\\alpha _{k-1}\)\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle s_{k}\(x\),\\alpha _{k-1}\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle x,\\alpha _{k-1}\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq131.gif), which implies ![
$$s_{k-1}\(x\) = x - 2\\left \\langle x,\\alpha _{k-1}\\right \\rangle /\\left \\langle \\alpha _{k-1},\\alpha _{k-1}\\right \\rangle = x$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq132.gif). Proceeding in this way, we prove (i) and (ii) simultaneously. Of course, (ii) implies (iii). □

Theorem 20.1.

The positive Weyl chamber ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq133.gif) is a fundamental domain for the action of ![
$$W$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq134.gif) on ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq135.gif) . More precisely, let ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq136.gif) .

(i)

There exists w ∈ W such that ![
$$w\(x\) \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq137.gif) .

(ii)

If w,w′ ∈ W and ![
$$w\(x\) \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+},w^{\\prime}\(x\) \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq138.gif) , then w = w′.

(iii)

If w,w′ ∈ W and ![
$$w\(x\) \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+},w^{\\prime}\(x\) \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq139.gif) , then w(x) = w′(x).

Proof.

Let w ∈ W be chosen so that the cardinality of

![
$$\\displaystyle{S =\\{ \\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\,\\big\\vert \\,\\left \\langle w\(x\),\\alpha \\right \\rangle < 0\\}}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equy.gif)

is as small as possible. We claim that S is empty. If not, then there exists an element of ![
$$\\beta \\in \\varSigma \\cap S$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq140.gif). We have ![
$$\\left \\langle w\(x\),-\\beta \\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq141.gif), and since s β preserves Φ + except for β, which it maps to − β, the set

![
$$\\displaystyle{S^{\\prime} =\\{ \\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\,\\big\\vert \\,\\left \\langle w\(x\),s_{ \\beta }\(\\alpha \)\\right \\rangle < 0\\}}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equz.gif)

is smaller than S by one. Since ![
$$S^{\\prime} =\\{ \\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\vert \\left \\langle s_{\\beta }w\(x\),\\alpha \\right \\rangle < 0\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq142.gif) this contradicts the minimality of |S|. Clearly, ![
$$w\(x\) \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq143.gif). This proves (i).

We prove (ii). We may assume that w′ = 1, so ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq144.gif). Since ![
$$\\left \\langle x,\\alpha \\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq145.gif) for all ![
$$\\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq146.gif), we have ![
$${\\varPhi }^{+} =\\{ \\alpha \\in \\varPhi \\vert \\left \\langle x,\\alpha \\right \\rangle > 0\\} =\\{ \\alpha \\in \\varPhi \\vert \\left \\langle x,\\alpha \\right \\rangle \\geqslant 0\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq147.gif). Since ![
$$w^{\\prime}\(x\) \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq148.gif), if α ∈Φ +, we have ![
$$\\left \\langle {w}^{-1}\(\\alpha \),x\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle \\alpha,w\(x\)\\right \\rangle \\geqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq149.gif) so ![
$${w}^{-1}\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq150.gif). By Proposition 20.6, this implies that w −1 = 1, whence (ii).

Part (iii) follows from Proposition 20.11(iii). □

Proposition 20.12.

The function ![
$$w\\longmapsto {\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)} \\in \\{\\pm 1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq151.gif) is a character of W. If α ∈ Φ, then ![
$${\(-1\)}^{l\(s_{\\alpha }\)} = -1$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq152.gif) .

Proof.

If l(w) = k and l(w′) = k′, write w = s 1⋯s k and ![
$$w^{\\prime} = s_{1}^{\\prime}\\cdots s_{k^{\\prime}}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq153.gif) as products of simple reflections. It follows from Proposition 20.4 that we may obtain a decomposition of ww′ into a product of simple reflections of minimal length from ![
$$ww^{\\prime} = s_{1}\\cdots s_{k}s_{1}^{\\prime}\\cdots s_{k^{\\prime}}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq154.gif) by discarding elements in pairs until the result is reduced. Therefore, ![
$$l\(ww^{\\prime}\) \\equiv l\(w\) + l\(w^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq155.gif) modulo 2, so ![
$$w\\longmapsto {\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq156.gif) is a character. (One may argue alternatively by showing that (−1) l(w) is the determinant of w in its action on ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq157.gif).)

If α ∈Φ, then by Proposition 20.7 there exists w ∈ W such that w(α) ∈Σ. By (20.7), we have ![
$$ws_{\\alpha }{w}^{-1} = s_{w\(\\alpha \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq158.gif), and ![
$$l\\big\(s_{w\(\\alpha \)}\\big\) = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq159.gif). It follows that ![
$${\(-1\)}^{s_{\\alpha }} = -1$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq160.gif). □

Proposition 20.13.

Let ![
$$\\tilde{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq161.gif) be a linear transformation of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq162.gif) that maps Φ to itself. Then there exists w ∈ W such that ![
$$\\tilde{w}\(\\mathcal{C}_{+}\) = w\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq163.gif) . The transformation ![
$${w}^{-1}\\tilde{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq164.gif) of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq165.gif) permutes the elements of Φ + and of Σ.

It is possible that ![
$${w}^{-1}\\tilde{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq166.gif) is not the identity. (See Exercise 25.2.)

Proof.

It is sufficient to show that ![
$${w}^{-1}\\tilde{w}\(\\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }\) = \\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq167.gif). Let ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq168.gif). Since the open Weyl chambers are defined to be the connected components of the complement of the set of hyperplanes perpendicular to the roots, and since ![
$$\\tilde{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq169.gif) permutes the roots, ![
$$\\tilde{w}\(\\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq170.gif) is an open Weyl chamber. By Theorem 20.1 there is an element w ∈ W such that ![
$${w}^{-1}\\tilde{w}\(x\) \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq171.gif), and ![
$${w}^{-1}\\tilde{w}\(x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq172.gif) must be in the interior ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq173.gif) since x lies in an open Weyl chamber, and these are permuted by W as well as by ![
$$\\tilde{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq174.gif). Now ![
$${w}^{-1}\\tilde{w}\(\\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq175.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq176.gif) are open Weyl chambers intersecting nontrivially in x, so they are equal.

The positive roots are characterized by the condition that α ∈Φ + if and only if ![
$$\\left \\langle \\alpha,x\\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq177.gif) for ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq178.gif). It follows that ![
$${w}^{-1}\\tilde{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq179.gif) permutes the elements of Φ +. Since the ![
$$\\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq180.gif) are determined by Φ +, these too are permuted by ![
$${w}^{-1}\\tilde{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq181.gif). □

Proposition 20.14.

If ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq182.gif) is any Weyl chamber then there is a unique element w of W such that ![
$$\\mathcal{C} = w\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq183.gif) . In particular, let w 0 be the unique element such that ![
$$-\\mathcal{C}_{+} = w_{0}\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq184.gif) . Then ![
$$w{_{0}\\varPhi }^{+} {=\\varPhi }^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq185.gif) and w 0 is the longest element of W.

The element w 0 is often called the long element of the Weyl group.

Proof.

It is clear that W permutes the Weyl chambers transitively. The uniqueness of w of W such that ![
$$\\mathcal{C} = w\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq186.gif) follows from Theorem 20.1.

Regarding w 0, since

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{C}_{+} =\\{ x\\vert \\mbox{ $\\{\\alpha,x\\}$ for $\\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$}\\},}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equaa.gif)

the element w 0 such that ![
$$w\\mathcal{C}_{+} = -\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq187.gif) sends positive roots to negative roots. Thus, its length equals the number of positive roots, and is maximal. □

An important particular element of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq188.gif) is the Weyl vector

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\rho = \\frac{1} {2}\\sum _{\\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\alpha.}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equab.gif)

Proposition 20.15.

If α is a simple root, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ s_{\\alpha }\(\\rho \) = \\rho - \\alpha,\\quad \\alpha \\in \\varSigma. }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(20.11)

Proof.

This follows since s α changes the sign of α and permutes the remaining positive roots. □

Let there be given a lattice Λ contained in ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq189.gif) that contains a basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq190.gif). Then ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq191.gif) may be identified with ![
$$\\mathbb{R} \\otimes _{\\mathbb{Z}}\\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq192.gif). We will assume that ![
$${\\alpha }^{\\vee }\(\\varLambda \) \\subseteq \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq193.gif), and that every root ![
$$\\alpha $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq194.gif) is in Λ. For example if Φ is the root system of a compact Lie group G with maximal torus T as in Chap. , then by Proposition 18.10 we may take Λ = X ∗(T). Elements of Λ are to be called weights, and our assumptions are satisfies by Proposition 18.10. A weight λ is called dominant if ![
$$\\lambda \\in {\\mathcal{C}}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq195.gif). By Theorem 20.1, every weight is equivalent by the action of W to a unique dominant weight.

Proposition 20.16.

If ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq196.gif) , then ![
$$\\lambda - w\(\\lambda \) \\in \\varLambda _{\\mathrm{root}}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq197.gif) .

Proof.

This is true if w is a simple reflection by (18.​1). The general case follows, since if ![
$$w = s_{1}\\cdots s_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq198.gif), where the s i are simple reflections, we may write ![
$$\\lambda - w\(\\lambda \) = \(\\lambda - s_{r}\(\\lambda \)\) + \(s_{r}\(\\lambda \) - s_{r-1}\(s_{r}\(\\lambda \)\) + \\cdots \\;$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq199.gif). □

Now let us assume that Φ spans ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq200.gif). This will be true if G is semisimple. Let ![
$$\\tilde{\\varLambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq201.gif) to be the set of vectors v such that ![
$${\\alpha }^{\\vee }\(v\) \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq202.gif) for ![
$${\\alpha }^{\\vee }{\\in \\varPhi }^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq203.gif). In the semisimple case the ![
$${\\alpha }^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq204.gif) span ![
$${\\mathcal{V}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq205.gif), ![
$$\\tilde{\\varLambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq206.gif) is a lattice. We have ![
$$\\tilde{\\varLambda }\\supseteq \\varLambda \\supseteq \\varLambda _{\\mathrm{root}}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq207.gif), and all three lattices span ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq208.gif), so ![
$$\[\\tilde{\\varLambda }:\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{root}}\] < \\infty $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq209.gif). The ![
$$\\alpha _{i}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq210.gif) are linearly independent, and in the semisimple case they are a basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq211.gif), so let ![
$$\\varpi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq212.gif) be the dual basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq213.gif). In other words, these vectors are defined by ![
$$\\alpha _{i}^{\\vee }\(\\varpi _{j}\) = \\delta _{ij}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq214.gif) (Kronecker delta). The ![
$$\\varpi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq215.gif) are called the fundamental dominant weights. Strictly speaking, because in our usage only elements of ![
$$\\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq216.gif) will be called weights, the ![
$$\\varpi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq217.gif) might not be weights by our conventions. However, we will call them the fundamental weights because this terminology is standard. Clearly the ![
$$\\varpi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq218.gif) span ![
$$\\tilde{\\varLambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq219.gif) as a ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq220.gif)-module.

Proposition 20.17.

In the semisimple case ![
$$\\rho = \\varpi _{1} + \\cdots + \\varpi _{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq221.gif) . In particular, ![
$$\\rho $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq222.gif) is a dominant weight. It lies in ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{+}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq223.gif) .

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\alpha = \\alpha _{i} \\in \\varSigma.$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq224.gif) By (20.11), we have ![
$${\\alpha }^{\\vee }\(\\rho \)\\,\\alpha = \\rho - s_{\\alpha }\(\\rho \) = \\alpha $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq225.gif). Thus, ![
$$\\alpha _{i}^{\\vee }\(\\rho \) = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq226.gif) for each ![
$$\\alpha _{i} \\in \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq227.gif). It follows that ρ is the sum of the fundamental dominant weights. Since ![
$$\\left \\langle \\rho,\\alpha _{i}\\right \\rangle > 0$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq228.gif), ρ lies in the interior of ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq229.gif). □

Up until now we have assumed that ![
$$\\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq230.gif) is a reduced root system, and much of the foregoing is false without this assumption. In Chap. , and indeed most of the book, the root systems are reduced, so this is enough for now. In Chap. , however, we will encounter relative root systems, which may not be reduced, so let us say a few words about them. If ![
$$\\varPhi \\subset \\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq231.gif) is not reduced, then we may still choose v 0 and partition Φ into positive and negative roots. We call a positive root simple if it cannot be expressed as a linear combination (with nonnegative coefficients) of other positive roots.

Proposition 20.18.

Let ![
$$\(\\varPhi,\\mathcal{V}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq232.gif) be a root system that is not necessarily reduced. If α and ![
$$\\lambda \\alpha \\in \\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq233.gif) with λ > 0, then λ = 1,2 or ![
$$\\frac{1} {2}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq234.gif) . Partition Φ into positive and negative roots, and let Σ be the set of simple roots. The elements of Σ are linearly independent. Any positive root may be expressed as a linear combination of elements of Σ with nonnegative integer coefficients.

Proof.

If α and β are proportional roots, say ![
$$\\beta = \\lambda \\alpha $$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq235.gif), then ![
$$2\\left \\langle \\beta,\\alpha \\right \\rangle /\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\alpha \\right \\rangle \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq236.gif) implies that 2λ is an integer and, by symmetry, so is 2λ−1. The first assertion is therefore clear. Let Ψ be the set of all roots that are not the double of another root. Then it is clear that Ψ is another root system with the same Weyl group as Φ. Let ![
$${\\varPsi }^{+} {=\\varPhi }^{+}\\cap \\varPsi$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_IEq237.gif). With our definitions, the set Σ of simple positive roots of Ψ + is precisely the set of simple positive roots of Φ. They are linearly independent by Proposition 20.1. If α ∈Φ +, we need to know that α can be expressed as a linear combination, with integer coefficients, of the elements of Σ. If α ∈Ψ, this follows from Proposition 20.1, applied to Ψ. Otherwise, α∕2 ∈Ψ, so α∕2 is a linear combination of the elements of Σ with integer coefficients, and therefore so is α. □

Exercises

Exercise 20.1.

Suppose that S is any subset of Φ such that if α ∈Φ, then either α ∈ S or − α ∈ S. Assume further more that if α,β ∈ S and if α + β ∈Φ then α + β ∈ S. Show that there exists w ∈ W such that w(S) ⊇Φ +. If either for every α ∈Φ either α ∈ S or − α ∈ W but never both, then w is unique.

Exercise 20.2.

Generalize (20.11) by proving, for w ∈ W:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ w\(\\rho \) = \\rho -\\sum _{ \\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{c} \\alpha\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{+} \\\\ {w}^{-1}\(\\alpha \)\\,{\\in \\varPhi }^{-} \\end{array} $}}\\alpha. }$$
](A79351_2_En_20_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

(20.12)
