# 21. Highest Weight Vectors

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

If G is a compact connected Lie group, we will show in Chap.​ 22 that its irreducible representations are parametrized uniquely by their highest weight vectors. In this chapter, we will explain what this means and give some illustrative examples. This chapter is to some extent a continuation of the example Chap.​ 19. As in that chapter, we will make many assertions that will only be proved in later chapters, mostly Chap.​ 22.

If G is a compact connected Lie group, we will show in Chap.​ 22 that its irreducible representations are parametrized uniquely by their highest weight vectors. In this chapter, we will explain what this means and give some illustrative examples. This chapter is to some extent a continuation of the example Chap.​ 19. As in that chapter, we will make many assertions that will only be proved in later chapters, mostly Chap.​ 22.

We return to the figures in Chap.​ 19 (which the reader should review). Let T be a maximal torus in G, with Λ = X ∗(T) embedded as a lattice in the Euclidean space ![
$$\\mathcal{V} = \\mathbb{R} \\otimes {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq1.gif). Let Λ root ⊆Λ be the lattice spanned by the roots.

If G is semisimple, then Λ root spans ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq2.gif) and has finite codimension in Λ. In this case, the coroots also span ![
$${\\mathcal{V}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq3.gif), so we may ask for the dual basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq4.gif). These are elements called ![
$$\\varpi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq5.gif) such that ![
$$\\alpha _{i}^{\\vee }\(\\varpi _{j}\) = \\delta _{ij}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq6.gif). These are the fundamental dominant weights. They are not necessarily in Λ, however: they are in Λ if G is simply connected as well as semisimple. We only will call elements of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq7.gif) weights if they are in Λ, so if G is not connected, the term "fundamental dominant weight" is a misnomer. But if G is semisimple and simply connected, the ![
$$\\varpi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq8.gif) are uniquely defined and span the weight lattice Λ. The fundamental dominant weights do not play a major role in the general theory but they give a convenient parametrization of Λ when G is semisimple, since then every element of Λ is of the form ![
$$\\sum n_{i}\\varpi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq9.gif) with n i nonnegative integers. (This is true even if G is not simply connected.) Since our examples will be semisimple, we will make use of the fundamental dominant weights.

Fig. 21.1

The weight and root lattices for SU(2)

Our first example is G = SU(3). The lattices Λ and its sublattice Λ root (of index 3) are marked in Fig. 21.1. The positive Weyl chamber ![
$${\\mathcal{C}}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq10.gif) is the shaded cone. It is a fundamental group for the Weyl group W, acting by simple reflections, which are the reflections in the two walls of ![
$${\\mathcal{C}}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq11.gif). The weight lattice Λ is marked with light dots and the root sublattice with darker ones. In this case G is semisimple and simply connected, so the fundamental dominant weights ![
$$\\varpi _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq12.gif) and ![
$$\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq13.gif) are defined and span the weight lattice. The root lattice is of codimension 3 in Λ.

Let (π, V ) be an irreducible complex representation of G. Then the restriction of π to T is a representation of T that will not be irreducible if π is not one-dimensional (since the irreducible representations of T are one-dimensional). It can be decomposed into a direct sum of one-dimensional irreducible subspaces of T corresponding to the characters of T. Some characters may occur with multiplicity greater than one. If μ ∈ X ∗(T), let m(μ) be the multiplicity of μ in the decomposition of π over T. Thus, m(μ) is the dimension of V (μ) ={ v ∈ V |π(t)v = λ(t)v for t ∈ T}. If m(λ) ≠ 0, we say that λ is a weight of the representation π.

For example, let G = SU(3), and let T be the diagonal torus. Let ![
$$\\varpi _{1},\\varpi _{2}: T\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq14.gif) be the fundamental dominant weights, labeled as in Chap.​ 19. They are the characters ![
$$\\varpi _{1}\(t\) = t_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq15.gif) and ![
$$\\varpi _{2}\(t\) = t_{1}t_{2} = t_{3}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq16.gif) where ![
$$t_{1},t_{2},t_{3}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq17.gif) are the entries in the diagonal matrix t.

Fig. 21.2

Left: The standard representation; Right: its dual

The standard representation of SU(3) is just the usual embedding ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(3\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(3, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq18.gif). The three one-dimensional subspaces spanned by the standard basis vectors of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{3}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq19.gif) afford the characters ![
$$\\varpi _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq20.gif), ![
$$-\\varpi _{1} + \\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq21.gif), and ![
$$-\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq22.gif). These are the weights of the standard representation. Each occurs with multiplicity one. On the other hand, the contragredient of the standard representation is its composition with the transpose-inverse automorphism of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(3, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq23.gif). The standard basis vectors in this dual representation afford the characters ![
$$-\\varpi _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq24.gif), ![
$$\\varpi _{1} - \\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq25.gif), and ![
$$\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq26123.gif).

In Fig. 21.2 (left), we have labeled the three weights in the standard representation with their multiplicities. (For this example each multiplicity is one.) In Fig. 21.2 (right), we have labeled the three weights of the dual of the standard representation. Such a diagram, illustrating the weights of an irreducible representation, is called a weight diagram.

In each irreducible representation π, there is always a weight λ of π in the positive Weyl chamber such that if μ is another weight of π then λ ≽ μ in the partial order. This weight is called the highest weight of the representation. We always have m(λ) = 1, so V (λ) is one-dimensional, and we call an element of V (λ) a highest weight vector. We have circled the highest weight vectors of the standard representation and its dual in Fig. 21.2.

Fig. 21.3

The irreducible representation ![
$$\\pi _{3\\varpi _{1}+6\\varpi _{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) of SU(2). The shaded region is the positive Weyl chamber, and ![
$$\\lambda = 3\\varpi _{1} + 6\\omega _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) is circled

The highest weight can be any element of ![
$$\\varLambda \\cap {\\mathcal{C}}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq29123.gif). In fact, there is a bijection between ![
$$\\varLambda \\cap {\\mathcal{C}}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) and the isomorphism classes of irreducible representations of G. Since there is a unique irreducible representation with the given highest weight λ, we will denote it by πλ. For example, if ![
$$\\lambda = 3\\varpi _{1} + 6\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq31123.gif), the weight diagram of πλ is shown in Fig. 21.3. Note that ![
$$\\lambda = 3\\varpi _{1} + 6\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) is marked with a circle.

From this we can see several features of the general situation. The set of weights of πλ can be characterized as follows. First, if μ is a weight of πλ then λ ≽ μ in the partial order. This puts μ in the translate by λ of the cone {μ ≼ 0}. This is the shaded region in Fig. 21.4. Moreover since the set of weights is invariant under the Weyl group W, we can actually say that λ ≽ w(μ) for all w ∈ W. In Fig. 21.3, this puts ![
$$\\mu $$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) in the hexagonal region that is the convex hull of the W-orbit Wλ ={ w(λ)|w ∈ W}. This region is marked with dashed lines.

Fig. 21.4

With λ the highest weight vector (circled) the shaded region is {μ|μ ≼ λ}

It will be noted that not every element of Λ inside the hexagon is a weight of πλ. Indeed, if μ is a weight of Λ then λ − μ ∈Λ root. In the particular example of Fig. 21.3, λ is itself in Λ root, so the weights of πλ are elements of the root lattice. What is true in general is that the weights of πλ are the μ inside the convex hull of Wλ such that λ − μ ∈Λ root.

Next let G = Sp(4). The root system is of type C 2. This group is also simply connected, so again the fundamental dominant weights ![
$$\\varpi _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) and ![
$$\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq35.gif) are in the weight lattice. The weight lattice and root lattice are illustrated in Fig. 21.5.

Fig. 21.5

The root and weight lattices of the C 2 root system

As in Fig. 21.1, the weight lattice Λ is marked with light dots and the root sublattice with darker ones. We have also marked the positive Weyl chamber, which is a fundamental group for the Weyl group W, acting by simple reflections.

The group Sp(4) admits a homomorphism Sp(4)→ SO(5), so it has both a four-dimensional and a five-dimensional irreducible representation. These are ![
$$\\pi _{\\varpi _{1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq36.gif) and ![
$$\\pi _{\\varpi _{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq37.gif), respectively. Their root diagrams may be found in Fig. 21.6.

Fig. 21.6

The fundamental representations of Sp(4)

The weight diagram of the irreducible representation ![
$$\\pi _{2\\varpi _{1}+3\\varpi _{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq38.gif) of Sp(4) is shown in Fig. 21.7.

Fig. 21.7

The irreducible representation ![
$$\\pi _{2\\varpi _{1}+3\\varpi _{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq46.gif) of Sp(4)

If we considered SO(5), the group would not be simply connected, so we do not expect the fundamental weights to both lie in the root lattice. Let us see what happens. As explained in Chap.​ 19, the weight lattice is ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq39.gif) and the simple roots are ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{1} -\\mathbf{e}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq40.gif) and ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq41.gif), that is, (1,−1) and (0,1). From this, the fundamental dominant weights are ![
$$\\varpi _{1} = \(1,0\)$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq42.gif) and ![
$$\\varpi _{2} = \(\\tfrac{1} {2}, \\tfrac{1} {2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq43.gif). The first is in the weight lattice but the second, being fractional, is not. So even though we call ![
$$\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq44.gif) a "fundamental dominant weight" it is not a weight of SO(5). It is, however, a weight of the universal covering group Spin(5). Indeed, ![
$$\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq45.gif) is the highest weight of a four-dimensional irreducible representation of Spin(5), the spin representation. Let t be an element of the maximal torus of Spin(5) that projects onto

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccccc} t_{1} & & & & \\\\ & t_{2} & & & \\\\ & & 1& & \\\\ & & &t_{2}^{-1} & \\\\ & & & & t_{1}^{-1} \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\mathrm{SO}\(5\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Then the four eigenvalues of t in the spin representation are ![
$$t_{1}^{\\pm 1/2}t_{2}^{\\pm 1/2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq47.gif), where the signs of the square roots depend on which of the two elements in the preimage of the above orthogonal matrix is chosen. The highest weight is ![
$$\\sqrt{ t_{1}t_{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq48.gif), the character corresponding to ![
$$\\varpi _{2} = \(\\tfrac{1} {2}, \\tfrac{1} {2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq49.gif).

Exercises

Exercise 21.1.

Consider the adjoint representation of SU(3) acting on the eight-dimensional Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq50.gif) of SU(3). (It may be shown to be irreducible.) Show that the highest weight vector is ![
$$\\varpi _{1} + \\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq51.gif), and construct a weight diagram.

Exercise 21.2.

Construct a weight diagram for the adjoint representation of Sp(4) or, equivalently, SO(5).

Exercise 21.3.

Consider the symmetric square of the standard representation of SU(3). This is an irreducible representation. Show that it has dimension six, and that its highest weight vector is ![
$$2\\varpi _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq52.gif). Construct its weight diagram.

Exercise 21.4.

Consider the tensor product of the contragredient of the standard representation of SU(3), having highest weight vector ![
$$\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq53.gif), with the adjoint representation, having highest weight vector ![
$$\\varpi _{1} + \\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq54.gif). We will see later in Exercise 22.4 that this tensor product has three irreducible constituents. They are the contragredient of the standard representation, the symmetric square of the standard representation, and another piece, which we will call ![
$$\\pi _{\\varpi _{1}+2\\varpi _{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq55.gif). The first two pieces are known, and the third can be obtained by subtracting the two others. Accepting for now the validity of this decomposition, construct the weight diagram for the irreducible representation ![
$$\\pi _{\\varpi _{1}+2\\varpi _{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_21_Chapter_IEq56.gif).

Exercise 21.5.

The Lie group G 2 has an irreducible seven-dimensional representation. This information, together with the root system, described in Chap.​ 19, is enough to determine the weight diagram. Give the weight diagram for this representation, and for the 14-dimensional adjoint representation.

# 22. The Weyl Character Formula

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

The character formula of Weyl [174] is the gem of the representation theory of compact Lie groups.

The character formula of Weyl [174] is the gem of the representation theory of compact Lie groups.

Let G be a compact connected Lie group and T a maximal torus. Let Λ = X ∗(T), and let Λ root be the lattice spanned by the roots. Then Λ ⊇Λ root. The index Λ : Λ root] may be finite (e.g. if G = SU(n)) or infinite (e.g. if G = U(n)). If the index is finite, then we say G is semisimple, and this corresponds to the semisimple case in [Chap.​ 20. Elements of Λ will be called weights.

We have written the characters of T additively. Sometimes we want to write them multiplicatively, however, so we introduce symbols eλ for ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq1.gif) subject to the rule ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{\\lambda }{\\mathrm{e}}^{\\mu } ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{\\lambda +\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq2.gif). More formally, let ![
$$\\mathcal{E}\(R\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq3.gif) denote the free R-module on the set of symbols ![
$$\\{{\\mathrm{e}}^{\\lambda }\\vert \\lambda \\in \\varLambda \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq4.gif). It consists of all formal sums ![
$$\\sum _{\\lambda \\in \\varLambda }n_{\\lambda }\\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq5.gif) with n λ ∈ R such that n λ = 0 for all but finitely many λ. It is a ring with the multiplication

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \(\\sum _{\\lambda \\in \\varLambda }n_{\\lambda } \\cdot {\\mathrm{e}}^{\\lambda }\\right \)\\left \(\\sum _{ \\mu \\in \\varLambda }m_{\\mu } \\cdot {\\mathrm{e}}^{\\mu }\\right \) =\\sum _{ \\nu \\in \\varLambda }\\left \(\\sum _{\\lambda +\\mu =\\nu }n_{\\lambda }m_{\\mu }\\right \) \\cdot {\\mathrm{e}}^{\\nu }. }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(22.1)

This makes sense because only finitely many n λ and only finitely many m μ are nonzero. Of course, ![
$$\\mathcal{E}\(R\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq6.gif) is just the group algebra over R of Λ. The Weyl group acts on ![
$$\\mathcal{E}\(R\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq7.gif), and we will denote by ![
$$\\mathcal{E}{\(R\)}^{W}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq8.gif) the subring of W-invariant elements. Usually, we are interested in the case ![
$$R = \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq9.gif), and we will denote ![
$$\\mathcal{E} = \\mathcal{E}\(\\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq10.gif), ![
$${\\mathcal{E}}^{W} = \\mathcal{E}{\(\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{W}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq11.gif). We will find it sometimes convenient to work in the larger ring ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq12.gif), which is the free Abelian group on ![
$$\\tfrac{1} {2}\\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq13.gif).

If ![
$$\\xi =\\sum _{\\lambda }n_{\\lambda } \\cdot {\\mathrm{e}}^{\\lambda }$$

By Theorem 17.1, class functions on G are the same thing as W-invariant functions on T. In particular, if χ is the character of a representation of G, then its restriction to T is a sum of characters of T and is invariant under the action of W. Thus, if λ ∈Λ, let n λ(χ) denote the multiplicity of λ in this restriction. We associate with χ the element

![

$${\\mathcal{E}}^{W}$$

Proposition 22.1.

We have w(Δ) = (−1) l(w) Δ for all w ∈ W.

Proof.

It is sufficient to check that s β (Δ) = −Δ for every simple root β. We recall that s β changes the sign of β and permutes the remaining simple roots. Of the factors in the first expression for Δ in (22.2), only two are changed : e−ρ and (e β − 1). These become [see (20.11)] e−ρ+β and (e−β − 1). The net effect is that Δ changes sign. □

An alternative way of explaining the same proof begins with the equation

](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq27123.gif). Proposition 22.1 follows by noting that by Proposition 20.1(ii) each simple reflection alters the sign of exactly one term in (22.3), and the result follows.

this is divisible by Δ. □

$$\\lambda \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$

$$\\lambda \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\left \\langle s_{\\alpha }w\(\\lambda \),v\\right \\rangle & =& \\left \\langle w\\left \(\\lambda \\right \) - 2\\frac{\\left \\langle w\(\\lambda \),\\alpha \\right \\rangle } {\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\alpha \\right \\rangle } \\alpha,v\\right \\rangle {}\\\\ & =& \\left \\langle w\\left \(\\lambda \\right \),v\\right \\rangle - 2\\frac{\\left \\langle w\(\\lambda \),\\alpha \\right \\rangle } {\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\alpha \\right \\rangle } \\left \\langle \\alpha,v\\right \\rangle > \\left \\langle w\\left \(\\lambda \\right \),v\\right \\rangle. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$

Proposition 22.4.

$$\\lambda \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{\\rho }\\prod _{ \\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\(1 -{\\mathrm{e}}^{-\\alpha }\),}$$

Therefore,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\chi \(\\lambda \) ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{\\lambda }\\prod _{ \\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\(1 +{ \\mathrm{e}}^{-\\alpha } +{ \\mathrm{e}}^{-2\\alpha } + \\cdots \\,\)\\sum _{ w\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\lambda +\\rho \)-\(\\lambda +\\rho \)}. }$$

If f is a class function on G, we have

$$\\displaystyle{\\det \\big\(\[\\mathrm{Ad}\({t}^{-1}\) - I_{\\mathfrak{p}}\]\\,\\vert \\,\\mathfrak{p}\\big\) =\\prod _{ \\alpha \\in \\varPhi }\\big\(\\alpha {\(t\)}^{-1} - 1\\big\) = \\vert \\prod _{ \\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\big\(\\alpha \(t\) - 1\\big\){\\vert }^{2}.}$$

$${\\mathcal{E}}^{W}$$

$$\\eta \\in {\\mathcal{E}}^{W}$$

![

If ξ and η are characters of G, identified with elements of ![

If λ and μ are weights in ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq76.gif), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\chi \(\\lambda \),\\chi \(\\mu \)\\right \\rangle = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} 1&\\quad \\text{if }\\lambda = \\mu,\\\\ 0 &\\quad \\text{otherwise}. \\end{array} \\right.}$$

$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{1} {\\vert W\\vert }\\left \[\\sum _{w\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{w}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\rho +\\lambda \)}\\right \]\\left \[\\sum _{ w^{\\prime}\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{w^{\\prime}}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w^{\\prime}\(\\rho +\\mu \)}\\right \]}$$

![
$$\\displaystyle{= \\frac{1} {\\vert W\\vert }\\left \[\\sum _{w,w^{\\prime}\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{w+w^{\\prime}}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\rho +\\lambda \)-w^{\\prime}\(\\rho +\\mu \)}\\right \].}$$

Proposition 22.6.

The set of χ(λ) with ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\varLambda \\cap \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq79.gif) is a basis of the free ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq80.gif) -module ![
$${\\mathcal{E}}^{W}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq81.gif) .

$${\\mathcal{E}}^{W}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq82.gif) is spanned by elements of the form

$$\\displaystyle{B\(\\lambda \) =\\sum _{\\mu \\in W\\cdot \\lambda }{\\mathrm{e}}^{\\mu },\\qquad l \\in \\varLambda \\cap \\mathcal{C}_{ +},}$$

where W ⋅ λ is the orbit of λ under the action of W. It is sufficient to show that B(λ) is in the ![

Theorem 22.3.

(Weyl) Assume that G is semisimple. If ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\varLambda \\cap \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq84.gif) , then χ(λ) is the character of an irreducible representation of G, and each irreducible representation is obtained this way.

We will denote by π(λ) the irreducible representation of G with character χλ.

Proof.

Let χ be an irreducible representation of G. Regarding χ as an element of ![
$${\\mathcal{E}}^{W}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq85.gif), we may expand χ in terms of the χ(λ) by Proposition 22.6. We write

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\chi =\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{c} \\lambda \\in \\varLambda \\cap \\mathcal{C}_{+} \\end{array} $}}n_{\\lambda }\\cdot \\chi \(\\lambda \),\\qquad n_{\\lambda } \\in \\mathbb{Z}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equm.gif)

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{1 = \\left \\langle \\chi,\\chi \\right \\rangle =\\sum _{\\lambda }n_{\\lambda }^{2}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equn.gif)

Therefore, exactly one n λ is nonzero, and that has value ±1. Thus, either χ(λ) or its negative is an irreducible character of G. To see that − χ(λ) is not a character, consider its restriction to T. By Proposition 22.4, the multiplicity of the character λ in − χ(λ) is − 1, which is impossible if − χ(λ) is a character. Hence, χ(λ) = χ is an irreducible character of G.

We have shown that every irreducible character of G is a χ(λ). It remains to be shown that every χ(λ) is a character. Since the class functions on G are identical to the W-invariant functions on T, the closure in L 2(G) of ![
$$\\mathcal{E}{\(\\mathbb{C}\)}^{W}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq86.gif) is identified with the space of all class functions on G. By Proposition 22.6, the χ(λ) form an L 2-basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{E}{\(\\mathbb{C}\)}^{W}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq87.gif). Since by the Peter–Weyl theorem the set of irreducible characters of G are an L 2 basis of the space of class functions, the characters of G cannot be a proper subset of the set of χ(λ). □

Now let us step back and see what we have established. We know that in group representation theory there is a duality between the irreducible characters of a group and its conjugacy classes. We can study both the conjugacy classes and the irreducible representations of a compact Lie group by restricting them to T. We find that the conjugacy classes of G are in one-to-one correspondence with the W-orbits of T. Dually, the irreducible representations of G are parametrized by the orbits of W on Λ = X ∗(T).

We study these orbits by embedding X ∗(T) in a Euclidean space ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq88.gif). The positive Weyl chamber ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq89.gif) is a fundamental domain for the action of W on ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq90.gif), and so the dominant weights—those in ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq91.gif)—are thus used to parametrize the irreducible representations. Of the weights that appear in the parametrized representation χ(λ), the parametrizing weight ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\mathcal{C}_{+} \\cap {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq92.gif) is maximal with respect to the partial order. We therefore call it the highest weight vector of the representation.

Proposition 22.7.

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\varDelta =\\sum _{w\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\rho \)}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(22.9)

Proof.

The irreducible representation χ(0) with highest weight vector 0 is obviously the trivial representation. Therefore, χ(0) = e0 = 1. The formula now follows from (22.4). □

Weyl gave a formula for the dimension of the irreducible representation with character χλ. Of course, this is the value χλ at the identity element of G, but we cannot simply plug the identity into the Weyl character formula since the numerator and denominator both vanish there. Naturally, the solution is to use L'Hôpital's rule, which can be formulated purely algebraically in this context.

Theorem 22.4 (Weyl).

The dimension of π(λ) is

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\left \\langle \\lambda + \\rho,\\alpha \\right \\rangle } {\\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\left \\langle \\rho,\\alpha \\right \\rangle }. }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(22.10)

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\varOmega : \\mathcal{E}_{2}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq93.gif) be the map

![

If α ∈Φ, let ![
$$\\partial _{\\alpha } : \\mathcal{E}_{2}\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{E}_{2}$$

![

$$\\partial =\\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\partial _{\\alpha }$$

We show that if w ∈ W and ![
$$f \\in \\mathcal{E}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq96.gif), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ w\\partial \(f\) = {\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}\\partial w\(f\). }$$

(22.11)

We note first that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\partial _{w\(\\alpha \)} \\circ w = w \\circ \\partial _{\\alpha } }$$

(22.12)

since applying the operator on the left-hand side to eλ gives ![
$$\\left \\langle w\(\\lambda \),w\(\\alpha \)\\right \\rangle \\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\lambda \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq97.gif), while the second gives ![
$$\\left \\langle \\lambda,\\alpha \\right \\rangle \\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq98.gif), and these are equal. Now, to prove (22.11), we may assume that w = s β is a simple reflection. By (22.12), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{w \\circ \\left \(\\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\partial _{w\(\\alpha \)}\\right \) = \\partial \\circ w.}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equq.gif)

But by Proposition 20.1(ii), the set of w(α) consists of Φ + with just one element, namely β, replaced by its negative. So (22.11) is proved.

We consider now what happens when we apply Ω ∘ ∂ to both sides of the identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sum _{w\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{\\lambda }{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\lambda +\\rho \)} = \\chi _{ \\lambda } \\cdot \\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\left \({\\mathrm{e}}^{\\alpha /2} -{\\mathrm{e}}^{-\\alpha /2}\\right \). }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equ14.gif)

(22.13)

On the left-hand side, by (22.11), applying ∂ gives

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{w\\in W}w\\left \(\\partial {\\mathrm{e}}^{\\lambda +\\rho }\\right \) =\\sum _{ w\\in W}w\\,\\left \(\\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\left \\langle \\lambda + \\rho,\\alpha \\right \\rangle {\\mathrm{e}}^{\\lambda +\\rho }\\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equr.gif)

$$\\vert W\\vert \\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\left \\langle \\lambda + \\rho,\\alpha \\right \\rangle$$

On the other hand, we apply ∂ = ∏ ∂ β one derivation at a time to the right-hand side of (22.13), expanding by the Leibnitz product rule to obtain a sum of terms, each of which is a product of χλ and the terms ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{\\alpha /2} -{\\mathrm{e}}^{-\\alpha /2}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq100.gif), with various subsets of the ∂ β applied to each factor. When we apply Ω, any term in which a ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{\\alpha /2} -{\\mathrm{e}}^{-\\alpha /2}$$

](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq103.gif) is hit by exactly one ∂ β survive. Of course, χλ is not hit by a ∂ β in any such term. In other words,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varOmega \\circ \\partial \\left \(\\chi _{\\lambda } \\cdot \\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\left \({\\mathrm{e}}^{\\alpha /2} -{\\mathrm{e}}^{-\\alpha /2}\\right \)\\right \) = \\theta \\cdot \\varOmega \(\\chi _{ \\lambda }\),}$$

where

$$\\displaystyle{\\vert W\\vert \\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\left \\langle \\lambda + \\rho,\\alpha \\right \\rangle = \\theta \\cdot \\varOmega \(\\chi _{\\lambda }\).}$$

$$\\theta = \\vert W\\vert \\prod _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\left \\langle \\rho,\\alpha \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq104.gif). Dividing by this, we obtain (22.10). □

Proposition 22.8.

Let λ be a dominant weight, and let (π,V ) be an irreducible representation with highest weight λ. Let w 0 be the longest Weyl group element (Proposition 20.14 ). Then the highest weight of the contragredient representation is − w 0 λ.

Proof.

We recall that the character of the contragredient is the complex conjugate of the character of π (Proposition 2.6). The weights that occur in the contragredient are therefore the negatives of the weights that occur in π. It follows that − λ is the lowest weight of ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq105.gif). The highest weight is therefore in the same Weyl group element as − λ, and the unique dominant weight in that orbit is − w 0λ. □

In 1967 Klimyk described a method of decomposing tensor products that is very efficient for computation. It is based on a simple idea and in retrospect it was found that the same idea appeared in a much earlier paper of Brauer (1937). The same idea appears in Steinberg [154]. We will prove a special case, leaving the general case for the exercises.

Proposition 22.9 (Brauer, Klimyk).

Suppose that λ and μ are in ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\) \\cap \\mathcal{C}_{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq106.gif). Decompose χ μ into a sum of weights ν ∈ X ∗ (T) with multiplicities m(ν):

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\chi _{\\mu } =\\sum _{\\nu }m\(\\nu \)\\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{\\nu }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equv.gif)

Suppose that for each ν with m(ν) ≠ 0 the weight λ + ν is dominant. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\chi _{\\lambda }\\,\\chi _{\\mu } =\\sum _{\\nu }m\(\\nu \)\\chi _{\\lambda +\\nu }. }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equ15.gif)

(22.14)

Since ![
$$\\chi _{\\lambda }\\chi _{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq107.gif) is the character of the tensor product representation, this gives the decomposition of this tensor product into irreducibles. The method of proof can be extended to the case where λ + ν is not dominant for all ν, though the answer is a bit more complicated to state (Exercise 22.5).

Proof.

By the Weyl character formula, we may write

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\chi _{\\lambda }\\chi _{\\mu } {=\\varDelta }^{-1}\\sum _{ \\nu }m\(\\nu \)\\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{\\nu }\\sum _{ w}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}\\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\lambda +\\rho \)}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equw.gif)

Interchange the order of summation, so that the sum over ν is the inner sum, and make the variable change ν → w(ν). Since m(ν) = m(w ν), we get

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\varDelta }^{-1}\\sum _{ w}\\sum _{\\nu }m\(\\nu \)\\,{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}\\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\lambda +\\nu +\\rho \)}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equx.gif)

Now we may interchange the order of summation again and apply the Weyl character formula to obtain (22.14). □

It is sometimes convenient to shift ρ by a W-invariant element of ![
$$\\mathbb{R} \\otimes {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq108.gif) so that it is in X ∗(T). Such a shift is harmless in the Weyl character formula and the Weyl dimension formula provided we shift by a vector that is orthogonal to all the roots, since ρ only appears in inner product with the roots. This is only possible if G is not semisimple, for if G is semisimple, there are no nonzero vectors orthogonal to the roots. Let us illustrate this trick with G = U(n). We identify X ∗(T) with ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq109.gif) by mapping the character

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} t_{1} & & \\\\ & \\ddots & \\\\ & & t_{n} \\end{array} \\right \)\\longmapsto \\prod t_{i}^{k_{i} } }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equ16.gif)

(22.15)

to ![
$$\(k_{1},\\ldots,k_{n}\) \\in {\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq110.gif). Then ρ is ![
$$\\frac{1} {2}\(n - 1,n - 3,\\ldots,1 - n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq111.gif). If n is even, it is an element of ![
$$\\mathbb{R} \\otimes {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq112.gif) but not of X ∗(T). However, if we add to it the W-invariant element ![
$$\\frac{1} {2}\(n - 1,\\ldots,n - 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq113.gif), we get

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\delta = \(n - 1,n - 2,\\ldots,1,0\) \\in {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equ17.gif)

(22.16)

We can now write the Weyl character formula in the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\chi \(\\lambda \) =\\varDelta _{ 0}^{-1}\\sum _{ w\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\lambda +\\delta \)}, }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equ18.gif)

(22.17)

where

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta _{0} =\\sum _{w\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\delta \)}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equy.gif)

We have simply multiplied the numerator and the denominator by the same W-invariant element so that both the numerator and the denominator are in X ∗(T).

In (22.7), we write the factor ![
$$\\vert \\varDelta {\\vert }^{2} = \\vert \\varDelta _{0}{\\vert }^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq114.gif) since ![
$${\(\\varDelta _{0}/\\varDelta \)}^{2} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{2\(\\delta -\\rho \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq115.gif). As a function on the group, this is just det(g) n−1, which has absolute value 1. Therefore, we may write the Weyl integration formula in the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{G}f\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g = \\frac{1} {\\vert W\\vert }\\int _{T}f\(t\)\\,\\vert \\varDelta _{0}\(t\){\\vert }^{2}\\,\\mathrm{d}t. }$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equ19.gif)

(22.18)

The next exercise treats the Frobenius–Schur indicator of an irreducible representation. This will be covered (in a slightly different form) in Theorem 43.1. If (π,V ) is a representation of the compact group G, and ![
$$B : V \\times V \\rightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq145.gif) is an invariant bilinear form, then B is unique up to scalar multiple (by a version of Schur's lemma), so B(x, y) = c B(y, x) for some constant c. Since B(x, y) = c 2 B(x, y), c = ±1. Thus the form B is either symmetric or skew-symmetric. If it is symmetric, then π(G) is contained in the orthogonal group of the form, in which case we say π is orthogonal. If B is skew-symmetric, then π(G) is contained in the symplectic group of the form, in which case ![
$$\\dim \(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq146.gif) is even, and we say that π is symplectic. Every self-contragredient representation is either orthogonal or symplectic but not both. See Chap.​ 43 for further details.

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varepsilon \(\\pi \) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{ll} 1 & \\text{if}\\ \\pi \\ \\text{is orthogonal,} \\\\ - 1 & \\text{if}\\ \\pi \\ \\text{is symplectic,} \\\\ 0 & \\text{if}\\ \\pi \\ \\text{is not self-contragredient.}\\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equag.gif)

The generalized χ(g 2) is (in the language of lambda rings) the second Adams operation applied to χ. More generally, for k ![
$$ \\geqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq15231.gif) 0, the Adams operation ![
$${\\psi }^{k}\\chi \(g\) = \\chi \({g}^{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq149.gif). We will return to the Adams operations in Chap.​ 33, and in particular we will see that ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq3214.gif) k χ is a generalized character for all k; for k = 2 this follows from Exercise 22.14. Suppose that for μ in the weight lattice Λ of G, m(μ) is the weight multiplicity for χ, so that in the notation of Chap.​ 22, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\chi =\\sum _{\\mu \\in \\varLambda }m\(\\mu \)\\,{\\mathrm{e}}^{\\mu }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_Equah.gif)

Then clearly

![

A method of computing the Frobenius–Schur indicator is simply to decompose ![

](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq3211.gif) 2χ into irreducibles and note the coefficient of the trivial representation. A better method is to use a result of Steinberg [155] (modestly called Lemma 79) that there exists an element η of order ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_22_Chapter_IEq4133.gif) 2 in the center of G such that if π is self-dual, then the central character of π applied to η is the Frobenius–Schur indicator. In Sage, irreducible representations (as WeylCharacterRing elements) have a method to compute the Frobenius–Schur indicator.

# 23. The Fundamental Group

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In this chapter, we will look more closely at the fundamental group of a compact Lie group G. We will show that it is a finitely generated Abelian group and that each loop in G can be deformed into any given maximal torus. Then we will show how to calculate the fundamental group. Along the way we will encounter another important Coxeter group, the affine Weyl group. The key arguments in this chapter are topological and are adapted from Adams [2].

In this chapter, we will look more closely at the fundamental group of a compact Lie group G. We will show that it is a finitely generated Abelian group and that each loop in G can be deformed into any given maximal torus. Then we will show how to calculate the fundamental group. Along the way we will encounter another important Coxeter group, the affine Weyl group. The key arguments in this chapter are topological and are adapted from Adams [2].

Proposition 23.1.

Let G be a connected topological group and Γ a discrete normal subgroup. Then Γ ⊂ Z(G).

Proof.

Let γ ∈Γ. Then g → gγg −1 is a continuous map G → Γ. Since G is connected and Γ discrete, it is constant, so ![
$$g\\gamma {g}^{-1} = \\gamma $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq1.gif) for all g. Therefore, γ ∈ Z(G). □

Proposition 23.2.

If G is a connected Lie group, then the fundamental group π 1 (G) is Abelian.

Proof.

Let ![
$$p : \\tilde{ G}\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq2.gif) be the universal cover. We identify the kernel ker(p) with π1(G). This is a discrete normal subgroup of ![
$$\\tilde{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq3.gif) and hence is central in ![
$$\\tilde{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq4.gif) by Proposition 23.1. In particular, it is Abelian. □

We remind the reader that an element of G is regular if it is contained in a unique maximal torus. Clearly, a generator of a maximal torus is regular. An element of G is singular if it is not regular. Let G reg and G sing be the subsets of regular and singular elements of G, respectively.

Proposition 23.3.

The set G sing is a finite union of submanifolds of G, each of codimension at least 3.

Proof.

By Proposition 18.14, the singular elements of G are the conjugates of the kernels T α of the roots. We first show that the union of the set of conjugates of T α is the image of a manifold of codimension 3 under a smooth map. Let α ∈Φ. The set of conjugates of T α is the image of ![
$$G/C_{G}\(T_{\\alpha }\) \\times T_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq5.gif) under the smooth map ![
$$\\left \(gC_{G}\(T_{\\alpha }\),u\\right \)\\mapsto gu{g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq6.gif). Let ![
$$r =\\dim \(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq7.gif), so ![
$$r - 1 =\\dim \(T_{\\alpha }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq8.gif). The dimension of ![
$$C_{G}\(T_{\\alpha }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is at least r \+ 2 since its complexified Lie algebra contains ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq10.gif), ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq11.gif), and ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{-\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq12.gif). Thus, the dimension of the manifold ![
$$G/C_{G}\(T_{\\alpha }\) \\times T_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq13.gif) is at most ![
$$\\dim \(G\) - \(r + 2\) + \(r - 1\) =\\dim \(G\) - 3$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq14.gif).

However, we have asserted more precisely that G sing is a union of submanifolds of codimension ![
$$ \\geqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq1231.gif) 3. This more precise statement requires a bit more work. If S ⊂Φ is any nonempty subset, let ![
$$U_{S} =\\bigcap \\{ T_{\\alpha }\\vert \\alpha \\in S\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq15.gif). Let V S be the open subset of U S consisting of elements not contained in U S′ for any larger S′. It is easily checked along the lines of (17.2) that the Jacobian of the map

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(g\\,C_{G}\(U_{S}\),u\\right \)\\mapsto gu{g}^{-1},\\qquad G/C_{ G}\(U_{S}\) \\times V _{S}\\longrightarrow G,}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equa.gif)

is nonvanishing, so its image is a submanifold of G by the inverse function theorem. The union of these submanifolds is G sing, and each has dimension ![
$$\\leqslant \\dim \(G\) - 3$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq16.gif). □

Lemma 23.1.

Let X and Y be Hausdorff topological spaces and f : X → Y a local homeomorphism. Suppose that U ∈ X is a dense open set and that the restriction of f to U is injective. Then f is injective.

Proof.

If ![
$$x_{1}\\neq x_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq17.gif) are elements of X such that ![
$$f\(x_{1}\) = f\(x_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq18.gif), find open neighborhoods V 1 and V 2 of x 1 and x 2, respectively, that are disjoint, and such that f induces a homeomorphism ![
$$V _{i}\\longrightarrow f\(V _{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq19.gif). Note that ![
$$U \\cap V _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq20.gif) is a dense open subset of V i , so ![
$$f\(U \\cap V _{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq21.gif) is a dense open subset of f(V i ). Since ![
$$f\(V _{1}\) \\cap f\(V _{2}\)\\neq \\varnothing $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq22.gif), it follows that ![
$$f\(U \\cap V _{1} \\cap V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq23.gif) is nonempty. If ![
$$z \\in f\(U \\cap V _{1} \\cap V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq24.gif), then there exist elements ![
$$y_{i} \\in U \\cap V _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq25.gif) such that f(y i ) = z. Since V i are disjoint ![
$$y_{1}\\neq y_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq26.gif); yet ![
$$f\(y_{1}\) = f\(y_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq27.gif), a contradiction since f|U is injective. □

We define a map ![
$$\\phi : G/T \\times T_{\\mathrm{reg}}\\longrightarrow G_{\\mathrm{reg}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq28.gif) by ![
$$\\phi \(gT,t\) = gt{g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq29.gif). It is the restriction to the regular elements of the map studied in Chap.​ 17.

Proposition 23.4.

(i)

The map ϕ is a covering map of degree |W|.

(ii)

If t ∈ T reg , then the |W| elements wtw −1 , w ∈ W are all distinct.

Proof.

For t ∈ T reg, the Jacobian of this map, computed in (17.2), is nonzero. Thus the map ϕ is a local homeomorphism.

We define an action of ![
$$W = N\(T\)/T$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq30.gif) on G ∕ T × T reg by

![
$$\\displaystyle{w : \(gT,t\)\\longrightarrow \(g{n}^{-1}T,ng{n}^{-1}\),\\quad w = nT \\in W.}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equb.gif)

W acts freely on G∕T, so the quotient map ![
$$G/T \\times T_{\\mathrm{reg}}\\longrightarrow W\\setminus \(G/T \\times T_{\\mathrm{reg}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq31.gif) is a covering map of degree |W|. The map ϕ factors through W∖(G∕T × T reg). Consider the induced map ![
$$\\psi : W\\setminus \(G/T \\times T_{\\mathrm{reg}}\)\\longrightarrow G_{\\mathrm{reg}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq32.gif). We have a commutative diagram :

Both ϕ and the horizontal arrow are local homeomorphisms, so ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq1525.gif) is a local homeomorphism. By Proposition 17.3, the elements wtw −1 are all distinct for t in a dense open subset of T reg. Thus, ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq1521.gif) is injective on a dense open subset of W∖(G∕T × T reg), and since it is a local homeomorphism, it is therefore injective by Lemma 23.1. This proves both (i) and (ii). □

Proposition 23.5.

Let p : X → Y be a covering map. The map ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(X\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(Y \)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq33.gif) induced by inclusion X → Y is injective.

Proof.

Suppose that p 0 and p 1 are loops in X with the same endpoints whose images in Y are path-homotopic. It is an immediate consequence of Proposition 13.2 that p 0 and p 1 are themselves path-homotopic. □

Proposition 23.6.

The inclusion G reg → G induces an isomorphism of fundamental groups :  ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G_{\\mathrm{reg}}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq34.gif) .

Proof.

Of course, we usually take the base point of G to be the identity, but that is not in G reg. Since G is connected, the isomorphism class of its fundamental group does not change if we move the base point P into G reg.

If p : [0, 1] → G is a loop beginning and ending at P, the path may intersect G sing. We may replace the path by a smooth path. Since G sing is a finite union of submanifolds of codimension at least 3, we may move the path slightly and avoid G sing. (For this we only need codimension 2.) Therefore, the induced map ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G_{\\mathrm{reg}}\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq35.gif) is surjective.

Now suppose that p 0 and p 1 are two paths in G reg that are path-homotopic in G. We may assume that both the paths and the homotopy are smooth. Since G sing is a finite union of submanifolds of codimension at least 3, we may perturb the homotopy to avoid it, so p 0 and p 1 are homotopic in G reg. Thus, the map ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G_{\\mathrm{reg}}\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq36.gif) is injective. □

Proposition 23.7.

We have ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G/T\) = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq37.gif) .

In Exercise 27.4 we will see that the Bruhat decomposition gives an alternative proof of this fact.

Proof.

Let ![
$$t_{0} \\in T_{\\mathrm{reg}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq38.gif) and consider the map f 0 : G∕T→G, ![
$$f_{0}\(gT\) = gt_{0}{g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq39.gif). We will show that the map ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G/T\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq40.gif) induced by f 0 is injective. We may factor f 0 as

![
$$\\displaystyle{G/T\\mathop{{\\longrightarrow } }^{\\upsilon }G/T \\times T_{\\mathrm{ reg}}\\mathop{{ \\longrightarrow } }^{\\phi }G_{\\mathrm{ reg}}\\longrightarrow G,}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equc.gif)

where the first map υ sends gT →(gT, t 0). We will show that each induced map

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\pi _{1}\(G/T\)\\mathop{{\\longrightarrow } }^{\\upsilon }\\pi _{ 1}\(G/T \\times T_{\\mathrm{reg}}\)\\mathop{{\\longrightarrow } }^{\\phi }\\pi _{ 1}\(G_{\\mathrm{reg}}\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(23.1)

is injective. It should be noted that T reg might not be connected, so G∕T × T reg might not be connected, and ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G/T \\times T_{\\mathrm{reg}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq41.gif) depends on the choice of a connected component for its base point. We choose the base point to be (T, t 0).

We can factor the identity map G∕T as ![
$$G/T\\mathop{{\\longrightarrow } }\\limits^{\\upsilon }G/T \\times T_{\\mathrm{reg}}\\longrightarrow G/T$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq42.gif), where the second map is the projection. Applying the functor π1, we see that π1(υ) has a left inverse and is therefore injective. Also π1(ϕ) is injective by Propositions 23.4 and 23.5, and the third map is injective by Proposition 23.6. This proves that the map induced by f 0 injects ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G/T\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq43.gif).

However, the map f 0 : G∕T → G is homotopic in G to the trivial map mapping G∕t to a single point, as we can see by moving t 0 to 1 ∈ G. Thus f 0 induces the trivial map ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G/T\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq44.gif) and so ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G/T\) = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq45.gif). □

Theorem 23.1.

The induced map ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(T\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq46.gif) is surjective. The group π 1 (G) is finitely generated and Abelian.

Proof.

One way to see this is to use have the exact sequence

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi _{1}\(T\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G/T\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equd.gif)

of the fibration G→G∕T (Spanier [149, Theorem 10 on p. 377]). It follows using Proposition 23.7 that ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(T\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq47.gif) is surjective. Alternatively, we avoid recourse to the exact sequence to recall more directly why π1(G∕T) implies that ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(T\) \\rightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq48.gif) is surjective. Given any loop in G, its image in G∕T can be deformed to the identity, and lifting this homotopy to G deforms the original path to a path lying entirely in T.

As a quotient of the finitely generated Abelian group π1(T), the group π1(G) is finitely generated and Abelian. □

Since the map ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(T\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$

$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq58.gif) is simply-connected, and the exponential map ![
$$\\exp : \\mathfrak{t}\\longrightarrow T$$

$$\\mathfrak{t}$$

$$\\mathfrak{t} \\rightarrow T$$

$$\\mathcal{V}$$

Proposition 23.8.

Define ![
$$\\tau : \\mathfrak{t} \\rightarrow {\\mathcal{V}}^{{\\ast}}$$

$$\\tau \(H\) \\in {\\mathcal{V}}^{{\\ast}}$$

$$\\frac{1} {2\\pi i}\\mathrm{d}\\lambda \(H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq66.gif) . Then τ is a linear isomorphism, and τ maps the kernel of ![
$$\\exp : \\mathfrak{t} \\rightarrow T$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq67.gif) to Λ ∨ . If α ∨ is a coroot, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ {\\alpha }^{\\vee } = \\tau \(2\\pi iH_{ \\alpha }\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(23.2)

Proof.

It is clear that τ is a linear isomorphism. It follows from Lemma 23.2(ii) that it maps the kernel of exp onto the coweight lattice. The identity (23.2) follows from Proposition 18.13. □

For each α ∈Φ and each ![
$$k \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq68.gif) define the hyperplane ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k} \\subset \\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq69.gif) to be

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\{H \\in \\mathfrak{t}\\vert \\tau \(H\)\(\\alpha \) = k\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equf.gif)

By Lemma 23.2, the preimage of T α in ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq70.gif) under the exponential map is the union of the ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq71.gif).

The geometry of these hyperplanes leads to the affine Weyl group (Bourbaki [23, Chap. IV Sect. 2]). This structure goes back to Stiefel [156] and has subsequently proved very important. Adams [2] astutely based his discussion of the fundamental group on the affine Weyl group. The fundamental group is also discussed in Bourbaki [24, Chap. IX]. The affine Weyl group was used by Iwahori and Matsumoto [86] to introduce a Bruhat decomposition into a reductive p-adic group. The geometry introduced by Stiefel also reappears as the "apartment" in the Bruhat-Tits building. Iwahori and Matsumoto also introduced the affine Hecke algebra as a convolution algebra of functions on a p-adic group, but the affine Hecke algebra has an importance in other areas of mathematics for example because of its role in Kazhdan-Lusztig theory.

In addition to the simple positive roots ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq72.gif), let − α0 be the highest weight in the adjoint representation. It is a positive root, so α0 is a negative root, the so-called affine root which will appear later in Chap.​ 30. We call a connected component of the complement of the hyperplanes ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq73.gif) an alcove. To identify a particular one, there is a unique alcove that is contained in the positive Weyl chamber which contains the origin in its closure. This alcove is the region bounded by the hyperplanes ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{a_{1},0}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq74.gif),..., ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{a_{r},0}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq75.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{-\\alpha _{0},1} = \\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha _{0},\\,-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq76.gif). It will be called the fundamental alcove ![
$$\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq77.gif).

We have seen (by Lemma 23.2) that the lattice Λ ∨ where the weights take integer values may be identified with the kernel of the exponential map ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}\\longrightarrow T$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq78.gif). Thus Λ ∨ may be identified with the fundamental group of T, which (by Proposition 23.1) maps surjectively onto π1(G). Therefore we need to compute the kernel of this homomorphism ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\\vee }\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq79.gif). We will show that it is the coroot lattice ![
$$\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq80.gif), which is the sublattice generated by the coroots α∨ (α ∈Φ).

Fig. 23.1

The Cartan subalgebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq81.gif), partitioned into alcoves, when G = SU(3) or PU(3). We are identifying ![
$$\\mathfrak{t} = {\\mathcal{V}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq82.gif) via the isomorphism τ, so the coroots are in ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq83.gif)

Before turning to the proofs, let us consider an example. Let G = PU(3), illustrated in Fig. 23.1. The hyperplanes ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq84.gif) are labeled, subdividing ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq85.gif) into alcoves, and the fundamental alcove ![
$$\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq86.gif) is shaded. The coweight lattice ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\\vee }\\mathop{\\cong}\\pi _{1}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq87.gif) consists of the vertices of the alcoves, which are the smaller dots. The heavier dots mark the coroot lattice.

If we consider instead G = SU(3), the diagram would be the same with only one difference : now not all the vertices of alcoves are in Λ ∨. In this example, ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\\vee } =\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq88.gif) consists of only the heavier dots. Not every vertex of the fundamental alcove is in the coweight lattice.

If α ∈Φ and ![
$$k \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq89.gif) let s α,k be the reflection in the hyperplane ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq90.gif). Thus

![
$$\\displaystyle{s_{\\alpha,k}\(x\) = x -\\left \(\\alpha \\left \(x\\right \) - k\\right \){\\alpha }^{\\vee }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equg.gif)

Let W aff be the group of transformations of ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq91.gif) generated by the reflections in the hyperplanes ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq92.gif). This is the affine Weyl group. In particular we will label the reflections in the walls of the fundamental alcove ![
$$s_{0},s_{1},\\ldots,s_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq93.gif), where if 1 ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq41253.gif) i ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq12342.gif) r then s i is the reflection in ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha _{i},0}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq94.gif), and s 0 is the reflection in ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha _{0},-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq95.gif).

Proposition 23.9.

(i)

The affine Weyl group acts transitively on the alcoves.

(ii)

The group W aff is generated by ![
$$s_{0},s_{1},\\ldots,s_{r}.$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq96.gif)

(iii)

The group W aff contains the group of translations by elements of ![
$$\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq97.gif) as a normal subgroup and is the semidirect product of W and the translation group of ![
$$\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq98.gif) .

Proof.

Let W′aff be the subgroup ![
$$s_{0},s_{1},\\ldots,s_{r}.$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq99.gif) Consider the orbit ![
$$W^{\\prime}_{\\mathrm{aff}}\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq100.gif) of alcoves. If ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq101.gif) is in this orbit, and ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq102.gif) is another alcove adjacent to ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq103.gif), then ![
$$\\mathcal{F} = w\\mathcal{F}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq104.gif) for some w ∈ W′ F and so ![
$$w\\mathcal{F}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq105.gif) is adjacent to ![
$$\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq106.gif), i.e. ![
$$w\\mathcal{F}_{2} = s_{i}\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq107.gif) for some s i . It follows that ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq108.gif) is in ![
$$W^{\\prime}_{\\mathrm{aff}}\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq109.gif) also. Since every alcove adjacent to an alcove in ![
$$W^{\\prime}_{\\mathrm{aff}}\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq110.gif) is also in it, it is clear that ![
$$W^{\\prime}_{\\mathrm{aff}}\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq111.gif) consists of all alcoves, proving (i).

We may now show that ![
$$W_{\\mathrm{aff}} = W^{\\prime}_{\\mathrm{aff}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq112.gif). It is enough to show that the reflection r = s α,k in the hyperplane ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq113.gif) is in W′aff. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{A}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq114.gif) be an alcove that is adjacent to ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq115.gif), and find w ∈ W′aff such that ![
$$w\(\\mathcal{A}\) = \\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq116.gif). Then w maps ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq117.gif) to one of the walls of ![
$$\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq118.gif), so wrw −1 is the reflection in that wall. This means ![
$$wr{w}^{-1} = s_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq119.gif) for some i and so ![
$$r = {w}^{-1}s_{i}w \\in W^{\\prime}_{\\mathrm{aff}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq120.gif). This completes the proof that W aff is generated by the s i .

Now we recall that the group ![
$$\\mathfrak{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq121.gif) of all affine linear maps of the real vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq122.gif) is the semidirect product of the group of linear transformations (which fix the origin) by the group of translations, a normal subgroup. If ![
$$v \\in \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq123.gif) we will denote by T(v) the translation x ↦ x \+ v. So ![
$$T\(\\mathfrak{t}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq124.gif) is normal in ![
$$\\mathfrak{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq125.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{G} = \\mathrm{GL}\(\\mathfrak{t}\) \\cdot T\(\\mathfrak{t}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq126.gif). This means that ![
$$\\mathfrak{G}/T\(\\mathfrak{t}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{GL}\(\\mathfrak{t}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq127.gif). The homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{G}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(\\mathfrak{t}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq128.gif) maps the reflection in ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq129.gif) to the reflection in the parallel hyperplane ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,0}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq130.gif) through the origin. This induces a homomorphism from W aff to W, and we wish to determine the kernel ![
$$\\mathfrak{K}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq131.gif), which is the group of translations in W aff.

First observe T(α∨) is in W aff, since it is the reflection in ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,0}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq132.gif) followed by the reflection in ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq133.gif). Let us check that ![
$$\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq134.gif) is normalized by W. Indeed we check easily that ![
$$s_{\\alpha,0}T\({\\beta }^{\\vee }\)s_{\\alpha _{0}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq135.gif) is translation by ![
$$s_{\\alpha,0}\({\\beta }^{\\vee }\) = {\\beta }^{\\vee }- \\alpha \({\\beta }^{\\vee }\){\\alpha }^{\\vee }\\in \\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq136.gif). Therefore ![
$$W \\cdot T\(\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq137.gif) is a subgroup of W′aff. Finally, we note that ![
$$s_{\\alpha,k} = T\(k{\\alpha }^{\\vee }\)s_{\\alpha,0}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq138.gif), so ![
$$W \\cdot T\(\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq139.gif) contains generators for W aff, and the proof is complete. □

The group W extended generated by W aff and translations by Λ may equal W aff or it may be larger. This often larger group is called the extended affine Weyl group. We will not need it, but it is important and we mention it for completeness.

We have constructed a surjective homomorphism ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\\vee }\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq140.gif). To recapitulate, the exponential map ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}\\longrightarrow T$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq141.gif) is a covering by a simply-connected group, so its kernel Λ ∨ may be identified with the fundamental group π1(T), and we have seen that the map ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(T\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq142.gif) induced by inclusion is surjective.

We recall that if X is a topological space then a path p : [0, 1]→ X is called a loop if p(0) = p(1).

Lemma 23.3.

Let ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq412511.gif) : Y → X be a covering map, and let p : [0, 1] → Y be a path. If ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq412534.gif) ∘ p : [0, 1]→ X is a loop that is contractible in X, then p is a loop.

Proof.

Let q =ϕ ∘ p, and let x = q(0). Let y = p(0), so ϕ(y) = x. What we know is that q(1) = x and what we need to prove is that p(1) = y.

Since q is contractible in X, we may find a family q u of paths indexed by u ∈ [0,1] such that q 0 = q while q 1 is the constant path q 1(t) = x. We may choose the deformation so that neither end point moves, that is, ![
$$q_{u}\(0\) = q_{u}\(1\) = x$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq143.gif) for all u. For each u, by the path lifting property of covering maps [Proposition 13.2(i)] we may find a unique path p u : [0, 1]→ Y such that ![
$$\\psi \\circ p_{u} = q_{u}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq144.gif) and p u (0) = y. In particular, p 0 = p. It is clear that p u (t) varies continuously as a function of both t and u. Since q 1 is constant, so is p 1 and therefore ![
$$p_{1}\(1\) = p_{1}\(0\) = y$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq145.gif). Now u ↦ p u (1) is a path covering a constant path, hence it too is constant, so ![
$$p_{0}\(1\) = p_{1}\(1\) = y$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq146.gif). □

Proposition 23.10.

The kernel of the surjective homomorphism ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\\vee }\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq147.gif) that we have described is ![
$$\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq148.gif) . Thus the fundamental group π 1 (G) is isomorphic to ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\\vee }/\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq149.gif) .

Proof.

First let us show that a coroot α∨ is in the kernel of this homomorphism. In view of (23.2) this means, concretely that if we take a path from 0 to 2πiH α in ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq150.gif) then the exponential of this map (which has both left and right endpoint at the identity) is contractible in G. We may modify the path so that it is the straight-line path, passing through πiH α. Then we write it as the concatenation of two paths, p ⋆ q in the notation of Chap.​ 13, where p(0) = 0 and p(1) = πiH α while q(0) = πiH α and q(1) = 2πiH α.

The exponential of this path ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{p\\star q} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{p} \\star { \\mathrm{e}}^{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq151.gif) is a loop. In fact, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\mathrm{e}}^{p\(0\)} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{q\(1\)} = i_{ \\alpha }\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 1\\;& \\\\ &\\;1 \\end{array} \\right \),\\quad {\\mathrm{e}}^{p\(1\)} ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{q\(0\)} = i_{ \\alpha }\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} - 1& \\\\ & - 1 \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equh.gif)

We will deform the path q, leaving p unchanged. Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{g\(u\) = i_{\\alpha }\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\cos \(\\pi u/2\)& -\\sin \(\\pi u/2\)\\\\ \\sin \(\\pi u/2\) & \\cos \(\\pi u/2\) \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_Equi.gif)

and consider q u = Ad(g(u))q. The endpoints of q u do change as u goes from 0 to 1, but the endpoints of ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{q_{u}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq152.gif) do not. Indeed ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{q_{u}\(0\)} = g\(u\)i_{\\alpha }\(-I\)g{\(u\)}^{-1} = i_{\\alpha }\(-I\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq153.gif) and similarly ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{q_{u}\(1\)} = i_{\\alpha }\(-1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq154.gif). Thus the path e p⋆q is homotopic to ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{p} \\star { \\mathrm{e}}^{q_{1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq155.gif). Now ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{q_{1}} = w_{\\alpha }{\\mathrm{e}}^{q}w_{\\alpha }^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq156.gif), which is the negative of the path e p , being the exponential of the straight line path from − πiH α to − 2πiH α. This proves that e p⋆q is path-homotopic to the identity.

Thus far we have shown that Λ coroot is in the kernel of the homomorphism ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\\vee }\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq157.gif). To complete the proof, we will now show that if K ∈Λ ∨ maps to the identity in π1(G), then ![
$$K \\in \\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq158.gif). We note that there are |W| alcoves that are adjacent to the origin; these are the alcoves ![
$$w\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq159.gif) with w ∈ W. We will show that we may assume that K lies in the closure of one of these alcoves. Indeed ![
$$\\mathcal{F} + K$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq160.gif) is an alcove, so there is some w′ ∈ W aff such that ![
$$\\mathcal{F} + K = w^{\\prime}\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq161.gif). Moreover, w′ may be represented as T(K′)w with ![
$$K^{\\prime} \\in \\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq162.gif) and w ∈ W. Thus ![
$$\\mathcal{F} + K - K^{\\prime} = w\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq163.gif) and since we have already shown that K′ maps to the identity in π1(G), we may replace K by K − K′ and assume that K is in the closure of ![
$$w\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq164.gif).

Our goal is to prove that K = 0, which will of course establish that establish ![
$$K \\in \\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq165.gif), as required. Since K and the origin are in the same alcove, we may find a path ![
$$p : \[0, 1\]\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq166.gif) from 0 to K such that p(u) is in the interior of the alcove for p(u) ≠ 0,1, while p(0) = 0 and p(1) = K are vertices of the alcove.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathrm{reg}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq167.gif) be the preimage of T reg in ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq168.gif) under the exponential map. It is the complement of the hyperplanes ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq169.gif), or equivalently, the union of the alcove interiors. We will make use of the map ![
$$\\psi : G/T \\times \\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathrm{reg}}\\longrightarrow G_{\\mathrm{reg}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq170.gif) defined by ![
$$\\phi \(gT,H\) = g{\\mathrm{e}}^{H}{g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq171.gif). It is the composition of the covering map ϕ in Proposition 23.4 with the exponential map ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathrm{reg}}\\longrightarrow T_{\\mathrm{reg}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq172.gif), which is also a covering, so ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq1522.gif) is a covering map.

Let N be a connected neighborhood of the identity in G that is closed under conjugation such that the preimage under exp of N in ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq173.gif) consists of disjoint open sets, each containing an a single element of the kernel Λ ∨ of the exponential map on ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq174.gif). Let ![
$$N_{\\mathfrak{t}} = \\mathfrak{t} {\\cap \\exp }^{-1}\(N\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq175.gif) be this reimage. Each connected component of ![
$$N_{\\mathfrak{t}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq176.gif) contains a unique element of Λ ∨.

We will modify p so that it is outside ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathrm{reg}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq177.gif) only near t = 1. Let ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq178.gif) be a small vector in the interior of ![
$$w\\mathcal{F}\\cap N$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq179.gif) and let ![
$$p^{\\prime} : \[0, 1\]\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq180.gif) be the path shifted by H. The vector H can be chosen in the connected component of ![
$$N_{\\mathfrak{t}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq181.gif) that contains 0 but no other element of Λ ∨. So p′(0) = H and ![
$$p^{\\prime}\(1\) = K + H$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq182.gif). When t is near 1 the path p′ may cross some of the ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha,k}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq183.gif) but only inside N.

The exponentiated path e p′(t) will be a loop close to e p(t) hence contractible. And e p′(t) will be near the identity 1 = e K in G at the end of the path where p′(t) may not be in the interior of ![
$$w\\mathcal{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq184.gif). Because, by Proposition 23.3, G reg is a union of codimension ![
$$ \\geqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq1232.gif) 3 submanifolds of G, we may find a loop q″ : [0, 1]→ G reg that coincides with e p′ until near the end where p′(t) is near v \+ H and e p′(t) reenters N. At the end of the path, q″ dodges out of T to avoid the singular subset of G, but stays near the identity. More precisely, if q″ is close enough to e p′ the paths will agree until e p′(t) and q″ are both inside N.

The loop q″ will have the same endpoints as e p′. It is still contractible by Proposition 23.6. Therefore we may use the path lifting property of covering maps [Proposition 13.2(i)] to lift the path q″ to a path ![
$$p^{\\prime\\prime} : \[0, 1\]\\longrightarrow G/T \\times \\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathrm{reg}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq185.gif) by means of ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq1523.gif), with p″(0) = (1 ⋅ T, H), the lifted path is a loop by Lemma 23.3. Thus ![
$$p^{\\prime\\prime}\(1\) = p^{\\prime\\prime}\(0\) = \(1 \\cdot T,H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq186.gif). Now consider the projection p‴ of p″ onto ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathrm{reg}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq187.gif). At the end of the path, the paths e p′ and ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq1524.gif) ∘ p″ are both within N, so p′ and p‴ can only vary within ![
$$N_{\\mathfrak{t}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq188.gif). In particular their endpoints, which are H \+ K and H respectively, must be the same, so K = 0 as required. □

Proposition 23.11.

Let G be a compact connected Lie group. The following are equivalent.

(i)

The root system Φ spans ![
$$\\mathcal{V} = \\mathbb{R} \\otimes {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq189.gif) .

(ii)

The fundamental group π 1 (G) is finite.

(iii)

The center Z(G) is finite.

If these conditions are satisfied, G is called semisimple.

Proof.

The root lattice spans ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq190.gif) if and only if the coroot lattice spans ![
$${\\mathcal{V}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq191.gif), which we are identifying with ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq192.gif). Since Λ ∨ is a lattice in ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq193.gif) of rank equal to ![
$$\\dim \(\\mathcal{V}\) =\\dim \(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq194.gif), the coroot lattice spans ![
$${\\mathcal{V}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq195.gif) if and only if ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\\vee }/\\varLambda _{\\mathrm{coroot}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq196.gif) is finite, and this, we have seen, is isomorphic to the fundamental group. Thus (i) and (ii) are equivalent. The center Z(G) is the intersection of the T α by Proposition 18.14. Thus the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{z}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq197.gif) of Z(G) is zero if and only if the ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq198.gif), which are the kernels of the roots interpreted as linear functionals on ![
$$\\mathfrak{t} = {\\mathcal{V}}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq199.gif). So Z(G) is finite if and only if ![
$$\\mathfrak{z} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq200.gif), if and only if the roots span ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq201.gif). The equivalence of all three statements is now proved. □

Let us now assume that G is semisimple. Let ![
$$\\tilde{\\varLambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq202.gif) be the set of ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_23_Chapter_IEq203.gif) such that ![
$${\\alpha }^{\\vee }\(\\lambda \) \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
