# 24. Complexification

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

Thus far, we have investigated the representations of compact connected Lie groups. In this chapter, we will see how the representation theory of compact connected Lie groups has implications for at least some noncompact Lie groups.

Thus far, we have investigated the representations of compact connected Lie groups. In this chapter, we will see how the representation theory of compact connected Lie groups has implications for at least some noncompact Lie groups.

Let K be a connected Lie group. A complexification of K consists of a complex analytic group G with a Lie group homomorphism i: K → G such that whenever f: K → H is a Lie group homomorphism into a complex analytic group, there exists a unique analytic homomorphism F: G → H such that f = F ∘ i. This is a universal property, so it characterizes G up to isomorphism.

A consequence of this definition is that the finite-dimensional representations of K are in bijection with the finite-dimensional analytic representations of G. Indeed, we may take H to be ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq1.gif). A finite-dimensional representation of K is a Lie group homomorphism ![
$$K\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq2.gif), and so any finite-dimensional representation of K extends uniquely to an analytic representation of G.

Proposition 24.1.

The group ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq3.gif) is the complexification of the Lie group ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq4.gif) .

Proof.

Given any complex analytic group H and any Lie group homomorphism ![
$$f: \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq5.gif), the differential is a Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)\\longrightarrow$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq6.gif) Lie(H). Since Lie(H) is a complex Lie algebra, this homomorphism extends uniquely to a complex Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Lie}\(H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq7.gif) by Proposition 11.3. By Theorems 13.5 and 13.6, ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq8.gif) is simply connected, so by Theorem 14.2 this map is the differential of a Lie group homomorphism ![
$$F: \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq9.gif). We need to show that F is analytic. Consider the commutative diagram

The top, left, and right arrows are all holomorphic maps, and ![
$$\\exp: \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq10.gif) is a local homeomorphism in a neighborhood of the identity. Hence F is holomorphic near 1. If ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq11.gif) and if ![
$$l\(g\): \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq12.gif) and ![
$$l\\big\(F\(g\)\\big\): H\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq13.gif) denote left translation with respect to g and F(g), then l(g) and ![
$$l\\big\(F\(g\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq14.gif) are analytic, and ![
$$F = l\\big\(F\(g\)\\big\) \\circ F \\circ l{\(g\)}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq15.gif). Since F is analytic at 1, it follows that it is analytic at g. □

We recall from Chap. , particularly the proof of Proposition 14.1, that if G is a Lie group and ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq16.gif) a Lie subalgebra of Lie(G), then there is an involutory family of tangent vectors spanned by the left-invariant vector fields corresponding to the elements of ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq17.gif). Since these vector fields are left-invariant, this involutory family is invariant under left translation.

Proposition 24.2.

Let G be a Lie group and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq18.gif) be a Lie subalgebra of Lie (G). Let H be a closed connected subset of G that is an integral submanifold of the involutory family associated with ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq19.gif), and suppose that 1 ∈ H. Then H is a subgroup of G.

One must not conclude from this that every Lie subalgebra of Lie(G) is the Lie algebra of a closed Lie subgroup. For example, if ![
$$G = {\(\\mathbb{R}/\\mathbb{Z}\)}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq20.gif), then the one-dimensional subalgebra spanned by a vector ![
$$\(x_{1},x_{2}\) \\in \\mathrm{Lie}\(G\) = {\\mathbb{R}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq21.gif) is the Lie algebra of a closed subgroup only if ![
$$x_{1}/x_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq22.gif) is rational or x 2 = 0.

Proof.

Let x ∈ H and let ![
$$U =\\{ y \\in H\\,\\vert \\,{x}^{-1}y \\in H\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq23.gif).

We show that U is open in H. If ![
$$y \\in U = H \\cap xH$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq24.gif), both H and xH are integral submanifolds for the involutory family associated with ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq25.gif), since the vector fields corresponding to elements of ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) are left-invariant. Hence by the uniqueness assertion of the local Frobenius theorem (Theorem 14.1) H and xH have the same intersection with a neighborhood of y in G, and it follows that U contains a neighborhood of y in H.

We next show that the complement of U is open in H. Suppose that y is an element H − U. Thus, y ∈ H but x −1 y∉H. By the local Frobenius theorem there exists an integral manifold V through x −1 y. Since H is closed, the intersection of V with a sufficiently small neighborhood of x −1 y in G is disjoint from H. Replacing V by its intersection with this neighborhood, we may assume that the intersection ![
$$xV \\cap H = \\varnothing $$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq27123.gif). Since H and xV are both integral manifolds through y, they have the same intersection with a neighborhood of y in G, and so xz ∈ V for z near y in H. Thus, z∉U. It follows that H − U is open.

We see that U is both open and closed in H and nonempty since 1 ∈ U. Since H is connected, it follows that U = H. This proves that if x,y ∈ H, then x −1 y ∈ H. This implies that H is a subgroup of G. □

Theorem 24.1.

Let K be a compact connected Lie group. Then K has a complexification K → G, where G is a complex analytic group. The induced map ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(K\)\\longrightarrow \\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) is an isomorphism. The Lie algebra of G is the complexification of the Lie algebra of K. Any faithful complex representation of K can be extended to a faithful analytic complex representation of G. Any analytic representation of G is completely reducible.

Proof.

By Theorem 4.2, K has a faithful complex representation, which is unitarizable, so we may assume that K is a closed subgroup of U(n) for some n. The embedding K → U(n) is the differential of a Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq29123.gif), where ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) is the Lie algebra of K. This extends, by Proposition 11.3, to a homomorphism of complex Lie algebras ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq31123.gif), and we identify ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) with its image.

Let ![
$$P =\\{{ \\mathrm{e}}^{iX}\\vert X \\in \\mathfrak{k}\\} \\subset \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq33123.gif), and let G = PK. Let ![
$$P^{\\prime} \\subset \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) be the set of positive definite Hermitian matrices. By Theorem 13.4, the multiplication map ![
$$P^{\\prime} \\times \\mathrm{U}\(n\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq35.gif) is a homeomorphism. Moreover, the exponentiation map from the vector space of Hermitian matrices to P′ is a homeomorphism. Since ![
$$i\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq36.gif) is a closed subspace of the real vector space of Hermitian matrices, P is a closed topological subspace of P′, and G = PK is a closed subset of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) = P^{\\prime}U\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq37.gif).

We associate with each element of ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq38.gif) a left-invariant vector field on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq39.gif) and consider the resulting involutory family on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq40.gif). We will show that G is an integral submanifold of this involutory family. We must check that the left-invariant vector field associated with an element Z of ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq41.gif) is everywhere tangent to G. It is easiest to check this separately in the cases Z = Y and Z = iY with ![
$$Y \\in \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq42.gif). Near the point e iX k ∈ G, with ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq43.gif) and k ∈ K, the path t →e i(X+tAd(k)Y) k is tangent to G when t = 0 and is also tangent to the path

![
$$\\displaystyle{t\\mapsto {\\mathrm{e}}^{iX}{\\mathrm{e}}^{it\\mathrm{Ad}\(k\)Y }k ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{iX}k{\\mathrm{e}}^{itY }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_Equa.gif)

(The two paths are not identical if [X,Y ]≠0, but this is not a problem.) The latter path is the left translate by e iX k of a path through the identity tangent to the left-invariant vector field corresponding to ![
$$iY \\in \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq44.gif). Since this vector field is left invariant, this shows that it is tangent to G at e iX k. This settles the case Z = iY. The case where Z = Y is similar and easier.

It follows from Proposition 24.2 that G is a closed subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq45.gif). Since P is homeomorphic to a vector space, it is contractible, and since G is homeomorphic to P × K, it follows that the inclusion K → G induces an isomorphism of fundamental groups.

The Lie algebra of G is, by construction, ![
$$i\\mathfrak{k} + \\mathfrak{k} = \\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq46.gif).

To show that G is the complexification of K, let H be a complex analytic group and f: K → H be a Lie group homomorphism. We have an induced homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Lie}\(H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq47.gif) of Lie algebras, which induces a homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathrm{Lie}\(G\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Lie}\(H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq48.gif) of complex Lie algebras, by Proposition 11.3. If ![
$$\\tilde{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq49.gif) is the universal covering group of G, then by Proposition 14.2 we obtain a Lie group homomorphism ![
$$\\tilde{G}\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq50.gif). To show that it factors through ![
$$G\\mathop{\\cong}\\tilde{G}/\\pi _{1}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq51.gif), we must show that the composite ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G\)\\longrightarrow \\tilde{G}\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq52.gif) is trivial. But this coincides with the composition ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(G\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\pi _{1}\(K\)\\longrightarrow \\tilde{K}\\longrightarrow K\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq53.gif), where ![
$$\\tilde{K}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq54.gif) is the universal covering group of K, and the composition ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(K\)\\longrightarrow \\tilde{K}\\longrightarrow K$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq55.gif) is already trivial. Hence the map ![
$$\\tilde{G}\\longrightarrow H$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq56.gif) factors through G, proving that G has the universal property of the complexification.

We constructed G as an analytic subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq57.gif) starting with an arbitrary faithful complex representation of K. Looking at this another way, we have actually proved that any faithful complex representation of K can be extended to a faithful analytic complex representation of G. The reason is that if we started with another faithful complex representation and constructed the complexification using that one, we would have gotten a group isomorphic to G because the complexification is characterized up to isomorphism by its universal property.

It remains to be shown that analytic representations of G are completely reducible. If (π,V ) is an analytic representation of G, then, since K is compact, by Proposition 2.1 there is a K-invariant inner product on V, and if U is an invariant subspace, then V = U ⊕ W, where W is the orthogonal complement of U. Then we claim that W is G-invariant. Indeed, it is invariant under ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq58.gif) and hence under ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathfrak{k} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq59.gif), which is the Lie algebra of G and, since G is connected, under G itself. □

In addition to the analytic notion of complexification that we have already described, there is another notion, which we will call algebraic complexification. We will not need it, and the reader may skip the rest of this chapter with no loss of continuity. Still, it is instructive to consider complexification from the point of view of algebraic groups, so we digress to discuss it now. If ![
$$\\mathcal{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq60.gif) is an affine algebraic group defined over the real numbers, then ![
$$K = \\mathcal{G}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq61.gif) is a Lie group and ![
$$G = \\mathcal{G}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq62.gif) is a complex analytic group, and G is the algebraic complexification of K. We will assume that ![
$$\\mathcal{G}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq63.gif) is Zariski-dense in ![
$$\\mathcal{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq64.gif) to exclude examples such as

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{G} =\\{ \(x,y\)\\,\\vert \\,{x}^{2} + {y}^{2} = \\pm 1\\},}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_Equb.gif)

which is an algebraic group with group law ![
$$\(x,y\)\(z,w\) = \(xz - yw,xw + yz\),$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq65.gif) but which has one Zariski-connected component with no real points.

We see that the algebraic complexification is a functor not from the category of Lie groups but rather from the category of algebraic groups ![
$$\\mathcal{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq66.gif) defined over ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq67.gif). So the algebraic complexification of a Lie group K depends on more than just the isomorphism class of K as a Lie group—it also depends on its realization as the group of real points of an algebraic group. We illustrate this point with an example.

Let G a and G m be the "additive group" and the "multiplicative group." These are algebraic groups such that for any field G a(F)≅F (additive group) and G m(F)≅F ×. The groups ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{1} = G_{\\text{a}} \\times \(\\mathbb{Z}/2\\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq68.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{2} = G_{\\text{m}}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq69.gif) have isomorphic groups of real points since ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{1}\(\\mathbb{R}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{R} \\times \(\\mathbb{Z}/2\\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq70.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{2}\(\\mathbb{R}\)\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{R}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq71.gif), and these are isomorphic as Lie groups. Their complexifications are ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{C} \\times \(\\mathbb{Z}/2\\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq72.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{2}\(\\mathbb{C}\)\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq73.gif). These groups are not isomorphic.

If ![
$$\\mathcal{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq74.gif) is an algebraic group defined over ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq75.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq76.gif), and if ![
$$K = \\mathcal{G}\(F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq77.gif), then we call a complex representation ![
$$\\pi: K\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq78.gif) algebraic if there is a homomorphism of algebraic groups ![
$$\\mathcal{G}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq79.gif) defined over ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq80.gif) such that the induced map of rational points is π. (This amounts to assuming that the matrix coefficients of π are polynomial functions.) With this definition, the algebraic complexification has an interpretation in terms of representations like that of the analytic complexification.

Proposition 24.3.

If ![
$$G = \\mathcal{G}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq81.gif) is the algebraic complexification of ![
$$K = \\mathcal{G}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq82.gif) , then any algebraic complex representation of K extends uniquely to an algebraic representation of G.

Proof.

This is clear since a polynomial function extends uniquely from ![
$$\\mathcal{G}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq83.gif) to ![
$$\\mathcal{G}\(\\mathbb{C}\).$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq84.gif) □

If K is a field and L is a Galois extension, we say that algebraic groups ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq85.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq86.gif) defined over K are L∕K-Galois forms of each other—or (more succinctly) L∕K-forms—if there is an isomorphism ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{1}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathcal{G}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq87.gif) defined over L. If ![
$$K = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq88.gif) and ![
$$L = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq89.gif) this means that ![
$$K_{1} = \\mathcal{G}_{1}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq90.gif) and ![
$$K_{2} = \\mathcal{G}_{2}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq91.gif) have isomorphic algebraic complexifications. A ![
$$\\mathbb{C}/\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq92.gif)-Galois form is called a real form.

The example in Proposition 24.4 will help to clarify this concept.

Proposition 24.4.

U (n) is a real form of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq93.gif) .

Compare this with Proposition 11.4, which is the Lie algebra analog of this statement.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq94.gif) be the algebraic group GL(n), and let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{G}_{2} =\\{ \(A,B\) \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n} \\times \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\\,\\vert \\,A {\\cdot }^{t}A + B {\\cdot }^{t}B = I,\\;A {\\cdot }^{t}B = B {\\cdot }^{t}A\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_Equc.gif)

The group law for G 2 is given by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(A,B\)\(C,D\) = \(AC - BD,AD + BC\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_Equd.gif)

We leave it to the reader to check that this is a group. This definition is constructed so that ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{2}\(\\mathbb{R}\) = \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq95.gif) under the map (A,B)→ A \+ Bi, when A and B are real matrices.

We show that ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{2}\(\\mathbb{C}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq96.gif)). Specifically, we show that if ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq97.gif) then there are unique matrices ![
$$\(A,B\) \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq98.gif) such that ![
$$A {\\cdot }^{t}A + B {\\cdot }^{t}B = I$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq99.gif) and ![
$$A {\\cdot }^{t}B = B {\\cdot }^{t}A$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq100.gif) with ![
$$A + Bi = g$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq101.gif). We consider uniqueness first. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(A + Bi\){\(}^{t}A {-}^{t}Bi\) = \({A\\,}^{t}A + {B\\,}^{t}B\) + \({B}^{t}A - {A}^{t}B\)i = I,}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_Eque.gif)

so we must have ![
$${g}^{-1} {= }^{t}A {-}^{t}Bi$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq102.gif) and thus ![
$${}^{t}{g}^{-1} = A - Bi$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq103.gif). We may now solve for A and B and obtain

![
$$\\displaystyle{A = \\tfrac{1} {2}\(g {+ }^{t}{g}^{-1}\),\\qquad B = \\tfrac{1} {2i}\(g {-}^{t}{g}^{-1}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(24.1)

This proves uniqueness. Moreover, if we define A and B by (24.1), then it is easy to see that ![
$$\(A,B\) \\in G_{2}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq104.gif) and ![
$$A + Bi = g$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq105.gif). □

It can be seen similarly that SU(n) and ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq106.gif) are ![
$$\\mathbb{C}/\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq107.gif) Galois forms of each other. One has only to impose in the definition of the second group G 2 an additional polynomial relation corresponding to the condition ![
$$\\det \(A + Bi\) = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq108.gif). (This condition, written out in terms of matrix entries, will not involve i, so the resulting algebraic group is defined over ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq109.gif).)

Remark 24.1.

Classification of Galois forms of a group is a problem in Galois cohomology. Indeed, the set of Galois forms of ![
$$\\mathcal{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq110.gif) is parametrized by ![
$${H}^{1}\(\\mathrm{Gal}\(L/K\),\\mathrm{Aut}\(\\mathcal{G}\)\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq111.gif). See Springer [150], Satake [144] and III.1 of Serre [148]. Tits [162] contains the definitive classification over real, p-adic, finite, and number fields.

Galois forms are important because if G 1 and G 2 are Galois forms of each other, then we expect the representation theories of G 1 and G 2 to be related. We have already seen this principle applied (for example) in Theorem 14.3. Our next proposition gives a typical application.

Proposition 24.5.

Let ![
$$\\pi: \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(m, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq112.gif) be an algebraic representation. Then π is completely reducible.

This would not be true if we removed the assumption of algebraicity. For example, the representation ![
$$\\pi: \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq113.gif) defined by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi \(g\) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 1&\\log \\vert \\det \(g\)\\vert \\\\ & 1 \\end{array} \\right \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_Equf.gif)

is not completely reducible—and it is not algebraic.

Proof.

Any irreducible algebraic representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq114.gif) can be extended to an algebraic representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq115.gif) and then restricted to U(n), where it is completely reducible because U(n) is compact. □

The irreducible algebraic complex representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq116.gif) are the same as the irreducible algebraic complex representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq117.gif), which in turn are the same as the irreducible complex representations of U(n). (The latter are automatically algebraic, and indeed we will later construct them as algebraic representations.)

These finite-dimensional representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq118.gif) may be parametrized by their highest weight vectors and classified as in the previous chapter. Their characters are given by the Weyl character formula.

Although the irreducible algebraic complex representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq119.gif) are thus the same as the irreducible representations of the compact group U(n), their significance is very different. These finite-dimensional representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq120.gif) are not unitary (except for the one-dimensional ones). They therefore do not appear in the Fourier inversion formula (Plancherel theorem). Unlike U(n), the noncompact group ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_24_Chapter_IEq121.gif) has unitary representations that are infinite-dimensional, and it is these infinite-dimensional representations that appear in the Plancherel theorem.

# 25. Coxeter Groups

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

As we will see in this chapter, Weyl groups and affine Weyl groups are examples of Coxeter groups, an important family of groups generated by "reflections."

As we will see in this chapter, Weyl groups and affine Weyl groups are examples of Coxeter groups, an important family of groups generated by "reflections."

Let G be a group, and let I be a set of generators of G, each of which has order 2. In practice, we will usually denote the elements of I by {s 1, s 2,..., s r } or {s 0,..., s r } with some definite indexing by integers. If s i , s j ∈ I, let n(i, j) = n(s i , s j ) be the order of s i s j . [Strictly speaking we should write n(s i , s j ) but prefer less uncluttered notation.] We assume n(i, j) to be finite for all s i , s j . The pair (G, I) is called a Coxeter group if the relations

![
$$\\displaystyle{ s_{i}^{2} = 1,\\qquad {\(s_{ i}s_{j}\)}^{n\(i, j\)} = 1 }$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(25.1)

are a presentation of G. This means that G is isomorphic to the quotient of the free group on a set of generators {σ i }, one for each s i ∈ I, by the smallest normal subgroup containing all elements

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sigma _{i}^{2},\\qquad {\(\\sigma _{ i}\\sigma _{j}\)}^{n\(i, j\)},}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equa.gif)

and in this isomorphism each generator σ i ↦ s i . Equivalently, G has the following universal property: if Γ is any other group having elements v i (one for each generator s i ) satisfying the same relations (25.1), that is, if

![
$$\\displaystyle{v_{i}^{2} = 1,\\qquad {\(v_{ i}v_{j}\)}^{n\(i, j\)} = 1,}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equb.gif)

then there exists a unique homomorphism G →Γ such that each s i → v i .

A word representing an element w of a Coxeter group (W, I) is a sequence ![
$$\(s_{i_{1}},\\ldots, s_{i_{k}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq1.gif) such that ![
$$w = s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq2.gif). The word is reduced if k is as small as possible. Thus, if the Coxeter group is a Weyl group and I the set of simple reflections, then k is the length of w. Less formally, we may abuse language by saying that ![
$$w = s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq3.gif) is a reduced word or reduced decomposition of w.

We return to the context of Chap.​ 20. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq4.gif) be a vector space, Φ a reduced root system in ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq5.gif), and W the Weyl group. We partition Φ into positive and negative roots and denote by Σ the simple positive roots. Let I ={ s 1,..., s r } be of simple reflections. By definition, W is generated by the set I. Let n(i, j) denote the order of s i s j . We will show that (W, I) is a Coxeter group. It is evident that the relations (25.1) are satisfied, but we need to see that they give a presentation of W.

Theorem 25.1.

Let W be the Weyl group of the root system Φ, and let I ={ s 1 ,...,s r } be the simple reflections. Then (W,I) is a Coxeter group.

We will give a geometric proof of this fact, making use of the system of Weyl chambers. As it turns out, every Coxeter group has a geometric action on a simplicial complex, a Coxeter complex, which for Weyl groups is closely related to the action on Weyl chambers. This point of view leads to the theory of buildings. See Tits [163] and Abramenko and Brown [1] as well as Bourbaki [23].

Proof.

Let (W′,I′) be the Coxeter group with generators {s 1′,..., s j ′} and the relations (25.1) where n(i, j) is the order of s i s j . Since the relations (25.1) are true in W we have a surjective homomorphism W′→ W sending s i ′ ↦ s i . We must show that it is injective. Let ![
$$s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{n}} = s_{j_{1}}\\cdots s_{j_{m}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq6.gif) be two decompositions of the same element w into products of simple reflections. We will show that we may go from one word ![
$$\\mathfrak{w} = \\left \(s_{i_{1}},\\ldots, s_{i_{n}}\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq7.gif) to the other ![
$$\\mathfrak{w} = \\left \(s_{j_{1}},\\ldots, s_{j_{m}}\\right \),$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq8.gif) only making changes corresponding to relations in the Coxeter group presentation. That is, we may insert or remove a pair of adjacent equal s i , or we may replace a segment s i , s j , s i ,... by s j , s i , s j ,... where the total number of s i and s j is each the order of 2n(s i , s j ). This will show that ![
$$s_{i_{1}}^{\\prime}\\cdots s^{\\prime}_{i_{n}} = s^{\\prime}_{j_{1}}\\cdots s^{\\prime}_{j_{m}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq9.gif) so the homomorphism W′→ W is indeed injective.

Let ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq10.gif) be the positive Weyl chamber. We have ![
$$s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{n}}\\mathcal{C} = s_{j_{1}}\\cdots s_{j_{m}}\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq11.gif). Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{w_{1} = s_{i_{1}},\\;w_{2} = s_{i_{1}}s_{i_{2}},\\;\\cdots \\;w_{n} = s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{n}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equc.gif)

The sequence of chambers

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathcal{C},w_{1}\\mathcal{C},w_{2}\\mathcal{C},\\ldots, w_{n}\\mathcal{C} = w\\mathcal{C} }$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(25.2)

are adjacent. We will say that ![
$$\\left \(\\mathcal{C},w_{1}\\mathcal{C},w_{2},\\ldots, w\\mathcal{C}\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq12.gif) is the gallery associated with the word ![
$$\\mathfrak{w} = \\left \(s_{i_{1}},\\ldots, s_{i_{k}}\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq13.gif) representing w. We find a path p from a point in the interior of ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq14.gif) to ![
$$w\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq15.gif) passing exactly through this sequence of chambers.

Similarly we have a gallery associated with the word ![
$$\\left \(s_{j_{1}},\\ldots, s_{j_{m}}\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq16.gif). We may similarly consider a path q from ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq17.gif) to ![
$$w\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq18.gif) having the same endpoints as p passing through the chambers of this gallery. We will consider what happens when we deform p to q.

If α ∈Φ let ℌ α be the set of ![
$$v \\in \\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq19.gif) such that α∨(v) = 0. This is the hyperplane perpendicular to the root α, and these hyperplanes are the walls of Weyl chambers. Let K 2 be the closed subset of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq20.gif) where two or more hyperplanes ℌ α intersect. It is a subset of codimension 2, that is, it is a (locally) finite union of codimension 2 linear subspaces of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq21.gif). Let K 3 be the closed subset of ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq22.gif) consisting of points P such that three hyperplanes ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha _{1}},\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha _{2}},\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha _{3}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq23.gif) pass through ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq24.gif), with the roots α1,α2 and α3 linearly independent. The subset K is of codimension 3 in ![
$$\\mathcal{V}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq25.gif). We have K 2 ⊃ K 3. The paths p and q do not pass through K 2.

Since K 3 has codimension 3 it is possible to deform p to q avoiding K 3. Let p u with u ∈ 0,1 be such a deformation, with p 0 = p and p 1 = p′. For each u the sequence of chambers through which p u form the gallery associated to some word representing w. We consider what happens to this word when the gallery changes as u is varied.

There are two ways the word can change. If i k = i k+1 then w k−1 = w k+1 and we have a crossing as in Fig. 25.1. The path may move to eliminate (or create) the crossing. This corresponds to eliminating (or inserting) a repeated ![
$$s_{i_{k}} = s_{i_{k+1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) from the word, and since ![
$$s_{i_{k}}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) has order 2 in the Coxeter group, the corresponding elements of the Coxeter group will be the same.

Fig. 25.1

Eliminating a crossing and recrossing of the same wall

Since the deformation avoids K 3, the only other way that the word can change is if the deformation causes the path to cross K 2, that is, some point where two or more hyperplanes ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha _{1}},\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha _{2}},\\ldots,\\mathfrak{H}_{\\alpha _{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) intersect, with the roots α1,...,α n in a two-dimensional subspace. In this case the transition looks like Fig. 25.2.

Fig. 25.2

Crossing K 2

This can happen if i k = i k+2 = ⋯ = i and i k+1 = i k+3 = ⋯ = j, and the effect of the crossing is to replace a subword of the form (s i , s j , s i ,...) by an equivalent (s j , s i , s j ,...), where the total number of s i and s j is 2n(s i , s j ). We have s i ′s j ′s i ′⋯ = s j ′s i ′s j ′⋯ in W′, so this type of transition also does not change the element of W′. We see that ![
$$s_{i_{1}}^{\\prime}\\cdots s^{\\prime}_{i_{n}} = s^{\\prime}_{j_{1}}\\cdots s^{\\prime}_{j_{m}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq29123.gif), proving that W ≅ W′. This concludes the proof that W is a Coxeter group. □

The Coxeter group (W, I) has a close relative called the associated braid group. We note that in the Coxeter group (W, I) with generators s i satisfying s i 2 = 1, the relation (s i s j ) n(i, j) = 1 (true when i ≠ j) can be written

![
$$\\displaystyle{ s_{i}s_{j}s_{i}\\cdots = s_{j}s_{i}s_{j}\\cdots \\,, }$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(25.3)

where the number of factors on both sides is n(i, j). Written this way, we call equation (25.3) the braid relation.

Now let us consider a group B with generators u i in bijection with the s i that are assumed to satisfy the braid relations but are not assumed to be of order two. Thus,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ u_{i}u_{j}u_{i}u_{j}\\cdots = u_{j}u_{i}u_{j}u_{i}\\cdots \\;, }$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(25.4)

where there are n(i, j) terms on both sides. Note that since the relation s i 2 = 1 is not true for the u i , it is not true that n(i, j) is the order of u i u j , and in fact u i u j has infinite order. The group B is called the braid group.

The term braid group is used due to the fact that the braid group of type A n is Artin's original braid group, which is a fundamental object in knot theory. Although Artin's braid group will not play any role in this book, abstract braid groups will play a role in our discussion of Hecke algebras in Chap.​ 46, and the relationship between Weyl groups and braid groups underlies many unexpected developments beginning with the use by Jones [91] of Hecke algebras in defining new knot invariants and continuing with the work of Reshetikhin and Turaev [135] based on the Yang–Baxter equation, with connections to quantum groups and applications to knot and ribbon invariants.

Consider a set of paths represented by a set of n \+ 1 nonintersecting strings connected to two (infinite) parallel posts in ℝ3 to be a braid. Braids are equivalent if they are homotopic. The "multiplication" in the braid group is concatenation: to multiply two braids, the endpoints of the first braid on the right post are tied to the endpoints of the second braid on the left post. In Fig. 25.3, we give generators u 1 and u 2 for the braid group of type A 2 and calculate their product. In Fig. 25.4, we consider u 1 u 2 u 1 and u 2 u 1 u 2; clearly these two braids are homotopic, so the braid relation u 1 u 2 u 1 = u 2 u 1 u 2 is satisfied.

Fig. 25.3

Generators u 1 and u 2 of the braid group of type A 2 and u 1 u 2

We did not have to make the map n part of the defining data in the Coxeter group since n(i, j) is just the order of s i s j . This is no longer true in the braid group. Coxeter groups are often finite, but the braid group (B, I) is infinite if |I| > 1.

Theorem 25.1 has an important complement due to Matsumoto [127] and (independently) by Tits. According to this result, if two reduced words represent the same element, then the corresponding elements represented by the same reduced words are equal in the braid group. (This is true for arbitrary Coxeter groups, but we will only prove it for Weyl groups and affine Weyl groups.) Both Theorem 25.1 and Matsumoto's theorem may be given proofs based on Proposition 20.7, and these may be found in Bourbaki [23]. We will give another geometric proof of Matsumoto's theorem based on ideas similar to those in the above proof of Theorem 25.1.

Theorem 25.2 (Matsumoto, Tits).

Let w ∈ W have length l(w) = r. Let ![
$$s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{r}} = s_{j_{1}}\\cdots s_{j_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) be two reduced decompositions of w into products of simple reflections. Then the corresponding words are equal in the braid group, that is, ![
$$u_{i_{1}}\\cdots u_{i_{r}} = u_{j_{1}}\\cdots u_{j_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq31123.gif) .

What we will actually prove is that if w of length k has two reduced decompositions ![
$$w = s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{k}} = s_{j_{1}}\\cdots s_{j_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq32123.gif), then the word ![
$$\(s_{i_{1}},\\ldots, s_{i_{k}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) may be transformed into ![
$$\(s_{j_{1}},\\ldots, s_{j_{k}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) by a series of substitutions, in which a subword (s i , s j , s i ,...) is changed to (s j , s i , s j ,...), both subwords having n(i, j) elements. For example, in the A 3 Weyl group, two words representing the long Weyl group element w 0 are s 1 s 2 s 1 s 3 s 2 s 1 and s 3 s 2 s 3 s 1 s 2 s 3. We may transform the first into the second by the following series of substitutions:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(121321\) \\leftrightarrow \(212321\) \\leftrightarrow \(213231\) \\leftrightarrow \(231213\) \\leftrightarrow \(232123\) \\leftrightarrow \(323123\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equd.gif)

Proof.

We associate with a word a gallery and a path as in the proof of Theorem 25.1. Of the hyperplanes ℌ α perpendicular to the roots, let ℌ 1⋯ℌ r be the ones separating ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq35.gif) and ![
$$w\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq36.gif). Since any path from ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq37.gif) to ![
$$w\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq38.gif) must cross these hyperplanes, the word associated with the path will be reduced if and only if it does not cross any one of these hyperplanes more than once. The paths p and q corresponding to the given reduced words thus have this property, and as in the proof of Theorem 25.1 it is easy to see that we may choose the deformation p u from p to q that avoids K 3, such that p u does not cross any of these hyperplanes more than once for any u.

Thus the sequence of words corresponding to the stages of p u are all reduced words, and it is easy to see that this implies that the only transitions allowed are ones implied by the braid relations. Therefore ![
$$u_{i_{1}}\\cdots u_{i_{r}} = u_{j_{1}}\\cdots u_{j_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq39.gif). □

As a typical example of how the theorem of Matsumoto and Tits is used, let us define the divided difference operators D i on ℰ. They were introduced by Lascoux and Schutzenberger, and independently by Bernstein, Gelfand, and Gelfand, in the cohomology of flag varieties. The divided difference operators are sometimes denoted ∂ i , but we will reserve that notation for the Demazure operators we will introduce below. D i acts on the group algebra of the weight lattice Λ; this algebra was denoted ℰ in Chap.​ 22. It has a basis eλ indexed by weights λ ∈Λ. We define

![
$$\\displaystyle{D_{i}f ={ \\left \({\\mathrm{e}}^{\\alpha _{i} } - 1\\right \)}^{-1}\\left \(f - s_{ i}f\\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Eque.gif)

It is easy to check that f − s i f is divisible in ℰ by ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{\\alpha _{i}} - 1$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq40.gif), so this operator maps ℰ to itself.

More formally, let ![
$$\\mathfrak{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq41.gif) be the localization of ℰ that is the subring of its field of fractions obtained by adjoining denominators of the form H(α) = eα − 1−1 with α ∈Φ. It is convenient to think of the D i as living in the ring ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq42.gif) of expressions of the form ∑ f w ⋅ w where ![
$$f_{w} \\in \\mathfrak{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq43.gif), and the sum is over w ∈ W. We have wfw −1 = w(f), that is, conjugation by a Weyl group element is the same as applying it to the element f of ![
$$\\mathfrak{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq44.gif). We have an obvious action of ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq45.gif) on ![
$$\\mathfrak{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq46.gif), and in this notation we write

![
$$\\displaystyle{D_{i} ={ \\left \({\\mathrm{e}}^{\\alpha _{i} } - 1\\right \)}^{-1}\\left \(1 - s_{ i}\\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Because ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{\\alpha _{i}} - 1$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq47.gif) divides f − s i f for f ∈ℰ, the operators D i act on ℰ.

Let n(i, j) be the order of s i s j in W, where i ≠ j. Then the D i satisfy the braid relation

Now we may give the first application of the theorem of Matsumoto and Tits. We may define, for w ∈ W an operator D w to be ![
$$D_{i_{1}}D_{i_{2}}\\cdots D_{i_{k}}$$

Theorem 25.4.

The affine Weyl group is also a Coxeter group (generated by s 0 ,...,s r ). Moreover, the analog of the Matsumoto-Tits theorem is true for the affine Weyl group: if w of length k has two reduced decompositions ![
$$w = s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{k}} = s_{j_{1}}\\cdots s_{j_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq77.gif) , then the word ![
$$\(s_{i_{1}},\\ldots, s_{i_{k}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq78.gif) may be transformed into ![
$$\(s_{j_{1}},\\ldots, s_{j_{k}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq79.gif) by a series of substitutions, in which a subword (s i , s j , s i ,...) is changed to (s j , s i , s j ,...), both subwords having n(i, j) elements.

Proof.

This may be proved by the same method as Theorem 25.1 and 25.2 (Exercise 25.3). □

As a last application of the theorem of Matsumoto and Tits, we discuss the Bruhat order on the Weyl group, which we will meet again in Chap.​ 27. This is a partial order, with the long Weyl group element maximal and the identity element minimal. If v and u are elements of the Weyl group W, then we write u ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq555.gif) v if, given a reduced decomposition ![
$$v = s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq80.gif) then there exists a subsequence (j 1,..., j l ) of (i 1,..., i k ) such that ![
$$u = s_{j_{1}}\\cdots s_{j_{l}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq81.gif). By Proposition 20.4 we may assume that ![
$$u = s_{j_{1}}\\cdots s_{j_{l}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq82.gif) is a reduced decomposition.

Proposition 25.4.

This definition does not depend on the reduced decomposition ![
$$v = s_{i_{1}}\\cdots s_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq83.gif).

Proof.

By Theorem 25.2 it is sufficient to check that if (i 1,..., i k ) is changed by a braid relation, then we can still find a subsequence (j 1,..., j l ) representing u. We therefore find a subsequence of the form (t, u, t,...) where the number of elements is the order of s t s u , and we replace this by (u, t, u,...). We divide the subsequence (j 1,..., j l ) into three parts: the portion extracted from that part of (i 1,..., i k ) before the changed subsequence, the portion extracted from the changed subsequence, and the portion extracted from after the changed subsequence. The first and last part do not need to be altered. A subsequence can be extracted from the portion in the middle to represent any element of the dihedral group generated by s t and s u whether it is (t, u, t,...) or (u, t, u,...), so changing this portion has no effect. □

We now describe (without proof) the classification of the possible reduced root systems and their associated finite Coxeter groups. See Bourbaki [23] for proofs. If Φ 1 and Φ 2 are root systems in vector spaces ![
$$\\mathcal{V}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq84.gif), ![
$$\\mathcal{V}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq85.gif), then Φ 1 ∪Φ 2 is a root system in ![
$$\\mathcal{V}_{1} \\oplus \\mathcal{V}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq86.gif). Such a root system is called reducible. Naturally, it is enough to classify the irreducible root systems.

The Dynkin diagram represents the Coxeter group in compact form. It is a graph whose vertices are in bijection with Σ. Let us label Σ ={ α1,...,α r }, and let ![
$$s_{i} = s_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_IEq87.gif). Let θ(α i ,α j ) be the angle between the roots α i and α j . Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{n\(s_{i},s_{j}\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cc} 2& \\mbox{ if $\\theta \(\\alpha _{i},\\alpha _{j}\) = \\frac{\\pi } {2} $,}\\\\ & \\\\ 3& \\mbox{ if $\\theta \(\\alpha _{i},\\alpha _{j}\) = \\frac{2\\pi } {3} $,}\\\\ & \\\\ 4& \\mbox{ if $\\theta \(\\alpha _{i},\\alpha _{j}\) = \\frac{3\\pi } {4} $,}\\\\ & \\\\ 6&\\mbox{ if $\\theta \(\\alpha _{i},\\alpha _{j}\) = \\frac{5\\pi } {6} $.} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_25_Chapter_Equq.gif)

These four cases arise in the rank 2 root systems A 1 × A 1, A 2, B 2 and G 2, as the reader may confirm by consulting the figures in Chap.​ 19.

In the Dynkin diagram, we connect the vertices corresponding to α i and α j only if the roots are not orthogonal. If they make an angle of 2π∕3, we connect them with a single bond; if they make an angle of 6π∕4, we connect them with a double bond; and if they make an angle of 5π∕6, we connect them with a triple bond. The latter case only arises with the exceptional group G 2.

If α i and α j make an angle of 3π∕4 or 5π∕6, then these two roots have different lengths; see Figs. 19.4 and 19.6. In the Dynkin diagram, there will be a double or triple bond in these examples, and we draw an arrow from the long root to the short root. The triple bond (corresponding to an angle of 5π∕6) is rare—it is only found in the Dynkin diagram of a single group, the exceptional group G 2. If there are no double or triple bonds, the Dynkin diagram is called simply laced.

The root system of type A n is associated with the Lie group SU(n \+ 1). The corresponding abstract root system is described in Chap.​ 19. All roots have the same length, so the Dynkin diagram is simply laced. In Fig. 25.5 we illustrate the Dynkin diagram when n = 5. The case of general n is the same—exactly n nodes strung together in a line (•​—​​•​​—⋯—​•).

Fig. 25.4

The braid relation. Left: u 1 u 2 u 1. Right: u 2 u 1 u 2

Fig. 25.5

The Dynkin diagram for the type A 5 root system

The root system of type B n is associated with the odd orthogonal group SO(2n \+ 1). The corresponding abstract root system is described in Chap.​ 19. There are both long and short roots, so the Dynkin diagram is not simply laced. See Fig. 25.6 for the Dynkin diagram of type B 5. The general case is the same (•​—​​•​​—⋯—•​​​ =​​​>​​​=​​​ •), with the arrow pointing towards the α n node corresponding to the unique short simple root.

Fig. 25.6

The Dynkin diagram for the type B 5 root system

Fig. 25.7

The Dynkin diagram for the type C 5 root system

The root system of type C n is associated with the symplectic group Sp(2n). The corresponding abstract root system is described in Chap.​ 19. There are both long and short roots, so the Dynkin diagram is not simply laced. See Fig. 25.7 for the Dynkin diagram of type C 5. The general case is the same (•​—​​•​​—⋯—•​​​ =​​​<​​​=​​​ •), with the arrow pointing from the α n node corresponding to the unique long simple root, towards α n−1.

Fig. 25.8

The Dynkin diagram for the type D 6 root system

The root system of type D n is associated with the even orthogonal group O(2n). All roots have the same length, so the Dynkin diagram is simply-laced. See Fig. 25.8 for the Dynkin diagram of type D 6. The general case is similar, but the cases n = 2 or n = 3 are degenerate, and coincide with the root systems A 1 × A 1 and A 3. For this reason, the family D n is usually considered to begin with n = 4. See Fig. 30.​2 and the discussion in Chap.​ 30 for further information about these degenerate cases.

These are the "classical" root systems, which come in infinite families. There are also five exceptional root systems, denoted E 6, E 7, E 8, F 4 and G 2. Their Dynkin diagrams are illustrated in Figs. 25.9–25.12.

Fig. 25.10

Fig. 25.11

The Dynkin diagram for the type E 8 root system

Fig. 25.12
