# 26. The Borel Subgroup

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

The Borel subgroup B of a (noncompact) Lie group G is a maximal closed and connected solvable subgroup. We will give several applications of the Borel subgroup in this chapter and the next. In this chapter, we will begin with the Iwasawa decomposition, an important decomposition involving the Borel subgroup. We will also show how invariant vectors with respect to the Borel subgroup give a convenient method of decomposing a representation into irreducibles. We will restrict ourselves here to complex analytic groups such as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq1.gif) obtained by complexifying a compact Lie group. A more general Iwasawa decomposition will be found later in Chap.​ 29.

The Borel subgroup B of a (noncompact) Lie group G is a maximal closed and connected solvable subgroup. We will give several applications of the Borel subgroup in this chapter and the next. In this chapter, we will begin with the Iwasawa decomposition, an important decomposition involving the Borel subgroup. We will also show how invariant vectors with respect to the Borel subgroup give a convenient method of decomposing a representation into irreducibles. We will restrict ourselves here to complex analytic groups such as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq2.gif) obtained by complexifying a compact Lie group. A more general Iwasawa decomposition will be found later in Chap.​ 29.

Let us begin with an example. Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq3.gif). It is the complexification of K = U(n), which is a maximal compact subgroup. Let T be the maximal torus of K consisting of diagonal matrices with eigenvalues that have absolute value 1. The complexification ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq4.gif) of T can be factored as TA, where A is the group of diagonal matrices with eigenvalues that are positive real numbers. Let B be the group of upper triangular matrices in G, and let B 0 be the subgroup of elements of B whose diagonal entries are positive real numbers. Finally, let N be the subgroup of unipotent elements of B. Recalling that a matrix is called unipotent if its only eigenvalue is 1, the elements of N are upper triangular matrices with diagonal entries that are all equal to 1. We may factor B = TN and B 0 = AN. The subgroup N is normal in B and B 0, so these decompositions are semidirect products.

Proposition 26.1.

With ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq5.gif) , K = U(n), and B 0 as above, every element of g ∈ G can be factored uniquely as bk where b ∈ B 0 and k ∈ K, or as aνk, where a ∈ A, ν ∈ N, and k ∈ K. The multiplication maps N × A × K → G and A × N × K → G are diffeomorphisms.

Proof.

First let us consider N × A × K → G. Let g ∈ G. Let ![
$$v_{1},\\ldots,v_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq6.gif) be the rows of g. Then by the Gram–Schmidt orthogonalization algorithm, we find constants θ ij (i < j) such that v n , ![
$$v_{n-1} + \\theta _{n-1,n}v_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq7.gif), ![
$$v_{n-2} + \\theta _{n-2,n-1}v_{n-1} + \\theta _{n-2,n}v_{n},\\ldots$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq8.gif) are orthogonal. Call these vectors ![
$$u_{n},\\ldots,u_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq9.gif), and let

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\nu }^{-1} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} 1&\\theta _{12} & \\cdots &\\theta _{1n} \\\\ & 1 & &\\theta _{2n}\\\\ & & \\ddots & \\vdots \\\\ & & & 1 \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equa.gif)

so ![
$$u_{1},\\ldots,u_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq10.gif) are the rows of ν−1 g. Let a be the diagonal matrix with diagonal entries ![
$$\\vert u_{1}\\vert,\\ldots,\\vert u_{n}\\vert $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq11.gif). Then ![
$$k = {a}^{-1}{\\nu }^{-1}g$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq12.gif) has orthonormal rows, and so g = νak = b 0 k is unitary with b 0 = νa. This proves that the multiplication map N × A × K → G is surjective. It follows from the facts that ![
$$B_{0} \\cap K =\\{ 1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq13.gif) and that ![
$$A \\cap N =\\{ 1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq14.gif) that it is injective. It is easy to see that the matrices a,ν, and k depend continuously on g, so the multiplication map A × N × K → G has a continuous inverse and hence is a diffeomorphism.

As for the map A × N × K → G, this is the composition of the first map with a bijection A × N × K → N × A × K, in which (a, n, k) ↦ (n′, a, k) if an = n′a. The latter map is also a diffeomorphism, and the conclusion is proved. □

The decomposition G ≅ A × N × K is called the Iwasawa decomposition of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq15.gif).

To give another example, if ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq16.gif), one takes K = O(n) to be a maximal compact subgroup, A is the same group of diagonal real matrices with positive eigenvalues as in the complex case, and N is the group of upper triangular unipotent real matrices. Again there is an Iwasawa decomposition, and one may prove it by the Gram–Schmidt orthogonalization process.

In this section, we will prove an Iwasawa decomposition if G is a complex Lie group that is the complexification of a compact connected Lie group K. This result contains the first example of ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq17.gif), though not the second example of ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq18.gif). A more general Iwasawa decomposition containing both examples will be obtained in Theorem 29.2.

We say that a Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq19.gif) is nilpotent if there exists a finite chain of ideals

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{n} = \\mathfrak{n}_{1} \\supset \\mathfrak{n}_{2} \\supset \\cdots \\supset \\mathfrak{n}_{N} =\\{ 0\\}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equb.gif)

such that ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{n},\\mathfrak{n}_{k}\] \\subseteq \\mathfrak{n}_{k+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq20.gif).

Example 26.1.

Let F be a field, and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq21.gif) be the Lie algebra over F consisting of upper triangular nilpotent matrices in GL(n, F). Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{n}_{k} =\\{ g \\in \\mathfrak{n}\\vert \\mbox{ $g_{ij} = 0$ if $j < i + k$}\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equc.gif)

For example, if n = 3,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{n} = \\mathfrak{n}_{1} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} 0&{\\ast}&{\\ast}\\\\ 0 &0 &{\\ast} \\\\ 0&0&0 \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},\\mathfrak{n}_{2} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} 0&0&{\\ast}\\\\ 0 &0 &0 \\\\ 0&0&0 \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},\\mathfrak{n}_{3} =\\{ 0\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equd.gif)

This Lie algebra is nilpotent.

We also say that a Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq22.gif) is solvable if there exists a finite chain of Lie subalgebras

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathfrak{b} = \\mathfrak{b}_{1} \\supset \\mathfrak{b}_{2} \\supset \\cdots \\supset \\mathfrak{b}_{N} =\\{ 0\\} }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(26.1)

such that ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{b}_{i},\\mathfrak{b}_{i}\] \\subseteq \\mathfrak{b}_{i+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq23.gif). It is not necessarily true that ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq24.gif) is an ideal in ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq25.gif). However, the assumption that ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{b}_{i},\\mathfrak{b}_{i}\] \\subseteq \\mathfrak{b}_{i+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) obviously implies that ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{b}_{i},\\mathfrak{b}_{i+1}\] \\subseteq \\mathfrak{b}_{i+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq27123.gif), so ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}_{i+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) is an ideal in ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq29123.gif).

Clearly, a nilpotent Lie algebra is solvable. The converse is not true, as the next example shows.

Example 26.2.

Let F be a field, and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq30132.gif) be the Lie algebra over F consisting of all upper triangular matrices in GL(n, F). Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{b}_{k} =\\{ g \\in \\mathfrak{b}\\vert \\mbox{ $g_{ij} = 0$ if $j < i + k - 1$}\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Eque.gif)

Thus, if n = 3,

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & \\mathfrak{b} = \\mathfrak{b}_{1} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} {\\ast}&{\\ast}&{\\ast}\\\\ 0 &{\\ast} &{\\ast} \\\\ 0&0&{\\ast} \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},& \\mathfrak{b}_{2} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} 0&{\\ast}&{\\ast}\\\\ 0 &0 &{\\ast} \\\\ 0&0&0 \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},\\\\ & \\quad\\quad \\mathfrak{b}_{3} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} 0&0&{\\ast}\\\\ 0 &0 &0 \\\\ 0&0&0 \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\}, & \\mathfrak{b}_{4} =\\{ 0\\}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

This Lie algebra is solvable. It is not nilpotent.

Proposition 26.2.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq31123.gif) be a Lie algebra, ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) an ideal of ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) , and ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime\\prime} = \\mathfrak{b}/\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq341232.gif) . Then ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq35.gif) is solvable if and only if ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq36.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq37.gif) are both solvable.

Proof.

Given a chain of Lie subalgebras (26.1) satisfying ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{b}_{i},\\mathfrak{b}_{i}\] \\subset \\mathfrak{b}_{i+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq38.gif), one may intersect them with ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq39.gif) or consider their images in ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq40.gif) and obtain corresponding chains in ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq41.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq42.gif) showing that these are solvable.

Conversely, suppose that ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq43.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq44.gif) are both solvable. Then there are chains

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime} = \\mathfrak{b}_{1}^{\\prime} \\supset \\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}_{2} \\supset \\cdots \\supset \\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}_{M} =\\{ 0\\},\\quad \\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime\\prime} = \\mathfrak{b}_{1}^{\\prime\\prime} \\supset \\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime\\prime}_{2} \\supset \\cdots \\supset \\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime\\prime}_{N} =\\{ 0\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq45.gif) be the preimage of ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}_{i}^{\\prime\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq46.gif) in ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq47.gif). Splicing the two chains in ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq48.gif) as

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{b} = \\mathfrak{b}_{1} \\supset \\mathfrak{b}_{2} \\supset \\cdots \\supset \\mathfrak{b}_{N} = \\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime} = \\mathfrak{b}_{1}^{\\prime} \\supset \\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}_{2} \\supset \\cdots \\supset \\mathfrak{b}^{\\prime}_{M} =\\{ 0\\}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equg.gif)

shows that ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq49.gif) is solvable. □

Proposition 26.3. (Dynkin)

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} \\subset \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq50.gif) be a Lie algebra of linear transformations over a field F of characteristic zero, and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq51.gif) be an ideal of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq52.gif) . Let ![
$$\\lambda\\,: \\mathfrak{h}\\longrightarrow F$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq53.gif) be a linear form. Then the space

![
$$\\displaystyle{W =\\{ v \\in V \\vert \\mbox{ $Y v = \\lambda \(Y \)v$ for all $Y \\in \\mathfrak{h}$}\\}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equh.gif)

is invariant under all of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq54.gif) .

Proof.

If W = 0, there is nothing to prove, so assume 0 ≠ v 0 ∈ W. Fix an element ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq55.gif). Let W 0 be the linear span of ![
$$v_{0},Xv_{0},{X}^{2}v_{0},\\ldots$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq56.gif), and let d be the dimension of W 0.

If ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq57.gif), then we will prove that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mbox{ $Z\(W_{0}\) \\subseteq W_{0}$ and the trace of $Z$ on $W_{0}$ is $\\dim \(W_{0}\) \\cdot \\lambda \(Z\)$}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(26.2)

To prove this, note that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ v_{0},Xv_{0},{X}^{2}v_{ 0},\\ldots,{X}^{d-1}v_{ 0} }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(26.3)

is a basis of W 0. With respect to this basis, for suitable c ij ∈ F, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ Z{X}^{i}v_{ 0} = \\lambda \(Z\){X}^{i}v_{ 0} +\\sum _{j<i}c_{ij}{X}^{j}v_{ 0}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(26.4)

This is proved by induction since

![
$$\\displaystyle{Z{X}^{i}v_{ 0} = XZ{X}^{i-1}v_{ 0} - \[X,Z\]{X}^{i-1}v_{ 0}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equi.gif)

By the induction hypothesis, ![
$$XZ{X}^{i-1}v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq58.gif) is ![
$$X\\lambda \(Z\){X}^{i-1}v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq59.gif) plus a linear combination of ![
$${X}^{j}v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq60.gif) with j < i, and ![
$$\[X,Z\]{X}^{i-1}v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq61.gif) is ![
$$\\lambda \(\[X,Z\]\){X}^{i-1}v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq62.gif) plus a linear combination of ![
$${X}^{j}v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq63.gif) with j < i − 1. The formula (26.4) follows. The invariance of W 0 under Z is now clear, and (26.2) also follows from (26.4) because with respect to the basis (26.3) the matrix of Z is upper triangular and the diagonal entries all equal λ(Z).

Now let us show that Xv 0 ∈ W. Let ![
$$Y \\in \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq64.gif). What we must show is that ![
$$Y Xv_{0} = \\lambda \(Y \)Xv_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq65.gif). The space W 0 is invariant under both X (obviously) and Y (by (26.2) taking Z = Y ). Thus, the trace of [X, Y ] = XY − YX on W 0 is zero. Since ![
$$Y \\in \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq66.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq67.gif) is an ideal, ![
$$\[X,Y \] \\in \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq68.gif) and we may take Z = [X, Y ] in (26.2). Since the characteristic of F is 0, we see that λ([X, Y ]) = 0. Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{Y Xv_{0} = XY v_{0} - \[X,Y \]v_{0} = \\lambda \(Y \)Xv_{0} - \\lambda \(\[X,Y \]\)v_{0} = \\lambda \(Y \)Xv_{0},}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equj.gif)

as required. □

Theorem 26.1.

(Lie) Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{b} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq69.gif) be a solvable Lie algebra of linear transformations over an algebraically closed field of characteristic zero. Assume that V ≠ 0.

(i)

There exists a vector v ∈ V that is a simultaneous eigenvector for all of ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq70.gif) .

(ii)

There exists a basis of V with respect to which all elements of ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq71.gif) are represented by upper triangular matrices.

Proof.

To prove (i), we may clearly assume that ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq72.gif). Let us first observe that ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq73.gif) has an ideal ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq74.gif) of codimension 1. Indeed, since ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq75.gif) is solvable, ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{b},\\mathfrak{b}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq76.gif) is a proper ideal, and the quotient Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}/\[\\mathfrak{b},\\mathfrak{b}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq77.gif) is Abelian; hence any subspace at all of ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}/\[\\mathfrak{b},\\mathfrak{b}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq78.gif) is an ideal. We choose a subspace of codimension 1, and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq79.gif) be its preimage in ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq80.gif).

Now ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq81.gif) is solvable and of strictly smaller dimension than ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq82.gif), so by induction there exists a simultaneous eigenvector v 0 for all of ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq83.gif). Let ![
$$\\lambda\\,: \\mathfrak{h}\\longrightarrow F$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq84.gif) be such that ![
$$Xv_{0} = \\lambda \(X\)v_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq85.gif). The space ![
$$W =\\{ v \\in V \\vert Xv = \\lambda \(X\)v\\,\\mathrm{for\\,all}\\,X \\in \\mathfrak{h}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq86.gif) is nonzero, and by Proposition 26.3 it is ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq87.gif)-invariant. Let ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{b} - \\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq88.gif). Since F is assumed to be algebraically closed, Z has an eigenvector on W, which will be an eigenvector v 1 for all of ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq89.gif) since it is already an eigenvector for ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq90.gif).

For (ii), the Lie algebra of linear transformations of V∕Fv 1 induced by those of ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq91.gif) is solvable, so by induction this quotient space has a basis ![
$$\\overline{v_{2}},\\ldots,\\overline{v_{d}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq92.gif) with respect to which every ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq93.gif) is upper triangular. This means that for suitable a ij ∈ F, we have ![
$$X\\overline{v_{j}} =\\sum _{2\\leqslant i\\leqslant j}a_{ij}\\overline{v_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq94.gif). Letting ![
$$v_{2},\\ldots,v_{d}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq95.gif) be representatives of the cosets ![
$$\\overline{v_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq96.gif) in V, it follows that X is upper triangular with respect to the basis ![
$$v_{1},\\ldots,v_{d}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq97.gif). □

Let K be a compact connected Lie group and ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq98.gif) its Lie algebra. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{k}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq99.gif) be the analytic complexification of ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq100.gif), so that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq101.gif) is the Lie algebra of the complex Lie group G that is the complexification of K. Let T be a maximal torus of K. We can embed its analytic complexification ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq102.gif) into G by the universal property of the complexification.

Let Φ be the root system of K and let Φ + be the positive roots with respect to some ordering. If α ∈Φ, let ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha } \\subset \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq103.gif) be the α-eigenspace. By Proposition 18.6, ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq104.gif) is one-dimensional, and we will denote by X α a nonzero element. Define

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathfrak{n} =\\bigoplus _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }. }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(26.5)

Then ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq105.gif) is a complex Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq106.gif). Indeed, if α and β are positive roots, it is impossible that α = −β, so by Proposition 18.4 (ii), ![
$$\[X_{\\alpha },X_{\\beta }\] \\subset \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha +\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq107.gif) if α + β is a positive root, and otherwise it is zero. In either case, it is in ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq108.gif).

Proposition 26.4.

The Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq109.gif) defined by (26.5) is nilpotent.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\varPhi _{k}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq110.gif) be the set of positive roots α such that α is expressible as the sum of at least k simple positive roots. Thus, ![
$$\\varPhi _{1}^{+} =\\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq111.gif), ![
$$\\varPhi _{1}^{+} \\supset \\varPhi _{2}^{+} \\supset \\varPhi _{3}^{+} \\supset \\cdots $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq112.gif), and eventually ![
$$\\varPhi _{k}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq113.gif) is empty. Define

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{n}_{k} =\\bigoplus _{\\alpha \\in \\varPhi _{k}^{+}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equk.gif)

It follows from Proposition 18.4 (ii) that ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{n},\\mathfrak{n}_{k}\] \\subseteq \\mathfrak{n}_{k+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq114.gif), and eventually ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq115.gif) is zero, so ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq116.gif) is nilpotent. □

Now let ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq117.gif) be the Lie algebra of T, and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{b} = \\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}} \\oplus \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq118.gif). Since ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}},\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }\] \\subseteq \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq119.gif), it is clear that ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq120.gif), like ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq121.gif), is closed under the Lie bracket and forms a complex Lie algebra. Moreover, since ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq122.gif) is Abelian and normalizes ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq123.gif), we have ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{b},\\mathfrak{b}\] \\subset \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq124.gif), and since ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq125.gif) is nilpotent and hence solvable, it follows that ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq126.gif) is solvable.

We aim to show that both ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq127.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq128.gif) are the Lie algebras of closed complex Lie subgroups of G.

Proposition 26.5.

Let G be the complexification of a compact connected Lie group K, and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq129.gif) be as in (26.5) . If π : G → GL (V) is any representation and ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq130.gif) , then π(X) is nilpotent as a linear transformation; that is, π(X) N = 0 for all sufficiently large N.

We note that it is possible for a nilpotent Lie algebra of linear transformations to contain linear transformations that are not nilpotent. For example, an Abelian Lie algebra is nilpotent as a Lie algebra but might well contain linear transformations that are not nilpotent.

Proof.

By Theorem 26.1, we may choose a basis of V such that all π(X) are upper triangular for ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq131.gif), where we are identifying π(X) with its matrix with respect to the chosen basis. What we must show is that if ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq132.gif), then the diagonal entries of this matrix are zero. It is sufficient to show this if ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq133.gif), where α is a positive root.

By the definition of a root, the character α of T is nonzero, and so its differential dα is nonzero. This means that there exists ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq134.gif) such that dα(H) ≠ 0, and by (18.9) the commutator [π(H),π(X α)] is a nonzero multiple of π(X α). Because it is a nonzero multiple of the commutator of two upper triangular matrices, it follows that π(X α) is an upper triangular matrix with zeros on the diagonal. Thus, it is nilpotent. □

Theorem 26.2.

(i)

Let G be the complexification of a compact connected Lie group K, let T be a maximal torus of K, let ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq135.gif) be the Lie algebra of T, and let ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq136.gif) be its complexification. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq137.gif) be as in (26.5), and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{b} = \\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}} \\oplus \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq138.gif) . Let ![
$$N =\\exp \(\\mathfrak{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq139.gif) and ![
$$B = T_{\\mathbb{C}}N$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq140.gif) . Then N and B are closed Lie subalgebras of G and ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq141.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq142.gif) are the Lie algebras of N and B.

(ii)

We may embed G in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq143.gif) for some n in such a way that K consists of unitary matrices, ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq144.gif) consists of diagonal matrices, and B consists of upper triangular matrices.

(iii)

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq145.gif) is a complex Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq146.gif) , and ![
$$U =\\exp \(\\mathfrak{u}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq147.gif) , then U is a complex analytic subgroup of N and ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq148.gif) is its Lie algebra. If ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq149.gif) is a real Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq150.gif) , and ![
$$U =\\exp \(\\mathfrak{u}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq151.gif) , then U is a Lie subgroup of N and ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq152.gif) is its Lie algebra.

(iv)

Suppose that ![
$$\\mathfrak{v}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq153.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq154.gif) are (complex) Lie subalgebras of ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq155.gif) such that ![
$$\\mathfrak{n} = \\mathfrak{v} \\oplus \\mathfrak{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq156.gif) . Let ![
$$V =\\exp \\left \(\\mathfrak{v}\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq157.gif) and ![
$$W =\\exp \\left \(\\mathfrak{w}\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq158.gif) so that by (iii) V and W are complex analytic subgroups of N. Then ![
$$V \\cap W = \\left \\{1\\right \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq159.gif) and N = V W.

The group B is called the standard Borel subgroup of G. A conjugate of B is called a Borel subgroup. A subgroup containing a Borel subgroup is called a parabolic subgroup. We will call a subgroup containing the standard Borel subgroup a standard parabolic.

Proof.

We will prove parts (i) and (ii) simultaneously.

Let π : K → GL(V ) be a faithful representation. We choose on V an inner product with respect to which π(k) is unitary for k ∈ K. By Theorem 24.1, we may extend π to a faithful complex analytic representation of G. We have already noted that ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq160.gif) is a solvable Lie algebra, so by Theorem 26.1 we may find a basis ![
$$v_{1},\\ldots,v_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq161.gif) of V with respect to which the linear transformations π(X) with ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq162.gif) are upper triangular. This means that ![
$$\\pi \(X\)v_{i} \\in \\sum _{j\\leqslant i}Fv_{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq163.gif). We claim that we may assume that the v i are orthonormal. This is accomplished by Gram–Schmidt orthonormalization. We first divide v i by |v i | so v i has length 1. Next we replace v 2 by ![
$$v_{2} -\\left \\langle v_{2},v_{1}\\right \\rangle v_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq164.gif) and so forth so that the v i are orthonormal. The matrices π(X) with ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq165.gif) remain upper triangular after these changes.

We identify G with its image in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq166.gif) and its Lie algebra with the corresponding Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\) = \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq167.gif). Thus, we write X instead of π(X) and regard it as a matrix.

Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{ = \\left \\{\\exp \(X\)\\vert X \\in \\mathfrak{n}\\}.\\right. }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(26.6)

We will show that N is a closed analytic subgroup of G with a Lie algebra that is N.

By Remark 8.1, if ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq168.gif) and Y = exp(X), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{Y = I + X + \\tfrac{1} {2}{X}^{2} +\\ldots + \\tfrac{1} {n!}{X}^{n}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equl.gif)

This is now a series with only finitely many terms since X is nilpotent by Proposition 26.5. Moreover, Y − I is a finite sum of upper triangular nilpotent matrices and hence is itself nilpotent, and reverting the exponential series, we have X = log(Y ), where we define

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\log \(Y \) = \(Y - 1\) -\\tfrac{1} {2}{\(Y - 1\)}^{2} + \\tfrac{1} {3}{\(Y - 1\)}^{3} -\\cdots + {\(-1\)}^{n-1} \\tfrac{1} {n}{\(Y - 1\)}^{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equm.gif)

if Y is an upper triangular unipotent matrix. As with the exponential series, only finitely many terms are needed since (Y − I) n = 0. This series defines a continuous map ![
$$\\log \\,: N\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq169.gif), which is the inverse of the exponential map. Therefore, ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq170.gif) is homeomorphic to N.

Next we show that N is a closed subset of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq171.gif) and in fact an affine subvariety. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq172.gif) be the Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq173.gif) consisting of upper triangular nilpotent matrices, and let ![
$$\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq174.gif) be a set of linear functionals on ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq175.gif) such that the intersection of the kernels of the λ i is ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq176.gif). N may be characterized as follows. An element ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq177.gif) is in N if and only if it is upper triangular and unipotent, and each ![
$$\\lambda _{i}\\left \(\\log \(g\)\\right \) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq178.gif). These conditions comprise a set of polynomial equations characterizing N, showing that it is closed.

Next we show that N is a group. Indeed, its intersection with a neighborhood of the identity is a local group by Proposition 14.1. Thus, if g, h are near the identity in N, we have gh ∈ N, so ϕ i (g, h) = 0 where ![
$$\\phi _{i}\(g,h\) = \\lambda _{i}\\left \(\\exp \(gh\)\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq179.gif). Thus, the polynomial ϕ i vanishes near the identity in N × N, and since N is a connected affine subvariety of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq180.gif), this polynomial vanishes identically on all of N. Thus, N is closed under multiplication, and it is a group.

Since ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}},\\mathfrak{n}\] \\subset \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq181.gif), the group ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq182.gif) normalizes N, so ![
$$B = T_{\\mathbb{C}}N$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq183.gif) is a subgroup of G. It is not hard to show that it is a closed Lie subgroup and its Lie algebra is ![
$$\\mathfrak{b}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq184.gif).

The same argument that proved that N is a Lie group proves (iii). In the case where ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq185.gif) is a complex Lie algebra, We simply take a larger set of linear functionals λ i on ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq186.gif) with a kernel that is the Lie subalgebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq187.gif) and argue identically to show first that ![
$$U =\\exp \(\\mathfrak{u}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq188.gif) is closed, and that it is a Lie subgroup. If ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq189.gif) is a real Lie algebra, we proceed in the same way but take the λ i to be real linear.

We turn to the proof of (iv). We saw in the proof of (ii) that the map ![
$$\\exp\\,: \\mathfrak{n}\\longrightarrow N$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq190.gif) is surjective, and given by a polynomial expression, with a polynomial inverse ![
$$\\log \\,: N\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq191.gif). Moreover, exp takes ![
$$\\mathfrak{v}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq192.gif) to V and ![
$$\\mathfrak{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq193.gif) to W, while log takes V to ![
$$\\mathfrak{v}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq194.gif) and W to ![
$$\\mathfrak{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq195.gif). It follows that ![
$$V \\cap W = \\left \\{1\\right \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq196.gif) since if ![
$$g \\in V \\cap W$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq197.gif) then ![
$$\\log \\left \(g\\right \) \\in \\mathfrak{v} \\cap \\mathfrak{w} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq198.gif), so g = 1.

To show that N = VW we note that the multiplication map V × W → N has as its differential the inclusion ![
$$\\mathfrak{v} \\oplus \\mathfrak{w}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq199.gif). But this map is the identity map. Therefore, by the inverse function theorem multiplication V × W → N is onto a neighborhood of the identity and therefore has an analytic inverse. This means that there are analytic maps ![
$$\\phi \\,: \\mathfrak{n}\\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq200.gif) and ![
$$\\psi \\,: \\mathfrak{n}\\longrightarrow W$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq201.gif), defined by power series convergent near the identity, such that ![
$$\\phi \\left \(X\\right \)\\psi \\left \(X\\right \) = {e}^{X}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq202.gif) for ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq203.gif). We will argue that ϕ and ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq8888.gif) are polynomials. Let X i be a basis of ![
$$\\mathfrak{v}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq204.gif) and let Y j be a basis of ![
$$\\mathfrak{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq205.gif). Let ![
$$\\lambda \\,: \\mathfrak{n}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq206.gif) be the map ![
$$\\lambda \\left \(X\\right \) =\\log \\left \(\\phi \\left \(X\\right \)\\right \) +\\log \\left \(\\psi \\left \(X\\right \)\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq207.gif). Then λ is the inverse map of the map μ that sends ![
$$X =\\sum c_{i}X_{i} +\\sum d_{j}Y _{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq208.gif) to ![
$$\\exp \\left \(\\sum c_{i}X_{i}\\right \)\\exp \\left \(\\sum d_{j}Y _{j}\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq209.gif). Regarding ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq210.gif) as a vector subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\\left \(n, \\mathbb{C}\\right \) = \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\\left \(\\mathbb{C}\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq211.gif), we see that ![
$$\\mu \\left \(X\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq212.gif) is a finite linear combination of finite products of the ![
$$c_{i}X_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq213.gif) and ![
$$d_{j}Y _{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq214.gif), where the products are taken in the sense of matrix multiplication. Inverting μ, we see that ![
$$\\lambda \\left \(X\\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq215.gif) also is a linear combination of such finite products of the ![
$$c_{i}X_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq216.gif) and ![
$$d_{j}Y _{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq217.gif). It is a finite such linear combination since only finitely many such products are nonzero : this is because the matrices X i and Y j are upper triangular and nilpotent. Projecting onto ![
$$\\mathfrak{v}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq218.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq219.gif) and exponentiating, we see that ϕ and ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq8881.gif) are polynomials.

Since both sides are polynomials, the identity ![
$$\\phi \\left \(X\\right \)\\psi \\left \(X\\right \) ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{X}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq220.gif), already proved for X near 0, is true for all X and it follows that the multiplication map V × W → N is surjective. This proves that N = VW. □

The Borel subgroup is a bit too big for the Iwasawa decomposition since it has a nontrivial intersection with K. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{a} = i\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq221.gif). It is the Lie algebra of a closed connected Lie subgroup A of T. If we embed K and G into ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq222.gif) as in Theorem 26.2, the elements of T are diagonal, and A consists of the subgroup of elements of T whose diagonal entries are positive real numbers. Let B 0 = AN.

Theorem 26.3. (Iwasawa decomposition)

With notations as in Theorem 26.2 and B 0 and A as above, each element of g ∈ G can be factored uniquely as bk where b ∈ B 0 and k ∈ K, or as aνk where a ∈ A, ν ∈ N and k ∈ K. The multiplication map A × N × K → G is a diffeomorphism.

Proof.

Let ![
$$G^{\\prime} = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq223.gif), K′ = U(n), A′ be the subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq224.gif) consisting of diagonal matrices with positive real eigenvalues, and N′ be the subgroup of upper triangular unipotent matrices in G′. By Theorem 26.2 (ii), we may embed G into G′ for suitable n such that K ends up in K′, N ends up in N′, and A ends up in K 0′.

We have a commutative diagram

where the vertical arrows are multiplications and the horizontal arrows are inclusions. By Proposition 26.1, the composition

![
$$\\displaystyle{ A \\times N \\times K\\longrightarrow A^{\\prime} \\times N^{\\prime} \\times K^{\\prime}\\longrightarrow G^{\\prime} }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(26.7)

is a diffeomorphism onto its image, and so the multiplication A × N × K → G is a diffeomorphism onto its image. We must show that it is surjective.

Since A, N, and K are each closed in A′, N′, and K′, respectively, the image of (26.7) is closed in G′ and hence in G. We will show that this image is also open in G. We note that ![
$$\\mathfrak{a} + \\mathfrak{n} + \\mathfrak{k} = \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq225.gif) since ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}} \\subset \\mathfrak{a} + \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq226.gif), and each ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha } \\subset \\mathfrak{n} + \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq227.gif). It follows that the dimension of A × N × K is greater than or equal to that of G. (These dimensions are actually equal, though we do not need this fact, since it is not hard to see that the sum ![
$$\\mathfrak{a} + \\mathfrak{n} + \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq228.gif) is direct.) Since multiplication is a diffeomorphism onto its image, this image is open and closed in G. But G is connected, so this image is all of G, and the theorem is now clear. □

As an application, we may now show why flag manifolds have a complex structure.

Theorem 26.4.

Let K be a compact connected Lie group and T a maximal torus. Then X = K∕T can be given the structure of a complex manifold in such a way that the translation maps g : xT → gxT are holomorphic. This action of K can be extended to an action of the complexification G by holomorphic maps.

Proof.

By the Iwasawa decomposition, we may write G = BK. Since ![
$$B \\cap K = T$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq229.gif), we have G∕B ≅ K∕T, and this diffeomorphism is K-equivariant. Now G is a complex Lie group and B is a closed analytic subgroup, so the quotient G∕B has the structure of a complex analytic manifold, and the action of G, a fortiori of K, consists of holomorphic maps. □

We turn now to a different use of the Borel subgroup. If (π, V ) is a finite-dimensional representation of K, then by Theorem 24.1, π can be extended to a complex analytic representation of G, and of course a complex analytic representation of G can be restricted back to K. So the categories of finite-dimensional representations of K, and the finite-dimensional analytic representations of G are equivalent.

Let λ be a weight. It is thus a character of ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq230.gif). Now B is a semidirect product ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}N$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq231.gif) with N normal, so ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}\\mathop{\\cong}B/N$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq232.gif). This means that λ may be extended to a character of B with N in its kernel.

We will show that each irreducible representation of G has an N-fixed vector v that is unique up to scalar multiple. It is the highest weight vector of the representation. Thus, if λ is the dominant weight, we have π(t)v = λ(t)v for ![
$$t \\in T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq233.gif). Since v is N-fixed, we may also write π(b)v = λ(b)v for b ∈ B. We will give some applications of this useful fact.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq234.gif) be the Lie algebra of N, defined by (26.5). We may similarly define ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}_{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq235.gif) to be the span of ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq236.gif) with α ∈Φ −. It is also the Lie algebra of a Lie subgroup of G, which we will denote N −. Let w 0 be a representative of the long Weyl group element. Then Ad(w 0) interchanges the positive and negative roots, so ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(w_{0}\)\\mathfrak{n} = \\mathfrak{n}_{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq237.gif) and ![
$$w_{0}Nw_{0}^{-1} = N_{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq238.gif).

Lemma 26.1.

The Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq239.gif) is generated by the X α as α runs through the simple positive roots.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq240.gif) be the algebra generated by the X α with α simple. Let us define the height of a positive root to be the number of simple roots into which it may be decomposed, counted with multiplicities. If α ∈Φ + is not simple, we may write α = β \+ γ where β and γ are in Φ +, and by induction on the height of α, we may assume that X β and X γ are in ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq241.gif). By Corollary 18.1, ![
$$\[X_{\\beta },X_{\\gamma }\]$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq242.gif) is a nonzero multiple of X α and so X α is in ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq243.gif). Thus, ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}^{\\prime} = \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq244.gif). □

Now ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq245.gif) is a complex Lie algebra and ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}_{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq246.gif), ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq247.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq248.gif) are Lie subalgebras, so we have homomorphisms ![
$$i_{\\mathfrak{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq249.gif), ![
$$i_{\\mathfrak{t}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq250.gif) and ![
$$i_{\\mathfrak{n}_{-}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq251.gif) mapping ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq252.gif), U(![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq253.gif) and ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq254.gif) into ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq255.gif). The Poincaré –Birkhoff–Witt theorem implies that these homomorphisms are injective, but we do not need that fact. If ξ is in ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq256.gif), for example, we will use the same notation ξ for ![
$$i_{\\mathfrak{n}}\(\\xi \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq257.gif), which is an abuse of notation since we are omitting to prove that ![
$$i_{\\mathfrak{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq258.gif) is injective. The multiplication map ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\) \\times U\(\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\) \\times U\(\\mathfrak{n}\)\\longrightarrow U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq259.gif) that sends (ξ, η, ζ) to ξ η ζ induces a linear map ![
$$\\mu\\,: U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\) \\otimes U\(\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\) \\otimes U\(\\mathfrak{n}\)\\longrightarrow U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq260.gif). With the above abuse of notation, we denote the image of μ as ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)U\(\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\)U\(\\mathfrak{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq261.gif).

Proposition 26.6. (Triangular decomposition)

The linear map ![
$$\\mu\\,: U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\) \\otimes U\(\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\) \\otimes U\(\\mathfrak{n}\)\\longrightarrow U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq262.gif) is surjective.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{R} = U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)U\(\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\)U\(\\mathfrak{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq263.gif) be the image of μ. Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq264.gif) contains generators of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq265.gif), it is enough to show that it is closed under multiplication. It is obvious that ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)\\mathfrak{R} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq266.gif). Moreover, since ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}},\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\] \\subseteq \\mathfrak{n}_{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq267.gif) we also have ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\)\\mathfrak{R} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq268.gif). It remains for us to show that ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}\)\\mathfrak{R} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq269.gif). By Lemma 26.1, ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq270.gif) is generated with X α with α simple, so it is enough to show that ![
$$X_{\\alpha }\\mathfrak{R} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq271.gif) when α is simple. First, if β ∈Φ + then ![
$$X_{\\alpha }X_{-\\beta } - X_{-\\beta }X_{\\alpha } = \[X_{\\alpha },X_{-\\beta }\] \\in \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq272.gif) unless β = α, by Proposition 18.4, while if β = α we have ![
$$\[X_{\\alpha },X_{-\\alpha }\] \\in \\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq273.gif). On the other hand if ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq274.gif) then [X α, H] is a constant multiple of X α. As a result of these relations, ![
$$X_{\\alpha }\\mathfrak{R} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq275.gif). □

Let (π, V ) be an irreducible representation of K. We may extend (π, V ) to an irreducible analytic representation of G. Let λ be the highest weight. Proposition 22.4 tells us that the weight space V (λ) corresponding to the highest weight λ is one-dimensional. Let v λ be a nonzero element. If α is a positive root, then ![
$$\\pi \(X_{\\alpha }\)v_{\\lambda } = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq276.gif) because it is in V (λ + α), which is zero. (Otherwise, λ is not a highest weight.) On the other hand the triangular decomposition gives some complementary information.

Theorem 26.5.

Let (π, V ) be an irreducible representation of K. Extend (πs, V ) to an irreducible analytic representation of G. Let λ be the highest weight. Then V (λ) = V N is the space of N-invariants.

Proof.

Clearly v ∈ V is N-invariant if and only if π(X α) = 0 for α ∈Φ +, and as we have noted this is true if v ∈ V (λ). We must show that N invariance implies that v ∈ V (λ). Since ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq277.gif) normalizes N, V N is ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq278.gif)-invariant and can be decomposed into weight spaces. So we may assume that v ∈ V (μ) for some μ, and the problem is to prove that μ = λ. We may write ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\) = U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)U\(\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\) \\oplus U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)U\(\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\)\\mathfrak{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq279.gif) where ![
$$\\mathfrak{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq280.gif) is the ideal of ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq281.gif) generated by ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq282.gif), and ![
$$\\mathfrak{J}v = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq283.gif). Therefore, ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)v = U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)U\(\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}\)v = U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)v$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq284.gif). But by Proposition 18.3 (iii) each weight in ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{n}_{-}\)v$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq285.gif) is ≼ μ, so ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)v$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq286.gif) does not contain V (λ). It is therefore a proper nonzero submodule. But V is irreducible, so this is a contradiction. □

Now suppose that we have a representation that we want to decompose into irreducibles. Theorem 26.5 gives a strategy for obtaining this decomposition. We remind the reader that if λ is a weight, that is, a character of ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq287.gif), then we may regard λ as a character of B in which N acts trivially, because ![
$$B/N\\mathop{\\cong}T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq288.gif).

Proposition 26.7.

Let W be a G-module that decomposes into a direct sum of finite-dimensional irreducible representations. Let λ be a dominant weight, and let π λ be the irreducible G-module with highest weight λ. Then the multiplicity of π λ as a G-module in W equals the multiplicity of λ as a B-module in W.

Proof.

Since N acts trivially in λ as a B-module, every B-submodule of W isomorphic to λ is contained in W N . By Theorem 26.5, each copy of πλ contains a unique vector in W N . The statement is therefore clear. □

To give an example, let us decompose the symmetric algebra ![
$$\\bigvee \({\\vee }^{2}{\\mathbb{C}}^{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq289.gif) for over the symmetric square of the standard module for ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq290.gif).

Proposition 26.8.

Let Ω be the space of n × n symmetric complex matrices. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{P}\(\\varOmega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq291.gif) be the ring of polynomials on Ω with the ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq292.gif) action (gf)(X) = f( t g ⋅ X ⋅ g). Then ![
$$\\mathcal{P}\(\\varOmega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq293.gif) is isomorphic to the ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq294.gif) -module ![
$$\\bigvee \({\\vee }^{2}{\\mathbb{C}}^{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq295.gif) .

Proof.

For any module W the polynomial ring on W is isomorphic as a ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq296.gif)-module to the symmetric algebra on W ∗. So it is sufficient to show that ![
$${\\vee }^{2}{\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq297.gif) and Ω are dual modules. Indeed, if ![
$$V = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq298.gif) and M is an n × n symmetric matrix then M induces a symmetric bilinear map ![
$$V \\times V \\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq299.gif) by ![
$$\(v_{1},v_{2}\){\\longmapsto }^{t}v_{1}Mv_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq300.gif). (We are thinking of v 1 and v 2 as column vectors.) The linear map ![
$${\\vee }^{2}V \\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq301.gif) identifies Ω with the dual space of ∨2 V. □

We identify the weight lattice Λ of U(n) or ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq302.gif) with ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq303.gif) as follows: if ![
$$\\lambda \\in {\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq304.gif) then we identify λ with the character

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} t_{1} & & \\\\ & \\ddots & \\\\ & & t_{n} \\end{array} \\right \)\\longmapsto \\prod t_{i}^{\\lambda _{i} }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equn.gif)

The weight λ is dominant if ![
$$\\lambda _{1} \\geqslant \\lambda _{2} \\geqslant \\cdots \\geqslant \\lambda _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq305.gif). Assuming this, we say that λ is even if the λ i are all even, and effective if λ n ![
$$ \\geqslant  $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq9999.gif) 0. It is not hard to see that λ is effective.

Theorem 26.6.

The ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq306.gif) -module ![
$$\\bigvee \({\\vee }^{2}{\\mathbb{C}}^{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq307.gif) decomposes into a direct sum of irreducible representations, each with multiplicity one. Let λ be a dominant weight. The irreducible representation with highest weight λ occurs in this decomposition if and only if λ is even. Each occurs with multiplicity one.

Proof.

By Proposition 26.8 we may work with the representation ![
$$\\mathcal{P}\(\\varOmega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq308.gif). As we have explained, our task is to compute the N-invariants of the representation. If X = (X ij ) ∈Ω, let X k (1 ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq444.gif) k ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq442.gif) n) be the upper left k × k minor, that is

![
$$\\displaystyle{X_{k} =\\det \(X_{ij}\)_{1\\leqslant i,j\\leqslant k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equo.gif)

We consider X k to be a polynomial function on Ω. It is simple to check that it is N-invariant, and we will show that the ring of N-invariants is generated by ![
$$X_{1},\\ldots,X_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq309.gif). Let Ω′ be the subspace of Ω characterized by the nonvanishing of the X k . It is a dense open set, so any element of ![
$$\\mathcal{P}\(\\varOmega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq310.gif) is determined by its restriction to Ω′. Now any double coset in N∖Ω′ ∕N is equivalent to a diagonal element; indeed the element X is in the same double coset as

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} X_{1} & & & \\\\ & X_{2}/X_{1} & & \\\\ & & X_{3}/X_{2} & \\\\ & & &\\ddots \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equp.gif)

Clearly any polynomial of X restricts to the diagonal as a polynomial

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} x_{1} & & & \\\\ & x_{2} & & \\\\ & & x_{3} & \\\\ & & &\\ddots \\end{array} \\right \) =\\sum _{\\mu \\in {\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}}a\(\\mu \){x}^{\\mu },\\quad {x}^{\\mu } = x_{ 1}^{\\mu _{1} }\\cdots x_{n}^{\\mu _{n} },}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_Equq.gif)

and since the value of x μ on X is ![
$$X_{1}^{\\mu _{1}-\\mu _{2}}X_{2}^{\\mu _{2}-\\mu _{3}}\\cdots $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq311.gif) if this is a polynomial of X we must have a(μ) = 0 unless ![
$$\\mu _{1} \\geqslant \\mu _{2} \\geqslant \\cdots $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq312.gif). Thus the x μ with μ dominant form a basis of the N-invariants. We have seen that there is one irreducible representation for each basis vector. Under the action in Proposition 26.8, the weight of the vector x μ is 2μ. Hence the highest weights of the irreducible representations in ![
$$\\bigvee \({\\vee }^{2}{\\mathbb{C}}^{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq313.gif) are the even dominant weights. □

The following proposition abstracts this situation. We will say that a representation of G that decomposes into a direct sum of finite-dimensional irreducible representations is multiplicity-free if no irreducible representation occurs in it with multiplicity greater than one. For example, we have just proved that ![
$$\\bigvee \({\\vee }^{2}{\\mathbb{C}}^{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq314.gif) is a multiplicity-free ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq315.gif)-module. By Proposition 26.7 a method of proving that a module W is multiplicity-free is to show that W N is multiplicity-free as a B-module. The next result exposes the underlying mechanism in the proof of Theorem 26.6.

In the following result we will assume that G is an affine algebraic group over ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq316.gif). We note that all of the usual examples, ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq317.gif), ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq318.gif), ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq319.gif), ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq320.gif),...are affine algebraic groups. We continue to assume that G is the complexification of a compact Lie group, and this assumption is true for these examples as well.

Theorem 26.7.

Assume that G is an affine algebraic group over the complex numbers. Assume that it is also the complexification of a compact Lie group K. Let X be a complex affine algebraic variety on which the group G acts algebraically. Assume that the Borel subgroup B has a dense open orbit in X. Let W be the space of algebraic functions on X. Then W is a multiplicity-free G-module.

The open orbit, if it exists, is always unique and dense, so the word "dense" could be eliminated from the statement. The theory of algebraic group actions is an important topic, and the standard monograph is Mumford, Fulton, and Kirwan [132]. Varieties (whether affine or not) with an open B-orbit are called spherical.

Proof.

We need to prove that W decomposes into a direct sum of finite -dimensional modules.

We begin by showing that if f ∈ W then the G-translates of f span a finite-dimensional vector space W(f). Since the group action G × X → X is algebraic, if f is a polynomial function on X, then (g, x) ↦ f(gx) is a polynomial function on G × X and so there exist polynomials ϕ i on G and ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq8882.gif) i on X such that ![
$$f\(gx\) =\\sum _{i}\\phi _{i}\(g\)\\psi _{i}\(x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq321.gif). Thus, the space W(f) of left translates of f is spanned by the functions ![
$$ \\psi $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq8883.gif) i and is finite-dimensional.

Now we embed X in an affine space, so that we may speak of the degree of a polynomial function. Let W N be the direct sum of the W(f) for f a polynomial of degree ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq4421.gif) N. Then W N is finite-dimensional and G-invariant. Because K is compact, W N decomposes into a direct sum of irreducible K-modules, which are also G-invariant subspaces since G is the complexification of K. Since ![
$$W_{N} \\subset W_{N+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq322.gif), may also choose these decompositions so that every irreducible that occurs in the decomposition of W N is also in the decomposition of W N+1. Taking the sum of all the irreducibles that occur in these decompositions shows that W is completely reducible.

Now let x 0 ∈ X such that Bx 0 is open and dense. If f ∈ W and g ∈ G, then the group action is by (gf)(x) = f(g −1 x). So if f is in W N and λ is a dominant weight such that bf = λ(b)f for all b ∈ B, we have ![
$$f\(bx_{0}\) = \\lambda {\(b\)}^{-1}f\(x_{0}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_26_Chapter_IEq323.gif). Because Bx 0 is dense, this means that f is determined up to a scalar multiple by this condition. This shows that W N is multiplicity-free as a B-module and therefore W is multiplicity-free as a G-module. □
