# 27. The Bruhat Decomposition

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

The Bruhat decomposition was discovered quite late in the history of Lie groups, which is surprising in view of its fundamental importance. It was preceded by Ehresmann's discovery of a closely related cell decomposition for flag manifolds. The Bruhat decomposition was axiomatized by Tits in the notion of a Group with (B, N) pair or Tits' system. This is a generalization of the notion of a Coxeter group, and indeed every (B, N) gives rise to a Coxeter group. We have remarked after Theorem 25.1 that Coxeter groups always act on simplicial complexes whose geometry is closely connected with their properties. As it turns out a group with (B N) pair also acts on a simplicial complex, the Tits' building. We will not have space to discuss this important concept but see Tits [163] and Abramenko and Brown [1].

The Bruhat decomposition was discovered quite late in the history of Lie groups, which is surprising in view of its fundamental importance. It was preceded by Ehresmann's discovery of a closely related cell decomposition for flag manifolds. The Bruhat decomposition was axiomatized by Tits in the notion of a Group with (B, N) pair or Tits' system. This is a generalization of the notion of a Coxeter group, and indeed every (B, N) gives rise to a Coxeter group. We have remarked after Theorem 25.1 that Coxeter groups always act on simplicial complexes whose geometry is closely connected with their properties. As it turns out a group with (B, N) pair also acts on a simplicial complex, the Tits' building. We will not have space to discuss this important concept but see Tits [163] and Abramenko and Brown [1].

In this chapter, in order to be consistent with the notation in the literature on Tits' systems, particularly Bourbaki [23], we will modify our notation slightly. In other chapters such as the previous one, N denotes the subgroup (26.6) of the Borel subgroup. That group will appear in this Chapter also, but we will denote it as U, reserving the letter N for the normalizer of T. Similarly, in this chapter U_ will be the subgroup formerly denoted N_.

Let G = GL(n, F), where F is a field, and let B be the Borel subgroup of upper triangular matrices in G. Taking T ⊂ B to be the subgroup of diagonal matrices in G, the normalizer N(T) consists of all monomial matrices. The Weyl group W = N(T)∕T≅S n . If w ∈ W is represented by ω ∈ N(T) then since T ⊂ B the double coset BωB is independent of the choice of representative ω, so by abuse of notation we write BwB for BωB. It is a remarkable and extremely important fact that ![
$$w\\longrightarrow BwB$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq1.gif) is a bijection between the elements of W and the double cosets ![
$$B\\setminus G/B$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq2.gif). We will prove the following Bruhat decomposition:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ G =\\bigcup BwB\\quad \(\\mathrm{disjoint}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(27.1)

The example of GL(2, F) is worth writing out explicitly. If ![
$$g = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a&b\\\\ c &d \\end{array} \\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq3.gif), then g ∈ B if c = 0. Therefore to prove the Bruhat decomposition, then for a representative ω of the long Weyl group element it will be convenient to take ![
$$\\omega = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 0& -\\varDelta {c}^{-1} \\\\ c& 0 \\end{array} \\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq4.gif) where Δ = ad − bc. Then this follows from the identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{{a\\;b\\choose c\\;d} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 1&a/c\\\\ & 1 \\end{array} \\right \)\\omega \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 1&d/c\\\\ & 1 \\end{array} \\right \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equa.gif)

We will prove this and also obtain a similar statement in complex Lie groups. Specifically, if G is a complex Lie group obtained by complexification of a compact connected Lie group, we will prove a "Bruhat decomposition" analogous to (27.1) in G. A more general Bruhat decomposition will be found in Theorem 29.5.

We will prove the Bruhat decomposition for a group with a Tits' system, which consists of a pair of subgroups B and N satisfying certain axioms. The use of the notation N differs from that of Chap.​ 26, though the results of that chapter are very relevant here.

Let G be a group, and let B and N be subgroups such that ![
$$T = B \\cap N$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq5.gif) is normal in N. Let W be the quotient group N∕T. As with ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq6.gif), we write wB instead of wB when ω ∈ N represents the Weyl group element w, and similarly we will denote Bw = Bω and BwB = BωB.

Let G be a group with subgroups B and N satisfying the following conditions.

Axiom TS1. The group ![
$$T = B \\cap N$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq7.gif) is normal in N.

Axiom TS2. There is specified a set I of generators of the group W = N∕T such that if s ∈ I then s 2 = 1.

Axiom TS3. Let w ∈ W and s ∈ I. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ wBs \\subset BwsB \\cup BwB. }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(27.2)

Axiom TS4. Let s ∈ I. Then ![
$$sB{s}^{-1}\\neq B$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq8.gif).

Axiom TS5. The group G is generated by N and B.

Then we say that (B, N, I) is a Tits' system.

We will be particularly concerned with the double cosets ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\) = BwB$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq9.gif) with w ∈ W. Then Axiom TS3 can be rewritten

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathcal{C}\(w\)\\, \\mathcal{C}\(s\) \\subset \\mathcal{C}\(w\) \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(ws\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(27.3)

which is obviously equivalent to (27.2). Taking inverses, this is equivalent to

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathcal{C}\(s\)\\,\\mathcal{C}\(w\) \\subset \\mathcal{C}\(w\) \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(sw\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(27.4)

As a first example, let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq10.gif), where F is any field. Let B be the Borel subgroup of upper triangular matrices in G, let T be the standard "maximal torus" of all diagonal elements, and let N be the normalizer in G of T. Then B is the semidirect product of T with the normal subgroup U of upper triangular unipotent matrices. The group N consists of the monomial matrices, that is, matrices having exactly one nonzero entry in each row and column. Let ![
$$I =\\{ s_{1}, \\ldots, s_{n-1}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq11.gif) be the set of simple reflections, namely s i is the image in W = N∕T of

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} I_{i-1} & & & \\\\ & \\,0\\,&1& \\\\ &1 &\\,0\\, & \\\\ & & &I_{n-1-i} \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equb.gif)

We will prove in Theorem 27.1 below that this (B, N, I) is a Tits' system. The proof will require introducing a root system into GL(n, F). Of course, we have already done this if ![
$$F = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq12.gif), but let us revisit the definitions in this new context.

Let ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq13.gif) be the group of rational characters of T. In case F is a finite field, we don't want any torsion in ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq14.gif); that is, we want ![
$$\\chi \\in {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq15.gif) to have infinite order so that ![
$$\\mathbb{R} \\otimes {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq16.gif) will be nonzero. So we define an element of X ∗(T) to be a character of ![
$$T\(\\overline{F}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq17.gif), the group of diagonal matrices in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\overline{F}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq18.gif), where ![
$$\\overline{F}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq19.gif) is the algebraic closure of F, of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\,t_{1}\\, & & \\\\ & \\,\\ddots\\, & \\\\ & & \\,t_{n}\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\longmapsto t_{1}^{k_{1} }\\ldots t_{n}^{k_{n} }, }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(27.5)

where ![
$$k_{i} \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq20.gif). Then ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq21.gif), so ![
$$\\mathcal{V} = \\mathbb{R} \\otimes {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq22.gif).

As usual, we write the group law in X ∗(T) additively.

In this context, by a root of T in G we mean an element α ∈ X ∗(T) such that there exists a group isomorphism x α of F onto a subgroup X α of G consisting of unipotent matrices such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ t\\,x_{\\alpha }\(\\lambda \)\\,{t}^{-1} = x_{ \\alpha }\\big\(\\alpha \(t\)\\,\\lambda \\big\),\\qquad t \\in T,\\,\\lambda \\in F. }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(27.6)

(Strictly speaking, we should require that this identity be true as an equality of morphisms from the additive group into G.) There are n 2 − n roots, which may be described explicitly as follows. If ![
$$1 \\leqslant i, j \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq23.gif) and i≠j, let

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\alpha _{ij}\(t\) = t_{i}\\,t_{j}^{-1} }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(27.7)

when t is as in (27.5). Then ![
$$\\alpha _{ij} \\in {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq24.gif), and if E ij is the matrix with 1 in the i, j position and 0's elsewhere, and if

![
$$\\displaystyle{x_{\\alpha }\(\\lambda \) = I + \\lambda E_{ij},}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equc.gif)

then (27.6) is clearly valid. The set Φ consisting of α ij is a root system; we leave the reader to check this but in fact it is identical to the root system of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq25.gif) or its maximal compact subgroup ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) already introduced in Chap.​ 18 when ![
$$n = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq27123.gif). Let Φ + consist of the "positive roots" α ij with i < j, and let Σ consist of the "simple roots" α i,i+1. We will sometimes denote the simple reflections s i = s α,where α = α i,i+1.

Suppose that α is a simple root. Let T α ⊂ T be the kernel of α. Let M α be the centralizer of T α, and let P α be the subgroup generated by B and M α. By abuse of language, P α is called a minimal parabolic subgroup. Observe that it is a parabolic subgroup since it contains the Borel subgroup. Strictly speaking it is not minimal amoung the parabolic subgroups, since the Borel itself is smaller. However it is minimal among non-Borel parabolic subgroups, and it is commonly called a minimal parabolic. in Chap.​ 30.) We have a semidirect product decomposition ![
$$P_{\\alpha } = M_{\\alpha }U_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq28123.gif), where U α is the group generated by the x β(λ) with ![
$$\\beta {\\in \\varPhi }^{+} -\\{ \\alpha \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq29123.gif). For example, if n = 4 and α = α23, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{T_{\\alpha } = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} t_{1} & & & \\\\ & t_{2} & & \\\\ & & t_{2} & \\\\ & & & t_{4} \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},\\quad M_{\\alpha } = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} \\,{\\ast}\\,& & & \\\\ &\\,{\\ast}\\, &\\,{\\ast}\\, & \\\\ &\\,{\\ast}\\,&\\,{\\ast}\\,& \\\\ & & &\\,{\\ast}\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equd.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{P_{\\alpha } = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} \\,{\\ast}\\,&\\,{\\ast}\\,&\\,{\\ast}\\,&\\,{\\ast}\\,\\\\ &\\,{\\ast}\\, &\\,{\\ast}\\, &\\,{\\ast}\\, \\\\ &\\,{\\ast}\\,&\\,{\\ast}\\,&\\,{\\ast}\\,\\\\ & & &\\,{\\ast}\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},\\quad U_{\\alpha } = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} 1&\\,{\\ast}\\,&\\,{\\ast}\\,&\\,{\\ast}\\,\\\\ &1 & &\\,{\\ast}\\, \\\\ & &1&\\,{\\ast}\\,\\\\ & & &1 \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Eque.gif)

where ∗ indicates an arbitrary value.

Lemma 27.1.

Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) for any field F, and let other notations be as above. If s is a simple reflection, then ![
$$B \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(s\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq31123.gif) is a subgroup of G.

Proof.

First, let us check this when n = 2. In this case, there is only one simple root s α where α = α12. We check easily that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{C}\(s_{\\alpha }\) = Bs_{\\alpha }B = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a&b\\\\ c &d \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(2,F\)\\,\\Big\\vert \\,c\\neq 0\\right \\},}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equf.gif)

so ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(s_{\\alpha }\) \\cup B = G$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq32123.gif).

In the general case, both ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(s_{\\alpha }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) and B are subsets of P α. We claim that their union is all of P α. Both double cosets are right-invariant by U α since U α ⊂ B, so it is sufficient to show that ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(s_{\\alpha }\) \\cup B \\supset M_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq34123.gif). Passing to the quotient in ![
$$P_{\\alpha }/U_{\\alpha }\\mathop{\\cong}M_{\\alpha }\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{GL}\(2\) \\times {\({F}^{\\times }\)}^{n-2}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq35.gif), this reduces to the case n = 2 just considered. □

We have an action of W on Φ as in Chap.​ 20. This action is such that if ω ∈ N represents the Weyl group element w ∈ W, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\omega x_{\\alpha }\(\\lambda \){\\omega }^{-1} \\in x_{ w\(\\alpha \)}\(F\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(27.8)

Other notations, such as the length function ![
$$l: W\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq36.gif), will be as in that chapter.

Lemma 27.2.

Let G = GL (n, F) for any field F, and let other notations be as above. If α is a simple root and w ∈ W such that w(α) ∈ Φ + , then ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\)\\,\\mathcal{C}\(s\) = \\mathcal{C}\(ws\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq37.gif) .

Proof.

We will show that

![
$$\\displaystyle{wBs \\subseteq BwsB.}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equg.gif)

If this is known, then multiplying both left and right by B gives ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\)\\,\\mathcal{C}\(s\) = BwBsB \\subseteq BwsB = \\mathcal{C}\(ws\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq38.gif). The other inclusion is obvious, so this is sufficient. Let ω and σ be representatives of w and s as cosets in N∕T = W, and let b ∈ B. We may write ![
$$b = tx_{\\alpha }\(\\lambda \)u$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq39.gif), where t ∈ T, λ ∈ F, and u ∈ U α. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\omega b\\sigma = \\omega t{\\omega }^{-1} \\cdot \\omega x_{ \\alpha }\(\\lambda \){\\omega }^{-1} \\cdot \\omega \\sigma \\cdot {\\sigma }^{-1}u\\sigma.}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equh.gif)

We have ![
$$\\omega t{\\omega }^{-1} \\in T \\subset B$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq40.gif) since ![
$$\\omega \\in N = N\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq41.gif). We have ![
$$\\omega x_{\\alpha }\(\\lambda \){\\omega }^{-1} \\in x_{w\(\\alpha \)}\(F\) \\subset B$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq42.gif) using (27.8) and the fact that w(α) ∈Φ +. We have ![
$${\\sigma }^{-1}u\\sigma \\in U_{\\alpha } \\subset B$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq43.gif) since M α normalizes U α and σ ∈ M α. We see that ωbσ ∈ BwsB as required. □

Proposition 27.1.

Let G = GL (n, F) for any field F, and let other notations be as above. If w, w′ ∈ W are such that l(ww′) = l(w) + l(w′), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{C}\(ww^{\\prime}\) = \\mathcal{C}\(w\) \\cdot \\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Proof.

It is sufficient to show that if l(w) = r, and if ![
$$w = s_{1}\\ldots s_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq44.gif) is a decomposition into simple reflections, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathcal{C}\(w\) = \\mathcal{C}\(s_{1}\)\\ldots \\mathcal{C}\(s_{r}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

(27.9)

Indeed, assuming we know this fact, let ![
$$w^{\\prime} = s^{\\prime}_{1}\\ldots s^{\\prime}_{r^{\\prime}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq45.gif) be a decomposition into simple reflections with r′ = l(r′). Then ![
$$s_{1}\\ldots s_{r}s^{\\prime}_{1}\\ldots s^{\\prime}_{r^{\\prime}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq46.gif) is a decomposition of ww′ into simple reflections with l(ww′) = r \+ r′, so

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{C}\(ww^{\\prime}\) = \\mathcal{C}\(s_{1}\)\\ldots \\mathcal{C}\(s_{r}\)\\,\\mathcal{C}\(s_{1}^{\\prime}\)\\ldots \\mathcal{C}\(s_{r^{\\prime}}^{\\prime}\) = \\mathcal{C}\(w\)\\,\\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equj.gif)

To prove (27.9), let s r = s α, and let ![
$$w_{1} = s_{1}\\ldots s_{r-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq47.gif). Then ![
$$l\(w_{1}s_{\\alpha }\) = l\(w_{1}\) + 1$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq48.gif), so by Propositions 20.2 and 20.5 we have ![
$$w^{\\prime}\(\\alpha \) {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq49.gif). Thus, Lemma 27.2 is applicable and ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\) = \\mathcal{C}\(w_{1}\)\\,\\mathcal{C}\(s_{r}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq50.gif). By induction on r, we have ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w_{1}\) = \\mathcal{C}\(s_{1}\)\\ldots \\mathcal{C}\(s_{r-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq51.gif) and so we are done. □

Theorem 27.1.

With G = GL (n, F) and B, N, I as above, (B, N, I) is a Tits' system in G.

Proof.

Only Axiom TS3 requires proof; the others can be safely left to the reader. Let α ∈Σ such that s = s α.

First, suppose that w(α) ∈ Φ +. In this case, it follows from Lemma 27.2 that wBs ⊂ BwsB.

Next suppose that ![
$$w\(\\alpha \){\\not\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq52.gif). Then ![
$$ws_{\\alpha }\(\\alpha \) = w\(-\\alpha \) = -w\(\\alpha \) {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq53.gif), so we may apply the case just considered, with ws α replacing w, to see that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ wsBs \\subset Bw{s}^{2}B = BwB. }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(27.10)

By Lemma 27.1, ![
$$B \\cup BsB$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq54.gif) is a group containing a representative of the coset of s ∈ N∕T, so ![
$$B \\cup BsB = sB \\cup sBsB$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq55.gif) and thus

![
$$\\displaystyle{Bs \\subset sB \\cup sBsB.}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Using (27.10),

![
$$\\displaystyle{wBs \\subset wsB \\cup wsBsB \\subset BwsB \\cup BwB.}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equl.gif)

This proves Axiom TS3. □

As a second example of a Tits' system, let K be a compact connected Lie group, and let G be its complexification. Let T be a maximal torus of K, let ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq56.gif) be the complexification of T, and let B be the Borel subgroup of G as constructed in Chap.​ 26. Let N be the normalizer in G of ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq57.gif), and let I be the set of simple reflections in W = N∕T. We will prove that (B, N, I) is a Tits' system in G, closely paralleling the proof just given for GL(n, F). In fact, if ![
$$F = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq58.gif) and ![
$$K = \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq59.gif), so ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq60.gif), the two examples, including the method of proof, exactly coincide.

The key to the proof is the construction of the minimal parabolic subgroup P α corresponding to a simple root α ∈Σ. Chap.​ 30.) Let T α be the kernel of α in T. The centralizer ![
$$C_{K}\(T_{\\alpha }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq61.gif) played a key role in Chap.​ 18, particularly in the proof of Theorem 18.1, where a homomorphism ![
$$i_{\\alpha }: \\mathrm{SU}\(2\)\\longrightarrow C_{K}\(T_{\\alpha }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq62.gif) was constructed. This homomorphism extends to a homomorphism, which we will also denote as i α, of the complexification ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq63.gif) into the centralizer ![
$$C_{G}\(T_{\\alpha }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq64.gif) of T α in G. Let P α be the subgroup generated by ![
$$i_{\\alpha }\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq65.gif) and B. Let M α be the group generated by ![
$$i_{\\alpha }\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq66.gif) and ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq67.gif). Finally, let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{u}_{\\alpha } =\\bigoplus _{ \\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{c} \\beta {\\in \\varPhi }^{+} \\\\ \\beta \\neq \\alpha \\end{array} $}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }\\;.}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equm.gif)

If ![
$$\\beta _{1},\\beta _{2} \\in \\{ \\beta {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\,\\vert \\,\\beta \\neq \\alpha \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq68.gif), then ![
$$\\beta _{1} + \\beta _{2}\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq69.gif), and if β1 \+ β2 is a root, it is also in ![
$$\\{\\beta {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\,\\vert \\,\\beta \\neq \\alpha \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq70.gif). It follows from this observation and Proposition 18.4 that ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq71.gif) is closed under the Lie bracket; that is, it is a complex Lie algebra of the Lie algebra denoted ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq72.gif) in Chap.​ 26. Theorem 26.2 (iii) shows that it is the Lie algebra of a complex Lie subgroup U α of G.

Proposition 27.2.

Let G be the complexification of the compact connected Lie group K, let α be a simple positive root of G with respect to a fixed maximal torus T of K, and let other notations be as above. Then M α normalizes U α .

Proof.

It is clear that B normalizes U α, so we need to show that ![
$$i_{\\alpha }\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq73.gif) normalizes U α. If ![
$$\\gamma \\in \\{ \\beta {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\,\\vert \\,\\beta \\neq \\alpha \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq74.gif) and δ = α or − α, then γ + δ≠0, and if γ + δ ∈Φ, then ![
$$\\gamma + \\delta \\in \\{ \\beta {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\,\\vert \\,\\beta \\neq \\alpha \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq75.gif). Thus ![
$$\[\\mathfrak{X}_{\\pm \\alpha },\\mathfrak{X}_{\\gamma }\] \\subseteq \\mathfrak{u}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq76.gif), and since by Theorem 18.1 and Proposition 18.8 the Lie algebra of ![
$$i_{\\alpha }\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq77.gif) is generated by ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq78.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{-\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq79.gif), it follows that the Lie algebra of ![
$$i_{\\alpha }\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq80.gif) normalizes the Lie algebra of U α. Since both groups are connected, it follows that ![
$$i_{\\alpha }\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq81.gif) normalizes U α.

□

Since M α normalizes U α, we may define P α to be the semidirect product M α U α. An analog of Lemma 27.1 is true in this context.

Lemma 27.3.

Let G be the complexification of the compact connected Lie group K, and let other notations be as above. If s is a simple reflection, then ![
$$B \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(s\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq82.gif) is a subgroup of G.

Proof.

Indeed, if s = s α, then ![
$$B \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(s\) = P_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq83.gif). From Theorem 18.1, the group M α contains a representative of s ∈ N∕T, so it is clear that ![
$$B \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(s\) \\subset P_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq84.gif). As for the other inclusion, both B and ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(s\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq85.gif) are invariant under right multiplication by U α, so it is sufficient to show that ![
$$M_{\\alpha } \\in B \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(s\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq86.gif). Moreover, both B and ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(s\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq87.gif) are invariant under right multiplication by ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq88.gif), so it is sufficient to show that ![
$$i_{\\alpha }\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\) \\subset B \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(s\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq89.gif). This is identical to Lemma 27.1 except that we work with ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq90.gif) instead of GL(2,F). We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{i_{\\alpha }\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a&b\\\\ c &d \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} B &\\mbox{ if $c = 0$ ,}\\\\ \\mathcal{C}\(s\) &\\mbox{ if $c\\neq 0$.} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equn.gif)

This completes the proof. □

Theorem 27.2.

Let G be the complexification of the compact connected Lie group K. With B, N, I as above, (B, N, I) is a Tits' system in G.

Proof.

The proof of this is identical to Theorem 27.1. The analog of Lemma 27.2 is true, and the proof is the same except that we use Lemma 27.3 instead of Lemma 27.1. All other details are the same. □

Now that we have two examples of Tits' systems, let us prove the Bruhat decomposition.

Theorem 27.3.

Let (B, N, I) be a Tits' system within a group G, and let W be the corresponding Weyl group. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ G =\\bigcup _{w\\in W}BwB, }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(27.11)

and this union is disjoint.

Proof.

Let us show that ![
$$\\bigcup _{w\\in W}\\mathcal{C}\(w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq91.gif) is a group. It is clearly closed under inverses. We must show that it is closed under multiplication.

Let us consider ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w_{1}\) \\cdot \\mathcal{C}\(w_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq92.gif), where ![
$$w_{1},\\,w_{2} \\in W$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq93.gif). We show by induction on l(w 2) that this is contained in a union of double cosets. If l(w 2) = 0, then w 2 = 1 and the assertion is obvious. If l(w 2) > 0, write w 2 = sw 2′, where s ∈ I and l(w 2′) < l(w 2). Then, by Axiom TS3, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{C}\(w_{1}\) \\cdot \\mathcal{C}\(w_{2}\) = Bw_{1}Bsw_{2}^{\\prime}B \\subset Bw_{1}Bw_{2}^{\\prime}B \\cup Bw_{1}sBw_{2}^{\\prime}B,}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equo.gif)

and by induction this is contained in a union of double cosets.

We have shown that the right-hand side of (27.11) is a group, and since it clearly contains B and N, it must be all of G by Axiom TS5.

It remains to be shown that the union (27.11) is disjoint. Of course, two double cosets are either disjoint or equal, so assume that ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\) = \\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq94.gif), where w, w′ ∈ W. We will show that w = w′.

Without loss of generality, we may assume that ![
$$l\(w\) \\leqslant l\(w^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq95.gif), and we proceed by induction on l(w). If l(w) = 0, then w = 1, and so ![
$$B = \\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq96.gif). Thus, in N∕T, a representative for w′ will lie in B. Since ![
$$B \\cap N = T$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq97.gif), this means that w′ = 1, and we are done in this case. Assume therefore that l(w) > 0 and that whenever ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w_{1}\) = \\mathcal{C}\(w_{1}^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq98.gif) with l(w 1) < l(w) we have ![
$$w_{1} = w_{1}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq99.gif).

Write w = w″s, where s ∈ I and l(w″) < l(w). Thus ![
$$w^{\\prime\\prime}s \\in \\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq100.gif), and since s has order 2, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{w^{\\prime\\prime} \\in \\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}\)s \\subset \\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}\) \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}s\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equp.gif)

by Axiom TS3. Since two double cosets are either disjoint or equal, this means that either

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime\\prime}\) = \\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}\)\\qquad\\text{or}\\qquad\\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime\\prime}\) = \\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}s\).}$$](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equq.gif)

Our induction hypothesis implies that either w″ = w′ or w″ = w′s. The first case is impossible since ![
$$ l\(w^{\\prime\\prime}\) < l\(w\) \\leqslant l\(w^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq1101.gif). Therefore w″ = w′s. Hence w = w″s = w′, as required. □

We return to the second example of a Tits' system. Let K be a compact connected Lie group, G its complexification. Let B be the standard Borel subgroup, containing a maximal torus ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq101.gif), with ![
$$T = T_{\\mathbb{C}} \\cap K$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq102.gif) the maximal torus of K. The group (26.6) which is usually denoted N will be denoted U (in this chapter only).

The flag manifold X = K∕T may be identified with ![
$$G/T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq103.gif) as in Theorem 26.4. We will use the Bruhat decomposition ![
$$G =\\bigoplus BwB$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq104.gif) to look more closely at X.

By Theorem 26.4, X is a complex manifold. It is compact since it is a continuous image of K. We may decompose ![
$$X =\\bigcup Y _{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq105.gif) where w runs through the Weyl group and Y w = BwB∕B. Let us begin by looking more closely at Y w . Let ![
$$U_{+}^{w} = U \\cap wU{w}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq106.gif) and ![
$$U_{-}^{w} = U \\cap wU_{-}{w}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq107.gif). The Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}_{+}^{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq108.gif) is the intersection of the Lie algebras of U and wUw −1, so

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{u}_{+}^{w} =\\bigoplus _{ \\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\cap {w\\varPhi }^{+}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha },}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equr.gif)

and similarly

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{u}_{+}^{w} =\\bigoplus _{ \\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\cap {w\\varPhi }^{-}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equs.gif)

Proposition 27.3.

The map u ↦ uwB is a bijection of U − w onto Y w .

Proof.

Clearly BwB∕B = UwB∕B. Moreover if u, u′ ∈ U then uwB = u′wB if and only if ![
$${u}^{-1}u^{\\prime} \\in U_{+}^{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq109.gif). We need to show that every coset in U∕U + w has a unique representative from U − +. This follows from Theorem 26.2 (iv). □

The orbits of B under the left action of B on X are the Y w . So the closure of Y w is a union of other Y u with u ∈ W. Which ones? We recall the Bruhat order that was introduced in Chap.​ 25. If ![
$$w = s_{i_{1}}\\ldots s_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq110.gif) is a reduced decomposition, then ![
$$u \\leqslant w$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq111.gif) if and only if u obtained by eliminating some of the factors. In other words, there is a subsequence ![
$$\(j_{1},\\ldots,j_{l}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq112.gif) of ![
$$\(i_{1},\\ldots,i_{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq113.gif) with ![
$$u = s_{j_{1}}\\ldots s_{j_{l}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq114.gif). It was shown in Proposition 25.4 that this definition does not depend on the decomposition ![
$$w = s_{i_{1}}\\ldots s_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq115.gif). Moreover, we may always arrange that ![
$$u = s_{j_{1}}\\ldots s_{j_{l}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq116.gif) is a reduced decomposition.

Our goal is to prove that Y u is contained in the closure of Y w if and only if ![
$$u \\leqslant v$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq1170.gif) in the Bruhat order. To prove this, we introduce the Bott-Samelson varieties. If ![
$$1 \\leqslant i \\leqslant r$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq117.gif), where r is the semisimple rank of K, that is, the number of simple reflections, let P i be minimal parabolic subgroup generated by s i and B.

Proposition 27.4.

The minimal parabolic ![
$$P_{i} = C\(1\) \\cup C\(s_{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq118.gif) . The quotient P i ∕B is diffeomorphic to the projective line ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq119.gif) .

Proof.

By Lemma 27.1, C(1) ∪ C(s i ) is a group, so ![
$$P_{i} = C\(1\) \\cup C\(s_{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq120.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq121.gif) is simply-connected, the injection ![
$$i_{\\alpha _{k}}: \\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq122.gif) as in Proposition 18.8 induces a homomorphism ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq123.gif) whose image is in ![
$$P_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq124.gif). Since ![
$$i_{\\alpha _{i}}\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq125.gif) contains s i , we have ![
$$P_{i} = i_{\\alpha _{i}}\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)B$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq126.gif). Therefore P i ∕B in bijection with ![
$$i_{\\alpha _{i}}\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq127.gif) modulo its intersection with B. The quotient of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq128.gif) by its Borel subgroup is the projective line ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq129.gif). □

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{w} = \(i_{1}, \\ldots,i_{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq130.gif), define a right action of B k on ![
$$P_{i_{1}} \\times \\ldots \\times P_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq131.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(p_{1}, \\ldots,p_{k}\) \\cdot \(b_{1}, \\ldots, b_{k}\) = \(p_{1}b_{1}, b_{1}^{-1}p_{ 2}b_{2}, \\ldots, b_{k-1}^{-1}p_{ k}b_{k}\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

(27.12)

where ![
$$p_{j} \\in P_{i_{j}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq132.gif) and b j ∈ B. We are mainly interested in the case where ![
$$\\mathfrak{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq133.gif) is a reduced word. The quotient ![
$$Z_{\\mathfrak{w}} = \(P_{i_{1}} \\times \\ldots \\times P_{i_{k}}\)/{B}^{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq134.gif) is called a Bott-Samelson variety. We also have a map ![
$$Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}\\longrightarrow Z_{\\mathfrak{w}^{\\prime}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq135.gif) where ![
$$\\mathfrak{w}^{\\prime} = \(i_{1},\\ldots,i_{k-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq136.gif) in which the orbit of ![
$$\(p_{1},\\ldots,p_{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq137.gif) goes to the orbit of ![
$$\(p_{1},\\ldots,p_{k-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq138.gif). This map is a fibration in which the typical fiber is ![
$$P_{i_{k}}/B\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{P}}^{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq139.gif). Thus the Bott-Samelson variety is obtained by successive fiberings of ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq140.gif). In particular it is a compact manifold.

We have a map ![
$$\\tau: Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}\\longrightarrow X$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq141.gif) induced by the map ![
$$\(p_{1},\\ldots,p_{k}\)\\longmapsto p_{1}\\ldots p_{k}B$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq142.gif). It is clearly well-defined. Let X w be the closure of Y w in X. It is called a Schubert variety. We will show that the image of ![
$$Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq143.gif) in X is precisely X w . Although we will not discuss this point, both ![
$$Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq144.gif) and X w are algebraic varieties. The variety ![
$$Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq145.gif) is less canonical, since it depends on the choice of a reduced word ![
$$\\mathfrak{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq146.gif). It is, however, easier to work with. For example ![
$$Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq147.gif) is smooth, whereas X w can be singular.

Bott-Samelson varieties play a key role in many aspects of the theory. The map τ is a birational equivalence, so they resolve the singularities of the Schubert varieties. They are used in Demazure's calculation of the action of T on the spaces of sections of line bundles on X restricted to X w as Demazure characters.

Theorem 27.4.

The image of τ is X w . The Schubert variety X w is the union of the Y u for ![
$$u \\leqslant w$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq1480.gif) in the Bruhat order.

Proof.

Since C(s i ) is dense in P i , the set ![
$$C\(s_{i_{1}}\) \\times \\ldots \\times C\(s_{i_{k}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq148.gif) is dense in ![
$$P_{i_{1}} \\times \\ldots \\times P_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq149.gif). Its image in X is ![
$$C\(s_{i_{1}}\)\\ldots C\(s_{i_{k}}\) = C\(w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq150.gif) by (27.9), and so the image of ![
$$C\(s_{i_{1}}\) \\times \\ldots \\times C\(s_{i_{k}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq151.gif) is Y w , and it is dense in ![
$$\\tau \(Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq152.gif). On the other hand, the image of ![
$$\\tau \(Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq153.gif) is closed since ![
$$Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq154.gif) is compact. Thus ![
$$\\tau \(Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq155.gif) is the closure of Y w , which by definition is X w .

Now since ![
$$P_{i} = C\(1\) \\cup C\(s_{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq156.gif), it is clear that τ(Z w ) is the union of the ![
$$C\(s_{j_{1}}\)\\ldots C\(s_{j_{l}}\)/B$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq157.gif) as (j 1,..., j l ) runs through the subwords of (i 1,..., i k ). If ![
$$u = s_{j_{1}}\\ldots s_{j_{l}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq158.gif) is a reduced decomposition, then by (27.9) this is C(u)∕B, and so we obtain every Y u for ![
$$u \\leq w$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq159.gif). If the decomposition is not reduced, it is still a union of C(v)∕B for ![
$$v \\leqslant u$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq160.gif), as follows easily from (27.3). □

The Borel-Weil theorem realizes an irreducible representation of a compact Lie group or its complexification as an action on the space of sections of a holomorphic line bundle on the flag variety. This will be our next topic. The Bruhat decomposition will play a role in the discussion insofar as we will need to know that the big Bruhat cell Bw 0 B is dense in G.

If (π, V ) is a complex representation of the compact connected Lie group K, then it follows from the definition of the complexification G that π has a unique extension to an analytic representation ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq161.gif). Similarly, the contragredient representation ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }: K\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\({V }^{{\\ast}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq162.gif) may be extended to an analytic representation of G. Let λ be the highest weight of π. By Proposition 22.8, the highest weight of ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq163.gif) is ![
$$\\hat{\\lambda } = -w_{0}\\lambda $$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq164.gif), where w 0 is the long element of the Weyl group W.

Now let X = G∕B be the flag variety. We will construct a line bundle ![
$$\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq165.gif) over X. This is a complex analytic manifold together with an analytic map ![
$$p: \\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\\longrightarrow X$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq166.gif). The fibers of p are one-dimensional complex vector spaces. Moreover every point x ∈ X has a neighborhood U such that the p −1(U) is a trivial bundle over U. This means that there is a complex analytic homeomorphism ![
$$\\psi: {p}^{-1}\(U\)\\longrightarrow U \\times \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq167.gif) such that the composition of ψ with the projection ![
$$U \\times \\mathbb{C}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq168.gif) is p.

To construct ![
$$\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq169.gif), define a right action of B on ![
$$G \\times \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq170.gif), by ![
$$\(g,\\varepsilon \)b = \(gb,\\hat{\\lambda }\(b\)\\varepsilon \)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq171.gif) for b ∈ B and ![
$$\(g,\\varepsilon \) \\in G \\times \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq172.gif). Then ![
$$\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq173.gif) is the quotient ![
$$\(G \\times \\mathbb{C}\)/B$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq174.gif). We will denote the orbit of ![
$$\(g,\\varepsilon \)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq175.gif) by ![
$$\[g,\\varepsilon \]$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq176.gif), so if b ∈ B then ![
$$\[g,\\varepsilon \] = \[gb,\\hat{\\lambda }\(b\)\\varepsilon \]$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq177.gif). The map ![
$$p: \\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\\longrightarrow X$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq178.gif) sends ![
$$\[g,\\varepsilon \]$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq179.gif) to gB. We leave it to the reader to check that this is a line bundle.

A section of ![
$$\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq180.gif) is a holomorphic map ![
$$s: X\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq181.gif) such that p ∘ s is the identity on X. It is well-known (and part of the Riemann-Roch theorem) that the space ![
$$\\varGamma \(\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq182.gif) of sections is finite-dimensional. We have compatible actions of G on X and on ![
$$\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq183.gif) by left translation: if γ ∈ G then ![
$$\\gamma: X\\longrightarrow X$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq184.gif) sends gB to γgB and ![
$$\\gamma: \\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq185.gif) sends ![
$$\[g,\\varepsilon \]$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq186.gif) to ![
$$\[\\gamma g,\\varepsilon \]$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq187.gif). Specifying a section is equivalent to giving a holomorphic map ![
$$\\phi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq188.gif) such that ![
$$\\phi \(gb\) =\\hat{ \\lambda }\(b\)\\phi \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq189.gif); the last condition is needed so that ![
$$s\(gB\) = \[g,\\phi \(g\)\]$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq190.gif) is well-defined. So ![
$$\\varGamma \(\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq191.gif) is isomorphic to the vector space H(λ) of such holomorphic maps ϕ.

The compatibility is that these actions commute with p. One says that ![
$$\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq192.gif) is an equivariant line bundle. Now we have an action of G on sections as follows. If ![
$$s \\in \\varGamma \(\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq193.gif) and ![
$$\\gamma \\in G$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq194.gif) then γs is the section ![
$$\\gamma s\(gx\) = \\gamma \(s\({\\gamma }^{-1}x\)\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq195.gif) for x ∈ X. This is equivalent to the action γϕ(g) = ϕ(γ−1 g) on H(λ).

Theorem 27.5.

(Borel-Weil) The space ![
$$\\varGamma \(\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq196.gif) is zero unless λ is dominant. If λ is dominant, then ![
$$\\varGamma \(\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq197.gif) is irreducible as a G-module, with highest weight λ.

Proof.

We will follow the now-familiar strategy of identifying the N-fixed vectors in the module. We will take for granted the well-known fact that the space of sections ![
$$\\varGamma \(\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq198.gif) is finite-dimensional. See Gunning and Rossi [60], Corollary 10 on page 241. Assume that ![
$$\\varGamma \(\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq199.gif) is nonzero. Let ϕ be the highest weight vector for some irreducible submodule. Then by Theorem 26.5 we have ϕ(ng) = ϕ(g) for ϕ ∈ H(λ), so ![
$$\\phi \(nw_{0}b\) =\\hat{ \\lambda }\(b\)\\,\\phi \(w_{0}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq200.gif). Thus ϕ is determined up to a constant on Nw 0 B = Bw 0 B. This is the big Bruhat cell, and it is open and dense in X. So ϕ is zero unless ϕ(w 0)≠0 and we may normalize it so ![
$$\\phi \(nw_{0}b\) =\\hat{ \\lambda }\(b\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq201.gif). This shows that there can be (up to scalar multiple) at most one N-fixed vector, and therefore ![
$$\\varGamma \(\\mathcal{L}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq202.gif), which we are assuming to be nonzero, is irreducible. Also, since ϕ is the highest weight vector, we can use it to compute the highest weight. Let ![
$$t \\in T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq203.gif). Then ![
$$t\\phi \(w_{0}\) = \\phi \({t}^{-1}w_{0}\) = \\phi \(w_{0} \\cdot w_{0}^{-1}{t}^{-1}w_{0}\) =\\hat{ \\lambda }\(w_{0}^{-1}{t}^{-1}w_{0}\) = \\lambda \(t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq204.gif). So by Theorem 26.5 the highest weight in the unique irreducible submodule of ![
$$H\(\\lambda \)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq205.gif) is λ. In particular λ is dominant.

We have yet to show that if λ is dominant then H(λ) is nonzero. The issue is whether the section whose existence on the big cell Bw 0 B follows from the above considerations can be extended to the entire group. We will accomplish this by exhibiting a G-equivariant map ![
$$V \\longrightarrow H\(\\lambda \)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq206.gif). y Proposition 22.8, the highest weight in ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\({V }^{{\\ast}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq207.gif) is ![
$$\\hat{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq208.gif), so if θ ∈ V ∗ is the highest weight vector then ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }\(b\)\\theta =\\hat{ \\lambda }\(b\)\\theta $$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq209.gif) for b ∈ B. Let us denote the dual pairing ![
$$V \\times {V }^{{\\ast}}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq210.gif) by ![
$$\(v,{v}^{{\\ast}}\)\\mapsto \\left \\langle v,{v}^{{\\ast}}\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq211.gif). Define a map v ↦ ϕ v from v to the space of holomorphic functions on G by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\phi _{v}\(g\) = \\left \\langle \\pi \({g}^{-1}\)v,\\theta \\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equt.gif)

We have ![
$$\\phi _{v}\(gb\) =\\hat{ \\lambda }\(b\)\\phi _{v}\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq212.gif) since the left-hand side is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\phi _{v}\(g\) = \\left \\langle \\pi \({b}^{-1}\)\\pi \({g}^{-1}\)v,\\theta \\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle \\pi \({g}^{-1}\)v,\\pi \(b\)\\theta \\right \\rangle =\\hat{ \\lambda }\(b\)\\left \\langle \\pi \({g}^{-1}\)v,\\theta \\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equu.gif)

So ϕ v ∈ H(λ). It is clear that ![
$$\\phi _{\\gamma v}\(g\) = \\phi _{v}\({\\gamma }^{-1}g\) = \(\\gamma \\phi _{v}\)\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq213.gif), so the map v ↦ ϕ v is equivariant. □

Exercises

Exercise 27.1.

Explain why Y w has complex dimension l(w), or real dimension 2l(w). Also explain why Y w is open in X w . Since X w is a union of Y w and subsets of lower dimension, we may say that l(w) is the dimension of the Schubert variety X w .

If W is a finite Weyl group then W has a longest element w 0. By the last exercise, the Bruhat cell Bw 0 B is the largest in the sense of dimension. It is therefore called the big Bruhat cell.

Exercise 27.2.

Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq214.gif). Show that g = (g ij ) ∈ G is in the big Bruhat cell if and only if all the bottom left minors

![
$$\\displaystyle{g_{n,1},\\qquad \\left \\vert \\begin{array}{cc} g_{n-1,1} & g_{n-1,2} \\\\ g_{n,1} & g_{n,2} \\end{array} \\right \\vert,\\qquad \\left \\vert \\begin{array}{ccc} g_{n-2,1} & g_{n-2,2} & g_{n-2,3} \\\\ g_{n-1,1} & g_{n-1,2} & g_{n-1,3} \\\\ g_{n,1} & g_{n,2} & g_{n,3} \\end{array} \\right \\vert,\\qquad \\ldots }$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equv.gif)

are nonzero. If n = 3, give a similar interpretation of all the Bruhat cells.

Exercise 27.3.

Show for an arbitrary reduced word that the fiber τ−1(x) of the Bott-Samelson map τ is a single point for x in general position. ("General position" means that this is true on a dense open subset of X w .)

Exercise 27.4.

Let M be a manifold. Suppose that M has an open contractible subset Ω whose complement is a union of submaniolds of codimension ![
$$\\geq 2$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq215.gif). Show that M is simply-connected. Use this to give another proof of 23.7, that the flag manifold is simply-connected.

Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq216.gif). We give a concrete interpretation of Bott-Samelson variety as follows. The group G acts on the set ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq217.gif) of flags ![
$$\\mathbf{U} = \(U_{0},\\ldots,U_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq218.gif) where ![
$$U_{0} \\subset U_{1} \\subset \\ldots \\subset U_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq219.gif) and each U i is an i-dimensional vector subspace of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq220.gif). We fix a flag ![
$$\\mathbf{V} = \(V _{0},\\ldots,V _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq221.gif), which we will call the standard flag. The Borel subgroup B may be taken to be the stabilizer of V. The parabolic subgroup P i is the set of g ∈ G such that gV j = V j for all j≠i.

Thus let ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq222.gif) be the set of flags. We have a bijection between X = G∕B and ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq223.gif) in which the coset gB is in bijection with the flag g V. In the same way we will describe ![
$$Z_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq224.gif) as the parameter space for a set of configurations of subspaces of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq225.gif) that are more complicated than simple flags but very similar in spirit. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{w} = \(s_{h_{1}},s_{h_{2}},\\ldots,s_{h_{k}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq226.gif) be a reduced word representing ![
$$w = s_{h_{1}}\\ldots s_{h_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq227.gif), and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{Z}_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq228.gif) be the set of sequences ![
$$\\mathcal{U} = \({\\mathbf{U}}^{0},\\ldots,{\\mathbf{U}}^{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq229.gif) of flags ![
$${\\mathbf{U}}^{i} = \(U_{0}^{i},\\ldots,U_{n}^{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq230.gif) such U 0 = V is the standard flag and ![
$$U_{j}^{i} = U_{j-1}^{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq231.gif) except when j = h i .

Exercise 27.5.

Let p 1,..., p k in G. Let U 0 =V, and define a sequence ![
$$\\mathcal{U} = \({\\mathbf{U}}^{0},\\ldots,{\\mathbf{U}}^{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq232.gif) of flags by

![

](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_Equw.gif)

Show that ![
$$\\mathcal{U}\\in \\mathfrak{Z}_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq233.gif) if and only if ![

](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq234.gif). Moreover if ![
$$\(p_{1}^{\\prime},\\ldots,p_{k}^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq235.gif) is another element of ![
$$P_{h_{1}} \\times \\ldots \\times P_{h_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq236.gif) then we have ![
$$p_{1}^{\\prime}\\ldots p_{i}^{\\prime}\\;{\\mathbf{U}}^{i-1} ={ \\mathbf{U}}^{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq237.gif) if and only if (p 1,..., p k ) and ![
$$\(p_{1}^{\\prime},\\ldots,p_{k}^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq238.gif) differ by an element of B k under the right action (27.12). Conclude that the map ![
$$P_{h_{1}} \\times \\ldots \\times P_{h_{k}}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{Z}_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq239.gif) induces a bijection ![
$$Z_{w}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{Z}_{\\mathfrak{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq240.gif).

Exercise 27.6.

Show that there is a commutative diagram

where the horizontal maps are the bijections described above, ϕ is the canonical map Z w → X w , and Φ is the map that sends the configuration ![
$$\({\\mathbf{U}}^{0},\\ldots,{\\mathbf{U}}^{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq241.gif) to its last flag U k .

For example, let n = 3. Then ![
$${\\mathbf{U}}^{0} = \(V _{0},V _{1},V _{2},V _{3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq242.gif) will be the standard flag. We have ![
$$U_{j}^{i} = U_{j-1}^{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq243.gif) except when (i, j) = (1, 1), (2, 2) or (3, 1), which means that we may find subspaces W 1, U 2 and U 1 of dimensions 1, 2, 1 such that ![
$${\\mathbf{U}}^{1} = \(V _{0},W_{1},V _{2},V _{3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq244.gif), ![
$${\\mathbf{U}}^{2} = \(V _{0},W_{1},U_{2},V _{3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq245.gif) and ![
$${\\mathbf{U}}^{3} = \(V _{0},U_{1},U_{2},U_{3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq246.gif). Thus we arrive at the following configuration:

Vertical lines represent inclusions, subscripts dimensions. The Bott-Samelson space is a moduli space for such configurations, where ![
$$\(V _{0},V _{1},V _{2},V _{3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq247.gif) are fixed as the standard flag.

We may compute the fibers of the map ϕ by solving the equivalent problem of computing the fibers of Φ. In this case, the question is, given U 0 (which is fixed) and U 3 (representing a point in X w ), how many such configurations are there? The only unknown is W 1, but from the above inclusions, W 1 may be characterized as the intersection of V 2 and U 2. This will be a one-dimensional space (hence the only possibility for W 1) except in the case where U 2 = V 2. Thus if x ∈ X w is in general position the fiber ϕ−1(x) consists of a single point. But if U 2 = V 2 then W 1 can be any one-dimensional subspace of U 2, so the fiber ϕ−1(x) is ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_27_Chapter_IEq248.gif).

# 28. Symmetric Spaces

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

We have devoted some attention to an important class of homogeneous spaces of Lie groups, namely flag manifolds. Another important class is that of symmetric spaces. In differential geometry, a symmetric space is a Riemannian manifold in which around every point there is an isometry reversing the direction of every geodesic. Symmetric spaces generalize the non-Euclidean geometries of the sphere (compact with positive curvature) and the Poincaré upper half-plane (noncompact with negative curvature). Like these two examples, they tend to come in pairs, one compact and one noncompact. They were classified by E. Cartan.

We have devoted some attention to an important class of homogeneous spaces of Lie groups, namely flag manifolds. Another important class is that of symmetric spaces. In differential geometry, a symmetric space is a Riemannian manifold in which around every point there is an isometry reversing the direction of every geodesic. Symmetric spaces generalize the non-Euclidean geometries of the sphere (compact with positive curvature) and the Poincaré upper half-plane (noncompact with negative curvature). Like these two examples, they tend to come in pairs, one compact and one noncompact. They were classified by E. Cartan.

Our approach to symmetric spaces will be to alternate the examination of examples with an explanation of general principles. In a few places (Remark 28.2, Theorem 28.2, Theorem 28.3, Proposition 28.3, and in the next chapter Theorem 29.5) we will make use of results from Helgason [66]. This should cause no problems for the reader. These are facts that need to be included to complete the picture, though we do not have space to prove them from scratch. They can be skipped without serious loss of continuity. In addition to Helgason [66], a second indispensable work on (mainly Hermitian) symmetric spaces is Satake [145].

It turns out that symmetric spaces (apart from Euclidean spaces) are constructed mainly as homogeneous spaces of Lie groups. In this chapter, an involution of a Lie group G is an automorphism of order 2.

Proposition 28.1.

Suppose that G is a connected Lie group with an involution θ. Assume that the group

![
$$\\displaystyle{ K =\\{ g \\in G\\,\\vert \\,\\theta \(g\) = g\\} }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(28.1)

is a compact Lie subgroup. In this setting, ![
$$X = G/K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq1.gif) is a symmetric space.

The involution θ is called a Cartan involution of G, and the involution it induces on the Lie algebra is called a Cartan involution of Lie(G).

Proof.

Clearly, G acts transitively on G∕K, and K is the stabilizer of the base point x 0, that is, the coset K ∈ G∕K. We put a positive definite inner product on the tangent space ![
$$T_{x_{0}}\(X\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq2.gif) that is invariant under the compact group K and also under θ. If x ∈ X, then we may find g ∈ G such that g(x 0) = x, and g induces an isomorphism ![
$$T_{x_{0}}\(X\)\\longrightarrow T_{x}\(X\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq3.gif) by which we may transfer this positive definite inner product to T x (X). Because the inner product on ![
$$T_{x_{0}}\(X\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq4.gif) is invariant under K, this inner product does not depend on the choice of g. Thus, X becomes a Riemannian manifold. The involution θ induces an automorphism of X that preserves geodesics through x 0, reversing their direction, so X is a symmetric space. □

We now come to a striking algebraic fact that leads to the appearance of symmetric spaces in pairs. The involution θ induces an involution of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathrm{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq5.gif). The + 1 eigenspace of θ is, of course, ![
$$\\mathfrak{k} = \\mathrm{Lie}\(K\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq6.gif). Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq7.gif) be the − 1 eigenspace. Evidently,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\[\\mathfrak{k},\\mathfrak{k}\] \\subset \\mathfrak{k},\[\\mathfrak{k},\\mathfrak{p}\] \\subset \\mathfrak{p},\[\\mathfrak{p},\\mathfrak{p}\] \\subset \\mathfrak{k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equa.gif)

From this, it is clear that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathfrak{g}_{c} = \\mathfrak{k} + i\\mathfrak{p} }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(28.2)

is a Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq8.gif). We observe that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq9.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq10.gif) have the same complexification; that is, ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathfrak{g} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{g}_{c} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq11.gif).

The appearance of these two Lie algebras with a common complexification means that symmetric spaces come in pairs. To proceed further, we will make some assumptions, which we now explain.

Hypothesis 28.1.

Let G be a noncompact connected semisimple Lie group with Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq12.gif) . Let θ be an involution of G such that the fixed subgroup K of θ is compact, as in Proposition 28.1 . Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq13.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq14.gif) be the + 1 and − 1 eigenspaces of θ on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq15.gif) , and let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq16.gif) be the Lie algebra defined by ( 28.2 ). We will assume that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq17.gif) is the Lie algebra of a second Lie group G c that is compact and connected. Let ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq18.gif) be the complexification of G c (Theorem 24.1 ). We assume that the Lie algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq19.gif) is the differential of a Lie group embedding ![
$$G\\longrightarrow G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq20.gif) and that θ extends to an automorphism of ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq21.gif) , also denoted θ, which stabilizes G c .

This means G and G c can be embedded compatibly in the complex analytic group ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq22.gif). The involution θ extends to ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq23.gif) and induces an involution on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq24.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{X + iY \\longmapsto X - iY,X \\in \\mathfrak{k},Y \\in \\mathfrak{p}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equb.gif)

The last statement in Hypothesis 28.1 means that this θ is the differential of an automorphism of G c . As a consequence the homogeneous space ![
$$X_{c} = G_{c}/K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq25.gif) is also a symmetric space, again by Proposition 28.1. The symmetric spaces X and X c , one noncompact and the other compact, are said to be in duality with each other.

Remark 28.1.

We will see in Theorem 28.3 that every noncompact semisimple Lie group admits a Cartan involution θ such that this hypothesis is satisfied. Our proof of Theorem 28.3 will not be self-contained, but we do not really need to rely on it as motivation because we will give numerous examples in this chapter and the next where Hypothesis 28.1 is satisfied.

Remark 28.2.

We do not specify G, K, and G c up to isomorphism by this description since different K could correspond to the same pair G and θ. But K is always connected and contains the center of G (Helgason [66], Chap. VI, Theorem 1.1 on p. 252). If we replace G by a semisimple covering group, the center increases, so we must also enlarge K, and the quotient space G∕K is unchanged. Hence, there is a unique symmetric space of noncompact type determined by the real semisimple Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq26123.gif). By contrast, the symmetric space of compact type is not uniquely determined by ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq27123.gif). There could be a finite number of different choices for G c and K resulting in different compact symmetric spaces that have the same universal covering space. We will not distinguish a particular one as the dual of X but say that any one of these compact spaces is in duality with X. See Helgason [66], Chap. VII, for a discussion of this point and other subtleties in the compact case.

Suppose that ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) and K = SO(n). Then ![

Let us obtain concrete realizations of the symmetric spaces G∕K and G c ∕K in Example 28.1. The group ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq43.gif) acts on the cone ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq44.gif) of positive definite real symmetric matrices by the action

![
$$\\displaystyle{ g: x\\longmapsto g\\,{x\\,}^{t}g. }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(28.3)

On the other hand, the group ![

Proposition 28.2.

Suppose that ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq48.gif) or ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq49.gif).

(i)

There exists g ∈ SO(n) such that g x t g is diagonal.

(ii)

The actions of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq50.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq51.gif) are transitive.

(iii)

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq52.gif) be the vector space of real symmetric matrices. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\) =\\{{ \\mathrm{e}}^{X}\\,\\vert \\,X \\in \\mathfrak{p}\\},\\mathcal{E}_{ n}\(\\mathbb{R}\) =\\{{ \\mathrm{e}}^{iX}\\,\\vert \\,X \\in \\mathfrak{p}\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equc.gif)

See Theorem 45.6 in Chap.  for an application.

Proof.

If ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq53.gif), then (i) is, of course, just the spectral theorem. However, if ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq54.gif), this statement may be less familiar. It is instructive to give a unified proof of the two cases. Give ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq55.gif) its usual inner product, so ![
$$\\left \\langle u,v\\right \\rangle =\\sum _{i}u_{i}\\overline{v_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq56.gif).

Let λ be an eigenvalue of x. We will show that the eigenspace ![
$$V _{\\lambda } =\\{ v \\in {\\mathbb{C}}^{n}\\,\\vert \\,xv = \\lambda v\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq57.gif) is stable under complex conjugation. Suppose that v ∈ V λ. If ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq58.gif), then both x and λ are real, and simply conjugating the identity xv = λv gives ![
$$x\\overline{v} = \\lambda \\overline{v}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq59.gif). On the other hand, if ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq60.gif), then ![
$$\\overline{x} {={ }^{t}x}^{-1} = {x}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq61.gif) and |λ| = 1 so ![
$$\\overline{\\lambda } = {\\lambda }^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq62.gif). Thus, conjugating xv = λv gives ![
$${x}^{-1}\\overline{v} = {\\lambda }^{-1}\\overline{v}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq63.gif), which implies that ![
$$x\\overline{v} = \\lambda \\overline{v}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq64.gif).

Now we can show that ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq65.gif) has an orthonormal basis consisting of eigenvectors v 1,...,v n such that ![
$$v_{i} \\in {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq66.gif). The adjoint of x with respect to the standard inner product is x or x −1 depending on whether ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq67.gif) or ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq68.gif). In either case, x is the matrix of a normal operator—one that commutes with its adjoint—and ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq69.gif) is the orthogonal direct sum of the eigenspaces of x. Each eigenspace has an orthonormal basis consisting of real vectors. Indeed, if v 1,...,v k is a basis of V λ, then since we have proved that ![
$$\\overline{v_{i}} \\in V _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq70.gif), the space is spanned by ![
$$\\frac{1} {2}\(v_{i} + \\overline{v_{i}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq71.gif) and ![
$$\\frac{1} {2i}\(v_{i} -\\overline{v_{i}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq72.gif); selecting a basis from this spanning set and applying the usual Gram–Schmidt orthogonalization process gives an orthonormal basis of real vectors.

In either case, we see that ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq73.gif) has an orthonormal basis consisting of eigenvectors v 1,...,v n such that ![
$$v_{i} \\in {\\mathbb{R}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq74.gif). Let ![
$$xv_{i} = \\lambda _{i}v_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq75.gif). Then, if ![
$$k \\in \\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq76.gif) is the matrix with columns x i and d is the diagonal matrix with diagonal entries λ i , we have xk = kd so ![
$${k}^{-1}xk = \\delta $$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq77.gif). As ![
$${k}^{-1} {= }^{t}k$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq78.gif) we may take the matrix ![
$$g = {k}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq79.gif). If the determinant of k is − 1, we can switch the sign of the first entry without harm, so we may assume k ∈SO(n) and (i) is proved.

For (i), we have shown that each orbit in ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq80.gif) or ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq81.gif) contains a diagonal matrix. The eigenvalues are positive real if ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq82.gif) or of absolute value 1 if ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq83.gif). In either case, applying the action (28.3) with ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq84.gif) or ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq85.gif) diagonal will reduce to the identity, proving (ii). For (iii), we use (ii) to write an arbitrary element ![
$$x$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq86.gif) of ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq87.gif) or ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq88.gif) as kdk −1, where k is orthogonal and d diagonal. The eigenvalues of d are either positive real if ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq89.gif) or of absolute value 1 if ![
$$x \\in \\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq90.gif). Thus, d = e Y , where Y is real or purely imaginary, and x = e X or e iX , where ![
$$X = kY {k}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq91.gif) or ![
$$-ikY {k}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq92.gif) is real. □

In the action (28.3) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq93.gif) or U(n) on ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$

](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq96.gif) and ![

](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq97.gif) with ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$

](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq99.gif), respectively. The actions of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq100.gif) and ![

](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq101.gif) on ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$

](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq104.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq105.gif) be the subspaces of matrices of determinant 1. Then the actions of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq106.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq107.gif) on ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq108.gif) and ![
