](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq109.gif) are transitive, so we may identify ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{R}\) = \\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)/\\mathrm{SO}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq110.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{R}\) = \\mathrm{SU}\(n\)/\\mathrm{SO}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq111.gif). Thus, we obtain concrete models of the dual symmetric spaces ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq112.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq113.gif).

We say that a symmetric space X is reducible if its universal cover decomposes into a product of two lower-dimensional symmetric spaces. If X is irreducible (i.e., not reducible) and not a Euclidean space, then it is classified into one of four types, called I, II, III, and IV. We next explain this classification.

Example 28.2.

If K 0 is a compact Lie group, then K 0 is itself a compact symmetric space, the geodesic reversing involution being ![
$$k\\longmapsto {k}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq114.gif). A symmetric space of this type is called Type II.

Example 28.3.

Suppose that G is itself obtained by complexification of a compact connected Lie group K 0 and that the involution θ of G is the automorphism of G as a real Lie group induced by complex conjugation. This means that on the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{k}_{0} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq115.gif) of G, where ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{0} = \\mathrm{Lie}\(K\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq116.gif), the involution θ sends ![
$$X + iY \\longmapsto X - iY$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq117.gif), ![
$$Y \\in \\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq118.gif). The fixed subgroup of θ is K 0, and the symmetric space is G∕K 0. A symmetric space of this type is called Type IV. It is noncompact.

We will show that the Type II and Type IV symmetric spaces are in duality. For this, we need a couple of lemmas. If R is a ring and e,f ∈ R we call e and f orthogonal central idempotents if ex = xe and fx = xf for all x ∈ R, e 2 = e, f 2 = f, and ef = fe.

Lemma 28.1.

(Peirce decomposition) Let R be a ring, and let e and f be orthogonal central idempotents. Assume that ![
$$1 = e + f$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq119.gif) . Then Re and Rf are (two-sided) ideals of R, and each is a ring with identity elements e and f, respectively. The ring R decomposes as Re ⊕ Rf.

Proof.

It is straightforward to see that Re is closed under multiplication and is a ring with identity element e and similarly for Rf. Since ![
$$1 = e + f$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq120.gif), we have ![
$$R = Re + Rf$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq121.gif), and ![
$$Re \\cap Rf = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq122.gif) because if ![
$$x \\in Re \\cap Rf$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq123.gif) we can write ![
$$x = re = r^{\\prime}f$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq124.gif), so ![
$$x = r^{\\prime}{f}^{2} = ref = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq125.gif). □

Lemma 28.2.

Regard ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathbb{C} = \\mathbb{C} \\otimes _{\\mathbb{R}}\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq126.gif) as a ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq127.gif) -algebra with scalar multiplication ![
$$a\(x \\otimes y\) = ax \\otimes y$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq128.gif), ![
$$a \\in \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq129.gif) . Then ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq130.gif) and ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\oplus \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq131.gif) are isomorphic as ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq132.gif) -algebras.

Proof.

Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{ e = \\tfrac{1} {2}\(1 \\otimes 1 + i \\otimes i\),\\qquad f = \\tfrac{1} {2}\(1 \\otimes 1 - i \\otimes i\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(28.4)

It is easily checked that e and f are orthogonal central idempotents whose sum is the identity element 1 ⊗ 1, and so we obtain a Peirce decomposition by Lemma 28.1. The ideals generated by e and f are both isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq133.gif). □

Theorem 28.1.

Let K 0 be a compact connected Lie group. Then the compact and noncompact symmetric spaces of Examples 28.2 and 28.3 are in duality.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq134.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq135.gif) be the Lie algebras of G and K 0, respectively. We have ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq136.gif). The involution ![
$$\\theta: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq137.gif) takes ![
$$a \\otimes X\\longrightarrow \\overline{a} \\otimes X$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq138.gif). By Lemma 28.2, we have ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0} \\oplus \\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq139.gif). Now θ induces the automorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\theta: a \\otimes b \\otimes X\\longrightarrow a \\otimes \\overline{b} \\otimes X,a,b \\in \\mathbb{C},\\,X \\in \\mathfrak{k}_{0}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equd.gif)

The + 1 and − 1 eigenspaces are spanned by vectors of the form ![
$$1 \\otimes 1 \\otimes X$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq140.gif) and 1 ⊗ i ⊗ X (![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq141.gif)), so the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq142.gif) as in (28.2) will be spanned by vectors of the form 1 ⊗ 1 ⊗ X and i ⊗ i ∘ X, and the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq143.gif) is ![
$$1 \\otimes 1 \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq144.gif).

Thus, with e and f as in (28.4), ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq145.gif) is the ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq146.gif)-linear span of ![
$$e \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq147.gif) and ![
$$f \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq148.gif). We can identify

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{g}_{c} = e \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0} \\oplus f \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathfrak{k}_{0} \\oplus \\mathfrak{k}_{0}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Eque.gif)

The involution θ interchanges these two components, and since ![
$$1 \\otimes 1 = e + f$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq149.gif), ![
$$\\mathfrak{k} = 1 \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq150.gif) embedded diagonally in ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}_{0} \\otimes \\mathfrak{k}_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq151.gif).

From this description, we see that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq152.gif) is the Lie algebra of K × K, which we take to be the group G c . The involution ![
$$\\theta: K \\times K\\longrightarrow K \\times K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq153.gif) is θ(x,y) = (y,x), and K is embedded diagonally. This differs from the description of the compact symmetric space of Type II in Example 28.2, but it is equivalent. We may see this as follows. We can map ![
$$K\\longrightarrow G_{c}/K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq154.gif) by ![
$$x\\longrightarrow \(x,1\)K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq155.gif). The involution sends this to ![
$$\(1,x\)K = \({x}^{-1},1\)K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq156.gif) since (x,x) ∈ K embedded diagonally. Thus, if we represent the cosets of G c ∕K this way, the symmetric space is parameterized by K, and the involution corresponds to ![
$$x\\longrightarrow {x}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq157.gif). □

If G∕K and G c ∕K are noncompact and compact symmetric spaces in duality, and if G∕K and G c ∕K are not of types IV and II, they are said to be of types III and I, respectively.

Theorem 28.2.

Let G be a noncompact, connected semisimple Lie group with an involution θ satisfying Hypothesis 28.1 . Then K is a maximal compact subgroup of G. Indeed, if K′ is any compact subgroup of G, then K′ is conjugate to a subgroup of K.

Proof.

This follows from Helgason [66], Theorem 2.1 of Chap. VI on page 246. (Note the hypothesis that K be compact in our Proposition 28.1.) The proof in [66] depends on showing that G∕K is a space of constant negative curvature. A compact group of isometries of such a space has a fixed point ([66], Theorem 13.1 of Chap. I on page 75). Now if K′ fixes xK ∈ G∕K, then ![
$${x}^{-1}K^{\\prime}x \\subseteq K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq158.gif). □

A semisimple real Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq159.gif) is compact if and only if the Killing form is negative definite. If this is the case, then ![
$$\\text{ad}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq160.gif) is contained in the Lie algebra of the compact orthogonal group with respect to this negative definite quadratic form, and it follows that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq161.gif) is the Lie algebra of a compact Lie group. A semisimple Lie algebra is simple if it has no proper nontrivial ideals.

Theorem 28.3.

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq162.gif) is a noncompact Lie algebra, then there exists a noncompact Lie group G with Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq163.gif) and a Cartan involution θ of G with fixed points that are a maximal subgroup K of G so that G∕K is a symmetric space of noncompact type. In particular, Hypothesis 28.1 is satisfied. If ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq164.gif) is simple, then G∕K is irreducible, and this construction gives a one-to-one correspondence between the simple real Lie algebras and the irreducible noncompact symmetric spaces of noncompact type.

Although we will not need this fact, it is very striking that the classification of irreducible symmetric spaces of noncompact type is the same as the classification of noncompact real forms of the semisimple Lie algebras.

Proof.

It follows from Helgason [66], Chap. III, Theorem 6.4 on p. 181, that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq165.gif) has a compact form; that is, a compact Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq166.gif) with an isomorphic complexification. It follows from Theorems 7.1 and 7.2 in Chap. III of [66] that we may arrange things so that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c} = \\mathfrak{k} + i\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq167.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{k} + \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq168.gif), where ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq169.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq170.gif) are the + 1 and − 1 eigenspaces of a Cartan involution θ, and that this Cartan involution is essentially unique. Let G c be the adjoint group of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq171.gif); that is, the group generated by exponentials of endomorphisms ad(X) with ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq172.gif). It is a compact Lie group with Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq173.gif)—see Helgason [66], Chap. II, Section 5. Thus, G c is a group of linear transformations of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq174.gif), but we extend them to complex linear transformations of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq175.gif), and so G c and the other groups ![
$$G,G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq176.gif), and K that we will construct will all be subgroups of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq177.gif). Let ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq178.gif) be the complexification of G c . The conjugation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq179.gif) with respect to ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq180.gif) induces an automorphism of ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq181.gif) as a real Lie group with a fixed-point set that can be taken to be G. The Cartan involution θ induces an involution of G with a fixed-point set K that is a subgroup with Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq182.gif). □

In Table 28.1, we give the classification of Cartan [31] of the Type I and Type III symmetric spaces. (The symmetric spaces of Type II and Type IV, as we have already seen, correspond to complex semisimple Lie algebras.)

In Table 28.1, the group SO∗(2n) consists of all elements of ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq184.gif) that stabilize the skew-Hermitian form

![
$$\\displaystyle{x_{1}\\overline{x_{n+1}} + x_{2}\\overline{x_{n+2}} +\\ldots +x_{n}\\overline{x_{2n}} - x_{n+1}\\overline{x_{1}} - x_{n+2}\\overline{x_{2}} -\\cdots - x_{2n}\\overline{x_{n}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equg.gif)

The subgroups ![
$$\\mathrm{S}\\big\(\\mathrm{O}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(q\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq185.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{S}\\big\(\\mathrm{U}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{U}\(q\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq186.gif) are the subgroups of ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq187.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{U}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq188.gif) consisting of elements of determinant 1. Cartan considered the special cases q = 1 significant enough to warrant independent classifications. The group ![
$$\\mathrm{S}\\big\(\\mathrm{O}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(1\)\\big\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{O}\(p\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq189.gif), and we have written K this way for types BII and DII.

For the exceptional groups, we have only described the Lie algebra of the maximal compact subgroup. We have given the real form from the classification of Tits [162]. In this classification, ![
$${}^{2}E_{6,2}^{16} {= }^{i}E_{6,r}^{d}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq190.gif), for example, where i, d, and r are numbers whose significance we will briefly discuss. They will all reappear in the next chapter.

The number i = 1 if the group is an inner form and 2 if it is an outer form. As we mentioned in Remark 24.1, real forms of G c are parameterized by elements of ![
$${H}^{1}\\big\(\\mathrm{Gal}\(\\mathbb{C}/\\mathbb{R}\),\\mathrm{Aut}\(G_{\\mathbb{C}}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq191.gif). If the defining co-cycle is in the image of

![
$$\\displaystyle{{H}^{1}\\big\(\\mathrm{Gal}\(\\mathbb{C}/\\mathbb{R}\),\\mathrm{Inn}\(G_{ c}\)\\big\)\\longrightarrow {H}^{1}\\big\(\\mathrm{Gal}\(\\mathbb{C}/\\mathbb{R}\),\\mathrm{Aut}\(G_{ c}\)\\big\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equh.gif)

where Inn(G c ) is the group of inner automorphisms, then the group is an inner form. Looking ahead to the next chapter, where we introduce the Satake diagrams, G is an inner form if and only if the symmetry of the Satake diagram, corresponding to the permutation ![
$$\\alpha \\longmapsto - \\theta \(\\alpha \)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq192.gif) of the relative root system, is trivial. Thus, from Fig. 29.​3, we see that SO(6,6) is an inner form, but the quasisplit group SO(7,5) is an outer form. For the exceptional groups, only E 6 admits an outer automorphism (corresponding to the nontrivial automorphism of its Dynkin diagram). Thus, for the other exceptional groups, this parameter is omitted from the notation.

The number r is the (real) rank—the dimension of the group ![
$$A =\\exp \(\\mathfrak{a}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq193.gif), where ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq194.gif) is a maximal Abelian subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq195.gif). The number d is the dimension of the anisotropic kernel, which is the maximal compact subgroup of the centralizer of A. Both A and M will play an extensive role in the next chapter.

We have listed the rank for the groups of classical type but not the exceptional ones since for those the rank is contained in the Tits' classification.

For classification matters we recommend Tits [162] supplemented by Borel [20]. The definitive classification in this paper, from the point of view of algebraic groups, includes not only real groups but also groups over p-adic fields, number fields, and finite fields. Knapp [106], Helgason [66], Onishchik and Vinberg [166], and Satake [144] are also very useful.

Example 28.4.

Consider ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)/\\mathrm{SO}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq196.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(2\)/\\mathrm{SO}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq197.gif). Unlike the general case of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)/\\mathrm{SO}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq198.gif) and SU(n)∕SO(n), these two symmetric spaces have complex structures. Specifically, ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq199.gif) acts transitively on the Poincaré upper half-plane ![
$$\\mathfrak{H} =\\{ z = x + iy\\,\\vert \\,x,y \\in \\mathbb{R},y > 0\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq200.gif) by linear fractional transformations:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\) \\ni \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a&b\\\\ c &d \\end{array} \\right \): z\\longmapsto \\frac{az + b} {cz + d}\\;.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equi.gif)

The stabilizer of the point ![
$$i \\in \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq201.gif) is ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq202.gif), so we may identify ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq203.gif) with ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)/\\mathrm{SO}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq204.gif). Equally, let ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq205.gif) be the Riemann sphere ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\cup \\{\\infty \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq206.gif), which is the same as the complex projective line ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq207.gif). The group ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq208.gif) acts transitively on ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq209.gif), also by linear fractional transformations:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{SU}\(2\) \\ni \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a & b\\\\ -\\bar{ b} &\\bar{a} \\end{array} \\right \): z\\longmapsto \\frac{az + b} {-\\bar{b}z +\\bar{ a}}\\,,\\vert a{\\vert }^{2}+\\vert b{\\vert }^{2} = 1.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equj.gif)

Again, the stabilizer of i is SO(2), so we may identify SU(2)∕SO(2) with ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq210.gif).

Both ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq211.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq212.gif) are naturally complex manifolds, and the action of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq213.gif) or ![
$$\\mathrm{SU}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq214.gif) consists of holomorphic mappings. They are examples of Hermitian symmetric spaces, which we now define. A Hermitian manifold is the complex analog of a Riemannian manifold. A Hermitian manifold is a complex manifold on which there is given a (smoothly varying) positive definite Hermitian inner product on each tangent space (which has a complex structure because the space is a complex manifold). The real part of this positive definite Hermitian inner product is a positive definite symmetric bilinear form, so a Hermitian manifold becomes a Riemannian manifold. A real-valued symmetric bilinear form B on a complex vector space V is the real part of a positive definite Hermitian form H if and only if it satisfies

![
$$\\displaystyle{B\(iX,iY \) = B\(X,Y \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equk.gif)

for if this is true it is easy to check that

![
$$\\displaystyle{H\(X,Y \) = \\tfrac{1} {2}\\big\(B\(X,Y \) - iB\(iX,Y \)\\big\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equl.gif)

is the unique positive definite Hermitian form with real part H. From this remark, a complex manifold is Hermitian by our definition if and only if it is Hermitian by the definition in Helgason [66].

A symmetric space X is called Hermitian if it is a Hermitian manifold that is homogeneous with respect to a group of holomorphic Hermitian isometries that is connected and contains the geodesic-reversing reflection around each point. Thus, if ![
$$X = G/K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq215.gif), the group G consists of holomorphic mappings, and if g(x) = y for x,y ∈ X, g ∈ X, then g induces an isometry between the tangent spaces at x and y.

The irreducible Hermitian symmetric spaces can easily be recognized by the following criterion.

Proposition 28.3.

Let ![
$$X = G/K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq216.gif) and ![
$$X_{c} = G_{c}/K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq217.gif) be a pair of irreducible symmetric spaces in duality. If one is a Hermitian symmetric space, then they both are. This will be true if and only if the center of K is a one-dimensional central torus Z. In this case, the rank of G c equals the rank of K.

In a nutshell, if K has a one-dimensional central torus, then there exists a homomorphism of ![
$$\\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq218.gif) into the center of K. The image of ![
$$\\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq219.gif) induces a group of isometries of X fixing the base point x 0 ∈ X corresponding to the coset of K. The content of the proposition is that X may be given the structure of a complex manifold in such a way that the maps on the tangent space at x 0 induced by this family of isometries correspond to multiplication by ![
$$\\mathbb{T}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq220.gif), which is regarded as a subgroup of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq221.gif).

Proof.

See Helgason [66], Theorem 6.1 and Proposition 6.2, or Wolf [176], Corollary 8.7.10, for the first statement. The latter reference has two other very interesting conditions for the space to be symmetric. The fact that G c and K are of equal rank is contained in Helgason [66] in the first paragraph of "Proof of Theorem 7.1 (ii), algebraic part" on p. 383. □

A particularly important family of Hermitian symmetric spaces are the Siegel upper half-spaces ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq222.gif), also known as Siegel spaces which generalize the Poincaré upper half-plane ![
$$\\mathfrak{H} = \\mathfrak{H}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq223.gif). We will discuss this family of examples in considerable detail since many features of the general case are already present in this example and are perhaps best understood with an example in mind.

In this chapter, if F is a field (always ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq224.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq225.gif)), the symplectic group is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n,F\) = \\left \\{g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(2n,F\)\\,\\vert \\,g\\,{J\\,}^{t}g = J\\right \\},J = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} & - I_{n} \\\\ I_{n}& \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equm.gif)

Write ![
$$g = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq226.gif), where A,B,C, and D are ![
$$n \\times n$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq227.gif) blocks. Multiplying out the condition g J t g = J gives the conditions

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\begin{array}{lll} A {\\cdot }^{t}B = B {\\cdot }^{t}A, &&C {\\cdot }^{t}D = D {\\cdot }^{t}C, \\\\ A {\\cdot }^{t}D - B {\\cdot }^{t}C = I,&&D {\\cdot }^{t}A - C {\\cdot }^{t}B = I. \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(28.5)

The condition g J t g = J may be expressed as ![
$$\(gJ\){\(}^{t}gJ\) = -I$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq228.gif), so gJ and t gJ are negative inverses of each other. From this, we see that t g is also symplectic, and so (28.5) applied to t g gives the further relations

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\begin{array}{lll} {}^{t}A \\cdot C {= }^{t}C \\cdot A, &&{}^{t}B \\cdot D {= }^{t}D \\cdot B, \\\\ {}^{t}A \\cdot D {-}^{t}C \\cdot B = I,&&{}^{t}D \\cdot A {-}^{t}B \\cdot C = I. \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(28.6)

If ![
$$A + iB \\in \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq229.gif), where the matrices A and B are real, then ![
$$A {\\cdot }^{t}A + B {\\cdot }^{t}B = I$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq230.gif) and ![
$$A {\\cdot }^{t}B = B {\\cdot }^{t}A$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq231.gif). Thus, if we take D = A and ![
$$C = -B$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq232.gif), then (28.5) is satisfied. Thus,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ A+iB\\longmapsto \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A &B\\\\ - B & A \\end{array} \\right \) }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(28.7)

maps U(n) into ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq233.gif) and is easily checked to be a homomorphism.

If W is a Hermitian matrix, we write W > 0 if W is positive definite.

If ![
$$\\varOmega \\subset {\\mathbb{R}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq234.gif) is any connected open set, we can form the tube domain over Ω. This is the set of all elements of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq235.gif) that has imaginary parts in Ω. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq236.gif) be the tube domain over ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq237.gif). Thus, ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq238.gif) is the space of all symmetric complex matrices ![
$$Z = X + iY$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq239.gif) where X and Y are real symmetric matrices such that Y > 0.

Proposition 28.4.

If ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq240.gif) and ![
$$g = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq241.gif) , then CZ + D is invertible. Define

![
$$\\displaystyle{ g\(Z\) = \(AZ + B\){\(CZ + D\)}^{-1}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(28.8)

Then ![
$$g\(Z\) \\in \\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq242.gif) , and ( 28.8 ) defines an action of ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq243.gif) on ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq244.gif) . The action is transitive, and the stabilizer of ![
$$iI_{n} \\in \\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq245.gif) is the image of U (n) under the embedding ( 28.7 ). If W is the imaginary part of g(Z) then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ W = {\({\\overline{Z}\\,}^{t}C {+ }^{t}D\)}^{-1}Y {\(CZ + D\)}^{-1}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

(28.9)

Proof.

Using (28.6), one easily checks that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\tfrac{1} {2i}\\big\(\({\\overline{Z}\\,}^{t}C {+ }^{t}D\)\(AZ + B\) - \({\\overline{Z}}^{t}A {+ }^{t}B\)\(CZ + D\)\\big\) = \\tfrac{1} {2i}\(Z -\\overline{Z}\) = Y, }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(28.10)

where Y is the imaginary part of Z. From this it follows that CZ \+ D is invertible since if it had a nonzero nullvector v, then we would have ![
$${}^{t}\\overline{v}Y v = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq246.gif), which is impossible since Y > 0.

Therefore, we may make the definition (28.8). To check that g(Z) is symmetric, the identity g(Z) = t g(Z) is equivalent to

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(AZ + B\)\({Z}^{t}C {+ }^{t}D\) = \({Z}^{t}A {+ }^{t}B\)\(CZ + D\)\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equn.gif)

which is easily confirmed using (28.5) and (28.6).

Next we show that the imaginary part W of g(Z) is positive definite. Indeed W equals ![
$$\\frac{1} {2i}\\big\(g\(Z\) -\\overline{g\(Z\)}\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq247.gif). Using the fact that ![
$$\\overline{g\(Z\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq248.gif) is symmetric and (28.10), this is

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\tfrac{1} {2i}\\big\(\(AZ + B\){\(CZ + D\)}^{-1} - {\({\\overline{Z}\\,}^{t}C {+ }^{t}D\)}^{-1}\({\\overline{Z}}^{t}A {+ }^{t}B\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equo.gif)

Simplifying this gives (28.9). From this it is clear that W is Hermitian and that W > 0. It is real, of course, though that is less clear from this expression. Since it is real and positive definite Hermitian, it is a positive definite symmetric matrix.

It is easy to check that ![
$$g\\big\(g^{\\prime}\(Z\)\\big\) = \(gg^{\\prime}\)\(Z\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq249.gif), so this is a group action. To show that this action is transitive, we note that if ![
$$Z = X + iY \\in \\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq250.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I & - X\\\\ & I \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equp.gif)

and this matrix takes Z to iY. Now if ![
$$h \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq251.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,g\\,& \\\\ &{\\,{}^{t}g}^{-1}\\, \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equq.gif)

and this matrix takes iY to iY ′, where Y ′ = g Y t g. Since Y > 0, we may choose g so that Y ′ = I. This shows that any element in ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq252.gif) may be moved to iI n , and the action is transitive.

To check that U(n) is the stabilizer of iI n is quite easy, and we leave it to the reader. □

Example 28.5.

By Proposition 28.4, we can identify ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq253.gif) with ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)/\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq254.gif). The fact that it is a Hermitian symmetric space is in accord with Proposition 28.3, since U(n) has a central torus. In the notation of Proposition 28.1, if ![
$$G = \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq255.gif) and ![
$$K = \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq256.gif) are embedded via (28.7), then the compact group G c is Sp(2n), where as usual Sp(2n) denotes ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\cap \\mathrm{U}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq257.gif).

We will investigate the relationship between Examples 28.1 and 28.5 using a fundamental map, the Cayley transform. For clarity, we introduce this first in the more familiar context of the Poincaré upper half-plane (Example 28.4), which is a special case of Example 28.5.

We observe that the action of G c = SU(2) on the compact dual ![
$$X_{c} = \\mathrm{SU}\(2\)/\\mathrm{SO}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq258.gif) can be extended to an action of ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq259.gif). Indeed, if we identify X c with the Riemann sphere ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq260.gif), then the action of SU(2) was by linear fractional transformations and so is the extension to ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq261.gif).

As a consequence, we have an action of ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq262.gif) on X c since ![
$$G \\subset G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq263.gif) and ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq264.gif) acts on X c . This is just the action by linear fractional transformations on ![
$$\\mathfrak{R} = \\mathbb{C} \\cup \\{\\infty \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq265.gif). There are three orbits: ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq266.gif), the projective real line ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{1}\(\\mathbb{R}\) = \\mathbb{R} \\cup \\{\\infty \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq267.gif), and the lower half-plane ![
$$\\overline{\\mathfrak{H}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq268.gif).

The Cayley transform is the element c ∈SU(2) given by

![
$$\\displaystyle{ c = \\tfrac{1} {\\sqrt{2i}}\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,1\\,& - i\\\\ 1 & \\;i \\end{array} \\right \),\\mathrm{so}\\quad {c}^{-1} = \\tfrac{1} {\\sqrt{2i}}\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\;i & i\\\\ - 1 &\\,1\\, \\end{array} \\right \). }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(28.11)

Interpreted as a transformation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq269.gif), the Cayley transform takes ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq270.gif) to the unit disk

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{D} =\\{ w \\in \\mathbb{C}\\,\\big\\vert \\,\\vert w\\vert < 1\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equr.gif)

Indeed, if ![
$$z \\in \\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq271.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{c\(z\) = \\frac{z - i} {z + i},}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equs.gif)

and since z is closer to i than to − i, this lies in ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq272.gif). The effect of the Cayley transform is shown in Fig. 28.1.

Fig. 28.1

The Cayley transform

The significance of the Cayley transform is that it relates a bounded symmetric domain ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq273.gif) to an unbounded one, ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq274.gif). We will use both ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq275.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq276.gif) together when thinking about the boundary of the noncompact symmetric space embedded in its compact dual.

Since ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq277.gif) acts on ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq278.gif), the group ![
$$c\\,\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)\\,{c}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq279.gif) acts on ![
$$c\(\\mathfrak{H}\) = \\mathfrak{D}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq280.gif). This group is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{SU}\(1,1\) = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,a\\,& b\\\\ \\bar{b} &\\,\\bar{a}\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\,\\Big\\vert \\,\\vert a{\\vert }^{2} -\\vert b{\\vert }^{2} = 1\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equt.gif)

The Cayley transform is generally applicable to Hermitian symmetric spaces. It was shown by Cartan and Harish-Chandra that Hermitian symmetric spaces could be realized on bounded domains in ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq281.gif). Piatetski-Shapiro [133] gave unbounded realizations. Korányi and Wolf [111, 112] gave a completely general theory relating bounded symmetric domains to unbounded ones by means of the Cayley transform.

Now let us consider the Cayley transform for ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq282.gif). Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq283.gif), ![
$$K = \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq284.gif), G c = Sp(2n), and ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq285.gif). Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{c = \\frac{1} {\\sqrt{2i}}\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I_{n}& - iI_{n} \\\\ I_{n}& iI_{n} \\end{array} \\right \),{c}^{-1} = \\frac{1} {\\sqrt{2i}}\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} iI_{n} &iI_{n} \\\\ - I_{n}& I_{n} \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equu.gif)

They are elements of Sp(2n). We will see that the scenario uncovered for ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq286.gif) extends to the symplectic group.

Our first goal is to show that ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq287.gif) can be embedded in its compact dual, a fact already noted when n = 1. The first step is to interpret ![
$$G_{c}/K$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq288.gif) as an analog of the Riemann sphere ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq289.gif), a space on which the actions of both groups ![
$$G$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq290.gif) and G c may be realized as linear fractional transformations. Specifically, we will construct a space ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq291.gif) that contains a dense open subspace ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq292.gif) that can be naturally identified with the vector space of all complex symmetric matrices. What we want is for ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq293.gif) to act on ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq294.gif), and if ![
$$g \\in G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq295.gif), with both ![
$$Z,g\(Z\) \\in \\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq296.gif), then g(Z) is expressed in terms of Z by (28.8).

Toward the goal of constructing ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq297.gif), let

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} P = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,h\\,& \\\\ &{\\,}^{t } {h}^{-1}\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,I\\,&X\\\\ & \\,I\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,h \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\),X \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\),X {= }^{t}X\\right \\}.& &{}\\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

(28.12)

This group is called the Siegel parabolic subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq298.gif). (The term parabolic subgroup will be formally defined in Chap. .) We will define ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq299.gif) to be the quotient ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}/P$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq300.gif). Let us consider how an element of this space can (usually) be regarded as a complex symmetric matrix, and the action of ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq301.gif) is by linear fractional transformations as in (28.8).

Proposition 28.5.

We have ![
$$PG_{c} = \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq302.gif) and ![
$$P \\cap G_{c} = cK{c}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq303.gif) .

Proof.

Indeed, P contains a Borel subgroup, the group B of matrices (28.12) with g upper triangular, so ![
$$PG_{c} = \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq304.gif) follows from the Iwasawa decomposition (Theorem 26.3). The group K is U(n) embedded via (28.7), and it is easy to check that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ cK{c}^{-1} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g& \\\\ &{}^{t}{g}^{-1} \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,g \\in \\mathrm{U}\(n\)\\right \\}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ13.gif)

(28.13)

It is clear that ![
$$cK{c}^{-1} \\subseteq P \\cap \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq305.gif). To prove the converse inclusion, it is straightforward to check that any unitary matrix in P is actually of the form (28.13), and so ![
$$P \\cap G_{c} \\subseteq cK{c}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq306.gif). □

We define ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n} = G_{\\mathbb{C}}/P$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq307.gif). We define ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq308.gif) to be the set of cosets gP, where ![
$$g = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq309.gif) and det(C) is nonsingular.

Lemma 28.3.

Suppose that

![
$$\\displaystyle{g = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \),g^{\\prime} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A^{\\prime}&B^{\\prime}\\\\ C^{\\prime} &D^{\\prime} \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equv.gif)

are elements of ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq310.gif) . Then gP = g′P if and only if there exists a matrix ![
$$h \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq311.gif) such that Ah = A′ and Ch = C′. If C is invertible, then AC −1 is a complex symmetric matrix. If this is true, a necessary and sufficient condition for gP = g′P is that C′ is also invertible and that ![
$$A{C}^{-1} = A^{\\prime}{\(C^{\\prime}\)}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq312.gif) .

Proof.

Most of this is safely left to the reader. We only point out the reason that AC −1 is symmetric. By (28.6), the matrix t CA is symmetric, so ![
$${}^{t}{C}^{-1} {\\cdot }^{t}CA \\cdot {C}^{-1} = A{C}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq313.gif) is also. □

Let ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq314.gif) be the vector space of ![
$$n \\times n$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq315.gif) complex symmetric matrices. By the Lemma 28.3, the map ![
$$\\sigma: \\mathcal{R}_{n}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq316.gif) defined by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sigma \(Z\) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} Z & - I\\\\ I & \\end{array} \\right \)P}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equw.gif)

is a bijection, and we can write

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sigma \(Z\) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \)P}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equx.gif)

if and only if ![
$$A{C}^{-1} = Z$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq317.gif).

Proposition 28.6.

If σ(Z) and ![
$$g\\big\(\\sigma \(Z\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq318.gif) are both in ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq319.gif) , where ![
$$g = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq320.gif) is an element of ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq321.gif) , then CZ + D is invertible and

![
$$\\displaystyle{g\\big\(\\sigma \(Z\)\\big\) = \\sigma \\big\(\(AZ + B\){\(CZ + D\)}^{-1}\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equy.gif)

Proof.

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{g\\big\(\\sigma \(Z\)\\big\) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,A\\,&B\\\\ C &\\,D\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} Z & - I\\\\ \\,I\\, & \\end{array} \\right \)P = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} AZ + B &\\; - A\\\\ CZ + D &\\; - C \\end{array} \\right \)P\\;.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equz.gif)

Since we are assuming this is in ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq322.gif), the matrix CZ \+ D is invertible by Lemma 28.3, and this equals ![
$$\\sigma \\big\(\(AZ + B\){\(CZ + D\)}^{-1}\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq323.gif). □

In view of Proposition 28.6 we will identify ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq324.gif) with its image in ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq325.gif). Thus, elements of ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq326.gif) become for us complex symmetric matrices, and the action of ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq327.gif) is by linear fractional transformations.

We can also identify ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq328.gif) with the compact symmetric space G c ∕K by means of the composition of bijections

![
$$\\displaystyle{G_{c}/K\\longrightarrow G_{c}/cK{c}^{-1}\\longrightarrow G_{ \\mathbb{C}}/P = \\mathfrak{R}_{n}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equaa.gif)

The first map is induced by conjugation by ![
$$c \\in G_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq329.gif). The second map is induced by the inclusion ![
$$G_{c}\\longrightarrow G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq330.gif) and is bijective by Proposition 28.5, so we may regard the embedding of ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq331.gif) into ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq332.gif) as an embedding of a noncompact symmetric space into its compact dual.

So far, the picture is extremely similar to the case where n = 1. We now come to an important difference. In the case of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq333.gif), the topological boundary of ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq334.gif) (or ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq335.gif)) in ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq336.gif) was just a circle consisting of a single orbit of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq337.gif) or even its maximal compact subgroup SO(2).

When ![
$$n \\geqslant 2$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq338.gif), however, the boundary consists of a finite number of orbits, each of which is the union of smaller pieces called boundary components. Each boundary component is a copy of a Siegel space of lower dimension. The boundary components are infinite in number, but each is a copy of one of a finite number of standard ones. Since the structure of the boundary is suddenly interesting when ![
$$n \\geqslant 2$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq3380.gif), we will take a closer look at it. For more information about boundary components, which are important in the theory of automorphic forms and the algebraic geometry of arithmetic quotients such as ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{Z}\)\\setminus \\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq339.gif), see Ash, Mumford, Rapoport, and Tai [11], Baily [13], Baily and Borel [14], and Satake [142, 144].

The first step is to map ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq340.gif) into a bounded region. Writing ![
$$Z = X + iY$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq341.gif), where X and Y are real symmetric matrices, ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq342.gif) if and only if Y > 0. So Z is on the boundary if Y is positive semidefinite yet has 0 as an eigenvalue. The multiplicity of 0 as an eigenvalue separates the boundary into several pieces that are separate orbits of G. (These are not the boundary components, which we will meet presently.)

If we embed ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq343.gif) into ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq344.gif), a portion of the border is at "infinity"; that is, it is in ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n} - \\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq345.gif). We propose to examine the border by applying cn, which maps ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq346.gif) into a region with a closure that is wholly contained in ℜ n .

Proposition 28.7.

The image of ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq347.gif) under c is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{D}_{n} =\\{ W \\in \\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }\\,\\vert \\,I -\\overline{W}W > 0\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equab.gif)

The group ![
$$c\\,\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)\\,{c}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq348.gif) , acting on ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq349.gif) by linear fractional transformations, consists of all symplectic matrices of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ \\overline{B } & \\overline{A} \\end{array} \\right \). }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ14.gif)

(28.14)

(Note that, since W is symmetric, ![
$$I -\\overline{W}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq350.gif) is Hermitian.)

Proof.

The condition on W to be in ![
$$c\(\\mathfrak{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq351.gif) is that the imaginary part of

![
$$\\displaystyle{{c}^{-1}\(W\) = -i\(W - I\){\(W + I\)}^{-1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equac.gif)

be positive definite. This imaginary part is

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & Y = -\\tfrac{1} {2}\\big\(\(W - I\){\(W + I\)}^{-1} + \(\\overline{W} - I\){\(\\overline{W} + I\)}^{-1}\\big\) = {}\\\\ & & -\\tfrac{1} {2}\\big\(\(W - I\){\(W + I\)}^{-1} + {\(\\overline{W} + I\)}^{-1}\(\\overline{W} - I\)\\big\), {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ15.gif)

where we have used the fact that both ![
$$\\overline{W}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq352.gif) and ![
$$\(\\overline{W} - I\){\(\\overline{W} + I\)}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq353.gif) are symmetric to rewrite the second term. This will be positive definite if and only if ![
$$\(\\overline{W} + I\)Y \(W + I\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq354.gif) is positive definite. This equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{-\\tfrac{1} {2}\\big\(\(\\overline{W} + I\)\(W - I\) + \(\\overline{W} - I\)\(W + I\)\\big\) = I -\\overline{W}W.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equad.gif)

Since ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq355.gif) maps ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq356.gif) into itself, ![
$$c\\,\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)\\,{c}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq357.gif) maps ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n} = c\(\\mathfrak{H}_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq358.gif) into itself. We have only to justify the claim that this group consists of the matrices of form (28.14). For ![
$$g = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \) \\in \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq359.gif) to have the property that c −1 g c is real, we need ![
$${c}^{-1}\\,g\\,c = \\overline{{c}^{-1}\\,g\\,c}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq360.gif), so

![
$$\\displaystyle{c\\,{\\overline{c}}^{-1}\\overline{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B \\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \)} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \)c\\,{\\overline{c}}^{-1},c\\,{\\overline{c}}^{-1} = \\sqrt{-i}\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 0 &I_{n} \\\\ I_{n}& 0 \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equae.gif)

This implies that ![
$$C = \\overline{B}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq361.gif) and ![
$$D = \\overline{A}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq362.gif). □

Proposition 28.8.

(i)

The closure of ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq363.gif) is contained within ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq364.gif) . The boundary of ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq365.gif) consists of all complex symmetric matrices W such that ![
$$I -\\overline{W}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq366.gif) is positive semidefinite but such that ![
$$\\det \(I -\\overline{W}W\) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq367.gif) .

(ii)

If W and W′ are points of the closure of ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq368.gif) in ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq369.gif) that are congruent modulo c G c −1 , then the ranks of ![
$$I -\\overline{W}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq370.gif) and ![
$$I -\\overline{W^{\\prime}}W^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq371.gif) are equal.

(iii)

Let W be in the closure of ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq372.gif) , and let r be the rank of ![
$$I -\\overline{W}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq373.gif) . Then there exists g ∈ c G c −1 such that g(W) has the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} W_{r}& \\\\ &I_{n-r} \\end{array} \\right \),W_{r} \\in \\mathfrak{D}_{n-r}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ16.gif)

(28.15)

Proof.

The diagonal entries in ![
$$\\overline{W}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq374.gif) are the squares of the lengths of the rows of the symmetric matrix W. If ![
$$I -\\overline{W}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq375.gif) is positive definite, these must be less than 1. So ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq376.gif) is a bounded domain within the set ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq377.gif) of symmetric complex matrices. The rest of (i) is also clear.

For (ii), if g ∈ c G c −1, then by Proposition 28.7 the matrix g has the form (28.14). Using the fact that both W and W′ are symmetric, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{I -\\bar{ W}^{\\prime}W = I - {\(\\bar{{W}\\,}^{t}B {+ }^{t}A\)}^{-1}\(\\bar{{W}\\,}^{t}\\bar{A} + \\overline{{}^{t}B}\)\(AW + B\){\(\\bar{B}W +\\bar{ A}\)}^{-1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equaf.gif)

Both W and W′ are in ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq378.gif), so by Proposition 28.6 the matrix ![
$$\\overline{B}W +\\bar{ A}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq379.gif) is invertible. Therefore, the rank of ![
$$I -\\overline{W^{\\prime}}W^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq380.gif) is the same as the rank of

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \(\\bar{{W}\\,}^{t}B {+ }^{t}A\)\(I -\\bar{ W}^{\\prime}W^{\\prime}\)\(\\bar{B}W +\\bar{ A}\) =& & {}\\\\ \(\\bar{{W}\\,}^{t}B {+ }^{t}A\)\(\\bar{B}W +\\bar{ A}\) - \(\\bar{{W}\\,}^{t}\\bar{A} + \\overline{{}^{t}B}\)\(AW + B\).& & {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ17.gif)

Using the relations (28.6), this equals ![
$$I -\\bar{ W}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq381.gif).

To prove (iii), note first that if ![
$$u \\in \\mathrm{U}\(n\) \\subset c\\,G\\,{c}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq382.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{c\\,G\\,{c}^{-1} \\ni \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,u\\,& \\\\ &\\,\\bar{u}\\, \\end{array} \\right \): W\\longmapsto u\\,{W\\,}^{t}u.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equag.gif)

Taking u to be a scalar, we may assume that − 1 is not an eigenvalue of W. Then W \+ I is nonsingular so ![
$$Z = {c}^{-1}W = -i\(W - I\){\(W + I\)}^{-1} \\in \\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq383.gif). Since Z is in the closure of ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq384.gif), it follows that ![
$$Z = X + iY$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq385.gif), where X and Y are real symmetric and Y is positive semidefinite. There exists an orthogonal matrix k such that ![
$$D = kY {k}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq386.gif) is diagonal with nonnegative eigenvalues. Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\gamma \(Z\) = iD,\\gamma = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,k\\,& \\\\ &\\,k\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I & - X\\\\ & I \\end{array} \\right \) \\in G.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equah.gif)

Thus, denoting ![
$$W^{\\prime} = c\\gamma {c}^{-1}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq387.gif),

![
$$\\displaystyle{W^{\\prime} = c\(iD\) = \(D - I\){\(D + I\)}^{-1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equai.gif)

Like D, the matrix W′ is diagonal, and its diagonal entries equal to 1 correspond to the diagonal entries of D equal to 0. These correspond to diagonal entries of ![
$$I -\\overline{W^{\\prime}}W^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq388.gif) equal to 0, so the diagonal matrices D and ![
$$I -\\overline{W^{\\prime}}W^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq389.gif) have the same rank. But by (ii), the ranks of ![
$$I -\\overline{W}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq390.gif) and ![
$$I -\\overline{W^{\\prime}}W^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq391.gif) are equal, so the rank of D is r. Clearly, W′ has the special form (28.15). □

Now let us fix r < n and consider

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{B}_{r} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} W_{r}& \\\\ &I_{n-r} \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,W_{r} \\in \\mathfrak{D}_{n-r}\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equaj.gif)

By Proposition 28.7, the subgroup of c G c −1 of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{c} \\begin{array}{cccc} A_{r}& 0 &B_{r}& 0 \\\\ 0 &I_{n-r}& 0 & 0 \\\\ \\overline{B_{r}}& 0 &\\overline{A_{r}}& 0 \\\\ 0 & 0 & 0 &I_{n-r} \\end{array} \\end{array} \\right \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equak.gif)

is isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2r, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq392.gif), and ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq393.gif) is homogeneous with respect to this subgroup. Thus, ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq394.gif) is a copy of the lower-dimensional Siegel space ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq395.gif) embedded into the boundary of ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq396.gif).

Any subset of the boundary that is congruent to a ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq397.gif) by an element of ![
$$cG{c}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq398.gif) is called a boundary component. There are infinitely many boundary components, but each of them resembles one of these standard ones. The closure of a boundary component is a union of lower-dimensional boundary components. L Now let us consider the union of the zero-dimensional boundary components, that is, the set of all elements equivalent to ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}_{0} =\\{ I_{n}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq399.gif). By Proposition 28.8, it is clear that this set is characterized by the vanishing of ![
$$I -\\overline{W}W$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq400.gif). In other words, this is the set ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq401.gif).

If D is a bounded convex domain in ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq402.gif), homogeneous under a group G of holomorphic mappings, the Bergman–Shilov boundary of D is the unique minimal closed subset B of the topological boundary ∂ D such that a function holomorphic on D and continuous on its closure will take its maximum (in absolute value). See Korányi and Wolf [112] for further information, including the fact that a bounded symmetric domain must have such a boundary.

Theorem 28.4.

The domain ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq403.gif) has ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq404.gif) as its Bergman–Shilov boundary.

Proof.

Let f be a holomorphic function on ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq405.gif) that is continuous on its closure. We will show that f takes its maximum on the set ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq406.gif). This is sufficient because G acts transitively on ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq407.gif), so the set ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq408.gif) cannot be replaced by any strictly smaller subspace with the same maximizing property.

Suppose ![
$$x \\in \\overline{\\mathfrak{D}_{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq409.gif) maximizes |f|. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq410.gif) be the boundary component containing x, so ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq411.gif) is congruent to some ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq412.gif). If r > 0, then noting that the restriction of f to ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq413.gif) is a holomorphic function there, the maximum modulus principle implies that f is constant on ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq414.gif) and hence |f| takes the same maximum value on the boundary of ![
$$\\mathfrak{B}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq415.gif), which intersects ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq416.gif). □

We now see that both the dual symmetric spaces ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq417.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq418.gif) appear in connection with ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq419.gif). The construction of ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq420.gif) involved building a tube domain over the cone ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq421.gif), while the dual ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq422.gif) appeared as the Bergman–Shilov boundary. (Since ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq423.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}{\(\\mathbb{R}\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq424.gif) are in duality, it is natural to extend the notion of duality to the reducible symmetric spaces ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq425.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq426.gif) and to say that these are in duality.)

This scenario repeats itself: there are four infinite families and one isolated example of Hermitian symmetric spaces that appear as tube domains over cones. In each case, the space can be mapped to a bounded symmetric domain by a Cayley transform, and the compact dual of the cone appears as the Bergman–Shilov boundary of the cone. These statements follow from the work of Koecher, Vinberg, and Piatetski-Shapiro [133], culminating in Korányi and Wolf [111, 112].

Let us describe this setup in a bit more detail. Let V be a real vector space with an inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq427.gif). A cone ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\\subset V$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq428.gif) is a convex open set consisting of a union of rays through the origin but not containing any line. The dual cone to ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq429.gif) is ![
$$\\{x \\in V \\vert \\left \\langle x,y\\right \\rangle > 0\\text{for all}y \\in \\mathcal{C}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq430.gif). If ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq431.gif) is its own dual, it is naturally called self-dual. It is called homogeneous if it admits a transitive automorphism group.

A homogeneous self-dual cone is a symmetric space. It is not irreducible since it is invariant under similitudes (i.e, transformations ![
$$x\\longmapsto \\lambda x$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq432.gif) where ![
$$\\lambda \\in {\\mathbb{R}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq433.gif)). The orbit of a typical point under the commutator subgroup of the group of automorphisms of the cone sits inside the cone, inscribed like a hyperboloid, though this description is a little misleading since it may be the constant locus of an invariant of degree > 2. For example, ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq434.gif) is the locus of det(x) = 1, and det is a homogeneous polynomial of degree n.

Homogeneous self-dual cones were investigated and applied to symmetric domains by Koecher, Vinberg, and others. A Jordan algebra over a field F is a nonassociative algebra over F with multiplication that is commutative and satisfies the weakened associative law ![
$$\(ab\){a}^{2} = a\(b{a}^{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq435.gif). The basic principle is that if ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\\subset V$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq436.gif) is a self-dual convex cone, then V can be given the structure of a Jordan algebra in such a way that ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq437.gif) becomes the set of squares in V.

In addition to Satake [145] Chap. I, Sect. 8, see Ash, Mumford, Rapoport, and Tai [11], Chap. II, for good explanations, including a discussion of the boundary components of a self-dual cone.

Example 28.6.

Let ![
$$D = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq438.gif), ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq439.gif), or ![
$$\\mathbb{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq440.gif). Let d = 1,2 or 4 be the real dimension of D. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{J}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq441.gif) be the set of Hermitian matrices in ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq442.gif), which is a Jordan algebra. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq443.gif) be the set of positive definite elements. It is a self-dual cone of dimension ![
$$n + \(d/2\)n\(n - 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq444.gif). It is a reducible symmetric space, but the elements of ![
$$g \\in \\mathcal{P}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq445.gif) such that multiplication by g as an ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq446.gif)-linear transformation of ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq447.gif) has determinant 1 is an irreducible symmetric space ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}^{\\circ }\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq448.gif) of dimension ![
$$n + \(d/2\)n\(n - 1\) - 1$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq449.gif). The dual ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{n}^{\\circ }\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq450.gif) is a compact Hermitian symmetric space.

Example 28.7.

The set defined by the inequality ![
$$x_{0} > \\sqrt{x_{1 }^{2 } + \\cdots + x_{n }^{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq451.gif) in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq452.gif) is a self-dual cone, which we will denote ![
$$\\mathcal{P}\(n,1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq453.gif). The group of automorphisms is the group of similitudes for the quadratic form ![
$$x_{0}^{2} - x_{1}^{2} -\\cdots - x_{n}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq454.gif). The derived group is SO(n,1), and its homogeneous space ![
$${\\mathcal{P}}^{\\circ }\(n,1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq455.gif) can be identified with the orbit of (1,0,...,0), which is the locus of the hyperboloid ![
$$x_{0}^{2} - x_{1}^{2} -\\cdots - x_{n}^{2} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq456.gif). The following special cases are worth noting: ![
$$\\mathcal{P}\(2,1\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathcal{P}_{2}\(\\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq457.gif) can be identified with the Poincaré upper half-plane, ![
$${\\mathcal{P}}^{\\circ }\(3,1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq458.gif) can be identified with ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{2}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq459.gif), and ![
$${\\mathcal{P}}^{\\circ }\(5,1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq460.gif) can be identified with ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{2}\(\\mathcal{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq461.gif).

Example 28.8.

The octonions or Cayley numbers are a nonassociative algebra ![
$$\\mathbb{O}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq462.gif) over ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq463.gif) of degree 8. The automorphism group of ![
$$\\mathbb{O}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq464.gif) is the exceptional group G 2. The construction of Example 28.6 applied to ![
$$D = \\mathbb{O}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq465.gif) does not produce a Jordan algebra if n > 3. If ![
$$n \\leqslant 3$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq466.gif), then ![
$$\\mathcal{J}_{n}\(\\mathbb{O}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq467.gif) is a Jordan algebra containing a self-dual cone ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{n}\(\\mathbb{O}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq468.gif). But ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{2}\(\\mathbb{O}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq469.gif) is the same as ![
$$\\mathcal{P}\(9,1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq470.gif). Only the 27-dimensional exceptional Jordan algebra ![
$$\\mathcal{J}_{3}\(\\mathbb{O}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq471.gif), discovered in 1947 by A. A. Albert, produces a new cone ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{3}\(\\mathbb{O}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq472.gif). It contains an irreducible symmetric space of codimension 1, ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{3}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{O}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq473.gif), which is the locus of a cubic invariant. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{E}_{3}^{\\circ }\(\\mathbb{O}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq474.gif) denote the compact dual. The Cartan classification of these 26-dimensional symmetric spaces is EIV.

The tube domain ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}\(\\mathcal{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq475.gif) over a self-dual cone ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq476.gif), consisting of all ![
$$X + iY \\in \\mathbb{C} \\otimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq477.gif), is a Hermitian symmetric space. These examples are extremely similar to the case of the Siegel space. For example, we can embed ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}\(\\mathcal{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq478.gif) in its compact dual ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}\(\\mathcal{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq479.gif), which contains ![
$${\\mathfrak{R}}^{\\circ }\(\\mathcal{C}\) = \\mathbb{C} \\otimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq480.gif) as a dense open set. A Cayley transform ![
$$c: \\mathfrak{R}\(\\mathcal{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{R}\(\\mathcal{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq481.gif) takes ![
$$\\mathfrak{H}\(\\mathcal{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq482.gif) into a bounded symmetric domain ![
$$\\mathfrak{D}\(\\mathcal{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq483.gif), the closure of which is contained in ![
$${\\mathfrak{R}}^{\\circ }\(\\mathcal{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq484.gif). The Bergman–Shilov boundary can be identified with the compact dual of the (reducible) symmetric space ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq485.gif), and its preimage under c consists of ![
$$X + iY \\in \\mathbb{C} \\otimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq486.gif) with Y = 0, that is, with the vector space V.

The nonassociative algebras ![
$$\\mathbb{O}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq487.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{J}_{3}\(\\mathbb{O}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq488.gif) are crucial in the construction of the exceptional groups and Lie algebras. See Adams [3], Jacobson [88], Onishchik and Vinberg [166] and Schafer [146] for constructions. Freudenthal [50] observed a phenomenon involving some symmetric spaces known as the magic square. Freudenthal envisioned a series of geometries over the algebras ![
$$\\mathbb{R}, \\mathbb{C}, \\mathbb{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq489.gif), and ![
$$\\mathbb{O}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq490.gif), and found a remarkable symmetry, which we will present momentarily. Tits [161] gave a uniform construction of the exceptional Lie algebras that sheds light on the magic square. See also Allison [6]. The paper of Baez [12] gives a useful survey of matters related to the exceptional groups, including the magic square and much more. A recent paper on the magic square, in the geometric spirit of Freudenthal's original approach, is Landsberg and Manivel [115]. And Tits' theory of buildings ([163], [1]) had its roots in his investigations of the geometry of the exceptional groups ([134]).

We will now take a look at the magic square Let us denote ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}\(\\mathcal{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq491.gif) as ![
$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq492.gif) if ![
$$\\mathcal{C} = \\mathcal{P}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq493.gif). We associate with this ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq494.gif) three groups G n (D), G′ n (D), and G n ″(D) such that ![
$$G_{n}^{\\prime\\prime}\(D\) \\supset G^{\\prime}_{n}\(D\) \\supset G_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq495.gif) and such that ![
$$G^{\\prime\\prime}\(D\)/G_{n}^{\\prime}\(D\) = \\mathfrak{R}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq496.gif), while ![
$$G^{\\prime}_{n}\(D\)/G_{n}\(D\) = \\mathcal{E}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq497.gif). Thus ![
$$G_{n}\(\\mathbb{R}\) = \\mathrm{SO}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq498.gif) and ![
$$G_{n}^{\\prime}\(\\mathbb{R}\) = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq499.gif), while ![
$$G_{n}^{\\prime\\prime}\(\\mathbb{R}\) = \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq500.gif).

These groups are tabulated in Fig. 28.2 together with the noncompact duals that produce tube domains. Note that the symmetric spaces ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\) \\times \\mathrm{U}\(n\)/\\mathrm{U}\(n\) = \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq501.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(2n, \\mathbb{C}\)/\\mathrm{U}\(n\) = \\mathcal{P}_{3}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq502.gif) of the center column are of Types II and IV, respectively. The "magic" consists of the fact that the square is symmetric.

Fig. 28.2

The 3 × 3 square. Left: compact forms. Right: noncompact forms

We have the following numerology:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\dim \\;G_{n}^{\\prime\\prime}\(D\) + 2\\;\\dim G\(D\) = 3\\,\\dim G^{\\prime}_{n}\(D\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ18.gif)

(28.16)

Indeed, ![
$$\\dim \\;G_{n}^{\\prime\\prime}\(D\) -\\dim \\; G^{\\prime}_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq503.gif) is the dimension of the tube domain, and this is twice the dimension ![
$$\\dim \\;G^{\\prime}\(D\) -\\dim \\; G_{n}\(D\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq504.gif) of the cone.

Although in presenting the 3 × 3 square—valid for all n—in Fig. 28.2 it seems best to take the full unitary groups in the second rows and columns, this does not work so well for the 4 × 4 magic square. Let us therefore note that we can also use modified groups that we call ![
$$H_{n}\(D\) \\subset H_{n}^{\\prime}\(D\) \\subset H_{n}^{\\prime\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq505.gif), which are the derived groups of the G n (D). We must modify (28.16) accordingly:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\dim \\;H^{\\prime\\prime}\(D\) + 2\\,\\dim \\;H\(D\) = 3\\dim H^{\\prime}_{n}\(D\) + 3. }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ19.gif)

(28.17)

See Fig. 28.3 for the resulting "reduced" 3 × 3 magic square.

Fig. 28.3

Left: the reduced 3 × 3 square. Right: dimensions

If n = 3, the reduced 3 × 3 square can be extended, resulting in Freudenthal's magic square, which we consider next. It will be noted that in Cartan's list (Table 28.1) some of the symmetric spaces have an SU(2) factor in K. Since SU(2) is the multiplicative group of quaternions of norm 1, these spaces have a quaternionic structure analogous to the complex structure shown by Hermitian symmetric spaces, where K contains a U(1) factor (Proposition 28.3). See Wolf [175]. Of the exceptional types, EII, EIV, EIX, FI, and G are quaternionic. Observe that in each case the dimension is a multiple of 4. Using some of these quaternionic symmetric spaces it is possible to extend the magic square in the special case where n = 3 by a fourth group H‴ n (D) such that H″ n (D) ×SU(2) is the maximal compact subgroup of the relevant noncompact form. It is also possible to add a fourth column when n = 3 due to existence of the exceptional Jordan algebra and ![
$$\\mathcal{P}_{3}\(\\mathbb{O}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_IEq506.gif).

The magic square then looks like Fig. 28.4. In addition to (28.17), there is a similar relation,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\dim \\;H^{\\prime\\prime\\prime}\(D\) + 2\\,\\dim \\;H^{\\prime}\(D\) = 3\\dim H^{\\prime\\prime}_{n}\(D\) + 5, }$$
](A79351_2_En_28_Chapter_Equ20.gif)

(28.18)

which suggests that the quaternionic symmetric spaces—they are FI, EII, EVI, and EIX in Cartan's classification—should be thought of as "quaternionic tube domains" over the corresponding Hermitian symmetric spaces.

Fig. 28.4

Left: the magic square. Right: dimensions

Exercises

In the exercises, we look at the complex unit ball, which is a Hermitian symmetric space that is not a tube domain. For these spaces, Piatetski-Shapiro [133] gave unbounded realizations that are called Siegel domains of Type II. (Siegel domains of Type I are tube domains over self-dual cones.)

$$\\mathfrak{R}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
