# 29. Relative Root Systems

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In this chapter, we will consider root systems and Weyl groups associated with a Lie group G. We will assume that G satisfies the assumptions in Hypothesis 28.1 of the last chapter. Thus, G is semisimple and comes with a compact dual G c . In Chap. , we associated with G c a root system and Weyl group. That root system and Weyl group we will call the absolute root system Φ and Weyl group W. We will introduce another root system Φ rel, called the relative or restricted root system, and a Weyl group W rel called the relative Weyl group. The relation between the two root systems will be discussed. The structures that we will find give Iwasawa and Bruhat decompositions in this context. This chapter may be skipped with no loss of continuity.

In this chapter, we will consider root systems and Weyl groups associated with a Lie group G. We will assume that G satisfies the assumptions in Hypothesis 28.1 of the last chapter. Thus, G is semisimple and comes with a compact dual G c . In Chap. , we associated with G c a root system and Weyl group. That root system and Weyl group we will call the absolute root system Φ and Weyl group W. We will introduce another root system Φ rel, called the relative or restricted root system, and a Weyl group W rel called the relative Weyl group. The relation between the two root systems will be discussed. The structures that we will find give Iwasawa and Bruhat decompositions in this context. This chapter may be skipped with no loss of continuity.

As we saw in Theorem 28.3, every semisimple Lie group admits a Cartan decomposition, and Hypothesis 28.1 will be satisfied. The assumption of semisimplicity can be relaxed—it is sufficient for G to be reductive, though in this book we only define the term "reductive" when G is a complex analytic group. A more significant generalization of the results of this chapter is that relative and absolute root systems and Weyl groups can be defined whenever G is a reductive algebraic group defined over a field F. If F is algebraically closed, these coincide. If ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq1.gif), they coincide with the structures defined in this chapter. But reductive groups over p-adic fields, number fields, or finite fields have many applications, and this reason alone is enough to prefer an approach based on algebraic groups. For this, see Borel [20] as well as Borel and Tits [21], Tits [162] (and other papers in the same volume), and Satake [144].

Consider, for example, the group ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SL}\(r, \\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq2.gif), the construction of which we recall. The group ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq3.gif) is the group of units of the central simple algebra ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{r}\(\\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq4.gif) over ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq5.gif). We have ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathbb{H}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Mat}_{2}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq6.gif) as ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq7.gif)-algebras. Consequently, ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes \\mathrm{Mat}_{r}\(\\mathbb{H}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Mat}_{2r}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq8.gif). The reduced norm ![
$$\\nu: \\mathrm{Mat}_{r}\(\\mathbb{H}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is a map determined by the commutativity of the diagram

(See Exercise 29.1.) The restriction of the reduced norm to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq10.gif) is a homomorphism ![
$$\\nu: \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{H}\)\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{R}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq11.gif) with a kernel that is the group ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(r, \\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq12.gif). It is a real form of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2r, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq13.gif), or of the compact group G c = SU(2r), and we may associate with it the Weyl group and root system W and Φ of SU(2r) of type A 2r−1. This is the absolute root system. On the other hand, there is also a relative or restricted root system and Weyl group, which we now describe.

Let K be the group of ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{SL}\(r, \\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq14.gif) such that ![
$${g\\,}^{t}\\bar{g} = I$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq15.gif), where the bar denotes the conjugation map of ![
$$\\mathbb{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq16.gif). By Exercise 5.7, K is a compact group isomorphic to Sp(2r). The Cartan involution θ of Hypothesis 28.1 is the map ![
$$g{\\longmapsto }^{t}\\bar{{g}}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq17.gif).

We will denote by ![
$$\\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq18.gif) the multiplicative group of the positive real numbers. Let ![
$$A\\mathop{\\cong}{\(\\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq19.gif) be the subgroup

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\;t_{1}\\; & & \\\\ & \\ddots & \\\\ & & \\;t_{r}\\; \\end{array} \\right \),t_{i} \\in \\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times },\\qquad \\prod t_{ i} = 1.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equa.gif)

The centralizer of A consists of the group

![
$$\\displaystyle{C_{G}\(A\) = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\;t_{1}\\; & & \\\\ & \\ddots & \\\\ & & \\;t_{r}\\; \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,t_{i} \\in {\\mathbb{H}}^{\\times }\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equb.gif)

The group ![
$$M = C_{G}\(A\) \\cap K$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq20.gif) consists of all elements with |t i | = 1. The group of norm 1 elements in ![
$${\\mathbb{H}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq21.gif) is isomorphic to SU(2) by Exercise 5.7 with n = 1. Thus M is isomorphic to SU(2) r .

On the other hand, the normalizer of N G (A) consists of all monomial quaternion matrices. The quotient ![
$$W_{\\mathrm{rel}} = N_{G}\(A\)/C_{G}\(A\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq22.gif) is of type A r−1. The "restricted roots" are "rational characters" of the group A, of the form ![
$$\\alpha _{ij} = t_{i}t_{j}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq23.gif), with i≠j. We can identify ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathrm{Lie}\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq24.gif) with ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq25.gif), in which case the subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) that transforms by ![
$$\\alpha _{ij}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) consists of all elements of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) having zeros everywhere except in the i,j position. In contrast with the absolute root system, where the eigenspace ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) of a root is always one-dimensional (see Proposition 18.6), these eigenspaces are all four-dimensional.

We see from this example that the group ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) looks like ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq31123.gif), but the root eigenspaces are "fattened up." The role of the torus T in Chap.  will be played by the group C G (A), which may be thought of as a "fattened up" and non-Abelian replacement for the torus.

We turn to the general case and to the proofs.

Proposition 29.1.

Assume that the assumptions of Hypothesis 28.1 are satisfied. Then the map

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(Z,k\)\\longmapsto \\exp \(Z\)k }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(29.1)

is a diffeomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{p} \\times K\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) .

Proof.

Choosing a faithful representation (π,V ) of the compact group G c , we may embed G c into GL(V ). We may find a positive definite invariant inner product on V and, on choosing an orthonormal basis, we may embed G c into U(n), where n = dim(V ). The Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) is then embedded into ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) in such a way that ![
$$\\mathfrak{k} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq35.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq36.gif) is contained in the space ![
$$\\mathfrak{P}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq37.gif) of n × n Hermitian matrices. We now recall from Theorem 13.4 and Proposition 13.7 that the formula (29.1) defines a diffeomorphism ![
$$\\mathfrak{P} \\times \\mathrm{U}\(n\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq38.gif). It follows that it gives a diffeomorphism of ![
$$\\mathfrak{p} \\times K$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq39.gif) onto its image. It also follows that (29.1) has nonzero differential everywhere, and as ![
$$\\mathfrak{p} \\times K$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq40.gif) and G have the same dimension, we get an open mapping ![
$$\\mathfrak{p} \\times K\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq41.gif). On the other hand, ![
$$\\mathfrak{p} \\times K$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq42.gif) is closed in ![
$$\\mathfrak{P} \\times \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq43.gif), so the image of (29.1) is closed as well as open in G. Since G is connected, it follows that (29.1) is surjective. □

If ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq44.gif) is an Abelian Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq45.gif) such that ![
$$\\mathfrak{a} \\subset \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq46.gif), we say ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq47.gif) is an Abelian subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq48.gif). This expression is used instead of "Abelian subalgebra" since ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq49.gif) itself is not a Lie subalgebra of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq50.gif). We will see later in Theorem 29.3 that a maximal Abelian subspace ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq51.gif) of ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq52.gif) is unique up to conjugation.

Proposition 29.2.

Assume that the assumptions of Hypothesis 28.1 are satisfied. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq53.gif) be a maximal Abelian subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq54.gif) . Then ![
$$A =\\exp \(\\mathfrak{a}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq55.gif) is a closed Lie subgroup of G, and ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq56.gif) is its Lie algebra. There exists a θ-stable maximal torus T of G c such that A is contained in the complexification ![
$$T_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq57.gif) regarded as a subgroup of ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq58.gif) . If ![
$$r =\\dim \(\\mathfrak{a}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq59.gif) , then ![
$$A\\mathop{\\cong}{\(\\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq60.gif) . Moreover, ![
$$A_{c} =\\exp \(i\\mathfrak{a}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq61.gif) is a compact torus contained in T. We have T = A c T M , where ![
$$T_{M} = {\(T \\cap K\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq62.gif) .

Proof.

By Proposition 15.2, A is an Abelian group. By Proposition 29.1, the restriction of exp to ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq63.gif) is a diffeomorphism onto its image, which is closed in G, and since ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq64.gif) is closed in ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq65.gif) it follows that ![
$$\\exp \(\\mathfrak{a}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq66.gif) is closed and isomorphic as a Lie group to the vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{R}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq67.gif). Exponentiating, the group ![
$$A\\mathop{\\cong}{\(\\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq68.gif).

Let ![
$$A_{c} =\\exp \(i\\mathfrak{a}\) \\subset G_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq69.gif). By Proposition 15.2, it is an Abelian subgroup. We will show that it is closed. If it is not, consider its topological closure ![
$$\\overline{A}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq70.gif). This is a closed connected Abelian subgroup of the compact group G c and hence a torus by Theorem 15.2. Since θ induces − 1 on ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq71.gif), it induces the automorphism ![
$$g\\longmapsto {g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq72.gif) on A c and hence on ![
$$\\overline{A}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq73.gif). Therefore, the Lie algebra of ![
$$\\overline{A}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq74.gif) is contained in the − 1 eigenspace ![
$$i\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq75.gif) of θ in Lie(G c ). Since ![
$$i\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq76.gif) is a maximal Abelian subspace of ![
$$i\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq77.gif), it follows that ![
$$i\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq78.gif) is the Lie algebra of ![
$$\\overline{A}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq79.gif), and therefore ![
$$\\overline{A}_{c} =\\exp \(i\\mathfrak{a}\) = A_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq80.gif).

Now let T be a maximal θ-stable torus of G c containing A c . We will show that T is a maximal torus of G c . Let ![
$$T^{\\prime} \\supseteq T$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq81.gif) be a maximal torus. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq82.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq83.gif) be the respective Lie algebras of T′ and T. Suppose that ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{t}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq84.gif). If ![
$$Y \\in \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq85.gif), then ![
$$\[Y{,}^{\\theta }H\] = {\[}^{\\theta }Y,H\] = -\[Y,H\] = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq86.gif) since ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq87.gif) is θ-stable and ![
$$Y,H \\in \\mathfrak{t}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq88.gif), which is Abelian. Thus, both H andθ H are in the centralizer of ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq89.gif). Now we can write H = H 1 \+ H 2, where ![
$$H_{1} = \\frac{1} {2}\(H {+ }^{\\theta }H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq90.gif) and ![
$$H_{2} = \\frac{1} {2}\(H {-}^{\\theta }H\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq91.gif). Note that the torus S i , which is the closure of ![
$$\\{\\exp \(tH_{i}\)\\,\\vert \\,t \\in \\mathbb{R}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq92.gif), is θ stable – indeed θ is trivial on S 1 and induces the automorphism ![
$$x\\longmapsto {x}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq93.gif) on S 2. Also ![
$$S_{i} \\subseteq T^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq94.gif) centralizes T. Consequently, TS i is a θ-stable torus and, by maximality of T, ![
$$S_{i} \\subseteq T$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq95.gif). It follows that ![
$$H_{i} \\in \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq96.gif), and so ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq97.gif). We have proven that ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}^{\\prime} = \\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq98.gif) and so T = T′ is a maximal torus.

It remains to be shown that T = A c T M . It is sufficient to show that the Lie algebra of T decomposes as ![
$$i\\mathfrak{a} \\oplus \\mathfrak{t}_{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq99.gif), where ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq100.gif) is the Lie algebra of T M . Since θ stabilizes T, it induces an endomorphism of order 2 of ![
$$\\mathfrak{t} = \\mathrm{Lie}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq101.gif). The + 1 eigenspace is ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{M} = \\mathfrak{t} \\cap \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq102.gif) since the + 1 eigenspace of θ on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq103.gif) is ![
$$\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq104.gif). On the other hand, the − 1 eigenspace of θ on ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq105.gif) contains ![
$$i\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq106.gif) and is contained in ![
$$i\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq107.gif), which is the − 1 eigenspace of θ on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq108.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq109.gif) is a maximal Abelian subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq110.gif), it follows that the − 1 eigenspace of θ on ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq111.gif) is exactly ![
$$i\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq112.gif), so ![
$$\\mathfrak{t} = i\\mathfrak{a} \\oplus \\mathfrak{t}_{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq113.gif). □

Lemma 29.1.

Let ![
$$Z \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq114.gif) be a Hermitian matrix. If ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq115.gif) commutes with exp (Z), then g commutes with Z.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq116.gif) be the distinct eigenvalues of Z. Let us choose a basis with respect to which Z has the matrix

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\lambda _{1}I_{r_{1}} & & \\\\ & \\ddots & \\\\ & & \\lambda _{h}I_{r_{h}} \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equc.gif)

Then exp(Z) has the same form with λ i replaced by exp(λ i ). Since the λ i are distinct real numbers, the exp(λ i ) are also distinct, and it follows that g has the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\,g_{1}\\, & & \\\\ & \\ddots & \\\\ & & \\,g_{h}\\, \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equd.gif)

where g i is an r i × r i block. Thus g commutes with Z. □

Proposition 29.3.

In the context of Proposition 29.2 , let ![
$$M = C_{G}\(A\) \\cap K$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq117.gif) . Then C G (A) = MA and ![
$$M \\cap A =\\{ 1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq118.gif) , so C G (A) is the direct product of M and A. The group T M is a maximal torus of M.

The compact group M is called the anisotropic kernel.

Proof.

Since ![
$$M \\subseteq K$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq119.gif) and ![
$$A \\subseteq \\exp \(\\mathfrak{p}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq120.gif), and since by Proposition 29.1 ![
$$K \\cap \\exp \(\\mathfrak{p}\) =\\{ 1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq121.gif), we have ![
$$M \\cap A =\\{ 1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq122.gif). We will show that C G (A) = MA. Let g ∈ M. By Proposition 29.1, we may write g = exp(Z)k, where ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq123.gif) and k ∈ K. If a ∈ A, then a commutes with exp(Z)k. We will show that any a ∈ A commutes with exp(Z) and with k individually. From this we will deduce that exp(Z) ∈ A and k ∈ M.

By Theorem 4.2, G c has a faithful complex representation ![
$$G_{c}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq124.gif). We extend this to a representation of ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq125.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq126.gif). Giving V a G c -invariant inner product and choosing an orthonormal basis, G c is realized as a group of unitary matrices. Therefore ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq127.gif) is realized as a Lie algebra of skew-Hermitian matrices, and since ![
$$i\\mathfrak{p} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq128.gif), the vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq129.gif) consists of Hermitian matrices.

We note that θ(Z) = −Z, θ(a) = a −1, and θ(k) = k. Thus if we apply the automorphism θ to the identity aexp(Z)k = exp(Z)ka, we get a −1exp(−Z)k = exp(−Z)ka −1. Since this is true for all a ∈ A, both exp(−Z)k and exp(Z)k are in C G (A). It follows that ![
$$\\exp \(2Z\) =\\big \(\\exp \(Z\)k\\big\)\\big\({\\exp \(-Z\)k\\big\)}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq130.gif) is in C G (A). Since ![
$$\\exp \(2Z\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq131.gif) commutes with A, by Lemma 29.1, Z commutes with the elements of A (in our matrix realization) and hence ![
$$\\mathrm{ad}\(Z\)\\mathfrak{a} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq132.gif). Because ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq133.gif) is a maximal Abelian subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq134.gif), it follows that ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq135.gif). Also, k centralizes A since exp(Z)k and exp(Z) both do, and so exp(Z) ∈ A and k ∈ M.

It is clear that ![
$$T_{M} = {\(T \\cap K\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq136.gif) is contained in C G (A) and K, so T M is a torus in M. Let T M ′ be a maximal torus of M containing T M . Then ![
$$A_{c}T^{\\prime}_{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq137.gif) is a connected Abelian subgroup of C G (A) containing T = A c T M , and since T is a maximal torus of G c we have A c T′ M = T. Therefore, ![
$$T_{M}^{\\prime} \\subset T$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq138.gif). It is also contained in K and connected. This proves that ![
$$T_{M} = T^{\\prime}_{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq139.gif) is a maximal torus of M. □

We say that a quasicharacter of ![
$$A\\mathop{\\cong}{\(\\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }\)}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq140.gif) is a rational character if it can be extended to a complex analytic character of ![
$$A_{\\mathbb{C}} =\\exp \(\\mathfrak{a}_{\\mathbb{C}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq141.gif). We will denote by X ∗(A) the group of rational characters of A. We recall from Chap.  that X ∗(A c ) is the group of all characters of the compact torus A c .

Proposition 29.4.

Every rational character of A has the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{r}\)\\longmapsto t_{1}^{k_{1} }\\cdots t_{r}^{k_{r} },k_{i} \\in \\mathbb{Z}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(29.2)

The groups X ∗ (A) and X ∗ (A c ) are isomorphic: extending a rational character of A to a complex analytic character of ![
$$A_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq142.gif) and then restricting it to A c gives every character of A c exactly once.

Proof.

Obviously (29.2) is a rational character. Extending any rational character of A to an analytic character of ![
$$A_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq143.gif) and then restricting it to A c gives a homomorphism ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(A\)\\longrightarrow {X}^{{\\ast}}\(A_{c}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq144.gif), and since the characters of X ∗(A c ) are classified by Proposition 15.4, we see that every rational character has the form (29.2) and that the homomorphism ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(A\)\\longrightarrow {X}^{{\\ast}}\(A_{c}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq145.gif) is an isomorphism.□

Since the compact tori T and A c satisfy ![
$$T \\supset A_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq146.gif), we may restrict characters of T to A c . Some characters may restrict trivially. In any case, if ![
$$\\alpha \\in {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq147.gif) restricts to ![
$$\\beta \\in {X}^{{\\ast}}\(A\) = {X}^{{\\ast}}\(A_{c}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq148.gif), we write α|β. Assuming that α and hence β are not the trivial character, as in Chap.  we will denote by ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq149.gif) the β-eigenspace of T on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq150.gif). We will also denote by ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq151.gif) the α-eigenspace of A c on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq152.gif). Since ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(A_{c}\) = {X}^{{\\ast}}\(A\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq153.gif), we may write

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}} = \\left \\{X \\in \\mathfrak{g}_{ \\mathbb{C}}\\,\\vert \\,\\mathrm{Ad}\(a\)X = \\alpha \(a\)X\\text{for all}a \\in A\\}.\\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Eque.gif)

We will see by examples that ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq154.gif) may be more than one-dimensional. However, ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq155.gif) is one-dimensional by Proposition 18.6, and we may obviously write

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}} =\\bigoplus _{ \\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{c} \\beta \\in {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\) \\\\ \\beta \\vert \\alpha \\end{array} $}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Let Φ be the set of β ∈ X ∗(T) such that ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq156.gif), and let Φ rel be the set of α ∈ X ∗(A) such that ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq157.gif).

If β ∈ X ∗(T), let ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\beta: \\mathfrak{t}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq158.gif) be the differential of β. Thus

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{d}\\beta \(H\) = \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}\\beta \({\\mathrm{e}}^{tH}\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{ t=0},H \\in \\mathfrak{t}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equg.gif)

As in Chap. , the linear form dβ is pure imaginary on the Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{M} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq159.gif) of the compact torus T. This means that dβ is real on ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq160.gif) and purely imaginary on ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq161.gif).

If ![
$$\\alpha \\in \\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq162.gif), the α-eigenspace ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq163.gif) can be characterized by either the condition (for ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq164.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{Ad}\(a\)X = \\alpha \(a\)X,a \\in A,}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equh.gif)

or

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \[H,X\] = \\mathrm{d}\\alpha \(H\)\\,X,H \\in \\mathfrak{a}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(29.3)

Let ![
$$c: \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq165.gif) denote the conjugation with respect to ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq166.gif). Thus, if ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq167.gif) is written as X \+ iY, where ![
$$X,Y \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq168.gif), then c(Z) = X − iY so ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} =\\{ Z \\in \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\,\\vert \\,c\(Z\) = Z\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq169.gif). Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq170.gif) be the Lie algebra of M. Thus, the Lie algebra of C G (A) = MA is ![
$$\\mathfrak{m} \\oplus \\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq171.gif). It is the 0-eigenspace of A on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq172.gif), so

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathbb{C}\(\\mathfrak{m} \\oplus \\mathfrak{a}\) \\oplus \\bigoplus _{\\alpha \\in \\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha } }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(29.4)

is the decomposition into eigenspaces.

Proposition 29.5.

(i)

In the context of Proposition 29.2 , if ![
$$\\alpha \\in \\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq173.gif) , then ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}} \\cap \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq174.gif) spans ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq175.gif) .

(ii)

If ![
$$0\\neq X \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}} \\cap \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq176.gif) , then ![
$$\\theta \(X\) \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{-\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}} \\cap \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq177.gif) and [X,θ(X)]≠0.

(iii)

The space ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}} \\cap \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq178.gif) is invariant under Ad (MA).

(iv)

If α,α′ ∈Φ rel , and if ![
$$X_{\\alpha } \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq179.gif), ![
$$X_{\\alpha ^{\\prime}} \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha ^{\\prime}}^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq180.gif) , then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\[X_{\\alpha },X_{\\alpha ^{\\prime}}\] \\in \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} \\mathbb{C}\(\\mathfrak{m} \\oplus \\mathfrak{a}\)&\\mbox{ if $\\alpha ^{\\prime} = -\\alpha $,}\\\\ \\mathfrak{X}_{ \\alpha +\\alpha ^{\\prime}} &\\mbox{ if $\\alpha + \\alpha ^{\\prime} \\in \\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}$,}\\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equi.gif)

while [X α ,X α′ ] = 0 if α′≠ − α and α + α′∉Φ.

This is in contrast with the situation in Chap. , where the spaces ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq181.gif) did not intersect the Lie algebra of the compact Lie group.

Proof.

We show that we may find a basis X 1,...,X h of the complex vector space ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq182.gif) such that ![
$$X_{i} \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq183.gif). Suppose that X 1,...,X h are a maximal linearly independent subset of ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{r\\mathrm{el}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq184.gif) such that ![
$$X_{i} \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq185.gif). If they do not span ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq186.gif), let ![
$$0\\neq Z \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq187.gif) be found that is not in their span. Then ![
$$c\(Z\) \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq188.gif) since applying c to (29.3) gives the same condition, with Z replaced by c(Z). Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\tfrac{1} {2}\\big\(Z + c\(Z\)\\big\),\\qquad \\tfrac{1} {2i}\\big\(Z - c\(Z\)\\big\)\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equj.gif)

are in ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq189.gif), and at least one of them is not in the span of X 1,...,X i since Z is not. We may add this to the linearly independent set X 1,...,X h , contradicting the assumed maximality. This proves (i).

For (ii), let us show that θ maps ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq190.gif) to ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{-\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq191.gif). Indeed, if ![
$$X \\in X_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq192.gif), then for a ∈ A we have ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(a\)X = \\alpha \(a\)X_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq193.gif). Since θ(a) = a −1, replacing a by its inverse and applying θ, it follows that Ad(a)θ(X) = α(a −1) θ(X). Since the group law in X ∗(A) is written additively, (−α)(a) = α(a −1). Therefore ![
$$\\theta \(X\) \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{-\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq194.gif).

Since θ and c commute, if ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq195.gif), then ![
$$\\theta \(X\) \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq196.gif).

The last point we need to check for (ii) is that if ![
$$0\\neq X \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}} \\cap \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq197.gif), then [X,θ(X)]≠0. Since ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}: G_{c}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(\\mathfrak{g}_{c}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq198.gif) is a real representation of a compact group, there exists a positive definite symmetric bilinear form B on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq199.gif) that is G c -invariant. We extend B to a symmetric ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq200.gif)-bilinear form ![
$$B: \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}} \\times \\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq201.gif) by linearity. We note that ![
$$Z = X + \\theta \(X\) \\in \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq202.gif) since θ(Z) = Z and ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq203.gif). In particular ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq204.gif). It cannot vanish since X and θ(X) lie in ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq205.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{-\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq206.gif), which have a trivial intersection. Therefore, B(Z,Z)≠0. Choose ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq207.gif) such that dα(H)≠0. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{B\\big\(X + \\theta \(X\),\[H,X - \\theta \(X\)\]\\big\) = B\\big\(Z,\\mathrm{d}\\alpha \(H\)Z\\big\)\\neq 0.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equk.gif)

On the other hand, by (10.3) this equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{-B\\big\(\[X + \\theta \(X\),X - \\theta \(X\)\],H\\big\) = 2B\\big\(\[X,\\theta \(X\)\],H\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equl.gif)

Therefore, [X,θ(X)]≠0.

For (ii), we will prove that ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq208.gif) is invariant under C G (A), which contains M. Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq209.gif) is obviously an Ad-invariant real subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq210.gif) it will follow that ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}} \\cap \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq211.gif) is Ad(M)-invariant. Since C G (A) is connected by Theorem 16.6, it is sufficient to show that ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq212.gif) is invariant under ad(Z) when Z is in the Lie algebra centralizer of ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq213.gif). Thus, if ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq214.gif) we have [H,Z] = 0. Now if ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq215.gif) we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\[H,\[Z,X\]\] = \[\[H,Z\],X\] + \[Z,\[H,X\]\] = \[Z,\\mathrm{d}\\alpha \(H\)X\] = \\mathrm{d}\\alpha \(H\)\[Z,X\].}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equm.gif)

Therefore, ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(Z\)X = \[Z,X\] \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq216.gif).

Part (iv) is entirely similar to Proposition 18.4 (ii), and we leave it to the reader. □

The roots in Φ can now be divided into two classes. First, there are those that restrict nontrivially to A and hence correspond to roots in Φ rel. On the other hand, some roots do restrict trivially, and we will show that these correspond to roots of the compact Lie group M. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{m} = \\mathrm{Lie}\(M\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq217.gif).

Proposition 29.6.

Suppose that β ∈Φ. If the restriction of β to A is trivial, then ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq218.gif) is contained in the complexification of ![
$$\\mathfrak{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq219.gif) and β is a root of the compact group M with respect to T M .

Proof.

We show that ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq220.gif) is θ-stable. Let ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq221.gif). Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \[H,X\] = \\mathrm{d}\\beta \(H\)X,H \\in \\mathfrak{t}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(29.5)

We must show that θ(X) has the same property. Applying θ to (29.5) gives

![
$$\\displaystyle{\[\\theta \(H\),\\theta \(X\)\] = \\mathrm{d}\\beta \(H\)\\,\\theta \(X\),H \\in \\mathfrak{t}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equn.gif)

If ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{t}_{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq222.gif), then θ(H) = H and we have (29.5) with θ(X) replacing X. On the other hand, if ![
$$H \\in i\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq223.gif) we have θ(H) = −H, but by assumption dβ(H) = 0, so we have (29.5) with θ(X) replacing X in this case, too. Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{t} = \\mathfrak{t}_{M} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq224.gif), we have proved that ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq225.gif) is θ-stable.

If a ∈ A and ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq226.gif), then Ad(a)X is trivial, so a commutes with the one-parameter subgroup ![
$$t\\longmapsto \\exp \(tX\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq227.gif), and therefore exp(tX) is contained in the centralizer of A in ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq228.gif). This means that exp(tX) is contained in the complexification of the Lie algebra of C G (A), which by Proposition 29.3 is ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\(\\mathfrak{m} \\oplus \\mathfrak{a}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq229.gif). Since θ is + 1 on ![
$$\\mathfrak{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq230.gif) and − 1 on ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq231.gif), and since we have proved that ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq232.gif) is θ-stable, we have ![
$$X \\in \\mathbb{C}\\mathfrak{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq233.gif). □

Now let ![

(29.6)

Theorem 29.1.

In the context of Proposition 29.7 , the set Φ rel of restricted roots is a root system. If α ∈Φ rel , there exists w α ∈ K that normalizes A and that induces on X ∗ (A) the reflection s α .

Proof.

Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{w_{\\alpha } = i_{\\alpha }\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} &1\\\\ - 1 & \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equr.gif)

We note w α ∈ K. Indeed, it is the exponential of

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{d}i_{\\alpha }\\left \(\\frac{\\pi } {2} \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} &1\\\\ - 1 & \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \) = \\frac{\\pi } {2} \\big\(X_{\\alpha }-X_{-\\alpha }\\big\) \\in \\mathfrak{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equs.gif)

since

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\exp \\left \(t\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} &1\\\\ - 1 & \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\cos \(t\) &\\sin \(t\)\\\\ -\\sin \(t\) &\\cos \(t\) \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equt.gif)

Now w α centralizes A α by Proposition 29.7. Also

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{ad}\\left \(\\frac{\\pi } {2} \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} &1\\\\ - 1 & \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \): \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 1& \\\\ & - 1 \\end{array} \\right \)\\longmapsto -\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 1& \\\\ & - 1 \\end{array} \\right \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equu.gif)

in ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq282.gif), and applying i α gives ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(w_{\\alpha }\)H_{\\alpha } = -H_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq283.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq284.gif) is spanned by the codimension 1 subspace ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq285.gif) and the vector H α, it follows that (in its action on ![
$$\\mathcal{V}_{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq286.gif)) w α has order 2 and eigenvalue − 1 with multiplicity 1. It therefore induces the reflection s α in its action on ![
$$\\mathcal{V}_{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq287.gif).

Now the proof that Φ rel is a root system follows the structure of the proof of Theorem 18.2. The existence of the simple reflection w α in the Weyl group implies that s α preserves the set Φ.

For the proof that if α and β are in Φ then ![
$$2\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle /\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\alpha \\right \\rangle \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq288.gif), we adapt the proof of Proposition 18.10. If λ ∈ X ∗(A c ), we will denote (in this proof only) by ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq289.gif) the λ-eigenspace of A c in the adjoint representation. We normally use this notation only if λ≠0 is a root. If λ = 0, then ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq290.gif) is the complexified Lie algebra of C G (A); that is, ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\(\\mathfrak{m} \\oplus \\mathfrak{a}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq291.gif). Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{W =\\bigoplus _{k\\in \\mathbb{Z}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta +k\\alpha } \\subseteq \\mathfrak{X}_{\\mathbb{C}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equv.gif)

We claim that W is invariant under ![
$$i_{\\alpha }\\big\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq292.gif). To prove this, it is sufficient to show that it is invariant under ![
$$di_{\\alpha }\\big\(\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq293.gif), which is generated by X α and X −α, since these are the images under i α of a pair of generators of ![
$$\\mathfrak{s}\\mathfrak{l}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq294.gif) by (29.8). These are the images of di α and i α, respectively. From (29.7), we see that ![
$$\\mathrm{ad}\(X_{\\alpha }\)\\mathfrak{X}_{\\gamma } \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\gamma +2\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq295.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{ad}\(X_{-\\alpha }\)\\mathfrak{X}_{\\gamma } \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\gamma -2\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq296.gif), proving that ![
$$i_{\\alpha }\(\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq297.gif) is invariant. In particular, W is invariant under ![
$$w_{\\alpha } \\in \\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq298.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathrm{ad}\(w_{\\alpha }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq299.gif) induces s α on ![
$$\\mathcal{V}_{\\mathrm{rel}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq300.gif), it follows that the set ![
$$\\{\\beta + k\\alpha \\vert k \\in \\mathbb{Z}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq301.gif) is invariant under s α and, by (18.1), this implies that ![
$$2\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\beta \\right \\rangle /\\left \\langle \\alpha,\\alpha \\right \\rangle \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq302.gif). □

The group ![
$$W_{\\mathrm{rel}} = N_{G}\(A\)/C_{G}\(A\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq303.gif) is the relative Weyl group. In Theorem 29.1 we constructed simple reflections showing that W rel contains the abstract Weyl group associated with the root system Φ rel. An analog of Theorem 18.3 is true – W rel is generated by the reflections and hence coincides with the abstract Weyl group. We note that by Theorem 29.1 the generators of W rel can be taken in K, so we may write ![
$$W_{\\mathrm{rel}} = N_{K}\(A\)/C_{K}\(A\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq304.gif).

Although we have proved that Φ rel is a root system, we have not proved that it is reduced. In fact, it may not be—we will give examples where the type of Φ rel is BC q and is not reduced! In Chap. , except for Proposition 20.18, it was assumed that the root system was reduced. Proposition 20.18 contains all we need about nonreduced root systems.

The relationship between the three root systems Φ, Φ M , and Φ rel can be expressed in a "short exact sequence of root systems,"

![
$$\\displaystyle{ 0\\longrightarrow \\varPhi _{M}\\longrightarrow \\varPhi \\longrightarrow \\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}\\longrightarrow 0, }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(29.9)

embedded in the short exact sequence (29.6) of Euclidean spaces. Of course, this is intended symbolically rather than literally. What we mean by this "short exact sequence" is that, in accord with Proposition 29.6, each root of M can be extended to a unique root of G c ; that the roots in Φ that are not thus extended from M are precisely those that restrict to a nonzero root in Φ rel; and that every root in Φ rel is a restricted root.

Proposition 29.8.

If α ∈Φ rel + is a simple positive root, then there exists a β ∈Φ + such that β is a simple positive root and β|α. Moreover, if β ∈Φ + is a simple positive root with a restriction to A that is nonzero, then its restriction is a simple root of ![
$$\\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq305.gif) .

Proof.

Find a root γ ∈Φ whose restriction to A is α. Since we have chosen the root systems compatibly, γ is a positive root. We write it as a sum of positive roots: γ = ∑β i . Each of these restricts either trivially or to a relative root in ![
$$\\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq306.gif), and we can write α as the sum of the nonzero restrictions of β i , which are positive roots. Because α is simple, exactly one restricted β i can be nonzero, and taking β to be this β i , we have β|α.

The last statement is clear. □

We see that the restriction map induces a surjective mapping from the set of simple roots in Φ that have nonzero restrictions to the simple roots in Φ rel. The last question that needs to be answered is when two simple roots of Φ can have the same nonzero restriction to Φ rel.

Proposition 29.9.

Let β ∈Φ + . Then − θ(β) ∈Φ + . The roots β and − θ(β) have the same restriction to A. If β is a simple positive root, then so is − θ(β), and if α is a simple root of Φ rel and β,β′ are simple roots of Φ rel both restricting to α, then either β′ = β or β′ = −θ(β).

Proof.

The fact that β and − θ(β) have the same restriction follows from Proposition 29.5 (ii). It follows immediately that − θ(β) is a positive root in Φ. The map ![
$$\\beta \\longmapsto - \\theta \(\\beta \)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq307.gif) permutes the positive roots, is additive, and therefore preserves the simple positive roots.

Suppose that α is a simple root of Φ rel and β,β′ are simple roots of Φ rel both restricting to α. Since β − β′ has trivial restriction to A c , it is θ-invariant. Rewrite β − β′ = θ(β − β′) as ![
$$\\beta +\\big \(-\\theta \(\\beta \)\\big\) = \\beta ^{\\prime} +\\big \(\\theta \(-\\beta ^{\\prime}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq308.gif). This expresses the sum of two simple positive roots as the sum of another two simple positive roots. Since the simple positive roots are linearly independent by Proposition 20.18, it follows that either β′ = β or β′ = −θ(β). □

The symmetry β↦ − θ(β) of the Weyl group is reflected by a symmetry of the Dynkin diagram. It may be shown that if G c is simply connected, this symmetry corresponds to an outer automorphism of ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq309.gif). Only the Dynkin diagrams of types A n , D n , and E 6 admit nontrivial symmetries, so unless the absolute root system is one of these types, β = −θ(β).

The relationship between the three root systems in the "short exact sequence" (29.9) may be elucidated by the "Satake diagram," which we will now discuss. Tables of Satake diagrams may be found in Table VI on p. 532 of Helgason [66], p. 124 of Satake [144], or in Table 4 on p. 229 of Onishchik and Vinberg [166]. The diagrams in Tits [162] look a little different from the Satake diagram but contain the same information.

In addition to the Satake diagrams we will work out, a few different examples are explained in Goodman and Wallach [56].

Knapp [106] contains a different classification based on tori (Cartan subgroups) that (in contrast with our "maximally split" torus T), are maximally anisotropic, that is, are split as little as possible. Knapp also discusses the relationships between different tori by Cayley transforms. In this classification the Satake diagrams are replaced by "Vogan diagrams."

In the Satake diagram, one starts with the Dynkin diagram of Φ. We recall that the nodes of the Dynkin diagram correspond to simple roots of G c . Those corresponding to roots that restrict trivially to A are colored dark. By Proposition 29.6, these correspond to the simple roots of the anisotropic kernel M, and indeed one may read the Dynkin diagram of M from the Satake diagram simply by taking the colored roots.

In addition to coloring some of the roots, the Satake diagram records the effect of the symmetry ![
$$\\beta \\longmapsto - \\theta \(\\beta \)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq310.gif) of the Dynkin diagram. In the "exact sequence" (29.9), corresponding nodes are mapped to the same node in the Dynkin diagram of Φ rel. We will discuss this point later, but for examples of diagrams with nontrivial symmetries see Figs. 29.3b and 29.5.

As a first example of a Satake diagram, consider ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(3, \\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq311.gif). The Satake diagram is ![
$$\\bullet \\!\\!\\!-\\!\\!\\circ \\!\\!\\!-\\!\\!\\bullet \\!\\!\\!-\\!\\!\\circ \\!\\!-\\!\\!\\bullet$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq312.gif). The symmetry β↦ − θ(β) is trivial. From this Satake diagram, we can read off the Dynkin diagram of ![
$$M\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{SU}\(2\) \\times \\mathrm{SU}\(2\) \\times \\mathrm{SU}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq313.gif) by erasing the uncolored dots to obtain the disconnected diagram ![
$$\\;\\bullet \\quad \\bullet \\quad \\bullet \\;$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq314.gif) of type ![
$$A_{1} \\times A_{1} \\times A_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq315.gif).

On the other hand, in this example, the relative root system is of type A 2. We can visualize the "short exact sequence of root systems" as in Fig. 29.1, where we have indicated the destination of each simple root in the inclusion ![
$$\\varPhi _{M}\\longrightarrow \\varPhi$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq316.gif) and the destinations of those simple roots in Φ that restrict nontrivially in the relative root system.

Fig. 29.1

The "short exact sequence of root systems" for ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(3, \\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq317.gif)

As a second example, let ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq318.gif), and let us consider the group G = SO(n,1). In this example, we will see that G has real rank 1 and that the relative root system of G is of type A 1. Groups of real rank 1 are in many ways the simplest groups. Their symmetric spaces are direct generalizations of the Poincaré upper half-plane, and the symmetric space of SO(n,1) is often referred to as hyperbolic n-space. (It is n-dimensional.) We have seen in Example 28.7 that this symmetric space can be realized as a hyperboloid.

We will see, consistent with our description of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{H}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq319.gif) as a "fattened up" version of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq320.gif), that SO(n,1) can be seen as a "fattened up" version of SO(2,1).

We originally defined G = SO(n,1) to be the set of ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n + 1, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq321.gif) such that g J t g = J, where J = J 1 and

![
$$\\displaystyle{J_{1} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I_{n}& \\\\ & - 1 \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equw.gif)

However, we could just as easily take J = J 2 and

![
$$\\displaystyle{J_{2} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} & &1\\\\ &I_{ n-1} & \\\\ 1& & \\end{array} \\right \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equx.gif)

since this symmetric matrix also has eigenvalues 1 with multiplicity n and − 1 with multiplicity − 1. Thus, if

![
$$\\displaystyle{u = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} 1/\\sqrt{2}& & - 1/\\sqrt{2} \\\\ &I_{n-1} & \\\\ 1/\\sqrt{2}& & 1/\\sqrt{2} \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equy.gif)

then u ∈O(n \+ 1) and ![
$$u\\,J{_{1}\\,}^{t}u = J_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq322.gif). It follows that if ![
$$g\\,J{_{1}\\,}^{t}g = J_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq323.gif), then h = ugu −1 satisfies ![
$$h\\,J{_{2}\\,}^{t}h = J_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq324.gif). The two orthogonal groups are thus equivalent, and we will take J = J 2 in the definition of O(n,1). Then we see that the Lie algebra of G is

A number of rank 1 groups, such as SO(n,1) can be found in Cartan's list. Notably, among the exceptional groups, we find Type FII. Most of these can be thought of as "fattened up" versions of ![

At the other extreme, let us consider the groups SO(n,n) and SO(n \+ 1,n − 1). The group SO(n,n) is split. This means that the anisotropic kernel is trivial and that the absolute and relative root systems Φ and Φ rel coincide. We can take ![

We leave the details of this case to the reader. The Satake diagram is shown in Fig. 29.3 when n = 6.

A more interesting case is SO(n \+ 1,n − 1). This group is quasisplit. This means that the anisotropic kernel M is Abelian. Since M contains no roots, there are no colored roots in the Dynkin diagram of a quasisplit group. A split group is quasisplit, but not conversely, as this example shows. This group is not split since the relative root systems Φ and Φ rel differ. We can take ![

The involution θ is transpose-inverse. In its effect on the torus T, ![

As a last example, we look next at the Lie group SU(p,q), where p > q. We will see that this has type BC q . Recall from Chap.  that the root system of type BC q can be realized as all elements of the form

Now the Lie algebra of SU(p,q) consists of

$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} a& x & b \\\\ y& u & {-}^{t}\\bar{x} \\\\ c & {-}^{t}\\bar{y}& {-}^{t}\\bar{a} \\end{array} \\right \)\\,\\Big\\vert \\,\\mbox{ $b,c,u$ skew-Hermitian}\\right \\}.}$$

We turn now to the Iwasawa decomposition for G admitting a Cartan decomposition as in Hypothesis 28.1. The construction is rather similar to what we have already done in Chap. .

Fig. 29.5

The Satake diagram of SU(p,q)

Proposition 29.10.

Let G, G c , K, ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq352.gif) , and θ satisfy Hypothesis 28.1 . Let M and A be as in Propositions 29.2 and 29.3 . Let Φ and Φ rel be the absolute and relative root systems, and let Φ + and Φ rel + be the positive roots with respect to compatible orders. Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{n} =\\bigoplus _{\\alpha \\in \\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}^{+}}\(\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha } \\cap \\mathfrak{g}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equak.gif)

Then ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq353.gif) is a nilpotent Lie algebra. It is the Lie algebra of a closed subgroup N of G. The group N is normalized by M and by A. We may embed the complexification ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq354.gif) of G into ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq355.gif) for some n in such a way that ![
$$G \\subseteq \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq356.gif), ![
$$G_{c} \\subseteq \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq357.gif), ![
$$K \\subseteq \\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq358.gif) , N is upper triangular, and θ(g) = t g −1 .

Proof.

As part of the definition of semisimplicity, it is assumed that the semisimple group G has a faithful complex representation. Since we may embed ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq359.gif) in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(2n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq360.gif), it has a faithful real representation. We may assume that ![
$$G \\subseteq \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq361.gif), where V is a real vector space. We may then assume that the complexification ![
$$G_{\\mathbb{C}} \\subseteq \\mathrm{GL}\(V _{\\mathbb{C}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq362.gif), where ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathbb{C} \\otimes V$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq363.gif) is the complexified vector space.

The proof that ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq364.gif) is nilpotent is identical to Proposition 26.4 but uses Proposition 29.5 (iv) instead of Proposition 18.4 (ii). By Lie's Theorem 26.1, we can find an ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq365.gif)-basis v 1,...,v n of V such that each ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq366.gif) is upper triangular with respect to this basis. It is nilpotent as a matrix by Proposition 26.5.

Choose a G c -invariant inner product on ![
$$V _{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq367.gif) (i.e., a positive definite Hermitian form ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq368.gif)). It induces an inner product on V; that is, its restriction to V is a positive definite ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq369.gif)-bilinear form. Now applying Gram–Schmidt orthogonalization to the basis v 1,...,v n , we may assume that they are orthonormal. This does not alter the fact that ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq370.gif) consists of upper triangular matrices. It follows by imitating the argument of Theorem 26.2 that ![
$$N =\\exp \(\\mathfrak{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq371.gif) is a Lie group with Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq372.gif). The group M normalizes N because its Lie algebra normalizes the Lie algebra of N by Proposition 18.4 (iii), so the Lie algebra of N is invariant under Ad(MA).

We have ![
$$G \\subseteq \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq373.gif) since G stabilizes V. It is also clear that ![
$$G_{c} \\subseteq \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq374.gif) since v i are an orthonormal basis and the inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq375.gif) was chosen to be G c -invariant. Since ![
$$K \\subseteq G \\cap G_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq376.gif), we have ![
$$K \\subseteq \\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq377.gif).

It remains to be shown that θ(g) = t g −1 for g ∈ G. Since G is assumed to be connected in Hypothesis 28.1, it is sufficient to show that θ(X) = − t X for ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq378.gif), and we may treat the cases ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq379.gif) and ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq380.gif) separately. If ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq381.gif), then X is skew-symmetric since ![
$$K \\subseteq \\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq382.gif). Thus, θ(X) = X = − t X. On the other hand, if ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq383.gif), then ![
$$iX \\in \\mathfrak{g}_{c}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq384.gif), and iX is skew-Hermitian because ![
$$G_{c} \\subseteq \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq385.gif). Thus, X is symmetric, and θ(X) = −X = − t X. □

Since M normalizes N, we have a Lie subgroup B = MAN of G. We may call it the (standard) ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq386.gif)-Borel subgroup of G. (If G is split or quasisplit, one may omit the "![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq387.gif)-" from this designation.) Let B 0 = AN.

Theorem 29.2.

(Iwasawa decomposition) With notations as above, each element of g ∈ G can be factored uniquely as bk, where b ∈ B 0 and k ∈ K, or as aνk where a ∈ A, ν ∈ N, and k ∈ K. The multiplication map ![
$$A \\times N \\times K\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq388.gif) is a diffeomorphism.

Proof.

This is nearly identical to Theorem 26.3, and we mostly leave the proof to the reader. We consider only the key point that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} = \\mathfrak{a} + \\mathfrak{n} + \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq389.gif). It is sufficient to show that ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}_{\\mathbb{C}} = \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{a} + \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{n} + \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq390.gif). We have ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}} \\subseteq \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{a} + \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{m} \\subseteq \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{a} + \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq391.gif), so it is sufficient to show that ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{n} + \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq392.gif) contains ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq393.gif) for each β ∈Φ. If β restricts trivially to A, then ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta } \\subseteq \\mathbb{C}\\mathfrak{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq394.gif) by Proposition 29.6, so we may assume that β restricts nontrivially. Let α be the restriction of β. If β ∈Φ +, then ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta } \\subseteq \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha } \\subset \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq395.gif). On the other hand, if β ∈Φ − and ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta }$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq396.gif), then ![
$$X + \\theta \(X\) \\in \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq397.gif) and ![
$$\\theta \(X\) \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{-\\beta } \\subseteq \\mathfrak{X}_{-\\alpha } \\subset \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq398.gif). In either case, ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\beta } \\subset \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{k} + \\mathbb{C}\\,\\mathfrak{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq399.gif). □

Our next goal is to show that the maximal Abelian subspace ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq400.gif) is unique up to conjugacy. First, we need an analog of Proposition 18.14 (ii). Let us say that ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq401.gif) is regular if it is contained in a unique maximal Abelian subspace of ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq402.gif) and singular if it is not regular.

Proposition 29.11.

(i)

If H is regular and ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq403.gif) satisfies [H,Z] = 0, then ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq404.gif) .

(ii)

An element ![
$$H \\in \\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq405.gif) is singular if and only if dα(H) = 0 for some α ∈Φ rel .

Proof.

The element H is singular if and only if there is some ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{p} - \\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq406.gif) such that [Z,H] = 0, for if this is the case, then H is contained in at least two distinct maximal Abelian subspaces, namely ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq407.gif) and any maximal Abelian subspace containing the Abelian subspace ![
$$\\mathbb{R}Z + \\mathbb{R}H$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq408.gif). Conversely, if no such Z exists, then any maximal Abelian subgroup containing H must obviously coincide with ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq409.gif).

Now (i) is clear.

We also use this criterion to prove (ii). Consider the decomposition of ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq410.gif) in the eigenspace decomposition (29.4):

![
$$\\displaystyle{Z = Z_{0} +\\sum _{\\alpha \\in \\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}}Z_{\\alpha },Z_{0} \\in \\mathbb{C}\(\\mathfrak{m} \\oplus \\mathfrak{a}\),\\;Z_{\\alpha } \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equal.gif)

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{0 = \[H,Z\] = \[H,Z_{0}\] +\\sum _{\\alpha \\in \\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}}\[H,Z_{\\alpha }\] =\\sum _{\\alpha \\in \\varPhi _{\\mathrm{rel}}}\\mathrm{d}\\alpha \(H\)Z_{\\alpha }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_Equam.gif)

Thus, for all α ∈Φ rel, we have either dα(H) = 0 or Z α = 0. So if dα(H)≠0 for all H then all Z α = 0 and ![
$$Z = Z_{0} \\in \\mathbb{C}\(\\mathfrak{m} \\oplus \\mathfrak{a}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq411.gif). Since ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq412.gif), this implies that ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq413.gif), and so H is regular. On the other hand, if dα = 0 for some α, then we can take ![
$$Z = Z_{\\alpha } - \\theta \(Z_{\\alpha }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq414.gif) for nonzero ![
$$Z_{\\alpha } \\in \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{rel}} \\cap \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq415.gif) and [Z,H] = 0, ![
$$Z \\in \\mathfrak{p} - \\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq416.gif). □

Theorem 29.3.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq417.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq418.gif) be two maximal Abelian subspaces of ![
$$\\mathfrak{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq419.gif) . Then there exists a ![
$$k \\in \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq420.gif) such that ![
$$\\mathrm{Ad}\(k\)\\mathfrak{a}_{1} = \\mathfrak{a}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq421.gif) .

Thus, the relative root system does not dependent in any essential way on the choice of ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq422.gif). The argument is similar to the proof of Theorem 16.4.

Proof.

By Proposition 29.11 (ii), ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq423.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{a}_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq424.gif) contain regular elements H 1 and H 2. We will show that ![
$$\[\\mathrm{Ad}\(k\)H_{1},H_{2}\] = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq425.gif) for some ![
$$k \\in \\mathfrak{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_29_Chapter_IEq426.gif). Choose an Ad-invariant inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$

# 30. Embeddings of Lie Groups

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In this chapter, we will contemplate how Lie groups embed in one another. Our aim is not to be systematic or even completely precise but to give the reader some tools for thinking about the relationships between different Lie groups.

In this chapter, we will contemplate how Lie groups embed in one another. Our aim is not to be systematic or even completely precise but to give the reader some tools for thinking about the relationships between different Lie groups.

If G is a Lie group and H a subgroup, then there exists a chain of Lie subgroups of G,

![
$$\\displaystyle{G = G_{0} \\supset G_{1} \\supset \\cdots \\supset G_{n} = H}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equa.gif)

such that each G i is maximal in G i−1. Dynkin [45–47] classified the maximal subgroups of semisimple complex analytic groups. Thus, the lattice of semisimple complex analytic subgroups of such a group is known.

Let K 1 and K 2 be compact connected Lie groups, and let G 1 and G 2 be their complexifications. Given an embedding ![
$$K_{1}\\longrightarrow K_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq1.gif), there is a unique analytic embedding ![
$$G_{1}\\longrightarrow G_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq2.gif). The converse is also true: given an analytic embedding ![
$$G_{1}\\longrightarrow G_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq3.gif), then K 1 embeds as a compact subgroup of G 2. However, any compact subgroup of G 2 is conjugate to a subgroup of K 2 (Theorem 28.2), so K 1 is conjugate to a subgroup of K 2. Thus, embeddings of compact connected Lie groups and analytic embeddings of their complexifications are essentially the same thing. To be definite, let us specify that in this chapter we are talking about analytic embeddings of complex analytic groups, with the understanding that the ideas will be applicable in other contexts. By a "torus," we therefore mean a group analytically isomorphic to ![
$${\(\\mathbb{C}\)}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq4.gif) for some n. We will allow ourselves to be a bit sloppy in this chapter, and we will sometimes write O(n) when we should really write ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq5.gif).

So let us start with embeddings of complex analytic Lie groups. A useful class of complex analytic groups that is slightly larger than the semisimple ones is the class of reductive complex analytic groups. A complex analytic group G (connected, let us assume) is called reductive if its linear analytic representations are completely reducible. For example, ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq6.gif) is reductive, though it is not semisimple.

Examples of groups that are not reductive are parabolic subgroups. Let G be the complexification of the compact connected Lie group K, and let B be the Borel subgroup described in Theorem 26.2. A subgroup of G containing B is called a standard parabolic subgroup. (Any conjugate of a standard parabolic subgroup is called parabolic.)

As an example of a group that is not reductive, let ![
$$P \\subset \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq7.gif) be the maximal parabolic subgroup consisting of matrices

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & {\\ast}\\\\ &g_{ 2} \\end{array} \\right \),g_{1} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{C}\),g_{2} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(s, \\mathbb{C}\),\\quad r+s = n.}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equb.gif)

In the standard representation corresponding to the inclusion ![
$$P\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq8.gif), the set of matrices which have last s entries that are zero is a P-invariant subspace of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq9.gif) that has no invariant complement. Therefore, this representation is not completely reducible, and so P is not reductive.

If G is the complexification of a connected compact group, then analytic representations of G are completely reducible by Theorem 24.1. It turns out that the converse is true—a connected complex analytic reductive group is the complexification of a compact Lie group. We will not prove this, but it is useful to bear in mind that whatever we prove for complexifications of connected compact groups is applicable to the class of reductive complex analytic Lie groups.

Even if we restrict ourselves to finding reductive subgroups of reductive Lie groups, the problem is very difficult. After all, any faithful representation gives an embedding of a Lie group in another. There is an important class of embeddings for which it is possible to give a systematic discussion. Following Dynkin, we call an embedding of Lie groups or Lie algebras regular if it takes a maximal torus into a maximal torus and roots into roots. Our first aim is to show how regular embeddings can be recognized using extended Dynkin diagrams.

We will use orthogonal groups to illustrate some points. It is convenient to take the orthogonal group in the form

We will take the realization ![
$$\\mathrm{O}_{J}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\cap \\mathrm{U}\(n\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq10.gif) of the usual orthogonal group in Exercise 5.3 with the maximal torus T consisting of diagonal elements of ![
$$\\mathrm{O}_{J}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\cap \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq11.gif). Then, as in Exercise 24.1, ![
$$\\mathrm{O}_{J}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq12.gif) is the analytic complexification of the usual orthogonal group ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq13.gif). We can take the ordering of the roots so that the root eigenspaces ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq14.gif) with α ∈Φ + are upper triangular.

We recall that the root system of type D n is the root system for SO(2n). Normally, one only considers D n when ![
$$n \\geqslant 4$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq15.gif). The reason for this is that the Lie groups SO(4) and SO(6) have root systems of types A 1 × A 1 and A 3, respectively. To see this, consider the Lie algebra of type SO(8). This consists of the set of all matrices of the form in Fig. 30.1.

The Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq16.gif) of T consists of the subalgebra of diagonal matrices, where all x ij = 0. The 24 roots α are such that each ![

Looking at the simple roots, we can see the inclusions of Dynkin diagrams in Fig. 30.2. The shadings of the nodes correspond to the shadings in Fig. 30.1.

The coincidences of root systems ![
$$D_{2} = A_{1} \\times A_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq19.gif) and D 3 = A 3 are worth explaining from another point of view. We may realize the group SO(4) concretely as follows. Let ![
$$V = \\mathrm{Mat}_{2}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq20.gif). The determinant is a nondegenerate quadratic form on the four-dimensional vector space V. Since all nondegenerate quadratic forms are equivalent, the group of linear transformations of V preserving the determinant may thus be identified with SO(4). We consider the group

![
$$\\displaystyle{G =\\{ \(g_{1},g_{2}\) \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\,\\vert \\,\\det \(g_{1}\) =\\det \(g_{2}\)\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equc.gif)

This group acts on V by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(g_{1},g_{2}\): X\\longmapsto g_{1}Xg_{2}^{-1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equd.gif)

This action preserves the determinant, so we have a homomorphism ![
$$G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{O}\(4\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq21.gif). There is a kernel Z Δ consisting of the scalar matrices in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq22.gif) embedded diagonally. We therefore have an injective homomorphism ![
$$G/{Z}^{\\varDelta }\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{O}\(4\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq23.gif). Both groups have dimension 6, so this homomorphism is a surjection onto the connected component SO(4) of the identity.

Fig. 30.2

The inclusions ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(4\) \\rightarrow \\mathrm{SO}\(6\) \\rightarrow \\mathrm{SO}\(8\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq24.gif)

Using the fact that ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq25.gif) is algebraically closed, the subgroup ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) of G maps surjectively onto SO(4). The kernel of the map
