$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{SO}\(4\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Eque.gif)

has order 2, and we may identify the simply-connected group ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) as the double cover ![
$$\\mathrm{Spin}\(4, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq28123.gif). Since SO(4) is a quotient of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq29123.gif), we see why its root system is of type A 1 × A 1.

Remark 30.1.

Although we could have worked with ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) at the outset, over a field F that was not algebraically closed, it is often better to use the realization ![
$$G/{Z}^{\\varDelta }\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{SO}\(4\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq31123.gif). The reason is that if F is not algebraically closed, the image of the homomorphism ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2,F\) \\times \\mathrm{SL}\(2,F\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{SO}\(4,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) may not be all of SO(4). Identifying ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2\) \\times \\mathrm{SL}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) with the algebraic group Spin(4), this is a special instance of the fact that the covering map ![
$$\\mathrm{Spin}\(n\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{SO}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq34123.gif), though surjective over an algebraically closed field, is not generally surjective on rational points over a field that is not algebraically closed. A surjective map may instead be obtained by working with the group of similitudes GSpin(n), which when n = 4 is the group G. This is analogous to the fact that the homomorphism ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2,F\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{PGL}\(2,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq35.gif) is not surjective if F is algebraically closed, which is why the adjoint group PGL(2,F) of SL(2) is constructed as GL(2,F) modulo the center, not SL(2) modulo the center.

We turn next to SO(6). Let W be a four-dimensional complex vector space. There is a homomorphism ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(W\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\({\\wedge }^{2}W\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{GL}\(6, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq36.gif), namely the exterior square map, and there is a homomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{GL}\({\\wedge }^{2}W\)\\mathop{\\longrightarrow }\\limits^{{\\wedge }^{2} }\\mathrm{GL}\({\\wedge }^{4}W\)\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equf.gif)

The latter map is symmetric since in the exterior algebra

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(v_{1} \\wedge \\ldots \\wedge v_{r}\) \\wedge \(w_{1} \\wedge \\ldots \\wedge w_{s}\) = {\(-1\)}^{rs}\(w_{ 1} \\wedge \\ldots \\wedge w_{s}\) \\wedge \(v_{1} \\wedge \\ldots \\wedge v_{r}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equg.gif)

(Each v i has to move past each w j producing rs sign changes.) Hence we may regard ∧2 as a quadratic form on GL(∧2 W). The subspace preserving the determinant is therefore isomorphic to SO(6). The composite

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{GL}\(W\)\\mathop{\\longrightarrow }\\limits^{{\\wedge }^{2} }\\mathrm{GL}\({\\wedge }^{2}W\)\\mathop{\\longrightarrow }\\limits ^{{\\wedge }^{2} }\\mathrm{GL}\({\\wedge }^{4}W\)\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equh.gif)

is the determinant, so the image of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(W\) = \\mathrm{SL}\(4, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq37.gif) in GL(∧2 W) is therefore contained in SO(6). Both ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(4, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq38.gif) and SO(6) are 15-dimensional and connected, so we have constructed a homomorphism onto SO(6). The kernel consists of { ± 1}, so we see that ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(6\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{SL}\(4, \\mathbb{C}\)/\\{ \\pm I\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq39.gif). Since SO(6) is a quotient of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(4, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq40.gif), we see why its root system is of type A 3.

The maps discussed so far, involving SO(2n) with n = 2,3, and 4, are regular. Sometimes (as in these examples) regular embeddings can be recognized by inclusions of ordinary Dynkin diagrams, but a fuller picture will emerge if we introduce the extended Dynkin diagram.

Let K be a compact connected Lie group with maximal torus T. Let G be its complexification. Let Φ, Φ +, Σ, and other notations be as in Chap.​ 18.

Proposition 30.1.

Suppose in this setting that S is any set of roots such that if α,β ∈ S and if α + β ⊂Φ, then α + β ∈ S. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{h} = \\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}} \\oplus \\bigoplus _{\\alpha \\in S}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equi.gif)

is a Lie subalgebra of Lie (G).

Proof.

It is immediate from Proposition 18.4 (ii) and Proposition 18.3 (ii) that this vector space is closed under the bracket. □

We will not worry too much about verifying that ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq41.gif) is the Lie algebra of a closed Lie subgroup of G except to remark that we have some tools for this, such as Theorem 14.3.

We have already introduced the Dynkin diagram in Chap.​ 25. We recall that the Dynkin diagram is obtained as a graph whose vertices are in bijection with Σ. Let us label ![
$$\\varSigma =\\{ \\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{r}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq42.gif), and let ![
$$s_{i} = s_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq43.gif). Let ![
$$\\theta \(\\alpha _{i},\\alpha _{j}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq44.gif) be the angle between the roots α i and α j . Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{n\(s_{i},s_{j}\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cc} 2& \\mbox{ if $\\theta \(\\alpha _{i},\\alpha _{j}\) = \\frac{\\pi } {2} $,}\\\\ & \\\\ 3& \\mbox{ if $\\theta \(\\alpha _{i},\\alpha _{j}\) = \\frac{2\\pi } {3} $,}\\\\ & \\\\ 4& \\mbox{ if $\\theta \(\\alpha _{i},\\alpha _{j}\) = \\frac{3\\pi } {4} $,}\\\\ & \\\\ 6&\\mbox{ if $\\theta \(\\alpha _{i},\\alpha _{j}\) = \\frac{5\\pi } {6} $.} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equj.gif)

The extended Dynkin diagram adjoins to the graph of the Dynkin diagram one more node, which corresponds to the negative root α0 such that − α0 is the highest weight vector in the adjoint representation. The negative root α0 is sometimes called the affine root, because of its role in the affine root system (Chap.​ 23). As in the usual Dynkin diagram, we connect the vertices corresponding to α i and α j only if the roots are not orthogonal. If they make an angle of 2π∕3, we connect them with a single bond; if they make an angle of 6π∕4, we connect them with a double bond; and if they make an angle of 5π∕6, we connect them with a triple bond.

The basic paradigm is that if we remove a node from the extended Dynkin diagram, what remains will be the Dynkin diagram of a subgroup of G. To get some feeling for why this is true, let us consider an example in the exceptional group G 2. We may take S in Proposition 30.1 to be the set of six long roots. These form a root system of type A 2, and ![
$$\\mathfrak{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq45.gif) is the Lie algebra of a Lie subgroup isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(3, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq46.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(3, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq47.gif) is the complexification of the simply-connected compact Lie group SU(2), it follows from Theorem 14.3 that there is a homomorphism ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(3, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq48.gif).

Fig. 30.3

The exceptional root α0 of G 2 (• = positive roots)

The ordinary Dynkin diagram of G 2 does not reflect the existence of this embedding. However, from Fig. 30.3, we see that the roots α2 and α0 can be taken as the simple roots of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(3, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq49.gif). The embedding ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(3, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq50.gif) can be understood as an inclusion of the A 2 (ordinary) Dynkin diagram in the extended G 2 Dynkin diagram (Fig. 30.4).

Fig. 30.4

The inclusion of SL(3) in G 2

Let us consider some more extended Dynkin diagrams. If n > 2, and if G is the odd orthogonal group SO(2n \+ 1), its root system is of type B n , and its extended Dynkin diagram is as in Fig. 30.5. We confirm this in Fig. 30.6 for SO(9) – that is, when n = 4 – by explicitly marking the simple roots α1,...,α n and the largest root α0.

Fig. 30.5

Next, if ![
$$n \\geqslant 5$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq51.gif) and ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SO}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq52.gif), the root system of G is D n , and the extended Dynkin diagram is as in Fig. 30.7. For example if n = 5, the configuration of roots is as in Fig. 30.8.

We leave it to the reader to check the extended Dynkin diagrams of the symplectic group Sp(2n), which is of type C n (Fig. 30.9).

The extended Dynkin diagram of type A n ![
$$\(n \\geqslant 2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq53.gif) is shown in Fig. 30.10. It has the feature that removing a node leaves the diagram connected. Because of this, the paradigm of finding subgroups of a Lie group by examining the extended Dynkin diagram does not produce any interesting examples for SL(n \+ 1) or GL(n \+ 1).

We already encountered the extended Dynkin diagram of G 2 is in Fig. 30.4. The extended Dynkin diagrams of all the exceptional groups are listed in Fig. 30.11.

Our first paradigm of recognizing the embedding of a group H in G by embedding the ordinary Dynkin diagram of H in the extended Dynkin diagram of G predicts the embedding of SO(2n) in SO(2n \+ 1) but not the embedding of SO(2n \+ 1) in SO(2n \+ 2). For this we need another paradigm, which we call root folding.

We note that the Dynkin diagram D n+1 has a symmetry interchanging the vertices α n and α n+1. This corresponds to an outer automorphism of SO(2n \+ 2), namely conjugation by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} I_{n-1} & & \\\\ & \\begin{array}{|c|} \\hline \\begin{array}{cc} \\,0\\,&1\\\\ 1 &\\,0\\, \\end{array} \\\\\\hline  \\end{array} & \\\\ & &I_{n-1} \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equk.gif)

which is in O(2n \+ 2) but not SO(2n \+ 2). The fixed subgroup of this outer automorphism stabilizes the vector ![
$$v_{0} {= }^{t}\(0,\\ldots,0,1,-1,0,\\ldots,0\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq54.gif). This vector is not isotropic (that is, it does not have length zero) so the stabilizer is the group SO(2n \+ 1) fixing the 2n \+ 1-dimensional orthogonal complement of v 0. In this embedding ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n + 1\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{SO}\(2n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq55.gif), the short simple root of SO(2n \+ 1) is embedded into the direct sum of ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha _{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq56.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha _{n+1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq57.gif). We invite the reader to confirm this for the embedding of ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(9\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{SO}\(10\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq58.gif) with the above matrices. We envision the D n+1 Dynkin diagram being folded into the B n diagram, as in Fig. 30.12.

Fig. 30.12

Embedding ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2n + 1\)\\hookrightarrow \\mathrm{SO}\(2n + 2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq59.gif) as "folding"

The Dynkin diagram of type D 4 admits a rare symmetry of order 3 (Fig. 30.13). This is associated with a phenomenon known as triality, which we now discuss.

Fig. 30.13

Triality

Referring to Fig. 30.1, the groups ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq60.gif) (i = 1,2,3,4) correspond to x 12, x 23, x 34 and x 35, respectively. The Lie algebra will thus have an automorphism τ that sends ![
$$x_{12}\\longrightarrow x_{34}\\longrightarrow x_{35}\\longrightarrow x_{12}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq61.gif) and fixes x 23. Let us consider the effect on ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq62.gif), which is the subalgebra of elements t with all x ij = 0. Noting that ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\alpha _{1}\(t\) = t_{1} - t_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq63.gif), ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\alpha _{2}\(t\) = t_{2} - t_{3}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq64.gif), ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\alpha _{3}\(t\) = t_{3} - t_{4}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq65.gif), and ![
$$\\mathrm{d}\\alpha _{4}\(t\) = t_{3} + t_{4}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq66.gif), we must have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\tau: \\left \\{\\begin{array}{ccc} t_{1} - t_{2} & \\longmapsto & t_{3} - t_{4} \\\\ t_{2} - t_{3} & \\longmapsto & t_{2} - t_{3} \\\\ t_{3} - t_{4} & \\longmapsto & t_{3} + t_{4} \\\\ t_{3} + t_{4} & \\longmapsto & t_{1} - t_{2} \\end{array} \\right.,}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equl.gif)

from which we deduce that

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\tau \(t_{1}\) = \\tfrac{1} {2}\(t_{1} + t_{2} + t_{3} - t_{4}\)\\,,& & {}\\\\ \\tau \(t_{2}\) = \\tfrac{1} {2}\(t_{1} + t_{2} - t_{3} + t_{4}\)\\,,& & {}\\\\ \\tau \(t_{3}\) = \\tfrac{1} {2}\(t_{1} - t_{2} + t_{3} + t_{4}\)\\,,& & {}\\\\ \\tau \(t_{4}\) = \\tfrac{1} {2}\(t_{1} - t_{2} - t_{3} - t_{4}\)\\,.& & {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

At first this is puzzling since, translated to a statement about the group, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\tau \\left \(\\begin{array}{cccccccc} t_{1} & & & & & & & \\\\ & t_{2} & & & & & & \\\\ & & t_{3} & & & & & \\\\ & & & t_{4} & & & & \\\\ & & & & t_{4}^{-1} & & & \\\\ & & & & & t_{3}^{-1} & & \\\\ & & & & & & t_{2}^{-1} & \\\\ & & & & & & & t_{1}^{-1} \\end{array} \\right \) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cccccccc} \\,t_{1}^{\\prime}\\, & & & & & & & \\\\ & \\,t_{2}^{\\prime}\\, & & & & & & \\\\ & & \\,t_{3}^{\\prime}\\, & & & & & \\\\ & & & \\,t_{4}^{\\prime}\\, & & & & \\\\ & & & & t_{4}^{{\\prime}\\;-1} & & & \\\\ & & & & & \\!\\!t_{3}^{{\\prime}\\;-1} & & \\\\ & & & & & & \\!\\!t_{2}^{{\\prime}\\;-1} & \\\\ & & & & & & & \\!\\!t_{1}^{{\\prime}\\;-1} \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equm.gif)

where

![
$$\\displaystyle{t_{1}^{\\prime} = \\sqrt{t_{1 } t_{2 } t_{3 } t_{4 }^{-1}}\\;,t_{2}^{\\prime} = \\sqrt{t_{1 } t_{2 } t_{3 }^{-1 }t_{4}}\\;,}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equn.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{t_{3}^{\\prime} = \\sqrt{t_{1 } t_{2 }^{-1 }t_{3 } t_{4}}\\;,t_{4}^{\\prime} = \\sqrt{t_{1 } t_{2 }^{-1 }t_{3 }^{-1 }t_{4 }^{-1}}\\;.}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equo.gif)

Due to the ambiguity of the square roots, this is not a univalent map.

The explanation is that since SO(8) is not simply-connected, a Lie algebra automorphism cannot necessarily be lifted to the group. However, there is automatically induced an automorphism τ of the simply-connected double cover Spin(8). The center of Spin(8) is ![
$$\(\\mathbb{Z}/2\\mathbb{Z}\) \\times \(\\mathbb{Z}/2\\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq67.gif), which has an automorphism of order 3 that does not preserve the kernel (of order 2) of τ. If we divide Spin(8) by its entire center ![
$$\(\\mathbb{Z}/2\\mathbb{Z}\) \\times \(\\mathbb{Z}/2\\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq68.gif), we obtain the adjoint group PGO(8), and the triality automorphism of Spin(8) induces an automorphism of order 3 of PGO(8). To summarize, triality is an automorphism of order 3 of either Spin(8) or PGO(8) but not of SO(8).

The fixed subgroup of τ in either Spin(8) or PGO(8) is the exceptional group G 2, and the inclusion of G 2 in Spin(8) can be understood as a folding of roots. The unipotent subgroup corresponding to a short simple root of G 2 is included diagonally in the three root groups ![
$$\\exp \(\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha _{i}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq69.gif), (i = 1,3,4) of Spin(8) as in Fig. 30.14 (left).

Triality has the following interpretation. The quadratic space V of dimension 8 on which SO(8) acts can be given the structure of a nonassociative algebra known as the octonions or Cayley numbers.

If f 1: V ⟶ V is any nonsingular orthogonal linear transformation, there exist linear transformations f 2 and f 3 such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{f_{1}\(xy\) = f_{2}\(x\)f_{3}\(y\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equp.gif)

The linear transformations f 2 and f 3 are only determined up to sign. The maps ![
$$ f_1 \\longmapsto f_2 $$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq301.gif) and ![
$$ f_1 \\longmapsto f_3 $$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq302.gif), though thus not well-defined as an automorphisms of SO(8), do lift to well-defined automorphisms of Spin(8), and the resulting automorphism ![
$$ f_1 \\longmapsto f_2 $$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq303.gif) is the triality automorphism. Triality permutes the three orthogonal maps f 1, f 2, and f 3 cyclicly. Note that if ![
$$f_{1} = f_{2} = f_{3}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq70.gif), then f 1 is an automorphism of the octonion ring, so the fixed group G 2 is the automorphism group of the octonions. See Chevalley [36], p.188. As an alternative to Chevalley's approach, one may first prove a local form of triality as in Jacobson [88] and then deduce the global form. See also Schafer [146]. Over an algebraically closed field, the octonion algebra is unique. Over the real numbers there are two forms, which correspond to the compact group O(8) and the split form O(4,4).

So far, the examples we have given of folding correspond to automorphisms of the group G. For an example that does not, consider the embedding of G 2 into Spin(7) (Fig. 30.14, right).

Fig. 30.14

The group G 2 embedded in Spin(8) and Spin(7)

A frequent way in which large subgroups of a Lie group arise is as fixed points of automorphisms, usually involutions. Many of these subgroups can be understood by the the paradigms explained above. A list of such subgroups can be found in Table 28.​1, for in this list, the compact subgroup K is the fixed point of an involution in the compact group G c , and this relationship is also true for the complexifications. For example, the first entry, corresponding to Cartan's classification AI, is the symmetric space with G c = SU(n) and the subgroup K = SO(n). Assuming that we use the version of the orthogonal group in Exercise 5.3, the involution θ is ![
$$g\\mapsto {J\\,}^{t}{g}^{-1}\\,J$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq71.gif), where J is given by (5.3). This involution extends to the complexification ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq72.gif), and the fixed point set is the subgroup ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq73.gif). If n is odd, then every simple root eigenspace of ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq74.gif) embeds in the direct sum of one or two simple root eigenspaces of ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq75.gif), and the embedding may be understood as an example of the root folding paradigm. But if n = 2r is even, then one of the roots of SO(2r), namely the simple root ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{r-1} + \\mathbf{e}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq76.gif), involves non-simple roots of SL(n).

Suppose that V 1 and V 2 are quadratic spaces (that is, vector spaces equipped with nondegenerate symmetric bilinear forms). Then V 1 ⊕ V 2 is naturally a quadratic space, so we have an embedding ![
$$\\mathrm{O}\(V _{1}\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(V _{2}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{O}\(V _{1} \\oplus V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq77.gif). The same is true if V 1 and V 2 are symplectic (that is, equipped with nondegenerate skew-symmetric bilinear forms). It follows that we have embeddings

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{O}\(r\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(s\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{O}\(r + s\),\\qquad \\mathrm{Sp}\(2r\) \\times \\mathrm{Sp}\(2s\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Sp}\\big\(2\(r + s\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equq.gif)

These embeddings can be understood as embeddings of extended Dynkin diagrams except in the orthogonal case where r and s are both odd (Exercise 30.2.

Also, if V 1 and V 2 are vector spaces with bilinear forms ![
$$\\beta _{i}: V _{i} \\times V _{i}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq78.gif), then there is a bilinear form B on V 1 ⊗ V 2 such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{B\(v_{1} \\otimes v_{2},v_{1}^{\\prime} \\otimes v_{2}^{\\prime}\) = \\beta _{1}\(v_{1},v_{1}^{\\prime}\)\\,\\beta _{2}\(v_{2},v_{2}^{\\prime}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equr.gif)

If both β1 and β2 are either symmetric or skew-symmetric, then B is symmetric. If one of β1 and β2 is symmetric and the other skew-symmetric, then B is skew-symmetric. Therefore, we have embeddings

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{O}\(r\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(s\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{O}\(rs\),\\qquad\\mathrm{Sp}\(2r\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(s\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Sp}\(2rs\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equs.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathrm{Sp}\(2r\) \\times \\mathrm{Sp}\(2s\) \\rightarrow \\mathrm{Sp}\(4rs\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(30.1)

The second embedding is the single most important "dual reductive pair," which is fundamental in automorphic forms and representation theory. A dual reductive pair in a Lie or algebraic group H consists of reductive subgroups G 1 and G 2 embedded in such a way that G 1 is the centralizer of G 2 in H and conversely. If H is the symplectic group, or more properly its "metaplectic" double cover, then H has an important infinite-dimensional representation ω introduced by Weil [172]. Weil showed in [173] that in many cases the restriction of the Weil representation to a dual reductive pair can be used to understand classical correspondences of automorphic forms due to Siegel. The importance of this phenomenon cannot be overstated. From Weil's point of view this phenomenon is a global one, but Howe [73] gave better foundations, including a local theory. This is a topic that transcends Lie theory since in much of the literature one will consider O(s) or Sp(2r) as algebraic groups defined over a p-adic field or a number field (and its adele ring). Expositions of pure Lie group applications may be found in Howe and Tan [78] and Goodman and Wallach [56].

The classification of dual reductive pairs in Sp(2n), described in Weil [173] and Howe [73], has its origins in the theory of algebras with involutions, due to Albert [5]. The connection between algebras with involutions and the theory of algebraic groups was emphasized earlier by Weil [171]. A modern and immensely valuable treatise on algebras with involutions and their relations with the theory of algebraic groups may be found in Knus, Merkurjev, Rost, and Tignol [107].

A classification of dual reductive pairs in exceptional groups is in Rubenthaler [138]. These examples have proved interesting in the theory of automorphic forms since an analog of the Weil representation is available.

So far, our point of view has been to start with a group G and understand its large subgroups H, and we have a set of examples sufficient for understanding most, but not all such pairs. Let us consider the alternative question: given H, how can we embed it in a larger group G?

Suppose, therefore that π: H →GL(V ) is a representation. We assume that it is faithful and irreducible. Then we get an embedding of H into GL(V ). However sometimes there is a smaller subgroup ![
$$G \\subset \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq79.gif) such that the image of π is contained in G. A frequent case is that G is an orthogonal or symplectic group. These cases may be classified by considering the theory of the Frobenius-Schur indicator, which is discussed in the exercises to this chapter and again in Chap.​ 43. The Frobenius-Schur indicator ε(π) is the multiplicity of the trivial character in the generalized character g↦χ(g 2), where χ is the character of π. It equals 0 unless ![
$$\\pi =\\hat{ \\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq80.gif) is self-contragredient, in which case either it equals 1 and π is orthogonal, or − 1 and π is symplectic. This means that if ε(π) = 1, then we may take G = O(n) where n = dim(V ), while if ![
$$\\epsilon \(\\pi \) = -1$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq81.gif), then dim(V ) is even, and we may take G = Sp(n).

The examples (30.1) can be understood this way. Here's a couple more. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{H} = \\mathrm{SL}\(2\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq82.gif), and let π be the symmetric k-th power representation. The vector space V is k \+ 1-dimensional. Exercise 22.15 computes the Frobenius-Schur indicator, and we see that H embeds in SO(k \+ 1) if k is even, and Sp(k \+ 1) if k is odd. For another example, if H is any simple Lie group, then the adjoint representation is orthogonal since the Killing form on the Lie algebra is a nondegenerate symmetric bilinear form. Thus for example we get an embedding of SL(3) into SO(8).

As a final topic, we discuss parabolic subgroups. Just as regular subgroups of G can be read off from the extended Dynkin diagram, the parabolic subgroups can be read off from the regular Dynkin diagram. Let ![
$$\\varSigma ^{\\prime} \\subset \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq83.gif) be any proper subset of the set of simple roots. Then Σ′ is the set of vertices of a (possibly disconnected) Dynkin diagram ![
$$\\mathcal{D}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq84.gif) contained in that of G. There will be a unique parabolic subgroup P such that, for a simple root α ∈Σ, the space ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{-\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq85.gif) is contained in the Lie algebra of P if and only if α ∈ S.

The roots ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{-\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq86.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq87.gif) with α ∈ S together with ![
$$\\mathfrak{t}_{\\mathbb{C}}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq88.gif) generate a Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq89.gif), which is the Lie algebra of a reductive Lie group M, and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{u} =\\bigoplus _{ \\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{c} \\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+} \\\\ \\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha } \\not\\subseteq \\mathfrak{m} \\end{array} $}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equt.gif)

is the Lie algebra of a unipotent subgroup U of P. (By unipotent we mean here that its image in any analytic representation of G consists of unipotent matrices.) The group P = MU. This factorization is called the Levi decomposition. The subgroup U of P is normal, so this decomposition is a semidirect product. The group M is called the Levi factor, and the group U is called the unipotent radical of P.

We illustrate all this with an example from the symplectic group. We take G = Sp(2n) to be {g | t gJg = J}, where

This realization of the symplectic group has the advantage that the ![
$$\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq90.gif) corresponding to positive roots α ∈Φ + all correspond to upper triangular matrices. We see from Fig. 30.9 that removing a node from the Dynkin diagram of type C n gives a smaller diagram, disconnected unless we take an end vertex, of type ![
$$A_{r-1} \\times C_{n-r}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq91.gif). This is the Dynkin diagram of a maximal parabolic subgroup with Levi factor ![
$$M = \\mathrm{GL}\(r\) \\times \\mathrm{Sp}\\big\(2\(n - r\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq92.gif). The subgroup looks like this:

![
$$\\displaystyle{M = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{c} \\begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \\hline \\,g\\,& & \\\\ \\hline  &\\,h\\,& \\\\ \\hline  & &\\,g^{\\prime}\\, \\\\ \\hline \\end{array} \\end{array} \\right \)\\,\\Big\\vert \\,g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(r\),h \\in \\mathrm{Sp}\(2m\)\\right \\},\\quad U = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{c} \\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}\\hline I_{r}& {\\ast} &{\\ast} \\\\ \\hline &I_{2m}& {\\ast} \\\\ \\hline & &I_{r} \\\\ \\hline \\end{array} \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equu.gif)

Here ![
$$m = n - r$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq93.gif). In the matrix M, the matrix g′ depends on g; it is determined by the requirement that the given matrix be symplectic. Figure 30.15 shows the parabolic subgroup with Levi factor ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(3\) \\times \\mathrm{Sp}\(4\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq94.gif) in GL(10). Its Lie algebra is shaded here: the Lie algebra of M shaded dark and the Lie algebra of U is shaded light.

Fig. 30.15

A parabolic subgroup of Sp(10)

Fig. 30.16

The Levi factor M = GL(3) ×Sp(4) is a proper subgroup of the larger group Sp(6) ×Sp(4), which can be read off from the extended Dynkin diagram. The Lie algebra of Sp(6) ×Sp(4) is shaded dark in Fig. 30.16.

Exercise 30.2.

In doing the last exercise, one case you may have trouble with is the embedding of ![
$$\\mathrm{S}\(\\mathrm{O}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(q\)\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq96.gif) into SO(p \+ q) when p and q are both odd. To get some insight, consider the embedding of SO(5) ×SO(5) into SO(10). (Note: ![
$$\\mathrm{S}\\big\(\\mathrm{O}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(q\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq97.gif) is the group of elements of determinant 1 in O(p) ×O(q) and contains SO(p) ×SO(q) as a subgroup of index 2. For this exercise, it does not matter whether you work with SO(5) ×SO(5) or ![
$$\\mathrm{S}\\big\(\\mathrm{O}\(5\) \\times \\mathrm{O}\(5\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq98.gif).) Take the form of SO(10) in Fig. 30.8. This stabilizes the quadratic form ![
$$x_{1}x_{10} + x_{2}x_{9} + x_{3}x_{8} + x_{4}x_{7} + x_{5}x_{6}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq99.gif). Consider the subspaces

![
$$\\displaystyle{V _{1} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{c} a\\\\ b \\\\ 0\\\\ 0 \\\\ c\\\\ -c \\\\ 0\\\\ 0 \\\\ d\\\\ e\\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},V _{2} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{c} 0\\\\ 0 \\\\ t\\\\ u \\\\ v\\\\ v \\\\ w\\\\ x \\\\ 0\\\\ 0 \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_Equv.gif)

Observe that these five-dimensional spaces are mutually orthogonal and that the restriction of the quadratic form is nondegenerate, so the stabilizers of these two spaces are mutually centralizing copies of SO(5). Exercise 30.3.

Let G be a semisimple Lie group. Assume that the Dynkin diagram of G has no automorphisms. Show that every representation is self-contragredient.

Let ![
$$\\varpi _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq100.gif) and ![
$$\\varpi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq101.gif) be the fundamental dominant weights for Spin(5), so that ![

](A79351_2_En_30_Chapter_IEq104.gif) has three distinct irreducible eight-dimensional representations, namely the standard representation of SO(8) and the two spin representations. Show that these are permuted cyclicly by the triality automorphism.
