# 32. Mackey Theory

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

Given a subgroup H of a finite group G, and a representation π of H, there is an induced representation π G of G. Mackey theory is concerned with intertwining operators between a pair of induced representations. It is based on a very simple idea: if the two representations are induced from subgroups H 1 and H 2, then every such intertwining operator is convolution with suitable function Δ, which has left and right translation properties by H 1 and H 2. This leads to a method of calculating the space of intertwining operators, based on the double cosets H 2\G/H 1.

Given a subgroup H of a finite group G, and a representation π of H, there is an induced representation π G of G. Mackey theory is concerned with intertwining operators between a pair of induced representations. It is based on a very simple idea: if the two representations are induced from subgroups H 1 and H 2, then every such intertwining operator is convolution with suitable function Δ, which has left and right translation properties by H 1 and H 2. This leads to a method of calculating the space of intertwining operators, based on the double cosets ![
$$H_{2}\\setminus G/H_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq1.gif).

If H is a subgroup of the finite group G, and if (π, V ) is a representation of H, then we define the induced representation ![
$$\({\\pi }^{G},{V }^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq2.gif) as follows. The vector space V G consists of all maps ![
$$f: G\\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq3.gif) that satisfy f(hg) = π(h) f(g) when h ∈ H. The representation ![
$${\\pi }^{G}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\({V }^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq4.gif) is by right translation

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\big\({\\pi }^{G}\(g\)f\\big\)\(x\) = f\(xg\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equa.gif)

It is easy to see that if f ∈ V G , then so is π G (g) f, and that π G is a representation. We will sometimes denote the representation ![
$$\({\\pi }^{G},{V }^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq5.gif) as ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{H}^{G}\(\\pi \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq6.gif). If V happens to be one-dimensional, we may identify ![
$$V = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq7.gif). Also in Theorem 32.1 the vector space Hom(V 1, V 2) plays a role; if V 1 and V 2 are one-dimensional we may identify Hom(V 1, V 2) with ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq8.gif).

We begin with an instructive example of how Mackey theory is used in practice. Let G = GL(2, F) where ![
$$F = \\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is a finite field, and let B be the Borel subgroup of upper triangular matrices. Let χ1 and χ2 be characters of F ×. Let χ be the character

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\chi \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} y_{1} & {\\ast}\\\\ &y_{ 2} \\end{array} \\right \) = \\chi _{1}\(y_{1}\)\\chi _{2}\(y_{2}\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(32.1)

of B. Similarly, let μ1 and μ2 be two other characters of F ×, and let μ be the corresponding character of B.

Proposition 32.1.

The representation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{B}^{G}\(\\chi \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq10.gif) is of degree q + 1. It is irreducible unless χ 1 = χ 2 . Moreover, it is isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{B}^{G}\(\\mu \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq11.gif) if and only if either χ 1 = μ 1 and χ 2 = μ 2 or χ 1 = μ 2 and χ 2 = μ 1 .

This completely classifies the principal series representations of GL(2, F). The irreducibles of this type are about half the irreducible representation of GL(2, F). The proof will be complete, assuming one fact that will be proved later in the chapter. The reason for this deviation from linear ordering of the material is heuristic—we assume that the reader will be more cheerful while reading the proof of Theorem 32.1 given an example of how the theorem is used.

Proof.

The index of B in G is easily seen to be q \+ 1, so this is the dimension of the induced representation. We recall that the vector space for the representation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{B}^{G}\(\\chi \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq12.gif) consists of the space of functions ![
$$f: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq13.gif) such that f(bg) = χ(b)f(g). Let us call this space V χ. The key calculation is to compute Hom G (V χ, V μ). We will show that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\begin{array}{c} \\dim \\;\\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{\\chi },V _{\\mu }\) =\\\\ \\\\ \\left \\{\\begin{array}{ll} 1&\\text{if}\\,\\chi _{1} = \\mu _{1},\\chi _{2} = \\mu _{2} \\\\ 0&\\text{otherwise} \\end{array} \\right \\} + \\left \\{\\begin{array}{ll} 1&\\text{if}\\,\\chi _{1} = \\mu _{2},\\chi _{2} = \\mu _{1} \\\\ 0&\\text{otherwise} \\end{array} \\right \\}\\;. \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(32.2)

Before showing how Mackey theory can be used to prove (32.2), let us observe that this implies the proposition. First, if χ1≠χ2, then it shows that ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{\\chi },V _{\\chi }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq14.gif) is one-dimensional, so V χ is irreducible. Moreover, (32.2) shows exactly when there is a nonzero intertwining operator ![
$$V _{\\chi }\\longrightarrow V _{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq15.gif), and the second statement is easily deduced.

To prove (32.2), we make use of Mackey's theorem, which we will prove later in the chapter. We recall that if f 1 and f 2 are functions on G, their convolution is the function

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(f_{1} {\\ast} f_{2}\)\(g\) =\\sum _{h\\in G}f_{1}\(gh\)\\,f_{2}\({h}^{-1}\) =\\sum _{ h\\in G}f_{1}\(h\)\\,f_{2}\({h}^{-1}g\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equb.gif)

Mackey's theorem (Theorem 32.1 below) asserts that any intertwining operator ![
$$T: V _{\\chi }\\longrightarrow V _{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq16.gif) is of the form Tf =Δ ∗ f where ![
$$\\varDelta: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq17.gif) is a function satisfying

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta \(b_{2}g\\,b_{1}\) = \\mu \(b_{2}\)\\varDelta \(g\)\\chi \(b_{1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equc.gif)

Such a function is determined by its values on a set of representatives for the double cosets ![
$$B\\setminus G/B$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq18.gif). By the Bruhat decomposition, there are just two double cosets:

![
$$\\displaystyle{G = B\\,1B\\cup Bw_{0}B,\\qquad w_{0} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} &1\\\\ 1 & \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equd.gif)

where 1 is, of course, the identity matrix. A quick proof is given below ([27.​1).]

So what we will prove is that Δ(1) = 0 unless χ1 = μ1 and χ2 = μ2, and that Δ(w 0) = 1 unless χ1 = μ2 and χ2 = μ1. Indeed,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta \(1\) =\\varDelta \\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} t_{1} & \\\\ & t_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)\\,\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 1& \\\\ &1 \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} t_{1}^{-1} & \\\\ & t_{2}^{-1} \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \) = \\mu \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} t_{1} & \\\\ & t_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)\\varDelta \(1\)\\chi {\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} t_{1} & \\\\ & t_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)}^{-1},}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Eque.gif)

that is,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta \(1\) = \\mu _{1}\(t_{1}\)\\mu _{2}\(t_{2}\)\\chi _{1}{\(t_{1}\)}^{-1}\\chi _{ 2}{\(t_{2}\)}^{-1}\\varDelta \(1\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Unless χ1 = μ1 and χ2 = μ2, we may choose t 1 and t 2 so that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mu _{1}\(t_{1}\)\\mu _{2}\(t_{2}\)\\chi _{1}{\(t_{1}\)}^{-1}\\chi _{ 2}{\(t_{2}\)}^{-1}\\neq 1,}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equg.gif)

proving Δ(1) = 0. The proof that Δ(w 0) = 0 unless χ1 = μ2 and χ2 = μ1 is similar. □

Now let us treat Mackey theory more systematically. We will work with finite groups and with representations over an arbitrary ground field F. In this generality, representations may not be completely reducible. Before considering Mackey theory in general, we will give two functorial interpretations of Frobenius reciprocity that correspond to the two special cases where H 1 = G and H 2 = G.

Let G be a finite group, F a field, and F[G] the group algebra. If ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq19.gif) is an representation in an F-vector space V, then V becomes an F[G] module by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\sum _{g\\in G}c_{g} \\cdot g\\right \)v =\\sum _{g\\in G}c_{g}\\pi \(g\)v,\\qquad \\sum _{g\\in G}c_{g} \\cdot g \\in F\[G\],}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equh.gif)

and, conversely, if V is an F[G]-module, then ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq20.gif) defined by π(g)v = gv is a representation. Thus, the categories of complex representations of G and F[G]-modules are equivalent. In either case, we may refer to V as a G-module. An intertwining operator for two representations is the same as an F[G]-module homomorphism for the corresponding F[G]-modules, and we call such a map a G-module homomorphism.

Also, if (σ, U) is a representation of G, then we can restrict σ to H to obtain a representation of H. We call U H the corresponding H-module. Thus, as sets, U and U H are equal.

Proposition 32.2.

(Frobenius reciprocity, first version) Let H be a subgroup of G and let (π, V ) be a representation of H. Let (σ, U) be a representation of G. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(U,{V }^{G}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Hom}_{ H}\(U_{H},V \). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(32.3)

In this isomorphism, ![
$$J \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(U,{V }^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq21.gif) and ![
$$j \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{H}\(U_{H},V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq22.gif) correspond if and only if j(u) = J(u)(1) and ![
$$J\(u\)\(g\) = j\\big\(\\sigma \(g\)u\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq23.gif) .

Proof.

Given ![
$$J \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(U,{V }^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq24.gif), define j(u) = J(u)(1). We show that j is in Hom H (U H , V ). Indeed, if h ∈ H, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{j\\big\(\\sigma \(h\)u\\big\) = J\\big\(\\sigma \(h\)u\\big\)\(1\) =\\big \({\\pi }^{G}\(h\)\\,J\(u\)\\big\)\(1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equi.gif)

because ![
$$J: U\\longrightarrow {V }^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq25.gif) is G-equivariant. This equals ![
$$J\(u\)\(1.h\) = J\(u\)\(h.1\) = \\pi \(h\)\\,J\(u\)\(1\) = \\pi \(h\)j\(u\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) because h ∈ H and J(u) ∈ V G . Therefore, j ∈Hom H (U H , V ).

Conversely, if ![
$$j \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{H}\(U_{H},V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq27.gif) and u ∈ U, we define ![
$$J\(u\): G\\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq28.gif) by ![
$$J\(u\)\(g\) = j\\big\(\\sigma \(g\)u\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq29.gif). We leave it to the reader to check that J(u) ∈ V G and that J: U → V G is G-equivariant. We also leave it to the reader to check that ![
$$J\\mapsto j$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq30.gif) and ![
$$j\\mapsto J$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq31.gif) are inverse maps and so ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(U,{V }^{G}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Hom}_{H}\(U_{H},V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq32.gif). □

If the ground field ![
$$F = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq33.gif), then we may reinterpret this statement in terms of characters. If η and χ are the characters of U and V, respectively, and if χ G is the character of the representation of G on V G , then by Theorem 2.5 we may express Proposition 32.2 by the well-known character identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \\langle \\chi,\\eta \\right \\rangle _{H} = \\left \\langle {\\chi }^{G},\\eta \\right \\rangle _{ G}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(32.4)

Dual to (32.3) there is also a natural isomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\({V }^{G},U\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Hom}_{ H}\(V,U\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(32.5)

This is slightly more difficult than Proposition 32.2, and it also involves ideas that we will need in our discussion of Mackey theory. We will approach this by means of a universal property.

Proposition 32.3.

Let H be a subgroup of G and let (π, V ) be a representation of H. If v ∈ V, define ![
$$\\epsilon \(v\): G\\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq34.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\epsilon \(v\)\(g\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cc} \\pi \(g\)v& \\text{if}g \\in H,\\\\ 0 &\\text{otherwise}. \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equj.gif)

Then ε(v) ∈ V G , and ![
$$\\epsilon: V \\longrightarrow {V }^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq35.gif) is H-equivariant. Let (σ, U) be a representation of G. If ![
$$j: V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq36.gif) is any H-module homomorphism, then there exists a unique G-module homomorphism ![
$$J: {V }^{G}\\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq37.gif) such that ![
$$j = J \\circ \\epsilon $$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq38.gif) . We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ J\(f\) =\\sum _{\\gamma \\in G/H}\\sigma \(\\gamma \)j\\big\(f\({\\gamma }^{-1}\)\\big\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(32.6)

Proof.

It is easy to check that ε(v) ∈ V G and that if h ∈ H, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\epsilon \\big\(\\pi \(h\)v\\big\) = {\\pi }^{G}\(h\)\\epsilon \(v\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(32.7)

Thus ε is H-equivariant.

We prove that if f ∈ V G , then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ f =\\sum _{G/H}{\\pi }^{G}\(\\gamma \)\\,\\epsilon \\big\(f\({\\gamma }^{-1}\)\\big\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(32.8)

Using (32.7), each term on the right-hand side of (32.8) is independent of the choice of representatives γ of the cosets in G∕H. Let us apply the right-hand side to g ∈ G. We get

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{G/H}\\,\\epsilon \\big\(f\({\\gamma }^{-1}\)\\big\)\(g\\gamma \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Only one coset representative γ of G∕H contributes since, by the definition of ε, the contribution is zero unless gγ ∈ H. Since we have already noted that each term on the right-hand side of (32.8) is independent of the choice of γ modulo right multiplication by an element of H, we may as well choose γ = g −1. We obtain ![
$$\\epsilon \\big\(f\(g\)\\big\)\(1\) = f\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq39.gif). This proves (32.8).

Suppose now that ![
$$J: {V }^{G}\\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq40.gif) is G-equivariant and that j = J ∘ ε. Then, using (32.8),

![
$$\\displaystyle{J\(f\) =\\sum _{G/H}J\\big\({\\pi }^{G}\(\\gamma \)\\epsilon \(f\({\\gamma }^{-1}\)\)\\big\) =\\sum _{ G/H}\\sigma \(\\gamma \)\(J \\circ \\epsilon \)\\big\(f\({\\gamma }^{-1}\)\\big\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equl.gif)

so J must satisfy (32.6). We leave it to the reader to check that J defined by (32.6) is independent of the choice of representatives γ for G∕H. We check that it is G-equivariant. If g ∈ G, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{J\\big\({\\pi }^{G}\(g\)f\\big\) =\\sum _{ \\gamma \\in G/H}\\sigma \(\\gamma \)j\\big\(f\({\\gamma }^{-1}g\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equm.gif)

The variable change ![
$$\\gamma \\longrightarrow g\\gamma $$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq41.gif) permutes the cosets in G∕H and shows that

![
$$\\displaystyle{J\\big\({\\pi }^{G}\(g\)f\\big\) =\\sum _{ \\gamma \\in G/H}\\sigma \(g\\gamma \)j\\big\(f\({\\gamma }^{-1}\)\\big\) = \\sigma \(g\)J\(f\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equn.gif)

as required. □

Corollary 32.1.

(Frobenius reciprocity, second version) If H is a subgroup of the finite group G, and if (σ, U) and (π, V ) are representations of G and H, respectively, then ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\({V }^{G},U\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Hom}_{H}\(V,U\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq42.gif) , and in this isomorphism ![
$$j \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{H}\(V,U\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq43.gif) corresponds to ![
$$J \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\({V }^{G},U\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq44.gif) if and only if they are related by (32.6).

Proof.

This is a direct restatement of Proposition 32.3. □

We turn next to Mackey theory. In the following statement, ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq45.gif) means ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{F}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq46.gif), the space of all linear maps.

Theorem 32.1.

(Mackey's theorem, geometric version) Suppose that G is a finite group, H 1 and H 2 subgroups, and ![
$$\(\\pi _{1},V _{1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq47.gif) and (π 2 , V 2 ) representations of H 1 and H 2 , respectively. Then ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{1}^{G},V _{2}^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq48.gif) is isomorphic as a vector space to the space of all functions ![
$$\\varDelta: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq49.gif) that satisfy

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\varDelta \(h_{2}gh_{1}\) = \\pi _{2}\(h_{2}\) \\circ \\varDelta \(g\) \\circ \\pi _{1}\(h_{1}\),\\qquad h_{i} \\in H_{i}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

(32.9)

In this isomorphism an intertwining operator ![
$$\\varLambda: V _{1}^{G}\\longrightarrow V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq50.gif) corresponds to Δ if Λ(f) = Δ ∗ f ( ![
$$f \\in V _{1}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq51.gif) ), where the "convolution" Δ ∗ f is defined by

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(\\varDelta {\\ast}f\)\(g\) =\\sum _{\\gamma \\in G/H_{1}}\\varDelta \(\\gamma \)\\,f\({\\gamma }^{-1}g\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(32.10)

Proof.

Let Δ satisfying (32.9) be given. It is easy to check, using (32.9) and the fact that ![
$$f \\in V _{1}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq52.gif), that (32.10) is independent of the choice of coset representatives γ for G∕H 1. Moreover, if h 2 ∈ H 2, then the variable change ![
$$\\gamma \\longrightarrow h_{2}\\gamma $$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq53.gif) permutes the cosets of G∕H 1, and again using (32.9), this variable change shows that ![
$$\\varDelta {\\ast}f \\in V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq54.gif). Thus ![
$$f\\longrightarrow \\varDelta {\\ast} f$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq55.gif) is a well-defined map ![
$$V _{1}^{G}\\longrightarrow V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq56.gif), and using the fact that G acts on both these spaces by right translation, it is straightforward to see that Λ(f) =Δ ∗ f defines an intertwining operator ![
$$V _{1}^{G}\\longrightarrow V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq57.gif).

To show that this map Δ↦ Λ is an isomorphism of the space of Δ satisfying (32.9) to ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{1}^{G},V _{2}^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq58.gif), we make use of Corollary 32.1. We must relate the space of Δ satisfying (32.9) to ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{H_{1}}\(V _{1},V _{2}^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq59.gif). Given ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{H_{1}}\(V _{1},V _{2}^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq60.gif) corresponding to ![
$$\\varLambda \\in \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{1}^{G},V _{2}^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq61.gif) as in that corollary, define ![
$$\\varDelta: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq62.gif) by ![
$$\\varDelta \(g\)v_{1} = \\lambda \(v_{1}\)\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq63.gif). The condition that ![
$$\\lambda \(v_{1}\) \\in V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq64.gif) for all v 1 ∈ V 1 is equivalent to

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta \(h_{2}g\) = \\pi _{2}\(h_{2}\) \\circ \\varDelta \(g\),\\qquad h_{2} \\in H_{2},}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equo.gif)

and the condition that ![
$$\\lambda: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq65.gif) is H 1-equivariant is equivalent to

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta \(gh_{1}\) =\\varDelta \(g\) \\circ \\pi _{1}\(h_{1}\),\\qquad h_{1} \\in H_{1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equp.gif)

Of course, these two properties together are equivalent to (32.9). We see that Corollary 32.1 implies a linear isomorphism between the space of functions Δ satisfying (32.9) and the elements of ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{1}^{G},V _{2}^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq66.gif). We have only to show that this correspondence is given by (32.10). In (32.6), we take H = H 1, ![
$$\(\\sigma,U\) = \(\\pi _{2}^{G},V _{2}^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq67.gif), and j = λ. Then J =Λ and (32.6) gives us, for ![
$$f \\in V _{1}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq68.gif),

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varLambda \(f\) =\\sum _{\\gamma \\in G/H_{1}}\\pi _{2}^{G}\(\\gamma \)\\lambda \\big\(f\({\\gamma }^{-1}\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equq.gif)

Applying this to g ∈ G,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varLambda \(f\)\(g\) =\\sum _{\\gamma \\in G/H_{1}}\\lambda \\big\(f\({\\gamma }^{-1}\)\\big\)\(g\\gamma \) =\\sum _{ \\gamma \\in G/H_{1}}\\varDelta \(g\\gamma \)f\({\\gamma }^{-1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equr.gif)

Making the variable change ![
$$\\gamma \\longrightarrow {g}^{-1}\\gamma $$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq69.gif), this equals (32.10). □

Remark 32.1.

Although we are working here with finite groups, Mackey's theorem is (since Bruhat [26]) a standard tool in representation theory of Lie groups also. The function Δ becomes a distribution.

Remark 32.2.

Suppose that H 1, H 2, and (π i , V i ) are as in Theorem 32.1. The function ![
$$\\varDelta: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq70.gif) associated with an intertwining operator ![
$$\\varLambda: V _{1}^{G}\\longrightarrow V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq71.gif) is clearly determined by its values on a set of representatives for the double cosets in ![
$$H_{2}\\setminus G/H_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq72.gif). The simplest case is when Δ is supported on a single double coset H 2γH 1. In this case, we say that the intertwining operator Λ is supported on H 2γH 1.

Proposition 32.4.

In the setting of Theorem 32.1, let γ ∈ G. Let ![
$$H_{\\gamma } = H_{2} \\cap \\gamma H_{1}{\\gamma }^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq73.gif) . Define two representations ![
$$\(\\pi _{1}^{\\gamma },V _{1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq74.gif) and ![
$$\(\\pi _{2}^{\\gamma },V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq75.gif) of H γ as follows. The representation ![
$$\\pi _{2}^{\\gamma }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq76.gif) is just the restriction of π 2 to H γ . On the other hand, we define ![
$$\\pi _{1}^{\\gamma }\(h\) = \\pi _{1}\({\\gamma }^{-1}h\\gamma \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq77.gif) for h ∈ H γ . The space of intertwining operators ![
$$\\varLambda: V _{1}^{G}\\longrightarrow V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq78.gif) supported on H 2 γH 1 is isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{H_{\\gamma }}\(\\pi _{1}^{\\gamma },\\pi _{2}^{\\gamma }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq79.gif) , the space of all ![
$$\\delta: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq80.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\delta \\circ \\pi _{1}^{\\gamma }\(h\) = \\pi _{ 2}^{\\gamma }\(h\) \\circ \\delta,\\qquad h \\in H_{ \\gamma }. }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(32.11)

Proof.

If ![
$$\\varDelta: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq81.gif) is associated with Λ as in Theorem 32.1, then Δ is by assumption supported on H 2γH 1, and (32.9) implies that Δ is determined by δ =Δ(γ). This is subject to a consistency condition derived from (32.9). If h ∈ H γ, then γh′ = hγ, where h′ = γ−1 hγ. We have h ∈ H 2 and h′ ∈ H 1, so by (32.9) the map ![
$$\\delta: V _{1}\\longrightarrow V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq82.gif) must satisfy (32.11). Conversely, if (32.11) is assumed, it is not hard to see that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta \(g\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} \\pi _{2}\(h_{2}\)\\delta \\pi _{1}\(h_{1}\)&\\text{if }g = h_{2}\\gamma h_{1} \\in H_{2}\\gamma H_{1},h_{i} \\in H_{i}, \\\\ 0 &\\text{if} g\\notin H_{2}\\gamma H_{1}\\,, \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equs.gif)

is a well-defined function ![
$$G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq83.gif) satisfying (32.9), and the corresponding intertwining operator Λ is supported on H 2γH 1. □

Theorem 32.2.

(Mackey's theorem, algebraic version) In the setting of Theorem 32.1, let γ 1 ,...,γ h be a complete set of representatives of the double cosets in ![
$$H_{2}\\setminus G/H_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq84.gif) . With γ = γ i , let ![
$$\\pi _{i}^{\\gamma }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq85.gif) be as in Proposition 32.4. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\dim \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\(V _{1}^{G},V _{ 2}^{G}\) =\\sum _{ i=1}^{h}\\dim \\mathrm{Hom}_{ H_{\\gamma _{i}}}\(\\pi _{1}^{\\gamma _{i} },\\pi _{2}^{\\gamma _{i} }\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

(32.12)

Proof.

If Δ is as in Theorem 32.1, write Δ = ∑ i Δ i , where

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta _{i}\(g\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} \\varDelta \(g\)&\\text{if}g \\in H_{2}\\gamma _{i}H_{1},\\\\ 0 &\\mathrm{otherwise }. \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equt.gif)

Then Δ i satisfy (32.9). Let Λ i be the intertwining operator. Then Λ i is supported on a single double coset, and the dimension of the space of such intertwining operators is computed in Proposition 32.4. □

Corollary 32.2.

Assume that the ground field F is of characteristic zero. Let H 1 and H 2 be subgroups of G and let (π, V ) be an irreducible representation of H 1 . Let γ 1 ,..., γ h be a complete set of representatives of the double cosets in ![
$$H_{2}\\setminus G/H_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq86.gif) . If γ ∈ G, let ![
$$H_{\\gamma } = H_{2} \\cap \\gamma H_{1}{\\gamma }^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq87.gif) , and let ![
$${\\pi }^{\\gamma }: H_{\\gamma }\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq88.gif) be the representation ![
$${\\pi }^{\\gamma }\(g\) = \\pi \({\\gamma }^{-1}g\\gamma \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq89.gif) . Then the restriction of π G to H 2 is isomorphic to

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\bigoplus _{i=1}^{h}\\mathrm{Ind}_{ H_{\\gamma _{i}}}^{H_{2} }\({\\pi }^{\\gamma _{i} }\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ13.gif)

(32.13)

In a word, first inducing and then restricting gives the same result as restricting, then inducing. This way of explaining the result is a pithy oversimplification that has to be correctly understood. More precisely, there are different ways we can restrict, namely given γ we may restrict to H γ, then induce; we have to sum over all these different ways. And the different ways depend only on the double coset H 2γH 1.

Proof.

Since we are assuming that the characteristic of F is zero, representations are completely reducible and it is enough to show that the multiplicity of an irreducible representation ![
$$\(\\pi _{2},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq90.gif) in π G is the same as the multiplicity of π2 in the direct sum (32.13). The multiplicity of π2 in π G is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\dim \\mathrm{Hom}_{H_{2}}\({V }^{G},V _{ 2}\) =\\dim \\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\({V }^{G},V _{ 2}^{G}\) =\\sum _{ i=1}^{h}\\dim \\mathrm{Hom}_{ H_{\\gamma _{i}}}\({\\pi }^{\\gamma _{i} },\\pi _{2}^{\\gamma _{i} }\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equu.gif)

by Frobenius reciprocity and Theorem 32.2. One more application of Frobenius reciprocity shows that this equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{i=1}^{h}\\dim \\mathrm{Hom}_{ H_{2}}\\big\(\\mathrm{Ind}_{H_{\\gamma _{i}}}^{H_{2} }\({\\pi }^{\\gamma _{i} }\),\\pi _{2}\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equv.gif)

□

Next we will reinterpret induced representations as obtained by "extension of scalars" as explained in Chap. . We must extend the setup there to noncommutative rings. In particular, we recall the basics of tensor products over noncommutative rings. Let ![
$$R$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq91.gif) be a ring, not necessarily commutative, and let W be a right R-module and V a left R-module. If C is an Abelian group (written additively), a map ![
$$f: W \\times V \\longrightarrow C$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq92.gif) is called balanced if (for ![
$$w,w_{1},w_{2} \\in W$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq93.gif) and ![
$$v,v_{1},v_{2} \\in V$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq94.gif))

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(w_{1} + w_{2},v\) = f\(w_{1},v\) + f\(w_{2},v\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equw.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(w,v_{1} + v_{2}\) = f\(w,v_{1}\) + f\(w,v_{2}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equx.gif)

and if r ∈ R,

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(wr,v\) = f\(w,rv\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equy.gif)

The tensor product W ⊗ R V is an Abelian group with a balanced map ![
$$T: W \\times V \\longrightarrow W \\otimes _{R}V$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq95.gif) such that if ![
$$f: W \\times V \\longrightarrow C$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq96.gif) is any balanced map into an Abelian group C, then there exists a unique homomorphism ![
$$F: W \\otimes _{R}V \\longrightarrow C$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq97.gif) of Abelian groups such that ![
$$f = F \\circ T.$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq98.gif) The balanced map T is usually denoted T(w,v) = w ⊗ v.

Remark 32.3.

The tensor product always exists and is characterized up to isomorphism by this universal property. If R is noncommutative, then W ⊗ R V does not generally have an R-module structure. However, in special cases it is a module. If A is another ring, we call W an (A,R)-bimodule if it is a left A-module and a right R-module, and if these module structures are compatible in the sense that if w ∈ W, a ∈ A, and r ∈ R, then a(wr) = (aw)r. If W is an (A,R)-bimodule, then W ⊗ R V has the structure of a left A-module with multiplication satisfying

![
$$\\displaystyle{a\(w \\otimes v\) = aw \\otimes v,\\qquad a \\in A.}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equz.gif)

If R is a subring of A, then A is itself an (A,R)-bimodule. Therefore, if V is a left R-module, we can consider A ⊗ R V and this is a left A-module.

Proposition 32.5.

If R is a subring of A and V is a left R-module, let V ′ be the left A-module A ⊗ R V. We have a homomorphism ![
$$i: V \\longrightarrow V ^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq99.gif) of R-modules defined by i(v) = 1 ⊗ v. If U is any left A-module and ![
$$j: V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq100.gif) is an R-module homomorphism, then there exists a unique A-module homomorphism ![
$$J: V ^{\\prime}\\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq101.gif) such that j = J ∘ i.

Proof.

Suppose that ![
$$J: V ^{\\prime}\\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq102.gif) is A-linear and satisfies ![
$$j = J \\circ i$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq103.gif). Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{J\(a \\otimes v\) = J\\big\(a\(1 \\otimes v\)\\big\) = aJ\(1 \\otimes v\) = aJ\\big\(i\(v\)\\big\) = aj\(v\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equaa.gif)

Since V ′ is spanned by elements of the form a ⊗ v, this proves that J, if it exists, is unique.

To show that J exists, note that we have a balanced map ![
$$A \\times V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq104.gif) given by ![
$$\(a,v\)\\longrightarrow aj\(v\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq105.gif). Hence, there exists a unique homomorphism ![
$$J: V ^{\\prime} = A \\otimes _{R}V \\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq106.gif) of Abelian groups such that J(a ⊗ v) = aj(v). It is straightforward to see that this J is A-linear and that J ∘ i = j. □

Proposition 32.6.

If R is a subring of A, U is a left A-module, and V is a left R-module, we have a natural isomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mathrm{Hom}_{R}\(V,U\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Hom}_{A}\(A \\otimes _{R}V,U\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ14.gif)

(32.14)

Proof.

This is a direct generalization of Proposition 11.1 (ii). It is also essentially equivalent to Proposition 32.5. Indeed, composition with ![
$$i: V \\longrightarrow V ^{\\prime} = A \\otimes _{R}V$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq107.gif) is a map ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{A}\(V ^{\\prime},U\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}_{R}\(V,U\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq108.gif), and the content of Proposition 32.5 is that this map is bijective. □

Proposition 32.7.

Suppose that H is a subgroup of G and V is an H-module. Then V is a module for the group ring F[H], which is a subring of F[G]. We have an isomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{{V }^{G}\\mathop{\\cong}F\[G\] \\otimes _{ F\[H\]}V }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equab.gif)

as G-modules.

Proof.

Comparing Proposition 32.3 and Proposition 32.5, the G-modules V G and ![
$$F\[G\] \\otimes _{F\[H\]}V$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq109.gif) satisfy the same universal property, so they are isomorphic. □

Finally, if ![
$$F = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq110.gif), let us recall the formula for the character of the induced representation. If χ is a class function of the subgroup H of G, let ![
$$\\dot{\\chi }: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq111.gif) be the function

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\dot{\\chi }\(g\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cc} \\chi \(g\)& \\text{if}g \\in H\\,,\\\\ 0 &\\mathrm{otherwise}, \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equac.gif)

and let ![
$${\\chi }^{G}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq112.gif) be the function

![
$$\\displaystyle{ {\\chi }^{G}\(g\) =\\sum _{ x\\in H\\setminus G}\\dot{\\chi }\(xg{x}^{-1}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ15.gif)

(32.15)

We note that since χ is assumed to be a class function, each term depends only on the coset of x in ![
$$H\\setminus G$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq113.gif). We may, of course, also write

![
$$\\displaystyle{ {\\chi }^{G}\(g\) = \\frac{1} {\\vert H\\vert }\\sum _{x\\in G}\\dot{\\chi }\(xg{x}^{-1}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equ16.gif)

(32.16)

Clearly, χ G is a class function on G.

Proposition 32.8.

Let (π,V ) be a complex representation of the subgroup H of the finite group G with character χ. Then the character of the induced representation π G is χ G .

Proof.

Let η be the character of a representation (σ,U) of G. We will prove that the class function χ G satisfies Frobenius reciprocity in its classical form (32.4). This suffices because χ G is determined by the inner product values ![
$$\\left \\langle {\\chi }^{G},\\eta \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq114.gif). We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle {\\chi }^{G},\\eta \\right \\rangle _{ G} = \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{g\\in G} \\frac{1} {\\vert H\\vert }\\sum _{x\\in G}\\dot{\\chi }\(xg{x}^{-1}\)\\,\\eta \(g\) =}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equad.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{g\\in G} \\frac{1} {\\vert H\\vert }\\sum _{h\\in H}\\sum _{ \\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{c} x \\in G \\\\ xg{x}^{-1} = h \\end{array} $}}\\chi \(h\)\\,\\eta \(g\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equae.gif)

Given h ∈ H, we can enumerate the pairs (g,x) ∈ G × G that satisfy xgx −1 = h by noting that they are the pairs (x −1 hx,x) with x ∈ G. So the sum equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert } \\frac{1} {\\vert H\\vert }\\sum _{h\\in H}\\sum _{x\\in G}\\chi \(h\)\\,\\eta \({x}^{-1}hx\) = \\frac{1} {\\vert H\\vert }\\sum _{h\\in H}\\chi \(h\)\\,\\eta \(h\) = \\left \\langle \\chi,\\eta \\right \\rangle _{H}}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equaf.gif)

since ![
$$\\eta \({x}^{-1}hx\) = \\eta \(h\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq115.gif). □

Exercises

Exercise 32.1.

Some points in the proof of Proposition 32.2 were left to the reader. Write out a complete proof.

Exercise 32.2.

Let H 1, H 2, and H 3 be subgroups of G, with ![
$$\(\\pi _{i},V _{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq116.gif) a representation of H i . Let there be given intertwining operators ![
$$\\varLambda _{1}: V _{1}^{G} \\rightarrow V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq117.gif) and ![
$$\\varLambda _{2}: V _{2}^{G} \\rightarrow V _{3}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq118.gif). Let ![
$$\\varDelta _{1}: G \\rightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq119.gif) and ![
$$\\varDelta _{2}: G \\rightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{2},V _{3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq120.gif) being the corresponding functions as in Theorem 32.1. Express the ![
$$\\varDelta: G \\rightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq121.gif) corresponding to the composition ![
$$\\varLambda _{2} \\circ \\varLambda _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq122.gif) in terms of Δ 1 and Δ 2.

Exercise 32.3.

Let H be a subgroup of G, and ![
$$\\psi: H \\rightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq123.gif) a linear character. Prove that the ring of G-module endomorphisms of the induced representation ψ G is isomorphic to the convolution ring of functions ![
$$\\varDelta: G \\rightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq124.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta \(h_{2}gh_{1}\) = \\psi \(h_{2}\)\\,\\varDelta \(g\)\\,\\psi \(h_{1}\),\\qquad h_{1},h_{2} \\in H.}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equag.gif)

What can you say about ψ G if this ring is commutative?

Exercise 32.4.

Let G = GL(2,F), where F is a finite field. Let B be the Borel subgroup of upper triangular matrices, and let N be its subgroup of unipotent matrices. Let ![
$$\\psi _{F}: F \\rightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq125.gif) be any nontrivial character. Define a character of N as follows:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\psi \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 1 & x\\\\ & 1 \\end{array} \\right \) = \\psi _{F}\(x\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equah.gif)

Let χ be a linear character of B as in (32.1). Show that up to scalar multiple there is a unique intertwining operator ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{B}^{G}\(\\chi \) \\rightarrow \\mathrm{Ind}_{N}^{G}\(\\psi \)$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_IEq126.gif).

Exercise 32.5.

Let H be the non-Abelian group of order q 3 consisting of all matrices

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & x&z\\\\ & 1 & y \\\\ & &1 \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equai.gif)

The center Z of matrices with x = y = 0. The subgroup A of matrices with x = 0 is Abelian but not central. Let χ and ψ be two linear characters of A.

(i)

Assume that χ and ψ have nontrivial restrictions to Z. Let χ H and ψ H be the induced representations. Use Mackey theory to prove that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\dim \\;\\mathrm{Hom}_{H}\({\\chi }^{H},{\\psi }^{H}\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{ll} 1 & \\text{if}\\,\\chi,\\psi\\, \\text{have the same restriction to Z;} \\\\ 0 & \\mathrm{otherwise}.\\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_32_Chapter_Equaj.gif)

(ii)

Prove that χ H is irreducible, and that χ H , ψ H are isomorphic if and only if χ and ψ have the same restriction to Z.

(iii)

Prove that given a nontrivial central character θ of Z, H has a unique irreducible representation with central character θ. This is the Stone–von Neumann theorem for finite fields.

# 33. Characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq1.gif)

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In the next few chapters, we will construct the irreducible representations of the symmetric group in parallel with the irreducible algebraic representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq2.gif). In this chapter, we will construct some generalized characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq3.gif). The connection with the representation theory of S k will become clear later.

In the next few chapters, we will construct the irreducible representations of the symmetric group in parallel with the irreducible algebraic representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq4.gif). In this chapter, we will construct some generalized characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq5.gif). The connection with the representation theory of S k will become clear later.

A complex representation (π,V ) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq6.gif) is algebraic if the matrix coefficients of π(g) are polynomial functions in the matrix coefficients g ij of ![
$$g = \(g_{ij}\) \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq7.gif) and of det(g)−1. Thus, if we choose a basis of V, then π(g) becomes a matrix ![
$$\\big\(\\pi \(g\)_{kl}\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq8.gif) with ![
$$1 \\leqslant k,l \\leqslant \\dim \(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq9.gif), and for each k,l we require that there be a polynomial P kl with n 2+1 entries such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi \(g\)_{kl} = P_{kl}\\big\(g_{11},\\ldots,g_{nn},\\det {\(g\)}^{-1}\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equa.gif)

The assumption that a representation is algebraic is similar to the assumption that it is analytic—it rules out representations such as complex conjugation ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\rightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq10.gif). It is not hard to show (using the Weyl character formula) that every analytic representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq11.gif) is algebraic, and of course the converse is also true.

A character χ is algebraic if it is the character of an algebraic representation. A generalized character, also called a virtual character, is the difference between two characters. If ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq12.gif), or more generally any algebraic group, we will say a generalized character is algebraic if it is ![
$$\\chi _{1} - \\chi _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq13.gif), where χ1 and χ2 are algebraic.

If R is a commutative ring, we will denote by ![
$$R_{\\mathrm{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq14.gif) the ring of symmetric polynomials in ![
$$x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq15.gif) having coefficients in R. Let e k and ![
$$h_{k} \\in \\mathbb{Z}_{\\mathrm{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq16.gif) be the kth elementary and complete symmetric polynomials in n variables. Specifically,

![
$$\\displaystyle{e_{k}\(x_{1,}\\ldots,x_{n}\) =\\sum _{1\\leq i_{1}<i_{2}<\\cdots <i_{k}\\leq n}x_{i_{1}}x_{i_{2}}\\ldots x_{i_{k}},}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equb.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{h_{k}\(x_{1,}\\ldots,x_{n}\) =\\sum _{1\\leq i_{1}\\leq i_{2}\\leq \\cdots \\leq i_{k}\\leq n}x_{i_{1}}x_{i_{2}}\\cdots x_{i_{k}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equc.gif)

If k > n, then e k = 0, although this is not true for h k . Our convention is that ![
$$e_{0} = h_{0} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq17.gif).

Let E(t) be the generating function for the elementary symmetric polynomials:

![
$$\\displaystyle{E\(t\) =\\sum _{ k=0}^{n}e_{ k}\\,{t}^{k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equd.gif)

Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ E\(t\) = \(1 + x_{1}t\)\(1 + x_{2}t\)\\cdots \(1 + x_{n}t\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(33.1)

since expanding the right-hand side and collecting the coefficients of t k will give each monomial in the definition of e k exactly once. Similarly, if

![
$$\\displaystyle{H\(t\) =\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }h_{ k}{t}^{k}\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Eque.gif)

then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ H\(t\) =\\prod _{ i=0}^{n}\(1 + x_{ i}t + x_{i}^{2}{t}^{2} + \\cdots \\,\) = {\(1 - x_{ 1}t\)}^{-1}\\cdots {\(1 - x_{ n}t\)}^{-1}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(33.2)

We see that

![
$$\\displaystyle{H\(t\)E\(-t\) = 1.}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Equating the coefficients in this identity gives us recursive relations

![
$$\\displaystyle{ h_{k} - e_{1}h_{k-1} + e_{2}h_{k-2} -\\cdots + {\(-1\)}^{k}e_{ k} = 0,\\qquad k > 0. }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(33.3)

These can be used to express the h's in terms of the e's or vice versa.

Proposition 33.1.

The ring ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}_{\\mathrm{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq18.gif) is generated as a ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq19.gif) -algebra by e 1 ,...,e n, and they are algebraically independent. Thus, ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}_{\\mathrm{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\] = \\mathbb{Z}\[e_{1},\\ldots,e_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq20.gif) is a polynomial ring. It is also generated by h 1 ,...,h n , which are algebraically independent, and ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}_{\\mathrm{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\] = \\mathbb{Z}\[h_{1},\\ldots,h_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq21.gif) .

Proof.

The fact that the e i generate ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}_{\\mathrm{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq22.gif) is Theorem 6.1 on p. 191 of Lang [116], and their algebraic independence is proved on p. 192 of that reference. The fact that h 1,...,h n also generate follows since (33.3) can be solved recursively to express the e i in terms of the h i . The h i must be algebraically independent since if they were dependent the transcendence degree of the field of fractions of ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}_{\\mathrm{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq23.gif) would be less than n, so the e i would also be algebraically dependent, which is a contradiction. □

If V is a vector space, let ∧ k V and ∨ k V denote the kth exterior and symmetric powers. If ![
$$T: V \\longrightarrow W$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq24.gif) is a linear transformation, then there are induced linear transformations ![
$${\\wedge }^{k}T: {\\wedge }^{k}V \\longrightarrow {\\wedge }^{k}W$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq25.gif) and ![
$${\\vee }^{k}T: {\\vee }^{k}V \\longrightarrow {\\vee }^{k}W$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq26123.gif).

Proposition 33.2.

If V is an n-dimensional vector space and ![
$$T: V \\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) an endomorphism, and if t 1 ,...,t n are its eigenvalues with multiplicities (that is, each eigenvalue is listed with its multiplicity as a root of the characteristic polynomial), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\text{ tr} {\\wedge }^{k}T = e_{ k}\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{n}\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(33.4)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\text{ tr} {\\vee }^{k}T = h_{ k}\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{n}\)\\,. }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(33.5)

Proof.

First, assume that T is diagonalizable and that v 1,...,v n are its eigenvectors, so ![
$$Tv_{i} = t_{i}v_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq28123.gif). Then a basis of ![
$${\\wedge }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) consists of the vectors

![
$$\\displaystyle{v_{i_{1}} \\wedge \\cdots \\wedge v_{i_{k}},\\qquad 1 \\leqslant i_{1} < i_{2} < \\cdots < i_{k} \\leqslant n,\\qquad }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equg.gif)

and this is an eigenvector of ![
$${\\wedge }^{k}T$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) with eigenvalue ![
$$t_{i_{1}}\\cdots t_{i_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq31123.gif). Summing these eigenvalues gives ![
$$e_{k}\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq32123.gif). Thus, (33.4) is true if T is diagonalizable. Similarly, a basis of ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) consists of the vectors

![
$$\\displaystyle{v_{i_{1}} \\vee \\cdots \\vee v_{i_{k}},\\qquad 1 \\leq i_{1} \\leqslant i_{2} \\leqslant \\cdots \\leq i_{k} \\leqslant n,}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equh.gif)

so (33.5) is also true if T is diagonalizable.

In the general case, both sides of (33.4) or (33.5) are continuous functions of the matrix entries of T. The left-hand side of (33.4) is continuous because if we refer T to a fixed basis, then ![
$$\\text{tr} {\\wedge }^{k}T$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) is the sum of the ![
$$\\binom{n}{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq35.gif) principal minors of its matrix with respect to this basis, and the right-hand side is continuous because it is a coefficient in the characteristic polynomial of T. Since the diagonalizable matrices are dense in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq36.gif), it follows that (33.4) is true for all T. As for (33.5), the h's are polynomial functions in the e's, as we see by solving (33.3) recursively, so the right-hand side of (33.5) is also continuous, and (33.5) is also proved. □

Theorem 33.1.

Let ![
$$f\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq37.gif) be a symmetric polynomial with integer coefficients. Define a function ψ f on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq38.gif) as follows. If t 1 ,...,t n are the eigenvalues of g, let

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\psi _{f}\(g\) = f\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{n}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(33.6)

Then ψ f is an algebraic generalized character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq39.gif) .

As in Proposition 33.2, there may be repeated eigenvalues. If this is the case, we count each eigenvalue with the multiplicity with which it occurs as a root of the characteristic polynomial.

Proof.

Let us call a symmetric polynomial f constructible if ψ f is a generalized character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq40.gif). The generalized characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq41.gif) form a ring since the direct sum and tensor product operations on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq42.gif)-modules correspond to addition and multiplication of characters. Since

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\psi _{f_{1}\\pm f_{2}} = \\psi _{f_{1}} \\pm \\psi _{f_{2}},\\qquad \\psi _{f_{1}f_{2}} = \\psi _{f_{1}}\\psi _{f_{2}}\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equi.gif)

it follows that the constructible polynomials also form a ring. The e k are constructible by Proposition 33.2 and generate ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}_{\\text{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq43.gif) by Proposition 33.1. Thus, the ring of constructible polynomials is all of ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}_{\\text{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq44.gif). □

In addition to the elementary and complete symmetric polynomials, we have the power sum symmetric polynomials

![
$$\\displaystyle{ p_{k}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = x_{1}^{k} + \\cdots + x_{ n}^{k}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(33.7)

Theorem 33.2.

Let G be a group, let χ be a character of G, and let k be a nonnegative integer. Then ![
$$g\\mapsto \\chi \({g}^{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq45.gif) is a virtual character of G.

Proof.

Let χ be the character corresponding to the representation ![
$$\\pi: G \\rightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq46.gif). If ψ is any generalized character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq47.gif), then ![
$$\\psi \\circ \\pi $$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq48.gif) is a generalized character of G. We take ![
$$\\psi = \\psi _{p_{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq49.gif), which is a generalized character by Theorem 33.1. If t 1,...,t n are the eigenvalues of π(g), then ![
$$t_{1}^{k},\\ldots,t_{n}^{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq50.gif) are the eigenvalues of π(g k ). Hence

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(\\psi _{p_{k}} \\circ \\pi \)\(g\) = \\chi \({g}^{k}\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(33.8)

proving that χ(g k ) is a generalized character. □

Proposition 33.3.

(Newton) The polynomials p k generate ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}_{\\mathrm{sym}}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq51.gif) as a ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq52.gif) -algebra.

Proof.

We will make use of the identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\log \(1 + t\) =\\sum _{ k=1}^{\\infty }\\frac{{\(-1\)}^{k-1}} {k} {t}^{k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equj.gif)

Replacing t by tx i in this identity, summing over the x i , and using (33.1), we see that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\log E\(t\) =\\sum _{ k=1}^{\\infty }\\frac{{\(-1\)}^{k-1}} {k} p_{k}{t}^{k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Exponentiating this identity,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }e_{ k}{t}^{k} =\\exp \\left \(\\sum _{ k=1}^{\\infty }\\frac{{\(-1\)}^{k-1}} {k} p_{k}{t}^{k}\\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equl.gif)

Expanding and collecting the coefficients of t k expresses e k as a polynomial in the p's, with rational coefficients. □

Let us return to the context of Theorem 33.2. Let G be a group and χ the character of a representation ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq53.gif). As we saw in that theorem, the functions ![
$$g\\longrightarrow \\chi _{k}\(g\) = \\chi \({g}^{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq54.gif) are generalized characters; indeed they are the functions ![
$$\\psi _{p_{k}} \\circ \\pi $$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq55.gif). They are conveniently computable and therefore useful. The operations ![
$$\\chi \\longrightarrow \\chi _{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq56.gif) on the ring of generalized characters of G are called the Adams operations. See also the exercises in Chap.​ 22 for more about the Adams operations.

Let us consider an example. Consider the polynomial

![
$$\\displaystyle{ s\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) =\\sum _{i\\neq j}x_{i}^{2}x_{ j} + 2\\sum _{i<j<k}x_{i}x_{j}x_{k}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

(33.9)

We find that

![
$$\\displaystyle{p_{1}^{3} =\\sum _{ i}x_{i}^{3} + 3\\sum _{ i\\neq j}x_{i}^{2}x_{ j} + 6\\sum _{i<j<k}x_{i}x_{j}x_{k},}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equm.gif)

so

![
$$\\displaystyle{ s = \\tfrac{1} {3}\(p_{1}^{3} - p_{ 3}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(33.10)

Hence, if ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq57.gif) is a representation affording the character χ, then we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(\\psi _{s} \\circ \\pi \)\(g\) = \\tfrac{1} {3}\\left \(\\chi {\(g\)}^{3} - \\chi \({g}^{3}\)\\right \). }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(33.11)

Such a composition of a representation with a ψ f is called a plethysm. The expression on the right-hand side is useful for calculating the values of this function, which we have proved is a virtual character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq58.gif), provided we know the values of the character χ. We will show in the next chapter that (for this particular s) this plethysm is actually a proper character. Indeed, we will actually prove that ψ s is a character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq59.gif), not just a virtual character. This will require ideas different from those than used in this chapter.

EXERCISES

Exercise 33.1.

Express each of the sets of polynomials ![
$$\\left \\{e_{k}\\,\\vert \\,k \\leqslant 5\\right \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq60.gif) and ![
$$\\left \\{p_{k}\\,\\vert \\,k \\leqslant 5\\right \\}$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_IEq61.gif) in terms of the other.

Exercise 33.2.

Here is the character table of S 4.

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \\hline & \\quad 1\\quad & \(123\) & \(12\)\(34\) & \(12\) & \(1234\) \\\\ \\hline \\chi _{1} & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\\\ \\hline \\chi _{2} & 1 & 1 & 1 & - 1 & - 1 \\\\ \\hline \\chi _{3} & 3 & 0 & - 1 & 1 & - 1 \\\\ \\hline \\chi _{4} & 3 & 0 & - 1 & - 1 & 1 \\\\ \\hline \\chi _{5} & 2 & - 1 & 2 & 0 & 0 \\\\ \\hline \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_33_Chapter_Equn.gif)

Let s be as in (33.9). Using (33.11), compute ψ s ∘ π when (π,V ) is an irreducible representation with character χ i for each i, and decompose the resulting class function into irreducible characters, confirming that it is a generalized character.
