$$j\\notin \\{i_{1},\\ldots,i_{k}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq28123.gif), and pairing those subsets containing j with those not containing j, we see that the sum ![
$$\\sum _{S\\supseteq \\{i_{1},\\ldots,i_{k}\\}}{\(-1\)}^{k-\\vert S\\vert } = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq29123.gif). Hence, we need only consider those terms where ![
$$\\{i_{1},\\ldots,i_{k}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) is a permutation of ![
$$\\{1,\\ldots,k\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq31123.gif). Remembering that B is symmetric, these terms all contribute equally and the result follows. □

Theorem 36.2.

Let λ be a partition of k, and let ![
$$n \\geqslant l\(\\lambda \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) . Then there exists an irreducible representation ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda } = \\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL\(n\)}}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) with character χ λ such that if ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq35.gif) has eigenvalues ![
$$t_{1},\\ldots,t_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq36.gif) , then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\chi _{\\lambda }\(g\) = s_{\\lambda }\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{n}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(36.3)

The restriction of ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq37.gif) to ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq38.gif) is an irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq39.gif) . If μ≠λ is another partition of k with ![
$$n \\geqslant l\(\\mu \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq40.gif) , then χ λ and χ μ are distinct.

Proof.

We know that the representation exists by applying Theorem 34.1 to the irreducible representation ![
$$\(\\rho,N_{\\rho }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq41.gif) of S k with character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq42.gif). The problem is to prove the irreducibility of the module ![
$$V _{\\rho } = \\left \({\\bigotimes }^{k}V \\right \) \\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}\[S_{k}\]}N_{\\rho }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq43.gif), which as the character ![
$$\\chi _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq44.gif) by Theorem 34.1. (As in Theorem 34.1, we are taking ![
$$V = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq45.gif).)

Let B be the ring of endomorphisms of ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq46.gif) that commute with the action of S k . We will show that B is spanned by the linear transformations

![
$$\\displaystyle{v_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes v_{k}\\longrightarrow gv_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes gv_{k},\\qquad g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(36.4)

We have an isomorphism ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}\\mathrm{End}\(V \)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{End}\\left\({\\bigotimes }^{k}V \\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq47.gif). In this isomorphism, ![
$$f_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes f_{k} {\\in \\bigotimes }^{k}\\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq48.gif) corresponds to the endomorphism ![
$$v_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes v_{k}\\longrightarrow f_{1}\(v_{1}\) \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes f_{k}\(v_{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq49.gif). Conjugation in ![
$$\\mathrm{End}\\left\({\\bigotimes }^{k}V \\right \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq50.gif) by an element of ![
$$\\sigma \\in S_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq51.gif) in the action (34.​1) on ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq52.gif) corresponds to the transformation

![
$$\\displaystyle{f_{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes f_{k}\\longrightarrow f_{\\sigma \(1\)} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes f_{\\sigma \(k\)}}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_Equj.gif)

of ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}\\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq53.gif). If ![
$$\\xi {\\in \\bigotimes }^{k}\\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq54.gif) commutes with this action, then ξ is a linear combination of elements of the form ![
$$B\(f_{1},\\ldots,f_{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq55.gif), where ![
$$B: \\mathrm{End}\(V \) \\times \\cdots \\times \\mathrm{End}{\(V \)\\longrightarrow \\bigotimes }^{k}\\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq56.gif) is the symmetric k-linear map

![
$$\\displaystyle{B\(f_{1},\\ldots,f_{k}\) =\\sum _{\\sigma \\in S_{k}}f_{\\sigma \(1\)} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes f_{\\sigma \(k\)}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_Equk.gif)

It follows from Proposition 36.1 that the vector space of such elements of ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}\\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq57.gif) is spanned by those of the form ![
$$Q\(f\) = B\(f,\\ldots,f\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq58.gif) with ![
$$f \\in \\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq59.gif). Since ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq60.gif) is dense in ![
$$\\mathrm{End}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq61.gif), the elements Q(f) with f invertible span the same vector space. This proves that the transformations of the form (36.4) span the space of transformations of ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq62.gif) commuting with the action of S k .

We temporarily restrict the action of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times S_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq63.gif) on ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq64.gif) to the compact subgroup ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\) \\times S_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq65.gif). Representations of a compact group are completely reducible, and the irreducible representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\) \\times S_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq66.gif) are of the form ![
$$\\pi \\otimes \\rho $$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq67.gif), where π is an irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq68.gif) and ρ is an irreducible representation of S k . Thus, we write

![
$$\\displaystyle{{ \\bigotimes }^{k}V \\mathop{\\cong}\\sum _{ i}\\pi _{i} \\otimes \\rho _{i}, }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(36.5)

where the π i and ρ i are irreducible representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq69.gif) and S k , respectively. We take the π i to be left ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq70.gif)-modules and the ρ i to be right S k -modules. This is because the commuting actions we have defined on ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq71.gif) have ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq72.gif) acting on the left and S k acting on the right.

The subspace of ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq73.gif) corresponding to ![
$$\\pi _{i} \\otimes \\rho _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq74.gif) is actually ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq75.gif)-invariant. This is because it is a complex subspace invariant under the Lie algebra action of ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq76.gif) and hence is invariant under the action of the complexified Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{u}\(n\) + i\\mathfrak{u}\(n\) = \\mathfrak{g}\\mathfrak{l}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq77.gif) and therefore under its exponential, ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq78.gif). So we may regard the decomposition (36.5) as a decomposition with respect to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times S_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq79.gif).

We claim that there are no repetitions among the isomorphism classes of the representations ρ i of S k that occur. This is because if ![
$$\\rho _{i}\\mathop{\\cong}\\rho _{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq80.gif), then if we denote by f an intertwining map ![
$$\\rho _{i}\\longrightarrow \\rho _{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq81.gif) and by τ an arbitrary nonzero linear transformation from the space of ![
$$\\pi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq82.gif) to the space of π j , then τ ⊗ f is a map from the space of ![
$$\\pi _{i} \\otimes \\rho _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq83.gif) to the space of ![
$$\\pi _{j} \\otimes \\rho _{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq84.gif) that commutes with the action of S k . Extending it by zero on direct summands in (36.5) beside ![
$$\\pi _{i} \\otimes \\rho _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq85.gif) gives an endomorphism of ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq86.gif) that commutes with the action of S k . It therefore is in the span of the endomorphisms (36.4). But this is impossible because those endomorphisms leave ![
$$\\pi _{i} \\otimes \\rho _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq87.gif) invariant and this one does not. This contradiction shows that the ρ i all have distinct isomorphism classes.

It follows from this that at most one ρ i can be isomorphic to the contragredient representation of ![
$$\\rho _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq88.gif). Thus, in ![
$$V _{\\rho } = \\left \({\\bigotimes }^{k}V \\right \) \\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}\[S_{k}\]}N_{\\rho }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq89.gif) at most one term can survive, and that term will be isomorphic to π i as a ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq90.gif) module for this unique i. We know that V ρ is nonzero since by Theorem 36.1 the polynomial s λ≠0 under our hypothesis that ![
$$l\(\\lambda \) \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq91.gif). Thus, such a π i does exist, and it is irreducible as a ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq92.gif)-module a fortiori as a ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq93.gif)-module.

It remains to be shown that if ![
$$\\mu \\neq \\lambda $$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq94.gif), then ![
$$\\chi _{\\mu }\\neq \\chi _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq95.gif). Indeed, the Schur polynomials s μ and s λ are distinct since the partition λ can be read off from the numerator in (36.1). □

We have constructed an irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq96.gif) for every partition ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq97.gif) of length ![
$$\\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq98.gif).

Proposition 36.2.

Suppose that ![
$$n \\geqslant l\(\\lambda \)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq99.gif) . Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\lambda ^{\\prime} = \(\\lambda _{1} - \\lambda _{n},\\lambda _{2} - \\lambda _{n},\\ldots,\\lambda _{n-1} - \\lambda _{n},0\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_Equl.gif)

In the ring ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq100.gif) of symmetric polynomials in n variables, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ s_{\\lambda }\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = e_{n}{\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\)}^{\\lambda _{n} }s_{\\lambda ^{\\prime}}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(36.6)

In terms of the characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq101.gif) , we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\mbox{ $\\chi _{\\lambda }\(g\) =\\det {\(g\)}^{\\lambda _{n}}\\chi _{\\lambda ^{\\prime}}\(g\)$.} }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(36.7)

Note that ![
$$e_{n}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = x_{1}\\cdots x_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq102.gif). Caution: This identity is special to ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq103.gif). The corresponding statement is not true in ![
$$\\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq104.gif).

Proof.

It follows from (36.1) that ![
$$s_{\\lambda }\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq105.gif) is divisible by ![
$${\(x_{1}\\cdots x_{n}\)}^{\\lambda _{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq106.gif). Indeed, each entry of the first column of the matrix in the numerator is divisible by ![
$$x_{1}^{\\lambda _{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq107.gif), so we may pull ![
$$x_{1}^{\\lambda _{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq108.gif) out of the first column, ![
$$x_{2}^{\\lambda _{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq109.gif) out of the second column, and so forth, obtaining (36.6).

If the eigenvalues of g are ![
$$t_{1},\\ldots,t_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq110.gif), then ![
$$e_{n}\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{n}\) = t_{1}\\cdots t_{n} =\\det \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq111.gif) and (36.7) follows from (36.6) and (36.3). □

Although we have constructed many irreducible characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq112.gif), it is not true that every character is a ![
$$\\chi _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq113.gif) for some partition λ. What we are missing are those of the form ![
$$\\det {\(g\)}^{-m}\\chi _{\\lambda }\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq114.gif), where m > 0 and ![
$$\\chi _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq115.gif) is not divisible by det(g) m . We may slightly expand the parametrization of the irreducible characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq116.gif) as follows. Let λ be a sequence of n integers, ![
$$\\lambda _{1} \\geqslant \\lambda _{2} \\geqslant \\cdots \\geqslant \\lambda _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq117.gif). (We no longer assume that the λ are nonnegative; if λ n < 0, such a λ is not a partition.) Then we can define a character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq118.gif) by (36.7) since even if λ is not a partition, λ′ is still a partition. We will denote this representation by ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq119.gif), and its character by ![
$$\\chi _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq120.gif).

We now have a representation ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq121.gif) for each ![
$$\\lambda \\in {\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq122.gif) such that ![
$$\\lambda _{1} \\geqslant \\lambda _{2} \\geqslant \\cdots \\geqslant \\lambda _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq123.gif). We will show that we have all the irreducible finite-dimensional analytic representations. We will call such a λ a dominant weight. Thus, the dominant weight λ is a partition if and only if ![
$$\\lambda _{n} \\geqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq124.gif). We call λ the highest weight of the representation ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq125.gif). This terminology is consistent with that introduced in Chap.​ 21.

Proposition 36.3.

Let π be a finite-dimensional irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq126.gif) . Then π is isomorphic to the restriction of ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq127.gif) for some λ.

Proof.

Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq128.gif). By Schur orthogonality, it is enough to show that the characters of the ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda } = \\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq129.gif) are dense in the space of class functions in L 2(G). We refer to a symmetric polynomial in ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq130.gif) and their inverses as a symmetric Laurent polynomial. We regard a symmetric Laurent functions as class functions on ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq131.gif) by applying it to the eigenvalues of ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq132.gif). Every symmetric polynomial is a linear combination of the characters of the πλ with λ a partition, so expanding the set of λ to dominant weights gives us all symmetric Laurent polynomials. Remembering that the eigenvalues α i of g satisfy ![
$$\\vert \\alpha _{i}\\vert = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq133.gif), we may approximate an arbitrary L 2 function by a symmetric Laurent polynomial by symmetrically truncating its Fourier expansion. □

Lemma 36.1.

If f is an analytic function on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq134.gif) , then f is determined by its restriction to ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq135.gif) .

Proof.

We show that if ![
$$f\\vert _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq136.gif) then f = 0. Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq137.gif) be the Lie algebra of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq138.gif) of consisting of skew-Hermitian matrices. Then the exponential map ![
$$\\exp: \\mathfrak{g}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq139.gif) is surjective, so f ∘ exp is zero on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq140.gif). Since f is analytic, so is f ∘ exp and it follows that f ∘ exp is zero on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g} \\oplus i\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq141.gif) which is all ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq142.gif). So f = 0 in a neighborhood of the identity in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq143.gif), so it vanishes identically. □

Proposition 36.4.

Let π 1 and π 2 be analytic representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq144.gif) . If π 1 and π 2 have isomorphic restrictions to ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq145.gif) , they are isomorphic.

Proof.

We may assume that π1 and π2 act on the same complex vector space V, and that ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(g\) = \\pi _{2}\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq146.gif) when ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq147.gif). Applying Lemma 36.1 to the matrix coefficients of π1 and π2 it follows that ![
$$\\pi _{1}\(g\) = \\pi _{2}\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq148.gif) for all ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq149.gif). □

Theorem 36.3.

Every finite-dimensional representation of the group ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq150.gif) extends uniquely to an analytic representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq151.gif) . The irreducible complex representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq152.gif) , or equivalently the irreducible analytic complex representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq153.gif) , are precisely the ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq154.gif) parametrized by the dominant weights λ.

Proof.

The fact that irreducible representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq155.gif) extend to analytic representations follows from the fact that such a representation is a ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq156.gif), proved in Proposition 36.3. Since ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq157.gif) is compact, each representation is a direct sum of irreducibles, and it follows that each representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq158.gif) extends to an analytic representation. The uniqueness of the extension follows from Proposition 36.4. The last statement now follows from Proposition 36.3. □

Proposition 36.5.

Suppose that λ is a partition and l(λ) > n. Then we have ![
$$s_{\\lambda }\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq159.gif) in the ring ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq160.gif) .

Proof.

If N = l(λ), then ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{N}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq161.gif), where λ N > 0 and N > n. Apply the homomorphism r N−1 defined by (34.​9), noting that ![
$$r_{N-1}\(e_{N}\) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq162.gif), since e N is divisible by x N , and r N−1 consists of setting x N = 0. It follows from (36.6) that r N−1 annihilates s λ. We may apply r N−2, etc., until we reach Λ (n) and so s λ = 0 in ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq163.gif). □

Theorem 36.4.

If λ is a partition of k let ρ λ denote the irreducible representation of S k affording the character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq164.gif) constructed in Theorem35.1 . If, moreover, ![
$$l\(\\lambda \) \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq165.gif) , let π λ denote the irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq166.gif) constructed in Theorem36.2 . Let ![
$$V = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq167.gif) denote the standard module of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq168.gif) . The ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times S_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq169.gif) module ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq170.gif) is isomorphic to ![
$$\\bigoplus _{\\lambda }\\pi _{\\lambda } \\otimes \\rho _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq171.gif), where the sum is over partitions of k of length ![
$$\\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq172.gif) .

Proof.

Most of this was proved in the proof of Theorem 36.2. Particularly, we saw there that each irreducible representation of S k occurring in (36.5) occurs at most once and is paired with an irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq173.gif). If ![
$$l\(\\lambda \) \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_36_Chapter_IEq174.gif), we saw in the proof of Theorem 36.2 that ρλ does occur and is paired with πλ. The one fact that was not proved there is that ρλ with l(λ) > n do not occur, and this follows from Proposition 36.5. □

# 37. Schur Polynomials and S k

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

Frobenius [51] discovered that the characters of the symmetric group can be computed using symmetric functions. We will explain this from our point of view. We highly recommend Curtis [39] as an account, both historical and mathematical, of the work of Frobenius and Schur on representation theory.

Frobenius [51] discovered that the characters of the symmetric group can be computed using symmetric functions. We will explain this from our point of view. We highly recommend Curtis [39] as an account, both historical and mathematical, of the work of Frobenius and Schur on representation theory.

We remind the reader that the elements of ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq1.gif), as generalized characters, are class functions on S k . The conjugacy classes of S k are parametrized by the partitions as follows. Let λ = (λ1,...,λ r ) be a partition of k. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq2.gif) be the conjugacy class consisting of products of disjoint cycles of lengths λ1, λ2,.... Thus, if k = 7 and λ = (3,3,1), then ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq3.gif) consists of the conjugates of (123) (456) (7) = (123) (456). We say that the partition λ is the cycle type of the permutations in the conjugacy class ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq4.gif). Let ![
$$z_{\\lambda } = \\vert S_{k}\\vert /\\vert \\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }\\vert $$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq5.gif).

The support of σ ∈ S k is the set of x ∈{ 1,2,3,..., k} such that σ(x) ≠ x.

Proposition 37.1.

Let m r be the number of i such that λ i = r. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ z_{\\lambda } =\\prod _{ r=1}^{k}{r}^{m_{r} }m_{r}!\\;. }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(37.1)

Proof.

z λ is the order of the centralizer of a representative element ![
$$g \\in \\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq6.gif). This centralizer is easily described.

First, we consider the case where g contains only cycles of length r in its decomposition into disjoint cycles. In this case (denoting m r = m), k = rm and we may write g = c 1⋯c m , where c m is a cycle of length r. The centralizer ![
$$C_{S_{k}}\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq7.gif) contains a normal subgroup N of order r m generated by c 1,...,c m . The quotient ![
$$C_{S_{k}}\(g\)/N$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq8.gif) can be identified with S m since it acts by conjugation on the m cyclic subgroups ![
$$\\left \\langle c_{1}\\right \\rangle,\\ldots,\\left \\langle c_{m}\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq9.gif). Thus, ![
$$\\vert C_{S_{k}}\(g\)\\vert = {r}^{m}m!$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq10.gif).

In the general case where g has cycles of different lengths, its centralizer is a direct product of groups such as the one just described. □

We showed in the previous chapter that the irreducible characters of S k are also parametrized by the partitions of k—namely to a partition μ there corresponds an irreducible representation s μ. Our aim is to compute s μ(g) when ![
$$g \\in \\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq11.gif) using symmetric functions.

Proposition 37.2.

The character values of the irreducible representations of S k are rational integers.

Proof.

Using the Jacobi–Trudi identity (Theorem 35.1), s λ is a sum of terms of the form ±h μ for various partitions μ. Each h μ is the character induced from the trivial character of S μ, so it has integer values. □

Let p λ (k ≥ 1) be the conjugacy class indicator, which we define to be the function

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\(g\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} z_{\\lambda }&\\text{if}\\ g \\in \\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }\\,,\\\\ 0 &\\mathrm{otherwise}. \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equa.gif)

As a special case, p k will denote the indicator of the conjugacy class of the k-cycle, corresponding to the partition λ = (k). The term 'conjugacy class indicator' is justified by the following result.

Proposition 37.3.

If ![
$$g \\in \\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq12.gif) , then ![
$$\\left \\langle \\mathbf{s}_{\\mu },\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\\right \\rangle = \\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq13.gif) .

Proof.

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\mathbf{s}_{\\mu },\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\\right \\rangle = \\frac{1} {\\vert S_{k}\\vert }\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{c} x \\in \\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda } \\end{array} $}}z_{\\lambda }\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\(x\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equb.gif)

The summand is constant on ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq14.gif) and equals z λ s μ(g) for any fixed representative g. The cardinality of ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq15.gif) is |S k |∕z λ and the result follows. □

It is clear that the p λ are orthogonal. More precisely, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \\langle \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda },\\mathbf{p}_{\\mu }\\right \\rangle = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} z_{\\lambda }&\\text{if}\\ \\lambda = \\mu,\\\\ 0 &\\mathrm{otherwise}. \\end{array} \\right. }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(37.2)

This is clear since p λ is supported on the conjugacy class ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq16.gif), which has cardinality |S k |∕z λ.

We defined p λ as a class function. We now show it is a generalized character.

Proposition 37.4.

If λ is a partition of k, then ![
$$\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda } \\in \\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq17.gif) .

Proof.

The inner products ![
$$\\left \\langle \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda },\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq18.gif) are rational integers by Propositions 37.2 and 37.3. By Schur orthogonality, we have ![
$$\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda } =\\sum _{\\mu }\\left \\langle \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda },\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\\right \\rangle \\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq19.gif), so ![
$$\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda } \\in \\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq20.gif). □

Proposition 37.5.

If h = l(λ), so ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{h}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq21.gif) and λ h > 0, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda } = \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{1}}\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{2}}\\cdots \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{h}}\\,.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equc.gif)

Proof.

From the definitions, ![
$$\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{1}}\\cdots \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{h}}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq22.gif) is induced from the class function f on the subgroup S λ of S k which has a value on (σ1,...,σ h ) that is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} \\lambda _{1}\\cdots \\lambda _{h}&\\text{if each}\\ \\sigma _{i}\\ \\text{is a}\\ \\lambda _{i}\\ \\text{-cycle}\\,,\\\\ 0 &\\mathrm{otherwise }. \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equd.gif)

The formula (32.​15) may be used to compute this induced class function. It is clear that ![
$$\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{1}}\\cdots \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{h}}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq23.gif) is supported on the conjugacy class of cycle type λ, and so it is a constant multiple of p λ. We write ![
$$\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{1}}\\cdots \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{h}} = c\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq24.gif) and use a trick to show that c = 1. By Proposition 37.3, since h k =s (k) is the trivial character of S k , we have ![
$$\\left \\langle \\mathbf{h}_{k},\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\\right \\rangle _{S_{k}} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq25.gif). On the other hand, by Frobenius reciprocity, ![
$$\\left \\langle \\mathbf{h}_{k},\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{1}}\\cdots \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{h}}\\right \\rangle _{S_{k}} = \\left \\langle \\mathbf{h}_{k},f\\right \\rangle _{S_{\\lambda }}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq26123.gif). As a class function, h k is just the constant function on S k equal to 1, so this inner product is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\prod _{i}\\left \\langle \\mathbf{h}_{\\lambda _{i}},\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{i}}\\right \\rangle _{S_{\\lambda _{ i}}} = 1.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Eque.gif)

Therefore, c = 1. □

Proposition 37.6.

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ k\\mathbf{h}_{k} =\\sum _{ r=1}^{k}\\mathbf{p}_{ r}\\,\\mathbf{h}_{k-r}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(37.3)

Proof.

Let λ be a partition of k. Let m s be the number of λ i equal to s. We will prove

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \\langle \\mathbf{p}_{r}\\mathbf{h}_{k-r},\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\\right \\rangle = rm_{r}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(37.4)

By Frobenius reciprocity, this inner product is ![
$$\\left \\langle f,\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\\right \\rangle _{S_{r}\\times S_{k-r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq27123.gif), where f is the function on S r × S k−r which as a value on (σ,τ), with σ ∈ S r and τ ∈ S k−r that is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} r&\\text{if}\\ \\sigma \\ \\text{is an}\\ r -\\ \\text{cycle,}\\\\ 0&\\mathrm{otherwise}.\\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equf.gif)

The value of f p λ restricted to S r × S k−r will be zero on (σ,τ) unless σ is an r-cycle [since f(σ,τ) must be nonzero] and τ has cycle type λ′, where λ′ is the partition obtained from λ by removing one part of length r [since p λ(σ,τ) must be nonzero]. The number of such pairs (σ,τ) is |S r |⋅|S k−r | divided by the product of the orders of the centralizers in S r and S k−r , respectively, of an r-cycle and of a permutation of cycle type λ′. That is,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{\\vert S_{r}\\vert \\cdot \\vert S_{k-r}\\vert } {r \\cdot {r}^{m_{r}-1}\(m_{r} - 1\)!\\prod _{s\\neq r}{s}^{m_{s}}m_{s}!}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equg.gif)

The value of f p λ on these conjugacy classes is rz λ. Therefore,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle f,\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\\right \\rangle _{S_{r}\\times S_{k-r}} = \\frac{1} {\\vert S_{r}\\vert \\cdot \\vert S_{k-r}\\vert }\\left \[ \\frac{\\vert S_{r}\\vert \\cdot \\vert S_{k-r}\\vert } {r \\cdot {r}^{m_{r}-1}\(m_{r} - 1\)!\\prod _{s\\neq r}{s}^{m_{s}}m_{s}!}\\right \]rz_{\\lambda }\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equh.gif)

which equals rm r . This proves (37.4).

We note that since λ is a partition of k, and since λ has m r cycles of length r, we have ![
$$k =\\sum _{ r=1}^{k}rm_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq28123.gif). Therefore,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\sum _{r=1}^{k}\\mathbf{p}_{ r}\\mathbf{h}_{k-r},\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\\right \\rangle =\\sum _{r}rm_{r} = k = \\left \\langle k\\mathbf{h}_{k},\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Because this is true for every λ, we obtain (37.3). □

Let ![
$$p_{\\lambda } = p_{\\lambda _{1}}p_{\\lambda _{2}}\\cdots \\in \\varLambda _{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq29123.gif), where p k is defined by (33.​7).

Proposition 37.7.

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ kh_{k} =\\sum _{ r=1}^{k}p_{ r}h_{k-r}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(37.5)

Proof.

We recall from (33.​2) that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }h_{ k}{t}^{k} =\\prod _{ i=1}^{n}{\(1 - x_{ i}t\)}^{-1},}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equj.gif)

which we differentiate logarithmically to obtain

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\frac{\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }kh_{k}{t}^{k-1}} {\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }h_{k}{t}^{k}} =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n} \\frac{d} {dt}\\,\\log {\(1 - x_{i}t\)}^{-1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Since

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{d} {dt}\\log {\(1 - x_{i}t\)}^{-1} =\\sum _{ r=1}^{\\infty }x_{ i}^{r}{t}^{r-1},}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equl.gif)

we obtain

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{k=1}^{\\infty }kh_{ k}{t}^{k-1} = \\left \[\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }h_{ k}{t}^{k}\\right \]\\sum _{ r=1}^{\\infty }p_{ r}\\,{t}^{r-1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equm.gif)

Equating the coefficients of t k−1, the result follows. □

Theorem 37.1.

We have ![
$$\\mathrm{ch}\(\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\) = p_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) .

Proof.

We have ![
$$\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda } = \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{1}}\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda _{2}}\\cdots $$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq31123.gif). Hence, it is sufficient to show that ch(p k ) = p k . This follows from the fact that they satisfy the same recursion formula—compare (37.5) with (37.3)—and that ch(h k ) = h k . □

Now we may determine the irreducible characters of S k .

Theorem 37.2.

Express each symmetric polynomial p λ as a linear combination of the s μ :

![
$$\\displaystyle{p_{\\lambda } =\\sum _{\\mu }c_{\\lambda \\mu }s_{\\mu }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equn.gif)

Then the coefficient c λμ is the value of the irreducible character s μ on elements of the conjugacy class ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) .

Proof.

Since n ≥ k, ![
$$\\mathrm{ch}: \\mathcal{R}_{k} \\rightarrow \\varLambda _{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq3313.gif) is injective, and it follows that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda } =\\sum _{\\mu }c_{\\lambda \\mu }\\,\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equo.gif)

Taking the inner product of this relation with s μ, we see that

![
$$\\displaystyle{c_{\\lambda \\mu } = \\left \\langle \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda },\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equp.gif)

The result follows from Proposition 37.3. □

Here is a variant of Theorem 37.2. Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta =\\prod _{i<j}\(x_{i} - x_{j}\) =\\det \(x_{j}^{n-i}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equq.gif)

be the Vandermonde determinant. which is the denominator in (36.​1).

Theorem 37.3.

(Frobenius) Let μ be a partition of k of length ⩽ n, and let λ be another partition of k. Let c λμ be the value of the character s μ on elements of the conjugacy class ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) . Then c λμ is the coefficient of

![
$$\\displaystyle{ x_{1}^{\\mu _{1}+n-1}x_{ 2}^{\\mu _{2}+n-2}\\cdots x_{ n}^{\\mu _{n} } }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(37.6)

in the polynomal p λ Δ.

Proof.

By Theorem 37.2, we have ![
$$p_{\\lambda } =\\sum _{\\mu }c_{\\lambda \\mu }s_{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq35.gif), and by (36.​1) this means that

![
$$\\displaystyle{p_{\\lambda }\\varDelta =\\sum _{\\mu }\\,c_{\\lambda \\mu }\\,\\det \(x_{j}^{\\mu _{i}+n-i}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equr.gif)

the determinant being the determinant in the numerator in (36.​1). The monomial (37.6) appears only in the μ term and the statement follows. □

As an example of Theorem 37.2, let us verify the irreducible characters of S 3. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{llll} s_{\(3\)} & = h_{3} =\\sum x_{i}^{3} & +\\sum \\nolimits_{i\\neq j}x_{i}^{2}x_{j}& +\\sum \\nolimits_{i<j<k}x_{i}x_{j}x_{k}, \\\\ s_{\(21\)} & = &\\sum \\nolimits_{i\\neq j}x_{i}^{2}x_{j} & + 2\\sum \\nolimits_{i<j<k}x_{i}x_{j}x_{k}, \\\\ s_{\(111\)} & = e_{\(3\)} = & &\\sum \\nolimits_{i<j<k}x_{i}x_{j}x_{k}. \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equs.gif)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{ll} p_{\(3\)} & =\\sum x_{i}^{3}, \\\\ p_{\(21\)} & =\\sum x_{i}^{3} +\\sum \\nolimits_{i\\neq j}x_{i}^{2}x_{j}, \\\\ p_{\(111\)} & =\\sum x_{i}^{3} + 3\\sum \\nolimits_{i\\neq j}x_{i}^{2}x_{j} + 6\\sum \\nolimits_{i<j<k}x_{i}x_{j}x_{k}, \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equt.gif)

so

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{lll} p_{\(111\)} & = s_{\(3\)} + s_{\(111\)} + 2s_{\(21\)} &, \\\\ p_{\(3\)} & = s_{\(3\)} + s_{\(111\)} - s_{\(21\)} &, \\\\ p_{\(21}\) & = s_{\(3\)} - s_{\(111\)}. & \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equu.gif)

These coefficients are precisely the coefficients in the character table of S 3:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{|l|l|} \\hline  &\\begin{array}{lll} \\;1\\;&\\;\(123\)\\;&\\;\(12\)\\; \\end{array} \\\\ \\hline \\begin{array}{ccc} \\mathbf{s}_{\(3\)} \\\\ \\mathbf{s}_{\(111\)} \\\\ \\mathbf{s}_{\(21\)} \\end{array} & \\begin{array}{ccc} \\;1\\;& \\; 1\\; & \\quad 1\\;\\\\ 1 & 1 &\\quad - 1 \\\\ 2& - 1& \\quad 0 \\end{array} \\\\ \\hline \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equv.gif)

Before we leave the representation theory of the symmetric group, let us recall the involution ι of Proposition 34.3 and Theorem 35.2, which interchanges s λ with s μ, where μ = λ t is the conjugate partition. It has a concrete interpretation in this context.

Lemma 37.1.

Let H be a subgroup of the finite group G. Let χ be a character of H, and let ρ be a one-dimensional character of G, which we may restrict to H. The induced character (ρχ) G equals ρχ G .

Thus, it does not matter whether we multiply by ρ before or after inducing to G.

Proof.

This may be proved either directly from the definition of the induced representation or by using (32.​15). □

Theorem 37.4.

If f is a class function on S k , its involute ι f is the result of multiplying f by the alternating character ![
$$\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq36.gif) of S k .

We refrain from denotingι f as ![
$$\\varepsilon \\mathbf{f}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq37.gif) because the graded ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq38.gif) has a different multiplication.

Proof.

Let us denote by ![
$$\\tau: \\mathcal{R}_{k}\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq39.gif) the linear map that takes a class function f on S k and multiplies it by ![
$$\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq40.gif), and assemble the τ in different degrees to a linear map of ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq41.gif) to itself. We want to prove that τ and ι are the same. By the definition of the e k and h k , they are interchanged by τ, and by Theorem 35.2 they are interchanged by ι. Since the e k generate ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq42.gif) as a ring, the result will follow if we check that τ is a ring homomorphism.

Applying Lemma 37.1 with ![
$$G = S_{k+l}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq43.gif), H = S k × S l , and ![
$$\\rho =\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq44.gif) shows that multiplying the characters χ and η of S k and S l each by ![
$$\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq45.gif) to obtain the charactersτχ andτη and then inducing the characterτχ ⊗τη of S k × S l to S k+l gives the same result as inducing χ ⊗ η and multiplying it by ![
$$\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_IEq46.gif). This shows that τ is a ring homomorphism. □

Exercise 37.1.

Compute the character table of S 4 using symmetric polynomials by the method of this chapter.

Exercise 37.2.

Prove the identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{ke_{k} =\\sum _{ r=1}^{k}{\(-1\)}^{r}p_{r}e_{ k-r}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_37_Chapter_Equw.gif)

Let us say that a partition λ is a ribbon partition if its Young diagram only has entries in the first row and column. The ribbon partitions of k are of the form (k − r, 1 r ) with 0 ⩽ r ⩽ k, where the notation means the partition with one part of length k − r and r parts of length 1.

Show that

![

# 38. The Cauchy Identity

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

Suppose that ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq1.gif) and ![
$$\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq2.gif) are two sets of variables. The Cauchy identity asserts that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\prod _{i=1}^{n}\\prod _{ j=1}^{m}{\(1 - \\alpha _{ i}\\beta _{j}\)}^{-1} =\\sum _{ \\lambda }s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)s_{\\lambda }\(\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(38.1)

where the sum is over all partitions λ (of all k). The series is absolutely convergent if all ![
$$\\vert \\alpha _{i}\\vert,\\vert \\beta _{i}\\vert <1$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq3.gif). It can also be regarded as an equality of formal power series.

Suppose that ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq4.gif) and ![
$$\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq5.gif) are two sets of variables. The Cauchy identity asserts that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\prod _{i=1}^{n}\\prod _{ j=1}^{m}{\(1 - \\alpha _{ i}\\beta _{j}\)}^{-1} =\\sum _{ \\lambda }s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)s_{\\lambda }\(\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(38.1)

where the sum is over all partitions λ (of all k). The series is absolutely convergent if all ![
$$\\vert \\alpha _{i}\\vert,\\vert \\beta _{i}\\vert <1$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq6.gif). It can also be regarded as an equality of formal power series.

The general context for our discussion of the Cauchy identity will be the Frobenius–Schur duality. For other approaches, see Exercises 26.4 and 38.4.

We recall from Chap.​ 34 that the characteristic map ![
$$\\mathrm{ch}: {\\mathcal{R}\\longrightarrow \\varLambda }^{\(N\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq7.gif) allows us to interpret a character (or class function) on the symmetric group S k as a symmetric polynomial in N variables that is homogeneous of degree k.

Here is a simple fact we will need. Notations are as in Chap.​ 37.

Proposition 38.1.

Let k be a nonnegative integer. Then we have the following identity in the ring ![
$${\\varLambda }^{\(N\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq8.gif) of symmetric polynomials.

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{{\\lambda\\ a\\ partition\\ of\\ k}}z_{\\lambda }^{-1}p_{ \\lambda } = h_{k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

Proof.

In view of Theorem 37.1 it is sufficient to show in ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq9.gif) that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}z_{\\lambda }^{-1}\\mathbf{p}_{ \\lambda } = \\mathbf{h}_{k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

We consider both sides as functions on S k . By definition, ![
$$\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq10.gif) is the function supported on the single conjugacy class ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq11.gif) with value z λ on that class; summing over all conjugacy classes, ![
$$\\sum _{\\lambda }z_{\\lambda }^{-1}\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq12.gif) is the constant function equal to 1 on S k , that is, ![
$$\\mathbf{h}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq13.gif). □

Next we will consider symmetric polynomials in two sets of variables, ![
$$\\alpha _{1}, \\ldots, \\alpha _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq14.gif) and ![
$$\\beta _{1}, \\ldots, \\beta _{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq15.gif). Consider a polynomial f in α 1,...,α n and β 1,...,β m that is (for fixed β) symmetric in α 1,..., α n and homogeneous of degree k, and also (for fixed α) symmetric in β 1,..., β m and homogeneous of degree l. Then we may transfer this by the Frobenius–Schur duality to ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k} \\otimes \\mathcal{R}_{l}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq16.gif). In other words, we may find an element ξ in ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k} \\otimes \\mathcal{R}_{l}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq17.gif) such that ![
$${\\mathrm{ch}}^{\(n\)} \\otimes {\\mathrm{ch}}^{\(m\)}\(\\xi\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq18.gif) is the given symmetric polynomial in two sets of variables.

Proposition 38.2.

Let k be a nonnegative integer. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sum _{{ \\lambda\\ a\\ partition\\ of\\ k}}s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha\)\\,s_{\\lambda }\(\\beta\) =\\sum _{{ \\lambda\\ a\\ partition\\ of\\ k}}z_{\\lambda }^{-1}p_{ \\lambda }\(\\alpha\)\\,p_{\\lambda }\(\\beta\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(38.2)

Proof.

Both sides polynomials in the α i and β i that are symmetric and homogeneous of degree k in either set of variables. Use the Frobenius–Schur duality to transfer the function on the right-hand side to a function on S k × S k . In view of Theorem 37.1 this is the function

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta \(\\sigma,\\tau\) =\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}z_{\\lambda }^{-1}\\mathbf{p}_{ \\lambda }\(\\sigma\)\\,\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\(\\tau\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

that maps ![
$$\(\\sigma,\\tau\) \\in S_{k} \\times S_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq19.gif) to the function that has the value z λ if σ and τ are in the conjugacy class ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq20.gif), and is zero if σ and τ are not conjugate. This function may be characterized as follows: if f is a class function, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{1} {k!}\\sum _{\\tau \\in S_{k}}\\varDelta \(\\sigma,\\tau\)\\,f\(\\tau\) = f\(\\sigma\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

Indeed, if σ is in the conjugacy class ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq21.gif), there are ![
$$\\left \\vert \\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }\\right \\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq22.gif) values of τ, namely the conjugates of σ, for which there is a contribution of ![
$$z_{\\lambda }f\(\\tau\) = z_{\\lambda }f\(\\sigma\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq23.gif), and since ![
$$\\left \\vert \\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }\\right \\vert z_{\\lambda } = k!$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq24.gif), the statement follows. Thus, Δ is the reproducing kernel for class functions. It is characterized by this property, together with the fact (with τ fixed) Δ(σ,τ) is constant on conjugacy classes of σ, and similarly for τ with σ fixed. Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(\\sigma\)\\,\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(\\tau\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

is also a class function in σ and τ separately, and it has the same reproducing property, as a consequence of Schur orthogonality. Hence these are equal. We see that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(\\sigma\)\\,\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(\\tau\) =\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}z_{\\lambda }^{-1}\\mathbf{p}_{ \\lambda }\(\\sigma\)\\,\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\(\\tau\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

and applying ![
$$\\mathrm{ch} \\otimes \\mathrm{ch}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq25.gif) we obtain (38.2). □

Theorem 38.1. (Cauchy)

Suppose ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) and ![
$$\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) are complex numbers of absolute value < 1. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\prod _{i=1}^{n}\\prod _{ j=1}^{m}{\(1 - \\alpha _{ i}\\beta _{j}\)}^{-1} =\\sum _{ \\lambda }s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)s_{\\lambda }\(\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(38.3)

The sum is over all partitions λ.

Proof.

Using (33.​2) in the nm variables α i β j , the left-hand side equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{k=0}h_{k}\(\\alpha _{i}\\beta _{j}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

so it is sufficient to show

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)s_{\\lambda }\(\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}\) = h_{k}\(\\alpha _{i}\\beta _{j}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

(38.4)

By (38.2) this equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}z_{\\lambda }^{-1}p_{ \\lambda }\(\\alpha\)\\,p_{\\lambda }\(\\beta\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ13.gif)

We now make the observation that ![
$$p_{k}\(\\alpha _{i}\\beta _{j}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq28123.gif), which is the k th power sum symmetric polynomial in nm variables α i β j , equals ![
$$p_{k}\(\\alpha\)p_{k}\(\\beta\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq29123.gif), and so ![
$$p_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{i}\\beta _{j}\) = p_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha\)p_{\\lambda }\(\\beta\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq30123.gif). The statement now follows from Proposition 38.1. □

The Cauchy identity may be interpreted as describing the decomposition of the symmetric algebra over the tensor product representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n} \\times \\mathrm{GL}_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq31123.gif), as we will now explain. Let G be a group, and let ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(\\varOmega\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) be a representation on some vector space Ω. Let g ∈ G, and let α 1,..., α N be the eigenvalues of π(g). Then ![
$$h_{k}\(\\alpha\) = h_{k}\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{N}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) and ![
$$e_{k}\(\\alpha\) = e_{k}\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq34233.gif) are the traces of ![
$$\\pi \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq35.gif) on the k th symmetric and exterior powers ![
$${\\vee }^{k}\\varOmega$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq36.gif) and ![
$${\\wedge }^{k}\\varOmega$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq37.gif), respectively. Therefore,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }h_{ k}\(\\alpha\) =\\prod _{ i=1}^{N}{\(1 - \\alpha _{ i}\)}^{-1}\\mathrm{and}\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }e_{ k}\(\\alpha\) =\\prod _{ i=1}^{N}\(1 + \\alpha _{ i}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ14.gif)

may be regarded as the characters of g on the symmetric and exterior algebras.

The symmetric algebra is infinite-dimensional, so strictly speaking the trace of an endomorphism only has a provisional meaning. Indeed the first series is only convergent if |α i | < 1, but there are several ways of handling this. One may try to choose g so that its eigenvalues are < 1, or one may simply regard the series as formal. Or, assuming no α i = 1, one may regard the series as obtained from

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }h_{ k}\(\\alpha\){t}^{k} =\\prod _{ i=1}^{N}{\(1 - t\\alpha _{ i}\)}^{-1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ15.gif)

by analytic continuation in t.

Proposition 38.3.

Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}_{m}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq38.gif) acting on the tensor product ![
$$\\varOmega = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n} \\otimes {\\mathbb{C}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq39.gif) of the standard modules of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq40.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{m}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq41.gif) . Then the symmetric algebra

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\bigvee \\varOmega \\mathop{\\cong}\\bigoplus _{\\lambda }\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}_{n} } \\otimes \\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}_{m} } }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ16.gif)

(38.5)

as G-modules, where the summation is over all partitions λ of length ![
$$\\leqslant \\min \(m,n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq42.gif) .

Proof.

If g has eigenvalues α i and h has eigenvalues β j , then (g, h) has eigenvalues α i β j on Ω, hence has trace h k (α i β j ) on ![
$${\\vee }^{k}\\varOmega$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq43.gif). By the Cauchy identity in the form (38.4), this equals ![
$$\\sum s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha\)\\,s_{\\lambda }\(\\beta\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq44.gif) where the sum is over partitions of k. [If the length of the partition λ is > n, we interpret s λ(α) as zero.] Combining the contributions over all k, the statement follows. □

There is a dual Cauchy identity.

Theorem 38.2.

Suppose α 1 ,..., α n and β 1 ,..., β m are complex numbers of absolute value < 1. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\prod _{i=1}^{n}\\prod _{ j=1}^{m}\(1 + \\alpha _{ i}\\beta _{j}\) =\\sum _{\\lambda }s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)s_{{\\lambda }^{t}}\(\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ17.gif)

(38.6)

Note that now each partition λ is paired with its conjugate partition λ t . This may be regarded as a decomposition of the exterior algebra on ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}{\(\\mathbb{C}\)}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq45.gif).

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq46.gif) be fixed complex numbers, and let Λ (m) be the ring of symmetric polynomials in β 1,..., β m with integer coefficients. We recall from Theorems 34.3 and 35.2 that Λ has an involution ι that interchanges s λ and s λ′. We have to be careful how we use ι because it does not induce an involution of Λ (m). Indeed, it is possible that in Λ (m) one of s λ and s λ′ is zero and the other is not, so no involution exists that simply interchanges them.

We write the Cauchy identity in the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\prod _{i=1}^{n}\\left \[\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }\\alpha _{ i}^{k}h_{ k}\(\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{m}\)\\right \] =\\sum _{\\lambda }s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)s_{\\lambda }\(\\beta _{1},\\ldots,b_{m}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ18.gif)

This is true for all m, and therefore we may write

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\prod _{i=1}^{n}\\left \[\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }\\alpha _{ i}^{k}h_{ k}\\right \] =\\sum _{\\lambda }s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)s_{\\lambda },}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ19.gif)

where the h k on the left and the second occurrence of s λ on the right are regarded as elements of the ring Λ, which is the inverse limit (34.​10) of the rings Λ (m), while α i and ![
$$s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq47.gif) are regarded as complex numbers. To this identity we may apply ι and obtain

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\prod _{i=1}^{n}\\left \[\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }\\alpha _{ i}^{k}e_{ k}\\right \] =\\sum _{\\lambda }s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)s_{\\lambda ^{\\prime}},}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ20.gif)

and now we specialize from Λ to Λ (m) and obtain (38.6). □

In this chapter and the next, we will give some applications of the Cauchy identity. First some preliminaries. If λ, μ, ν are partitions, there is defined a nonnegative integer ![
$$c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq48.gif) called the Littlewood–Richardson coefficient. It is (by definition) zero unless ![
$$\\left \\vert \\lambda \\right \\vert = \\left \\vert \\mu \\right \\vert + \\left \\vert \\nu \\right \\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq49.gif), where we recall that ![
$$\\left \\vert \\lambda \\right \\vert =\\sum \\lambda _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq50.gif) is the sum of the parts, that is, λ is a partition of ![
$$\\left \\vert \\lambda \\right \\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq51.gif). There is a combinatorial description of ![
$$C_{\\mu\\nu}^{\\lambda}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq01.gif), but we will not describe it (except in special cases). For this Littlewood–Richardson rule see Macdonald [124] or Stanley [153].

The next theorem, asserting the equivalence of three definitions of ![
$$C_{\\mu\\nu}^{\\lambda}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq02.gif), shows that the Littlewood–Richardson coefficients have three distinct representation theoretic interpretations. They have other interpretations too. For example, they describe the structure constants in the cohomology ring of Grassmannians with respect to the basis of cohomology classes corresponding to Schubert cycles. If ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\lambda _{2},\\ldots,\\lambda _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq52.gif) is a partition of length ![
$$\\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq53.gif), we will denote by ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq54.gif) the irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq55.gif) parametrized by λ.

Let G be a group and H a subgroup. A rule describing how irreducible representations of G decompose into irreducibles when restricted to H is called a branching rule. The tensor product rule describing how the tensor product π ⊗ π′ of irreducibles ![
$$\\pi,\\pi ^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq56.gif) of H decomposes into irreducibles of H may be thought of a branching rule. Indeed, ![
$$\\pi \\otimes \\pi ^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq57.gif) extends to an irreducible representation of H × H, so the tensor product rule is really a branching rule for H embedded in G = H × H diagonally.

All three definitions of the Littlewood–Richardson coefficients may be characterized as branching rules. To specify a branching rule, we need to specify an embedding of a group H in a larger group G. The embeddings ![
$$H \\rightarrow G$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq58.gif) in the three branching rules as follows. The first is the embedding of ![
$$S_{k} \\times S_{l}\\longrightarrow S_{k+l}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq59.gif) that we worked with in Chap.​ 34. The second is the diagonal embedding ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq60.gif). The third is the Levi embedding of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(p, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(q, \\mathbb{C}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(p + q, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq61.gif) as follows:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \(g,h\)\\longmapsto \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g& \\\\ &h \\end{array} \\right\),g \\in \\mathrm{GL}_{p}\(\\mathbb{C}\),h \\in \\mathrm{GL}_{q}\(\\mathbb{C}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ21.gif)

(38.7)

As usual, we are only interested in analytic representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq62.gif), which are the same as representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq63.gif), so we could equally well work with the embeddings ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{U}\(n\) \\times \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq64.gif) and the Levi embedding ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{U}\(q\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{U}\(p + q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq65.gif).

Remarkably, these three branching rules involve the same coefficients ![
$$c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq66.gif). This is the content of the next result.

Theorem 38.3.

Let ![
$$\\lambda,\\mu,\\nu$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq67.gif) be partitions such that ![
$$\\left \\vert \\lambda \\right \\vert = \\left \\vert \\mu \\right \\vert + \\left \\vert \\nu \\right \\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq68.gif) . Then the following three definitions of ![
$$c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq69.gif) are equivalent. We will denote k = |μ| and l = |ν|.

(i)

Let ρ λ be the irreducible representation of S k+l with character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq70.gif) . Then ![
$$C_{\\mu\\nu}^{\\lambda}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq03.gif) is the multiplicity of ![
$$\\rho _{\\mu } \\otimes \\rho _{\\nu }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq71.gif) in the restriction of ρ λ to S k × S l .

(ii)

Let ![
$$n \\geqslant\\vert \\lambda \\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq72.gif) . Then ![
$$c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq73.gif) is the multiplicity of ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq74.gif) in the decomposition of the representation ![
$$\\pi _{\\mu }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)} \\otimes \\pi _{\\nu }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq75.gif) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq76.gif) into irreducibles.

(ii)

Let p ≥ k and q ≥ l. Then ![
$$C_{\\mu\\nu}^{\\lambda}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq444.gif) is the multiplicity of ![
$$\\pi _{\\mu }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(p\)} \\otimes \\pi _{\\nu }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(q\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq77.gif) in the restriction of π μ GL (p+q) to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(p, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(q, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq78.gif) into irreducibles.

Proof.

We note that (i) can be expressed as the identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\\mathbf{s}_{\\nu } =\\sum _{\\mu }c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }\\mathbf{s}_{ \\lambda },}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ22.gif)

since taking the inner product of the left-hand side with ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq79.gif) and using Frobenius reciprocity gives the coefficient of ![
$$\\rho _{\\mu } \\otimes \\rho _{\\nu }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq80.gif) in the restriction of ![
$$\\rho _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq81.gif) from ![
$$S_{k+l}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq82.gif) to S k × S l . On the other hand (ii) can be expressed as the identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{s_{\\mu }\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\)\\,s_{\\nu }\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) =\\sum _{\\lambda }c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }s_{ \\lambda }\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ23.gif)

in the ring Λ (n) of symmetric polynomials. Indeed, substituting for x i the eigenvalues of ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq83.gif), the Schur polynomial s λ becomes the character of ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq84.gif), and the left-hand side becomes the character of ![
$$\\pi _{\\mu }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)} \\otimes \\pi _{\\nu }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq85.gif). Thus the equivalence of (i) and (ii) follows from Proposition 34.4.

As for the equivalence of (ii) and (iii), we give an argument based on the Cauchy identity. Comparing the characters of ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(p+q\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq86.gif) and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigoplus _{\\mu,\\nu }c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }\\pi _{ \\mu }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(p\)} \\otimes \\pi _{ \\nu }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(q\)}}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ24.gif)

on the matrix (38.7), we see that (iii) is equivalent to the identity

![
$$\\displaystyle{s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{p},\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{q}\) =\\sum _{\\mu,\\nu }c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }s_{ \\mu }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{p}\)s_{\\nu }\(\\beta _{1},\\ldots,\\beta _{q}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ25.gif)

where α 1,..., α p are the eigenvalues of g and β 1,..., β q are the eigenvalues of h. In a more succinct notation, we write the left-hand side s λ(α, β), so what we need to prove is

![
$$\\displaystyle{ s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha,\\beta\) =\\sum _{\\mu,\\nu }c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }s_{ \\mu }\(\\alpha\)s_{\\nu }\(\\beta\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ26.gif)

(38.8)

Let γ1 ,..., γ n be arbitrary complex numbers. By the Cauchy identity for

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{\\lambda }s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha,\\beta\)s_{\\lambda }\(\\gamma\) =\\prod _{i,k}{\(1 - \\alpha _{i}\\gamma _{k}\)}^{-1}\\prod _{ j,k}{\\left \(1 - \\beta _{j}\\gamma _{k}\\right\)}^{-1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ27.gif)

Also by the Cauchy identity this equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\sum _{\\mu }s_{\\mu }\(\\alpha\)s_{\\mu }\(\\gamma\)\\right\)\\left \(\\sum _{\\nu }s_{\\nu }\(\\beta\)s_{\\nu }\(\\gamma\)\\right\) =\\sum _{\\mu,\\nu }s_{\\mu }\(\\alpha\)s_{\\nu }\(b\)\\sum _{\\lambda }c_{\\mu \\nu }^{\\lambda }s_{ \\lambda }\(\\gamma\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ28.gif)

Since the functions s λ(γ) are linearly independent as λ varies, we may compare the coefficients of s λ(γ) and obtain (38.8). □

It is worth pondering the mechanism behind the proof that (ii) is equivalent to (iii). We will reconsider it after some preliminaries.

We begin with the notion of a correspondence in the sense of Howe, who wrote many papers on this subject: see Howe [75, 77]. A correspondence is a bijection between a set of irreducible representations of a group G and another group H. The relevant examples arise in the following manner.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq87.gif) be a group with a representation Θ, and let G and H be subgroups that centralize each other. Thus, we have a homomorphism ![
$$G \\times H\\longrightarrow \\mathfrak{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq88.gif). (Often this homomorphism is injective so G × H is a subgroup of ![
$$\\mathfrak{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq89.gif), but we do not require this.) We assume given a representation Θ of ![
$$\\mathfrak{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq90.gif) with the following property: when Θ is restricted to G × H, it becomes a direct sum ![
$$\\pi _{i} \\otimes \\pi _{i}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq91.gif), where ![
$$\\pi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq92.gif) are irreducible representations of G, and ![
$$\\pi _{i}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq93.gif) are irreducible representations of H. We assume that each ![
$$\\pi _{i} \\otimes \\pi _{i}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq94.gif) occurs with multiplicity at most one, and moreover, there are no repetitions between the representations ![
$$\\pi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq95.gif) and no repetitions among the ![
$$\\pi _{i}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq96.gif). (This definition is adequate if G and H are compact but might need to be generalized slightly if they are not.) If this condition is satisfied, we say the representation Θ induces a correspondence for G and H. The correspondence is the bijection ![
$$\\pi _{i}\\longleftrightarrow \\pi _{i}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq97.gif). Here are some examples.

  * Let G = S k , ![
$$H = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq98.gif), and ![
$$\\mathfrak{G} = G \\times H$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq99.gif). The representation Θ is the action on ![
$${\\otimes }^{k}{\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq100.gif) in Theorem 36.4. That theorem implies that Θ induces a correspondence. Indeed, by Theorem 36.4 the correspondence is the bijection ![
$$\\rho _{\\lambda }\\longleftrightarrow \\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq101.gif), as λ runs through partitions of k that have length ![
$$\\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq102.gif). Thus, the Frobenius–Schur duality is an example of a correspondence.

  * Consider ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq103.gif), ![
$$H = \\mathrm{GL}\(m, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq104.gif) acting on ![
$$\\varOmega = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n} \\otimes {\\mathbb{C}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq105.gif) as above. Since ![
$$\(g \\otimes I_{m}\)\(I_{n} \\otimes h\) = \(g \\otimes h\) = \(I_{n} \\otimes h\)\(g \\otimes I_{m}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq106.gif), the actions of G and H commute. Let Θ be the action on the symmetric algebra of Ω. It is actually a representation of ![
$$\\mathfrak{G} = \\mathrm{GL}\(\\varOmega\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq107.gif). As we have already explained, when restricted to G × H, the Cauchy identity implies the decomposition (38.5), so Θ induces a correspondence. This is the bijection ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}\\longleftrightarrow \\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(m\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq108.gif) as λ runs through all partitions of length ![
$$\\leqslant \\min \(m,n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq109.gif). This equivalence is sometimes referred to as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(m\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq110.gif) -duality.

  * Howe conjectured [73], and it was eventually proved, that if G and H are reductive subgroups of ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2N,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq111.gif), where ![
$$F$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq112.gif) is a local field (including ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq113.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq114.gif)), then the Weil (oscillator) representation induces a correspondence. In some cases one of the groups of the correspondence must be replaced by a covering group. In one most important case, ![
$$G = \\mathrm{Sp}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq115.gif) and ![
$$H = \\mathrm{O}\(m\),$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq116.gif) where nm = N, so the correspondence relates representations of symplectic groups (or their double covers) to representations of an orthogonal group. This phenomenon is known as Howe duality. It is closely related to the theta liftings in the theory of automorphic forms. Here the Weil representation is a projective representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(2N,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq117.gif) with a construction that is similar to the construction of a projective representation of the orthogonal groups in Chap.​ 31. In place of the Clifford algebra one uses a Heisenberg group or the symplectic Clifford algebra, often called the Weyl algebra.

Now let us consider the following abstract situation. Let G and G′ be groups. Let H and H′ be subgroups of G and H, respectively. We will assume that G and G′ are subgroups of a larger group ![
$$\\mathfrak{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq118.gif) such that H′ is the centralizer of G, and H is the centralizer of G′. Now let us assume that ![
$$\\mathfrak{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq119.gif) has a representation Θ that induces correspondences between G and H′, and between G′ and H.

We summarize this situation by a "see-saw" diagram:

(38.9)

The vertical lines are inclusions, and the diagonal lines are correspondences. Now we can show that the pairs G, H and G′, H′ have the same branching rule (except inverted with respect to inclusion).

Proposition 38.4.

Let there be given a see-saw (38.9). Let π i G and π i H′ be corresponding representations of G and H′, and let ![
$$\\pi _{j}^{G^{\\prime}}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq120.gif) and ![
$$\\pi _{j}^{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq121.gif) be corresponding representations of G′ and H. Then the multiplicity of ![
$$\\pi _{j}^{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq122.gif) in ![
$$\\pi _{i}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq123.gif) equals the multiplicity of ![
$$\\pi _{i}^{H^{\\prime}}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq124.gif) in ![
$$\\pi _{j}^{G^{\\prime}}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq125.gif) .

Proof.

We may express the correspondences as follows:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\varTheta \\vert _{G\\times H^{\\prime}} =\\bigoplus _{i\\in I}\\pi _{i}^{G} \\otimes \\pi _{ i}^{H^{\\prime}},\\varTheta \\vert _{ H\\times G^{\\prime}} =\\bigoplus _{j\\in J}\\pi _{j}^{H} \\otimes \\pi _{ j}^{G^{\\prime}}, }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ30.gif)

(38.10)

for suitable indexing sets I and J. We first observe that if σ is an irreducible of H that occurs in any ![
$$\\pi _{i}^{G}\\vert _{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq126.gif), then σ = π j H for some j. Indeed, it follows from the second decomposition that the ![
$$\\pi _{j}^{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq127.gif) are precisely the irreducibles of H that occur in the restriction of Θ to H, from which this statement is clear. Therefore, we may find integers c(i, j) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\pi _{i}^{G}\\vert _{ H} =\\bigoplus _{j\\in J}c\(i,j\)\\pi _{j}^{H} }$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ31.gif)

(38.11)

and similarly

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi _{j}^{G^{\\prime}}\\vert _{ H^{\\prime}} =\\bigoplus _{i\\in I}d\(i,j\)\\pi _{i}^{H^{\\prime}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ32.gif)

What we must prove is that c(i, j) = d(i, j). Now combining the first equation in (38.10) with (38.11) we get

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varTheta _{H\\times H^{\\prime}} =\\bigoplus _{i,j}c\(i,j\)\\pi _{j}^{H} \\otimes \\pi _{ i}^{H^{\\prime}}}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ33.gif)

and similarly

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varTheta _{H\\times H^{\\prime}} =\\bigoplus _{i,j}d\(i,j\)\\pi _{j}^{H} \\otimes \\pi _{ i}^{H^{\\prime}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ34.gif)

Comparing, the statement follows. □

Now let us reconsider the equivalence of (ii) and (iii) in Theorem 38.3. This may be understood as a refllection of the following see-saw:

The left vertical line is the diagonal embedding ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(n\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq128.gif), and the right vertical line is the Levi embedding ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(q\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(p + q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq129.gif). The ambient group is ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\varOmega\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq130.gif) where ![
$$\\varOmega = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n} \\otimes {\\mathbb{C}}^{p+q}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq131.gif) acting on the symmetric algebra ![
$$\\bigvee \\varOmega$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq132.gif). More specifically, with ![
$$H = \\mathrm{GL}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq133.gif) and ![
$$G^{\\prime} = \\mathrm{GL}\(p + q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq134.gif), H × G′ acts on ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n} \\otimes {\\mathbb{C}}^{p+q}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq135.gif) in the obvious way; with ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq136.gif) and ![
$$H^{\\prime} = \\mathrm{GL}\(p\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq137.gif) we use the isomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\mathbb{C}}^{n} \\otimes {\\mathbb{C}}^{p+q}\\mathop{\\cong}\({\\mathbb{C}}^{n} \\otimes {\\mathbb{C}}^{p}\) \\oplus \({\\mathbb{C}}^{n} \\otimes {\\mathbb{C}}^{q}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_Equ35.gif)

with the first ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq138.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(p\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq139.gif) acting on the first component, and the second ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq140.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq141.gif) on the second component. Proposition 38.4 asserts that the two branching rules are the same, which is the equivalence of (ii) and (iii) in Theorem 38.3.

The paper of Howe, Tan, and Willenbring [79] gives many more examples of see-saws applied to branching rules. Kudla [113] showed that many constructions in the theory of automorphic forms could be explained by see-saws.

Branching rules are important for many problems and are the subject of considerable literature. Branching rules for the orthogonal and symplectic groups are discussed in Goodman and Wallach 56], [Chap.​ 8. King [101] is a useful survey of branching rules for classical groups. Many branching rules are programmed into Sage.

Let G × G act on the ring of matrix coefficients ![

](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq151.gif) of ![
$$\\pi$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq152.gif) by

$$\\displaystyle{\(g,h\)f\(x\) = f\\big\(\\tau \(g\)xh\\big\).}$$

Show that this representation is isomorphic to ![
$$\\pi \\otimes \\pi$$

Let us call a function on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq154.gif) regular if, as a function of g = (g ij ) it is a polynomial in the g ij and det(g)−1. A regular function on ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_38_Chapter_IEq155.gif) is a polynomial. Thus, it is a regular function on ![
