# 39. Random Matrix Theory

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In this chapter, we will work not with ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq1.gif) but with its compact subgroup U(n). As in the previous chapters, we will consider elements of ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq2.gif) as generalized characters on S k . If ![
$$\\mathbf{f} \\in \\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq3.gif), then ![
$$f ={ \\mathrm{ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{f}\) \\in \\varLambda _{k}^{\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq4.gif) is a symmetric polynomial in n variables, homogeneous of weight k. Then ![
$$\\psi _{f}: \\mathrm{U}\(n\)\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq5.gif), defined by (33.​6), is the function on U(n) obtained by applying f to the eigenvalues of g ∈U(n). We will denote ![
$$\\psi _{f} ={ \\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{f}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq6.gif). Thus, Ch(n) maps the additive group of generalized characters on S k to the additive group of generalized characters on U(n). It extends by linearity to a map from the Hilbert space of class functions on S k to the Hilbert space of class functions on U(n).

In this chapter, we will work not with ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq7.gif) but with its compact subgroup U(n). As in the previous chapters, we will consider elements of ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq8.gif) as generalized characters on S k . If ![
$$\\mathbf{f} \\in \\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq9.gif), then ![
$$f ={ \\mathrm{ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{f}\) \\in \\varLambda _{k}^{\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq10.gif) is a symmetric polynomial in n variables, homogeneous of weight k. Then ![
$$\\psi _{f}: \\mathrm{U}\(n\)\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq11.gif), defined by (33.​6), is the function on U(n) obtained by applying f to the eigenvalues of g ∈U(n). We will denote ![
$$\\psi _{f} ={ \\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{f}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq12.gif). Thus, Ch(n) maps the additive group of generalized characters on S k to the additive group of generalized characters on U(n). It extends by linearity to a map from the Hilbert space of class functions on S k to the Hilbert space of class functions on U(n).

Proposition 39.1.

Let f be a class function on S k . Write ![
$$\\mathbf{f} =\\sum _{\\lambda }c_{\\lambda }\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq13.gif), where the sum is over the partitions of k. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert \\mathbf{f}{\\vert }^{2} =\\sum _{ \\lambda }\\vert c_{\\lambda }{\\vert }^{2},\\qquad \\vert {\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{f}\){\\vert }^{2} =\\sum _{ l\(\\lambda \)\\leqslant n}\\vert c_{\\lambda }{\\vert }^{2}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Proof.

The s λ are orthonormal by Schur orthogonality, so ![
$$\\vert \\mathbf{f}{\\vert }^{2} =\\sum \\vert c_{\\lambda }{\\vert }^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq14.gif). By Theorem 36.2, ![
$${\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq15.gif) are distinct irreducible characters when λ runs through the partitions of k with length ⩽ n, while, by Proposition 36.5, Ch(n)(s λ) = 0 if l(λ) > n. Therefore, we may write

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{f}\) =\\sum _{ l\(\\lambda \)\\leqslant n}c_{\\lambda }\\,{\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{s}_{ \\lambda }\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equb.gif)

and the ![
$${\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq16.gif) in this decomposition are orthonormal by Schur orthogonality on U(n). Thus, ![
$$\\vert {\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{f}\){\\vert }^{2} =\\sum _{l\(\\lambda \)\\leqslant n}\\vert c_{\\lambda }{\\vert }^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq17.gif). □

Theorem 39.1.

The map Ch(n) is a contraction if n < k and an isometry if n ≥ k. In other words, if f is a class function on S k ,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert {\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{f}\)\\vert \\leqslant \\vert \\mathbf{f}\\vert }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equc.gif)

with equality when n ≥ k.

Proof.

This follows immediately from Proposition 39.1 since if n ≥ k every partition of k has length ⩽ n. □

Theorem 39.1 is a powerful tool for transferring computations from one group to another, in this case from the unitary group to the symmetric group. The underlying principle is that of a correspondence introduced in the last chapter. This is not unlike Proposition 38.4, where we showed how correspondences may be used to transfer a branching rule from one pair of groups to another.

We will illustrate Theorem 39.1 with a striking result of Diaconis and Shahshahani [42], who showed by this method that the traces of large random unitary matrices are normally distributed. We will give a second example of using a correspondence to transfer a calculation from one group to another below in the theorem of Keating and Snaith, were we will employ GL n ×GL m duality in a similar way.

A measure is called a probability measure if its total volume is 1. Suppose that X and Y are topological spaces and that X is endowed with a Borel probability measure dμ X . Let ![
$$f: X\\longrightarrow Y$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq18.gif) be a continuous function. We can push the measure dμ X forward to probability measure dμ Y on Y, defined by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{Y }\\phi \(y\)\\,d\\mu _{Y }\(y\) =\\int _{X}\\phi \\big\(f\(x\)\\big\)\\,d\\mu _{X}\(x\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equd.gif)

for measurable functions on Y. Concretely, this measure gives the distribution of the values f(x) when x ∈ X is a random variable.

For example, the trace of a Haar random unitary matrix g ∈U(n) is distributed with a measure dμ n on ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq19.gif) satisfying

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\phi \\big\(\\mathrm{tr}\(g\)\\big\)\\,dg =\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\phi \(z\)\\ d\\mu _{n}\(z\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(39.1)

We say that a sequence ν n of Borel probability measures on a space X converges weakly to a measure ν if ![
$$\\int _{X}\\phi \(x\)\\,d\\nu _{n}\(x\)\\longrightarrow \\int _{X}\\phi \(x\)\\,d\\nu \(x\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq20.gif) for all bounded continuous functions θ on X. We will see that the measures μ n converge weakly as ![
$$n\\mathop{\\longrightarrow }\\limits \\infty $$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq21.gif) to a fixed Gaussian measure

![
$$\\displaystyle{ d\\mu \(z\) = \\frac{1} {\\pi }{e}^{-\({x}^{2}+{y}^{2}\) }\\,dx \\wedge dy,\\qquad z = x + iy. }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(39.2)

Let us consider how surprising this is! As n varies, the number of eigenvalues increases and one might expect the standard deviation of the traces to increase with n. This is what would happen were the eigenvalues of a random symmetric matrix uncorrelated. That it converges to a fixed Gaussian measure means that the eigenvalues of a random unitary matrix are quite evenly distributed around the circle.

Intuitively, the eigenvalues "repel" and tend not to lie too close together. This is reflected in the property of the trace—that its distribution does not spread out as n is increased. This can be regarded as a reflection of (17.3). Because of the factor ![
$$\\vert t_{i} - t_{j}{\\vert }^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq22.gif), matrices with close eigenvalues have small Haar measure in U(n). Dyson [48] gave the following analogy. Consider the eigenvalues of a Haar random matrix distributed on the unit circle to be like the distribution of charged particles in a Coulomb gas. At a certain temperature (![
$$T = \\frac{1} {2}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq23.gif)), this model gives the right distribution. The exercises introduce Dyson's "pair correlation" function that quantifies the tendency of the eigenvalues to repel at close ranges. Figure 39.1 shows the probability density

![
$$\\displaystyle{ R_{2}\(1,\\theta \) = {n}^{2} -\\frac{{\\sin }^{2}\(n\\theta /2\)} {{\\sin }^{2}\(\\theta /2\)} }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(39.3)

that there are eigenvalues at both e it and e i(t+θ) as a function of θ (for n = 10). (Consult the exercises for the definition of R m and a proof that R 2 is given by (39.3).) We can see from this figure that the probability is small when θ is small, but is essentially independent of θ if θ is moderate.

Fig. 39.1

The pair correlation R 2(1,θ) when n = 10

Weak convergence requires that for any continuous bounded function ϕ

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\lim _{n\\longrightarrow \\infty }\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\phi \(z\)\\,d\\mu _{n}\(z\) =\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\phi \(z\)\\,d\\mu \(z\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Eque.gif)

or in other words

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\lim _{n\\longrightarrow \\infty }\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\phi \\big\(\\mathrm{tr}\(g\)\\big\)\\,dg =\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\phi \(x + iy\)\\,d\\mu \(z\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(39.4)

Remarkably, if ϕ(z) is a polynomial in z and ![
$$\\overline{z}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq24.gif), this identity is exactly true for sufficiently large n, depending only on the degree of the polynomial! Of course, a polynomial is not a bounded continuous function, but we will deduce weak convergence from this fact about polynomial functions.

Proposition 39.2.

Let k,l ≥ 0. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\mathrm{tr}{\(g\)}^{k}\\,\\overline{\\mathrm{tr}{\(g\)}^{l}}\\,dg = 0\\quad \\mbox{ if $k\\neq l$,}}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equf.gif)

while

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\vert \\mathrm{tr}\(g\){\\vert }^{2k}\\,dg \\leqslant k!\\;,}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equg.gif)

with equality when n ≥ k.

Proof.

If k ≠ l, then the variable change ![
$$g\\longrightarrow {e}^{i\\theta }g$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq25.gif) multiplies the left-hand side by e i(k−l)θ ≠1 for θ in general position, so the integral vanishes.

Assume that k = l. We show that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\vert \\mathrm{tr}\(g\){\\vert }^{2k}\\,dg = k! }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(39.5)

provided k ⩽ n. Note that if ![
$$V = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) is the standard module for U(n), then tr(g) k is the trace of g acting on ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) as in (36.​4). As in (34.​6), we may decompose

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\bigotimes }^{k}V =\\bigoplus _{ \\lambda }d_{\\lambda }V _{\\lambda },}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equh.gif)

where d λ is the degree of the irreducible representation of S k with character s λ, and V λ is an irreducible module of U(n) by Theorem 36.2. The L 2-norm of f(g) = tr(g) k can be computed by Proposition 39.1, and we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\vert \\mathrm{tr}\(g\){\\vert }^{2k}dg = \\vert f{\\vert }^{2} =\\sum _{ \\lambda }d_{\\lambda }^{2}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Of course, the sum of the squares of the degrees of the irreducible representations of S k is |S k | = k!, and (39.5) is proved. If k > n, then the same method can be used to evaluate the trace, and we obtain ![
$$\\sum _{\\lambda }d_{\\lambda }^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq28123.gif), where now the sum is restricted to partitions of length ⩽ n. This is < k!. □

Theorem 39.2.

Suppose that ϕ(z) is a polynomial in z and ![
$$\\overline{z}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) of degree ⩽ 2n. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\phi \\big\(\\mathrm{tr}\(g\)\\big\)\\,dg =\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\phi \(z\)\\,d\\mu \(z\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(39.6)

where dμ is the measure (39.2) .

Proof.

It is sufficient to prove this if ![
$$\\phi \(z\) = {z}^{k}{\\overline{z}}^{l}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq30123.gif). If deg(ϕ) ⩽ 2n, then k \+ l ⩽ 2n so either k ≠ l or both k,l ⩽ n, and in either case Proposition 39.2 implies that the left-hand side equals 0 if k ≠ l and k! if k = l. What we must therefore show is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}{z}^{k}\\,{\\overline{z}}^{l}\\,d\\mu \(z\) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} k!&\\mbox{ if $k = l$,} \\\\ 0 &\\mbox{ if $k\\neq l$}. \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equj.gif)

The measure dμ(z) is rotationally symmetric, and if k ≠ l, then replacing z by e i θ z multiplies the left-hand side by e i θ(k−l), so the integral is zero in that case. Assume therefore that ϕ(x \+ iy) = |z|2k . Then using polar coordinates (so z = x \+ iy = re i θ ) the integral equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\vert z{\\vert }^{2k}d\\mu \(z\) = \\tfrac{1} {\\pi }\\int _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }\\int _{ -\\infty }^{\\infty }{\({x}^{2} + {y}^{2}\)}^{k}{e}^{-\({x}^{2}+{y}^{2}\) }\\,dx\\,dy =}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equk.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\tfrac{1} {\\pi }\\int _{0}^{2\\pi }\\int _{ 0}^{\\infty }{r}^{2k}\\,{e}^{-2r}\\,r\\,dr\\,d\\theta = 2\\int _{ 0}^{\\infty }{r}^{2k+1}\\,{e}^{-2r}\\,dr =\\varGamma \(k + 1\) = k!}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equl.gif)

and the theorem is proved. □

This establishes (39.4) when ϕ is a polynomial—indeed the sequence becomes stationary for large n. However, it does not establish weak convergence. To this end, we will study the Fourier transforms of the measures μ n and μ.

The Fourier transform of a probability measure ν on ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{N}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq3123.gif) is called its characteristic function. Concretely,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\hat{\\nu }\(y_{1},\\ldots,y_{N}\) =\\int _{{\\mathbb{R}}^{N}}{e}^{i\(x_{1}y_{1}+\\cdots +x_{N}y_{N}\)}d\\nu \(x\),\\qquad x = \(x_{ 1},\\ldots,x_{N}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equm.gif)

Theorem 39.3.

Let ![
$$\\nu _{1},\\nu _{2},\\nu _{3},\\ldots$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) and ν be probability measures on ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{N}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq33132.gif) . Suppose that the characteristic functions ![
$$\\widehat{\\nu _{i}}\(y_{1},\\ldots,y_{N}\)\\longrightarrow \\hat{\\nu }\(y_{1},\\ldots,y_{N}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq34132.gif) pointwise for all ![
$$\(y_{1},\\ldots,y_{N}\) \\in {\\mathbb{R}}^{N}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq35.gif) . Then the measures ν i converge weakly to ν.

Proof omitted.

A proof may be found in Billingsley [18], Theorem 26.3 (when N = 1) and Sect. 28 (for general N). The precise statement we need is on p. 383 before Theorem 29.4.□

In the case at hand, we wish to compare probability measures on ![
$$\\mathbb{C} = {\\mathbb{R}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq36.gif), and it will be most convenient to define the Fourier transform as a function of ![
$$w = u + iv \\in \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq37.gif). Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\hat{\\mu }\(w\) =\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}{e}^{i\(zw+\\overline{zw}\)}d\\mu \(z\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equn.gif)

and similarly for the ![
$$\\hat{\\mu }_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq38.gif).

Proposition 39.3.

The functions ![
$$\\hat{\\mu }_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq39.gif) converge uniformly on compact subsets of ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq40.gif) to ![
$$\\hat{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq41.gif) .

Proof.

The function ![
$$\\hat{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq42.gif) is easily computed. As the Fourier transform of a Gaussian distribution, ![
$$\\hat{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq43.gif) is also Gaussian and in fact ![
$$\\hat{\\mu }\(w\) = {e}^{-\\vert w{\\vert }^{2} }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq44.gif). We write this as a power series:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\hat{\\mu }\(w\) = F\(\\vert w\\vert \),\\qquad F\(r\) =\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }\\frac{1} {k!}{\(-1\)}^{k}{r}^{2k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equo.gif)

The radius of convergence of this power series is ∞.

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\hat{\\mu }_{n}\(w\)& =& \\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\left \[\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }\\sum _{ l=0}^{\\infty }\\frac{{i}^{k+l}{z}^{k}\\,{w}^{k}\\,{\\overline{z}}^{l}\\,{\\overline{w}}^{l}} {k!\\,l!} \\right \]d\\mu _{n}\(z\) {}\\\\ & =& \\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }\\sum _{ l=0}^{\\infty }\\frac{{i}^{k+l}} {k!\\,l!} \\left \[\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\,{z}^{k}\\,{\\overline{z}}^{l}\\,d\\mu _{ n}\(z\)\\right \]{w}^{k}\\,{\\overline{w}}^{l}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

The interchange of the summation and the integration is justified since the measure dμ n is compactly supported, and the series is uniformly convergent when z is restricted to a compact set. By Proposition 39.2 and the definition (39.1) of μ n , the integral inside brackets vanishes unless k = l, so

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\hat{\\mu }_{n}\(w\)& =& F_{n}\(\\vert w\\vert \),\\qquad F_{n}\(r\) =\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }a_{ k,n}\\frac{{\(-1\)}^{k}} {k!} {r}^{2k}, {}\\\\ a_{k,n}& =& \\frac{1} {k!}\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\vert z{\\vert }^{2k}d\\mu _{ n}\(z\). {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

By Proposition 39.2 the coefficients a k,n satisfy ![
$$0 \\leqslant a_{k,n} \\leqslant 1$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq45.gif) with equality when k > n. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert F\(r\) - F_{n}\(r\)\\vert = \\left \\vert \\sum _{k=n}^{\\infty }\(1 - a_{ k,n}\)\\frac{{\(-1\)}^{k}} {k!} {r}^{2k}\\right \\vert \\leqslant \\sum _{ k=n}^{\\infty }\\frac{{r}^{2k}} {k!},}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equp.gif)

which converges to 0 uniformly as ![
$$n\\longrightarrow \\infty $$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq46.gif) when r is restricted to a compact set. □

Corollary 39.1.

The measures μ n converge weakly to μ.

Proof.

This follows immediately from the criterion of Theorem 39.3. □

Since we have not proved Theorem 39.3, let us point out that we can immediately prove (39.4) for a fairly big set of test functions ϕ. For example, if ϕ is the Fourier transform of an integrable function ψ with compact support, we can write

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\phi \\big\(\\mathrm{tr}\(g\)\\big\)\\,dg =\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\phi \(z\)\\,d\\mu _{n}\(z\) =\\int _{\\mathbb{C}}\\psi \(w\)\\,\\hat{\\mu }_{n}\(w\)\\,du \\wedge dv,w = u + iv,}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equq.gif)

by the Plancherel formula and, since we have proved that ![
$$\\hat{\\mu }_{n}\\longrightarrow \\mu $$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq47.gif) uniformly on compact sets (39.4) is clear for such ϕ.

Diaconis and Shahshahani [42] proved a much stronger statement to the effect that the quantities

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{tr}\(g\),\\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{2}\),\\ldots,\\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{r}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equr.gif)

where g is a Haar random element of U(n), are distributed like the moments of r independent Gaussian random variables. Strikingly, what the proof requires is the full representation theory of the symmetric group in the form of Theorem 37.1!

Proposition 39.4.

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\vert \\mathrm{tr}\(g\){\\vert }^{2k_{1} }\\ \\vert \\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{2}\){\\vert }^{2k_{2} }\\cdots \\vert \\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{r}\){\\vert }^{2k_{r} }\\ dg \\leqslant \\prod _{j=1}^{r}{j}^{k_{j} }\\ k_{j}! }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

(39.7)

with equality provided k 1 \+ 2k 2 \+ ⋯ + rk r ⩽ n.

Proof.

Let ![
$$k = k_{1} + 2k_{2} + \\cdots + rk_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq48.gif), and let λ be the partition of k containing k 1 entries equal to 1, k 2 entries equal to 2, and so forth. By Theorem 37.1, we have ![
$${\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\) = \\psi _{p_{\\lambda }}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq49.gif). This is the function

![
$$\\displaystyle{g\\mapsto \\mathrm{tr}{\(g\)}^{k_{1} }\\mathrm{tr}{\({g}^{2}\)}^{k_{2} }\\cdots \\mathrm{tr}{\({g}^{r}\)}^{k_{r} }}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equs.gif)

since ![
$$p_{\\lambda } = p_{\\lambda _{1}}\\cdots p_{\\lambda _{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq50.gif), and applying ![
$$p_{\\lambda _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq51.gif) to the eigenvalues of g gives ![
$$\\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{\\lambda _{i}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq52.gif).

The left-hand side of (39.7) is thus the L 2 norm of Ch(n), and if k ⩽ n, then by Theorem 39.1 we may compute this L 2 norm in S k . It equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{1} {\\vert S_{k}\\vert }\\sum _{\\sigma \\in S_{k}}\\vert \\mathbf{p}_{\\lambda }\(\\sigma \){\\vert }^{2} = z_{ \\lambda }}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equt.gif)

by (37.​2). This is the right-hand side of (39.7). If k > n, the proof is identical except that Theorem 39.1 only gives an inequality in (39.7). □

Theorem 39.4.

(Diaconis and Shahshahani) The joint probability distribution of the ![
$$\\big\(\\mathrm{tr}\(g\),\\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{2}\),\\ldots,\\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{r}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq53.gif) near ![
$$\(z_{1},\\ldots,z_{r}\) \\in {\\mathbb{C}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq54.gif) is a measure weakly converging to

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\prod _{j=1}^{r}\\frac{1} {j}\\pi {e}^{-\\pi \\vert z_{j}{\\vert }^{2}/j }\\ dx_{j} \\wedge dy_{j}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(39.8)

By an ensemble we mean a topological space with elements that are matrices, given a probability measure. Random matrix theory is concerned with the statistical distribution of the eigenvalues of the matrices in the ensemble, particularly local statistical facts such as the spacing of these eigenvalues.

The original focus of random matrix theory was not on unitary matrices but on random Hermitian matrices. The reason for this had to do with the origin of the theory in nuclear physics. In quantum mechanics, an observable quantity such as energy or angular momentum is associated with a Hermitian operator acting on a Hilbert space with elements that correspond to possible states of a physical system. An eigenvector corresponds to a state in which the observable has a definite value, which equals the eigenvalue of the operator on that eigenvector. The Hermitian operator corresponding to the energy level of the physical system (a typical observable) is called the Hamiltonian. A Hamiltonian operator is typically positive definite.

It was observed by Wigner and his collaborators that although the spectra of atomic nuclei (emitting or absorbing neutrons) were hopeless to calculate from first principles, the spacing of the eigenvalues still obeyed statistical laws that could be studied. To this end, random Hermitian operators were studied, first by Wigner, Gaudin, Mehta, and Dyson. The book of Mehta [128] is the standard treatise on the subject from the point of view taken by this physics-inspired literature. The papers of Dyson [49] also greatly repay study. The more recent books of Anderson, Guionnet, and Zeitouni [7], Deift [40], Katz and Sarnak [95] and the handbook [4] are all strongly recommended.

Although the Hilbert space on which the Hermitian operator corresponding to an observable acts is infinite-dimensional, one may truncate the operator, replacing the Hilbert space with a finite-dimensional invariant subspace. The operator is then realized as a Hermitian matrix.

To study the local properties of the eigenvalues, one seeks to give the real vector space of Hermitian matrices a probability measure which is invariant under the action of the unitary group by conjugation, since one is interested in the eigenvalues, and these are preserved under conjugation. The usual way is to assume that the matrix entries are independent random variables with normal (i.e., Gaussian) distributions. This probability space is called the Gaussian unitary ensemble (GUE). Two other ensembles model physical systems with time reversal symmetry. For these, the type of symmetry depends on whether reversing the direction of time multiplies the operator by ± 1. The ensemble that models systems with a Hamilton that is unchanged under time-reversal consists of real symmetric matrices and is called the Gaussian orthogonal ensemble (GOE). The ensemble modeling systems with a Hamiltonian that is antisymmetric under time-reversal can be represented by quaternionic Hermitian matrices and is called the Gaussian symplectic ensemble (GSE). See Dyson [48] and Mehta [128] for further information about this point.

The space of positive definite Hermitian matrices is an open subset of the space of all Hermitian matrices, and this space is isomorphic to the Type IV symmetric space ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)/\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq56.gif), under the map which associates with the coset g U(n) in the symmetric space the Hermitian matrix ![
$${g\\,}^{t}\\bar{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq57.gif). Similarly the positive-definite parts of the GOE and GSE are ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)/\\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq58.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{H}\)/\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq59.gif) with associated probability measures.

Dyson [48] shifted focus from the Gaussian ensembles to the circular ensembles that are the compact duals of the symmetric spaces ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)/\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq60.gif), ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)/\\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq61.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{H}\)/\\mathrm{Sp}\(2n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq62.gif). For example, by Theorem 28.2, the dual of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)/\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq63.gif) is just U(n). Haar measure makes this symmetric space into the circular unitary ensemble (CUE). The ensemble is called circular because the eigenvalues of a unitary matrix lie on the unit circle instead of the real line. It is the CUE that we have studied in this chapter. Note that in the GUE, we cannot use Haar measure to make ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)/\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq64.gif) into a measure space, since we want a probability measure on each ensemble, but the noncompact group ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq65.gif) has infinite volume. This is an important advantage of the CUE over the GUE. And as Dyson observed, as far as the local statistics of random matrices are concerned—for examples, with matters of spacing of eigenvalues—the circular ensembles are faithful mirrors of the Gaussian ones. The circular orthogonal and symplectic ensembles (COE and CSE) are similarly the measure spaces U(n)∕O(n) and U(2n)∕Sp(2n) with their unique invariant probability measures.

In recent years, random matrix theory has found a new application in the study of the zeros of the Riemann zeta function and similar arithmetic data. The observation that the distribution of the zeros of the Riemann zeta function should have a local distribution similar to that of the eigenvalues of a random Hermitian matrix in the GUE originated in a conversation between Dyson and Montgomery, and was confirmed numerically by Odlyzko and others; see Rubinstein [139]. See Katz and Sarnak [94] and Conrey [38] for surveys of this field, Keating and Snaith [99] for a typical paper from the extensive literature. The paper of Keating and Snaith is important because it marked a paradigm shift away from the study of the spacing of the zeros of ζ(s) to the distribution of the values of ![
$$\\zeta \(\\frac{1} {2} + it\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq66.gif), which are, in the new paradigm, related to the values of the characteristic polynomial of a random matrix.

Theorem 39.5.

(Keating and Snaith) Let k be a nonnegative integer. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\vert \\det \(g - I\){\\vert }^{2k}\\,dg =\\prod _{ j=0}^{n-1}\\frac{j!\(j + 2k\)!} {\(j + k\){!}^{2}} }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(39.9)

This was proved by Keating and Snaith using the Selberg integral. However an alternative proof was found by Alex Gamburd (see Bump and Gamburd [29]) which we will give here. This proof is similar to that of Theorem 39.4 in that we will transfer the computation from U(n) to another group. Whereas in Theorem 39.4 we used the Frobenius–Schur duality to transfer the computation to the symmetric group S k , here we will use the Cauchy identity to transfer the computation from U(n) to U(2k). The two procedures are extremely analogous and closely related to each other.

Proof.

Let t 1,...,t k and u 1,...,u k be complex numbers. We will show that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\prod _{i=1}^{k}\(1 + t_{ i}\\det \(g\)\)\(u_{i} +\\det {\(g\)}^{-1}\)\\,dg = s_{ \({n}^{k}\)}\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{k},u_{1},\\ldots,u_{k}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

(39.10)

Here (n k ) = (n,...,n,0,...,0) is the partition with k nonzero parts, each equal to n. Taking t i = u i = 1 gives ![
$$\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\vert 1 +\\det \(g\){\\vert }^{2k}\\,dg$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq67.gif), because |det(g)| = 1 so ![
$$\\det {\(g\)}^{-1} = \\overline{\\det \(g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq68.gif). This equals the left-hand side of (39.9) because if g is a unitary matrix so is − g. Now ![
$$s_{\({n}^{k}\)}\(1,\\ldots,1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq69.gif) with 2k entries equal to 1 is the dimension of an irreducible representation of U (2k), which may be evaluated using the Weyl dimension formula (Theorem 22.10). We leave it to the reader to check that this dimension equals the right-hand side of (39.9).

Thus, consider the left-hand side of (39.10). If the eigenvalues of g are α1,...,α n , by the dual Cauchy identity the integrand equals

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & \\prod _{i=1}^{k}\\prod _{ j=1}^{n}\(1 + t_{ i}\\alpha _{j}\)\(1 + u_{i}\\alpha _{j}\)\\det {\(g\)}^{-k} {}\\\\ & & \\quad =\\sum _{\\lambda }s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)\\,s_{{\\lambda }^{t}}\(t_{1},\\ldots,t_{n},u_{1},\\ldots,u_{n}\)\\,{\\overline{\\det \(g\)}}^{k}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_Equ13.gif)

Now each ![
$$s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq70.gif) is the character of an irreducible representation of U(n) if it is nonzero, that is, if the length of λ is ⩽ n. In particular ![
$$\\det {\(g\)}^{n} = s_{\({k}^{n}\)}\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_39_Chapter_IEq71.gif). So by Schur orthogonality, integrating over g picks off the contribution of a single term, with λ = (k n ) and λ t = (n k ). This proves (39.10). □

# 40. Symmetric Group Branching Rules and Tableaux

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

If ![
$$G \\supset H$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq1.gif) are groups, a branching rule is an explicit description of how representations of G decompose into irreducibles when restricted to H. By Frobenius reciprocity, this is equivalent to asking how representations of H decompose into irreducibles on induction to G. In this chapter, we will obtain the branching rule for the symmetric groups.

If ![
$$G \\supset H$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq2.gif) are groups, a branching rule is an explicit description of how representations of G decompose into irreducibles when restricted to H. By Frobenius reciprocity, this is equivalent to asking how representations of H decompose into irreducibles on induction to G. In this chapter, we will obtain the branching rule for the symmetric groups.

Suppose that λ is a partition of k and that μ is a partition of l with ![
$$k \\leqslant l$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq3.gif). We write ![
$$\\lambda \\subseteq \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq4.gif) or ![
$$\\lambda \\supseteq \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq5.gif) if the Young diagram of ![
$$\\lambda$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq6.gif) is contained in the Young diagram of μ. Concretely this means that ![
$$\\lambda _{i} \\leqslant \\mu _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq7.gif) for all i. If ![
$$\\lambda \\neq \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq8.gif), we write ![
$$\\lambda \\subset \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq9.gif) or ![
$$\\mu \\supset \\lambda$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq10.gif).

We will denote by ![
$$\\rho _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq11.gif) the irreducible representation of S k parametrized by ![
$$\\lambda$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq12.gif). We follow the notation of the last chapter in regarding elements of ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq13.gif) as generalized characters of S k . Thus, ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq14.gif) is the character of the representation ![
$$\\rho _{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq15.gif).

Proposition 40.1.

Let λ be a partition of k, and let μ be a partition of k − 1. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda },\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\\mathbf{e}_{1}\\right \\rangle = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} 1&{ if \\lambda \\supset \\mu,}\\\\ 0 &{otherwise.} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Proof.

Applying ![
$$\\mathrm{ch}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq16.gif), it is sufficient to show that

![
$$\\displaystyle{e_{1}s_{\\mu } =\\sum _{\\lambda \\supset \\mu }s_{\\lambda }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equb.gif)

We work in Λ (n) for any sufficiently large n; of course n = k is sufficient. Let Δ denote the denominator in (36.​1), and let

![
$$\\displaystyle{ M = \\left \\vert \\begin{array}{cccc} x_{1}^{\\mu _{n}} & x_{2}^{\\mu _{n}} & \\cdots & x_{n}^{\\mu _{n}} \\\\ x_{1}^{\\mu _{n-1}+1} & x_{2}^{\\mu _{n-1}+1} & \\cdots & x_{n}^{\\mu _{n-1}+1}\\\\ \\vdots & \\vdots & & \\vdots \\\\ x_{1}^{\\mu _{1}+n-1} & x_{2}^{\\mu _{1}+n-1} & \\cdots &x_{n}^{\\mu _{1}+n-1} \\end{array} \\right \\vert. }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(40.1)

By (36.​1), we have ![
$$s_{\\mu } = M/\\varDelta$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq17.gif) and ![
$$e_{1} =\\sum x_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq18.gif), so

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\varDelta e_{1}s_{\\mu } =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}x_{ i}M =\\sum _{ i=1}^{n}\\left \\vert \\begin{array}{ccccc} x_{1}^{\\mu _{n}} & \\cdots & x_{i}^{\\mu _{n}+1} & \\cdots & x_{n}^{\\mu _{n}} \\\\ \\vdots & & \\vdots & & \\vdots \\\\ x_{1}^{\\mu _{n-j}+j} &\\cdots &x_{i}^{\\mu _{n-j}+j+1} & \\cdots & x_{n}^{\\mu _{n-j}+j}\\\\ \\vdots & & \\vdots & & \\vdots \\\\ x_{1}^{\\mu _{1}+n-1} & \\cdots & x_{i}^{\\mu _{1}+n} &\\cdots &x_{n}^{\\mu _{1}+n-1} \\end{array} \\right \\vert. }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(40.2)

We claim that this equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sum _{j=1}^{n}\\left \\vert \\begin{array}{ccccc} x_{1}^{\\mu _{n}} & \\cdots & x_{i}^{\\mu _{n}} & \\cdots & x_{n}^{\\mu _{n}} \\\\ \\vdots & & \\vdots & & \\vdots \\\\ x_{1}^{\\mu _{n-j}+j+1} & \\cdots &x_{i}^{\\mu _{n-j}+j+1} & \\cdots &x_{n}^{\\mu _{n-j}+j+1}\\\\ \\vdots & & \\vdots & & \\vdots \\\\ x_{1}^{\\mu _{1}+n-1} & \\cdots & x_{i}^{\\mu _{1}+n-1} & \\cdots & x_{n}^{\\mu _{1}+n-1} \\end{array} \\right \\vert. }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(40.3)

In (40.2), we have increased the exponent in exactly one column of M by one and then summed over columns; in (40.3), we have increased the exponent in exactly one row of M by one and then summed over rows. In either case, expanding the determinants and summing over i or j gives the result of first expanding M and then in each resulting monomial increasing the exponent of exactly one x i by one. These are the same set of terms, so (40.2) and (40.3) are equal.

In (40.3), not all terms may be nonzero. Two consecutive rows will be the same if ![
$$\\mu _{n-j} + j + 1 = \\mu _{n-j+1} + j + 1$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq19.gif), that is, if ![
$$\\mu _{n-j} = \\mu _{n-j+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq20.gif). In this case, the determinant is zero. Discarding these terms, (40.3) is the sum of all s λ as λ runs through those partitions of k that contain μ. □

Theorem 40.1.

Let λ be a partition of k and let μ be a partition of k − 1. The following are equivalent.

(i)

The representation ρ λ occurs in the representation of S k induced from the representation S μ of ![
$$S_{k-1} \\subset S_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq21.gif) ; in this case it occurs with multiplicity one.

(ii)

The representation ρ μ occurs in the representation of S k restricted from the representation S λ of ![
$$S_{k} \\supset S_{k-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq22.gif) ; in this case it occurs with multiplicity one.

(iii)

The partition ![
$$\\mu \\subset \\lambda$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq23.gif) .

Proof.

Statements (i) and (ii) are equivalent by Frobenius reciprocity. Noting that S 1 is the trivial group, we have ![
$$S_{k-1} = S_{k-1} \\times S_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq24.gif). By definition, ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\\mathbf{e}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq25.gif) is the character of S k induced from the character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu } \\otimes \\mathbf{e}_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) of S k−1 × S 1. With this in mind, this theorem is just a paraphrase of Proposition 40.1. □

A representation is multiplicity-free if in its decomposition into irreducibles, no irreducible occurs with multiplicity greater than 1.

Corollary 40.1.

If ρ is an irreducible representation of S k−1 , then the representation of S k induced from ρ is multiplicity-free; and if τ is an irreducible representation of S k then the representation of S k−1 restricted from τ is multiplicity-free.

Proof.

This is an immediate consequence of the theorem. □

Let λ be a partition of k. By a standard (Young) tableau of shape λ, we mean a labeling of the diagram of λ by the integers 1 through k in such a way that entries increase in each row and column. As we explained earlier, we represent the diagram of a partition by a series of boxes. This is more convenient than a set of dots since we can then represent a tableau by putting numbers in the boxes to indicate the labeling.

For example, the standard tableaux of shape (3,2) are:

The following theorem makes use of the following chain of groups:

![
$$\\displaystyle{S_{k} \\supset S_{k-1} \\supset \\cdots \\supset S_{1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equc.gif)

These have the remarkable property that the restriction of each irreducible representation of S i to S i−1 is multiplicity-free and the branching rule is explicitly known. Although this is a rare phenomenon, there are a couple of other important cases:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{U}\(n\) \\supset \\mathrm{U}\(n - 1\) \\supset \\cdots \\supset \\mathrm{U}\(1\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equd.gif)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{O}\(n\) \\supset \\mathrm{O}\(n - 1\) \\supset \\cdots \\supset \\mathrm{O}\(2\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Eque.gif)

Theorem 40.2.

If λ is a partition of k, the degree of the irreducible representation ρ λ of S k associated with λ is equal to the number of standard tableaux of shape λ.

Proof.

Removing the top box (labeled k) from a tableau of shape λ results in another tableau, of shape μ (say), where μ ⊂ λ. Thus, the set of tableaux of shape λ is in bijection with the set of tableaux of shape μ, where μ runs through the partitions of k − 1 contained in λ.

The restriction of ρ λ to S k−1 is the direct sum of the irreducible representations ρ μ , where μ runs through the partitions of k − 1 contained in λ, and by induction the degree of each such ρ μ equals the number of tableaux of shape μ. The result follows. □

Tableaux are an important topic in combinatorics. Fulton [53] and Stanley [153] have extensive discussions of tableaux, and there is a very good discussion of standard tableaux in Knuth [109].

A famous formula, due to Frame, Robinson, and Thrall, for the number of tableaux of shape λ—that is, the degree of ρ λ—is the hook length formula. There are many proofs in the literature. For a variety of proofs see Fulton [53], Knuth [109], Macdonald [124], Manivel [126], Sagan [141] (with anecdote), and Stanley [153]. The hook length formula is equivalent to an older formula of Frobenius and (independently) Young, which is treated in Exercise 40.4.

For each box B in the diagram of λ, the hook at B consists of B, all boxes to the right and below. The hook length is the length of the hook. For example, Fig. 40.1 shows a hook for the partition λ = (5,5,4,3,3) of 20. This hook has length 5.

Theorem 40.3. (Hook length formula)

Let λ be a partition of k. The number of standard tableaux of shape λ equals k! divided by the product of the lengths of the hooks.

For the example, we have indicated the lengths of the hooks in Fig. 40.1. By the hook length formula, we see that the number of tableaux of shape λ is

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{20!} {9 \\cdot 8 \\cdot 7 \\cdot 4 \\cdot 2 \\cdot 8 \\cdot 7 \\cdot 6 \\cdot 3 \\cdot 1 \\cdot 6 \\cdot 5 \\cdot 4 \\cdot 1 \\cdot 4 \\cdot 3 \\cdot 2 \\cdot 3 \\cdot 2 \\cdot 1} = 34,641,750,}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equf.gif)

and this is the degree of the irreducible representation ρ λ of S 20.

Proof.

See Exercise 40.5. □

Fig. 40.1

The hook length formula for λ = (5,5,4,3,3)

Proposition 40.1 is a special case of Pieri's formula, which we explain and prove. First, we give a bit of background on the Littlewood–Richardson rule, of which Pieri's formula is itself a special case.

The multiplicative structure of the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}\\mathop{\\cong}\\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) is of intense interest. If λ and μ are partitions of r and k, respectively, then we can decompose

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu } =\\sum _{\\lambda }c_{\\lambda \\mu }^{\\nu }\\mathbf{s}_{ \\nu },}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equg.gif)

where the sum is over partitions ν of r \+ k. The coefficients ![
$$c_{\\lambda \\mu }^{\\nu }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) are called the Littlewood–Richardson coefficients. They are integers since the ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\nu }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) are a ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq30123.gif)-basis of the free Abelian group ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{r+k}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq31123.gif).

Applying ![
$${\\mathrm{ch}}^{\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq32123.gif), we may also write

![
$$\\displaystyle{s_{\\lambda }s_{\\mu } =\\sum _{\\lambda }c_{\\lambda \\mu }^{\\nu }s_{ \\nu }}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equh.gif)

as a decomposition of Schur polynomials, or ![
$$\\chi _{\\lambda }\\chi _{\\mu } =\\sum c_{\\lambda \\mu }^{\\nu }\\chi _{\\nu }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) in terms of the irreducible characters of U(n) parametrized by λ, μ, and ν. Using the fact that the ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) are orthonormal, we have also

![
$$\\displaystyle{c_{\\lambda \\mu }^{\\nu } = \\left \\langle \\mathbf{s}_{ \\lambda }\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu },\\mathbf{s}_{\\nu }\\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Proposition 40.2.

The coefficients ![
$$c_{\\lambda \\mu }^{\\nu }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq35.gif) are nonnegative integers.

Proof.

This is clear from any one of the characterizations in Theorem 38.3. □

Given that the Littlewood–Richardson coefficients are nonnegative integers, a natural question is to ask for a combinatorial interpretation. Can ![
$$c_{\\lambda \\mu }^{\\nu }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq36.gif) be realized as the cardinality of some set? The answer is yes, and this interpretation is known as the Littlewood–Richardson rule. We refer to Fulton [53], Stanley [153], or Macdonald [124] for a full discussion of the Littlewood–Richardson rule.

Even just to state the Littlewood–Richardson rule in full generality is slightly complex, and we will content ourselves with a particularly important special case. This is where λ = (r) or λ = (1,...,1), so ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda } = \\mathbf{h}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq37.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq38.gif). This simple and useful case of the Littlewood–Richardson rule is called Pieri's formula. We will now state and prove it.

If ![
$$\\mu \\subset \\lambda$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq39.gif) are partitions, we call the pair (μ, λ) a skew partition and denote it ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq40.gif). Its diagram is the set-theoretic difference between the diagrams of λ and μ. We call the skew partition ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq41.gif) a vertical strip if its diagram does not contain more than one box in any given row. It is called a horizontal strip if its diagram does not contain more than one box in any given column.

For example, if μ = (3, 3), then the partitions λ of 8 such that ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq42.gif) is a vertical strip are (4, 4), (4, 3, 1), and (3, 3, 1, 1). The diagrams of these skew partitions are the shaded regions in Fig. 40.2.

Theorem 40.4. (Pieri's formula)

Let μ be a partition of k, and let ![
$$r \\geq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq43.gif) . Then ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\\mathbf{e}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq44.gif) is the sum of the ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq45.gif) as λ runs through the partitions of k + r containing μ such that ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq46.gif) is a vertical strip. Also, ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\\mathbf{h}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq47.gif) is the sum of the ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq48.gif) as λ runs through the partitions of k + r such that ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq49.gif) is a horizontal strip.

Proof.

Since by Theorems 34.3 and 35.2 applying the involution ι interchanges ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq50.gif) and ![
$$\\mathbf{h}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq51.gif) and also interchanges ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq52.gif) and ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq53.gif), the second statement follows from the first, which we prove.

Fig. 40.2

Vertical strips

The proof that ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\\mathbf{e}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq54.gif) is the sum of the ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq55.gif) as λ runs through the partitions of k \+ r containing μ such that ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq56.gif) is a vertical strip is actually identical to the proof of Proposition 40.1. Choose ![
$$n \\geqslant k + r$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq57.gif) and, applying ![
$$\\mathrm{ch}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq58.gif), it is sufficient to prove the corresponding result for Schur polynomials.

With notations as in that proof, we see that ![
$$\\varDelta e_{r}s_{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq59.gif) equals the sum of ![
$$\\binom{k}{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq60.gif) terms, each of which is obtained by multiplying M, defined by (40.1), by a monomial ![
$$x_{i_{1}}\\cdots x_{i_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq61.gif), where ![
$$i_{1} <\\cdots <i_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq62.gif). Multiplying M by ![
$$x_{i_{1}}\\cdots x_{i_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq63.gif) amounts to increasing the exponent of ![
$$x_{i_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq64.gif) in the i r th column by one. Thus, we get ![
$$\\varDelta e_{r}s_{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq65.gif) if we take M, increase the exponents in r columns each by one, and then add the resulting ![
$$\\binom{k}{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq66.gif) determinants.

We claim that this gives the same result as taking M, increasing the exponents in r rows each by one, and then adding the resulting ![
$$\\binom{k}{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq67.gif) determinants. Indeed, either way, we get the result of taking each monomial occurring in the expansion of the determinant M, increasing the exponents of exactly r of the x i each by one, and adding all resulting terms.

Thus, e r s μ equals the sum of all terms (36.​1) where ![
$$\(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq68.gif) is obtained from ![
$$\(\\mu _{1},\\ldots,\\mu _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq69.gif) by increasing exactly r of the μ i by one. Some of these terms may not be partitions, in which case the determinant in the numerator of (36.​1) will be zero since it will have repeated rows. The terms that remain will be the partitions of k \+ r of length such that ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq70.gif) is a vertical strip. These partitions all have length ≤ n because we chose n large enough. Thus, e r s μ is the sum of s λ for these λ, as required. □

Exercises

The next problem generalizes Exercise 37.3. If λ and μ are partitions such that the Young diagram of λ contains that of μ, then the pair (λ,μ) is called a skew shape and is denoted ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq71.gif). Its Young diagram is the set-theoretic difference between the Young diagrams of λ and μ. The skew shape is called a ribbon shape if the diagram is connected and contains no 2 × 2 squares. For example, if λ = (5, 4, 4, 3, 2) and μ = (5, 3, 2, 2, 2) then the skew shape ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq72.gif) is a ribbon shape. Its diagram is the shaded region in the following figure.

If ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq73.gif) is a ribbon shape, we call its height, denoted ![
$$\\mathrm{ht}\(\\lambda \\setminus \\mu \)$$
](A79351_2_En_40_Chapter_IEq74.gif) one less than the number of rows involved in its Young diagram. In the example, the height is 2.

The following result is called the Murnaghan–Nakayama rule (Stanley [153]). It is the combinatorial basis of the Boson–Fermion correspondence in the theory of infinite-dimensional Lie algbras.

where the sum is over all partitions λ of k \+ r such that ![

](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq20.gif) contains π′ μ . Since algebraic representations of ![

](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq21.gif) correspond precisely to representations of its maximal compact subgroup, this is equivalent to asking for the branching rule from U(n) to U(n − 1).

This question has a simple and beautiful answer in Theorem 41.1 below. We say that the integer sequences λ = (λ1,...,λ n ) and ![
$$\\mu = \(\\mu _{1},\\ldots,\\mu _{n-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq22.gif) interlace if

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\lambda _{1} \\geqslant\\mu _{1} \\geqslant\\lambda _{2} \\geqslant\\mu _{2} \\geqslant\\cdots \\geqslant\\mu _{n-1} \\geqslant\\lambda _{n}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Proposition 41.1.

Suppose that λ n and μ n−1 are nonnegative, so the integer sequences λ and μ are partitions. Then λ and μ interlace if and only if λ ⊃ μ and the skew partition ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq23.gif) is a horizontal strip.

This is obvious if one draws a diagram.

Proof.

Assume that λ ⊃ μ and ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq24.gif) is a horizontal strip. Then λ j ≥ μ j because λ ⊃ μ. We must show that ![
$$\\mu _{j} \\geqslant\\lambda _{j+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq25.gif). If it is not, ![
$$\\lambda _{j} \\geqslant\\lambda _{j+1} > \\mu _{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq26123.gif), which implies that the diagram of ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) contains two entries in the μ j \+ 1 column, namely in the j and j \+ 1 rows, which is a contradiction since ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) was assumed to be a horizontal strip. We have proved that λ and μ interlace. The converse is similar. □

Theorem 41.1.

Let ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) and ![
$$\\mu = \(\\mu _{1},\\ldots,\\mu _{n-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq3023252.gif) be integer sequences with ![
$$\\lambda _{1} \\geqslant\\lambda _{2} \\geqslant\\cdots $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq31213.gif) and ![
$$\\mu _{1} \\geqslant\\mu _{2} \\geqslant\\cdots $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) . Then the restriction of π λ to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n - 1, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) contains a copy of π μ ′ if and only if λ and μ interlace. The restriction of π λ is multiplicity-free.

Proof.

We restriction the representation π λ of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq34113.gif) to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n-1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq35.gif) in two stages. First, we restrict it to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n-1}\(\\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}_{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq36.gif), and then we restrict it from ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n-1}\(\\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}_{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq37.gif) to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n-1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq38.gif). Here ![
$$\(g,h\) \\in \\mathrm{GL}_{n-1}\(\\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}_{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq39.gif) is embedded in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq40.gif) as in (38.​7). Every irreducible character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\) = {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq41.gif) is of the form ![
$$\\alpha \\longmapsto {\\alpha }^{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq42.gif) for some ![
$$k \\in \\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq43.gif), and we will denote this character as ![
$$\\pi^{\\prime\\prime}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq01.gif).

We may order the eigenvalues of (g,h) so that ![
$$\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq44.gif) are the eigenvalues of g, and α n is the eigenvalue of h. Since ![
$$s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq45.gif) is a homogeneous polynomial of degree |λ| = ∑λ i , and since ![
$$s_{\\mu }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n-1}\)\\alpha _{n}^{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq46.gif) is homogeneous of degree |μ| + k, ![
$$\\pi _{\\mu }^{\\prime} \\otimes \\pi ^{\\prime\\prime}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq47.gif) can occur in the restriction of π λ to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n-1}\(\\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}_{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq011.gif) if and only if k = |λ|−|μ|. In other words, the fact that Schur polynomials are homogeneous implies that the multiplicity of ![
$$\\pi^{\\prime}_{\\mu}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq48.gif) in π λ restricted to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n-1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq49.gif) equals the multiplicity of ![
$$\\pi^{\\prime}_{\\mu} \\otimes \\pi^{\\prime\\prime}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq03.gif) to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}_{n-1}\(\\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}_{1}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq50.gif) where k = |λ|−|μ|. By Theorem 38.3 this equals the Littlewood–Richardson coefficient ![
$$c_{\\mu\\nu}^{\\lambda}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq04.gif) where ν = (k), and by Pieri's formula (Theorem 40.4) this equals 1 if ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq51.gif) is a horizontal strip, 0 otherwise. By Proposition 41.1 this means that the partitions λ and μ must interlace. □

We can now give a combinatorial formula for the degree of the irreducible representation π λ of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq52.gif), where ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq53.gif) and ![
$$\\lambda _{1} \\geqslant\\cdots \\geqslant\\lambda _{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq54.gif). A Gelfand–Tsetlin pattern of degree n consists of n decreasing integer sequences of lengths n,n − 1,...,1 such that each adjacent pair interlaces. For example, if the top row is 3, 2, 1, there are eight possible Gelfand–Tsetlin patterns:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{ccccc} 3& &2& &1\\\\ &3 & &2 & \\\\ & &3& & \\end{array} \\qquad \\qquad \\begin{array}{ccccc} 3& &2& &1 \\\\ &3 & &2 & \\\\ & &2& & \\end{array} \\qquad \\qquad \\begin{array}{ccccc} 3& &2& &1 \\\\ &3 & &1 & \\\\ & &3& & \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equb.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{ccccc} 3& &2& &1\\\\ &3&&1& \\\\ & &2& & \\end{array} \\qquad \\qquad \\begin{array}{ccccc} 3& &2& &1\\\\ &3&&1& \\\\ & &1& & \\end{array} \\qquad \\qquad \\begin{array}{ccccc} 3& &2& &1\\\\ &2&&2& \\\\ & &2& & \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equc.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{ccccc} 3& &2& &1\\\\ &2&&1& \\\\ & &2& & \\end{array} \\qquad \\qquad \\begin{array}{ccccc} && &&\\\\ &&\\mathrm{and}&&\\\\ &&&&\\end{array} \\qquad \\qquad \\begin{array}{ccccc} 3& &2& &1\\\\ &2&&1& \\\\ & &1& & \\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equd.gif)

Theorem 41.2.

The degree of the irreducible representation π λ of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq55.gif) equals the number of Gelfand–Tsetlin patterns whose top row is λ.

Thus, ![
$$\\dim \\big\(\\pi _{\(3,2,1\)}\\big\) = 8$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq56.gif).

Proof.

The proof is identical in structure to Theorem 40.2. The Gelfand–Tsetlin patterns of shape λ can be counted by noting that striking the top row gives a Gelfand–Tsetlin pattern with a top row that is a partition μ of length n − 1 that interlaces with λ. By induction, the number of such patterns is equal to the dimension of ![
$$\\pi^{\\prime}_{\\mu}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq2155.gif), and the result now follows from the branching rule of Theorem 41.1. □

Just as with the symmetric group, the dimension of an irreducible representation of U(n) can be expressed as the number of tableaux of a certain type. By a semistandard Young tableau of shape λ we mean a filling of the boxes in the Young diagram of shape λ in which the columns are strictly increasing but the rows are only weakly increasing.

Proposition 41.2.

Let λ be a partition of length ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq09.gif) n. The degree of the irreducible representation π λ of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq57.gif) equals the number semistandard Young tableaux of shape λ with entries in {1,2,...,n}.

Proof.

In view of Theorem 41.2 it is sufficient to exhibit a bijection between these tableaux and the Gelfand–Tsetlin patterns with top row λ. We will explain how to go from the tableau to the Gelfand–Tsetlin pattern. Given a tableau, the top row of the Gelfand–Tsetlin pattern is the shape: of the tableau:

Removing all boxes labeled n gives a second tableau, with entries in 1, 2,..., n − 1. Its shape is the second row of the Gelfand–Tsetlin pattern:

We continue removing the boxes labeled n − 1, and the resulting shape is the third row:

Continuing in this way we obtain a Gelfand–Tsetlin pattern. We leave it to the reader to convince themselves that this is a bijection. □

The relationship between representation theory and the combinatorics of tableaux is subtle and interesting. It can be understood as just an analogy, but at a deeper level, it can be understood as a reflection of the theory of quantum groups. We start by explaining the analogy.

There is an algorithm, the Robinson–Schensted–Knuth (RSK) algorithm, which describes bijections between pairs of tableaux of the same shape (or of conjugate shapes) and various combinatorial objects. Historically, the RSK algorithm first occurred in Robinson's work on the representation theory of the symmetric group [136]. It was rediscovered in the early 1960s by Schensted [147], who was motivated the question of the longest increasing subsequence of an integer sequence, and substantially generalized by Knuth [108]. It has applications in various fields from linguistics to algebraic geometry. We will comment mainly on its connections with representation theory, so we begin by pointing out how it gives combinatorial analogs of the correspondences that we are familiar with, Frobenius–Schur duality and GL n × GL m duality. We will focus on Frobenius–Schur duality.

Let us recapitulate two facts. Let λ be a partition of k with length ![
$$ \\leqslant $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq010.gif) n.

  * Let SYT(λ) be the set of standard tableaux of shape λ having entries in {1,..., k}. Then by Proposition 40.2 the cardinality of ST(k) equals the degree of the irreducible representation ρ λ of S k corresponding to λ.

  * Let SSYT(λ, n) be the set of semistandard tableau of shape λ having entries in {1,..., n}. Then by Proposition 41.2 the cardinality of SSYT(λ, n) equals the degree of the irreducible representation ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq58.gif) with highest weight λ.

For more about the RSK algorithm, see Fulton [53], Knuth [109] Sect. 5.1.4, or Stanley [153], van Leeuwen [164] and the original papers. Our interest here in the RSK algorithm comes from the fact that it is the basis of the combinatorial side of a series of analogies between results in representation theory and combinatorics. There are three main versions of RSK, each analogous to a fact in representation theory. Briefly, the three representation-theoretic facts in question are:

  * The decomposition of ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\[S_{k}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq59.gif) under the action of S k × S k by left and right translation;

  * Frobenius–Schur duality;

  * GL(n) × GL(m) duality.

We will take these one at a time, focussing on the second.

The first version of RSK (Robinson) gives a bijection between S k and the set of pairs of standard tableaux of the same shape λ. That is, between S k and the disjoint union

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigsqcup _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}\\mathrm{SYT}\(\\lambda \) \\times \\mathrm{SYT}\(\\lambda \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Eque.gif)

So k!, the cardinality of S k , equals the number of pairs of standard tableaux of size k with the same shape. Beyond this combinatorial reason, let us observe another representation-theoretic reason that these two sets have the same cardinality. Indeed, the cardinality of any finite group equals the sum of the squares of the degrees of its irreducible representations.

The second version of RSK (Schensted) gives a bijection between the set of sequences {m 1,...,m k } with m i ∈{ 1,...,n} (called words) and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigsqcup \\limits_{\\scriptstyle {\\rm \\lambda\\,a\\,partition\\,of\\,}k \\hfill \\atop \\scriptstyle \\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,l\({\\rm \\lambda }\)\\,\\, \\leqslant \\,\\,n \\hfill}}\\mathrm{SYT}\(\\lambda \) \\times \\mathrm{SSYT}\(\\lambda ,n\).$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(41.2)

Let us again observe that these sets have the same cardinality, which we may prove using Frobenius–Schur duality in the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\otimes }^{k}{\\mathbb{C}}^{n}\\mathop{\\cong}\\bigoplus \\limits_{\\scriptstyle {\\rm \\lambda\\,a\\,partition\\,of\\,}k \\hfill \\atop \\scriptstyle \\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,l\({\\rm \\lambda }\)\\,\\, \\leqslant \\,\\,n \\hfill}}\\rho _{\\lambda }\\otimes \\pi _{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{GL}\(n\)}.$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Indeed, the dimension of the left-hand side is n k , which is the cardinality of the set of integer sequences; the right-hand side has the same cardinality as the above disjoint union. So the second RSK bijection is a combinatorial analog of Frobenius–Schur duality.

The third RSK bijection (Knuth) is between the set of n × m matrices whose entries are nonnegative integers is in bijection with

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigsqcup _{\\lambda }\\mathrm{SSYT}\(\\lambda,m\) \\times \\mathrm{SSYT}\(\\lambda,n\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equg.gif)

This may be thought of a combinatorial analog of GL n × GL m duality. In particular there is a combinatorial proof of the Cauchy identity (see Stanley [153]). Knuth also found a variant for matrices whose entries are 0 and 1 and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigsqcup _{\\lambda }\\mathrm{SSYT}\(\\lambda,m\) \\times \\mathrm{SSYT}\({\\lambda }^{t},n\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equh.gif)

where λ t is the conjugate partition. This is related to the dual Cauchy identity, and the version of GL n × GL m duality for the exterior algebra on ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n} \\times {\\mathbb{C}}^{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq60.gif).

All of these combinatorial bijections are based on one process, called Schensted insertion, which we will explain. Given a semistandard Young tableaux Q of shape λ and an integer m, there is a tableau ![
$$\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline m\\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\rightarrow Q$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq61.gif) whose shape μ is obtained from λ by adding one box (somewhere).

To compute ![
$$\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline m\\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\rightarrow Q$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq62.gif) we insert the m into the first row at its "best" location. It can go at the end if it is larger or equal to all of the entries in the row, and if this is true, the algorithm terminates. Otherwise, it will have to displace or "bump" one of the entries in the row. It displaces the first entry that its greater than it. The displaced entry is then inserted into the second row. If it is greater than or equal to all the entries in the row, then we add the entry at the end of the row and the algorithm terminates. Otherwise, we continue by inserting the bumped entry into the third row, and so forth.

Let us do an example. We will calculate ![
$$\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline 1 \\\\ \\hline \\end{array} \\longrightarrow Q$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq63.gif) where Q is the following tableau:

We've shaded the box where the inserted ![
$$\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline 1 \\\\ \\hline \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq64.gif) will go. The 1 bumps the 2 which is then inserted into the second row:

again we've shaded the location where the inserted 2 will go. The 3 that is bumped will then go in the third row. This time it will go at the end:

The algorithm therefore terminates and we see that ![
$$\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline 1 \\\\ \\hline \\end{array} \\longrightarrow Q$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq65.gif) is the tableau:

Now let us explain the second RSK algorithm mentioned above, which is the bijection of {1,..., n} k with (41.2). We begin with a sequence (m 1,..., m k ) and the empty tableau, which we will denote by ![
$$\\varnothing $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq66.gif). We insert the m i one by one, finally ending up with a tableau

![
$$\\displaystyle{Q = \\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline m_{1} \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\rightarrow \\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline m_{2} \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\rightarrow \\cdots \\rightarrow \\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline m_{k} \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\rightarrow \\varnothing }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Actually ![
$$\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline m_{k} \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} = \\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline m_{k} \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\rightarrow \\varnothing $$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq67.gif), so this is the same as ![
$$\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline m_{1} \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\rightarrow \\cdots \\rightarrow \\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline m_{k} \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\;$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq68.gif).

Clearly Q is in SSYT(λ, n) for some partition λ of k. We obtain another tableau P, called the recording tableau of the same shape which has the entries {1, 2, 3,..., k} by putting 1 in the first box that was created (necessarily the upper left-hand corner), then 2 in the second box that was created, and so forth. The recording tableau is a clearly a standard tableau. The bijection maps the sequence (m 1,..., m k ) to the pair (P, Q) in (41.2).

During the years prior to the late 1980s, one could say that tableau combinatorics and representation theory existed in parallel. The RSK algorithm existed as a combinatorial analog of the Frobenius–Schur duality correspondence (and GL n × GL m duality), but a direct connection between these topics was missing until Kashiwara described crystals as an aspect of the developing theory of quantum groups. The book [72] of Hong and Kang and the paper Kashiwara [93] are good introductions to this topic.

We will not give a complete definition of crystals here. Our goal is to describe them sufficiently well to explain their connection with the RSK algorithm. Crystals are purely combinatorial analogs of Lie group representations, but now the connection is more than an analogy: crystals are derived from Lie group representations by a process of deformation.

Let us begin with a Lie group G (say a compact Lie group or its complexification) with weight lattice Λ. Let λ ∈Λ be a dominant weight. The crystal ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq69.gif) is a combinatorial analog of the irreducible representation ![
$$\\pi^{G}_{\\lambda}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq016.gif) having highest weight λ.

The crystal ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq70.gif) is a directed graph with vertices that may be identified with some type of tableaux (at least for the classical Cartan types). Its cardinality (i.e., the number of vertices in this graph) is equal to the dimension of ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq71.gif). The edges of the graph are labeled by integer ![
$$1 \\leq i \\leq r$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq72.gif) where r is the semisimple rank, that is, the number of simple roots. There is a weight function ![
$$\\mathrm{wt}: \\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda } \\rightarrow \\varLambda$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq73.gif) such that if P and Q are vertices with an edge ![
$$P\\mathop{\\longleftarrow}\\limits^{i}Q$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq74.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{wt}\(Q\) = \\mathrm{wt}\(P\) + \\alpha _{i}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equj.gif)

If χλ is the character of ![
$$\\pi^{G}_{\\lambda}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq017.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\chi _{\\lambda } =\\sum _{P\\in \\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }}{\\mathrm{e}}^{\\mathrm{wt}\(P\)}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(41.3)

(The notation eλ is as in Chap.​ 22.)

Let us consider the case ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq75.gif). The semisimple rank r is n − 1. Assuming that the dominant weight λ is a partition, the vertices of ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq76.gif) are the semistandard Young tableaux in SSYT(λ,n), and the weight function is easy to describe: the weight of a tableau is ![
$$\\mu = \(\\mu _{1},\\ldots,\\mu _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq77.gif) where μ i is the number of boxes labeled i in the tableau. Figure 41.1 shows the crystal with n = 3 and λ = (3,1): The edges are labeled 1 or 2. These correspond to the simple roots α1 and α2.

Fig. 41.1

The crystal with highest weight λ = (3,1,0). The weight diagram (see Chap.​ 21) is supplied to the right, to orient the reader

In the case ![
$$G = GL\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq78.gif) where we have identified the vertices with tableaux, the edges have the following meaning: if there is an edge labeled i from P to Q, then Q is obtained from P by changing an entry labeled i to i \+ 1. (But if there is more than one box labeled i, deciding which is to be changed is not entirely straightforward.)

For GL(n), the weight function may be described as follows: Λ, we recall, is identified with ![
$${\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq79.gif), in which μ = (μ 1,...,μ n ) is identified with the character μ ∈Λ X ∗(T), where T is the diagonal torus and the character μ maps

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{z} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} t_{1} & & \\\\ & \\ddots & \\\\ & & t_{n} \\end{array} \\right \)\\longmapsto \\prod t_{i}^{\\mu _{i} }.}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Then if P ∈SSYT(λ,n) we define μ = wt(P) by letting μ i be the number of entries in the tableau equal to i. So (41.3) becomes the combinatorial formula for Schur polynomial:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ s_{\\lambda }\(z_{1},\\ldots,z_{n}\) =\\sum _{P}{\\mathbf{z}}^{\\mathrm{wt}\(P\)} }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(41.4)

where ![
$${\\mathbf{z}}^{\\mathrm{wt}\(P\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq80.gif) is the product of z i as i runs through the entries in the tableau P. We will not prove (41.4), which is due to Littlewood, but proofs may be found in Fulton [53] or Stanley [153].

Crystals have a purely combinatorial tensor product rule that exactly parallels the decomposition rule for tensor products of Lie group representations. That is, if ![
$$\\mathcal{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq81.gif) and ![
$$\\mathcal{C}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq82.gif) are crystals, a crystal ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\\otimes \\mathcal{C}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq83.gif) is defined which is the disjoint union of "irreducible" crystals, each isomorphic to a crystal of the type ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq84.gif). If λ, μ and ν are dominant weights, then the number of copies of ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq85.gif) in the decomposition of ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\mu } \\otimes \\mathcal{B}_{\\nu }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq86.gif) equals the multiplicity of ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq87.gif) in ![
$$\\pi _{\\mu }^{G} \\otimes \\pi _{\\nu }^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq88.gif).

Crystals give an explanation of the RSK algorithm. The point is that the tensor product operation is closely related to Schensted insertion. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{B} = \\mathcal{B}_{\(1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq89.gif). This is Kashiwara's standard crystal. It looks like this:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline 1\\\\ \\hline \\end{array} {\\mathop{\\longrightarrow }\\limits }^{1}\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline 2 \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} {\\mathop{\\longrightarrow }\\limits }^{2}\\cdots {\\mathop{\\longrightarrow }\\limits }^{n-1}\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline n \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\;.}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equl.gif)

Now we have an isomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{B}\\otimes \\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }\\mathop{\\cong}\\bigsqcup _{\\mu }\\mathcal{B}_{\\mu }}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_Equm.gif)

as μ runs through all the partitions with Young diagrams that are obtained from λ by adding one box. In this isomorphism, if P is a tableau of shape λ, the element ![
$$\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline i\\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\otimes P$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq90.gif) in ![
$$\\mathcal{B}\\otimes \\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq91.gif) corresponds to the tableaux ![
$$\\begin{array}{|l|} \\hline i\\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\rightarrow P$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq92.gif) obtained by Schensted insertion in one of the ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq93.gif). Which ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq94.gif) it lives in depends on the row in which the Schensted insertion terminates. The crystal analog of Frobenius–Schur duality expresses ![
$${\\otimes }^{k}\\mathcal{B}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq95.gif) as a disjoint union of copies of ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq96.gif) as λ runs through the partitions of k; the number of times ![
$$\\mathcal{B}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq97.gif) occurs equals the number of standard tableaux of shape λ.

Crystals are a concrete link between the combinatorics of tableaux and representation theory. Let V λ be the module for the representation ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda }^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq98.gif). We would like to deform the group G to obtain a "quantum group" depending on a parameter q. The quantum group q should be G in the limit. This scenario does not quite work, but instead, one may replace G by its (slightly modified) universal enveloping algebra which is a Hopf algebra (Exercise 41.3). This has a deformation ![
$$U_{q}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq99.gif). This Hopf algebra is the quantized enveloping algebra. It was introduced by Drinfeld and (independently) Jimbo in 1986, in response to developments in mathematical physics. If the parameter ![
$$q\\longrightarrow 1$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq100.gif) we recover ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq101.gif). If ![
$$q\\longrightarrow 0$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq102.gif), the Hopf algebra ![
$$U_{q}\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq103.gif) does not have a limit but its modules do. They "crystalize" and the crystal is a basis of the resulting module. We refer to Hong and Kang [72] for an account following Kashiwara.

Exercise 41.3.

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq104.gif) be a Lie algebra. Let ![
$$U = U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq105.gif) be its universal enveloping algebra.

(i)

Show that the map ![
$$\\varDelta: \\mathfrak{g} \\rightarrow U \\otimes U$$
](A79351_2_En_41_Chapter_IEq106.gif) defined by Δ(X) = X ⊗ 1 + 1 ⊗ X satisfies Δ(X)Δ(Y ) −Δ(Y )Δ(X) =Δ([X,Y ]) and conclude that Δ extends to a ring homomorphism U → U ⊗ U.
