# 42. Minors of Toeplitz Matrices

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

This chapter can be read immediately after Chap. 39. It may also be skipped without loss of continuity. It gives further examples of how Frobenius–Schur duality can be used to give information about problems related to random matrix theory.

This chapter can be read immediately after Chap.​ 39. It may also be skipped without loss of continuity. It gives further examples of how Frobenius–Schur duality can be used to give information about problems related to random matrix theory.

Let ![
$$f\(t\) =\\sum _{ n=-\\infty }^{\\infty }d_{n}{t}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq1.gif) be a Laurent series representing a function ![
$$f: \\mathbb{T}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq2.gif) on the unit circle. We consider the Toeplitz matrix

![
$$\\displaystyle{T_{n-1}\(f\) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} d_{0} & d_{1} & \\cdots &d_{n-1} \\\\ d_{-1} & d_{0} & \\cdots &d_{n-2}\\\\ \\vdots & \\vdots & & \\vdots \\\\ d_{1-n}&d_{2-n}&\\cdots & d_{0} \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Szegö [157] considered the asymptotics of ![
$$D_{n-1}\(f\) =\\det \\big \(T_{n-1}\(f\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq3.gif) as ![
$$n \\longrightarrow \\infty$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq01.gif). He proved, under certain assumptions, that if

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(t\) =\\exp \\left \(\\sum _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }c_{ n}{t}^{n}\\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equb.gif)

then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ D_{n-1}\(f\) \\sim \\exp \\left \(nc_{0} +\\sum _{ k=1}^{\\infty }kc_{ k}c_{-k}\\right \)\\,. }$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(42.1)

In other words, the ratio is asymptotically 1 as ![
$$n\\longrightarrow \\infty$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq4.gif). See Böttcher and Silbermann [22] for the history of this problem and applications of Szegö's theorem.

A generalization of Szegö's theorem was given by Bump and Diaconis [28], who found that the asymptotics of minors of Toeplitz matrices had a similar formula. Very strikingly, the irreducible characters of the symmetric group appear in the formula.

One may form a minor of a Toeplitz matrix by either striking some rows and columns or by shifting some rows and columns. For example, if we strike the second row and first column of T 4(f), we get

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} d_{1} & d_{2} & d_{3} & d_{4} \\\\ d_{-1} & d_{0} & d_{1} & d_{2} \\\\ d_{-2} & d_{-1} & d_{0} & d_{1} \\\\ d_{-3} & d_{-2} & d_{-1} & d_{0} \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equc.gif)

This is the same result as we would get by simply shifting the indices in T 3(f); that is, it is the determinant ![
$$\\det \(d_{\\lambda _{i}-i+j}\)_{1\\leqslant i,j\\leqslant 4}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq5.gif) where λ is the partition (1). The most general Toeplitz minor has the form ![
$$\\det \(d_{\\lambda _{i}-\\mu _{j}-i+j}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq6.gif), where λ and μ are partitions. The asymptotic formula of Bump and Diaconis holds λ and μ fixed and lets ![
$$n\\longrightarrow \\infty$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq7.gif).

The formula with μ omitted [i.e., for ![
$$\\det \(d_{\\lambda _{i}-i+j}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq8.gif)] is somewhat simpler to state than the formula, involving Laguerre polynomials, with both λ and μ. We will content ourselves with the special case where μ is trivial.

We will take the opportunity in the proof of Theorem 42.1 to correct a minor error in [28]. The statement before (3.4) of [28] that "...the only terms that survive have ![
$$\\alpha _{k} = \\beta _{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq9.gif)" is only correct for terms of degree ≤ n. (We thank Barry Simon for pointing this out.)

If λ is a partition, let χλ denote the character of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq10.gif) defined in Chap.​ 36.

We will use the notation like that at the end of Chap.​ 22, which we review next. Although we hark back to Chap.​ 22 for our notation, the only "deep" fact that we need from Part II of this book is the Weyl integration formula. For example, the Weyl character formula in the form that we need it is identical to the combination of (36.​1) and (36.​3). The proof of Theorem 42.1 in [28], based on the Jacobi–Trudi and Cauchy identities, did not make use of the Weyl integration formula, so even this aspect of the proof can be made independent of Part II.

Let T be the diagonal torus in ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq11.gif). We will identify ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq12.gif) by mapping the character (22.​15) to ![
$$\(k_{1},\\ldots,k_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq13.gif). If ![
$$\\chi \\in {X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq14.gif) we will use the "multiplicative" notation ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{\\chi }$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq15.gif) for ![
$$\\chi$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq16.gif) so as to be able to form linear combinations of characters yet still write ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq17.gif) additively. The Weyl group W can be identified with the symmetric group ![
$$S_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq18.gif) acting on ![
$${X}^{{\\ast}}\(T\) = {\\mathbb{Z}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq19.gif) by permuting the characters. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{E}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq20.gif) be the free Abelian group on X ∗(T). (This differs slightly from the use of ![
$$\\mathcal{E}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq21.gif) at the end of Chap.​ 22.)

Elements of ![
$$\\mathcal{E}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq22.gif) are naturally functions on T. Since each conjugacy class of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq23.gif) has a representative in T, and two elements of T are conjugate in G if and only if they are equivalent by W, class functions on G are the same as W-invariant functions on W. In particular, a W-invariant element of ![
$$\\mathcal{E}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq24.gif) may be regarded as a function on the group. We write the Weyl character formula in the form (22.​17) with ![
$$\\delta = \(n - 1,n - 2,\\ldots,1,0\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq25.gif) as in (22.​16).

If λ and μ are partitions of length ![
$$ \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq020.gif), let

![
$$\\displaystyle{D_{n-1}^{\\lambda,\\mu }\(f\) =\\det \(d_{ \\lambda _{i}-\\mu _{j}-i+j}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equd.gif)

It is easy to see that this is a minor in a larger Toeplitz matrix.

Theorem 42.1 (Heine, Szegö, Bump, Diaconis).

Let ![
$$f \\in {L}^{1}\(\\mathbb{T}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) be given, with ![
$$f\(t\) =\\sum _{ n=-\\infty }^{\\infty }d_{n}{t}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) . Let λ and μ be partitions of length ![
$$\\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) . Define a function Φ n,f on ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) by ![
$$\\varPhi _{n,f}\(g\) =\\prod _{ i=1}^{n}f\(t_{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq30132.gif) , where t i are the eigenvalues of ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq31123.gif) . Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{D_{n-1}^{\\lambda,\\mu }\(f\) =\\int _{\\mathrm{ U}\(n\)}\\varPhi _{n,f}\(g\)\\,\\overline{\\chi _{\\lambda }\(g\)}\\,\\chi _{\\mu }\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g\\,.}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Eque.gif)

If λ and μ are trivial, this is the classical Heine–Szegö identity. Historically, a "Hermitian" precursor of this formula may be found in Heine's 1878 treatise on spherical functions, but the "unitary" version seems due to Szegö. The following proof of the general case is different from that given by Bump and Diaconis, who deduced this formula from the Jacobi–Trudi identity.

Proof.

By the Weyl integration formula in the form (22.​18), and the Weyl character formula in the form (22.​17), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & \\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\varPhi _{n,f}\(g\)\\overline{\\chi _{\\lambda }\(g\)}\\chi _{\\mu }\(g\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g {}\\\\ & & \\quad = \\frac{1} {n!}\\int _{\\mathbb{T}}\\varPhi _{n,f}\(t\)\\left \(\\sum _{w\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\mu +\\delta \)}\\right \)\\left \(\\sum _{ w^{\\prime}\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w^{\\prime}\)}{\\mathrm{e}}^{-w^{\\prime}\(\\lambda +\\delta \)}\\right \)\\mathrm{d}t {}\\\\ & & \\quad = \\frac{1} {n!}\\int _{\\mathbb{T}}\\varPhi _{n,f}\(t\)\\left \(\\sum _{w,w^{\\prime}\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)+l\(w^{\\prime}\)}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\mu +\\delta \)-w^{\\prime}\(\\lambda +\\delta \)}\\right \)\\mathrm{d}t. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

Interchanging the order of summation and integration, replacing w by w′w, and then making the variable change ![
$$t\\longmapsto w^{\\prime}\\,t$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq32123.gif), we get

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{1} {n!}\\sum _{w^{\\prime}\\in W}\\left \[\\sum _{w\\in W}\\int _{T}\\varPhi _{n,f}\(t\)\\left \({\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\mu +\\delta \)-\\lambda -\\delta }\\right \)\\mathrm{d}t\\right \].}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Each w′ contributes equally, and we may simply drop the summation over w′ and the 1∕n! to get

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{w\\in W}\\int _{T}\\varPhi _{n,f}\(t\)\\left \({\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}{\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\mu +\\delta \)-\\lambda -\\delta }\\right \)\\mathrm{d}t.}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equg.gif)

Now, as a function on T, the weight ![
$${\\mathrm{e}}^{w\(\\mu +\\delta \)-\\lambda -\\delta }$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) has the effect

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} t_{1} & & \\\\ & \\ddots & \\\\ & & t_{n} \\end{array} \\right \)\\longmapsto \\prod _{i=1}^{n}t_{ i}^{\\mu _{w\(i\)}+\(n-w\(i\)\)-\\lambda _{i}-\(n-i\)} =\\prod _{ i=1}^{n}t_{ i}^{\\mu _{w\(i\)}-w\(i\)-\\lambda _{i}+i}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equh.gif)

Thus, the integral is

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & \\sum _{w\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}\\prod _{ i=1}^{n}\\int _{ \\mathbb{T}}\\left \(\\sum _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }d_{ k}t_{i}^{k}\\right \)t_{ i}^{\\mu _{w\(i\)}-w\(i\)-\\lambda _{i}+i}\\mathrm{d}t {}\\\\ & & \\qquad =\\sum _{w\\in W}{\(-1\)}^{l\(w\)}\\prod _{ i=1}^{n}d_{ -\\mu _{w\(i\)}+w\(i\)+\\lambda _{i}-i}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

Since the Weyl group is S n and (−1) l(w) is the sign character, by the definition of the determinant, this is the determinant ![
$$D_{n-1}^{\\lambda,\\mu }\(f\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq34123.gif). □

As we already mentioned, we will only consider here the special case where μ is (0,..., 0). We refer to [28] for the general case. If μ is trivial, then Theorem 42.1 reduces to the formula

![
$$\\displaystyle{ D_{n-1}^{\\lambda }\(f\) =\\int _{\\mathrm{ U}\(n\)}\\varPhi _{n,f}\(g\)\\,\\overline{\\chi _{\\lambda }\(g\)}\\,\\mathrm{d}g, }$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(42.2)

where

![
$$\\displaystyle{D_{n-1}^{\\lambda }\(f\) =\\det \(d_{ \\lambda _{i}-i+j}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Theorem 42.2 (Szegö, Bump, Diaconis).

Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\(t\) =\\exp \\left \(\\sum _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }c_{ k}{t}^{k}\\right \),}$$

$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }: S_{k}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{Z}$$

(The product is actually finite.) Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{D_{n-1}^{\\lambda }\(f\) \\sim \\frac{1} {m!}\\sum _{\\xi \\in S_{m}}\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(\\xi \)\\,\\varDelta \(f,\\xi \)\\,\\exp \\left \(nc_{0} +\\sum _{ k=1}^{\\infty }kc_{ k}c_{-k}\\right \).}$$

Our assumption that ∑|c k | < ∞ implies that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\exp \\left \(\\sum \\vert c_{k}\\vert \\,\\vert \\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{k}\)\\vert \\right \)\\mathrm{d}g <\\infty,}$$

First, take λ to be trivial, so that m = 0. This special case is Szegö's original theorem. By (42.2),

![
$$\\displaystyle{D_{n-1}\(f\) =\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\exp \\left \(\\sum _{k}c_{k}\\,\\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{k}\)\\right \)\\mathrm{d}g =\\int _{\\mathrm{ U}\(n\)}\\prod _{k}\\exp \\left \(c_{k}\\,\\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{k}\)\\right \)\\mathrm{d}g\\,.}$$

$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & &{ \\mathrm{e}}^{nc_{0} }\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\prod _{k}\\left \[\\sum _{\\alpha _{k}=0}^{\\infty }\\frac{c_{k}^{\\alpha _{k}}} {\\alpha _{k}!} \\mathrm{tr}{\({g}^{k}\)}^{\\alpha _{k} }\\right \]\\left \[\\sum _{\\alpha _{k}=0}^{\\infty }\\frac{c_{-k}^{\\beta _{k}}} {\\beta _{k}!}{ \\overline{\\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{k}\)}}^{\\beta _{k} }\\right \]\\mathrm{d}g {}\\\\ & & \\quad ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{nc_{0} }\\sum _{\(\\alpha _{k}\)}\\sum _{\(\\beta _{k}\)}\\int _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)}\\left \(\\prod _{k}\\frac{c_{k}^{\\alpha _{k}}} {\\alpha _{k}!} \\mathrm{tr}{\({g}^{k}\)}^{\\alpha _{k} }\\right \)\\left \(\\prod _{k}\\frac{c_{-k}^{\\beta _{k}}} {\\beta _{k}!}{ \\overline{\\mathrm{tr}\({g}^{k}\)}}^{\\beta _{k} }\\right \)\\mathrm{d}g, {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

where the sum is now over all sequences (α k ) and (β k ) of nonnegative integers. The integrand is multiplied by ![

where

](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equq.gif)

Now consider the terms with ![
$$r \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq05.gif). When ![

$$\\mathcal{R}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq45.gif) to the space of class functions in L 2(G) is an isometry, and if ν = ν′, then by (37.​2) we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle {\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{p}_{ \\nu }\),{\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{p}_{ \\sigma }\)\\right \\rangle _{\\mathrm{U}\(n\)} = \\left \\langle \\mathbf{p}_{\\nu },\\mathbf{p}_{\\sigma }\\right \\rangle _{S_{r}} = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} z_{\\nu }&\\mbox{ if $\\nu = \\sigma $,} \\\\ 0 &\\text{otherwise.} \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equr.gif)

(This is the same fact we used in the proof of Proposition 39.4.) Thus, when ![
$$r \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq46.gif), we have C(r,n) = C(r) where, using the explicit form (37.​1) of z ν , we have

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} C\(r\)& =&{ \\mathrm{e}}^{nc_{0} }\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\nu $ a partition of $r$}}z_{\\nu }\\left \(\\prod _{k}\\frac{{\(c_{k}\\,c_{-k}\)}^{\\alpha _{k}}} {{\(\\alpha _{k}!\)}^{2}} \\right \) {}\\\\ & =&{ \\mathrm{e}}^{nc_{0} }\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\nu $ a partition of $r$}}\\left \(\\prod _{k}\\frac{{\(kc_{k}\\,c_{-k}\)}^{\\alpha _{k}}} {\\alpha _{k}!} \\right \). {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{r}C\(r\) ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{nc_{0} }\\prod _{k}\\sum _{\\alpha _{k}=0}^{\\infty }\\left \(\\frac{{\(kc_{k}\\,c_{-k}\)}^{\\alpha _{k}}} {\\alpha _{k}!} \\right \) ={ \\mathrm{e}}^{nc_{0} }\\prod _{k}\\exp \(kc_{k}c_{-k}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equs.gif)

so as ![
$$n\\longrightarrow \\infty$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq47.gif), the series ∑ r C(r,n) stabilizes to the series ∑ r C(r) that converges to the right-hand side of (42.1).

To prove (42.1), we must bound the tails of the series ∑ r C(r,n). It is enough to show that there exists an absolutely convergent series ![
$$\\sum _{r}\\vert D\(r\)\\vert <\\infty$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq48.gif) such that ![
$$\\vert C\(r,n\)\\vert \\leqslant \\vert D\(r\)\\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq49.gif). First, let us consider the case where ![
$$c_{k} = \\overline{c_{-k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq50.gif). In this case, we may take D(r) = C(r). The absolute convergence of the series ∑|D(r)| follows from our assumption that ![
$$\\sum \\vert k\\vert \\,\\vert c_{k}{\\vert }^{2} <\\infty$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq51.gif) and the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality. In this case,

![
$$\\displaystyle{C\(r,n\) ={ \\left \\|\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\nu $ a partition of $r$}}\\left \(\\prod _{k}\\frac{c_{k}^{\\alpha _{k}}} {\\alpha _{k}!} \\right \){\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{p}_{ \\nu }\)\\right \\|}^{2},}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equt.gif)

where, as before, ![
$$\\alpha _{k} = \\alpha _{k}\(\\nu \)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq52.gif) is the number of parts of size k of the partition ν and the inner product is taken in ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq53.gif). Invoking the fact from Theorem 39.1 that the ![
$${\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq54.gif) is a contraction, this is bounded by

![
$$\\displaystyle{C\(r,n\) ={ \\left \\|\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\nu $ a partition of $r$}}\\left \(\\prod _{k}\\frac{c_{k}^{\\alpha _{k}}} {\\alpha _{k}!} \\right \)\\mathbf{p}_{\\nu }\\right \\|}^{2},}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equu.gif)

where now the inner product is taken in S r , and of course this is C(r). If we do not assume ![
$$c_{k} = \\overline{c_{-k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_IEq55.gif), we may use the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality and bound C(r, n) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\|\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\nu $ a partition of $r$}}\\left \(\\prod _{k}\\frac{c_{k}^{\\alpha _{k}}} {\\alpha _{k}!} \\right \){\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{p}_{ \\nu }\)\\right \\|\\cdot \\left \\|\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\sigma $ a partition of $r$}}\\left \(\\prod _{k}\\frac{c_{-k}^{\\beta _{k}}} {\\beta _{k}!} \\right \)\\,{\\mathrm{Ch}}^{\(n\)}\(\\mathbf{p}_{ \\sigma }\)\\right \\|\\,.}$$
](A79351_2_En_42_Chapter_Equv.gif)

Each norm is dominated by the corresponding norm in R k and, proceeding as before, we obtain the same bound with c k replaced by ![
$$\\max \(\\vert c_{k}\\vert,\\vert c_{-k}\\vert \)$$

Now (42.1) is proved, which is the special case with λ trivial. We turn now to the general case.

We will make use of the identity

![

Since S m contains m!∕z λ elements of cycle type μ and ![

and using this value, we see that when ![

$$\\displaystyle{C\(r,\\xi \) =\\varDelta \(f,\\xi \)\\sum _{ \\mbox{ $\\begin{array}{c} \(\\beta _{k}\) \\\\ \\sum k\\beta _{k} = r \\end{array} $}}\\frac{{\(kc_{k}c_{-k}\)}^{\\beta _{k}}} {\\beta _{k}!}.}$$

The series is

# 43. The Involution Model for S k

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

Let σ 1 = 1, σ 2 = (12), σ 3 = (12)(34),... be the conjugacy classes of involutions in S k . It was shown by Klyachko and by Inglis et al. [82] that it is possible to specify a set of characters ![
$$\\psi _{1},\\psi _{2},\\psi _{3},\\ldots$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq1.gif) of degree 1 of the centralizers of ![
$$\\sigma _{1},\\sigma _{2},\\sigma _{3},\\ldots$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq2.gif) such that the direct sum of the induced representations of the ![
$$\\psi_i$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq037.gif) contains every irreducible representation exactly once. In the next chapter, we will see that translating this fact and related ones to the unitary group gives classical facts about symmetric and exterior algebra decompositions due to Littlewood [120].

Let σ 1 = 1, σ 2 = (12), σ 3 = (12)(34),... be the conjugacy classes of involutions in S k . It was shown by Klyachko and by Inglis et al. [82] that it is possible to specify a set of characters ![
$$\\psi _{1},\\psi _{2},\\psi _{3},\\ldots$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq3.gif) of degree 1 of the centralizers of ![
$$\\sigma _{1},\\sigma _{2},\\sigma _{3},\\ldots$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq4.gif) such that the direct sum of the induced representations of the ![
$$\\psi_i$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq01.gif) contains every irreducible representation exactly once. In the next chapter, we will see that translating this fact and related ones to the unitary group gives classical facts about symmetric and exterior algebra decompositions due to Littlewood [120].

If (π, V) is a self-contragredient irreducible complex representation of a compact group G, we may classify π as orthogonal (real) or symplectic (quaternionic). We will now explain this classification due to Frobenius and Schur [52]. We recall that the contragredient representation to (π, V) is the representation ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\({V }^{{\\ast}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq5.gif) on the dual space V ∗ of V defined by ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }\(g\) = \\pi {\({g}^{-1}\)}^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq6.gif), which is the adjoint of π(g −1). Its character is the complex conjugate of the character of π.

Proposition 43.1.

The irreducible complex representation π is self-contragredient if and only if there exists a nondegenerate bilinear form ![
$$B: V \\times V \\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq7.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ B\\big\(\\pi \(g\)v,\\pi \(g\)w\\big\) = B\(v,w\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(43.1)

The form B is unique up to a scalar multiple. We have B(w,v) =   B(v,w), where   = ±1.

Proof.

To emphasize the symmetry between V and V ∗, let us write the dual pairing ![
$$V \\times {V }^{{\\ast}}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq8.gif) in the symmetrical form ![
$$L\(v\) = \\left \[\\!\[v,L\\right \]\\!\]$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq9.gif). The contragredient representation thus satisfies ![
$$\\left \[\\!\[\\pi \(g\)v,L\\right \]\\!\] = \\left \[\\!\[v,\\hat{\\pi }\({g}^{-1}\)L\\right \]\\!\]$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq10.gif), or ![
$$\\left \[\\!\[\\pi \(g\)v,\\hat{\\pi }\(g\)L\\right \]\\!\] = \\left \[\\!\[v,L\\right \]\\!\]$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq11.gif). Any bilinear form ![
$$B: V \\times V \\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq12.gif) is of the form ![
$$B\(v,w\) = \\left \[\\!\[v,\\lambda \(w\)\\right \]\\!\]$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq13.gif), where ![
$$\\lambda: V \\longrightarrow {V }^{{\\ast}}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq14.gif) is a linear isomorphism. It is clear that (43.1) is satisfied if and only if λ intertwines π and ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq15.gif).

Since π and ![
$$\\hat{\\pi }$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq16.gif) are irreducible, Schur's lemma implies that λ, if it exists, is unique up to a scalar multiple, and the same conclusion follows for B. Now (v,w)↦B(w,v) has the same property as B, and so B(w,v) =   B(v,w) for some constant  . Applying this identity twice,   2 B(v,w) = B(v,w) so   = ±1. □

If (π, V) is self-contragredient, let   π be the constant   in Proposition 43.1; otherwise let   π = 0. If   π = 1, then we say that π is orthogonal or real; if ![
$$\\epsilon _{\\pi } = -1$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq17.gif), we say that π is symplectic or quaternionic. We call   π the Frobenius–Schur indicator of π.

Theorem 43.1 (Frobenius and Schur).

Let (π, V) be an irreducible representation of the compact group G. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\epsilon _{\\pi } =\\int _{G}\\chi \({g}^{2}\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g.}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Proof.

We have ![
$$p_{2} = h_{2} - e_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq18.gif) in Λ (n). Indeed, ![
$$p_{2}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq19.gif) equals

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\sum _{i}x_{i}^{2}& & = \\left \(\\sum _{ i}x_{i}^{2} +\\sum _{ i<j}x_{i}x_{j}\\right\) -\\left \(\\sum _{i<j}x_{i}x_{j}\\right\) {}\\\\ & & = h_{2}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\) - e_{2}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{n}\)\\,. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

By (33.​8) and Proposition 33.2, this means that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\chi \({g}^{2}\) = \\mathrm{tr}\\big\({\\vee }^{2}\\pi \(g\)\\big\) -\\mathrm{tr}\\big\({\\wedge }^{2}\\pi \(g\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Equb.gif)

We see that   π is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G}\\mathrm{tr}\\big\({\\vee }^{2}\\pi \(g\)\\big\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g -\\int _{ G}\\mathrm{tr}\\big\({\\wedge }^{2}\\pi \(g\)\\big\)\\,\\mathrm{d}g.}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Equc.gif)

Thus, what we need to know is that ![
$${\\vee }^{2}\\pi \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq20.gif) contains the trivial representation if and only if   π = 1, while ![
$${\\wedge }^{2}\\pi \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq21.gif) contains the trivial representation if and only if ![
$$\\epsilon _{\\pi } = -1$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq22.gif).

If ![
$${\\vee }^{2}\\pi \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq23.gif) contains the trivial representation, let ![
$$\\xi \\in {\\vee }^{2}V$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq24.gif) be a ![
$${\\vee }^{2}\\pi \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq25.gif)-fixed vector. Let ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq26123.gif) be a G-invariant inner product on V. There is induced a G-invariant Hermitian inner product on ![
$${\\vee }^{2}V$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) such that ![
$$\\left \\langle v_{1} \\vee v_{2},w_{1} \\vee w_{2}\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle v_{1},v_{2}\\right \\rangle \\left \\langle w_{1},w_{2}\\right \\rangle,$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) and we may define a symmetric bilinear form on V by ![
$$B\(v,w\) = \\left \\langle v \\vee w,\\xi \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq29213.gif). Thus,   π = 1.

Conversely, if   π = 1, let B be a symmetric invariant bilinear form. By the universal property of the symmetric square, there exists a linear form ![
$$L: {\\vee }^{2}V \\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) such that ![
$$B\(v,w\) = L\(v \\vee w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq31123.gif), and hence a vector ![
$$\\xi \\in {\\vee }^{2}V$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) such that ![
$$B\(v,w\) = \\left \\langle v \\vee w,\\xi \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq33123.gif), which is a ![
$${\\vee }^{2}\\pi \(g\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq34123.gif)-fixed vector.

The case where ![
$$\\epsilon _{\\pi } = -1$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq35.gif) is identical using the exterior square. □

Proposition 43.2.

Let (π, V) be an irreducible complex representation of the compact group G. Then π is the complexification of a real representation if and only if   π = 1. If this is true, π(G) is conjugate to a subgroup of the orthogonal group O (n).

Proof.

First, suppose that ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq36.gif) is the complexification of a real representation. This means that there exists a real vector space V 0 and a homomorphism ![
$$\\pi _{0}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V _{0}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq37.gif) such that ![
$$V \\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{C} \\otimes _{\\mathbb{R}}V _{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq38.gif) as G-modules. Every compact subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(V _{0}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq39.gif) is conjugate to a subgroup of O(n). Indeed, if ![
$$\\left \\langle \\!\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle \\!\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq40.gif) is a positive definite symmetric bilinear form on V 0, then averaging it gives another positive definite symmetric bilinear form

![
$$\\displaystyle{B_{0}\(v,w\) =\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\,\\left \\langle \\pi _{0}\(g\)v,\\pi _{0}\(g\)w\\right \\rangle \\,\\right \\rangle \\mathrm{d}g}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Equd.gif)

that is G-invariant. Choosing a basis of V 0 that is orthonormal with respect to this basis, the matrices of π 0(g) will all be orthogonal. Extending B 0 by linearity to a symmetric bilinear form on V, which we identify with ![
$$\\mathbb{C} \\otimes V _{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq41.gif), gives a symmetric bilinear form showing that   π = 1.

Conversely, if   π = 1, there exists a G-invariant symmetric bilinear form B on V. We will make use of both B and a G-invariant inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq42.gif) on V. They differ in that B is linear in the second variable, while the inner product is conjugate linear. If w ∈ V, consider the linear functional v ↦ B(v,w). Every linear functional is the inner product with a unique element of V, so there exists λ(w) ∈ V such that ![
$$B\(v,w\) = \\left \\langle v\\;,\\lambda \(w\)\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq43.gif). The map ![
$$\\lambda: V \\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq44.gif) is ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq45.gif)-linear but not ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq46.gif)-linear; in fact, it is complex antilinear. Let ![
$$V _{0} =\\{ v \\in V \\,\\vert \\,\\lambda \(v\) = v\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq47.gif). It is a real vector space. We may write every element v ∈ V as a sum ![
$$v = u + iw$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq48.gif), where u,w ∈ V 0, taking ![
$$u = \\frac{1} {2}\\big\(v + \\lambda \(v\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq49.gif) and ![
$$w = \\frac{1} {2i}\\big\(v - \\lambda \(v\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq50.gif). This decomposition is unique since ![
$$\\lambda \(v\) = u - iw$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq51.gif), and we may solve for u and w. Therefore, V = V 0 ⊕ iV 0 and V is the complexification of V 0. Since B and H are both G-invariant, it is easy to see that λ ∘ π(g) = π(g) ∘ λ, so π leaves V 0-invariant and induces a real representation with the complexification π. □

Theorem 43.2.

Let G be a finite group. Let ![
$$\\mu: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq52.gif) be the sum of the irreducible characters of G.

(i)

Suppose that   π = 1 for every irreducible representation π. Then, for any g ∈ G, μ(g) is the number of solutions to the equation x 2 = g in G.

(ii)

Suppose that μ(1) is the number of solutions to the equation x 2 = 1. Then   π = 1 for all irreducible representations π.

Proof.

If π is an irreducible representation of G, let χ π be its character. We will show

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sum _{\\mbox{ irreducible $\\pi $}}\\chi _{\\pi }\(g\)\\epsilon _{\\hat{\\pi }} = \\#\\{x \\in G\\,\\vert \\,{x}^{2} = g\\}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(43.2)

Indeed, by Theorem 43.1, the left-hand side equals

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{\\chi }\\chi \(g\) \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{x\\in G}\\overline{\\chi \({x}^{2}\)} =\\sum _{x\\in G}\\left \[ \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{\\chi }\\chi \(g\)\\,\\overline{\\chi \({x}^{2}\)}\\right \].}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Eque.gif)

Let C be the conjugacy class of g. By Schur orthogonality, the expression in brackets equals 1∕|C| if x 2 is conjugate to g and zero otherwise. Each element of the conjugacy class will have the same number of square roots, so counting the number of solutions to x 2 ∼ g (where ∼ denotes conjugation) and then dividing by |C| gives the number of solutions to x 2 = g. This proves (43.2).

Now (43.2) clearly implies (i). It also implies (ii) because, taking g = 1, each coefficient χ π (1) is a positive integer, so

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{\\mbox{ irreducible $\\pi $}}\\chi _{\\pi }\(1\)\\,\\epsilon _{\\hat{\\pi }} =\\sum _{\\mbox{ irreducible $\\pi $}}\\chi _{\\pi }\(1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Equf.gif)

is only possible if all   π are equal to 1. □

Let K be a field and F a subfield. Let V be a K-vector space. If ![
$$\\pi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq53.gif) is a representation of a group G over K, we say that π is defined over F if there exists an F-vector space V 0 and a representation ![
$$\\pi _{0}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V _{0}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq54.gif) over F such that π is isomorphic to the representation of G on the K-vector space K ⊗ F V 0. The dimension over K of V must clearly equal the dimension of V 0 as an F-vector space.

Theorem 43.3.

Every irreducible representation of S k is defined over ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq55.gif) .

Proof.

The construction of Theorem 35.1 contained no reference to the ground field and works just as well over ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq56.gif). Specifically, our formulation of Mackey theory was valid over an arbitrary field, so if λ and μ are conjugate partitions, the computation of Proposition 35.5 shows that there is a unique intertwining operator ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{S_{\\lambda }}^{S_{k}}\(\\varepsilon\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Ind}_{ S_{\\mu }}^{S_{k}}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq57.gif), where we are now considering representations over ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq58.gif). The image of this intertwining operator is a rational representation which has a complexification that is the representation ρ λ of S k parametrized by λ. □

In this chapter, we will call an element x ∈ G an involution if x 2 = 1. Thus, the identity element is considered an involution by this definition. If G = S k , then by Theorem 43.3 every irreducible representation is defined over ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq59.gif), a fortiori over ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq60.gif), and so by Theorem 43.2 we have   π = 1 for all irreducible representations π. Therefore, the number of involutions is equal to the sum of the degrees of the irreducible characters, and moreover the sum of the irreducible characters evaluated at g ∈ S k equals the number of solutions to x 2 = g. In particular, it is a nonnegative integer.

It is possible to prove that the sum of the degrees of the irreducible representations of G is equal to the number of involutions when G = S k using the Robinson–Schensted correspondence (see Knuth [109], Sect. 5.1.4, or Stanley [153], Corollary 7.13.9). Indeed, both numbers are equal to the number of standard tableaux.

Let G be a group (such as S k ) having the property that all   π = 1, so the number of involutions of G is the sum of the degrees of the irreducible representations. Let ![
$$x_{1},\\ldots,x_{h}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq61.gif) be representatives of the conjugacy classes of involutions. The cardinality of a conjugacy class x is the index of its centralizer C G (x), so ![
$$\\sum \[G: C_{G}\(x_{i}\)\]$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq62.gif) is the number of involutions of G. Since this is the sum of the degrees of the irreducible characters of G, it becomes a natural question to ask whether we may specify characters ![
$$\\psi_i$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq038.gif) of degree 1 of C G (x i ) such that the direct sum of the induced characters ![
$$\\psi_{i}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq039.gif) contains each irreducible character exactly once. If so, these data comprise an involution model for G. Involution models do not always exist, even if all   π = 1.

A complete set of representatives of the conjugacy classes of S k are 1, (12), (12)(34),.... To describe their centralizers, we first begin with the involution (12)(34)(56)⋯(2r − 1,2r) ∈ S 2r . Its centralizer, as described in Proposition 37.1, has order 2 r r!. It has a normal subgroup of order 2 r generated by the transpositions (12), (34),..., and the quotient is isomorphic to S r . We denote this group B 2r . It is isomorphic to the Weyl group of Cartan type B r .

Now consider the centralizer in S k of (12)(34)⋯(2r − 1,2r) where 2r < k. It is contained in S 2r × S k−2r , where the second S k−2r acts on ![
$$\\{2r + 1,2r + 2,\\ldots,k\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq63.gif) and equals B 2r × S k−2r . The theorem of Klyachko, Inglis, Richardson, and Saxl is that we may specify characters of these groups with inductions to S k that contain every irreducible character exactly once. There are two ways of doing this: we may put the alternating character on S k−2k and the trivial character on B 2r , or conversely we may put the alternating character (restricted from S 2r ) on B 2r and the trivial character on S k−2r .

Let ω 2r be the character of S 2r induced from the trivial character of B 2r .

Proposition 43.3.

The restriction of ω 2r to S 2r−1 is isomorphic to the character of S 2r−1 induced from the character ω 2r−2 to S 2r−1 .

Proof.

First, let us show that ![
$$B_{2r}\\setminus S_{2r}/S_{2r-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq64.gif) consists of a single double coset. Indeed, S 2r acts transitively on X ={ 1,2,...,2r}, and the stabilizer of 2r is S 2r−1. Therefore, we can identify ![
$$S_{2r}/S_{2r-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq65.gif) with X and ![
$$B_{2r}\\setminus S_{2r}/S_{2r-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq66.gif) with ![
$$B_{2r}\\setminus X$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq67.gif). Since B 2r acts transitively on X, the claim is proved.

Thus, we can compute the restriction of ω2r to S 2r−1 by Corollary 32.2 to Theorem 32.2, taking H 1 = B 2r , ![
$$H_{2} = S_{2r-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq68.gif), G = S 2r , π = 1, with γ = 1 the only double coset representative. We see that the restriction of ![
$$\\omega _{2r} = \\mathrm{Ind}_{H_{1}}^{G}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq69.gif) is the same as the induction of 1 from ![
$$H_{\\gamma } = B_{2r} \\cap S_{2r-1} = B_{2r-2}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq70.gif) to H 2. Inducing in stages first from B 2r−2 to S 2r−2 and then to S 2r−1, this is the same as the character of S 2r−1 induced from ω 2r−2. □

We are preparing to compute ω 2r . The key observation of Inglis, Richardson, and Saxl is that Proposition 43.3, plus purely combinatorial considerations, contains enough information to do this.

We call a partition ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\lambda _{2},\\ldots\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq71.gif) even if every λ i is an even integer.

If λ is a partition, let ![
$$R_{i}\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\lambda _{2},\\ldots,\\lambda _{i-1},\\lambda _{i} + 1,\\lambda _{i+1},\\ldots\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq72.gif) be the result of incrementing the ith part. In applying this raising operator, we must always check that the resulting sequence is a partition. For this, we need either i = 1 or λ i < λ i−1. Similarly, we have the lowering operator ![
$$L_{i}\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\lambda _{2},\\ldots,\\lambda _{i-1},\\lambda _{i} - 1,\\lambda _{i+1},\\ldots\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq73.gif), which is a partition if λ i > λ i+1.

Lemma 43.1.

Every partition of 2r − 1 having exactly one odd part is contained in a unique even partition of 2r.

Proof.

Let μ be a partition of 2r − 1 having exactly one odd part μ i . The unique even partition of 2r containing μ is R i μ. Note that this is a partition since i = 1 or μ i < μ i−1. (We cannot have μ i and μ i−1 both equal since one is odd and the other is even.) □

Proposition 43.4.

Let S be a set of partitions of 2r. Assume that:

(i)

Each partition of 2r − 1 contained in an element of S has exactly one odd part;

(ii)

Each partition of 2r − 1 with exactly one odd part is contained in a unique element of S;

(iii)

The trivial partition (2r) ∈ S.

Then S consists of the set S 0 of even partitions of 2r.

Proof.

First, we show that S contains S 0. Assume on the contrary that λ ∈ S 0 is not in S. We assume that the counterexample λ is minimal with respect to the partial order, so if λ′ ∈ S 0 with λ′ ≺ λ, then λ′ ∈ S. Let i = l(λ). We note that i > 1 since if i = 1, then λ is the unique partition of 2r of length 1, namely (2r), which is impossible since ![
$$\\lambda \\notin S$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq74.gif) while (2r) ∈ S by assumption (iii).

Let μ = L i λ. It is a partition since we are decrementing the last nonzero part of λ. It has a unique odd part μ i , so by (ii) there is a unique τ ∈ S such that μ ⊂ τ. Evidently, τ = R j μ for some j. Let us consider what j can be.

We show first that j cannot be > i. If it were, we would have ![
$$j = i + 1$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq75.gif) because i is the length of μ and λ. Now assuming ![
$$\\tau = R_{i+1}\\mu = R_{i+1}L_{i}\\lambda $$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq76.gif), we can obtain a contradiction as follows. We have ![
$$\\tau _{i-1} = \\lambda _{i-1} \\geq \\lambda _{i} > \\lambda _{i} - 1 = \\tau _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq77.gif), so ![
$$\\nu = L_{i-1}\\tau $$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq78.gif) is a partition. It has three odd parts, namely ν i−1,ν i and ν i+1. This contradicts (i) for ν ⊂ τ ∈ S.

Also j cannot equal i. If it did, we would have ![
$$\\tau = R_{i}L_{i}\\lambda = \\lambda $$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq79.gif), a contradiction since τ ∈ S while ![
$$\\lambda \\notin S$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq80.gif).

Therefore, j < i. Let ![
$$\\sigma = R_{j}L_{i}\\tau = R_{j}^{2}L_{i}^{2}\\lambda $$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq81.gif). Note that σ is a partition. Indeed, either j = 1 or else τ j ≠τ j−1 since one is odd and the other one is even, and we are therefore permitted to apply R j . Furthermore, τ i ≠τ i+1 since one is odd and the other one is even, so we are permitted to apply L i .

Since λ is even, σ is even, and since j < i, σ ≺ λ. By our induction hypothesis, this implies that σ ∈ S. Now let ![
$$\\theta = L_{i}\\tau = L_{j}\\sigma $$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq82.gif). This is easily seen to be a partition with exactly one odd part (namely θ j ), and it is contained in two distinct elements of S, namely τ and σ. This contradicts (ii).

This contradiction shows that S ⊃ S 0. We can now show that S = S 0. Otherwise, S contains S 0 and some other partition ![
$$\\lambda \\notin S_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq83.gif). Let μ be any partition of 2r − 1 contained in λ. Then μ has exactly one odd part by (i), so by Lemma 43.1 it is contained in some element λ′ ∈ S 0 ⊂ S. Since ![
$$\\lambda \\notin S_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq84.gif), λ and λ′ are distinct elements of S both containing μ, contradicting (ii). □

Theorem 43.4.

The character ω 2r of S 2r is multiplicity-free. It is the sum of all irreducible characters s λ with λ an even partition of 2r.

Proof.

By induction, we may assume that this is true for S 2r−2. The restriction of ω2r to S 2r−1 is the same as the character induced from w 2r−2 by Proposition 43.3. Using the branching rule for the symmetric groups, its irreducible constituents consist of all s μ , where μ is a partition of S 2r−1 containing an even partition of 2r − 2, and clearly this is the set of partitions of 2r − 1 having exactly one odd part. There are no repetitions.

We see immediately that ω2r is multiplicity-free since its restriction to S 2r−1 is multiplicity-free. Let S be the set of partitions λ of 2r such that s λ is contained in ω2r . Again using the branching rule for symmetric groups, we see that this set satisfies conditions (i) and (ii) of Proposition 43.4 and condition (iii) is clear by Frobenius reciprocity. The result now follows from Proposition 43.4. □

We may now show that S k has an involution model. The centralizer of the involution (12)(34)⋯(2r − 1,r) is B 2r × S k−2r .

Theorem 43.5 (Klyachko, Inglis, Richardson, and Saxl).

Every irreducible character of S k occurs with multiplicity 1 in the sum

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigoplus _{2r\\leqslant k}\\mathrm{Ind}_{B_{2r}\\times S_{k-2r}}^{S_{k} }\(1\\otimes \\varepsilon\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_Equg.gif)

where ![
$$\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq85.gif) is the alternating character of S k−2r .

Proof.

We will show that ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{B_{2r}\\times S_{k-2r}}^{S_{k}}\(1\\otimes \\varepsilon\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq86.gif) is the sum of the s λ as λ runs through the partitions of k having exactly k − 2r odd parts. Indeed, it is obvious that if λ is a partition of k, there is a unique even partition μ such that λ ⊃ μ and ![
$$\\lambda \\setminus \\mu $$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq87.gif) is a vertical strip; the partition μ is obtained by decrementing each odd part of λ. Since ω2r is the sum of all s λ where λ is a partition of 2r into even parts, it follows from Pieri's formula that the character ![
$$\\omega _{2r}\\mathbf{e}_{k-2r}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq88.gif) is the sum of all s λ where λ is a partition of k having exactly k − 2r odd parts.

We note that the number of odd parts of any partition λn of k is congruent to k modulo 2 because k = ∑λ i . The result follows by summing over r. □

and (2k − 1, 2k). It is thus a Weyl group of Cartan type B k with order k!2 k . It has a linear character ξ2k having value − 1 on these "simple reflections." This is the character (−1) l(w) of Proposition 20.12. Let ![
$$\\eta _{2k} = \\mathrm{Ind}_{B_{2k}}^{S_{2k}}\(\\xi _{2k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq105.gif) be the character of S 2k induced from this linear character of B 2k . The goal of this exercise will be to prove analogs of Theorem 43.4 and the other results of this chapter for η 2k .

Exercise 43.3.

Prove the analog of Proposition 43.3. That is, show that inducing the restriction of η 2r to S 2r−1 is isomorphic to the character of S 2r−1 induced from the character η 2r−2 to S 2r−1.

Let ![
$$\\mathcal{S}_{2k}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq106.gif) be the set of characters s λ of S 2k where λ is a partition of 2k such that if μ is the conjugate partition, then ![
$$\\mu _{i} = \\lambda _{i} + 1$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq107.gif) for all i such that λ i ≥ i. For example, the partition λ = (5, 5, 4, 3, 3, 2) has conjugate (6, 6, 5, 3, 2), and the hypothesis is satisfied. Visually, this assumption means that the diagram of λ can be assembled from two congruent pieces, as in Fig. 43.1. We will describe these as the "top piece" and the "bottom piece," respectively.

Exercise 43.4.

Prove that if ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\mathcal{T}_{2k+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq111.gif), then there are unique partitions ![
$$\\mu \\in \\mathcal{S}_{2k}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq112.gif) and ![
$$\\nu \\in \\mathcal{S}_{2k+2}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq113.gif) such that the diagram of λ contains the diagram of μ and is contained in the diagram of ν. (Hint: The diagrams of the skew partitions λ − μ and ν − λ, each consisting of a single node, must be corresponding nodes of the top piece and bottom piece.)

Exercise 43.5.

Let Σ be a set of partitions of 2k \+ 2. Assume that each partition λ of 2k \+ 1 is contained in an element of Σ if and only if ![
$$\\lambda \\in \\mathcal{T}_{2k+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq114.gif), in which case it is contained in a unique element of Σ. Show that ![
$$\\varSigma = S_{2k+2}$$
](A79351_2_En_43_Chapter_IEq115.gif). [This is an analog of Proposition 43.4. It is not necessary to assume any condition corresponding to (iii) of the proposition.]

Show that η 2k is multiplicity-free and that the representations occurring in it are precisely the s λ with ![

# 44. Some Symmetric Algebras

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

The results of the last chapter can be translated into statements about the representation theory of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq1.gif). For example, we will see that each irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq2.gif) occurs exactly once in the decomposition of the symmetric algebra of ![
$$V \\oplus {\\wedge }^{2}V$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq3.gif), where ![
$$V = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq4.gif) is the standard module of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq5.gif).

The results of the last chapter can be translated into statements about the representation theory of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq6.gif). For example, we will see that each irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq7.gif) occurs exactly once in the decomposition of the symmetric algebra of ![
$$V \\oplus {\\wedge }^{2}V$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq8.gif), where ![
$$V = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is the standard module of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq10.gif). The results of this chapter are also proved in Goodman and Wallach 56], Howe [77], Littlewood [120], and Macdonald [124]. See Theorem 26.6 and the exercises to [Chap.​ 26 for alternative proofs of some of these results.

Let us recall some ideas that already appeared in Chap.​ 38. If ![
$$\\rho: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq11.gif) is a representation, then ![
$$\\bigvee V$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq12.gif) and ![
$$\\bigwedge V$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq13.gif) become modules for G and we may ask for their decomposition into irreducible representations of V. For some representations ρ, this question will have a simple answer, and for others the answer will be complex. The very simplest case is where ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq14.gif). In this case, each ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq15.gif) is itself irreducible, and each ∧ k V is either irreducible (if ![
$$k <\\dim \(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq16.gif)) or zero.

We can encode the solution to this question with generating functions

![
$$\\displaystyle{P_{\\rho }^{\\vee }\(g;t\) =\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }\\text{tr}\\left\(g\\vert {\\vee }^{k}V \\right\){t}^{k},\\qquad P_{ \\rho }^{\\wedge }\(g;t\) =\\sum _{ k=0}^{\\infty }\\text{tr}\\left\(g {\\wedge }^{k}V \\right\){t}^{k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equa.gif)

Proposition 44.1.

Suppose that ![
$$\\rho: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq17.gif) is a representation and ![
$$\\gamma _{1},\\ldots,\\gamma _{d}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq18.gif) are the eigenvalues of ρ(g). Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ P_{\\rho }^{\\vee }\(g,t\) =\\prod _{ i}{\(1 - t\\gamma _{i}\)}^{-1},\\qquad P_{ \\rho }^{\\wedge }\(g,t\) =\\prod _{ i}\(1 + t\\gamma _{i}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(44.1)

Proof.

The traces of ρ(g) on ![
$${\\vee }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq19.gif) and ∧ k V are

![
$$\\displaystyle{h_{k}\(\\gamma _{1},\\ldots,\\gamma _{d}\)\\qquad \\text{and}\\qquad e_{k}\(\\gamma _{1},\\ldots,\\gamma _{d}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equb.gif)

so this is a restatement of (33.​1) and (33.​2). □

We see that for all g, ![
$$P_{\\rho }^{\\vee }\(g,t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq20.gif) is convergent if ![
$$t <\\max \(\\vert \\gamma _{i}{\\vert }^{-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq21.gif) and has meromorphic continuation in t, while ![
$$P_{\\rho }^{\\wedge }\(g,t\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq22.gif) is a polynomial in t of degree equal to the dimension of V. We will denote ![
$$P_{\\rho }^{\\vee }\(g\) = P_{\\rho }^{\\vee }\(g,1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq23.gif) and ![
$$P_{\\rho }^{\\wedge }\(g\) = P_{\\rho }^{\\wedge }\(g,1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq24.gif). Then we specialize t = 1 in (44.1) and write

![
$$\\displaystyle{ P_{\\rho }^{\\vee }\(g\) =\\prod _{ i}{\(1 - \\gamma _{i}\)}^{-1},\\qquad P_{ \\rho }^{\\wedge }\(g\) =\\prod _{ i}\(1 + \\gamma _{i}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(44.2)

For the first equation, this is understood to be an analytic continuation since the series defining ![
$$P_{\\rho }^{\\vee }$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq25.gif) might not converge when t = 1.

Let ![
$$V = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n}$$

](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq27123.gif) -module in the usual way. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\vee }^{k}\({\\vee }^{2}V \)\\mathop{\\cong}\\left\({\\bigotimes }^{2k}\\;V \\right\) \\otimes _{ \\mathbb{C}\[S_{2k}\]}\\omega _{2k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equc.gif)

as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) -modules. It is the direct sum of the π λ as λ runs through all even partitions of k.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\mathbb{C}_{\\mathrm{trivial}}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) denote ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) denoted as a trivial module of ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\[B_{2k}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq31123.gif). It is sufficient to prove that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ {\\vee }^{k}\({\\vee }^{2}V \)\\mathop{\\cong}\\left\({\\bigotimes }^{2k}V \\right\) \\otimes _{ \\mathbb{C}\[B_{2k}\]}\\mathbb{C}_{\\mathrm{trivial}} }$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(44.3)

as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq322132.gif)-modules. Indeed, assuming this, the right-hand side is isomorphic to

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{c} \\left\(\\left\({\\bigotimes }^{2k}V \\right\) \\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}\[S_{2k}\]}\\mathbb{C}_{\[S_{2k}\]}\\right\) \\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}\[B_{2k}\]}\\mathbb{C}_{\\mathrm{trivial}}\\mathop{\\cong} \\\\ \\left\({\\bigotimes }^{2k}V \\right\) \\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}\[S_{2k}\]}\\left\(\\mathbb{C}_{\[S_{2k}\]} \\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}\[B_{2k}\]}\\mathbb{C}_{\\mathrm{trivial}}\\right\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\left\({\\bigotimes }^{2k}V \\right\) \\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}\[S_{2k}\]}\\omega _{2k}.\\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equd.gif)

To prove (44.3), we will use the universal properties of the symmetric power and tensor products to construct inverse maps

![
$$\\displaystyle{{\\vee }^{k}\({\\vee }^{2}V \)\\longleftrightarrow \\left\({\\bigotimes }^{2k}V \\right\) \\otimes _{ \\mathbb{C}\[B_{2k}\]}\\mathbb{C}_{\\mathrm{trivial}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Eque.gif)

Here ![
$$B_{2k} \\subset S_{2k}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq33123.gif) acts on ![
$${\\bigotimes }^{k}V$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq34123.gif) on the right by the action (34.​1).

First, we note that the map

$$\\displaystyle{\(v_{1},\\ldots,v_{2k}\)\\longmapsto \(v_{1} \\vee v_{2}\) \\vee \\cdots \\vee \(v_{2k-1} \\vee v_{2k}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equf.gif)

commutes with the right action of B 2k . It is 2k-linear and hence induces a map

$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha:{ \\bigotimes }^{2k}V \\longrightarrow {\\vee }^{k}\({\\vee }^{2}V \),\\qquad\\alpha \(v_{ 1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes v_{2k}\) = \(v_{1} \\vee v_{2}\) \\vee \\cdots \\vee \(v_{2k-1} \\vee v_{2k}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equg.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left\({\\bigotimes }^{2k}V \\right\) \\times \\mathbb{C}_{\\mathrm{ trivial}}\\longrightarrow {\\vee }^{k}\({\\vee }^{2}V \),\\qquad \(\\xi,t\)\\mapsto t\\alpha \(\\xi \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equh.gif)

](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq35.gif)-balanced and there is an induced map

](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equi.gif)

As for the other direction, we first note that for ![
$$v_{3},v_{4},\\ldots,v_{2k}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq36.gif) fixed, using the fact that ![
$$\\otimes _{\\mathbb{C}\[B_{2k}\]}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq37.gif)is B 2k -balanced, the map

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(v_{1},v_{2}\)\\longmapsto \(v_{1} \\otimes v_{2} \\otimes v_{3} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes v_{2k}\) \\otimes 1 \\in \\left\({\\bigotimes }^{2k}V \\right\) \\otimes _{ \\mathbb{C}\[B_{2k}\]}\\mathbb{C}_{\\mathrm{trivial}}}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equj.gif)

is symmetric and bilinear, so there is induced a map

](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Now with ![
$$\\xi _{1} \\in {\\vee }^{2}V$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq38.gif) and v 5,..., v 2k fixed, the map

](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equm.gif)

With ![
$$v_{5},\\ldots,v_{2k}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq39.gif) fixed, denote by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mu _{v_{5},\\ldots,v_{2k}}: {\\vee }^{2}V \\times {\\vee }^{2}V \\longrightarrow \\left\({\\bigotimes }^{2k}V \\right\) \\otimes _{ \\mathbb{C}\[B_{2k}\]}\\mathbb{C}_{\\mathrm{trivial}}}$$

the map ![

A polynomial character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq50.gif) is one with matrix coefficients that are polynomials in the coordinates functions g ij not involving det−1. As we know, they are exactly the characters of πλ where ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{n}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq51.gif) is a partition. We may express Theorem 44.3 as saying that every polynomial character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq52.gif) occurs exactly once in the algebra ![
$$\\left\(\\bigwedge V \\right\) \\otimes \\bigvee {\(\\bigvee }^{2}V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq53.gif), which is the tensor product of the exterior algebra over V with the symmetric algebra over the exterior square representation.

There are dual forms of these results. Let ![
$$\\tilde{\\omega }_{2k} = \\mathrm{Ind}_{B_{2k}}^{S_{2k}}\(\\varepsilon \)$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq54.gif) be the character of S 2k obtained by inducing the alternating character ![
$$\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq55.gif) from B 2k .

$$\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq61.gif). By Theorem 37.4, this isιω2k , and by Theorems 43.4, and 35.2, this is the sum of the ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq62.gif) with λ t even. □

Theorem 44.5 (D. E. Littlewood).

Let α 1 ,..., α n be complex numbers, |α i | < 1. Then

![
$$\\prod\\limits_{1 \\leqslant i \\leqslant j \\leqslant n} {\(1 - \\alpha _i \\alpha _j \)^{ - 1} = \\sum\\limits_{\\lambda ^t \\,even} {s_\\lambda \(\\alpha 1,...,\\alpha _n \).} }$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(44.5)

The sum is over even partitions.

Proof.

Similar to Theorem 44.2. □

Theorem 44.6 (D. E. Littlewood).

Let α 1 ,..., α n be complex numbers, |α i | < 1. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left\[\\prod _{1\\leqslant i\\leqslant n}{\(1 - \\alpha _{i}\)}^{-1}\\right\]\\left\[\\prod _{ 1\\leqslant i<j\\leqslant n}{\(1 - \\alpha _{i}\\alpha _{j}\)}^{-1}\\right\] =\\sum _{\\mbox{ $ \\begin{array}{c} \\lambda \\end{array} $}}s_{\\lambda }\(\\alpha _{1},\\ldots,\\alpha _{n}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_Equv.gif)

The sum is over all partitions.

Similar to Theorem 44.3, and actually equivalent to Theorem 44.3 using the identity ![
$$\(1 + \\alpha _{i}\){\(1 - \\alpha _{i}^{2}\)}^{-1} = {\(1 - \\alpha _{i}\)}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_44_Chapter_IEq66.gif). □
