# 45. Gelfand Pairs

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

We recall that a representation θ of a compact group G is called multiplicity-free if in its decomposition into irreducibles,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\theta =\\bigoplus _{i}d_{i}\\pi _{i}, }$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(45.1)

each irreducible representation π i occurs with multiplicity d i = 0 or 1. A common situation that we have seen already several times is for a group G ⊃ H to have the property that for some representation τ of H the induced representation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{H}^{G}\(\\tau\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq1.gif) is multiplicity-free.

We recall that a representation θ of a compact group G is called multiplicity-free if in its decomposition into irreducibles,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\theta =\\bigoplus _{i}d_{i}\\pi _{i}, }$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(45.1)

each irreducible representation π i occurs with multiplicity d i = 0 or 1. A common situation that we have seen already several times is for a group G ⊃ H to have the property that for some representation τ of H the induced representation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{H}^{G}\(\\tau\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq2.gif) is multiplicity-free.

In this chapter we will see how the question of showing that a representation is multiplicity-free leads to the consideration of a Hecke algebra. If the Hecke algebra is commutative, the representation is multiplicity free. If it is not commutative, it may also have an interesting structure, as we will see in the next chapter. Another approach to multiplicity-free representations may be seen in Theorem 26.7

Of course, we have only defined induced representations when H and G are finite. Assuming H and G are finite, saying that ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{H}^{G}\(\\tau\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq3.gif) is multiplicity-free means that each irreducible representation π of G, when restricted to H, can contain at most one copy of τ, and formulated this way, the statement makes sense even if H and G are infinite.

The most striking examples we have seen are when ![
$$H = S_{k-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq4.gif) and G = S k and when ![
$$H = \\mathrm{U}\(n - 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq5.gif) and G = U(n). In these examples every irreducible representation τ of H has this "multiplicity one" property. Such examples are fairly rare. A far more common circumstance is for a single representation τ of H to have the multiplicity one property. For example, we showed in Theorem 43.4 that inducing the trivial representation from the group B 2k of S 2k produces a multiplicity-free representation. However, this would not be true for some other irreducible representations.

Proposition 45.1.

Suppose θ is a representation of a finite group G. A necessary and sufficient condition that θ be multiplicity-free is that the ring EndG (θ) be commutative.

Proof.

In the decomposition (45.1), we have ![
$$\\mathrm{End}_{G}\(\\theta\) =\\bigoplus \\mathrm{Mat}_{d_{i}}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq6.gif). This is commutative if and only if all d i ⩽ 1. □

Let G be a group, finite for the time being, and H a subgroup. Then (G,H) is called a Gelfand pair if the representation of G induced by the trivial representation of H is multiplicity-free. We also refer to H as a Gelfand subgroup. More generally, if π is an irreducible representation of H, then (G,H, π) is called a Gelfand triple if π G is multiplicity-free. See Gross [59] for a lively discussion of Gelfand pairs.

From Proposition 45.1, Gelfand pairs are characterized by the commutativity of the endomorphism ring of an induced representation. To study it, we make use of Mackey theory.

Proposition 45.2.

Let G be a finite group, and let ![
$$H_{1},H_{2},H_{3}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq7.gif) be subgroups. Let (π i, V i ) be complex representations of H 1 , H 2 , and H 3 and let ![
$$L_{1}: V _{1}^{G}\\longrightarrow V _{2}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq8.gif) and ![
$$L_{2}: V _{2}^{G}\\longrightarrow V _{3}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq9.gif) be intertwining operators. Let ![
$$\\varDelta _{1}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq10.gif) and ![
$$\\varDelta _{2}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{2},V _{3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq11.gif) correspond to L 1 and L 2 as in Theorem 32.1 . Then ![
$$\\varDelta _{2} {\\ast}\\varDelta _{1}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(V _{1},V _{3}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq12.gif) corresponds to ![
$$L_{2} \\circ L_{1}: V _{1}^{G}\\longrightarrow V _{3}^{G}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq13.gif) , where the convolution is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta _{2} {\\ast}\\varDelta _{1}\(g\) =\\sum _{\\gamma \\in H_{2}\\setminus G}\\varDelta _{2}\(g{\\gamma }^{-1}\) \\circ \\varDelta _{ 1}\(\\gamma\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

Proof.

Note that, using (32.​9), the summand ![
$$\\varDelta _{2}\(g{\\gamma }^{-1}\)\\varDelta _{1}\(\\gamma\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq14.gif) does not depend on the choice of representative ![
$$\\gamma \\in H_{2}\\setminus G$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq15.gif). The result is easily checked. □

Theorem 45.1.

Let H be a subgroup of the finite group G, and let (π, V) be a representation of H. Then (G,H, π) is a Gelfand triple if and only if the convolution algebra ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq16.gif) of functions ![
$$\\varDelta: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{End}_{\\mathbb{C}}\(V\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq17.gif) satisfying

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varDelta \(h_{2}gh_{1}\) = \\pi \(h_{2}\) \\circ \\varDelta \(g\) \\circ \\pi \(h_{1}\),\\qquad h_{1},h_{2} \\in H,}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

is commutative.

We call a convolution ring ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq18.gif) of this type a Hecke algebra.

Proof.

By Proposition 45.2, this condition is equivalent to the commutativity of the endomorphism ring ![
$$\\mathrm{End}_{G}\({V }^{G}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq19.gif), so this follows from Proposition 45.1. □

In this chapter, an involution of a group G is a map ι: G → G of order 2 that is anticommutative:

![
$$\\displaystyle{{}^{\\iota }\(g_{ 1}g_{2}\) {={ }^{\\iota }g_{ 2}\\,}^{\\iota }g_{ 1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

Similarly, an involution of a ring R is an additive map of order 2 that is anticommutative for the ring multiplication.

A common method of proving that such a ring is commutative is to exhibit an involution and then show that this involution reduces to the identity map.

Theorem 45.2.

Let H be a subgroup of the finite group G, and suppose that G admits an involution fixing H such that every double coset of H is invariant: HgH = H ι g H. Then H is a Gelfand subgroup.

Proof.

The ring ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq20.gif) of Theorem 45.1 is just the convolution ring of H-bi-invariant functions on G. We have an involution on this ring:

![
$$\\displaystyle{{}^{\\iota }\\varDelta \(g\) =\\varDelta {\(}^{\\iota }g\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

It is easy to check that

![
$$\\displaystyle{{}^{\\iota }\(\\varDelta _{ 1} {\\ast}\\varDelta _{2}\) {= }^{\\iota }\\varDelta _{ 2} {{\\ast}}^{\\iota }\\varDelta _{ 1}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

On the other hand, each Δ is constant on each double coset, and these are invariant under ι by hypothesis, so ι is the identity map. This proves that ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq21.gif) is commutative, so (G,H) is a Gelfand pair. □

Let S n denote the symmetric group. We can embed ![
$$S_{n} \\times S_{m} \\rightarrow S_{n+m}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq22.gif) by letting S n act on the first n elements of the set {1,2,3,..., n \+ m} and letting S m act on the last m elements.

Proposition 45.3.

The subgroup ![
$$S_{n} \\times S_{m}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq23.gif) is a Gelfand subgroup of S n+m .

We already know this: the representation of S n+m induced from the trivial character of S n × S m is the product in the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq24.gif) of h n by h m . By Pieri's formula, one computes, assuming without loss of generality that n > m,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{h}_{n}\\mathbf{h}_{m} =\\sum _{ k=0}^{m}\\mathbf{s}_{ \(n+m-k,k\)}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

Thus, the induced representation is multiplicity-free. We prove this again to illustrate Theorem 45.2.

Proof.

Let H = S n × S m and ![
$$G = S_{n+m}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq25.gif). We take the involution ι in Theorem 45.2 to be the inverse map ![
$$g\\longrightarrow {g}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq26123.gif). We must check that each double coset is ι-stable.

It will be convenient to represent elements of S n+m by permutation matrices. We will show that each double coset HgH has a representative of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} I_{r}& 0 & 0 & 0 \\\\ 0 &0_{n-r}& 0 &I_{n-r} \\\\ 0 & 0 &I_{m-n+r}& 0 \\\\ 0 &I_{n-r}& 0 &0_{n-r} \\end{array} \\right\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

(45.2)

Here I n and 0 n are the n × n identity and zero matrices, and the remaining 0 matrices are rectangular blocks.

We start with g in block form,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

where A, B, C, and D are subpermutation matrices—that is, matrices with only 1's and 0's, and with at most one nonzero entry in each row and column. Here A is n × n and D is m × m. Let r be the rank of A. Then clearly B and C both must have rank n − r, and so D has rank ![
$$m - n + r$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq27123.gif).

Multiplying A on the left by an element of S n , we may arrange its rows so that its nonzero entries lie in the first r rows. Then multiplying on the right by an element of S n , we may put these in the upper left-hand corner. Similarly, we may arrange that D has its nonzero entries in the upper left-hand corner. Now the form of the matrix is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} T_{r}& 0 & 0 & 0 \\\\ 0 & 0_{n-r} & 0 &U_{n-r} \\\\ 0 & 0 &V _{m-n+r}& 0 \\\\ 0 &W_{n-r}& 0 & 0_{n-r} \\end{array} \\right\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

where the sizes of the square blocks are indicated by subscripts. The matrices T, U, V, and W are permutation matrices (invertible). Left multiplication by element of ![
$$S_{r} \\times S_{n-r} \\times S_{m-n+r} \\times S_{n-r}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq28123.gif) can now replace these four matrices by identity matrices. This proves that (45.2) is a complete set of double coset representatives.

Since these double coset representatives are all invariant under the involution, by Theorem 45.2 it follows that S n × S m is a Gelfand subgroup. □

Proposition 45.4.

Suppose that (G,H, ψ) is a Gelfand triple, and let (π, V) be an irreducible representation of G. Then there exists at most one space ![
$$\\mathcal{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq29123.gif) of functions on G satisfying

![
$$\\displaystyle{ M\(hg\) = \\psi \(h\)M\(g\),\\qquad \\quad \(h \\in H\)\\,, }$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

(45.3)

such that ![
$$\\mathcal{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq30123.gif) is closed under right translation and such that the representation of G on ![
$$\\mathcal{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq31123.gif) by right translation is isomorphic to π.

The space ![
$$\\mathcal{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq32123.gif) is called a model of π, meaning a concrete realization of the representation in a space of functions on G.

Proof.

This is just the Frobenius reciprocity. The space of functions satisfying (45.3) is ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{H}^{G}\(\\psi\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq33123.gif), so ![
$$\\mathcal{M}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq34123.gif), if it exists, is the image of an element of ![
$$\\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\\big\(V,\\mathrm{Ind}_{H}^{G}\(\\psi\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq35.gif). This is one-dimensional since the induced representation is assumed to be multiplicity-free. □

We turn now to Gelfand pairs in compact groups. We will obtain a result similar to Theorem 45.1 by a different method.

Let C(G) be the space of continuous functions on the compact group G. It is a ring (without unit) under convolution. If ![
$$ \\phi \\in C\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq0035.gif), and if (π, V) is a finite-dimensional representation, let ![
$$\\pi \(\\phi\): V \\longrightarrow V$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq36.gif) denote the endomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi \(\\phi\)\\,v =\\int _{G}\\phi \(g\)\\,\\pi \(g\)\\,v\\,\\mathrm{d}g.}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ13.gif)

One checks easily that if ![
$$ \\phi,\\psi \\in C\(G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq0036.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi \(\\phi {\\ast} \\psi\) = \\pi \(\\phi\) \\circ \\pi \(\\psi\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ14.gif)

Let H be a closed subgroup of G. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq37.gif) be the subring of C(G) consisting of functions that are both left- and right-invariant under H. If (π, V) is a representation of G, let V H denote the space of H-fixed vectors.

Theorem 45.3.

Let H be a closed subgroup of the compact group G. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq38.gif) be the subring of C(G) consisting of functions that are both left- and right-invariant under H. If ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq39.gif) is commutative, then V H is at most one-dimensional for every irreducible representation (π, V) of G.

In this case, extending the definition from the case of finite groups, we say (G,H) is a Gelfand pair or that H is a Gelfand subgroup of G.

Proof.

Let ξ,η ∈ V H . For g ∈ G, let

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\phi _{\\xi,\\eta }\(g\) = \\overline{\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)\\xi,\\eta \\right \\rangle },}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ15.gif)

where ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq40.gif) is an invariant inner product on V (Proposition 2.1). It is easy to see that ![
$$\\phi _{\\xi,\\eta } \\in \\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq41.gif). We will prove that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\pi \(\\phi _{\\xi,\\eta }\)\\,v = \\tfrac{1} {\\dim \(V\)}\\left \\langle v,\\xi \\right \\rangle \\,\\eta. }$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ16.gif)

(45.4)

Indeed, taking the inner product of the left-hand side with an arbitrary vector θ ∈ V, Schur orthogonality (Theorem 2.4) gives

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\begin{array}{ll} \\,\\left \\langle \\pi \(\\phi _{\\xi,\\eta }\)v,\\theta \\right \\rangle & =\\int _{G}\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)\\,v,\\theta \\right \\rangle \\overline{\\left \\langle \\pi \(g\)\\xi,\\eta \\right \\rangle }\\mathrm{d}g\\end{array} & =& \\tfrac{1} {\\dim \(V\)}\\left \\langle v,\\xi \\right \\rangle \\left \\langle \\eta,\\theta \\right \\rangle,{}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ17.gif)

and since this is true for every θ, we have (45.4).

Now we show that the image of ![
$$\\pi \(\\phi _{\\eta,\\xi } {\\ast} \\phi _{\\xi,\\eta }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq42.gif) is ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\\eta $$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq43.gif). Indeed, applying (45.4) twice, we see that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi \(\\phi _{\\eta,\\xi } {\\ast} \\phi _{\\xi,\\eta }\)\\,v = \\pi \(\\phi _{\\eta,\\xi }\) \\circ \\pi \(\\phi _{\\xi,\\eta }\)\\,v = \\tfrac{1} {\\dim {\(V\)}^{2}} \\left \\langle v,\\xi \\right \\rangle \\left \\langle \\eta,\\eta \\right \\rangle \\,\\xi.}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ18.gif)

The image of this is contained in the linear span of η, and taking v = ξ shows that the map is nonzero. Since ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq44.gif) is assumed commutative, this also equals ![
$$\\pi \(\\phi _{\\xi,\\eta } {\\ast} \\phi _{\\eta,\\xi }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq45.gif). Hence, its image is also equal to ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\\,\\xi $$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq46.gif), and so we see that ξ and η both belong to the same one-dimensional subspace of V. □

To give an example where we can verify the hypotheses of Theorem 45.3, let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SO}\(n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq47.gif), and let H = SO(n), which we embed into the upper left-hand corner of G:

![
$$\\displaystyle{g\\longmapsto \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,g\\,&0\\\\ 0 &\\,1\\, \\end{array} \\right\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ19.gif)

We also embed K = SO(2) into the lower right-hand corner:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a & b\\\\ - b &a \\end{array} \\right\)\\longmapsto \\left \(\\begin{array}{c} \\begin{array}{|c|c|} \\hline I_{n-1}& 0 \\\\ \\hline 0 &\\begin{array}{cc} a &b\\\\ - b &a \\end{array} \\\\ \\hline  \\end{array} \\end{array} \\right\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ20.gif)

(45.5)

Proposition 45.5.

With ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SO}\(n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq48.gif) , H = SO (n), and K = SO (2) embedded as explained above, every double coset in ![
$$H\\setminus G/H$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq49.gif) has a representative in K.

Proof.

Let g ∈ G. Write the last column of g in the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{c} bv_{1} \\\\ bv_{2}\\\\ \\vdots \\\\ bv_{n} \\\\ a\\end{array} \\right\) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{c} bv\\\\ a\\end{array} \\right\),v = \\left \(\\begin{array}{c} v_{1}\\\\ \\vdots \\\\ v_{n} \\end{array} \\right\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ21.gif)

where ![
$${b}^{2} + {a}^{2} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq50.gif) and v has length 1. Complete v to an orthogonal matrix h ∈ H. Then it is simple to check that the last column of h −1 g is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{c} 0\\\\ \\vdots\\\\ 0 \\\\ b\\\\ a \\end{array} \\right\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ22.gif)

so with k the matrix in (45.5), the last column of ![
$${k}^{-1}{h}^{-1}g$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq51.gif) is

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\xi _{0} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{c} 0\\\\ \\vdots\\\\ 0 \\\\ 1 \\end{array} \\right\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ23.gif)

(45.6)

This implies that ![
$${k}^{-1}{h}^{-1}g \\in \\mathrm{O}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq52.gif), so g and k lie in the same double coset. □

Theorem 45.4.

The subgroup SO (n) of SO (n \+ 1) is a Gelfand subgroup.

Proof.

With ![
$$G = \\mathrm{SO}\(n + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq53.gif), H = SO(n), and K = SO(2) embedded as explained above, we exhibit an involution of G, namely

![
$$\\displaystyle{g\\mapsto {\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I_{n}& \\\\ & - 1 \\end{array} \\right\)}^{t}g\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I_{n}& \\\\ & - 1 \\end{array} \\right\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ24.gif)

This involution maps H to itself and is the identity on matrices in O(2). Hence, the involution of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq54.gif) that it induces is the identity, and ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq55.gif) is therefore commutative. □

Now let us think a bit about what this means in concrete terms. The quotient G∕H may be identified with the sphere S n . Indeed, thinking of S n as the unit sphere in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{n+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq56.gif), G acts transitively and H is the stabilizer of a point in S n .

Consequently, we have an action of G on L 2(S n ), and this may be thought of as the representation induced from the trivial representation of O(n).

Theorem 45.5.

Let (π, V) be an irreducible representation of O (n \+ 1). Then there exists at most one subspace of L 2 (S n ) that is invariant under the action of O (n \+ 1) and affords a representation isomorphic to π.

This gives us a concrete model for at least some representations of O(n \+ 1).

Proof.

Let ϕ: V → L 2(S n ) be an intertwining operator. It is sufficient to show that ϕ is uniquely determined up to a constant multiple. The O(n \+ 1)-equivariance of ϕ amounts to the formula

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\phi \\big\(\\pi \(g\)\\,v\\big\)\(x\) = \\phi \(v\)\({g}^{-1}x\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ25.gif)

(45.7)

for g ∈O(n \+ 1), v ∈ V, and x ∈ S n .

Let ![
$$\\left \\langle \\cdot,\\cdot \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq57.gif) be an invariant Hermitian form on V. This form is nondegenerate, so each linear functional on V is of the form ![
$$v \\rightarrow \\left \\langle v,\\eta \\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq58.gif) for some vector η. In particular, with ξ0 ∈ S n as in (45.6), there exists a vector η ∈ V such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\phi \(v\)\(\\xi _{0}\) = \\left \\langle v,\\eta \\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ26.gif)

By (45.7), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\phi \(v\)\\big\(\\pi \(g\)\\,\\xi _{0}\\big\) = \\left \\langle \\pi \({g}^{-1}\)v,\\eta \\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle v,\\pi \(g\)\\eta \\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_Equ27.gif)

This makes it clear that ϕ is determined by η, and it also shows that η is O(n)-invariant since ξ0 ∈ S n is O(n)-fixed. Since the space of O(n)-fixed vectors is at most one-dimensional, the theorem is proved. □

Proposition 45.6.

If g ∈ U (n), then there exist k 1 and k 2 ∈ O(n) such that k 1 gk 2 is diagonal.

Proof.

Let x = g t g. This is a unitary symmetric matrix. By Proposition 28.2, there exists k 1 ∈ O(n) such that ![
$$k_{1}xk_{1}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq59.gif) is diagonal. It is unitary, so its diagonal entries have absolute value 1. Taking their square roots, we find a unitary diagonal matrix d such that ![
$$k_{1}xk_{1}^{-1} = {d}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq60.gif). This means that ![
$${\({d}^{-1}k_{1}g\)}^{t}\({d}^{-1}k_{1}g\) = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq61.gif), so ![
$$k_{2}^{-1} = {d}^{-1}k_{1}g$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq62.gif) is orthogonal and ![
$$k_{1}gk_{2} = d$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq63.gif). □

Theorem 45.6.

The group O (n) is a Gelfand subgroup of U (n).

Proof.

Let G = U(n) and H = O(n), and let ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq64.gif) be the ring of Theorem 45.3. The transpose involution of G preserves H and thus induces an involution of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq65.gif). By Proposition 45.6, every double coset in ![
$$H\\setminus G/H$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq66.gif) has a diagonal representative, so this involution is the identity map, and it follows that ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_45_Chapter_IEq67.gif) is commutative. Therefore, H is a Gelfand subgroup. □

Exercises

Exercise 45.1.

Let G be any compact group. Let H = G × G, and embed G into H diagonally, that is, by the map g↦(g, g). Use the involution method to prove that G is a Gelfand subgroup of H.

Exercise 45.2.

Use the involution method to show that O(n) is a Gelfand subgroup of U(n).

Exercise 45.3.

Show that each irreducible representation of O(3) has an O(2)-fixed vector, and deduce that L 2(S 2) is the (Hilbert space) direct sum of all irreducible representations of O(3), each with multiplicity one.

# 46. Hecke Algebras

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In this chapter, we will contemplate how Lie groups embed in one another. Our aim is not to be systematic or even completely precise but to give the reader some tools for thinking about the relationships between different Lie groups.

A Coxeter group (Chap.​ 25) is a group W which may be given the following description. The group W has generators s i (i = 1,2,...,r) with relations ![
$$s_{i}^{2} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq1.gif) and for each pair of indices i and j the "braid relations"

![
$$\\displaystyle{s_{i}s_{j}s_{i}\\cdots = s_{j}s_{i}s_{j}\\cdots }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equa.gif)

where the number of terms on both sides is the same integer n(i, j). An example is the symmetric group S k , where s i is the transposition (i,i \+ 1). In this case ![
$$r = k - 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq2.gif).

Given a Coxeter group W, we may deform its group algebra as follows. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{H}\(W\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq3.gif) be the ring with generators t i satisfying the same braid relations

![
$$\\displaystyle{t_{i}t_{j}t_{i}\\cdots = t_{j}t_{i}t_{j}\\cdots \\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equb.gif)

but we replace the relation ![
$$s_{i}^{2} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq4.gif) by a more general relation

![
$$\\displaystyle{t_{i}^{2} = \(q - 1\)t_{i} + q.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equc.gif)

The parameter q may be a complex number or an indeterminate. If q = 1, we recover the group algebra of W.

Hecke algebras are ubiquitous. They arise in various seemingly different ways: as endomorphism rings of induced representations for the groups of Lie type such as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq5.gif) (Iwahori [84], Howlett and Lehrer [80]); as convolution rings of functions on p-adic groups (Iwahori and Matsumoto [86]); as rings of operators acting on the equivariant K-theory of flag varieties (Lusztig [122], Kazhdan and Lusztig [98]); as rings of transfer matrices in statistical mechanics and quantum mechanics (Temperley and Lieb [160], Jimbo [90]), in knot theory (Jones [91]), and other areas. It is the context for defining the Kazhdan–Lusztig polynomials, which occur in seemingly unrelated questions in representation theory, geometry and combinatorics [97]. Some of these different occurrences of Hecke algebras may seem unrelated to each other, but this can be an illusion when in fact deep and surprising connections exist.

Following Iwahori [84], we will study a certain "Hecke algebra" ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq6.gif) that, as we will see, is isomorphic to the Hecke algebra of the symmetric group S k . The ring ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq7.gif) can actually be defined if q is any complex number, but if q is a prime power, it has a representation-theoretic interpretation. We will see that it is the endomorphism ring of the representation of ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq8.gif), where ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq9.gif) is the finite field with q elements, induced from the trivial representation of the Borel subgroup B of upper triangular matrices in G. The fact that it is a deformation of ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\[S_{k}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq10.gif) amounts to a parametrization of a certain set of irreducible representations of G—the so-called unipotent ones—by partitions.

If instead of ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq11.gif) we take ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{Q}_{p}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq12.gif), where ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}_{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq13.gif) is the p-adic field, and we take B to be the Iwahori subgroup consisting of elements g of ![
$$K = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{Z}_{p}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq14.gif) that are upper triangular modulo p, then one obtains the affine Hecke algebra, which is similar to ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq15.gif) but infinite-dimensional. It was introduced by Iwahori and Matsumoto [86]. The role of the Bruhat decomposition in the proofs requires a generalization of the Tits' system described in Iwahori [85]. This Hecke algebra contains a copy of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(p\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq16.gif). On the other hand, it also contains the ring of K-bi-invariant functions, the so-called spherical Hecke algebra (Satake [143], Tamagawa [158]). The spherical Hecke algebra is commutative since K is a Gelfand subgroup of G. The spherical Hecke algebra is (when k = 2) essentially the portion corresponding to the prime p of the original Hecke algebra introduced by Hecke [65] to explain the appearance of Euler products as the L-series of automorphic forms. See Howe [76] and Rogawski [137] for the representation theory of the affine Hecke algebra.

Let F be a field. Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq17.gif) and, as in Chap.​ 27, let B be the Borel subgroup of upper triangular matrices in G. A subgroup P containing B is called a standard parabolic subgroup. (More generally, any conjugate of a standard parabolic subgroup is called parabolic.)

Let k 1,...,k r be positive integers such that ![
$$\\sum _{i}k_{i} = k$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq18.gif). Then S k has a subgroup isomorphic to ![
$$S_{k_{1}} \\times \\cdots \\times S_{k_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq19.gif) in which the first ![
$$S_{k_{1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq20.gif) acts on ![
$$\\{1,\\ldots,k_{1}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq21.gif), the second ![
$$S_{k_{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq22.gif) acts on ![
$$\\{k_{1} + 1,\\ldots,k_{1} + k_{2}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq23.gif), and so forth. Let Σ denote the set of k − 1 transpositions ![
$$\\{\(1,2\),\(2,3\),\\ldots,\(k - 1,k\)\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq24.gif).

Lemma 46.1.

Let J be any subset of Σ. Then there exist integers k 1 ,...,k r such that the subgroup of S k generated by J is ![
$$S_{k_{1}} \\times \\cdots \\times S_{k_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq25.gif).

Proof.

If J contains ![
$$\(1,2\),\(2,3\),\\ldots,\(k_{1} - 1,k_{1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq26856.gif), then the subgroup they generate is the symmetric group ![
$$S_{k_{1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq27632.gif) acting on ![
$$\\{1,\\ldots,k_{1}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq28485.gif). Taking k 1 as large as possible, assume that J omits ![
$$\(k_{1},k_{1} + 1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq296523.gif). Taking k 2 as large as possible such that J contains ![
$$\(k_{1} + 1,k_{1} + 2\),\\ldots,\(k_{1} + k_{2} - 1,k_{1} + k_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq304856.gif), the subgroup they generate is the symmetric group ![
$$S_{k_{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq31865.gif) acting on ![
$$\\{k_{1} + 1,\\ldots,k_{1} + k_{2}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq32452.gif), and so forth. Thus J contains generators of each factor in ![
$$S_{k_{1}} \\times \\cdots \\times S_{k_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq33652.gif) and does not contain any element that is not in this product, so this is the group it generates. □

The notations from Chap.​ 27 will also be followed. Let T be the maximal torus of diagonal elements in G, N the normalizer of T, and ![
$$W = N/T$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq34862.gif) the Weyl group. Moreover, Φ will be the set of all roots, Φ + the positive roots, and Σ the simple positive roots. Concretely, elements of Φ are the k 2 − k rational characters of T of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\alpha _{ij}\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\,t_{1}\\, & & \\\\ & \\,\\ddots\\, & \\\\ & & \\,t_{n}\\, \\end{array} \\right \) = t_{i}t_{j}^{-1},}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equd.gif)

where ![
$$1 \\leqslant i,j \\leqslant n$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq35.gif), Φ + consists of ![
$$\\{\\alpha _{ij}\\,\\big\\vert \\,i <j\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq36.gif), and ![
$$\\varSigma =\\{\\alpha _{i,i+1}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq37.gif). Identifying W with S k , the set Σ in Lemma 46.1 is then the set of simple reflections.

Let J be any subset of Σ. Let W J be the subgroup of W generated by the s α with α ∈Σ. Then, by Lemma 46.1, we have (for suitable k i )

![
$$\\displaystyle{W_{J}\\mathop{\\cong}S_{k_{1}} \\times \\cdots \\times S_{k_{r}}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(46.1)

Let N J be the preimage of W J in N under the canonical projection to W. Let P J be the group generated by B and N J . Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{P_{J} = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} G_{11} & G_{12} & \\cdots &G_{1r} \\\\ 0 &G_{22} & \\cdots &G_{2r}\\\\ \\vdots & & \\ddots & \\vdots \\\\ 0 & 0 &\\cdots &G_{rr} \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\}, }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(46.2)

where each G ij is a k i × k j block. The group P J is a semidirect product ![
$$P_{J} = M_{J}U_{J} = U_{J}M_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq38.gif), where M J is characterized by the condition that G ij = 0 unless i = j, and the normal subgroup U J is characterized by the condition that each G ii is a scalar multiple of the identity matrix in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k_{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq39.gif). The groups P J with J a proper subset of Σ are called the standard parabolic subgroups, and more generally any subgroup conjugate to a P J is called parabolic. The subgroup U J is the unipotent radical of P J (that is, its maximal normal unipotent subgroup), and M J is called the standard Levi subgroup of P J . Evidently,

![
$$\\displaystyle{M_{J}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{GL}\(k_{1},F\) \\times \\cdots \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(k_{r},F\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(46.3)

Any subgroup conjugate in P J to M J (which is not normal) would also be called a Levi subgroup.

As in Chap.​ 27, we note that a double coset ![
$$B\\omega B$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq40.gif), or more generally P I ωP J with ![
$$I,J \\subset \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq41.gif), does not depend on the choice ω ∈ N of representative for an element w ∈ W, and we will use the notation BwB = C(w) or P I wP J for this double coset. Let ![
$$B_{J} = M_{J} \\cap B$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq42.gif). This is the standard "Borel subgroup" of M J .

Proposition 46.1.

(i)

Let ![
$$J \\subseteq \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq43.gif) . Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{M_{J} =\\bigcup _{w\\in W_{J}}B_{J}wB_{J}\\quad \(\\mathrm{disjoint}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Eque.gif)

(ii)

Let ![
$$I,J \\subseteq \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq44.gif) . Then, if ![
$$w \\in W$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq45.gif) , we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{BW_{I}wW_{J}B = P_{I}wP_{J}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(46.4)

(iii)

The canonical map ![
$$w\\longmapsto P_{I}wP_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq46.gif) from ![
$$W\\longrightarrow P_{I}\\setminus G/P_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq47.gif) induces a bijection

![
$$\\displaystyle{W_{I}\\setminus W/W_{J}\\mathop{\\cong}P_{I}\\setminus G/P_{J}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Proof.

For (i), we have (46.3) for suitable k i . Now B J is the direct product of the Borel subgroups of these ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k_{i},F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq48.gif), and W J is the direct product (46.1). Part (i) follows directly from the Bruhat decomposition for ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq49.gif) as proved in Chap.​ 27.

As for (ii), since ![
$$BW_{I} \\subset P_{I}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq50.gif) and ![
$$W_{J}B \\subset P_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq51.gif), we have ![
$$BW_{I}wW_{J}B \\subseteq P_{I}wP_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq52.gif). To prove the opposite inclusion, we first note that

![
$$\\displaystyle{wBW_{J} \\subseteq BwW_{J}B. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(46.5)

Indeed, any element of ![
$$W_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq53.gif) can be written as ![
$$s_{1}\\cdots s_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq54.gif), where ![
$$s_{i} = s_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq55.gif), with ![
$$\\alpha _{i} \\in J$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq56.gif). Using Axiom TS3 from Chap.​ 27, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{wBs_{1}\\cdots s_{r} \\subset BwBs_{2}\\cdots s_{r}B \\cup Bws_{1}Bs_{2}\\cdots s_{r}B}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equg.gif)

and, by induction on r, both sets on the right are contained in BwW J B. This proves (46.5). A similar argument shows that

![
$$\\displaystyle{W_{I}BwW_{J} \\subseteq BW_{I}wW_{J}B. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(46.6)

Now, using (i),

![
$$\\displaystyle{P_{I}wP_{J} = U_{I}M_{I}wM_{J}U_{J} \\subset U_{I}B_{I}W_{I}B_{I}wB_{J}W_{J}B_{J}U_{J} \\subset BW_{I}BwBW_{J}B.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equh.gif)

Applying (46.5) and (46.6), we obtain ![
$$BW_{I}wW_{J}B \\supseteq P_{I}wP_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq57.gif), whence (46.4).

As for (iii), since by the Bruhat decomposition ![
$$w\\longmapsto BwB$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq58.gif) is a bijection ![
$$W\\longrightarrow B\\setminus G/B$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq59.gif), (46.4) implies that ![
$$w\\longrightarrow P_{I}wP_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq60.gif) induces a bijection ![
$$W_{I}\\setminus W/W_{J}\\longrightarrow P_{I}\\setminus G/P_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq61.gif). □

To proceed further, we will assume that ![
$$F = \\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq62.gif) is a finite field. We recall from Chap.​ 34 that ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq63.gif) denotes the free Abelian group generated by the isomorphism classes of irreducible representations of the symmetric group S k , or, as we sometimes prefer, the additive group of generalized characters. It can be identified with the character ring of S k . However, we do not need its ring structure, only its additive structure and its inner product, in which the distinct isomorphism classes of irreducible representations form an orthonormal basis.

Similarly, let ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq64.gif) be the free Abelian group generated by the isomorphism classes of irreducible representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq65.gif) or equivalently the additive group of generalized characters. Like ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq66.gif), we can make ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq67.gif) into the k-homogeneous part of a graded ring, a point we will take up in the next chapter.

Proposition 46.2.

Let H be a group, and let M 1 and M 2 be subgroups of H. Then in the character ring of H, the inner product of the characters induced from the trivial characters of M 1 and M 2 , respectively, is equal to the number of double cosets in ![
$$M_{1}\\setminus H/M_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq68.gif).

Proof.

By the geometric form of Mackey's theorem (Theorem 32.1), the space of intertwining maps from ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{M_{1}}^{H}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq69.gif) to ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{M_{2}}^{H}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq70.gif) is isomorphic to the space of functions ![
$$\\varDelta: H\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}\(\\mathbb{C}, \\mathbb{C}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq71.gif) that satisfy ![
$$\\varDelta \(m_{2}hm_{1}\) =\\varDelta \(h\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq72.gif) for m i ∈ M i . Of course, a function has this property if and only if it is constant on double cosets, so the dimension of the space of such functions is equal to the number of double cosets. On the other hand, the dimension of the space of intertwining operators equals the inner product in the character ring by (2.7). □

Theorem 46.1.

There is a unique isometry of ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq73.gif) into ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq74.gif) in which for each subset I of Σ the representation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{W_{I}}^{W}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq75.gif) maps to the representation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{P_{I}}^{G}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq76.gif) . This mapping takes irreducible representations to irreducible representations.

Proof.

If ![
$$I \\subseteq \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq77.gif), let χ I denote the character of S k induced from the trivial character of W I , and let ![
$$\\chi _{I}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq78.gif) denote the character of G induced from the trivial character of P I .

We note that the representations χ I of ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq79.gif) span ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq80.gif). Indeed, by the definition of the multiplication in ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq81.gif), inducing the trivial representation from ![
$$S_{k_{1}} \\times \\cdots \\times S_{k_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq82.gif) to S k , where ∑ k i = k, gives the representation denoted

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{h}_{k_{1}}\\mathbf{h}_{k_{2}}\\cdots \\mathbf{h}_{k_{r}}\\,,}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equi.gif)

which is χ I . Expanding the right-hand side of (35.​10) expresses each ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq83.gif) as a linear combination of such representations, and by Theorem 35.1 the ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq84.gif) span ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq85.gif); hence so do the χ I .

We would like to define a map ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{R}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq86.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{I}n_{I}\\chi _{I}\\longmapsto \\sum _{I}n_{I}\\chi _{I}\(q\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(46.7)

where the sum is over subsets of Σ. We need to verify that this is well-defined and an isometry.

By Proposition 46.1, if ![
$$I,J \\subseteq \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq87.gif), the cardinality of ![
$$W_{I}\\setminus W/W_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq88.gif) equals the cardinality of ![
$$P_{I}\\setminus G/P_{J}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq89.gif). By Proposition 46.2, it follows that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\chi _{I},\\chi _{J}\\right \\rangle _{S_{k}} = \\left \\langle \\chi _{I}\(q\),\\chi _{J}\(q\)\\right \\rangle _{\\mathrm{GL}\(k,\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(46.8)

Now, if ![
$$\\sum n_{I}\\chi _{I}\(q\) = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq90.gif), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\left \\langle \\sum _{I}n_{I}\\chi _{I},\\sum _{I}n_{I}\\chi _{I}\\right \\rangle _{S_{k}}& =& \\sum _{I,J}n_{I}n_{J}\\left \\langle \\chi _{I},\\chi _{J}\\right \\rangle _{S_{k}} {}\\\\ & =& \\sum _{I,J}n_{I}n_{J}\\left \\langle \\chi _{I}\(q\),\\chi _{J}\(q\)\\right \\rangle _{\\mathrm{GL}\(k,\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)} {}\\\\ & =& \\left \\langle \\sum _{I}n_{I}\\chi _{I}\(q\),\\sum _{I}n_{I}\\chi _{I}\(q\)\\right \\rangle _{\\mathrm{GL}\(k,\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)} = 0, {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

so ![
$$\\sum n_{I}\\chi _{I} = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq91.gif). Therefore (46.7) is well-defined, and (46.8) shows that it is an isometry.

It remains to be shown that irreducible characters go to irreducible characters. Indeed, if χ is an irreducible character of W = S k , and if ![
$$\\hat{\\chi }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq92.gif) is the corresponding character of ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq93.gif), then ![
$$\\left \\langle \\hat{\\chi },\\hat{\\chi }\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle \\chi,\\chi \\right \\rangle = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq94.gif), so either ![
$$\\hat{\\chi }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq95.gif) or ![
$$-\\hat{\\chi }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq96.gif) is an irreducible character, and it is sufficient to show that ![
$$\\hat{\\chi }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq97.gif) occurs with positive multiplicity in some proper character of G. Indeed, ![
$$\\chi = \\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq98.gif) for some partition λ, and by (35.​10) this means that χ appears with multiplicity one in the character induced from the trivial character of S λ . Consequently, ![
$$\\hat{\\chi }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq99.gif) occurs with multiplicity one in ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{P_{I}}^{G}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq100.gif), where I is any subset of Σ such that ![
$$W_{I}\\mathop{\\cong}S_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq101.gif). This completes the proof. □

If λ is a partition, let ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq102.gif), ![
$$\\mathbf{h}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq103.gif), and ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq104.gif) denote the images of the characters ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq105.gif), ![
$$\\mathbf{h}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq106.gif), and ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq107.gif), respectively, of S k under the isomorphism of Theorem 46.1. Thus ![
$$\\mathbf{h}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq108.gif) is the trivial character. The character ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq109.gif) is called the Steinberg character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq110.gif). The characters ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq111.gif) are the unipotent characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq112.gif). This is not a proper definition of the term unipotent character because the construction as we have described it depends on the fact that the unipotent characters are precisely those that occur in ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{B}^{G}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq113.gif). This is true for ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq114.gif) but not (for example) for ![
$$\\mathrm{Sp}\(4, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq115.gif). See Deligne and Lusztig [41] and Carter [32] for unipotent characters of finite groups of Lie type and Vogan [167] for an extended meditation on unipotent representations.

Proposition 46.3.

As a virtual representation, the alternating character ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq116.gif) of S k admits the following expression:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{e}_{k} =\\sum _{J\\subseteq \\varSigma }{\(-1\)}^{\\vert J\\vert }\\mathrm{Ind}_{W_{J}}^{W}\(1\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equj.gif)

Proof.

We recall that ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{k} = \\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq117.gif), where λ is the partition (1,...,1) of K. The right-hand side of (35.​10) gives

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{e}_{k} = \\left \\vert \\begin{array}{ccccc} \\mathbf{h}_{1} & \\mathbf{h}_{2} & \\mathbf{h}_{3} & \\cdots & \\mathbf{h}_{k} \\\\ 1 &\\mathbf{h}_{1} & \\mathbf{h}_{2} & \\cdots &\\mathbf{h}_{k-1} \\\\ 0 & 1 &\\mathbf{h}_{1} & \\cdots &\\mathbf{h}_{k-2}\\\\ \\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots & & \\vdots \\\\ 0 & 0 & 0 &\\cdots & \\mathbf{h}_{1} \\end{array} \\right \\vert.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equk.gif)

Expanding this gives a sum of exactly 2 k−1 monomials in the ![
$$\\mathbf{h}_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq118.gif), which are in one-to-one correspondence with the subsets J of Σ. Indeed, let J be given, and let ![
$$k_{1},k_{2},k_{3},\\ldots$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq119.gif) be as in Lemma 46.1. Then there is a monomial that has |J| 1's taken from below the diagonal; namely, if ![
$$\\alpha _{i,i+1} \\in \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq120.gif), then there is a 1 taken from the i \+ 1,i position, and there is an ![
$$\\mathbf{h}_{k_{1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq121.gif) taken from the 1,k 1 position, an ![
$$\\mathbf{h}_{k_{2}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq122.gif) taken from the ![
$$k_{1} + 1,k_{1} + k_{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq123.gif) position, and so forth. This monomial equals ![
$${\(-1\)}^{\\vert J\\vert }\\mathbf{h}_{k_{1}}\\mathbf{h}_{k_{2}}\\cdots$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq124.gif), which is (−1)|J| times the character induced from the trivial representation of ![
$$W_{J} = S_{k_{1}} \\times S_{k_{2}} \\times \\cdots$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq125.gif). □

Theorem 46.2.

As a virtual representation, the Steinberg representation ![
$$\\mathbf{e}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq126.gif) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq127.gif) admits the following expression:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{e}_{k}\(q\) =\\sum _{J\\subseteq \\varSigma }{\(-1\)}^{\\vert J\\vert }\\mathrm{Ind}_{P_{J}}^{P}\(1\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equl.gif)

Proof.

This follows immediately from Proposition 46.3 on applying the mapping of Theorem 46.1. □

For our next considerations, there is no reason that F needs to be finite, so we return to the case where ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq128.gif) of a general field F. We will denote by U the group of upper triangular unipotent matrices in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq129.gif).

Proposition 46.4.

Suppose that S is any subset of Φ such that if α ∈ S, then ![
$$-\\alpha \\notin S$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq130.gif), and if α, β ∈ S and α + β ∈Φ, then α + β ∈ S. Let U S be the set of g = (g ij ) in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq131.gif) such that g ii = 1, and if i≠j, then g ij = 0 unless α ij ∈ S. Then U S is a group.

Proof.

Let ![
$$\\tilde{S}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq132.gif) be the set of (i, j) such that the root α ij ∈ S. Translating the hypothesis on S into a statement about ![
$$\\tilde{S}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq133.gif), if ![
$$\(i,j\) \\in \\tilde{S}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq134.gif) we have i < j, and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mbox{if both $\(i,j\)$ and $\(j,k\)$ are in $\\tilde{S}$, then $i\\neq k$ and $\(i,k\) \\in \\tilde{S}$}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(46.9)

From this it is easy to see that if g and h are in U S , then so are g −1 and gh. □

As a particular case, if w ∈ W, then ![
$$S {=\\varPhi }^{+} \\cap {w\\varPhi }^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq135.gif) satisfies the hypothesis of Proposition 46.4, and we denote

![
$$\\displaystyle{U_{{\\varPhi }^{+}\\cap {w\\varPhi }^{-}} = U_{w}^{-}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equm.gif)

Similarly, ![
$$S {=\\varPhi }^{+} \\cap {w\\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq136.gif) meets this hypothesis, and we denote

![
$$\\displaystyle{U_{{\\varPhi }^{+}\\cap {w\\varPhi }^{+}} = U_{w}^{+}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equn.gif)

Finally, let U be the group of all upper triangular unipotent matrices in G, which was denoted N in Chap.​ 27.

Let l(w) denote the length of the Weyl group element, which (as in Chap.​ 20) is the smallest k such that w can be written as a product of k simple reflections.

Proposition 46.5.

Let ![
$$F = \\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq137.gif) be finite, and let w ∈ W. We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert U_{w}^{-}\\vert = {q}^{l\(w\)}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equo.gif)

Proof.

By Propositions 20.2 and 20.5, the cardinality of ![
$$S {=\\varPhi }^{+} \\cap {w{}^{-1}\\varPhi }^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq138.gif) is l(w), so this follows from the definition of U S . □

Proposition 46.6.

Let w ∈ W. The multiplication map ![
$$U_{w}^{+} \\times U_{w}^{-}\\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq139.gif) is bijective.

Proof.

We will prove this if F is finite, the only case we need. In this case ![
$$U_{w}^{+} \\cap U_{w}^{-} =\\{1\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq140.gif) by definition since the sets ![
$${\\varPhi }^{+} \\cap {w\\varPhi }^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq141.gif) and ![
$${\\varPhi }^{+} \\cap {w\\varPhi }^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq142.gif) are disjoint. Thus, if ![
$$u_{1}^{+}u_{1}^{-} = u_{2}^{+}u_{2}^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq143.gif) with ![
$$u_{i}^{\\pm }\\in U_{w}^{\\pm }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq144.gif), then ![
$${\(u_{2}^{+}\)}^{-1}u_{1}^{+} = u_{2}^{-}{\(u_{1}^{-}\)}^{-1} \\in U_{w}^{+} \\cap U_{w}^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq145.gif) so ![
$$u_{1}^{\\pm } = u_{2}^{\\pm }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq146.gif). Therefore, the multiplication map ![
$$U_{w}^{+} \\times U_{w}^{-}\\longrightarrow U$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq147.gif) is injective. To see that it is surjective, note that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert U_{w}^{-}\\vert = {q}^{{\\vert \\varPhi }^{+}\\cap {w\\varPhi }^{-}\\vert },\\vert U_{w}^{+}\\vert = {q}^{{\\vert \\varPhi }^{+}\\cap {w\\varPhi }^{+}\\vert },}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equp.gif)

so the order of ![
$$U_{w}^{+} \\times U_{w}^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq148.gif) is ![
$${q}^{{\\vert \\varPhi }^{+}\\vert } = \\vert U\\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq149.gif), and the surjectivity is now clear. □

We are interested in the size of the double coset BwB. In geometric terms, G∕B can be identified with the space of F-rational points of a projective algebraic variety, and the closure of BwB∕B is an algebraic subvariety in which BwB∕B is an open subset; the dimension of this "Schubert cell" turns out to be l(w).

If ![
$$F = \\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq150.gif), an equally good measure of the size of BwB is its cardinality. It can of course be decomposed into right cosets of B, and its cardinality will be the order of B times the cardinality of the quotient BwB∕B.

Proposition 46.7.

Let ![
$$F = \\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq151.gif) be finite, and let ![
$$w \\in W$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq152.gif) . The order of BwB∕B is q l(w).

Proof.

We will show that ![
$${u}^{-}\\longmapsto {u}^{-}wB$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq153.gif) is a bijection ![
$$U_{w}^{-}\\longrightarrow BwB/B$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq154.gif). The result then follows from Proposition 46.5.

Note that every right coset in BwB∕B is of the form bwB for some b ∈ B. Using Proposition 46.6, we may write b ∈ B uniquely in the form ![
$${u}^{-}{u}^{+}t$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq155.gif) with ![
$${u}^{\\pm }\\in U_{w}^{\\pm }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq156.gif) and ![
$$t \\in T$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq157.gif). Now ![
$${w}^{-1}{u}^{+}tw = {w}^{-1}{u}^{+}w.{w}^{-1}tw \\in B$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq158.gif) because ![
$${w}^{-1}{u}^{+}w \\in U$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq159.gif) and ![
$${w}^{-1}tw \\in T$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq160.gif). Therefore ![
$$bwB = {u}^{-}wB$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq161.gif).

It is now clear that the map ![
$${u}^{-}\\longmapsto {u}^{-}wB$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq162.gif) is surjective. We must show that it is injective; in other words, if ![
$$u_{1}^{-}wB = u_{2}^{-}wB$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq163.gif) for ![
$$u_{i}^{-}\\in U_{w}^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq164.gif), then ![
$$u_{1}^{-} = u_{2}^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq165.gif). Indeed, if ![
$${u}^{-} = {\(u_{1}^{-}\)}^{-1}u_{2}^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq166.gif) then ![
$${w}^{-1}{u}^{-}w \\in B$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq167.gif) from the equality of the double cosets. On the other hand, ![
$${w}^{-1}{u}^{-}w$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq168.gif) is lower triangular by the definition of U w −. It is both upper triangular and lower triangular, and unipotent, so ![
$${u}^{-} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq169.gif). □

With k and q fixed, let ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq170.gif) be the convolution ring of B-bi-invariant functions on G. The dimension of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq171.gif) equals the cardinality of ![
$$B\\setminus G/B$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq172.gif), which is |W| = k! by the Bruhat decomposition. A basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq173.gif) consists of the functions ϕ w (w ∈ W), where ϕ w is the characteristic function of the double coset ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\) = BwB$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq174.gif). We normalize the convolution as follows:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(f_{1} {\\ast} f_{2}\)\(g\) = \\frac{1} {\\vert B\\vert }\\sum _{x\\in G}f_{1}\(x\)f_{2}\({x}^{-1}g\) = \\frac{1} {\\vert B\\vert }\\sum _{x\\in G}f_{1}\(gx\)f_{2}\({x}^{-1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equq.gif)

With this normalization, the characteristic function f 1 of B serves as a unit in the ring.

The ring ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq175.gif) is a normed ring with the L 1 norm. That is, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert f_{1} {\\ast} f_{2}\\vert \\leqslant \\vert f_{1}\\vert \\cdot \\vert f_{2}\\vert,}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equr.gif)

where

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert f\\vert = \\frac{1} {\\vert B\\vert }\\sum _{x\\in G}\\vert f\(x\)\\vert.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equs.gif)

There is also an augmentation map, that is, a ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq176.gif)-algebra homomorphism ![
$$\\epsilon: \\mathcal{H}\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq177.gif) given by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\epsilon \(f\) = \\frac{1} {\\vert B\\vert }\\sum _{x\\in G}f\(x\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equt.gif)

By Proposition 46.7, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\epsilon \(\\phi _{w}\) = {q}^{l\(w\)}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(46.10)

Proposition 46.8.

Let w,w′ ∈ W such that ![
$$l\(ww^{\\prime}\) = l\(w\) + l\(w^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq178.gif) . Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\phi _{ww^{\\prime}} = \\phi _{w}\\phi _{w^{\\prime}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equu.gif)

Proof.

By Proposition 27.1, we have ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(ww^{\\prime}\) = \\mathcal{C}\(w\)\\,\\mathcal{C}\(w^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq179.gif). Therefore ϕ w ∗ ϕ w′ is supported in ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(ww^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq180.gif) and is hence a constant multiple of ϕ ww′. Writing ![
$$\\phi _{w} {\\ast} \\phi _{w^{\\prime}} = c\\phi _{ww^{\\prime}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq181.gif), applying the augmentation ε, and using (46.10), we see that c = 1. □

Proposition 46.9.

Let s ∈ W be a simple reflection. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\phi _{s} {\\ast} \\phi _{s} = q\\phi _{1} + \(q - 1\)\\phi _{s}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equv.gif)

Proof.

By (27.​2), we have ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(s\)\\,\\mathcal{C}\(s\) \\subseteq \\mathcal{C}\(1\) \\cup \\mathcal{C}\(s\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq182.gif). Therefore, there exist constants λ and μ such that ![
$$\\phi _{s} {\\ast} \\phi _{s} = \\lambda \\phi _{1} + \\mu \\phi _{s}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq183.gif). Evaluating both sides at the identity gives λ = q. Now applying the augmentation and using the special cases ε(ϕ s ) = q, ![
$$\\epsilon \(f_{1}\) = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq184.gif) of (46.10), we have ![
$${q}^{2} = \\lambda \\cdot 1 + \\mu \\cdot q = q + \\mu q$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq185.gif), so ![
$$\\mu = q - 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq186.gif). □

Let q be a nonzero element of a field containing ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq187.gif), and let ![
$$R = \\mathbb{C}\[q,{q}^{-1}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq188.gif). Thus q might be a complex number, in which case the ring ![
$$R = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq189.gif) or it might be transcendental over ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq190.gif), in which case the ring R will be the ring of Laurent polynomials over ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq191.gif).

We will define a ring ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq192.gif) as an algebra over R. Specifically, ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq193.gif) is the free ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\[q\]$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq194.gif)-algebra on generators ![
$$f_{s_{\\alpha _{i}}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq195.gif) (![
$$i = 1,\\ldots,k - 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq196.gif)) subject to the relations

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} f_{s_{\\alpha _{i}}}^{2}& =& q + \(q - 1\)f_{s_{\\alpha _{i}}}\\,,{}\\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

(46.11)

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} f_{s_{\\alpha _{i}}} {\\ast} f_{s_{\\alpha _{i+1}}} {\\ast} f_{s_{\\alpha _{i}}}& =& f_{s_{\\alpha _{i+1}}} {\\ast} f_{s_{\\alpha _{i}}} {\\ast} f_{s_{\\alpha _{i+1}}},{}\\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ13.gif)

(46.12)

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} f_{s_{\\alpha _{i}}} {\\ast} f_{s_{\\alpha _{j}}}& =& f_{s_{\\alpha _{i}}} {\\ast} f_{s_{\\alpha _{j}}}\\quad \\mbox{if $\\vert i - j\\vert> 1$.}{}\\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ14.gif)

(46.13)

We note that ![
$$f_{s_{\\alpha }}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq197.gif) is invertible, with inverse ![
$${q}^{-1}f_{\\alpha _{i}} + {q}^{-1} - 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq198.gif), by (46.11).

Although ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq199.gif) is thus defined as an abstract ring, its structure reflects that of the Weyl group W of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq200.gif), which, as we have seen, is a Coxeter group. We recall what this means. Let ![
$$s_{\\alpha _{1}},\\ldots,s_{\\alpha _{k-1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq201.gif) be the simple reflections of W. By Theorem 25.1, the group W has a presentation with generators ![
$$s_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq202.gif) and relations

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} s_{\\alpha _{i}}^{2}& =& 1, {}\\\\ s_{\\alpha _{i}}s_{\\alpha _{i+1}}s_{\\alpha _{i}}& =& s_{\\alpha _{i+1}}s_{\\alpha _{i}}s_{\\alpha _{i+1}},\\quad 1 \\leqslant i \\leqslant k - 2\\,, {}\\\\ s_{\\alpha _{i}}s_{\\alpha _{j}}& =& s_{\\alpha _{j}}s_{\\alpha _{i}}\\quad \\mbox{if $\\vert i - j\\vert> 1$.} {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ15.gif)

Of course, since ![
$$s_{\\alpha _{i}}^{2} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq203.gif), the relation ![
$$s_{\\alpha _{i}}s_{\\alpha _{i+1}}s_{\\alpha _{i}} = s_{\\alpha _{i+1}}s_{\\alpha _{i}}s_{\\alpha _{i+1}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq204.gif) is just another way of writing ![
$${\(s_{\\alpha _{i}}s_{a_{i+1}}\)}^{3} = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq205.gif).

Proposition 46.10.

If q = 1, the Hecke ring ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq206.gif) is isomorphic to the group ring of S k .

Proof.

This is clear from Theorem 25.1 since if q = 1 the defining relations of the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq207.gif) coincide with the Coxeter relations presenting S k . □

Thus ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq208.gif) is a deformation of ![
$$\\mathbb{C}\[S_{k}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq209.gif), and its representation theory is the same as the representation theory of the symmetric group, one might therefore ask whether the Frobenius–Schur duality between the representations of S k and ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq210.gif), which has been a great theme for us, can be extended to representations of this Hecke algebra. The answer is affirmative. The role of ![
$$\\mathrm{U}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq211.gif) is played by a "quantum group," which is not actually a group at all but a Hopf algebra. Frobenius–Schur duality in this quantum context is due to Jimbo [89]. See also Zhang [179].

If w ∈ W is arbitrary, we want to associate an element f w of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq212.gif) extending the definition of the generators. The next result will make this possible. (Of course, f w is already defined if w is a simple reflection.)

Proposition 46.11.

Suppose that w ∈ W with l(w) = r, and suppose that ![
$$w = s_{1}\\cdots s_{r} = s_{1}^{\\prime}\\cdots s_{r}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq213.gif) are distinct decompositions of minimal length into simple reflections. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{f_{s_{1}} {\\ast}\\cdots {\\ast} f_{s_{r}} = f_{s_{1}^{\\prime}} {\\ast}\\cdots {\\ast} f_{s_{r}^{\\prime}}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ16.gif)

(46.14)

Proof.

Let B be the braid group generated by ![
$$u_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq214.gif) parametrized by the simple roots α i , with ![
$$n\(u_{\\alpha _{i}},u_{\\alpha _{j}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq215.gif) equal to the order (2 or 3) of ![
$$s_{\\alpha _{i}}s_{\\alpha _{j}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq216.gif). Let ![
$$s_{i} = s_{\\beta _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq217.gif) and ![
$$s_{i}^{\\prime} = s_{\\gamma _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq218.gif)with ![
$$\\beta _{i},\\gamma _{i} \\in \\varSigma$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq219.gif), and let ![
$$u_{i} = u_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq220.gif), ![
$$u_{i}^{\\prime} = u_{\\beta _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq221.gif) be the corresponding elements of B. By Theorem 25.2, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{u_{1}\\cdots u_{r} = u_{1}^{\\prime}\\cdots u_{r}^{\\prime}\\,. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ17.gif)

(46.15)

Since the ![
$$f_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq222.gif) satisfy the braid relations, there is a homomorphism of B into the group of invertible elements of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq223.gif) such that ![
$$u_{\\alpha _{i}}\\longmapsto f_{\\alpha _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq224.gif). Applying this homomorphism to (46.15), we obtain (46.14). □

If w ∈ W, let ![
$$w = s_{1}\\cdots s_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq225.gif) be a decomposition of w into r = l(w) simple reflections, and define

![
$$\\displaystyle{f_{w} = f_{s_{1}} {\\ast}\\cdots {\\ast} f_{s_{r}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equw.gif)

According to Proposition 46.11, this f w is well-defined.

Theorem 46.3 (Iwahori).

The f w form a basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq226.gif) as a free R-module. Thus, the rank of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq227.gif) is |W|.

Proof.

First, assume that q is transcendental, so that R is the ring of Laurent polynomials in q. We will deduce the corresponding statement when ![
$$q \\in \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq228.gif) at the end.

Let us check that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{w\\in W}Rf_{w} = \\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ18.gif)

(46.16)

It is sufficient to show that this R-submodule is closed under right multiplication by generators f s of W with s a simple reflection. If ![
$$l\(ws\) = l\(w\) + 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq229.gif), then ![
$$f_{w}f_{s} = f_{ws}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq230.gif). On the other hand, if ![
$$l\(ws\) = l\(w\) - 1$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq231.gif), then writing w′ = ws we have ![
$$f_{w}f_{s} = f_{w^{\\prime}s}f_{s} = f_{w^{\\prime}}f_{s}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq232.gif), which by (46.11) is a linear combination of f w′ and ![
$$f_{w^{\\prime}}f_{s} = f_{_{w}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq233.gif).

It remains to be shown that the sum (46.16) is direct. If not, there will be some Laurent polynomials c w (q), not all zero, such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{w}c_{w}\(q\)f_{w} = 0.}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equx.gif)

There exists a rational prime p such that c w (p) are not all zero. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq234.gif) be the convolution ring of B-bi-invariant functions on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{p}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq235.gif). It follows from Propositions 46.8 and 46.9 that (46.11)–(46.13) are all satisfied by the standard generators of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq236.gif), so we have a homomorphism ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq237.gif) mapping each f w to the corresponding generator ϕ w of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq238.gif) and mapping ![
$$q\\longmapsto p$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq239.gif). The images of the f w are linearly independent in ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq240.gif), yet since the c w (p) are not all zero, we obtain a relation of linear independence. This is a contradiction.

The result is proved if q is transcendental. If ![
$$0\\neq q_{0} \\in \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq241.gif), then there is a homomorphism ![
$$R\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq242.gif), and a compatible homomorphism ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q_{0}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq243.gif), in which ![
$$q\\longmapsto q_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq244.gif). What we must show is that the R-basis elements f w remain linearly independent when projected to ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q_{0}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq245.gif). To prove this, we note that in ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq246.gif) we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{f_{w}f_{w^{\\prime}} =\\sum _{w^{\\prime\\prime}\\in W}a_{w,w^{\\prime},w^{\\prime\\prime}}\(q,{q}^{-1}\)f_{w^{\\prime\\prime}},}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equy.gif)

where a w,w′,w″ is a polynomial in q and q −1. We may construct ring ![
$$\\tilde{\\mathcal{H}}_{k}\(q_{0}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq247.gif) over ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq248.gif) with basis elements ![
$$\\tilde{f}_{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq249.gif) indexed by W and specialized ring structure constants ![
$$a_{w,w^{\\prime},w^{\\prime\\prime}}\(q_{0},{q_{0}}^{-1}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq250.gif). The associative law in ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq251.gif) boils down to a polynomial identity that remains true in this new ring, so this ring exists. Clearly, the identities (46.11)–(46.13) are true in the new ring, so there exists a homomorphism ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q_{0}\)\\longrightarrow \\tilde{\\mathcal{H}}_{k}\(q_{0}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq252.gif) mapping the f w to the ![
$$\\tilde{f}_{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq253.gif). Since the ![
$$\\tilde{f}_{w}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq254.gif) are linearly independent, so are the f w in ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q_{0}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq255.gif). □

Let us return to the case where q is a prime power.

Theorem 46.4.

Let q be a prime power. Then the Hecke algebra ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq256.gif) is isomorphic to the convolution ring of B-bi-invariant functions on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq257.gif) , where B is the Borel subgroup of upper triangular matrices in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq258.gif) . In this isomorphism, the standard basis element f w (w ∈ W) corresponds to the characteristic function of the double coset BwB.

Proof.

It follows from Propositions 46.8 and 46.9 that (46.11)–(46.13) are all satisfied by the elements ϕ w in the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq259.gif) of B-bi-invariant functions on ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq260.gif), so there exists a homomorphism ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq261.gif) such that f w ↦ϕ w . Since the ![
$$\\{f_{w}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq262.gif) are a basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq263.gif) and the ϕ w are a basis of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq264.gif), this ring homomorphism is an isomorphism. □

Exercises

Exercise 46.1.

Show that any subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq265.gif) containing B is of the form (46.2).

Exercise 46.2.

For ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(3\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq266.gif), describe ![
$$U_{w}^{+}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq267.gif) and ![
$$U_{w}^{-}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq268.gif) explicitly for each of the six Weyl group elements.

Exercise 46.3.

Let G be a finite group and H a subgroup. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq269.gif) be the "Hecke algebra" of H bi-invariant functions, with multiplication being the convolution product normalized by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(f_{1} {\\ast} f_{2}\)\(g\) = \\frac{1} {\\vert H\\vert }\\sum _{x\\in G}f_{1}\(x\)f_{2}\({x}^{-1}g\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equz.gif)

If ![
$$\(\\pi,\\,V \)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq270.gif) is an irreducible representation of G, let V H be the subspace of H-fixed vectors. Then V H becomes a module over ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq271.gif) with the action

![
$$\\displaystyle{f \\cdot v = \\vert H{\\vert }^{-1}\\sum _{g\\in G}f\(g\)\\pi \(g\)v. }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equ19.gif)

(46.17)

![
$$f \\cdot v = \\vert H{\\vert }^{-1}\\sum _{g\\in G}f\(g\)\\pi \(g\)v$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq272.gif). Show that V H , if nonzero, is irreducible as an ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq273.gif)-module. (Hint: If W is a nonzero invariant subspace of V H , and v ∈ V H , then since V is irreducible, we have ![
$$f_{1} \\cdot w = v$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq274.gif) for some function f 1 on ![
$$G$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq275.gif), where ![
$$f_{1} \\cdot w$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq276.gif) is defined as in (46.17) even though ![
$$f_{1}\\not\\in \\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq277.gif). Show that ![
$$f \\cdot w = v$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq278.gif), where ![
$$f =\\varepsilon {\\ast}f_{1}{\\ast}\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq279.gif) and ![
$$\\varepsilon$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq280.gif) is the characteristic function of H. Observe that ![
$$f \\in \\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq281.gif) and conclude that V H = W.)

Exercise 46.4.

In the setting of Exercise 46.3, show that ![
$$\(\\pi,V \)\\longmapsto {V }^{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq282.gif) is a bijection between the isomorphism classes of irreducible representations of G with V H ≠0 and isomorphism classes of irreducible ![
$$\\mathcal{H}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq283.gif)-modules.

Exercise 46.5.

Show that if (π,V ) is an irreducible representation of ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq284.gif) with character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq285.gif), then the degree of the corresponding representation of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq286.gif) is the degree of the irreducible character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq287.gif) of S k . (Thus, the degree ![
$$d_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq288.gif) of ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq289.gif) is the dimension of V B .) Show that d λ is the multiplicity of ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq290.gif) in ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}_{B}^{G}\(1\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq291.gif).

Exercise 46.6.

Assume that q is a prime. Prove that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathcal{H}_{k}\(q\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\bigoplus _{\\mbox{$\\lambda $ a partition of k}}\\mathrm{Mat}_{d_{\\lambda }}\(\\mathbb{C}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{C}\[S_{k}\].}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equaa.gif)

Exercise 46.7.

Prove that the degree of the irreducible character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq292.gif) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq293.gif) is a polynomial in q whose value when q = 1 is the degree d λ of the irreducible character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq294.gif) of S k .

Exercise 46.8.

An element of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq295.gif) is called semisimple if it is diagonalizable over the algebraic closure of ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq296.gif). A semisimple element is called regular if its eigenvalues are distinct. If λ is a partition of k, let ![
$$c_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq297.gif) be a regular semisimple element of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq298.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{c_{\\lambda } = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\,c_{1}\\, & & \\\\ & \\,\\ddots\\, &\\\\ & & \\,c_{r}\\, \\end{array} \\right \),c_{i} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equab.gif)

and such that the eigenvalues of c i generate ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{\\lambda _{i}}}$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq299.gif). Of course, c λ isn't completely determined by this description. Such a c λ will exist (for k fixed) if q is sufficiently large.

(i)

Show that, if k = 2, then the unipotent characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(2, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq300.gif) have the following values:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}\\hline & \\,c_{\(11\)}\\, & \\,c_{\(2\)}\\, \\\\ \\hline\\,\\mathbf{s}_{\(11\)}\\, & 1 & 1 \\\\ \\hline \\mathbf{s}_{\(2\)} & 1 & - 1 \\\\ \\hline\\end{array} }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_Equac.gif)

Note that this is the character table of S 2.

(ii)

More generally, prove that in the notation of Chap.​ 37, the value of the character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq301.gif) on the conjugacy class c λ of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq302.gif) equals the value of the character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\mu }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq303.gif) on the conjugacy class ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_46_Chapter_IEq304.gif) of S k .
