# 47. The Philosophy of Cusp Forms

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

There are four theories that deserve to be studied in parallel. These are:

  * The representation theory of symmetric groups S k ;

  * The representation theory of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\);$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq1.gif)

  * The representation theory of GL(k, F) where F is a local field;

  * The theory of automorphic forms on GL(k).

There are four theories that deserve to be studied in parallel. These are:

  * The representation theory of symmetric groups S k ;

  * The representation theory of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\);$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq2.gif)

  * The representation theory of GL(k, F) where F is a local field;

  * The theory of automorphic forms on GL(k).

In this description, a local field is ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq3.gif), ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq4.gif), or a field such as the p-adic field ![
$$\\mathbb{Q}_{p}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq5.gif) that is complete with respect to a non-Archimedean valuation. Roughly speaking, each successive theory can be thought of as an elaboration of its predecessor. Both similarities and differences are important. We list some parallels between the four theories in Table 47.1.

The plan of this chapter is to discuss all four theories in general terms, giving proofs only for the second stage in this tower of theories, the representation theory of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq6.gif). (The first stage is already adequately covered.) Although the third and fourth stages are outside the scope of this book, our goal is to prepare the reader for their study by exposing the parallels with the finite field case.

There is one important way in which these four theories are similar: there are certain representations that are the "atoms" from which all other representations are built and a "constructive process" from which the other representations are built. Depending on the context, the "atomic" representations are called cuspidal or discrete series representations. The constructive process is parabolic induction or Eisenstein series. The constructive process usually (but not always) produces an irreducible representation.

Harish-Chandra [62] used the term "philosophy of cusp forms" to describe this parallel, which will be the subject of this chapter. One may substitute any reductive group for GL(k) and most of what we have to say will be applicable. But GL(k) is enough to fix the ideas.

In order to explain the philosophy of cusp forms, we will briefly summarize the theory of Eisenstein series before discussing (in a more serious way) a part of the representation theory of GL(k) over a finite field. The reader only interested in the latter may skip the paragraphs on automorphic forms. When we discuss automorphic forms, we will prove nothing and state exactly what seems relevant in order to see the parallel. For ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq7.gif), we prove more, but mainly what we think is essential to see the parallel. Our treatment is greatly influenced by Howe [74] and Zelevinsky [178]. To go deeper into the representation theory of the finite groups of Lie type, Carter [32] is an exceedingly useful reference.

For the symmetric groups, there is only one "atom"—the trivial representation of S 1. The constructive process is ordinary induction from S k × S l to S k+l , which was the multiplication ∘ in the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq8.gif) introduced in Chap. . The element that we have identified as atomic was called h 1 there. It does not generate the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq9.gif). However, h 1 k is the regular representation (or character) of S k , and it contains every irreducible representation. To construct every irreducible representation of S k from this single irreducible representation of S 1, the constructive process embodied in the multiplicative structure of the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq10.gif) must be supplemented by a further procedure. This is the extraction of an irreducible from a bigger representation h 1 k that includes it. This extraction amounts to finding a description for the "Hecke algebra" that is the endomorphism ring of h 1 k . This "Hecke algebra" is isomorphic to the group ring of S k .

For the groups ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq11.gif), let us construct a graded ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq12.gif) analogous to the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq13.gif) in Chap. . The homogeneous part ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq14.gif) will be the free Abelian group on the set of isomorphism classes of irreducible representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq15.gif), which may be identified with the character ring of this group; the multiplicative structure of the character ring is not used. Instead, there is a multiplication ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}\(q\) \\times \\mathcal{R}_{l}\(q\)\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{R}_{k+l}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq16.gif), called parabolic induction. Consider the maximal parabolic subgroup P = MU of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k + l, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq17.gif), where

![
$$\\displaystyle{M\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\times \\mathrm{GL}\(l, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\) = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & \\\\ & g_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)\\,\\Big\\vert \\,g_{1} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\),\\,g_{2} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(l, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\right \\}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equa.gif)

and

![
$$\\displaystyle{U = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I_{k}&X \\\\ &I_{l} \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,X \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{k\\times l}\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equb.gif)

The group P is a semidirect product, since U is normal, and the composition

![
$$\\displaystyle{M\\longrightarrow P\\longrightarrow P/U}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equc.gif)

is an isomorphism. So given a representation (π1,V 1) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq18.gif) and a representation (π2,V 2) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(l, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq19.gif), one may regard the representation π1 ⊗ π2 of M as a representation of ![
$$P/U\\mathop{\\cong}M$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq20.gif) and pull it back to a representation of P in which U acts trivially. Inducing from P to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k + l, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq21.gif) gives a representation that we will denote π1 ∘ π2. By the definition of the induced representation, it acts by right translation on the space V 1 ∘ V 2 of all functions ![
$$f: G\\longrightarrow V _{1} \\otimes V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq22.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & {\\ast}\\\\ &g_{ 2} \\end{array} \\right \)h\\right \) =\\big \(\\pi _{1}\(g_{1}\)\\otimes \\pi _{2}\(g_{2}\)\\big\)f\(h\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equd.gif)

With this multiplication, ![
$$\\mathcal{R}\(q\) =\\bigoplus \\mathcal{R}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq23.gif) is a graded ring (Exercise 47.1). Inspired by ideas of Philip Hall, Green [58] defined the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq24.gif) and used it systematically by in his description of the irreducible representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq25.gif). Like ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq26459.gif), it can be given the structure of a Hopf algebra. See Zelevinsky [178] and Exercise 47.5.

If, imitating the construction with the symmetric group, we start with the trivial representation ![
$$\\mathbf{h}_{1}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq27652.gif) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(1, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq28652.gif) and consider all irreducible representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq29482.gif) that occur in h 1(q) k , we get exactly the unipotent representations (i.e., the s k (q) of Chap. ), and this is the content of Theorem 46.1. To get all representations, we need more than this. There is a unique smallest set of irreducible representations of the ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq30641.gif)—the cuspidal ones—such that we can find every irreducible representation as a constituent of some representation that is a ∘ product of cuspidal ones. We will give more precise statements later in this chapter.

At the third stage in the tower of theories, the most important representations are infinite-dimensional, and analysis is important as well as algebra in their understanding. The representation theory of algebraic groups over a local field F is divided into the case where F is Archimedean—that is, ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq31452.gif) or ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq32652.gif)—and where F is non-Archimedean.

If F is Archimedean, then an algebraic group over F is a Lie group, more precisely a complex analytic group when ![
$$F = \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq33652.gif). The most important feature in the representation theory of reductive Lie groups is the Langlands classification expressing every irreducible representation as a quotient of one that is parabolically induced from discrete series representations. Usually the parabolically induced representation is itself irreducible and there is no need to pass to a quotient. See Knapp [104], Theorem 14.92 on p. 616 for the Langlands classification. Knapp [104] and Wallach [168] are comprehensive accounts of the representation theory of noncompact reductive Lie groups.

For reductive p-adic groups—that is, reductive algebraic groups over a non-Archimedean local field—the situation is similar and in some ways simpler. The most important discrete series representations are the supercuspidals. There is again a Langlands classification expressing every irreducible representation as a quotient of one parabolically induced from discrete series. Surveys of the representation theory of p-adic groups can be found in Cartier [33] and Moeglin [130]. Two useful longer articles with foundational material are Casselman [34] and Bernstein and Zelevinsky [16]. The most important foundational paper is Bernstein and Zelevinsky [17]. Chapter  of Bump [27] emphasizes GL(2) but is still useful.

Class of groups | Atoms | Synthetic process | Analytic process | Unexpected symmetry

---|---|---|---|---

S k | h 1 | Induction | Restriction | (Trivial)

![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq34856.gif) | Cuspidal representations | Parabolic induction | Unipotent invariants | ![
$$\\mathcal{R}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq35.gif) is commutative

The fourth of the four theories in the tower is the theory of automorphic forms. In developing this theory, Selberg and Langlands realized that certain automorphic forms were basic, and these are called cusp forms. The definitive reference for the Selberg–Langlands theory is Moeglin and Waldspurger [131]. Let us consider the basic setup.

Let ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq36.gif). Let Γ be a discrete subgroup of G such that ![
$$\\varGamma \\setminus G$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq37.gif) has finite volume such as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq38.gif). An automorphic form on G with respect to Γ is a smooth complex-valued function f on G that is K-finite, ![
$$\\mathcal{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq39.gif)-finite, of moderate growth and automorphic, and has unitary central character. We define these terms now.

The group G acts on functions by right translation: ρ(g)f(h) = f(hg). The group K is the maximal compact subgroup O(n), and f is K-finite if the space of functions ρ(κ)f with κ ∈ K spans a finite-dimensional vector space.

The Lie algebra ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq40.gif) of G also acts by right translation: if ![
$$X \\in \\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq41.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(Xf\)\(g\) = \\frac{\\mathrm{d}} {\\mathrm{d}t}f\(g{\\mathrm{e}}^{tX}\)\\,\\Big\\vert _{ t=0}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Eque.gif)

As a consequence, the universal enveloping algebra ![
$$U\(\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq42.gif) acts on smooth functions. Let ![
$$\\mathcal{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq43.gif) be its center. This is a ring of differential operators on G that are invariant under both right and left translation (Exercise 10.2). For example, it contains the Casimir element constructed in Theorem 10.2 (from the trace bilinear form B on ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq44.gif); in this incarnation, the Casimir element is the Laplace–Beltrami operator. The function f is called ![
$$\\mathcal{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq45.gif) -finite if the image of f under ![
$$\\mathcal{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq46.gif) is a finite-dimensional vector space.

Embed G into 2k 2-dimensional Euclidean space ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{k}\(\\mathbb{R}\) \\oplus \\mathrm{Mat}_{k}\(\\mathbb{R}\) = {\\mathbb{R}}^{2{k}^{2} }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq47.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{g\\longmapsto \(g,{g}^{-1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equf.gif)

Let ![
$$\\|\\;\\|$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq48.gif) denote the Euclidean norm in ![
$${\\mathbb{R}}^{2{k}^{2} }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq49.gif) restricted to G. The function f is said to be of moderate growth if ![
$$f\(g\) < C\\|{g\\|}^{N}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq50.gif) for suitable C and N.

The function f is called automorphic with respect to Γ if f(γg) = f(g) for all γ ∈Γ.

We will consider functions f such that for some character ω of ![
$$\\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq51.gif) we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\;z\\;&& \\\\ &\\ddots &\\\\ & &\\;z\\; \\end{array} \\right \)g\\right \) = \\omega \(z\)\\,f\(g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equg.gif)

for all ![
$$z \\in \\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq52.gif). The character ω is the central character. It is fixed throughout the discussion and is assumed unitary; that is, |ω(z)| = 1.

Let V be a vector space on which K and ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq53.gif) both act. The actions are assumed to be compatible in the sense that both induce the same representation of Lie(K). We ask that V decomposes into a direct sum of finite-dimensional irreducible subspaces under K. Then V is called a ![
$$\(\\mathfrak{g},K\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq54.gif)-module. If every irreducible representation of K appears with only finite multiplicity, then we say that V is admissible. For example, let (π,H) be an irreducible unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H, and let V be the space of K-finite vectors in H. It is a dense subspace and is closed under actions of both ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq55.gif) and K, so it is a ![
$$\(\\mathfrak{g},K\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq56.gif)-module. The ![
$$\(\\mathfrak{g},K\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq57.gif)-modules form a category that can be studied by purely algebraic methods, which captures the essence of the representations.

The space ![
$$\\mathcal{A}\(\\varGamma \\setminus G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq58.gif) of automorphic forms is not closed under ρ because K-finiteness is not preserved by ρ(g) unless g ∈ K. Still, both K and ![
$$\\mathfrak{g}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq59.gif) preserve the space ![
$$\\mathcal{A}\(\\varGamma \\setminus G\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq60.gif). A subspace that is invariant under these actions and irreducible in the obvious sense is called an automorphic representation. It is a ![
$$\(\\mathfrak{g},K\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq61.gif)-module.

Given an automorphic form f on ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq62.gif) with respect to ![
$$\\varGamma = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq63.gif), if k = r \+ t we can consider the constant term along the parabolic subgroup P with Levi factor GL(r) ×GL(t). This is the function

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{\\mathrm{Mat}_{r\\times t}\(\\mathbb{Z}\)\\setminus \\mathrm{Mat}_{r\\times t}\(\\mathbb{R}\)}f\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I &X\\\\ & I \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & \\\\ & g_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \)\\mathrm{d}X}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equh.gif)

for ![
$$\(g_{1},g_{2}\) \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{R}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq64.gif). If the constant term of f along every maximal parabolic subgroup vanishes then f is called a cusp form. An automorphic representation is called automorphic cuspidal if its elements are cusp forms.

Let ![
$${L}^{2}\(\\varGamma \\setminus G,\\omega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq65.gif) be the space of measurable functions on g that are automorphic and have central character ω and such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{\\varGamma Z\\setminus G}\\vert f\(g\){\\vert }^{2}\\,\\mathrm{d}g < \\infty.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equi.gif)

The integral is well-defined modulo Z because ω is assumed to be unitary. Cusp forms are always square-integrable—an automorphic cuspidal representation embeds as a direct summand in ![
$${L}^{2}\(\\varGamma \\setminus G,\\omega \)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq66.gif). In particular, it is unitary.

There is a construction that is dual to the constant term in the Selberg–Langlands theory, namely the construction of Eisenstein series. Let (π1,V 1) and (π2,V 2) be automorphic cuspidal representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq67.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq68.gif), where r \+ t = k. Let P = MU be the maximal parabolic subgroup with Levi factor ![
$$M = \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{R}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq69.gif). The modular quasicharacter ![
$$\\delta _{P}: P\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{R}_{+}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq70.gif) is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\delta _{P}\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & {\\ast}\\\\ &g_{ 2} \\end{array} \\right \) = \\frac{\\vert \\det \(g_{1}\){\\vert }^{t}} {\\vert \\det \(g_{2}\){\\vert }^{r}}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equj.gif)

by Exercise 1.2. The space of the ![
$$\(\\mathfrak{g},K\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq71.gif)-module of the induced representation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\pi _{2} \\otimes \\delta _{P}^{s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq72.gif) of G consists of K-finite functions ![
$$f_{s}: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq73.gif) such that any element f s ′ of the ![
$$\(\\mathfrak{g},K\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq74.gif)-submodule of C ∞ (G) generated by f s satisfies the condition that

![
$$\\displaystyle{f_{s}^{\\prime}\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & X\\\\ &g_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equk.gif)

is independent of X and equals δ P s+1∕2 times a finite linear combination of functions of the form ![
$$f_{1}\(g_{1}\)f_{2}\(g_{2}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq75.gif), where f i ∈ V i . Due to the extra factor ![
$$\\delta _{P}^{1/2}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq76.gif), this induction is called normalized induction, and it has the property that if s is purely imaginary (so that ![
$$\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\pi _{2} \\otimes \\delta _{P}^{s}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq77.gif) is unitary), then the induced representation is unitary.

Then, for re(s) sufficiently large and for ![
$$f_{s} \\in \\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\pi _{2} \\otimes \\delta _{P}^{s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq78.gif), the series

![
$$\\displaystyle{E\(g,f_{s},s\) =\\sum _{P\(\\mathbb{Z}\)\\setminus \\mathrm{GL}\(k,\\mathbb{Z}\)}f_{s}\(\\gamma g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equl.gif)

is absolutely convergent. Here ![
$$P\(\\mathbb{Z}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq79.gif) is the group of integer matrices in P with determinant ± 1.

Unlike cusp forms, the Eisenstein series are not square-integrable. Nevertheless, they are needed for the spectral decomposition of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{Z}\)\\setminus \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq80.gif). This is analogous to the fact that the characters ![
$$x\\longmapsto {\\mathrm{e}}^{2\\pi i\\alpha x}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq81.gif) of ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq82.gif) are not square-integrable, but as eigenfunctions of the Laplacian, a self-adjoint operator, they are needed for its spectral theory and comprise its continuous spectrum. The spectral problem for ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{Z}\)\\setminus \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq83.gif) has both a discrete spectrum (comprised of the cusp forms and residues of Eisenstein series) and a continuous spectrum. The Eisenstein series (analytically continued in s and restricted to the unitary principal series) are needed for the analysis of the continuous spectrum.

For the purpose of analytic continuation, we call a family of functions ![
$$f_{s} \\in \\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\pi _{2} \\otimes \\delta _{P}^{s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq84.gif) a standard section if the restriction of the functions f s to K is independent of s.

Theorem 47.1 (Selberg, Langlands).

Let r + t = k. Let P and Q be the parabolic subgroups of GL (k) with Levi factors GL (r) × GL (t) and GL (t) × GL (r), respectively. Suppose that ![
$$f_{s} \\in \\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\pi _{2} \\otimes \\delta _{P}^{s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq85.gif) is a standard section. Then E(g,f s ,s) has meromorphic continuation to all s. There exists an intertwining operator

![
$$\\displaystyle{M\(s\): \\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\pi _{2} \\otimes \\delta _{P}^{s}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{ 2} \\otimes \\pi _{1} \\otimes \\delta _{Q}^{-s}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equm.gif)

such that the functional equation

![
$$\\displaystyle{ E\(g,f_{s},s\) = E\\big\(g,M\(s\)f_{s},-s\\big\) }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(47.1)

is true.

The intertwining operator M(s) is given by an integral formula

![
$$\\displaystyle{ M\(s\)f\(g\) =\\int _{\\mathrm{Mat}_{t\\times r}\(\\mathbb{R}\)}f\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} & - I_{t} \\\\ I_{r}& \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I &X\\\\ & I \\end{array} \\right \)g\\right \)\\mathrm{d}X. }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(47.2)

This integral may be shown to be convergent if ![
$$\\mathrm{re}\(s\) > \\frac{1} {2}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq86.gif). For other values of s, it has analytic continuation. This integral emerges when one looks at the constant term of the Eisenstein series with respect to Q. We will not explain this further but mention it because these intertwining integrals are extremely important and will reappear in the finite field case in the proof of Proposition 47.3.

The two constructions—constant term and Eisenstein series—have parallels in the representation theory of GL(k, F), where F is a local field including ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq87.gif), ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq88.gif), or a p-adic field. These constructions are functors between representations of GL(k, F) and those of the Levi factor of any parabolic subgroup. They are the Jacquet functors in one direction and parabolic induction in the other. (We will not define the Jacquet Functors, but they are the functors r U,1 in Bernstein and Zelevinsky [17].) Moreover, these constructions also descend to the case of representation theory of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq89.gif), which we look at next.

An irreducible representation (π,V ) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq90.gif) is called cuspidal if there are no fixed vectors for the unipotent radical of any (standard) parabolic subgroup. If P ⊇ Q are parabolic subgroups and U P and U Q are their unipotent radicals, then U P ⊆ U Q , and it follows that a representation is cuspidal if and only if it has no fixed vectors for the unipotent radical of any (standard) maximal parabolic subgroup; these are the subgroups of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I_{r}&X \\\\ &I_{t} \\end{array} \\right \)\\,\\Big\\vert \\,X \\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{r\\times t}\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\right \\},r+t = k. }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(47.3)

Proposition 47.1.

Let (π,V ) be a cuspidal representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq91.gif) . If U is the unipotent radical of a standard maximal parabolic subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq92.gif) and if ![
$$\\eta: V \\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq93.gif) is any linear functional such that ![
$$\\eta \\big\(\\pi \(u\)\\,v\\big\) = \\eta \(v\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq94.gif) for all u ∈ U and all v ∈ V, then η is zero.

This means that the contragredient of a cuspidal representation is cuspidal.

Proof.

Choose an invariant inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\;,\\;\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq95.gif) on V. There exists a vector y ∈ V such that ![
$$\\eta \(v\) = \\left \\langle v,y\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq96.gif). Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle v,\\pi \(u\)y\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle \\pi {\(u\)}^{-1}v,y\\right \\rangle = \\eta \\big\(\\pi {\(u\)}^{-1}v\\big\) = \\eta \(v\) = \\left \\langle v,y\\right \\rangle }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equn.gif)

for all u ∈ U and v ∈ V, so π(u)y = y. Since π is cuspidal, y = 0, whence η = 0. □

Proposition 47.2.

Every irreducible representation (π,V ) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq97.gif) is a constituent in some representation π 1 ∘⋯ ∘ π m with the π i cuspidal.

Proof.

If π is cuspidal, then we may take m = 1 and π1 = π. There is nothing to prove in this case.

If π is not cuspidal, then there exists a decomposition k = r \+ t such that the space V U of U-fixed vectors is nonzero, where U is the group (47.3). Let P = MU be the parabolic subgroup with Levi factor ![
$$M = \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq98.gif) and unipotent radical U. Then V G is an M-module since M normalizes U. Let ρ ⊗ τ be an irreducible constituent of M, where ρ and τ are representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq99.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq100.gif). By induction, we may embed ρ into π1 ∘⋯ ∘ π h and σ into π h+1 ∘⋯ ∘ π m for some cuspidals π i . Thus, we get a nonzero M-module homomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{{V }^{U}\\longrightarrow \\rho \\otimes \\tau \\longrightarrow \(\\pi _{ 1} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{h}\) \\otimes \(\\pi _{h+1} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{m}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equo.gif)

By Frobenius reciprocity (Exercise 47.2), there is thus a nonzero ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq101.gif)-module homomorphism

![
$$\\displaystyle{V \\longrightarrow \(\\pi _{1} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{h}\) \\circ \(\\pi _{h+1} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{m}\) = \\pi _{1} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{m}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equp.gif)

Since π is irreducible, this is an embedding. □

The notion of a cuspidal representation can be extended to Levi factors of parabolic subgroups. Let ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{r}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq102.gif), where the λ i are positive integers whose sum is k. We do not assume λ i ≥ λ i+1. Such a decomposition we call an ordered partition of k. Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{P_{\\lambda } = \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cccc} g_{11} & {\\ast} &\\cdots & {\\ast}\\\\ &g_{ 22} & \\cdots & {\\ast}\\\\ & & \\ddots & \\vdots\\\\ & & &g_{ rr} \\end{array} \\right \)\\,\\Big\\vert \\,g_{ii} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\right \\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equq.gif)

This parabolic subgroup has Levi factor

![
$$\\displaystyle{M_{\\lambda } = \\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{1}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\) \\times \\cdots \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{r}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equr.gif)

and unipotent radical U λ characterized by ![
$$g_{ii} = I_{\\lambda _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq103.gif). Any irreducible representation πλ of M λ is of the form ⊗ π i , where π i is a representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq104.gif). We say that π is cuspidal if each of the π i is cuspidal.

Let B k be the standard Borel subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq105.gif), consisting of upper triangular matrices, and let ![
$$B_{\\lambda } =\\prod B_{\\lambda _{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq106.gif). We regard this as the Borel subgroup of M λ. A standard parabolic subgroup of M λ is a proper subgroup Q containing B λ. Such a subgroup has the form ∏ Q i , where each Q i is either ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq107.gif) or a parabolic subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq108.gif) and at least one Q i is proper. The parabolic subgroup is maximal if exactly one Q i is a proper subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq109.gif) and that Q i is a maximal parabolic subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq110.gif). A parabolic subgroup of M λ has a Levi subgroup and a unipotent radical; if Q is a maximal parabolic subgroup of M λ, then the unipotent radical of Q is the unipotent radical of the unique Q i that is a proper subgroup of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq111.gif), and it follows that π = ⊗π i is cuspidal if and only if it has no fixed vector with respect to the unipotent radical of any maximal parabolic subgroup of M λ.

Parabolic induction is as we have already described it for maximal parabolic subgroups. The group P λ = M λ U λ is a semidirect product with the subgroup U λ normal, and so the composition

![
$$\\displaystyle{M_{\\lambda }\\mathop{ \\longrightarrow }\\limits P_{\\lambda }\\longrightarrow P_{\\lambda }/U_{\\lambda }}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equs.gif)

is an isomorphism, where the first map is inclusion and the second projection. This means that the representation πλ of M λ may be regarded as a representation of P λ in which U λ acts trivially. Then π1 ∘⋯ ∘ π r is the representation induced from P λ.

Theorem 47.2.

The multiplication in ![
$$\\mathcal{R}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq112.gif) is commutative.

Proof.

We will frame our proof in terms of characters rather than representations, so in this proof elements of ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{k}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq113.gif) are generalized characters of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq114.gif).

We make use of the involution ![
$$\\iota: \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq115.gif) defined by

Let r \+ t = k. The involution takes the standard parabolic subgroup P with Levi factor ![
$$M = \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq116.gif) to the standard parabolic subgroupι P with Levi factor ![
$${}^{\\iota }M = \\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq117.gif). It induces the map ![
$${M\\longrightarrow }^{\\iota }M$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq118.gif) given by

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & \\\\ & g_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)\\longmapsto \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} {}^{\\iota }g_{2} & \\\\ &{ }^{\\iota }g_{1} \\end{array} \\right \),g_{1} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\),g_{2} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equt.gif)

where ![
$${}^{\\iota }g_{1} = w_{r} {\\cdot }^{t}g_{1}^{-1} \\cdot w_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq119.gif) and ![
$${}^{\\iota }g_{2} = w_{t} {\\cdot }^{t}g_{2}^{-1} \\cdot w_{t}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq120.gif). Now since every element of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq121.gif) is conjugate to its transpose, if μ is the character of an irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq122.gif) with n = k, r, or t, we have ![
$$\\mu {\(}^{\\iota }g\) = \\overline{\\mu \(g\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq123.gif). Let μ1 and μ2 be the characters of representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq124.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq125.gif). Composing the character ![
$$\\bar{\\mu }_{2} \\otimes \\bar{ \\mu }_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq126.gif) ofι M with ![
$$\\iota: {M\\longrightarrow }^{\\iota }M$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq127.gif) and then parabolically inducing from P to ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq128.gif) will give the same result as parabolically inducing the character directly fromι P and then composing with ι. The first way gives μ1 ∘ μ2, and the second gives the conjugate of ![
$$\\bar{\\mu }_{2} \\circ \\bar{ \\mu }_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq129.gif) (that is, μ2 ∘ μ1), and so these are equal. □

Unfortunately, the method of proof in Theorem 47.2 is rather limited. We next prove a strictly weaker result by a different method based on an analog of the intertwining integrals (47.2). These intertwining integrals are very powerful tools in the representation theory of Lie and p-adic groups, and they are closely connected with the constant terms of the Eisenstein series and with the functional equations. It is for this reason that we give a second, longer proof of a weaker statement.

Proposition 47.3.

Let (π 1 ,V 1 ) and (π 2 ,V 2 ) be representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq130.gif) and ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq131.gif) . Then there exists a nonzero intertwining map between the representations π 1 ∘ π 2 and π 2 ∘ π 1 .

Proof.

Let f ∈ V 1 ∘ V 2. Thus ![
$$f: G\\longrightarrow V _{1} \\otimes V _{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq132.gif) satisfies

![
$$\\displaystyle{ f\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & {\\ast}\\\\ &g_{ 2} \\end{array} \\right \)h\\right \) =\\big \(\\pi _{1}\(g_{1}\)\\otimes \\pi _{2}\(g_{2}\)\\big\)f\(h\),g_{1} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\),g_{2} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(47.4)

Now define ![
$$Mf: G\\longrightarrow V _{2} \\otimes V _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq133.gif) by

![
$$\\displaystyle{Mf\(h\) = \\tau \\sum _{X\\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{r\\times t}\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)}f\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} & - I_{r} \\\\ I_{t}& \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I &X\\\\ & I \\end{array} \\right \)h\\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equu.gif)

where ![
$$\\tau: V _{1} \\otimes V _{2}\\longrightarrow V _{2} \\otimes V _{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq134.gif) is defined by ![
$$\\tau \(v_{1} \\otimes v_{2}\) = v_{2} \\otimes v_{1}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq135.gif). Let us show that Mf ∈ V 2 ∘ V 1. A change of variables ![
$$X\\longmapsto X - Y$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq136.gif) in the definition of Mf shows that

![
$$\\displaystyle{Mf\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I_{r}& Y \\\\ &I_{t} \\end{array} \\right \)h\\right \) = Mf\(h\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equv.gif)

Also, if ![
$$g_{1} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq137.gif) and ![
$$g_{2} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(t, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq138.gif), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & Mf\\left \(\\!\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{2} & \\\\ & g_{1} \\end{array} \\right \)h\\right \) = \\tau \\sum _{X\\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{r\\times t}\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)}f\\left \(\\!\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & \\\\ & g_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} & - I_{r} \\\\ I_{t}& \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I &g_{2}^{-1}Xg_{ 1} \\\\ & I \\end{array} \\right \)h\\right \)\\!.& {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

Making the variable change ![
$$X\\longmapsto g_{2}Xg_{1}^{-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq139.gif) and then using (47.4) and the fact that ![
$$\\tau \\circ \\big \(\\pi _{1}\(g_{1}\) \\otimes \\pi _{2}\(g_{2}\)\\big\) =\\big \(\\pi _{2}\(g_{2}\) \\otimes \\pi _{1}\(g_{1}\)\\big\) \\circ \\tau $$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq140.gif) shows that

![
$$\\displaystyle{Mf\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{2} & \\\\ & g_{1} \\end{array} \\right \)h\\right \) =\\big \(\\pi _{2}\(g_{2}\)\\otimes \\pi _{1}\(g_{1}\)\\big\)Mf\(h\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equw.gif)

Thus Mf ∈ V 2 ∘ V 1.

The map M is an intertwining operator since G acts on both the spaces of π1 ∘ π2 and π2 ∘ π1 by right translation, and ![
$$f\\longmapsto Mf$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq141.gif) obviously commutes with right translation. We must show that it is nonzero. Choose a nonzero vector ξ ∈ V 1 ⊗ V 2. Define

![
$$\\displaystyle{f\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} A&B\\\\ C &D \\end{array} \\right \) = \\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} \\big\(\\pi _{1}\(A\) \\otimes \\pi _{2}\(D\)\\big\)\\xi &\\quad \\mbox{ if $C = 0$,} \\\\ 0 &\\quad \\mathrm{otherwise}, \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equx.gif)

where A, B, C and D are blocks, A being r × r and D being t × t, etc. It is clear that f ∈ V 1 ∘ V 2. Now

![
$$\\displaystyle{Mf\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} &I_{t} \\\\ - I_{r}& \\end{array} \\right \) = \\tau \\sum _{X\\in \\mathrm{Mat}_{r\\times t}}f\\left \(\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} & - I_{r} \\\\ I_{t}& \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} I &X\\\\ & I \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} & - I_{t} \\\\ I_{r}& \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equy.gif)

and the term is zero unless X = 0, so this equals τ(ξ)≠0. This proves that the intertwining operator M is nonzero. □

Returning momentarily to automorphic forms, the functional equation (47.1) extends to Eisenstein series in several complex variables attached to cusp forms for general parabolic subgroups. We will not try to formulate a precise theorem, but suffice it to say that if π i are automorphic cuspidal representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq142.gif) and ![
$$s = \(s_{1},\\ldots,s_{r}\) \\in {\\mathbb{C}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq143.gif), and if ![
$$d_{s}: P_{\\lambda }\(\\mathbb{R}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq144.gif) is the quasicharacter

![
$$\\displaystyle{d_{s}\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} \\,g_{1}\\, & & \\\\ & \\ddots & \\\\ & & \\,g_{r}\\, \\end{array} \\right \) = \\vert \\det \(g_{1}\){\\vert }^{s_{1} }\\cdots \\vert \\det \(g_{r}\){\\vert }^{s_{r} },}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equz.gif)

then there is a representation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes \\pi _{r} \\otimes d_{s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq145.gif) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq146.gif) induced parabolically from the representation ![
$$\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes \\pi _{r} \\otimes d_{s}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq147.gif) of M λ. One may form an Eisenstein series by a series that is absolutely convergent if re(s i − s j ) are sufficiently large and that has meromorphic continuation to all s i . There are functional equations that permute the constituents ![
$$\\vert \\det {\\vert }^{s_{i}} \\otimes \\pi _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq148.gif).

If some of the π i are equal, the Eisenstein series will have poles. The polar divisor maps out the places where the representations ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes \\pi _{r} \\otimes d_{s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq149.gif) are reducible. Restricting ourselves to the subspace of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq150.gif) where ∑ s i = 0, the following picture emerges. If all of the π i are equal, then the polar divisor will consist of r(r − 1) hyperplanes in parallel pairs. There will be r! points where r − 1 hyperplanes meet in pairs. These are the points where the induced representation ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes \\pi _{r} \\otimes d_{s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq151.gif) is maximally reducible. Regarding the reducibility of representations, we will see that there are both similarities and dissimilarities with the finite field case.

Returning to the case of a finite field, we will denote by T the subgroup of diagonal matrices in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq152.gif). If α is a root, we will denote by U α the one-dimensional unipotent of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq153.gif) corresponding to α. Thus, if α = α ij in the notation (27.​7), then X α consists of the matrices of the form I \+ tE ij , where E ij has a 1 in the i, jth position and zeros elsewhere.

If λ = (λ1,...,λ r ) is an ordered partition of k, π i are representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq154.gif), and ![
$$\\pi _{\\lambda } = \\pi _{1} \\otimes \\cdots \\otimes \\pi _{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq155.gif) is the corresponding representation of M λ, we will use Ind(πλ) as an alternative notation for π1 ∘⋯ ∘ π r .

Theorem 47.3 (Harish-Chandra).

Suppose that λ = (λ 1 ,...,λ r ) and μ = (μ 1 ,...,μ t ) are ordered partitions of k, and let π λ = ⊗π i and π μ ′ = ⊗π j ′ be cuspidal representations of M λ and M μ , respectively. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\dim \\;\\mathrm{Hom}_{\\mathrm{GL}\(k,\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)}\\big\(\\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{\\lambda }\),\\mathrm{Ind}\(\\pi _{\\mu }^{\\prime}\)\\big\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equaa.gif)

is zero unless r = t. If r = t, it is the number of permutations σ of {1,2,...,r} such that λ σ(i) = μ i and ![
$$\\pi _{\\sigma \(i\)}\\mathop{\\cong}\\pi _{i}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq156.gif) .

See also Harish-Chandra [62], Howe [74] and Springer [151].

Proof.

Let V i be the space of π i and let V i ′ be the space of π i ′, so πλ acts on V = ⊗V i and πμ acts on V ′ = ⊗V i ′. By Mackey's theorem in the geometric form of Theorem 32.1, the dimension of this space of intertwining operators is the dimension of the space of functions ![
$$\\varDelta: \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Hom}_{\\mathbb{C}}\(V,V ^{\\prime}\)$$
