This theorem has some important consequences.

Theorem 47.4.

Suppose that λ = (λ 1 ,...,λ r ) is an ordered partition of k, and let π λ = ⊗π i be a cuspidal representation of M λ . Suppose that no ![
$$\\pi _{i}\\mathop{\\cong}\\pi _{j}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq192.gif) . Then π 1 ∘⋯ ∘ π r is irreducible. Its isomorphism class is unchanged if the λ i and π i are permuted. If (μ 1 ,...,μ t ) is another ordered partition of k, and ![
$$\\pi _{\\mu }^{\\prime} = \\pi _{1}^{\\prime} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{t}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq193.gif) is a cuspidal representation of M μ , with the π i ′ also distinct, then ![
$$\\pi _{1} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{r}\\mathop{\\cong}\\pi _{1}^{\\prime} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{t}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq194.gif) if and only if r = t and there is a permutation σ of {1,...,r} such that μ i = λ σ(i) and ![
$$\\pi _{i}^{\\prime}\\mathop{\\cong}\\pi _{\\sigma \(i\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq195.gif) .

Remark 47.1.

This is the usual case. If q is large, the probability that there is a repetition among a list of randomly chosen cuspidal representations is small.

Remark 47.2.

The statement that the isomorphism class is unchanged if the λ i and π i are permuted is the analog of the functional equations of the Eisenstein series.

Proof.

By Theorem 47.3, the dimension of the space of intertwining operators of Ind(πλ) to itself is one, and it follows that this space is irreducible. The last statement is also clear from Theorem 47.3. □

Suppose now that l is a divisor of k and that k = lt. Let π0 be a cuspidal representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(l, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq196.gif). Let us denote by π0 ∘t the representation π0 ∘⋯ ∘ π0 (t copies). We call any irreducible constituent of π0 ∘t a π0-monatomic irreducible representation. As a special case, if π0 is the trivial representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(1, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq197.gif), this is the Hecke algebra identified in Iwahori's Theorem 46.3. There, we saw that the endomorphism ring of π0 ∘t was the Hecke algebra ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{t}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq198.gif), a deformation of the group algebra of the symmetric group S t , and thereby obtained a parametrization of its irreducible constituents by the irreducible representations of S t or by partitions of t. The following result generalizes Theorem 46.3.

Theorem 47.5 (Howlett and Lehrer).

Let π 0 be a cuspidal representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(l, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq199.gif) . Then the endomorphism ring ![
$$\\mathrm{End}\(\\pi _{0}^{\\circ t}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq200.gif) is naturally isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{t}\({q}^{l}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq201.gif) .

Proof.

Proofs may be found in Howlett and Lehrer [80] and Howe [74]. □

Corollary 47.1.

There exists a natural bijection between the set of partitions λ of t and the irreducible constituents σ λ(π) of π 0 ∘t . The multiplicity of σ λ(π) in π 0 ∘t equals the degree of the irreducible character s λ of the symmetric group S t parametrized by λ.

Proof.

The multiplicity of σλ(π) in π0 ∘t equals the multiplicity of the corresponding module of ![
$$\\mathcal{H}_{t}\({q}^{l}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq202.gif). By Exercise 46.5, this is the degree of s λ. □

Although we will not make use of the multiplicative structure that is contained in this theorem of Howlett and Lehrer, we may at least see immediately that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\dim \\big\(\\mathrm{End}\(\\pi _{0}^{\\circ t}\)\\big\) = t!, }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(47.6)

by Theorem 47.3, taking μ = λ and all π i , π i ′ to be π0. This is enough for the following result.

Theorem 47.6.

Let (λ 1 ,...,λ r ) be an ordered partition of k, and let ![
$$\\lambda _{i} = l_{i}t_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq203.gif) . Let π i be a cuspidal representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(l_{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq204.gif) , with no two π i isomorphic. Let θ i be a π i -monatomic irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\lambda _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq205.gif) . Let θ λ = ⊗θ i . Then Ind (θ λ ) is irreducible, and every irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq206.gif) is of this type. If (μ 1 ,...,μ t ) is another ordered partition of k, and θ i ′ be a family of monatomic representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(\\mu _{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq207.gif) with respect to another set of distinct cuspidals, and let θ μ ′ = ⊗θ i ′. Then ![
$$\\mathrm{Ind}\(\\theta _{\\lambda }\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathrm{Ind}\(\\theta _{\\mu }^{\\prime}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq208.gif) if and only if r = t, and there exists a permutation σ of {1,...,r} such that μ i = λ σ(i) and ![
$$\\theta _{i}^{\\prime}\\mathop{\\cong}\\theta _{\\sigma \(i\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq209.gif) .

Proof.

We note the following general principle: χ is a character of any group, and if χ = ∑ d i χ i is a decomposition into subrepresentations such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\chi,\\chi \\right \\rangle =\\sum d_{i}^{2},}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equah.gif)

then the χ i are irreducible and mutually nonisomorphic. Indeed, we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum d_{i}^{2} = \\left \\langle \\chi,\\chi \\right \\rangle =\\sum d_{ i}^{2}\\left \\langle \\chi _{ i},\\chi _{i}\\right \\rangle +\\sum _{i\\neq j}d_{i}d_{j}\\left \\langle \\chi _{i},\\chi _{j}\\right \\rangle.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equai.gif)

All the inner products ![
$$\\left \\langle \\chi _{i},\\chi _{i}\\right \\rangle \\geqslant 1$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq210.gif) and all the ![
$$\\left \\langle \\chi _{i},\\chi _{j}\\right \\rangle \\geqslant 0$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq211.gif), so this implies that the ![
$$\\left \\langle \\chi _{i},\\chi _{i}\\right \\rangle = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq212.gif) and all the ![
$$\\left \\langle \\chi _{i},\\chi _{j}\\right \\rangle = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq213.gif).

Decompose each ![
$$\\pi _{i}^{\\circ t_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq214.gif) into a direct sum ![
$$\\sum _{j}d_{ij}\\theta _{ij}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq215.gif) of distinct irreducibles θ ij with multiplicities d ij . The representation θ i is among the θ ij . We have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\pi _{1}^{\\circ t_{1} } \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{r}^{\\circ t_{r} } =\\sum _{j_{1}}\\cdots \\sum _{j_{r}}\(d_{1j_{1}}\\cdots d_{rj_{r}}\)\\,\\theta _{1j_{1}} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\theta _{rj_{r}}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equaj.gif)

The dimension of the endomorphism ring of this module is computed by Theorem 47.3. The number of permutations of the advertised type is t 1!⋯t r ! because each permutation must map the d i copies of π i among themselves.

On the other hand, by (47.6), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{j_{1}}\\cdots \\sum _{j_{r}}{\(d_{1j_{1}}\\cdots d_{rj_{r}}\)}^{2} = t_{ 1}!\\cdots t_{r}!}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equak.gif)

also. By the "general principle" stated at the beginning of this proof, it follows that the representations ![
$$\\theta _{1j_{1}} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\theta _{rj_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq216.gif) are irreducible and mutually nonisomorphic.

Next we show that every irreducible representation π is of the form Ind(θ λ). If π is cuspidal, then π is monatomic, and so we can just take r = t 1 = 1, θ 1 = π1. We assume that π is not cuspidal. Then by Proposition 47.2 we may embed π into π1 ∘⋯ ∘ π m for some cuspidal representations π i . By Proposition 47.4, we may order these so that isomorphic π i are adjacent, so π is embedded in a representation of the form ![
$$\\pi _{1}^{\\circ t_{1}} \\circ \\cdots \\circ \\pi _{r}^{\\circ t_{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq217.gif), where π i are nonisomorphic cuspidal representations. We have determined the irreducible constituents of such a representation, and they are of the form Ind(θ λ), where θ i is π i -monatomic. Hence π is of this form.

We leave the final uniqueness assertion for the reader to deduce from Theorem 47.3. □

The great paper of Green [58] constructs all the irreducible representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq218.gif). Systematic use is made of the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq219.gif). However, Green does not start with the cuspidal representations. Instead, Green takes as his basic building blocks certain generalized characters that are "lifts" of modular characters, described in the following theorem.

Theorem 47.7 (Green).

Let G be a finite group, and let ![
$$\\rho: G\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq220.gif) be a representation. Let ![
$$f \\in \\mathbb{Z}\[X_{1},\\ldots,X_{k}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq221.gif) be a symmetric polynomial with integer coefficients. Let ![
$$\\theta:\\bar{ \\mathbb{F}}_{q}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq222.gif) be any character. Let ![
$$\\chi: G\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq223.gif) be the function

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\chi \(g\) = f\\big\(\\theta \(\\alpha _{1}\),\\ldots,\\theta \(\\alpha _{k}\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equal.gif)

Then θ is a generalized character.

Proof.

First, we reduce to the following case: ![
$$\\theta:\\bar{ \\mathbb{F}}_{q}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq224.gif) is injective and ![
$$f\(X_{1},\\ldots,X_{k}\) =\\sum X_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq225.gif). If this case is known, then by replacing ρ by its exterior powers we get the same result for the elementary symmetric polynomials, and hence for all symmetric polynomials. Then we can take ![
$$f\(X_{1},\\ldots,X_{k}\) =\\sum X_{i}^{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq226.gif), effectively replacing θ by θ r . We may choose r to match any given character on a finite field containing all eigenvalues of all g, obtaining the result in full generality.

We recall that if l is a prime, a group is l-elementary if it is the direct product of a cyclic group and an l-group. According to Brauer's characterization of characters (Theorem 8.4(a) on p. 127 of Isaacs [83]), a class function is a generalized character if and only if its restriction to every l-elementary subgroup H (for all l) is a generalized character. Thus, we may assume that G is l-elementary. If p is the characteristic of ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq227.gif), whether l = p or not, we may write G = P × Q where P is a p-group and p∤ |Q|. The restriction of χ to Q is a character by Isaacs, [83], Theorem 15.13 on p. 268. The result will follow if we show that χ(g p q) = χ(q) for g p ∈ P, q ∈ Q. Since g p and q commute, using the Jordan canonical form, we may find a basis for the representation space of ρ over ![
$$\\bar{\\mathbb{F}}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq228.gif) such that ρ(q) is diagonal and ρ(g p ) is upper triangular. Because the order of g p is a power of p, its diagonal entries are 1's, so q and g p q have the same eigenvalues, whence χ(g p q) = χ(q). □

Since the proof of this theorem of Green is purely character-theoretic, it does not directly produce irreducible representations. And the characters that it produces are not irreducible. (We will look more closely at them later.) However, Green's generalized characters have two important advantages. First, their values are easily described. By contrast, the values of cuspidal representations are easily described on the semisimple conjugacy classes, but at other classes require knowledge of "degeneracy rules" which we will not describe. Second, Green's generalized character can be extended to a generalized character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{r}}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq229.gif) for any r, a property that ordinary characters do not have.

Still, the cuspidal characters have a satisfactory direct description, which we turn to next. Choosing a basis for ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq230.gif) as a k-dimensional vector space over ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq231.gif) and letting ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq232.gif) act by multiplication gives an embedding ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq233.gif). Call the image of this embedding T (k). More generally, if ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{r}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq234.gif) is a partition of k, then T λ is the group ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{\\lambda _{1}}}^{\\times }\\times \\cdots \\times \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{\\lambda _{r}}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq235.gif) embedded in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq236.gif) the same way. We will call any T λ—or any conjugate of such a group—a torus. An element of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq237.gif) is called semisimple if it is diagonalizable over the algebraic closure of ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq238.gif). This is equivalent to assuming that it is contained in some torus. It is called regular semisimple if its eigenvalues are distinct. This is equivalent to assuming that it is contained in a unique torus.

There is a very precise duality between the conjugacy classes of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq239.gif) and its irreducible representations. Some aspects of this duality are shown in Table 47.2. In each case, there is an exact numerical equivalence. For example, the number of unipotent conjugacy classes is the number of partitions of k, and this is also the number of unipotent representations, as we saw in Theorem 46.1. Again, the number of cuspidal representations equals the number of regular semisimple conjugacy classes whose eigenvalues generate ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq240.gif). We will prove this in Theorem 47.8.

Table 47.2

The duality between conjugacy classes and representations

Class type | Representation type

---|---

Central conjugacy classes | One-dimensional representations

Regular semisimple conjugacy classes | Induced from distinct cuspidals

Regular semisimple conjugacy classes whose eigenvalues generate ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq241.gif) | Cuspidal representations

Unipotent conjugacy classes | Unipotent representations

Conjugacy classes whose characteristic polynomial is a power of an irreducible | Monatomic representations

To formalize this duality, and to exploit it in order to count the irreducible cuspidal representations, we will divide the conjugacy classes of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq242.gif) into "types." Roughly, two conjugacy classes have the same type if their rational canonical forms have the same shape. For example, ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(2, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq243.gif) has four distinct types of conjugacy classes. They are

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,a\\,& \\\\ &\\,b\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\Big\\vert \\,a\\neq b\\right \\},\\qquad & \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,a\\,& \\\\ &\\,a\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\}, {}\\\\ & \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,a\\,&1\\\\ &\\,a\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\}, & \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} & 1\\\\ \\, - {\\nu }^{1+q } \\, &\\,\\nu +{\\nu }^{q}\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \\},{}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

where the last consists of the conjugacy classes of matrices whose eigenvalues are ν and ν q , where ![
$$\\nu \\in \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{2}} - \\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq244.gif). In the duality, these four types of conjugacy classes correspond to the four types of irreducible representations: the q \+ 1-dimensional principal series, induced from a pair of distinct characters of GL(1); the one-dimensional representations χ ∘ det, where χ is a character of ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq245.gif); the q-dimensional representations obtained by tensoring the Steinberg representation with a one-dimensional character; and the q − 1-dimensional cuspidal representations.

Let ![
$$f\(X\) = {X}^{d} + a_{d-1}{X}^{d-1} + \\cdots + a_{0}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq246.gif) be a monic irreducible polynomial over ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq247.gif) of degree d. Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{U\(f\) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccccc} 0 & 1 & 0 &\\cdots & 0\\\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & & 0\\\\ \\vdots & & \\vdots & & \\vdots \\\\ 0 & 0 & 0 &\\cdots & 1\\\\ - a_{ 0} & - a_{1} & - a_{2} & \\cdots & - a_{d-1} \\end{array} \\right \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equam.gif)

be the rational canonical form. Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{U_{r}\(f\) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccccc} U\(f\)& I_{d} & 0 &\\cdots & 0 \\\\ 0 &U\(f\)& I_{d} & & \\\\ 0 & 0 &U\(f\)& & \\vdots\\\\ \\vdots & & & \\ddots & \\\\ 0 & & \\cdots & &U\(f\) \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equan.gif)

an array of r × r blocks, each of size d × d. If ![
$$\\lambda = \(\\lambda _{1},\\ldots,\\lambda _{t}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq248.gif) is a partition of r, so that λ1 ≥⋯ ≥ λ t are nonnegative integers with |λ| = ∑ i λ i = r, let

![
$$\\displaystyle{U_{\\lambda }\(f\) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} U_{\\lambda _{1}}\(f\)&& \\\\ &\\ddots & \\\\ &&U_{\\lambda _{t}}\(f\) \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equao.gif)

Then every conjugacy class of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq249.gif) has a representative of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} U_{{\\lambda }^{1}}\(f_{1}\)&& \\\\ &\\ddots & \\\\ &&U_{{\\lambda }^{m}\(f_{m}\)} \\end{array} \\right \), }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

(47.7)

where the f i are distinct monic irreducible polynomials, and each ![
$${\\lambda }^{i} = \(\\lambda _{1}^{i},\\lambda _{2}^{i},\\ldots \)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq250.gif) is a partition. The conjugacy class is unchanged if the f i and λ i are permuted, but otherwise, they are uniquely determined.

Thus the conjugacy class is determined by the following data: a pair of sequences r 1,..., r m and d 1,..., d m of integers, and for each 1 ⩽ i ⩽ m a partition λ i of r i and a monic irreducible polynomial ![
$$f_{i} \\in \\mathbb{F}_{q}\[X\]$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq251.gif) of degree d i , such that no f i = f j if i≠j. The data ![
$$\(\\{r_{i}\\},\\{d_{i}\\},\\{{\\lambda }^{i}\\},\\{f_{i}\\}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq252.gif) and ![
$$\(\\{r_{i}^{\\prime}\\},\\{d_{i}^{\\prime}\\},\\{{\(\\lambda ^{\\prime}\)}^{i}\\},\\{f_{i}^{\\prime}\\}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq253.gif) parametrize the same conjugacy class if and only if they both have the same length m and there exists a permutation σ ∈ S m such that r i ′ = r σ(i), d i ′ = d σ(i), ![
$${\(\\lambda ^{\\prime}\)}^{i} = {\\lambda }^{\\sigma \(i\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq254.gif) and f i ′ = f σ(i).

We say two conjugacy classes are of the same type if the parametrizing data have the same length m and there exists a permutation σ ∈ S m such that r i ′ = r σ(i), d i ′ = d σ(i), ![
$${\(\\lambda ^{\\prime}\)}^{i} = {\\lambda }^{\\sigma \(i\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq255.gif). (The f i and f i ′ are allowed to differ.) The set of types of conjugacy classes depends on k, but is independent of q (though if q is too small, some types might be empty).

Lemma 47.1.

Let {N 1 ,N 2 ,...}n be a sequence of numbers, and for each N k let X k be a set of cardinality N k (X k disjoint). Let Σ k be the following set. An element of Σ k consists of a 4-tuple ![
$$\(\\{r_{i}\\},\\{d_{i}\\},\\{{\\lambda }^{i}\\},\\{x_{i}\\}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq256.gif) , where ![
$$\\{r_{i}\\} =\\{ r_{1},\\ldots,r_{m}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq257.gif) and ![
$$\\{d_{i}\\} =\\{ d_{1},\\ldots,d_{m}\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq258.gif) are sequences of positive integers, such that ∑r i d i = k, together with a sequence {λ i } of partitions of r i and an element ![
$$x_{i} \\in X_{d_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq259.gif) , such that no x i are equal. Define an equivalence relation ∼ on Σ k in which two elements are considered equivalent if they can be obtained by permuting the data, that is, if σ ∈ S m then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(\\{r_{i}\\},\\{d_{i}\\},\\{{\\lambda }^{i}\\},\\{x_{ i}\\}\) \\sim \(\\{r_{\\sigma \(i\)}\\},\\{d_{\\sigma \(i\)}\\},\\{{\\lambda }^{\\sigma \(i\)}\\},\\{x_{ \\sigma \(i\)}\\}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equap.gif)

Let M k be the number of equivalence classes. Then the sequence of numbers N k is determined by the sequence of numbers M k .

Proof.

By induction on k, we may assume that the cardinalities ![
$$N_{1},\\ldots,N_{k-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq260.gif) are determined by the M k . Let M k ′ be the cardinality of the set of equivalence classes of ![
$$\(\\{r_{i}\\},\\{d_{i}\\},\\{{\\lambda }^{i}\\},\\{x_{i}\\}\) \\in \\varSigma _{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq261.gif) in which no x i ∈ X k . Clearly M′ k depends only on the cardinalities N 1,..., N k−1 of the sets ![
$$X_{1},\\ldots,X_{k-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq262.gif) from which the x i are to be drawn, so (by induction) it is determined by the M i . Now we claim that ![
$$N_{k} = M_{k} - M_{k}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq263.gif). Indeed, if given ![
$$\(\\{r_{i}\\},\\{d_{i}\\},\\{{\\lambda }^{i}\\},\\{x_{i}\\}\) \\in \\varSigma _{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq264.gif) of length m, if any x i ∈ X k , then since ![
$$\\sum _{i=1}^{m}r_{i}d_{i} = k$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq265.gif), we must have m = 1, r 1 = 1, d 1 = k, and the number of such elements is exactly N k . □

Theorem 47.8.

The number of cuspidal representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq266.gif) equals the number of irreducible monic polynomials of degree k over ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq267.gif) .

Proof.

We can apply the lemma with X k either the set of cuspidal representations of S k or with the set of monic irreducible polynomials of degree k over ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq268.gif). We will show that in the first case, M k is the number of irreducible representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq269.gif), while in the second, M k is the number of conjugacy classes. Since these are equal, the result follows.

If X k is the set of cuspidal representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq270.gif), from each element ![
$$\(\\{r_{i}\\},\\{d_{i}\\},\\{{\\lambda }^{i}\\},\\{x_{i}\\}\) \\in \\varSigma _{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq271.gif) we can build an irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq272.gif) as follows. First, since x i is a cuspidal representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(d_{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq273.gif) we can build the x i -monatomic representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(d_{i}r_{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq274.gif) by decomposing ![
$$x_{i}^{\\circ r_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq275.gif). By Corollary 47.1, the irreducible constituents of ![
$$x_{i}^{\\circ r_{i}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq276.gif) are parametrized by partitions of r i , so x i and λ i parametrize an x i -monatomic representation π i of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(r_{i}d_{i}, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq277.gif). Let π = π1 ∘⋯ ∘ π m . By Theorem 47.4, every irreducible representation of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq278.gif) is constructed uniquely (up to permutation of the π i ) in this way.

On the other, take X k to be the set of monic irreducible polynomials of degree k over ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq279.gif). We have explained above how the conjugacy classes of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq280.gif) are parametrized by such data. □

Deligne and Lusztig [41] gave a parametrization of characters of any reductive group over a finite field by characters of tori. Carter [32] is a basic reference for Deligne–Lusztig characters. Many important formulae, such as a generalization of Mackey theory to cohomologically induced representations and an extension of Green's "degeneracy rules," are obtained. This theory is very satisfactory but the construction requires l-adic cohomology. For ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq281.gif), the parametrization of irreducible characters by characters of tori can be described without resorting to such deep methods. The key point is the parametrization of the cuspidal characters by characters of ![
$$T_{\(k\)}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq282.gif). Combining this with parabolic induction gives the parametrization of more general characters by characters of other tori.

Thus let ![
$$\\theta: T_{\(k\)}\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq283.gif) be a character such that the orbit of θ under ![
$$\\mathrm{Gal}\(\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}/\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq284.gif) has cardinality k. The number of ![
$$\\mathrm{Gal}\(\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}/\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq285.gif)-orbits of such characters is

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{1} {n}\\sum _{d\\vert n}\\mu \\left \(\\frac{n} {d}\\right \){q}^{d}, }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

(47.8)

where μ is the Möbius function—the same as the number of semisimple conjugacy classes. Then exists a cuspidal character ![
$$\\sigma _{k} = \\sigma _{k,\\theta }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq286.gif) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq287.gif) whose value on a regular semisimple conjugacy class g is zero unless g conjugate to an element of T (k), that is, unless the eigenvalues of g are the roots ![
$$\\alpha,{\\alpha }^{q},\\ldots,{\\alpha }^{{q}^{k-1} }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq288.gif) of an irreducible monic polynomial of degree k in ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}\[X\]$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq289.gif), so that ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}} = \\mathbb{F}_{q}\[\\alpha \]$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq290.gif). In this case,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sigma _{k}\(g\) = {\(-1\)}^{k-1}\\sum _{ j=0}^{k-1}\\theta \({\\alpha }^{{q}^{j} }\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equaq.gif)

By Theorem 47.8, the number of σ k, θ is the total number of cuspidal representations, so this is a complete list.

We will first construct σ k under the assumption that θ, regarded as a character of ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq291.gif), can be extended to a character ![
$$\\theta:\\bar{ \\mathbb{F}}_{q}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq292.gif) that is injective. This is assumption is too restrictive, and we will later relax it. We will also postpone showing that that σ k is independent of the extension of θ to ![
$$\\bar{\\mathbb{F}}_{q}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq293.gif). Eventually we will settle these points completely in the special case where k is a prime.

Let

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\chi _{k}\(g\) =\\sum _{ i=1}^{k}\\theta \(\\alpha _{ i}\), }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(47.9)

where α i are the eigenvalues of ![
$$g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq294.gif). By Green's theorem, χ k is a generalized character.

Proposition 47.4.

Assume that θ can be extended to a character ![
$$\\theta:\\bar{ \\mathbb{F}}_{q}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq295.gif) that is injective. Then the inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\chi _{k},\\chi _{k}\\right \\rangle = k$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq296.gif) .

Proof.

We will first prove that this is true for q sufficiently large, then show that it is true for all q. We will use "big O" notation, and denote by O(q −1) any term that is bounded by a factor independent of q times q −1. The idea of the proof is to show that as a function of q, the inner product is k \+ O(q −1). Since it is an integer, it must equal k when q is sufficiently large.

The number of elements of ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq297.gif) is ![
$${q}^{{k}^{2} } + O\({q}^{{k}^{2}-1 }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq298.gif). This is clear since G is the complement of the determinant locus in ![
$$\\mathrm{Mat}_{k}\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{F}_{q}^{{k}^{2} }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq299.gif). The set G reg of regular semisimple elements also has order ![
$${q}^{{k}^{2} } + O\({q}^{{k}^{2}-1 }\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq300.gif) since it is the complement of the discriminant locus. Since |χ k (g)|⩽ k for all g,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\chi _{k},\\chi _{k}\\right \\rangle = \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{g\\in G_{\\mathrm{reg}}}\\vert \\chi _{k}\(g\){\\vert }^{2} + O\({q}^{-1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equar.gif)

Because every regular element is contained in a unique conjugate of some T λ, which has exactly [G: N G (T λ)] such conjugates, this equals

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}\[G: N_{G}\(T_{\\lambda }\)\]\\sum _{g\\in T_{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{reg}}}\\vert \\chi _{k}\(g\){\\vert }^{2} + O\({q}^{-1}\) {}\\\\ & & \\quad = \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{\\lambda }\[G: N_{G}\(T_{\\lambda }\)\]\\sum _{g\\in T_{\\lambda }}\\vert \\chi _{k}\(g\){\\vert }^{2} + O\({q}^{-1}\), {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

the last step using the fact that the complement of the T λ reg in T λ is of codimension one. We note that the restriction of χ k to T λ is the sum of k distinct characters, so

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{g\\in T_{\\lambda }}\\vert \\chi _{k}\(g\){\\vert }^{2} = k\\vert T_{ \\lambda }\\vert.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equas.gif)

Thus the inner product is

![
$$\\displaystyle{k \\times \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{\\lambda }\[G: N_{G}\(T_{\\lambda }\)\]\\vert T_{\\lambda }\\vert + O\({q}^{-1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equat.gif)

We have

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{\\lambda }\[G: N_{G}\(T_{\\lambda }\)\]\\vert T_{\\lambda }\\vert & =& \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{\\lambda }\[G: N_{G}\(T_{\\lambda }\)\]\\vert T_{\\lambda }^{\\mathrm{reg}}\\vert + O\({q}^{-1}\) {}\\\\ & =& \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\vert G_{\\mathrm{reg}}\\vert + O\({q}^{-1}\) {}\\\\ & =& 1 + O\({q}^{-1}\). {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ13.gif)

The result is now proved for q sufficiently large.

To prove the result for all q, we will show that the inner product ![
$$\\left \\langle \\chi _{k},\\chi _{k}\\right \\rangle$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq301.gif) is a polynomial in q. This will follow if we can show that if S is the subset of G consisting of the union of conjugacy classes of a single type, then [G: C G (g)] is constant for g ∈ S and

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sum _{g\\in S}\\vert \\chi _{k}\(g\){\\vert }^{2} }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ14.gif)

(47.10)

is a polynomial in q. We note that for each type, the index of the centralizer of (47.7) is the same for all such matrices, and that this index is polynomial in q. Thus it is sufficient to show that the sum over the representatives (47.7) is a polynomial in q. Moreover, the value of χ k is unchanged if every instance of a U r (f) is replaced with r blocks of U(f), so we may restrict ourselves to semisimple conjugacy classes in confirming this. Thus if k = ∑ d i r i , we consider the sum (47.10), where the sum is over all matrices

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccc} U_{\(r_{1}\)}\(f_{1}\)&& \\\\ &\\ddots & \\\\ &&U_{\(r_{m}\)}\(f_{m}\) \\end{array} \\right \),}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equau.gif)

where f i are distinct irreducible polynomials, each of size d i , and U (r)(f) is the sum of r blocks of U(f). It is useful to conjugate these matrices so that they are all elements of the same torus T λ for some λ. The set S is then a subset of T λ characterized by exclusion from certain (non-maximal) subtori.

Let us look at an example. Suppose that λ = (2,2,2) and k = 6. Then S consists of elements of T λ, which may be regarded as ![
$${\(\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{2}}\)}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq302.gif) of the form (α,β,γ), where α, β and γ are distinct elements of ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{2}}^{\\times }- \\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq303.gif). Now if we sum (47.10) over all of T λ we get a polynomial in q, namely 6(q 2 − 1)3. On the other hand, we must subtract from this three contributions when one of α, β and γ is in ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq304.gif). These are subtori of the form T (2,2,1). We must also subtract three contributions from subgroups of the form T (2,2) in which two of α, β, and γ are equal. Then we must add back contributions that have been subtracted twice, and so on.

In general, the set S will consist of the set T λ minus subtori T 1,..., T N . If I is a subset of {1,..., N} let ![
$$T_{I} =\\bigcap _{i\\in I}T_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq305.gif). We now use the inclusion–exclusion principle in the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{g\\in S}\\vert \\chi _{k}\(g\){\\vert }^{2} =\\sum _{ g\\subset T_{\\lambda }}\\vert \\chi _{k}\(g\){\\vert }^{2} +\\sum _{ \\varnothing \\neq I\\subseteq \\{1,\\ldots,N\\}}{\(-1\)}^{\\vert I\\vert }\\sum _{ g\\in T_{I}}\\vert \\chi _{k}\(g\){\\vert }^{2}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equav.gif)

Each of the sums on the right is easily seen to be a polynomial in q, and so is (47.10). □

Theorem 47.9.

Assume that θ is an injective character ![
$$\\theta:\\bar{ \\mathbb{F}}_{q}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq306.gif) . For each k there exists a cuspidal σ k = σ k,θ of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq307.gif) such that if g is a regular semisimple element of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq308.gif) with eigenvalues that are the Galois conjugates of ![
$$\\nu \\in \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq309.gif) such that ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{k}} = \\mathbb{F}_{q}\(\\nu \)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq310.gif) , then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sigma _{k,\\theta }\(g\) = {\(-1\)}^{k-1}\\sum _{ i=0}^{k-1}\\theta \({\\nu }^{{q}^{i} }\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ15.gif)

(47.11)

If 1 k denotes the trivial character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq311.gif) , then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\chi _{n} =\\sum _{ k=1}^{n}{\(-1\)}^{k-1}\\sigma _{ k} \\circ 1_{n-k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equaw.gif)

Note that σ k ∘ 1 n−k is an irreducible character of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq312.gif) by Theorem 47.4. So this gives the expression of χ n in terms of irreducibles.

Proof.

By induction, we assume the existence of σ k and the decomposition of χ k as stated for k < n, and we deduce them for k = n.

We will show first that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \\langle \\chi _{n},\\sigma _{k} \\circ 1_{n-k}\\right \\rangle = {\(-1\)}^{k-1}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ16.gif)

(47.12)

Let P = MU be the standard parabolic subgroup with Levi factor ![
$$M = \\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(n - k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq313.gif) and unipotent radical U. If m ∈ M and u ∈ U, then as matrices in ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq314.gif), m and mu have the same characteristic polynomials, so χ n (mu) = χ n (m). Thus, in the notation of Exercise 47.2(ii), with χ = χ n , we have χ U = χ restricted to M. Therefore,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\chi _{n},\\sigma _{k} \\circ 1_{n-k}\\right \\rangle _{G} = \\left \\langle \\chi _{n},\\sigma _{k} \\otimes 1_{n-k}\\right \\rangle _{M}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equax.gif)

Let

![

![

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{1} {\\vert U\\vert }\\sum _{u\\in U}\\chi _{n}\\left \(u\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} m_{1} & \\\\ & m_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \) = \\frac{1} {\\vert U\\vert }\\sum _{r=1}^{n-1}{\(-1\)}^{r-1}\(\\sigma _{ r}\\circ 1_{n-r}\)\\left \(u\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} m_{1} & \\\\ & m_{2} \\end{array} \\right \)\\right \),}$$

since by Exercise 47.2(ii), this will show that the representation affording the character σ n has no U-invariants, the definition of cuspidality. The summand on the left-hand side is independent of u, and by the definition of χ n the left-hand side is just ![

If g is a regular element of T (k), then the value of σ k on a regular element of T (k ) is now given by (47.11) since if k < n then σ k ∘ 1 n−k vanishes on g, which is not conjugate to any element of the parabolic subgroup from which σ k ∘ 1 n−k is induced. □

See Exercise 47.9 for an example showing that the cuspidal characters that we have constructed are not enough because of our assumption that θ is injective. Without attempting a completely general result, we will now give a variation of Theorem 47.9 that is sufficient to construct all cuspidal representations of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$

Proposition 47.5.

Let ![
$$\\theta:\\bar{ \\mathbb{F}}_{q}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq326.gif) be a character. Assume that the restriction of θ to ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq327.gif) is trivial, but that for any 0 < d ⩽ k, the restriction of θ to ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{d}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq328.gif) does not factor through the norm map ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{d}}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{r}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq329.gif) for any proper divisor r of d. Then

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\chi _{k},\\chi _{k}\\right \\rangle = k + 1.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equbd.gif)

Proof.

The proof is similar to Proposition 47.4. It is sufficient to show this for sufficiently large q. As in that proposition, the sum is

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\frac{1} {\\vert G\\vert }\\sum _{\\mbox{ $\\lambda $ a partition of $k$}}\[G: N_{G}\(T_{\\lambda }\)\]\\sum _{g\\in T_{\\lambda }}\\vert \\chi _{k}\(g\){\\vert }^{2} + O\({q}^{-1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Eqube.gif)

We note that ![
$$\[N_{G}\(T_{\\lambda }\): T_{\\lambda }\] = z_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq330.gif), defined in (37.​1). With our assumptions if the partition λ contains r parts of size 1, the restriction of χ k to T λ consists of r copies of the trivial character, and k − r copies of other characters, all distinct. (Exercise 47.8.) The inner product of χ k with itself on T λ is thus k − r \+ r 2. The sum is thus

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{\\lambda } \\frac{1} {z_{\\lambda }}\(k + {r}^{2} - r\) + O\({q}^{-1}\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equbf.gif)

We can interpret this as a sum over the symmetric group. If σ ∈ S k , let r(σ) be the number of fixed points of σ. In the conjugacy class of shape λ, there are k!∕z λ elements, and so

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\sum _{\\lambda } \\frac{1} {z_{\\lambda }}\(k + {r}^{2} - r\) = \\frac{1} {k!}\\sum _{\\sigma \\in S_{k}}\(k + r{\(\\sigma \)}^{2} - r\(\\sigma \)\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equbg.gif)

Now ![
$$r\(\\sigma \) = \\mathbf{h}_{\(k-1,1\)} = \\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)} + \\mathbf{h}_{k}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq331.gif) in the notation of Chap. . Here, of course, h k =s (k) is the trivial character of S k and s (k−1,1) is an irreducible character of degree k − 1. We note that r(σ)2 − r(σ) is the value of the character ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)}^{2} + \\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq332.gif), so the sum is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle k\\mathbf{h}_{k} + \\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)}^{2} + \\mathbf{s}_{ \(k-1,1\)},\\mathbf{h}_{k}\\right \\rangle = k\\left \\langle \\mathbf{h}_{k},\\mathbf{h}_{k}\\right \\rangle + \\left \\langle \\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)}^{2},\\mathbf{h}_{ k}\\right \\rangle + \\left \\langle \\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)},\\mathbf{h}_{k}\\right \\rangle }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equbh.gif)

where the inner product is now over the symmetric group. Clearly ![
$$\\left \\langle \\mathbf{h}_{k},\\mathbf{h}_{k}\\right \\rangle = 1$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq333.gif) and ![
$$\\left \\langle \\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)},\\mathbf{h}_{k}\\right \\rangle = 0$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq334.gif). Since the character s (k−1,1) is real and h k is the constant function equal to 1,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\langle \\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)}^{2},\\mathbf{h}_{ k}\\right \\rangle = \\left \\langle \\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)},\\mathbf{s}_{\(k-1,1\)}\\right \\rangle = 1,}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equbi.gif)

and the result follows. □

Theorem 47.10.

Suppose that n is a prime, and let ![
$$\\theta: \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{n}}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow {\\mathbb{C}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq335.gif) be a character that does not factor through the norm map ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{n}}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{r}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq336.gif) for any proper divisor r of n. Then there exists a cuspidal character σ n,θ of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq337.gif) such that if g is a regular semisimple element with eigenvalues ![
$$\\nu,{\\nu }^{q},\\ldots \\in \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq338.gif) then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sigma _{n,\\theta }\(g\) = {\(-1\)}^{n-1}\\sum _{ i=0}^{n-1}\\theta \({\\nu }^{{q}^{i} }\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equ18.gif)

(47.14)

This gives a complete list of the cuspidal characters of ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq339.gif) .

The assumption that n is prime is unnecessary.

Proof.

By Exercise 47.11, we can extend θ to a character of ![
$$\\bar{\\mathbb{F}}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq340.gif) without enlarging the kernel. Thus the kernel of θ is contained in ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{n}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq341.gif) and does not contain the kernel of any norm map ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{n}}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{r}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq342.gif) for any proper divisor r of n. There are now two cases.

If χ is nontrivial on ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq343.gif), then we may proceed as in Theorem 47.9. We are not in the case of that theorem, since we have not assumed that the kernel of θ is trivial, and we do not guarantee that the sequence of cuspidals σ k that we construct can be extended to all k. However, if d ⩽ k, our assumptions guarantee that the restriction of θ to ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{d}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq344.gif) does not factor through the norm map to ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq345.gif) for any proper divisor of d, since the kernel of θ is contained in ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{n}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq346.gif), whose intersection with ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{d}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq347.gif) is just ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq348.gif) since n is prime and d < n. In particular, the kernel of θ cannot contain the kernel of ![
$$N: \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{d}}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{r}}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq349.gif). We get ![
$$\\left \\langle \\chi _{k},\\chi _{k}\\right \\rangle = k$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq350.gif) for k ⩽ n, and proceeding as in Theorem 47.9 we get a sequence of cuspidal representations σ k of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq351.gif) with k ⩽ n such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\chi _{k} =\\sum _{ r=1}^{k}{\(-1\)}^{r-1}\\sigma _{ r} \\circ 1_{k-r}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equbj.gif)

If θ is trivial on ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq352.gif), it is still true that the restriction of θ to ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{d}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq353.gif) does not factor through the norm map to ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{{q}^{r}}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq354.gif) for any proper divisor of d whenever k ⩽ n. So ![
$$\\left \\langle \\chi _{k},\\chi _{k}\\right \\rangle = k + 1$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq355.gif) by Theorem 47.5. Now, we can proceed as before, except that σ1 = 11, so σ1 ∘ 1 k−1 is not irreducible—it is the sum of two irreducible representations s (k−1,1)(q) and s (k)(q) of ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(k, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq356.gif), in the notation of Chap. . Of course, s (k)(q) is the same as 1 k in the notation we have been using. The rest of the argument goes through as in Theorem 47.9. In particular the inner product formula ![
$$\\left \\langle \\chi _{k},\\chi _{k}\\right \\rangle = k + 1$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq357.gif) together with fact that 11 ∘ 1 k−1 accounts for two representations in the decomposition of χ k guarantees that σ k , defined to be ![
$$\\chi _{k} -\\sum _{r<k}{\(-1\)}^{r}\\sigma _{r} \\circ 1_{k-r}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq358.gif) is irreducible.

The cuspidal characters we have constructed are linearly independent by (47.14). They are equal in number to the total number of cuspidal representations, and so we have constructed all of them. □

Let us consider next representations of reductive groups over local fields. The problem is to parametrize irreducible representations of Lie and p-adic groups such as GL(k, F), where ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq359.gif), ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq360.gif) or a non-Archimedean local field.

The parametrization of irreducible representations by characters of tori, which we have already seen for finite fields, extends to representations of Lie and p-adic groups such as GL(k, F), where ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq361.gif), ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq362.gif) or a non-Archimedean local field. If T is a maximal torus of G = GL(k, F), then the characters of T parametrize certain representations of G. As we will explain, not all admissible representations can be parametrized by characters of tori, though (as we will explain) in some sense most are so parametrized. Moreover, if we expand the parametrization we can get a bijection. This is the local Langlands correspondence, which we will now discuss (though without formulating a precise statement).

In this context, a torus is the group of rational points of an algebraic group that, over the algebraic closure of F, is isomorphic to a product of r copies of the multiplicative group G m. (See Chap. .) The torus is called anisotropic if it has no subtori isomorphic to G m over F. If ![
$$F = \\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq363.gif), an anisotropic torus is compact. For example, ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq364.gif) contains two conjugacy classes of maximal tori—the diagonal torus, and the compact torus SO(2). Over the complex numbers, the group ![
$$\\mathrm{SO}\(2, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq365.gif) is conjugate by the Cayley transform to the diagonal subgroup, since if a 2 \+ b 2 = 1, then

![
$$\\displaystyle{c\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a & b\\\\ - b &a \\end{array} \\right \){c}^{-1} = \\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} a + bi& \\\\ &a - bi \\end{array} \\right \),\\qquad \\quad c = \\frac{1} {\\sqrt{2i}}\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} 1& i\\\\ 1 & - i \\end{array} \\right \).}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equbk.gif)

Thus, SO(2) is an anisotropic torus. If G is semisimple, then G has an anisotropic maximal torus if and only if its maximal compact subgroup K has the same rank as G. An examination of Table 28.​1 shows that this is sometimes true and sometimes not. For example, by Proposition 28.3, this will be the case if G∕K is a Hermitian symmetric space. The group SO(n,1) has anisotropic maximal tori if n is even, but not if n is odd. ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(k, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq366.gif) does only if k = 2.

If F is a local field and E∕F is an extension of degree k, then, as in the case of a finite field, we may embed ![
$${E}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{GL}\(k,F\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq367.gif), and the norm one elements will be an anisotropic torus of SL(k, F). From this point of view, we see why ![
$$\\mathrm{SL}\(2, \\mathbb{R}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq368.gif) is the only special linear group over ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq369.gif) that has an anisotropic maximal torus—the algebraic closure ![
$$\\mathbb{C}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq370.gif) of ![
$$\\mathbb{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq371.gif) is too small.

Let G be a locally compact group and Z its center. Let (π,V ) be an irreducible unitary representation of G. By Schur's lemma, π(z) acts by a scalar ω(z) of absolute value 1 for z ∈ Z. Let L 2(G,ω) be the space of all functions f on G such that f(zg) = ω(z)f(g) and

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\int _{G/Z}\\vert f\(g\){\\vert }^{2}\\,\\mathrm{d}g < \\infty.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equbl.gif)

The group G acts on L 2(G,ω) by right translation. The representation π is said to be in the discrete series if it can be embedded as a direct summand in L 2(G,ω). If G is a reductive group over a local field, the irreducible representations of G can be built up from discrete series representations of Levi factors of parabolic subgroups by parabolic induction.

Let F be a local field, and let E∕F be a finite extension. Then the (relative) Weil group W E∕F is a certain finite extension of E ×. It fits in an exact sequence:

![
$$\\displaystyle{1\\longrightarrow {E}^{\\times }\\longrightarrow W_{ E/F}\\longrightarrow \\mathrm{Gal}\(E/F\)\\longrightarrow 1.}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_Equbm.gif)

If E′ ⊃ E is a bigger field, there is a canonical map ![
$$W_{E^{\\prime}/F}\\longrightarrow W_{E/F}$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq372.gif) inducing the norm map ![
$$E^{\\prime}\\longrightarrow E$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq373.gif), and the absolute Weil group W F is the inverse limit of the W E∕F . The discrete series representations of GL(k, F) are then parametrized by the irreducible k-dimensional complex representations of W E∕F . This is a slight oversimplification—we are neglecting the Steinberg representation and a few other discrete series that can be parametrized by replacing W E∕F by the slightly larger Weil–Deligne group.

This parametrization of irreducible representations of GL(k, F) by local Langlands correspondence. Borel [19] is still a useful reference for the Langlands correspondences, though the correspondence must be made more precise than the formulation in this paper, written before many of the results were proved. Henniart's ICM talk [68] is a good more recent reference. The local Langlands conjectures for GL(k) over non-Archimedean local fields of characteristic zero were proved by Harris and Taylor [63]. The p-adic case had been proved earlier by Laumon, Rappoport, and Stuhler, and another proof was given soon after Harris and Taylor by Henniart [67].

Assume that G = GL(k) over a local field F. We now explain why most but not all discrete series representations correspond to characters of anisotropic tori. If T is a maximal torus of G, then T∕Z is anisotropic if ![
$$T\\mathop{\\cong}{E}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq374.gif) where E∕F is an extension of degree k. If θ is a character of E × then inducing θ to W E∕F gives a representation of W E∕F of degree k. This gives a parametrization of many—even most—discrete series representations by characters of tori. In fact, if F is non-Archimedean and the residue characteristic is prime to k, then every irreducible representation is of this form. This is proved in Tate [159] (2.2.5.3). A simple proof when k = 2 is given in Bump [27], Proposition 4.9.3.

Although the parametrization of the discrete series representations by characters of tori is thus a more complex story for local fields than for finite fields, the construction of the irreducible representations by parabolic induction still follows the same pattern as in the finite field case. An analog of Theorem 47.3 is true, and the method of proof extends—the function Δ becomes a distribution, and the corresponding analog of Mackey theory is due to Bruhat [26]. Some differences occur because of measure considerations. There are important differences between the finite field case and the local field case when reducibility occurs. The finite field statement Corollary 47.1 is both suggestive and misleading when looking at the local field case. See Zelevinsky [177]. Zelevinsky's complete results are reviewed in Harris and Taylor [63].

Turning at last to automorphic forms, characters of tori still parametrize automorphic representations, and characters of anisotropic tori parametrize automorphic cuspidal representations. Thus, if E∕F is an extension of number fields with [E: F] = k and A E is the adele ring of E, and if θ is a character of ![
$$A_{E}^{\\times }/{E}^{\\times }$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq375.gif), then there should exist an automorphic representation of GL(k, F) whose L-function is the same as the L-function of θ. If E∕F is cyclic, this is a theorem of Arthur and Clozel [8], Sect. 3.6. In contrast with the situation over local fields, however, where "most" discrete series are parametrized by characters of tori, the cuspidal representations obtained this way are rare. A few more are obtained if we allow parametrizations by the global Weil group, but even these are in the minority. The literature on this topic is too vast to survey here, but we mention one result: in characteristic p, the Langlands parametrization of global automorphic forms on GL(n) was proved by Lafforgue [114].

Exercises

Exercise 47.1 (Transitivity of parabolic induction).

(i)

Let P be a parabolic subgroup of GL(k) with Levi factor M and unipotent radical U, so P = MU. Suppose that Q is a parabolic subgroup of M with Levi factor M Q and unipotent radical U Q . Show that M Q is the Levi factor of a parabolic subgroup R of GL(k) with unipotent radical U Q U.

(ii)

In the setting of (i), show that parabolic induction from M Q directly to GL(k) gives the same result as parabolically inducing first to M, and then from M to GL(k).

(iii)

Show that the multiplication ∘ is associative and that ![
$$\\mathcal{R}\(q\)$$
](A79351_2_En_47_Chapter_IEq376.gif) is a ring.

$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$

(i)

Let V 0 be the span of elements of the form w − π(u)w with u ∈ U. Show that V = V U ⊕ V 0, as M-modules, and that any P-equivariant map ![

(ii)

Let χ be a character of G, and let σ be a character of M. Let Ind(σ) be the character of the representation of G parabolically induced from σ, and let χ U be the function on M defined by

![

Show that χ U is a class function on M, and that
