# 48. Cohomology of Grassmannians

Daniel Bump1

(1)

Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA

Abstract

In this chapter, we will deviate from our usual policy of giving complete proofs in order to explain some important matters. Among other things, we will see that the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq1.gif) introduced in Chap. 34 has yet another interpretation in terms of the cohomology of Grassmannians.

In this chapter, we will deviate from our usual policy of giving complete proofs in order to explain some important matters. Among other things, we will see that the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq2.gif) introduced in Chap.  has yet another interpretation in terms of the cohomology of Grassmannians.

References for this chapter are Fulton [53], Hiller [70], Hodge and Pedoe [71], Kleiman [102], and Manivel [126].

We recall the notion of a CW-complex. Intuitively, this is just a space decomposed into open cells, the closure of each cell being contained in the union of cells of lower dimension—for example, a simplicial complex. (See Dold [44], Chap. , and the appendix in Milnor and Stasheff [129].) Let ![
$$\\mathbb{B}_{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq3.gif) be the closed unit ball in Euclidean n-space. Let ![
$$\\mathbb{B}_{n}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq4.gif) be its interior, the unit disk, and let ![
$$\\mathbb{S}_{n-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq5.gif) be its boundary, the n − 1 sphere. We are given a Hausdorff topological space X together with set ![
$$\\mathcal{S}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq6.gif) of subspaces of X. It is assumed that X is the disjoint union of the ![
$$C_{i} \\in \\mathcal{S}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq7.gif), which are called cells. Each space ![
$$C_{i} \\in \\mathcal{S}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq8.gif) is homeomorphic to ![
$$\\mathbb{B}_{d\(i\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq9.gif) for some d(i) by a homeomorphism ![
$$\\varepsilon _{i}: \\mathbb{B}_{d\(i\)}^{\\circ }\\longrightarrow C_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq10.gif) that extends to a continuous map ![
$$\\varepsilon _{i}: \\mathbb{B}_{d\(i\)}\\longrightarrow X$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq11.gif). The image of ![
$$\\mathbb{S}_{d\(i\)-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq12.gif) under ![
$$\\varepsilon _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq13.gif) lies in the union of cells C i of strictly lower dimension. Thus, if we define the n-skeleton

![
$$\\displaystyle{X_{n} =\\bigcup _{d\(i\)\\leq n}C_{i},}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equa.gif)

the image of ![
$$\\mathbb{S}_{d\(i\)-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq14.gif) under ![
$$\\varepsilon _{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq15.gif) is contained in X d(i)−1. It is assumed that its image is contained in only finitely many C i and that X is given the Whitehead topology, in which a subset of X is closed if and only if its intersection with each C i is closed.

Let K be a compact Lie group, T a maximal compact subgroup, and X the flag manifold K∕T. We recall from Theorem 26.4 that X is naturally a complex analytic manifold. The reason (we recall) is that we can identify X = G∕B where G is the complexification of K and B is its Borel subgroup.

The Lefschetz fixed-point formula can be used to show that the Euler characteristic of X is equal to the order of the Weyl group W. Suppose that M is a manifold of dimension n and ![
$$f: M\\longrightarrow M$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq16.gif) a map. We define the Lefschetz number of f to be

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\varLambda \(f\) =\\sum _{ d=0}^{n}{\(-1\)}^{d}\\,\\text{tr}\\big\(f\\vert {H}^{d}\(M, \\mathbb{Q}\)\\big\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equb.gif)

A fixed point of f is a solution to the equation f(x) = x. The fixed point x is isolated if it is the only fixed point in some neighborhood of x. According to the "Lefschetz fixed-point formula," if M is a compact manifold and f has only isolated fixed points, the Lefschetz number is the number of fixed points counted with multiplicity; see Dold [43].

Let g ∈ K, and let f = f g : X → X be translation by g. If g is the identity, then f induces the identity map on X and hence on its cohomology in every dimension. Therefore, the Euler characteristic is Λ(f). On the other hand, Λ(f) is unchanged if f is replaced by a homotopic map, so we may compute it by moving g to a generator of T. (We are now thinking of X as K∕T.) Then f(hT) = hT if and only if g is in the normalizer of T, so there is one fixed point for each Weyl group element. The local Lefschetz number, which is the multiplicity of the fixed point in the fixed point formula, may also be computed for each fixed point (see Adams [2]) and equals 1. So Λ(f) = |W|, and this is the Euler characteristic of X.

It is possible to be a bit more precise than this: H i (X) = 0 unless i is even and ![
$$\\sum _{i}\\dim {H}^{2i}\(X\) = \\vert W\\vert$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq17.gif). We will explain the reason for this now.

We may give a cell decomposition making X into a CW-complex as follows. If w ∈ W, then BwB∕B is homeomorphic to ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{l\(w\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq18.gif), where l is the length function on W. The proof is the same as Proposition 46.7: the unipotent subgroup U w − which has the Lie algebra is

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\bigoplus _{\\alpha {\\in \\varPhi }^{+}\\cap {w\\varPhi }^{-}}\\mathfrak{X}_{\\alpha }}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equc.gif)

is homeomorphic to ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{l\(w\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq19.gif), and ![
$$u\\longmapsto uwB$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq20.gif) is a homeomorphism of U w − onto BwB∕B. The closure ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq21.gif) of BwB∕B—known as a "closed Schubert cell"—is a union of cells of smaller dimension, so G∕B becomes a CW complex. Since the homology of a CW-complex is the same as the cellular homology of its skeleton (Dold [44], Chap. ), and all the cells in this complex have even dimension—the real dimension of BwB∕B is 2l(w)—it follows that the homology of X is all even-dimensional.

Since X is a compact complex analytic manifold (Theorem 26.4), it is an orientable manifold, and by Poincaré duality we may associate with ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq22.gif) a cohomology class, and these classes span the cohomology ring H ∗(X) as a vector space.

This description can be recast in the language of algebraic geometry. A substitute for the cohomology ring was defined by Chow [37]. See Hartshorne [64], Appendix A, for a convenient synopsis of the Chow ring, and see Fulton [54] for a modern treatment. In the graded Chow ring of a nonsingular variety X, the homogeneous elements of degree r are rational equivalence classes of algebraic cycles. Here an algebraic cycle of codimension r is an element of the free Abelian group generated by the irreducible subvarieties of codimension r. Rational equivalence of cycles is an equivalence relation of algebraic deformation. For divisors, which are cycles of codimension 1, it coincides with the familiar relation of linear equivalence. We recall that two divisors D 1 and D 2 are linearly equivalent if D 1 − D 2 is the divisor of a function f in the function field of X.

The multiplication in the Chow ring is the intersection of cycles. If two subvarieties Y and Z (of codimensions m and n) are given, we say that Y and Z intersect properly if every irreducible component of ![
$$Y \\cap Z$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq23.gif) has codimension m \+ n. (If m \+ n exceeds the dimension of X, this means that Y and Z have an empty intersection.) Chow's lemma asserts that Y and Z may be deformed to intersect properly. That is, there exist Y ′ and Z′ rationally equivalent to Y and Z, respectively, such that Y and Z′ intersect properly. The intersection ![
$$X \\cap Z$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq24.gif) is then a union of cycles of codimension m \+ n, whose sum in the Chow ring is ![
$$Y \\cap Z$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq25.gif). (They must be counted with a certain intersection multiplicity.)

The "moving" process embodied by Chow's lemma will be an issue for us when we consider the intersection pairing in Grassmannians, so let us contemplate a simple case of intersections in ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq26751.gif). Hartshorne [64], I.7, gives a beautiful and complete treatment of intersection theory in ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{n}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq27856.gif).

The space ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq28695.gif), which we will come to presently, resembles flag manifolds and Grassmannians in that the Chow ring and the cohomology ring coincide. (Indeed, ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq29265.gif) is a Grassmannian.) The homology of ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq301545.gif) can be computed very simply since it has a cell decomposition in which each cell is an affine space ![
$${\\mathbb{A}}^{i}\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{C}}^{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq317562.gif).

![
$$\\displaystyle{ {\\mathbb{P}}^{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\) = {\\mathbb{C}}^{n} \\cup {\\mathbb{C}}^{n-1} \\cup \\cdots \\cup {\\mathbb{C}}^{0},\\dim \({\\mathbb{C}}^{i}\) = 2i. }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ1.gif)

(48.1)

Each cell contributes to the homology in exactly one dimension, so

![
$$\\displaystyle{H_{i}\\big\({\\mathbb{P}}^{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\left \\{\\begin{array}{cl} \\mathbb{Z}& \\;\\mbox{ if $i \\leq 2n$ is even,} \\\\ 0 &\\;\\mathrm{otherwise}. \\end{array} \\right.}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equd.gif)

The cohomology is the same by Poincaré duality. The multiplicative structure in the ring ![
$${H}^{{\\ast}}\\big\({\\mathbb{P}}^{n}\(\\mathbb{C}\)\\big\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq323685.gif) is that of a truncated polynomial ring. The cohomology class of a hyperplane [![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{n-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq338795.gif) in the decomposition (48.1)] is a generator.

Let us consider the intersection of two curves Y and Z in ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{2}\(\\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq348746.gif). The intersection Y ⋅ Z, which is the product in the Chow ring, 1, is a cycle of degree zero, that is, just a sum of points. The rational equivalence class of a cycle of degree zero is completely determined by the number of points, and intersection theory on ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq35.gif) is fully described if we know how to compute this number.

Each curve is the locus of a homogeneous polynomial in three variables, and the degree of this polynomial is the degrees of the curves, d(Y ) and d(Z). According to Bezout's theorem, the number of points in the intersection of Y and Z equals d(Y ) d(Z).

Fig. 48.1

A curve of degree d in ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq36.gif) is linearly equivalent to d lines

Bezout's theorem can be used to illustrate Chow's lemma. First, note that a curve of degree d is rationally equivalent to a sum of d lines (Fig. 48.1), so Y is linearly equivalent to a sum of d(Y ) lines, and Z is linearly equivalent to a sum of d(Z) lines. Since two lines have a unique point of intersection, the first set of d(Y ) lines will intersect the second set of d(Z) lines in exactly d(Y ) d(Z) points, which is Bezout's theorem for ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq37.gif) (Fig. 48.2).

Fig. 48.2

Bezout's theorem via Chow's lemma

It is understood that a point of transversal intersection is counted once, but a point where Y and Z are tangent is counted with a multiplicity that can be defined in different ways.

Fig. 48.3

The self-intersection multiplicity of a cycle in ![
$${\\mathbb{P}}^{2}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq38.gif)

The intersection ![
$$Y \\cdot Z$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq39.gif) must be defined even when the cycles Y and Z are equal. For this, one may replace Z by a rationally equivalent cycle before taking the intersection. The self-intersection ![
$$Y \\cdot Y$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq40.gif) is computed using Chow's lemma, which allows one copy of Y to be deformed so that its intersection with the undeformed Y is transversal (Fig. 48.3). Thus, replacing Y by a rationally equivalent cycle, one may count the intersections straightforwardly (Fig. 48.2).

The Chow ring often misses much of the cohomology. For example, if X is a curve of genus g > 1, then ![
$${H}^{1}\(X\)\\mathop{\\cong}{\\mathbb{Z}}^{2g}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq41.gif) is nontrivial, yet the cohomology of an algebraic cycle of codimension d lies in H 2d (X), and is never odd-dimensional. However, if X is a flag variety, projective space, or Grassmannian, the Chow ring and the cohomology ring are isomorphic. The cup product corresponds to the intersection of algebraic cycles.

Let us now consider intersection theory on G∕P, where P is a parabolic subgroup, that is, a proper subgroup of G containing B. For such a variety, the story is much the same as for the flag manifold—the Chow ring and the cohomology ring can be identified, and the Bruhat decomposition gives a decomposition of the space as a CW-complex. We can write

![
$$\\displaystyle{B\\setminus G/P\\mathop{\\cong}W/W_{P},}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Eque.gif)

where W P is the Weyl group of the Levi factor of P. If ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(n\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq42.gif), this is Proposition 46.1(iii). If w ∈ W, let ![
$$\\mathcal{C}{\(w\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq43.gif) be the open Schubert cell B w P∕P, and let ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq44.gif) be its closure, which is the union of ![
$$\\mathcal{C}{\(w\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq45.gif) and open Schubert cells of lower dimension. The closed Schubert cells ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq46.gif) give a basis of the cohomology.

We will discuss the particular case where ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(r + s, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq47.gif) and P is the maximal parabolic subgroup

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} g_{1} & {\\ast}\\\\ &g_{ 2} \\end{array} \\right \)\\,\\Big\\vert \\,g_{1} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{C}\),g_{2} \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(s, \\mathbb{C}\)\\right \\}}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equf.gif)

with Levi factor ![
$$M = \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{C}\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(s, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq48.gif). The quotient X r,s = G∕P is then the Grassmannian, a compact complex manifold of dimension rs. In this case, the cohomology ring H ∗(X r,s ) is closely related to the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq49.gif) introduced in Chap. .

To explain this point, let us explain how to "truncate" the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq50.gif) and obtain a finite-dimensional algebra that will be isomorphic to ![
$${H}^{{\\ast}}\(X_{r,s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq51.gif). Suppose that ![
$$\\mathcal{J}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq52.gif) is the linear span of all ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq53.gif) such that the length of λ is > r. Then ![
$$\\mathcal{J}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq54.gif) is an ideal, and the quotient ![
$$\\mathcal{R}/\\mathcal{J}_{r}{\\mathop{\\cong}\\varLambda }^{\(r\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq55.gif) by the characteristic map. Indeed, it follows from Proposition 36.5 that ![
$$\\mathcal{J}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq56.gif) is the kernel of the homomorphism ![
$${\\mathrm{ch}}^{\(n\)}: {\\mathcal{R}\\longrightarrow \\varLambda }^{\(n\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq57.gif).

We can also consider the ideal ![
$$^{\\iota }\\mathcal{J}_{s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq58.gif), where ι is the involution of Theorem 34.3. By Proposition 35.2, this is the span of the ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq59.gif) in which the length of λ t is greater than s—in other words, in which ![
$$\\lambda _{1}> s$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq60.gif). So ![
$$\\mathcal{J}_{r} {+ }^{\\iota }\\mathcal{J}_{s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq61.gif) is the span of all ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq62.gif) such that the diagram of λ does not fit in an ![
$$r \\times s$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq63.gif) box. Therefore, the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{r,s} = \\mathcal{R}/\(\\mathcal{J}_{r} {+ }^{\\iota }\\mathcal{J}_{s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq64.gif) is spanned by the images of ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq65.gif) where the diagram of λ does fit in an r × s box. For example, ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{3,2}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq66.gif) is spanned by ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq67.gif), ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq68.gif), ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(2\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq69.gif), ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(11\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq70.gif), ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(21\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq71.gif), ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(22\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq72.gif), ![
$$s_{\(111\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq73.gif), ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(211\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq74.gif), ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(221\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq75.gif), and ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\(222\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq76.gif). It is a free ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq77.gif)-module of rank 10. In general the rank of the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq78.gif) is ![
$$\\binom{r + s}{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq79.gif), which is the number of partitions of r \+ s of length ⩽ r into parts not exceeding s—that is, partitions with diagrams that fit into a box of dimensions r × s.

Theorem 48.1.

The cohomology ring of X r,s is isomorphic to ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq80.gif) . In this isomorphism, the cohomology classes of the Schubert cells correspond to the ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq81.gif) , as λ runs through the partitions with diagrams that fit into an r × s box.

We will not prove this. Proofs (all rather similar and based on a method of Hodge) may be found in Fulton [53], Hiller [70], Hodge and Pedoe [71], and Manivel [126]. We will instead give an informal discussion of the result, including a precise description of the isomorphism and an example.

Let us explain how to associate a partition λ with a diagram that is contained in the r × s box with a Schubert cell of codimension equal to |λ|. In fact, to every coset wW P in W∕W P we will associate such a partition.

Right multiplication by an element of ![
$$W_{P}\\mathop{\\cong}S_{r} \\times S_{s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq82.gif) consists of reordering the first r columns and the last s columns. Hence, the representative w of the given coset in W∕W P may be chosen to be a permutation matrix such that the entries in the first r columns are in ascending order, and so that the entries in the last s columns are in ascending order. In other words, if σ is the permutation such that ![
$$w_{\\sigma \(j\),j}\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq83.gif), then

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sigma \(1\) <\\sigma \(2\) <\\cdots <\\sigma \(r\),\\sigma \(r + 1\) <\\sigma \(r + 2\) <\\cdots <\\sigma \(r + s\). }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ2.gif)

(48.2)

With this choice, we associate a partition λ as follows. We mark some of the zero entries of the permutation matrix w as follows. If ![
$$1 \\leq j \\leq r$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq84.gif), if the 1 in the ith row is in the last s columns, and if the 1 in the jth column is above (i,j), then we mark the (i,j)th entry. For example, if r = 3 and s = 2, here are a some examples of a marked matrix:

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccccc} \\;1\\;& & & & \\\\ &\\;1\\; & & & \\\\ \\bullet & \\bullet & &\\;1\\;& \\\\ & &\\;1\\; & & \\\\ \\bullet & \\bullet & \\bullet & &\\;1\\; \\end{array} \\right \),\\quad \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccccc} \\;1\\;& & & & \\\\ \\bullet & & &\\;1\\; & \\\\ &\\;1\\;& & & \\\\ & &\\;1\\; & & \\\\ \\bullet & \\bullet & \\bullet & &\\;1\\; \\end{array} \\right \),\\quad \\left \(\\begin{array}{ccccc} \\;1\\;& & & & \\\\ \\bullet & & &\\;1\\; & \\\\ \\bullet & & & &\\;1\\;\\\\ &\\;1\\; & & & \\\\ & &\\;1\\;& & \\end{array} \\right \) }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ3.gif)

(48.3)

Now, we collect the marked columns and read off the permutation. For each row containing marks, there will be a part of the permutation equal to the number of marks in that row. In the three examples above, the respective permutations λ are:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(2,2,1\),\(2,1,1\),\(2\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equg.gif)

Their diagrams fit into a 2 × 3 box. We will write ![
$$\\mathcal{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq85.gif) for the closed Schubert cell ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq86.gif) when λ and w are related this way.

Let F i be the vector subspace of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{r+s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq87.gif) consisting of vectors of the form ![
$$^{t}\(x_{1},\\ldots,x_{i},0,\\ldots,0\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq88.gif). The group G acts on the Grassmannian ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq89.gif) of r-dimensional subspaces of ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{r+s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq90.gif). The stabilizer of F r is precisely the parabolic subgroup P, so there is a bijection ![
$$X_{r,s}\\longrightarrow \\mathcal{G}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq91.gif) in which the coset ![
$$gP\\longmapsto gF_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq92.gif). We topologize ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq93.gif) by asking that this map be a homeomorphism.

We can characterize the Schubert cells in terms of this parametrization by means of integer sequences. Given a sequence ![
$$\(d\) = \(d_{0},d_{1},\\ldots,d_{r+s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq94.gif) with

![
$$\\displaystyle{ 0 \\leq d_{0} \\leq d_{1} \\leq \\cdots \\leq d_{r+s} = r,0 \\leq d_{i} \\leq 1, }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ4.gif)

(48.4)

we can consider the set ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq95.gif) of V in ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq96.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\dim \(V \\cap F_{i}\) = d_{i}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ5.gif)

(48.5)

Let ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq97.gif) be the set of ![
$$V$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq98.gif) in ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq99.gif) such that

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\dim \(V \\cap F_{i}\) \\geq d_{i}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ6.gif)

(48.6)

The function ![
$$V \\longmapsto \\dim \(V \\cap F_{i}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq100.gif) is upper semicontinuous on ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq101.gif), that is, for any integer n, ![
$$\\{V \\,\\vert \\,\\dim \(V \\cap F_{i}\) \\geq n\\}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq102.gif) is closed. Therefore, ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq103.gif) is closed, and in fact it is the closure of ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq104.gif).

Lemma 48.1.

In the characterization of ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq105.gif) it is only necessary to impose the condition (48.6) at integers 0 < i < r + s such that ![
$$d_{i+1} = d_{i}> d_{i-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq106.gif) .

Proof.

If ![
$$d_{i+1}> d_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq107.gif) and ![
$$\\dim \(V \\cap F_{i+1}\) \\geq d_{i+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq108.gif), then since ![
$$V \\cap F_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq109.gif) has codimension at most 1 in ![
$$V \\cap F_{i+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq110.gif) we do not need to assume ![
$$\\dim \(V \\cap F_{i}\) \\geq d_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq111.gif). If ![
$$d_{i} = d_{i-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq112.gif) and ![
$$\\dim \(V \\cap F_{i-1}\) \\geq d_{i-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq113.gif) then ![
$$\\dim \(V \\cap F_{i-1}\) \\geq d_{i-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq114.gif). □

We will show ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq115.gif) is the image in ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq116.gif) of an open Schubert cell. For example, with r = 3 and s = 2, taking w to be the first matrix in (48.3), we consider the Schubert cell BwP∕P, which has the image in ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{3,2}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq117.gif) that consists of all bwF 3, where b ∈ B. A one-dimensional unipotent subspace of B is sufficient to produce all of these elements, and a typical such space consists of all matrices of the form

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccccc} \\,1\\,& & & & \\\\ &\\,1\\, & & & \\\\ & &\\,1\\,&\\alpha & \\\\ & & & \\,1\\, & \\\\ & & & &\\,1\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{ccccc} \\,1\\,& & & & \\\\ &\\,1\\, & & & \\\\ & & &\\,1\\,& \\\\ & &\\,1\\, & & \\\\ & & & &\\,1\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\left \(\\begin{array}{c} x_{1} \\\\ x_{2} \\\\ x_{3} \\\\ 0\\\\ 0 \\end{array} \\right \) = \\left \(\\begin{array}{c} x_{1} \\\\ x_{2} \\\\ \\alpha x_{3} \\\\ x_{3} \\\\ 0 \\end{array} \\right \)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equh.gif)

with α fixed. These may be characterized by the conditions (48.5) with

![
$$\\displaystyle{\(d_{0},\\ldots,d_{5}\) = \(0,1,2,2,3,3\).}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equi.gif)

Proposition 48.1.

The image in ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq118.gif) of the Schubert cell ![
$$\\mathcal{C}\(w\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq119.gif) corresponding to the partition λ (the diagram of which, we have noted, must fit in an r × s box) is ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq120.gif) , where the integer sequence ![
$$\(d_{0},d_{1},\\ldots,d_{r+s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq121.gif) where

![
$$\\displaystyle{ d_{k} = i\\Longleftrightarrow s + i - \\lambda _{i} \\leq k \\leq s + i - \\lambda _{i+1}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ7.gif)

(48.7)

Similarly, the image of ![
$$\\mathcal{C}{\(w\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq122.gif) is ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq123.gif) .

We note that, by Lemma 48.1, if (d) is the sequence in (48.7), the closed Schubert cell ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq124.gif) is characterized by the conditions

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\dim \(V \\cap F_{s+i-\\lambda _{i}}\) \\geq i. }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ8.gif)

(48.8)

Also, by Lemma 48.1, this only needs to be checked when ![
$$\\lambda _{i}> \\lambda _{i+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq125.gif). [The characterization of the open Schubert cell still requires ![
$$\\dim \(V \\cap F_{k}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq126.gif) to be specified for all k, not just those of the form s \+ i − λ i .]

Proof.

We will prove this for the open cell. The image of ![
$$\\mathcal{C}{\(w\)}^{\\circ }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq127.gif) in ![
$$\\mathcal{G}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq128.gif) consists of all spaces bwF r with b ∈ B, so we must show that, with d i as in (48.7), we have

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\dim \(bwF_{r} \\cap F_{i}\) = d_{i}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equj.gif)

Since b stabilizes F i , we may apply b −1, and we are reduced to showing that

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\dim \(wF_{r} \\cap F_{i}\) = d_{i}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equk.gif)

If σ is the permutation such that ![
$$w_{\\sigma \(j\),j}\\neq 0$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq129.gif), then the number of entries below the nonzero element in the ith column, where ![
$$1 \\leq i \\leq r$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq130.gif), is ![
$$r + s - \\sigma \(i\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq131.gif). However, r − i of these are not "marked." Therefore, ![
$$\\lambda _{i} =\\big \(r + s - \\sigma \(i\)\\big\) - \(r - i\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq132.gif), that is,

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\sigma \(i\) = s + i - \\lambda _{i}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ9.gif)

(48.9)

Now wF r is the space of vectors that have arbitrary values in the σ(1), σ(2),...,σ(r) positions, and all other entries are zero. So the dimension of ![
$$wF_{r} \\cap F_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq133.gif) is the number of k such that ![
$$1 \\leq j \\leq r$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq134.gif) and ![
$$\\sigma \(k\) \\leq i$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq135.gif). Using (48.2),

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathrm{dim}\(wF_{r} \\cap F_{i}\) = k\\Longleftrightarrow\\sigma \(i\) \\leq k <\\sigma \(i + 1\),}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equl.gif)

which by (48.9) is equivalent to (48.7). □

When (d) and λ are related as in (48.7), we will also denote the Schubert cell ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(d\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq136.gif) by ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq137.gif).

As we asserted earlier, the cohomology ring X r,s is isomorphic to the quotient ![
$$\\mathcal{R}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq138.gif) of the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq139.gif), which has played such a role in this last part of the book. To get some intuition for this, let us consider the identity in ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq140.gif)

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathbf{s}_{\(1\)} \\cdot \\mathbf{s}_{\(1\)} = \\mathbf{s}_{\(2\)} + \\mathbf{s}_{\(11\)}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equm.gif)

By the parametrization we have given, ![
$$\\mathbf{s}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq141.gif) corresponds to the Schubert cell ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\\lambda }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq142.gif). In the case at hand, the relevant cells are characterized by the following conditions:

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} \\mathfrak{C}_{\(1\)}& =& \\{V \\,\\vert \\,\\dim \(V \\cap F_{s}\) \\geq 1\\}, {}\\\\ \\mathfrak{C}_{\(2\)}& =& \\{V \\,\\vert \\,\\dim \(V \\cap F_{s-1}\) \\geq 1\\}, {}\\\\ \\mathfrak{C}_{\(11\)}& =& \\{V \\,\\vert \\,\\dim \(V \\cap F_{s+1}\) \\geq 2\\}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ10.gif)

So our expectation is that if we deform ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(1\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq143.gif) into two copies ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(1\)}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq144.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(1\)}^{\\prime\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq145.gif) that intersect properly, the intersection will be rationally equivalent to the sum of ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(2\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq146.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(11\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq147.gif). We may choose spaces G s and H s of codimension s such that ![
$$G_{s} \\cap H_{s} = F_{s-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq148.gif) and ![
$$G_{s} + H_{s} = F_{s+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq149.gif). Now let us consider the intersection of

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\mathfrak{C}^{\\prime}_{\(1\)} =\\{ V \\,\\vert \\,\\dim \(V \\cap G_{s}\) \\geq 1\\},\\mathfrak{C}^{\\prime\\prime}_{\(1\)} =\\{ V \\,\\vert \\,\\dim \(V \\cap H_{s}\) \\geq 1\\}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equn.gif)

If V lies in both ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(1\)}^{\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq150.gif) and ![
$$\\mathfrak{C}_{\(1\)}^{\\prime\\prime}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq151.gif), then let v′ and v″ be nonzero vectors in ![
$$V \\cap G_{s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq152.gif) and ![
$$V \\cap H_{s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq153.gif), respectively. There are two possibilities. Either v′ and v″ are proportional, in which case they lie in ![
$$V \\cap F_{s-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq154.gif), so ![
$$V \\in \\mathfrak{C}_{\(2\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq155.gif), or they are linearly independent. In the second case, both lie in F s+1, so ![
$$V \\in \\mathfrak{C}_{\(11\)}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq156.gif).

The intersection theory of flag manifolds is very similar to that of Grassmannians. The difference is that while the cohomology of Grassmannians for ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(r\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq157.gif) is modeled on the ring ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq158.gif), which can be identified as in Chap.  with the ring Λ of symmetric polynomials, the cohomology of flag manifolds is modeled on a polynomial ring. Specifically, if B is the Borel subgroup of ![
$$G = \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{C}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq159.gif), then the cohomology ring of G∕B is a quotient of the polynomial ring ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq160.gif), where each x i is homogeneous of degree 2. Lascoux and Schützenberger defined elements of the polynomial ring ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq161.gif) called Schubert polynomials which play a role analogous to that of the Schur polynomials (See Fulton [53] and Manivel [126]).

A minor problem is that H ∗(G∕B) is not precisely the polynomial ring ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq162.gif) but a quotient, just as ![
$${H}^{{\\ast}}\(\\mathcal{G}_{r,s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq163.gif) is not precisely ![
$$\\mathcal{R}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq164.gif) or even its quotient ![
$$\\mathcal{R}/\\mathcal{J}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq165.gif), which is isomorphic to the ring of symmetric polynomials in ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq166.gif).

The ring ![
$$\\mathbb{Z}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq167.gif) should be more properly regarded as the cohomology ring of an infinite CW-complex, which is the cohomology ring of the space ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq168.gif) of ![
$$r$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq169.gif)-flags in ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{\\infty }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq170.gif). That is, let ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq171.gif) be the space of ![
$$r$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq172.gif)-flags in ![
$${\\mathbb{C}}^{r+s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq173.gif):

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\{0\\} = F_{0} \\subset F_{1} \\subset F_{2} \\subset \\cdots \\subset F_{r} \\subset {\\mathbb{C}}^{r+s},\\dim \(F_{ i}\) = i. }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ11.gif)

(48.10)

We can regard ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq174.gif) as G∕P, where P is the parabolic subgroup

![
$$\\displaystyle{ \\left \\{\\left \(\\begin{array}{cc} \\,b\\,&{\\ast}\\\\ &\\,g\\, \\end{array} \\right \)\\,\\vert \\,b \\in B,\\,g \\in \\mathrm{GL}\(r, \\mathbb{C}\)\\right \\}. }$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ12.gif)

(48.11)

We may embed ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{r,s}\\hookrightarrow \\mathcal{F}_{r,s+1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq175.gif), and the union of the ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq176.gif) (topologized as the direct limit) is ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{r}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq177.gif). The open Schubert cells in ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq178.gif) correspond to double cosets ![
$$B\\setminus G/P$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq179.gif) parametrized by elements ![
$$w \\in S_{r+s}/S_{s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq180.gif). As we increase s, the CW-complex ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{r,s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq181.gif) is obtained by adding new cells, but only in higher dimension. The n-skeleton stabilizes when s is sufficiently large, and so ![
$${H}^{n}\(\\mathcal{F}_{r}\)\\mathop{\\cong}{H}^{n}\(F_{r,s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq182.gif) if s is sufficiently large. The ring ![
$${H}^{{\\ast}}\(\\mathcal{F}_{r}\)\\mathop{\\cong}\\mathbb{Z}\[x_{1},\\ldots,x_{r}\]$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq183.gif) is perhaps the natural domain of the Schubert polynomials.

The cohomology of Grassmannians (and flag manifolds) provided some of the original evidence for the famous conjectures of Weil [170] on the number of points on a variety over a finite field. Let us count the number of points of X r,s over the field ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq184.gif) with field elements. Representing the space as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)/P\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq185.gif), where n = r \+ s, its cardinality is

![
$$\\displaystyle\\begin{array}{rcl} & & \\frac{\\vert \\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\vert } {\\vert P\(\\mathbb{F}_{a}\)\\vert } = \\frac{\({q}^{n}-1\)\({q}^{n}-q\)\\cdots \({q}^{n}-{q}^{n-1}\)} {\({q}^{r}-1\)\({q}^{r}-q\)\\cdots \({q}^{r}-{q}^{r-1}\) \\cdot \({q}^{s}-1\)\({q}^{s}-q\)\\cdots \({q}^{s}-{q}^{s-1}\) \\cdot {q}^{rs}}. {}\\\\ \\end{array}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equ13.gif)

In the denominator, we have used the Levi decomposition of P = MU, where the Levi factor ![
$$M = \\mathrm{GL}\(r\) \\times \\mathrm{GL}\(s\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq186.gif) and the unipotent radical U has dimension rs. This is a Gaussian binomial coefficient ![
$$\\binom{n}{r}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq187.gif). It is a generating function for the cohomology ring ![
$${H}^{{\\ast}}\(X_{r,s}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq188.gif).

Motivated by these examples and other similar ones, as well as the examples of projective nonsingular curves (for which there is cohomology in dimension 1, so that the Chow ring and the cohomology ring are definitely distinct), Weil proposed a more precise relationship between the complex cohomology of a nonsingular projective variety and the number of solutions over a finite field. Proving the Weil conjectures required a new cohomology theory that was eventually supplied by Grothendieck. This is the l-adic cohomology. Let ![
$$\\bar{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq189.gif) be the algebraic closure of ![
$$\\mathbb{F}_{q}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq190.gif), and let ![
$$\\phi: X\\longrightarrow X$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq191.gif) be the geometric Frobenius map, which raises the coordinates of a point in X to the qth power. The fixed points of ϕ are then the elements of ![
$$X\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq192.gif), and they may be counted by means of a generalization of the Lefschetz fixed-point formula:

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert X\(F_{q}\)\\vert =\\sum _{ k=0}^{2n}{\(-1\)}^{k}\\,\\mathrm{tr}\(\\phi \\vert {H}^{k}\)\\,.}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equo.gif)

The dimensions of the l-adic cohomology groups are the same as the complex cohomology, and in these examples (since all the cohomology comes from algebraic cycles) the odd-dimensional cohomology vanishes while on ![
$${H}^{2i}\(X\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq193.gif) the Frobenius endomorphism acts by the scalar q i . Thus,

![
$$\\displaystyle{\\vert X\(F_{q}\)\\vert =\\sum _{ k=0}^{n}\\dim {H}^{2k}\(X\)\\,{q}^{k}.}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_Equp.gif)

The l-adic cohomology groups have the same dimensions as the complex ones. Hence, the Grothendieck–Lefschetz fixed-point formula explains the extraordinary fact that the number of points over a finite field of the Grassmannian or flag varieties is a generating function for the complex cohomology.

Exercises

Exercise 48.1.

Consider the space ![
$$\\mathcal{F}_{r,s}\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq194.gif) of r-flags in ![
$${\\mathbb{F}}^{r+s}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq195.gif). Compute the cardinality by representing it as ![
$$\\mathrm{GL}\(n, \\mathbb{F}_{q}\)/P\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq196.gif), where P is the parabolic subgroup (48.11). Show that ![
$$\\vert \\mathcal{F}_{r,s}\(\\mathbb{F}_{q}\)\\vert =\\sum _{i}d_{i}\(r,s\)\\,{q}^{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq197.gif), where for fixed s, we have ![
$$d_{i}\(r,s\) = \\binom{r + i - 1}{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq198.gif).

Exercise 48.2.

Prove that ![
$${H}^{{\\ast}}\(\\mathcal{F}_{r}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq199.gif) is a polynomial ring in r generators, with generators in ![
$${H}^{2}\(\\mathcal{F}_{r}\)$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq200.gif) being the cohomology classes of the canonical line bundles ξ i ; here ![
$$x_{i}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq201.gif) associates with a flag (48.10) the one-dimensional vector space ![
$$F_{i}/F_{i-1}$$
](A79351_2_En_48_Chapter_IEq202.gif).

## Appendix: Sage

Sage is a system of free mathematical software that is under active development. Although it was created to do number theory calculations, it contains considerable code for combinatorics, and other areas. For Lie groups, it can compute tensor products of representations, symmetric and exterior powers, and branching rules. It knows the roots, fundamental dominant weights, Weyl group actions, etc. There is also excellent support for symmetric functions and crystals. Many other things are in Sage : Iwahori Hecke algebras, Bruhat order, Kazhdan–Lusztig polynomials, and so on.

This appendix is not a tutorial, but rather a quick introduction to a few of the problems Sage can solve. For a systematic tutorial, you should go through the Lie Methods and Related Combinatorics thematic tutorial available at:

 http://www.sagemath.org/doc/thematic_tutorials/lie.html

Other Sage tutorials may be found at  http://www.sagemath.org/help.html  . You should learn Sage 's systems of on-line documentation, tab completion, and so forth.

You should try to run the most recent version of Sage you can because there are continual improvements. Important speedups were added to the Lie group code in both versions 5.4 and 5.5. For simple tasks Sage can be treated as a command-line calculator (or you can use a notebook interface) but for more complicated tasks you can write programs using Python . You can contribute to Sage development: if you want a feature and it doesn't exist, you can make it yourself, and if it is something others might want, eventually get it into the distributed version.

For computations with representations it is convenient to work in a WeylCharacterRing. There are two notations for these. In the default notation, a representation is represented by its highest weight vector, as an element of its ambient space in the notation of the appendices in Bourbaki [ 23 ]. Let us give a brief example of a dialog using the standard notation.

sage: B3=WeylCharacterRing("B3"); B3

The Weyl Character Ring of Type ['B', 3] with Integer Ring

coefficients

sage: B3.fundamental_weights()

Finite family {1: (1,0,0), 2: (1,1,0), 3: (1/2,1/2,1/2)}

sage: [B3(f) for f in B3.fundamental_weights()]

[B3(1,0,0), B3(1,1,0), B3(1/2,1/2,1/2)]

sage: [B3(f).degree() for f in B3.fundamental_weights()]

[7, 21, 8]

sage: B3(1,1,0).symmetric_power(3)

B3(1,0,0) + 2*B3(1,1,0) + B3(2,1,1) + B3(2,2,1) + B3(3,1,0)

\+ B3(3,3,0)

sage: [f1,f2,f3]=B3.fundamental_weights()

sage: B3(f3)

B3(1/2,1/2,1/2)

sage: B3(f3)^3

4*B3(1/2,1/2,1/2) + 3*B3(3/2,1/2,1/2) + 2*B3(3/2,3/2,1/2)

\+ B3(3/2,3/2,3/2)

This illustrates different ways of interacting with Sage as a command-line interpreter. I prefer to run Sage from within an Emacs buffer; others prefer the notebook. For complicated tasks, such as loading some Python code, you may write your commands in a file and load or attach it. Whatever your method of interacting with the program, you can have a dialog with this one. Sage provides a prompt (" sage :") after which you type a command. Sage will sometimes produce some output, sometimes not; in any case, when it is done it will give you another prompt.

The first line contains two commands, separated by a semicolon. The first command creates the WeylCharacterRing B3 but produces no output. The second command " B3 " prints the name of the ring you have just created. Elements of the ring are virtual representations of the Lie group   having Cartan type B 3 . Addition corresponds to direct sum, multiplication to tensor product.

The ring B3 is a Python class, and like every Python class it has methods and attributes which you can use to perform various tasks. If at the sage: prompt you type B3 then hit the tab key, you will get a list of Python methods and attributes that B3 has. For example, you will notice methods dynkin_diagram and extended_dynkin_diagram . If you want more information about one of them, you may access the on-line documentation, with examples of how to use it, by typing B3.dynkin_diagram?

Turning to the next command, the Python class B3 has a method called fundamental_weights . This returns a Python dictionary with elements that are the fundamental weights. The third command gives the irreducible representations with these highest weights, as a Python list. After that, we compute the degrees of these, the symmetric cube of a representation, the spin representation B3(1/2,1/2,1/2) and its square.

We can alternatively create the WeylCharacterRing with an alternative syntax when you create it with the option style="coroots" . This is most appropriate for semisimple Lie groups: for a semisimple Lie group, we recall that the fundamental dominant weights are defined to be the dual basis to the coroots. Assuming that the group is simply connected the fundamental dominant weights are weights, that is, characters of a maximal torus. For such a case, where G is semisimple and simply connected, every dominant weight may be uniquely expressed as a linear combination, with nonzero integer coefficients, of the fundamental dominant weights. This gives an alternative notation for the representations, as the following example shows:

sage: B3=WeylCharacterRing("B3",style="coroots"); B3

The Weyl Character Ring of Type ['B', 3] with Integer Ring

coefficients

sage: B3.fundamental_weights()

Finite family {1: (1,0,0), 2: (1,1,0), 3: (1/2,1/2,1/2)}

sage: [B3(f) for f in B3.fundamental_weights()]

[B3(1,0,0), B3(0,1,0), B3(0,0,1)]

sage: [B3(f).degree() for f in B3.fundamental_weights()]

[7, 21, 8]

sage: B3(0,1,0).symmetric_power(3)

B3(1,0,0) + 2*B3(0,1,0) + B3(1,0,2) + B3(0,1,2) + B3(2,1,0)

\+ B3(0,3,0)

sage: [f1,f2,f3]=B3.fundamental_weights()

sage: B3(f3)

B3(0,0,1) sage:

B3(f3)^3

4*B3(0,0,1) + 3*B3(1,0,1) + 2*B3(0,1,1) + B3(0,0,3)

This is the same series of computations as before, just in a different notation.

For Cartan Type A r , if you use style="coroots" , you are effectively working with the group   . There is no way to represent the determinant in this notation. On the other hand, if you use the default style, the determinant is represented by A2(1,1,1) (in the case r = 2) so if you want to do computations for   , do not use coroot style.

Sage knows many branching rules. For example, here is how to calculate the restriction of a representation from   to   .

sage: A3=WeylCharacterRing("A3",style="coroots")

sage: C2=WeylCharacterRing("C2",style="coroots")

sage: r=A3(6,4,1)

sage: r.degree()

6860

sage: r.branch(C2,rule="symmetric")

C2(5,1) + C2(7,0) + C2(5,2) + C2(7,1) + C2(5,3)

\+ C2(7,2) + C2(5,4) + C2(7,3) + C2(5,5) + C2(7,4)

To get documentation about Sage's branching rules, either see the thematic tutorial or enter the command:

sage: get_branching_rule?

As another example, let us compute

There are different ways of doing this computation. An efficient way is just to compute decompose the tenth power of the standard character into irreducibles: if   then its modulus squared is ∑ a λ 2 .

sage: A1=WeylCharacterRing("A1")

sage: A1(1)

A1(0,0)

sage: A1([1])

A1(1,0)

sage: A1([1])^10

42*A1(5,5) + 90*A1(6,4) + 75*A1(7,3) + 35*A1(8,2) + 9*A1(9,1)

\+ A1(10,0)

sage: (A1([1])^10).monomial_coefficients()

{(8, 2): 35, (10, 0): 1, (9, 1): 9, (5, 5): 42,

(7, 3): 75, (6, 4): 90}

sage: sum(v^2 for v in (A1([1])^10).monomial_coefficients().values())

16796

Alternatively,   is itself a character. We can compute this character, then apply the method monomial_coefficients . This gives a dictionary with entries that are these coefficients. We can extract the value of 0, which we implement as A1.space().zero() .

sage: z = A1.space().zero(); z

(0, 0)

sage: ((A1([1])^10*A1([0,-1])^10)).monomial_coefficients()[z]

16796

Let us check that the moments of the trace are Catalan numbers:

sage: [sum(v^2 for v in

(A1([1])^k).monomial_coefficients().values()) for k in [0..10]]

[1, 1, 2, 5, 14, 42, 132, 429, 1430, 4862, 16796]

sage: [catalan_number(k) for k in [0..10]]

[1, 1, 2, 5, 14, 42, 132, 429, 1430, 4862, 16796]

You may also use the method weight_multiplicities of a Weyl character to get a dictionary of weight multiplicities indexed by weight.

sage: A2=WeylCharacterRing("A2")

sage: d=A2(6,2,0).weight_multiplicities(); d

{(0, 6, 2): 1, (5, 0, 3): 1, (3, 5, 0): 1, ...

(Output suppressed.) Here is how to extract a single multiplicity. The space method of the WeylCharacterRing returns the ambient vector space of the weight lattice, and we may use this to generate a key.

sage: L=A2.space(); L

Ambient space of the Root system of type ['A', 2]

sage: k=L((3,3,2)); k

(3, 3, 2)

sage: type(k)

<class 'sage.combinat.root_system.ambient_space.

AmbientSpace_with_category.element_class'>

sage: d[k]

3

In addition to the Lie group code in Sage , the symmetric function code in Sage will be useful to readers of this book. You may convert between different bases of the ring of symmetric functions (such as the Schur basis s and the power sum basis p ) and calculate important symmetric functions such as the Hall–Littlewood symmetric functions. Moreover, Sage knows about the Hopf algebra structure on the ring of symmetric functions. For example:

sage: Sym = SymmetricFunctions(QQ)

sage: s = Sym.schur()

sage: s[2]^2

s[2, 2] + s[3, 1] + s[4]

sage: (s[2]^2).coproduct()

s[] # s[2,2] + s[] # s[3,1] + s[] # s[4] + 2*s[1] # s[2,1]

\+ 2*s[1] # s[3] + s[1, 1] # s[1, 1] + s[1, 1] # s[2]

\+ s[2] # s[1, 1] + 3*s[2] # s[2] + 2*s[2, 1] # s[1]

\+ s[2, 2] # s[] + 2*s[3] # s[1] + s[3, 1] # s[]

\+ s[4] # s[]

sage: def f(a,b): return a*b.antipode()

sage: (s[2]^2).coproduct().apply_multilinear_morphism(f)

0

We've computed (in the notation introduced in the exercises to Chapter 35 )   applied to   . This computation may of course also be done using the defining property of the antipode.

You can get a command line tutorial for the symmetric function code with:

sage: SymmetricFunctions?
